DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN OIL FIRMS MAY BE ALLOWED ENTRY INTO TAIWAN MARKET THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Foreign oil firms are eyeing the much anticipated opening of Taiwan's petroleum market, which is expected to happen as early as this September as long as related legislation proceeds smoothly.

Exxon-Mobil, one of the largest oil conglomerates in the world, has mapped out plans to establish 10 service stations in northern and central Taiwan initially, in the belief that the market will be opened before long.

Exxon's plan to edge into the local market, which will undoubtedly be followed by similar moves by other international oil firms, poses a threat to the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) and the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), the only private oil processor and operator in Taiwan now.

According to Chen Chao-yi, secretary-general of the Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the legislation of the petroleum management law is expected to be passed during the current Legislative Yuan session, which ends in May.

After 21 rounds of debates and discussions between the administration and the legislature and among the ruling and opposition parties since 1999, Taiwan's legislators seem poised to close the matter during this legislative session. This will make the passage of the petroleum management law possible this summer, paving the way for the entrance of foreign oil conglomerates into the Taiwan market three months after the legislation is passed.
If everything goes smoothly, the foreign oil firms are expected to be allowed to enter the market on Sept. 1 at the earliest, which would symbolize the formal liberalization of Taiwan's oil market.
Meanwhile, the expected passage of the petroleum management law will also mandate the formal establishment of the Cabinet-level Bureau of Energy and the privatization of CPC itself, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LEGISLATORS VISIT BEIJING

TEXT.P: A group of opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators, including former Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan, left Taipei Sunday for a six-day visit to Beijing.

The six-member delegation is scheduled to call on Chen Yunlin, director of the mainland Chinese State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, and officials of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

PFP legislator Chen Chen-sheng said that the visit is aimed at reducing cross-strait hostility so that the two sides can reduce the threat of military confrontation, curtail an arms race and avoid an unnecessary waste of resources.
He added that the lawmakers also hope to urge the mainland government to provide an essential degree of protection for Taiwan businessmen working in the mainland.

A total of 16 PFP legislators were originally slated to be a part of the delegation. However, most stayed behind after their colleague PFP legislator Diane Lee was hospitalized Wednesday after a scuffle with independent legislator Lo Fu-chu, who punched her in the face.
Liu said that a number of PFP legislators had to remain in Taiwan to ensure that the incident would not be dismissed offhandedly.
The lawmakers are also scheduled to visit Tianjin and Xian.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOLDS PRIMARY FOR NOMINATION REFERENCE FOR YEAREND'S ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) held an inner-party primary election Sunday for a reference to determine the nominations of party candidates for the yearend legislative, local mayoral and magistrate elections.

The yearend legislative and local elections, the first since the DPP took over the presidency in May 2000, are crucial to the DPP's political strength in the legislature and the layout of the party's power in cities and counties under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
Presently, the opposition Kuomintang still holds a majority in the legislature.

One hundred and forty-five DPP members have registered to compete in the primary for the yearend constituency legislative election, 31 plan to strive for nomination to run in the election for at-large legislators, and six have registered to run for overseas Chinese legislative seats, sources at DPP headquarters said.
The nominations of DPP candidates to run for at-large and overseas Chinese legislative seats will depend on the number of votes cast by party members.

As for the local mayoral and magistrate elections, almost all the nominees for the elections have been determined after coordination by the DPP headquarters, the sources said, adding that only Kaohsiung County and Taoyuan County must proceed with the second stage of voting by party members.

According to the DPP's regulations, party member voting, part of the primary election process, accounts for 30 percent of the primary, while a public opinion poll conducted earlier in the year accounts for 70 percent.
The results of the poll on DPP nominees for constituency legislative seats will be unveiled after the voting ends Sunday afternoon.
Voting time is from 9 a.m. through 4 p.m. The DPP headquarters estimated that the voting rate will exceed 70 percent.
President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reportedly will not vote in the primary elections in order to maintain executive neutrality.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN, SECRETARY-GENERAL ASSURE SMOOTH-RUNNING PRIMARIES

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Sunday that the party has looked into reported cases of the use of forged or duplicate party membership cards in the party's primaries conducted the same day, and that there are "no problems."

Hsieh said while casting his vote in the party primaries for the year-end legislative, mayoral and county chief elections that people are naturally nervous when such a large-scale primary is held for the first time.
The DPP boasts approximately 31,000 members in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city, and about 190,000 members islandwide. Hsieh serves concurrently as Kaohsiung mayor.

Meanwhile, in Taipei, where approximately 20,000 DPP members are eligible to vote in the primaries, DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said that a special task force will continue to investigate reported cases of vote buying even after the results of the primaries are announced later in the evening.
Wu speculated that most cases of duplicate party membership cards are due to members who have reapplied for membership or for replacements after losing their original cards.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA'S LARGEST BICYCLE SHOW KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Representatives from the world's leading bicycle producing countries vowed Sunday in Taipei to bolster global environmental protection while seeking business prosperity for themselves.

More than 200 bicycle industry leaders from Canada, Italy, Japan, the United States and Taiwan got together at the Taipei International Convention Center Sunday for the Global Bicycle Summit to discuss issues concerning bicycle development trends, marketing strategies, the various regulations of different countries, and the growing global popularity of electric bikes.

In a joint statement, the bicycle leaders vowed to promote the use and production of environmentally-friendly electric bikes and to protect the globe from industrial pollution, especially that of transportation vehicles.

Expressing support for Taiwan bicycle industry's determination to promote electric bikes, Lin Tah-hsiung, the Republic of China's deputy environmental protection administrator, announced during the summit that for Taiwanese users of electric bikes, the Environmental Protection Administration will subsidize NT$3,000 (US$92) for each unit purchase so as to prop up islandwide sales of the relatively new product.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou concretely supported the use of electric bikes by riding one personally at the event.

Describing himself a permanent bike lover who rode bicycles to school from his high school years in Taiwan to his graduate school years in the United States, Ma said that Taipei City Hall is studying a bicycle policy that would allow Taipei residents to ride around town on exclusive bike paths, a challenging project in the crowded and complicated city.

Meanwhile, the 2001 Taipei International Bicycle Exhibition kicked off at the Taipei World Trade Center Saturday with a total of 629 bicycle manufacturers and exporters from home and abroad participating.

The number of exhibitors surged to 629 this year, including 120 foreign firms, while that of display booths reached 1,739. The 2001 Taipei International Bicycle Exhibition is now the largest in Asia and the second biggest worldwide, according to a spokesman for the China External Trade Development Council, which sponsors the show.

Taiwan exhibitors in the show kicked off a "Three-New Policy" movement to make Taiwan, already a leading bicycle producing country in the world, a center for the global bike industry. The "Three New Policy" -- new materials, new functions and new usage -- is aimed at further upgrading the quality of Taiwan-made bicycles and making the products more competitive in world markets, they said.
During the exhibition, a locally-developed hydrogen-fueled "clear bike," the first kind of it worldwide, made its debut.

The hydrogen-powered bike's maker said that it consumes only 30 grams of hydrogen every 60 kilometers. Its battery weighs less than 10 kilograms, about one-third of that of lead-acid batteries and about half of that of nickel-hydrogen batteries, according to the maker.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE'S MAINLAND CHINA DREAM (I)

TEXT.P: If you love someone, send him or her to mainland China, a "school" that fosters fast growth and maturity. Likewise, if you hate somebody, let him or her go to the mainland, a "hell" that can "break" a person in the blink of an eye.

"Dreaming of success" is the common feature of Taiwanese who go to mainland China to invest, work or study. Over there, working hard is no guarantee of success, but it's an undisputed fact that anyone who wants to succeed must work hard.

Twenty years after mainland China launched its "open-door" economic reforms, the number of Taiwan citizens who travel to the mainland for family reunions, investment or study continues to set new records.
Official tallies compiled by both sides of the Taiwan Strait show that Taiwanese made at least 3 million visits to the mainland in 2000 alone.

Visiting the mainland is no longer a craze confined to elderly retired soldiers who moved to Taiwan from the mainland at the end of the Chinese civil war in the late 1940s. It has instead gradually become a phenomenon of everyday life in Taiwan.

And in the face of the enthusiastic mainland-bound migration mania, many relevant issues are worthy of study -- what those people dream of doing on the mainland, how many of them succeed, how many of them see their dreams shattered, and how their lives are there.

Taiwan people who jump on the mainland bandwagon do so for various reasons. While some people aspire to find a new lease on life for their traditional businesses or to launch new ventures, many youths want to study there, and others are simply seeking reunion with their family members there.

But generally speaking, Taiwan migrants to the mainland can be divided into four groups -- owners of Taiwan-financed companies, management staff of those companies, students and family members of the aforesaid three kinds of people.

Among the "owners" group is a 29-year-old man who asked to be identified only by his family name, Soong. The scion of a family that has run a traditional manufacturing business in central Taiwan for years, Soong moved to Shanghai three years ago to manage a production facility there. His eyes lack the shafts of passion so common in people of his age. What he shows is precocious sophistication.

Soong said investing in mainland China is something that was "forced" upon him. "Under the wave of the economic globalization, Taiwan's traditional businesses have no alternative but to relocate to mainland China, which boasts cheaper labor and land," he explained.

As the eldest son of a business family, Soong said he is not free to choose what he does with his life and career. "Life is lonely in Shanghai. Work is the only thing in my everyday life," he complained.

Much to Soong's disappointment and frustration, his Shanghai factory is still operating in the red. "I sometimes think of withdrawing my investment from the mainland and returning to Taiwan. But the idea usually recedes quickly. I'm unwilling to give up now after devoting so much energy, time and capital to my business here."

Soong said even though he understands that very few Taiwan enterprises have managed to establish themselves in the vast mainland market over the past two decades, he still wants to continue to strive for a breakthrough there. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE'S MAINLAND CHINA DREAM (II)

TEXT.P: "Migrating to the mainland for work is a road of no return," says Mr. Chen, who manages an electronics factory in Dongguan, Guangdong province, invested by a publicly listed Taiwan company.
Chen recalled that his company sent him to the mainland five years ago to set up a production facility in Dongguan to save operational costs.
"I accepted the assignment with a view to increasing my professional experience. But I didn't think at that time that I would stay long on the mainland," he said.

Nowadays, Chen said, "return to Taiwan" is no longer his favorite choice. "For one thing, our Taiwan headquarters has no suitable position for me. On the other hand, I'm afraid that I can no longer adapt myself to the life of a salaryman in Taiwan," he added.
Asked if he were allowed to make a choice again, would he still opt for working on the mainland? Chen, who was divorced last year, paused a while and then said: "There is no 'if' in real life."

In contrast to Taiwan businesspeople's complicated feelings about their movement to the mainland, their family members and young Taiwan migrant students seem to have more romantic dreams of their lives of future on the mainland.

A Taiwan student at a Shanghai medical college, identified himself as "Little Lee," said he chose to travel to Shanghai for study mainly because he could realize his dream to study medicine without the need to take part in highly competitive entrance examinations in Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Lee said, four years of life in Shanghai have changed many of his concepts and ideals. In fact, he no longer spends much time in school and instead devotes much of his energy to running an advertising agency.

Lee said he has no plan to return to Taiwan at least in the foreseeable future. "Since Taiwan does not recognize the mainland academic accreditation, I plans to stay in Shanghai to operate my advertising business," he said, adding he is convinced that he stands a good chance of success with the extensive human connections he has developed during his four-year schooling in Shanghai.

And for Mrs. Tu, her migration to the mainland is mainly for "living together with her husband." Mrs. Tu, who already made three visits to her husband's workplace in Dongguan, said the living environment in the Dongguan area is not good. "There is almost no fun, no amusement facilities there," she said. "Nevertheless, nothing is more important than family reunion. I have decided to move there to live together with my husband and I believe that tomorrow will be better."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY TO ADD CRIMINAL STATUTES TO ANTI-CD PIRACY LAW

TEXT.P: Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said Sunday that his ministry will gather related government agency officials to discuss the incorporation of criminal statutes into an anti-CD piracy draft law in the next few days.

Demonstrating Taiwan's determination to protect intellectual property rights, Chen said that the Economics Ministry will specify criminal responsibility for copyright infringements in an optical media management statute currently being drafted in accordance with similar measures in the Copyright Law.

Chen's remarks came a day after the release of a 471-page report on foreign trade barriers compiled by the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) Office. The 10 pages dedicated to Taiwan detail U.S. concerns for trade barriers in such major areas as intellectual property rights and the island's telecommunications market.

Following the publication of the report, the USTR Office is scheduled to publish its annual list of countries that require close monitoring and could be subject to trade sanctions under the Special 301 provisions of the 1989 U.S. Omnibus Trade Act if the countries fail to address U.S. concerns.

Chen said the United States has demanded that Taiwan impose stricter laws to discourage CD piracy, which he said has become so rampant that pirated music CDs are sometimes available before the official products have actually hit the local market.

Officials in Taipei have speculated that the USTR Office is likely to include Taiwan on the "priority watch list" of its "Special 301" report this year to turn up the pressure on Taiwan to deal with intellectual piracy.

However, the officials have expressed optimism that timely completion of legislative preparations for the optical media management statute would keep Taiwan off the "Special 301" priority watch list, which will be published at the end of April.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MOVES TO CRACK DOWN ON MIDDLE EASTERN CON-ARTISTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government Sunday formally launched an inter-division operation to bar Middle Eastern criminals from entering Taiwan and crack down on them if they are already here.

The operation, dubbed the "Sutong Project," is a collaborative action conducted by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to cut down on the number of crimes committed by con artists from the Middle East, said officials from the MOI's National Police Administration (NPA).
The operation was designed in the wake of a spate of thefts and burglaries committed by people from the Middle East and reported by Taiwan's department stores and jewelry shops in recent months.
According to the NPA officials, the Middle Eastern con artists usually enter Taiwan on tourist visas for short stays of three to seven days using forged passports.
After they commit the crimes, they immediately fence the stolen goods before exiting Taiwan with the cash, NPA officials noted.

MOFA authorities, meanwhile, note that according to their investigations, most of the Middle Eastern crooks use Thailand as their operations base, and obtain their visas from Taiwan's representative or liaison offices in Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia and the Philippines.

MOFA officials said that from now on, all Middle Eastern applicants for Taiwan entry visas will have to provide an additional bust photo for each visa application to make it easier for immigration authorities to identify them when they enter or exit Taiwan.
Taiwan's immigration authorities will be able to identify the visitors more easily if they use identical photos with different names and different passports, MOFA officials said.
Under the operation, the NPA authorities will be responsible for building an archive of Middle Eastern people who have committed crimes on the island over the past five years.

The NPA authorities will also notify the island's car leasing companies, hotels and motels that all patronage or temporary stays by visitors from the Middle East must be immediately reported to police authorities. The requirement is designed to allow airport and customs police enough time and sufficient evidence to nab the unlawful, according to the NPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR CRITICIZES DPP PRIMARIES

TEXT.P: The head of the Kuomintang caucus in the Legislative Yuan Sunday voiced strong criticism of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) primaries held across the island the same day.

Legislator Cheng Yung-chin, KMT Legislative caucus head, said that rumors of bribery, falsified identities of party members, and ghost party memberships have been spreading since the primaries were announced.
Cheng called on eligible voters to open their eyes before casting their votes in the elections for legislators, magistrates and mayors scheduled for Dec. 1, 2001.
Cheng said that DPP has always declared its opposition to election bribery, but bribe rumors have been spreading since the primaries were announced last December.

In addition, the DPP-led government has not done well in the past year since it assumed power on May 20, 2000, Cheng said. Taiwan's economy is in a drastic decline, the unemployment rate is soaring and social security is worsening, the KMT legislator said.
Noting that the KMT will hold party primaries in May, Cheng claimed that the party is opposed to "black gold", bribery, and violence and will punish all those who violate primary regulations.

Cheng also predicted that none of three largest political parties will win half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan in the yearend election. But he predicted that the KMT would win 90 to 100 Legislative seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CD-R MAKERS SAY FEES CHARGED BY PHILIPS TOO HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's CD-R manufacturers took concerted action Sunday to protest against what they say are the overly high fees charged by Philips Electronics Inc. for the use of its patented technology in their production of CD-Rs.
The manufacturers said the exorbitant fees have sharply increased their production costs and weakened their products' market competitiveness.
Ritek Corp., one of Taiwan's major CD-R manufacturers, said that when the selling price of CD-R was US$3-4 a piece, Philips charged each Taiwan CD-R manufacturer 300 Japanese yen (US$2.72) per piece.
Ritek officials said that although Philips has significantly reduced the fee along with the decline in CD-R prices, the charges are still too high.

They noted that CD-R prices have dropped to between US$0.20 to US$0.25 per piece at present from US$0.70 per unit in 1999. With Philips charging 10 Japanese yen (US$0.083) per piece, the fee accounts for 32 percent to 41 percent of a CD-R manufacturer's production costs, seriously affecting the product's competitiveness, they added.
Taiwan's CD-R manufacturers reportedly plan to file a complaint with Philips' legal adviser in a bid to obtain a satisfactory solution to the matter.
They also plan to file a petition Monday with the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CONTINUE PROMOTING CROSS-STRAIT TIES FOR ASIA PEACE: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed the Republic of China's commitment Sunday to forging rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait for the sake of maintaining peace, stability and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region.
President Chen made the remarks at a "world citizens forum" organized by the World Citizens Assembly (WCA). The forum was held at the Taipei International Convention Center.

Noting that cross-strait relations are vital to the Asia-Pacific situation, Chen said the ROC has consistently promoted goodwill exchanges with mainland China in a realistic manner in hopes of contributing to regional peace and security.

"And we look forward to seeing mainland China face up to the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now ruled by separate governments," Chen said, adding that he hopes the two sides can resume regular dialogue on an equal, reciprocal basis to jointly create a "win-win" scenario.
Chen went on to say he believes that pursuing the common values of human rights and democracy can help reduce conflicts and bring peace to the world.

He further said the ROC, as a constructive member of the Global Village, is more than willing to play an active role in international organizations and world affairs to contribute to progress in world civilization.
The president also said he is very delighted to see the World Citizens Assembly convene its first plenary meeting in the 21st century in Taiwan.

"It marks the WCA's determination to continue working for international peace and prosperity and for curbing global conflict," Chen said, adding that for its part, the ROC will do its utmost to help boost world harmony and progress.

President Chen also recognized the WCA's long-term efforts to boost world peace and the common well-being of mankind. He said the ROC government and people warmly welcome all delegates to the WCA meeting, many of whom have traveled halfway round the world to come to Taiwan.
Over the past five decades, Chen went on, the ROC has achieved economic prosperity through concerted efforts of its government and people.

"And our people even used love and ballots to complete our country's first-ever democratic transition of power between different political parties in last year's presidential election. This is a milestone in the global Chinese community and has set a new model for democratic development in Asia," the president added.

The World Citizens Assembly is a non-governmental organization affiliated with the United Nations. It is dedicated to promoting world peace. This is the first time that the organization has held a plenary meeting in Taiwan in its 26-year history. The San Francisco-based organization now has more than 5,000 members from 50 nations around the world.
At Sunday's session, the WCA announced April 1 as the "Taiwan World Citizens Day."

In his opening remarks, WCA Chairman Douglas Mattern, a U.S. citizen, said terminating warfare and avoiding meaningless sacrifice of human lives are the top priority of the WCA missions for the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA CHALLENGES BEIJING TO WATCH HIS ACTIVITIES IN TAIWAN: CBC

TEXT.P: Canada's national broadcasting network noted Saturday that Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, challenged Beijing's leaders to watch his activities in Taiwan, as he has nothing to hide.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. said the Buddhist monk arrived in Taiwan on Saturday. "Speaking to a packed news conference, he said he has nothing to hide from Beijing, which has accused him of colluding with the island's separatists," the CBC said.
The Dalai Lama has repeatedly said he is not seeking Tibetan independence from China, which has ruled his Himalayan homeland with an iron fist since 1950, the CBC noted.
In a Taipei-datelined report, the CBC quoted the Tibetan leader as saying China's rigid authoritarian system is not the answer to the huge country's many problems.

The spiritual leader's 10-day visit to Taiwan has inflamed political and religious passions on the island of 23 million. He was greeted by both supporters and protesters on arrival at Taiwan's airport, the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR URGES SALES OF REQUESTED WEAPONS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A U.S. senator has urged the Bush administration to sell all the weapons systems that Taiwan has requested, stressing that increasing the preparedness of Taiwan's defense forces "will decrease the chances that the United States will need to become involved in a conflict in the Taiwan Straits, or that such a conflict will occur in the first place."

Addressing the Senate floor Friday, Senator Jon Kyl (R-Ariz.) said that "not only do we need to sell Taiwan the necessary military equipment for defense against China, our defense officials and military personnel need to be able to work with their Taiwanese counterparts to ensure that they know how to use the equipment."

"Our long-term goal is to live in peace and prosperity with the Chinese people, as well as to promote democratic transition in that country. China's far-reaching ambitions in Asia, coupled with efforts to modernize and strengthen its military force, however, require the United States to exercise leadership," Kyl said.

He noted that there is no doubt that Communist China will and should play a larger role on the world stage in the coming years, but "the challenge before us is to deal with this emerging power in a way that enhances our security by dealing candidly and strongly with some of the troubling facts and trends. It is time to take a more clear-eyed approach to dealing with China."

The Clinton administration believed that Communist China could be reformed solely by the influence of the West. Unfortunately, Kyl said, this theory has not proved true, adding that Beijing's embrace of Western-style capitalism has not been accompanied by respect for human rights, the rule of law, true democratization, or a less belligerent attitude toward its neighbors.

"Indeed, serious problems with China have grown worse. And continuing to gloss over these problems for fear of disrupting the fragile U.S.-China relationship, primarily for trade reasons, only exacerbates the problems," emphasized the senator.

Kyl then quoted Secretary of State Colin Powell as saying in his confirmation hearing that "I believe it is in our best interest to seriously evaluate China's military strategy, plans for modernization of its People's Liberation Army, including the expansion of its ICBM capability, and buildup of forces opposite Taiwan. Let us not risk underestimating China's intentions or capabilities, possibly finding ourselves in the midst of a conflict we could have prevented." (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. NAVY RECOMMENDS SELLING AEGIS DESTROYERS TO TAIWAN: N.Y. TIMES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 1 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: "Taiwan needs a significant infusion of new weapons, including a sophisticated ship-borne radar system for Aegis-class Destroyers", the New York Times quoted a U.S. naval confidential review as reporting Sunday.
The review was an assessment report made by U.S. Pacific Fleet officers who had visited Taiwan to assess its naval requirements in light of Beijing's military buildup, the paper said.

The review pointed out that in addition to procuring the Aegis class destroyer's sophisticated radar system by 2010, Taiwan also needs Kidd-class destroyers as a "stopgap." The review also concluded that Taiwan needs new submarines as well as an underwater sonar array to detect Chinese submarines.
Taiwan has also been in discussions on the new Patriot anti-missile system known as PAC-3, and similar studies have been carried out concerning other parts of Taiwan's military, the Times reported.

The U.S. Naval Officers believe that the year 2010 will be important because it will take at least eight years or "more to agree on a configuration of the Aegis radar system for Taiwan's navy, build the ship and integrate it into Taiwan's naval fleet," the report added.

"Experts familiar with the officers' review say it concludes that by 2010 Taiwan will need vessels equipped with long-range surface-to-air missiles, a sophisticated battle management system and a phased-array radar, which is the hallmark of the Aegis system," the Times reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HARBORS NO GRIEVANCES, WILL NEVER TAKE TO STREETS: SOONG

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Sunday his party insists on adopting a rational political style and will never take to streets simply for partisan purposes.

Soong made the remarks in response to a suggestion by some people that the PFP took to streets in protest of a recent physical assault on PFP Legislator Diane Lee by independent lawmaker Lo Fu-chu during a legislative committee meeting.
Soong rejected the proposal, saying that the PFP does not want to copy the strategy adopted by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) before it came to power last year.

Noting that the PFP harbors no grievances, Soong said the party will adhere to its rational, no-nonsense political style. "We'll never take to streets for short-term partisan gains. We'll honor our commitment to working for the common well-being of all local people."
Soong reminded local politicians that Taiwan's party politics has undergone significant changes following last year's presidential election.
"Local voters have become ever more independent-minded. They will no longer blindly toe party lines," Soong noted, adding that many local politicians have not yet discerned this great change.

He went on to say the results of last year's [residential election indicated that 60 percent of local voters support the PFP and the Kuomintang's policy on promoting rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait.

"The electoral outcome also showed that 70 percent of local voters want sweeping domestic reforms," Soong said. "Against this backdrop, the PFP will continue upholding its reformist platform and rational political style."

Soong also reminded the current DPP government that local people's patience has its limit. "Our voters can no longer wait. The DPP government should speed up political reform, judicial reform and parliamentary reform to wipe out corruption and ensure clean politics," he urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PRIMARIES FOR CANDIDATES FOR YEAREND ELECTIONS TO BE HELD IN MAY

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang will hold primaries on May 5 for candidates for the elections for legislators, county magistrates and mayors in December.

But KMT officials say that there would be no need to hold primaries in more than half of the counties and cities involved in the December elections because only a single candidate has registered to run in these counties and cities.
These counties and cities include the cities of Keelung and Tainan, as well as Ilan, Pingtung, Taitung, Kinmen, Lienchiang and Penghu Counties.
The candidates for Taoyuan County and Taichung City are still being coordinated, while the candidate for Taipei County has not been fixed yet.
The DPP held primaries for its candidates in the December elections Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PURSUING SPIRITUAL ENLIGHTENMENT TO ENSURE WORLD PEACE: DALAI LAMA

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama said here Sunday that all people around the world should pay more heed to human values after enjoying material affluence.

"Only continued pursuit of spiritual enlightenment can achieve real world peace," the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader said in a speech on "Ethics in the New Millennium" delivered at the Linkou Stadium in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan.
Addressing a packed audience, the Dalai Lama said love and compassion would be the remedy to cure the illness carried over from the old millennium.

Speaking in Tibetan and English, the Dalai Lama said history has shown that the ceaseless efforts to push for progress in materials over the past century has brought human beings to nowhere. "Instead there were pains after pains troubling human beings."

The winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize went on to say that while the fast pace of development in science, technology and economics had made the world a smaller place and brought human relations closer, many people are still on the fringes of society.

"So we must not continue to tread the traditional path if we are to solve the lingering problems ... We have to adopt a more open-minded attitude," he said, adding: "Love is critical ... and remember, when anyone gives love to another, happiness emerges from their mind, and they then are the biggest beneficiaries."

Citing his experiences of meeting a number of the world's richest men who despite their material wealth said they felt lacking in spirituality, the Nobel laureate said he had asked them to be more caring towards others. "In this way one would have his mind be occupied by happiness," he said.

Speaking on the same occasion, Vice President Annette Lu said it's an honor for the people of Taiwan to have the highly respected spiritual leader Dalai Lama to visit the Republic of China again. The Dalai Lama visited Taiwan for the first time in 1997.
Thanks to his presence, Lu said, "different peoples and 10-odd religions were brought together here."
A joint prayer, attended by leaders of varied religions including Christian, Catholics and Taoism, immediately followed the Dalai Lama's speech to pray for the well-being of the ROC and its people.
Before his speech, the Dalai Lama held a brief "purification ceremony" to drive away any evil spirits away from the stadium and to let in Buddha.
Hundreds of policemen were deployed in and around the stadium, and the crowd was required to pass through a metal-detector at the entrance.
Under police protection normally granted to a national leader, the Dalai Lama was driven from his hotel to the stadium some 40 kilometers (24 miles) south of Taipei in a black limousine.
Earlier in the day he met with 100-plus Tibetans, including some illegal immigrants who asked for his assistance to secure them legal residence status in Taiwan.

The Dalai Lama, who has lived in exile in India since the failure of an anti-China uprising in Tibet in 1959, arrived in Taipei Saturday for a 10-day "religious visit." He is scheduled to meet with President Chen Shui-bian on April 5 for wide-ranging talks.
On Sunday evening, the Dalai Lama paid a visit to the Taipei City Hall where Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presented him a "Key to Taipei" as a gift.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PRESENTS 'KEY TO TAIPEI' TO DALAI LAMA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presented a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama Sunday, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
The Dalai Lama, who arrived in Taipei Saturday for a 10-day religious trip, met with Ma at the Taipei City Hall after delivering a speech at the Linkou Stadium.
He told Ma that despite their different traditions in Chinese, Japanese and Buddhist teachings, "they can learn and understand one another."
The winner of the 1989 Nobel Prize for Peace also encouraged the people of Taiwan "to overcome all difficulties with confidence, wisdom, perseverance and patience."

The Dalai Lama described as "encouraging" the fact that lots of people in Taiwan have interest in Buddhism, and pointed out that his current visit will be complementary to the exchange of Chinese and Tibetan Buddhism.
He lauded the island's achievements in political democracy, education and economic development, especially the pace of democratization.

Several ranking Taipei City officials were also present at the meeting. They included Taipei City Council Vice Speaker Fei Hung-tai, Civil Affairs Bureau Director Lin Cheng-hsiu and Cultural Affairs Bureau Director Lung Ying-tai.
Earlier, the Dalai Lama met with some 100-plus Tibetans staying in Taiwan at the Linkou Stadium and delivered a speech titled "Ethics in the New Millennium.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 2, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro-French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL TAIWAN BUSINESS LEAGUE DONATES CASH FOR INDIAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Business League of Central Taiwan donated NT$1.11 million (US$33,846) to India on Monday to help victims of a devastating earthquake that jolted that country earlier this year.
Representatives of the business league presented the cash donation to Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu as a token to echo Lu's recent calls for the display of "compassion toward India."

Accepting the cash aid on behalf of the Indian earthquake victims, Lu said this donation is particularly touching and significant as the people of central Taiwan themselves were the victims of a killer quake in 1999. That temblor claimed more then 2,000 lives and caused a countless amount of property damage, and central Taiwan has still not fully recovered from the devastation, Lu noted.

In March, Taiwan's EVA Airways carried US$270,000 worth of relief goods to India for the same purpose. The donation of relief goods, by Taiwan-based air carriers and shippers, was also made in response to Lu's appeal to the people of Taiwan to help quake victims in India.
India suffered its deadliest earthquake in 50 years on Jan. 26 when a quake measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale rattled the western state of Gujarat, killing some 25,000 people.
India maintains no diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'GO SLOW' POLICY REVIEW ALREADY REFERRED TO CABINET: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has sent a comprehensive review of the "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment to the Cabinet for approval and implementation, a senior official said Monday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan interior affairs committee meeting, MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the MAC has suggested in the report that mainland China-bound investment projects worth more than US$50 million each be screened and approved on a case-by-case basis.

The government's top mainland policy planner explained that the main consideration of the "no haste" or "go slow" policy review focuses on more reasonably reflecting the demand of the Taiwan economy and industries.
"And it's up to the Executive Yuan (Cabinet) to decide when the adjusted mainland investment policy will be put into force," Tsai told lawmakers.

The "go slow" policy was formulated by the former Kuomintang government with a view to cooling off enthusiastic mainland investment fever among local business people. Under the policy, high-technology enterprises are banned from investing in mainland China and capital investment of any single project should not exceed US$50 million.

With Taiwan, mainland and global economic trends changing rapidly, the local business community has been pushing the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government to adjust the "go slow" policy and ease mainland investment restrictions.
Noting that the "go slow" policy is critical to Taiwan's industrial development, Tsai said the government must exercise prudence and wisdom in implementing the policy.
Tsai said the MAC and other relevant government agencies have reviewed the "go slow" policy in line with the two principles directed by President Chen Shui-bian -- openness and effective management.

"In formulating new regulatory measures, we have placed priority on ensuring transparency and reasonableness to facilitate realization of our policy goals of better 'risk management' and 'keeping business roots' in Taiwan," Tsai explained.

According to Tsai, the "go slow" policy review also includes easing restrictions on the items that local enterprises will be allowed to invest on the mainland as well as the establishment of a capital risk management mechanism and a capital inflow system for the return of Taiwan firms' earnings from mainland operations.

Meanwhile, Tsai told the legislators that the government is scheduled to complete an overall review and planning by the end of June for the proposal to allow mainland people to make sightseeing tours of Taiwan.

Tsai said the new "open-door" policy will be implemented in a gradual manner based on several basic principles -- imposing a quota system, "group in and group out," and adopting necessary complementary measures to ensure national security and stability.
"Opening the door to mainland tourists must comply with our overall mainland policy and formulate relevant complementary measures to safeguard our national security," Tsai noted.
In the initial stage, Tsai said, the new opening measure is expected to bring Taiwan an economic bonanza worth some NT$20 billion (US$613.5 million).
Tsai further stressed that the opening of Taiwan's tourist market to mainland visitors is mainly aimed at promoting mutual understanding between the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"In consideration of national security, we'll carry out the new open-door policy in an orderly and gradual manner," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 190.19 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 190.19 points to close at 5,607.73.
Market turnover amounted to NT$75.99 billion (US$2.32 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: 10-DAY SHOW FEATURING MAN LIVING WITH POISONOUS SNAKES DISCONTINUED

TEXT.P: An event featuring "a man living with poisonous snakes for 240 hours" was discontinued after Justice Minister Chen Ting-nan reported the "death game" to police in accordance with what he termed his "obligations as a citizen."
Chen was referring to the recent spine-chilling show sponsored by several underground shops in celebration of the first anniversary of their opening.

Lin Ching-feng, the 28-year old man from Pingtung who took the challenge to live for 10 days with poisonous snakes in a small glass-walled room for a prize of NT$1 million (US$30,300), if he survived, had signed a declaration stating that he was voluntarily taking part in the event.

The event had attracted many spectators to the small transparent show room each day since it began last Friday. Several of Lin's family members went to the site of the event Sunday to tearfully try to persuade him to discontinue the stunt.

After seeing media reports about the event, the justice minister also went to the scene Sunday to express his concern. He later informed police, who then arrived to remove Lin from the "snake den" for questioning.

Chen told the media Monday that he was only fulfilling his duty as a citizen, suggesting to police that such an exhibition was in violation of regulations safeguarding social order. The specific regulation he was referring to states that anyone who performs an action in public that violates public decency laws will be subject to detention for up to three days or to a maximum fine of NT$12,000 (US$364).
The justice minister also noted that Lin is not bound to the contract he signed, saying that under the law, "any actions or documents that run counter to public order or decency will be invalid."

Chen said the sponsor told him that some of the snakes that were in the same room with Lin are so lethal that if Lin were bitten, it is likely that no serum would have been able to save him and he would have most probably died.
Chen lamented that such "death games" have been used commercially in Taiwan, saying that these kind of events obviously run counter to the maintenance of social order.
Chen stressed that he only suggested to police that such hazardous games be discontinued and that he did not give them specific instructions.
Police have now turned the case over to the Taipei Prosecutor's Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 190.19 points to close at 5,607.73.
The bourse opened at 5,797.85 and continued to go down due to a drop in electronics share prices. The index fluctuated between 5,797.85 and 5,596.18 during trading.

A total of 2.19 billion stocks worth NT$75.99 billion (US$2.32 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.91 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$98.59 billion (US$3.01 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 4.3 percent, followed by electrical shares and cement stocks, both at 3.6 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 3.1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 3 percent, textile issues at 2.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.9 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 484 to 63, with 39 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUN YAT-SEN'S GRANDDAUGHTER CALLS FOR KMT-PFP TIE-UP

TEXT.P: A granddaughter of Republic of China founder Dr. Sun Yat-sen on Monday called for collaboration between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), two of Taiwan's opposition parties.

Sun Shui-fang, who lives in the United States, said the KMT and the PFP should tie up as they share a common political philosophy based on the "Three Principles of the People" advocated by her grandfather.
Sun, who is currently in Taipei for meetings, made the remarks while calling on PFP Chairman James Soong at the party's headquarters.

Calling for esprit de corps among all political parties in Taiwan, Sun said that Dr. Sun Yat-sen is the founding father of all the people of the Chinese race and that his thoughts, showcased by the "Three Principles of the People," are thoughts for every Chinese person regardless of their political affiliations.
The "Three Principles of the People" is the intellectual property of all the Chinese people, she stressed.

In a keynote speech she delivered late last month at the First Chungshan Spirit Academic Seminar sponsored by the Sun Wen Society in Taipei, Sun said the thoughts of her grandfather should be used as the basis for peaceful reunification across the Taiwan Strait.

In response to Sun's call for cooperation between the KMT and the PFP, PFP Chairman James Soong noted that the PFP should strive to build its own sovereignty as a political party and that its success should not rely on cooperation with certain other parties or be at the mercy of certain other parties' failures.
Soong also said he expects that the KMT, the PFP and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party will fight a three-way battle in the year-end legislative, mayoral and county chief elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO THINK OVER "APPROPRIATE" TIME FOR TRIMMING STATE ENTERPRISES

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday that the current economic situation is not too good and that the ministry will think over what the "appropriate" moment is for trimming down state-owned enterprises.
Lin made the remarks while reporting to a legislative committee on the substantial measures taken by the ministry to deal with the sluggish domestic economy and rising unemployment.

Legislators from across the political spectrum asked questions about whether state-owned enterprises will layoff staff or cut salaries, with some legislators suggesting that layoffs would exacerbate the domestic unemployment problems.
Legislators Huang Mu-tien and Lee Chia-chin from the opposition Kuomintang said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs should shoulder a greater responsibility for the high unemployment rate.
Lin retorted that "even a god could not solve the problem" as it is the result of external factors, adding that his ministry can only provide relief.
Legislator Lee Chia-chin noted that seven out of 12 state-owned enterprises have been losing money, asking whether layoffs or salary cuts are imminent.
Lin responded by saying that the pace of privatization of state-owned enterprises has been dragging on for several years, noting that losses have widened as this process has dragged on.

Each state-owned enterprise will have to consider laying off staff, cutting salaries, merging with other companies or soliciting outside investors when they formulate their plans of action, or else they will have no chance of survival, said Lin. He added that the staff of China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) has agreed to a plan that includes some layoffs and salary cuts.

Asked if such moves will only make the domestic unemployment situation worse, Lin said that having state-owned enterprises continue to lose money is not a viable option. He did say that as the timing for slimming down such enterprises is not good, the ministry will work out when will be a more suitable time for implementing such measures, pointing out that such moves are necessary in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREZ CHEN CALLS FOR EFFORTS TO BUILD TAIWAN INTO A CARING SOCIETY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that taking care of the elderly is tantamount to taking care of the general populace, and letting the elderly lead healthy and comfortable lives with dignity will allow the greater population to lead lives of the same quality.

Chen called for a concerted islandwide effort to build Taiwan into a caring society in which the government is aided by the private sector's vast resources in its efforts to raise the island's standard of living and allow all people to look forward to a good future.

Addressing an audience at the Presidential Office in honor of a group of voluntary workers who devote their money, energy and time to bolstering the well-being of the elderly, Chen said senior citizen policy is now one of the most pressing and important tasks that the government is facing. Taiwan society is increasingly graying and the elderly already constitute 8 percent of the entire population.
It is essential that the government map out proper social welfare plans to improve care for the elderly and widen senior citizen's services to raise their standards of living, Chen noted.
Chen expressed respect and gratitude to the voluntary workers for their longtime unselfish and compassionate efforts to serve the elderly.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC KEEPS CLOSE WATCH ON U.S.-MAINLAND AIRCRAFT COLLISION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is closely watching the repercussions of a midair collision between a U.S. spy plane and a mainland Chinese fighter jet over the South China Sea on Sunday, government spokesman Su Cheng-ping said Monday.
Noting that the collision was an accident involving mainland Chinese and U.S. aircraft, Su said the incident and its repercussions have no direct correlation with the ROC.
He added that nevertheless the incident is likely to have a grave impact on regional development and stability if it is not handled properly.
"Therefore, the government is keeping a close watch on the development of the incident," Su said in response to a press inquiry about the government's views on the incident.
Su said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) presented a report on the incident to the Cabient shortly after it happened, but he declined to elaborate on the report's details.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the council has made a comprehensive review of the incident and its possible developments and impact on the Asia-Pacific and Taiwan Strait situations. The MAC charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.
To her knowledge, Tsai said, other government agencies are also evaluating the possible impact of the incident from different angles based on their own functions.

According to Tsai, the situation could worsen if the United States and mainland China fail to handle the issue in an appropriate manner. Tsai said she is hopeful that both sides will exercise self-restraint in dealing with the matter.
Tsai further said it is premature to forecast at this moment whether the incident will have any impact on the relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The Ministry of National Defense (MND) also refused to comment on whether the incident would affect the upcoming talks with the United States on the ROC's arms procurement plans.

MND officials said they are closely monitoring the development of the incident through various channels and will work out measures to cope with the possible impact on ROC-U.S. arms talks scheduled to take place in Washington, D.C. later this month.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, MND Deputy Minister Kao Yang said how the incident will affect U.S. arms sales to Taiwan depends on how quickly the incident can be resolved.

Foreign wire service reports said U.S. officials on Monday headed to the mainland Chinese island of Hainan, where a U.S. Navy surveillance plane and its 24-member crew made an emergency landing after a midair collision with a mainland fighter Sunday.
The United States said it expects mainland China to return the EP-3 surveillance aircraft and its crew -- and underscored that the plane is considered U.S. territory under international law.

"The entire aircraft is considered sovereign U.S. territory, and the Chinese are not to seize, inspect or board it without U.S. permission," said Lt. Commander Sean Kelly, a spokesman for the U.S. Pacific Command in Honolulu.
"As far as we know, they have not boarded the plane," he said. The EP-3 contains classified electronic eavesdropping equipment.
A mainland Chinese pilot has reportedly been missing since the accident.
