DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS MEET WITH ARATS OFFICIALS ON 'THREE LINKS' ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 2 (CNA) (By Fang Hsu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the Republic of China's opposition People First Party (PFP) met with mainland Chinese officials Monday to exchange views on the opening of direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait.

The seminar was chaired by Sun Yafu, vice president of Beijing's quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), which is authorized to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

In addition to ARATS staff, officials from mainland China's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, Ministry of Information Technology and Telecom Industries, and the Civil Aviation Administration of China also attended the forum to signify Beijing's intention to push for early opening of direct cross-strait trade, mail and transport links, commonly known as the "major three links."
The six-member PFP delegation is headed by veteran Legislator Liu Sung-fan, also a former president of the ROC's Legislative Yuan, or parliament.

Liu said the opening of the "major three links" is in the interests of the governments and people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. "Therefore, we hope that political and technical obstacles to the opening of the 'major three links' can be removed as early as possible," he added.
Liu further said a main purpose of the PFP delegation's current visit is to collect first-hand information about mainland China's opinions and policy regarding the "major three links."

"The findings or results of our present trip will be used as reference for the formulation of our party platform in preparation for Taiwan's year-end elections for legislators and local government chiefs.

The visiting PFP legislators are scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen Tuesday for wide-ranging talks. Following its Beijing visit, the group will travel to Tianjin and Xian for fact-finding visits.
The PFP legislative delegation arrived in Beijing Sunday and is scheduled to return to Taiwan Friday.
Noting that the delegation only represents the PFP, Liu said it current mainland visit has nothing to do with the ROC government.
Liu said issues related to the "major three links" are the main concern of the group's present mainland visit.

"We hope to find a solution that can help break the current cross-strait impasse," Liu said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should use wisdom to resolve their disputes and mend their differences through peaceful dialogue.

In his view, Liu said the ROC's DPP-led government should consider recognizing the 1992 consensus on "one China, separate interpretations" as a starting point to facilitate resumption of cross-strait dialogue and improvement of bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BUYERS HOLD NT$16 BILLION WORTH OF TAIWAN STOCKS

TEXT.P: Foreign buyers owned more than NT$1.6 trillion (US$ 50 billion) worth of Taiwan shares as of the end of March, accounting for 16.45 percent of the local listed and over-the-counter markets' total value, statistics released Monday by the Taiwan Stock Exchange show.
According to the statistics, foreign investors owned NT$1.01 trillion worth of shares listed on the local listed market alone, accounting for 9.79 percent of the market's total value.

Stocks of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation, United Micro Electronics Corp. and Hou Hai Precision Industry Corp. were the top three most possessed by foreign buyers, the same tallies indicate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI OLYMPIC HEAD VISITS IRAN

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) Chairman Huang Ta-chow arrived in Iran Monday and signed an official agreement with his Iranian Olympic Committee counterpart to increase two-way training exchanges.

The agreement, which finalizes a draft signed in February 1999, calls for each committee to invite the other to invitational events, provide training facilities for the other side, exchange coaches, and invite the other when conducting training courses for coaches.
According to the CTOC headquarters in Taipei, Huang invited Iranian Vice President Mostafa Hashemitaba, who serves concurrently as chairman of the Iranian Olympic Committee, to visit Taiwan.
Accompanied by CTOC Secretary General Chen Kuo-yi and Deputy Secretary General Chen Yun-ming, Huang also called on the Iranian committee's Secretary General Bahram Afsharzadeh.

Huang traveled to Iran's Kish free trade area from the United Arab Emirates, where he had met with a number of sports officials. Earlier last week, Huang was in Kuwait to attend a meeting of the Asian Olympic Committee Board of Directors.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION TO FIGHT CANCER FORMED

TEXT.P: Some 17 civic and medical groups formed a foundation Monday to fight against cancer in the hopes of making Taiwan a more healthy island and reducing local cancer rates.

Huang Fu-yuan, deputy director general of the Department of Health, said during the launch of the Formosa Cancer Foundation that although he is a doctor, he was unable to prevent his own sister from dying of breast cancer and his sister-in-law from dying of stomach cancer.

Huang lamented that he was too busy and his family members were not vigilant enough, so his sister and sister-in-law did not receive early treatment and lost their lives in their 40s. It is the biggest regret of his life, he added.

Huang noted that cancer kills 30,000 people in Taiwan every year, one quarter of the island's annual deaths. He added that he is gratified to see that anti-cancer civic groups have taken the initiative to form the foundation to raise awareness of the fight against cancer.

Jacqueline Whang-Peng, a member of the nation's prestigious research institute Academia Sinica and vice president of the Taiwan Union Against Cancer, was chosen to serve as the chairperson of the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 KILLED, 12 INJURED IN FIRE BOMB ATTACK AT A TAIWAN MATH SCHOOL

TEXT.P: A woman and a little boy were killed and 12 were injured Monday when a man tossed a Molotov cocktail at a school in northern Taiwan, police said.
The dead were identified as Huang Chiu-min, 37, principal of Chia Yu Children's Mental Arithmetic School, and Lo Kuan-lin, a nine-year-old boy studying at the school.
Twelve others, aged between one and 60, were hospitalized with minor and heavy injuries they suffered in the resulting fire, which burned down the four-story school building, police said.
Witnesses said a motorcyclist wearing a helmet threw the fire bomb and ran. Police were hunting for the man.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TAIWAN INVESTORS TURN PROFITS FROM MAINLAND OPERATIONS: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen's craze for investing in mainland China has shown no signs of abating and the ratio of Taiwan firms which manage to turn profits from mainland operations has increased, according to the results of a poll released Monday.
The survey of some 2,000 domestic companies with overseas investments was conducted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in the fourth quarter of last year.
Survey results show that 73.6 percent of those companies have invested in mainland China, up 4.5 percent from the level recorded in the MOEA's 1999 survey.

According to last year's poll, 23 percent of the respondents have invested in five Southeast Asian countries -- Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia and Singapore. About 18 percent said they have invested in the United States.

The poll also found that 39.4 percent of Taiwan-financed companies managed to post earnings from their mainland operations last year, compared to 30.7 percent who said their mainland businesses were still operating in the red.

This was the first time that the ratio of profitable mainland operations exceeded that of money-losing businesses, MOEA officials said, adding the figures indicated that Taiwan investors' operations on the mainland have been improving.
The survey further discovered that Taiwan-financed firms on the mainland have become less dependent on Taiwan for the supplies of raw materials, parts or semi-finished products.

In last year's survey, only 43.2 percent said they relied on Taiwan for the supplies of raw materials and semi-finished products, compared to 44.7 percent who said they secured raw materials and parts from the mainland market.

The figures indicated that Taiwan investors have increasingly relied on mainland suppliers for raw materials and parts as their new strategy to cut production costs and attract identification of mainland consumers, MOEA officials said.

Meanwhile, MOEA officials said mainland China remained the No. 1 overseas investment destination for Taiwan entrepreneurs. Compared with similar MOEA surveys conducted in 1996, 1998 and 1999, the percentages of mainland China-bound investors to firms with overseas investments were 72.7 percent, 71.1 percent and 69.1 percent, respectively.

In addition to its cheap labor and land, MOEA officials said, mainland China has become even more attractive to Taiwan investors in the past few years because of several fresh reasons, including the wave of economic globalization, Taipei's and Beijing's imminent accession to the World Trade Organization and the U.S. granting to Beijing of permanent normal trade relations (PNTR).

The latest MOEA survey also found that 55.9 percent of Taiwan investors in mainland China have posted gains in their business turnover over the past year, and that more than 60 percent of those who have invested in Vietnam, Thailand and Hong Kong have also seen increases in their overseas business volumes.

Survey results further showed that 72 percent of companies with overseas investments said their domestic business turnover still exceeded their overseas business volume. More than 40 percent of large enterprises said their overseas turnover accounted for less than 10 percent of their total annual business volumes, indicating that most large business groups have kept their business roots in Taiwan.
In contrast, 47 percent of small- and medium-sized enterprises have seen their overseas turnover exceed their domestic business volumes.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WILL TRY TO CUT JOBLESS RATE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated his concern over rising unemployment Monday, saying that the Cabinet will seek to cut the jobless rate.

The premier made the remarks when he presided over a meeting and listened to a report by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on how to step up the use of an employment stabilization fund to promote employment around the nation.

The premier said that the Executive Yuan has adopted various measures to deal with the unemployment problem, such as easing housing loan repayments for the jobless, providing short-term unemployment benefit and providing health insurance.

The government is also seeking to cooperate with the private sector to improve the investment environment, ease regulations governing employment contracts, promote the restructuring of enterprises, upgrade business competitiveness and strengthen the country's economic structure.
Chang noted that the lackluster economy and the fast adjustment of the industrial structure have combined to make the employment market bleaker.

He said that his government knows that the jobless problem is not simple, but involves the livelihoods of hundreds of thousands of families, and added that stimulating the economy and cutting the jobless rate is a priority of his Cabinet.

The high domestic jobless rate of 3.71 percent in February has been cause for alarm, prompting Chang to convene a meeting March 26 of the heads of the Council of Economic Planning and Development, Ministry of Finance, CLA, Department of Health, the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission and the Council of Aboriginal Affairs.

President Chen Shui-bian also expressed his concern about the rising jobless rate when he presided over a nine-person policymaking team March 27 and instructed the premier to adopt related measures to cut the jobless rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMY MIGHT IMPROVE IN SECOND HALF: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi predicted Monday that the local economy might recover in the third or fourth quarter of this year, while the U.S. economy should recover in the fourth quarter of 2001.
Lin made the remarks when he answered interpellation questions raised by members of the Economic and Energy Committee in the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Chen Ching-pao (KMT-Kinmen County) asked Lin whether he will allow his salary to be cut, which employees of state-run enterprises have done due to what he called their poor performance. Lin rejected Chen's statement, insisting that some state-run enterprises have turned a deficit into a surplus.
Legislator Huang Mu-tien (KMT-Taoyuan County) said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs should bear the responsibility for the high local unemployment rate.
Lin replied that his ministry could only do so much in the current international economic climate. "Even God couldn't figure a way out of this situation," he said.
Answering another question from Lin Sheng-liang (KMT-Taipei County), Lin Hsin-yi predicted that the local economy would begin recovering during the third or fourth quarter.
Meanwhile, Chen Pao-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, expressed the hope that June's unemployment rate will not surpass 4 percent.
However, Legislator Weng Chin-chu (DPP-Changhua County) pessimistically said that June's jobless rate will surpass 5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR LAUNCHES DIRECT FLIGHT TO SAN JOSE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Eva Air has announced that it will begin operating direct flights to San Jose, California Tuesday.
The carrier will offer one flight per day in conjunction with U.S. firm American Airlines, which will provide Boeing 747 jumbo jets for the route, according to Eva's Monday announcement.

Flights will depart Taipei at 1:20 p.m. and arrive in San Jose at 9:50 p.m. the next day; while coming the opposite way, flights will leave San Jose at 1:30 p.m. and arrive in Taipei on 5:55 p.m. the next day, according to the statement.
Eva will provide ground crew and maintenance service for American Airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO IMPROVE TIES WITH TIBETAN GOVERNMENT-IN-EXILE, MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will improve ties with the Tibetan government-in-exile in India, despite the "fact" that Tibet is technically still a part of the ROC, Chairman Hsu Cheng-kuang of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission said Monday.

In a report on the commission's agenda to the Legislative Yuan, Hsu admitted that there have been misunderstandings between his commission and the Dalai Lama's government caused by "the burden of history and the lack of channels of contact between the two sides."
However, Hsu said his commission will broaden contacts with the exiled Tibetan government and provide services to Tibetan people on the principle of humanitarianism.

Hsu noted that his commission did not invite the Dalai Lama, who arrived on the island Sunday for a 10-day visit, but said it had been consulted by the government on how to receive the Tibetan spiritual leader.

As for the 100-odd Tibetan refugees currently in Taiwan, Hsu said amnesty would be an option to grant them residence rather than revising the existing laws, which would require a "troublesome" overall review of related regulations.

Turning to the Mongolia question, Hsu said his commission will try to help the republic with its information education and share with it Taiwan's experience in creating its "democratic and economic miracles."

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP WILL TAKE OWN DEVELOPMENT DIRECTION: CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) reaffirmed Monday that PFP will take its own development direction.
James Soong pointed out that the development and growth of the party will not depend on cooperation with other political parties or on the failure of another party.
He made the remarks during a meeting with Sun Shui-fong -- the grand-daughter of Republic of China founder Dr. Sun Yat-sen -- who called on Soong at PFP headquarters.
In response to media speculation that the PFP will cooperate with the opposition Kuomintang, Soong said that the PFP should rely on its own hard work to serve the public.

Soong noted that local political commentators have said that President Chen Shui-bian's success in the presidential election of March 18, 2000 resulted from the splitting of the KMT, adding that if the KMT cooperates with the PFP, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) would have no future.

Predicting the outcome of the elections of legislators and magistrates scheduled to be held Dec. 1, 2001, Soong said the three largest political parties -- the KMT, the DPP and the PFP -- are all unlikely to get fewer than 100 seats and more than 40.
Speaking on the possibility of cooperation between the KMT and PFP in the coming election, Soong said that PFP and KMT will go cooperate but will also compete with each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOEING OPTIMISTIC ABOUT ASIAN MARKET

TEXT.P: A senior Boeing official said in Taipei Monday that Taiwan will need an estimated 190 commercial airplanes costing approximately US$27 billion over the next two decades, making it one of the fastest-growing markets in Asia.

Randy Baseler, vice president for marketing of Boeing Commercial Airplanes, predicted at a press conference that Taiwan's civil aviation sector will grow faster than the Asia Pacific region's annual 6.7 percent.
China Airlines, EVA Airways and Far East Air Transport are the company's major Taiwan clients.

Meanwhile, Baseler confirmed that the Seattle-based company has contracted Taiwan Aerospace Co. to manufacture tail assemblies for Boeing 717s, a partnership it is estimated will bring in US$20 million a year for the local aerospace industry leader.
He added that the two companies are currently discussing further cooperative opportunities, including a US$180 million plan to manufacture Boeing 737 tail assemblies at Taiwan Aerospace plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEAKER YEN WILL NOT TRIGGER FINANCIAL STORM: CBC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A senior official of Taiwan's Central Bank of China predicted Monday that the yen's depreciation trend is unlikely to trigger another Asian financial storm.
Chou A-ting, director-general of the bank's Foreign Exchange Department, said that Japanese trading figures are not in the red, as was the case of Thailand in 1997.
Thailand relied almost entirely on foreign capital, which carries great inherent risks, he said, adding that most nations are now more alert about capital flow and short-term foreign capital.

He speculated that the yen fell to a 30-month low against the greenback earlier in the day mainly as a result of the release of a quarterly Bank of Japan report that indicated a pessimistic outlook from Japan's biggest manufacturers.
Chou added that other Asian currencies will inevitably be affected, but that they will reflect their own economic fundamentals eventually.

He warned that if other Asian countries were to competitively weaken their currencies, not only would such a move not have the desired effect of stimulating exports, it would also result in inflationary pressure.

Regarding the local currency, Chou said that Taiwan's annual economic growth rate is above 5 percent, unlike Japan's, which stands at less than 1 percent. Also, with the net amount of foreign investment in March maintaining a moderate level of between US$500 million to US$1 billion, he continued, the new Taiwan dollar is unlikely to follow in the yen's footsteps.

DOC.HEADLINE: PETROLEUM DEMAND RELIES ON IMPORTS: CPC HEAD

TEXT.P: Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) Chairman C.W. Chen said Monday that Taiwan relies heavily on foreign imports of petroleum and natural gas to meet local demand.

Despite the fact that Taiwan produces some petroleum and natural gas, Chen said the island's scant production is not enough to cover domestic consumption due to the cost of oil and gas exploration. He noted that 99 percent of Taiwan's oil and gas needs are met through imports.

Chen made the remarks while answering questions from lawmakers Liao Fu-pen and Yu Cheng-tao at a legislative committee meeting after paying an inspection trip to the CPC's construction of a liquid natural gas (LNG) storage tank in Yungan, Kaohsiung County.

Citing a written report on the Yungan LNG plant, Liao said that the plant authorities are carrying out the third-phase construction of the storage tank as part of the CPC's efforts to satisfy the local demand for LNG. According to the report, the CPC's annual LNG supplies are around 4.5 million tons at present, a figure that is expected to reach 7.4 million tons in 2007.

Liao also asked Chen whether Taiwan has the potential to become a "second Kuwait," because Taiwan and the seabed surrounding it are rich in petroleum and LNG reserves, according to some information gleaned from satellites.

Pouring cold water on Liao's idea, the CPC chairman replied that while it might be true that there may be 5-6 billion cubic meters of LNG deposited deep beneath the seabed some 100 nautical miles off the Kaohsiung coast, the CPC has decided against exploring the reserves as the expected profits would not be sufficient to offset the cost of the exploration.

Currently, the CPC pays up to NT$800 million in exploration fees per year, he added, noting that petroleum and natural gas are normally found deep below the earth and are not easily detected by satellite imaging.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWLY APPOINTED PHILIPPINE REP. TO ROC TO ASSUME DUTIES APRIL 17
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, April 2 (CNA) (By Philip Liu & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Philippine Representative to the Republic of China Edgardo Espinosa is scheduled to arrive in Taipei April 17 to assume his duties.
Espinosa said that he will promote bilateral cooperation in economics, agriculture and fisheries, labor and tourism, as well as strengthening friendly relations between the two countries.
Citing Taiwan as the Philippines third-largest trade partner, Espinosa said that efforts will be also made to strengthen exchanges in information and technology, as well as culture.

He said he will also try to lure more Taiwan investors to Subic and Clark Special Economic Zones to invest in telecommunications, electronics, technology, agriculture and tourism so as to enlarge the volume of Taipei-Manila trade.

He also expressed deep concern over Filipinos working illegally in Taiwan, saying that even though such workers make up only a small proportion of the 98,000 Filipinos working in Taiwan, he will try to help them resolve their problems.

Espinosa, 56, graduated from the Philippine Army Academy in 1967 and obtained a masters degree in Public Administration from the University of the Philippines. He was dean of the Command and General Staff College before accepting his new job.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL APPOINTEES TO GET ONE YEAR TO GIVE UP DUAL CITIZENSHIP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced Monday that it will seek to amend the law so that any politically appointed government officials with dual citizenship will have one year to give up their non-Republic of China citizenship.
After a recent cross-ministerial meeting, the MOI decided that the amendment is necessary to avoid future controversy.

Participants at the meeting agreed that a one-year grace period is necessary because most appointments come extemporaneously, while different countries have different procedures regarding citizenship, which means that renouncements can take varying lengths of time.

In addition, the group decided to propose another amendment to allow dual-citizenship specialists to return to Taiwan to take up teaching or research positions without the need for individual government approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING LIBERIAN LEADER MEETS WITH FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) (By David Hsu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor met with former President Lee Teng-hui Monday for a 20-minute discussion.

Foreign Ministry officials who were present at the meeting at the Taiwan Research Institute -- of which Lee is chairman -- said afterward that Lee and Taylor chatted pleasantly during the courtesy call.
Meanwhile Taylor's wife Jewel Howard Taylor visited the Republic of China's Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Monday to gain an understanding of the ROC's social welfare system.
She was warmly welcomed by ROC Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya and officials of the Social Affairs Department under the MOI.
Chang briefed the first lady on the ROC's overall social welfare system, whereupon Jewel Howard praised the ROC for its "progressive social welfare system and integrated security network."
She was especially interested in the ROC's child welfare system and measures and gathered some relevant information "to bring back to Liberia for reference."

Chang told her that the ROC government has "long devoted itself to establishing a sound social welfare system" and added that the ROC government has given priority to establishing a social security network in the past two years to allow people to live in a stable and secure environment.
Taylor and his wife arrived in Taiwan on March 28 for a seven-day visit at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA SAYS HE WILL NOT SEEK INDEPENDENCE FOR TIBET

TEXT.P: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama said in Taipei Monday that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence.
He made the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
The Nobel Prize laureate, who fled Tibet to India in 1959, told the lawmakers that the present situation in Tibet "is not good for either Tibet or the People's Republic of China."
"It is a common disaster for both Tibet and the PRC," the Dalai Lama noted, adding that Tibet's culture, tradition and natural environment are facing destruction.
As a spokesman for free Tibetans, the Dalai Lama said that he has been trying to seek a solution for his homeland -- to have the PRC grant a genuine autonomy for Tibet.
He stressed that his personal stance is not to seek Tibetan independence, but to seek a genuine autonomy.
The Dalai Lama said that he will demand nothing from Beijing. "As I stated before, whether the incarnation system of the Dalai Lama will continue to exist should be decided by the Tibetans."
"If they want to maintain the system, then keep it; otherwise, the system can be abolished," he said.
The Dalai Lama said that he has also stated before that in case he is able to return to Tibet, he wants to hand over the political power to a government formed through democratic elections.
During the hour-long speech, the Dalai Lama said that all people are members of a family and that everyone therefore has the responsibility of caring about the future of humankind and the earth.
Before the speech, the Dalai Lama presented a hata to Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng.
Earlier in the day, the Dalai Lama expounded the meaning of the "Prajina Paramita" (Heart Sutra) at the Linkou Stadium before a packed audience.

He said the foundation of the Buddha's teachings lies in compassion and added that the reason for practicing the teachings is to wipe out the persistence of ego, which he termed the number one enemy of compassion.

"Compassion and love is the source of external and internal peace and is also the root of racial survival," said the Dalai Lama, who arrived in Taipei last Saturday for what has been described as a 10-day "religious trip" at the invitation of the Chinese Buddhist Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 3, or the 10th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy during its successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1882: Jesse James, head of the notorious outlaw James Gang and mastermind of countless bank and train robberies, is gunned down by Robert Ford, one of his own gang, at his home in St. Joseph, Missouri.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, which blended classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1973: The International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors Association opens its 12th convention in Taipei.
1975: S. K Chow, ROC minister of state, leaves for Riyadh to express the condolences of the Chinese government in the death of King Faisal.
1975: The Free China Relief Association marks its 25th anniversary.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1976: An 11-member Japanese Diet mission including former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: Dr. Montanaro, Paraguayan minister of the Interior, arrives in Taipei for Chiang's memorial services.
1982: Bueno Aires celebrates the invasion of the Falkland Islands while the United Nations says Argentina must pull out.
1991: Martha Graham, American dancer and choreographer, dies at the age of 97. A central figure in modern dance, she founded the Dance Repertory Theatre in New York City in 1930.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng says that the KMT has agreed to let Defense Minister Tang Fei serve as President-elect Chen Shui-bian's premier in his "personal capacity."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO UNUSUAL PLA MOVEMENTS: ROC MILITARY SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese military forces have shown no signs of unusual movement since Sunday's mid-air collision between a U.S. surveillance aircraft and a mainland intercepter jet over the South China Sea created tension in the region, the Republic of China's military spokesman said Tuesday.

Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said at a regular press conference that mainland forces, including the Second Artillery which controls the missiles deployed opposite Taiwan, have been conducting only routine drills.
He added that the Republic of China's own combat readiness drills have carried on as usual and have not been affected by Sunday's incident.

Huang also said the ROC military is fully monitoring the situation, but he would not comment on whether the Defense Ministry believes that the incident will affect the upcoming U.S.-ROC arms sales talks in Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE REP WARNS TAIWAN TO COMPLY WITH TELECOMS TRADE AGREEMENTS

TEXT.P: The United States warned Taiwan and three other trading partners on Monday to improve compliance with bilateral trade agreements on telecommunications services or face possible retaliatory actions.

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Zoellick said in a statement while releasing the annual section 1377 trade report that the United States will seek "specific action consistent with telecommunications trade commitments of certain U.S. trading partners."
He singled out Colombia, Mexico, South Africa and Taiwan as raising "serious concerns" among U.S officials regarding those countries' compliance with their telecoms trade obligations.

The report said that Taiwan's telecommunications sector regulations have imposed serious limitations on the competitive offering of telecoms services by U.S. firms and have undermined new entrants into Taiwan's market.

"The restrictions also appear to be inconsistent with the commitments undertaken by Taiwan as part of its bilateral WTO accession negotiations with the United States to liberalize its telecommunications market by July 1, 2001," the report said.

Zoellick warned that if Taiwan does not take the necessary steps to fulfill its commitments, he will consider "appropriate actions," including those contained within section 1374 of the 1988 Trade Act."

Section 1374 of the 1988 Trade Act requires the U.S. trade representative to investigate and identify the "priority countries" with respect to the imposition of trade barriers on U.S. telecoms companies.
If a country is identified as a priority country, the president is then authorized under section 1376 of the same act to take action, including imposing trade sanctions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 160.91 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 160.91 points to close at 5,446.82.
Market turnover amounted to NT$69.89 billion (US$2.12 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH DEMANDS BEIJING NOT TAMPER WITH U.S. RECONNAISSANCE PLANE

TEXT.P: The United States will help Taiwan defend itself, but at this point the Bush administration has still not made any decision on the question of this year's arms sales to Taiwan, White House spokesman Scott McClellan said Monday.

McClellan made the remarks at a regular press briefing when asked what impact Sunday's mid-air collision between a U.S. reconnaissance plane and a Communist Chinese jet fighter over the South China Sea would have on Bush's pending decision regarding Taiwan's request for advanced weapons, including four Arleigh Burke-class Aegis destroyers.
McClellan said that "the president has repeatedly iterated our support for the Taiwan Relations Act, and we will help Taiwan defend itself."
He stressed that the focus now is on getting immediate access to the plane's 24 crew members being held in mainland China.

Earlier President George W. Bush demanded that Beijing grant the United States immediate consular access to the 24 crew members of the U.S. Navy reconnaissance plane and return the plane without any tampering.
"I sent a very clear message and I expect them to heed the message," Bush told reporters at the White House.
Bush said Beijing's refusal to let U.S. officials talk to the crew members right away was "inconsistent with customary diplomatic practices and the desire of both countries for better relations."
According to McClellan, mainland Chinese officials finally offered to let U.S. consular officials visit the crew members late Tuesday night.

Several American media reports said that Chinese officials had boarded the U.S. SP-3 reconnaissance jet, but the White House refused to confirm them. The reports raised concerns about the possibility of the plane's classified surveillance technology falling into Beijing's hands.

Bush insisted that the U.S. plane was on a routine mission in international airspace when it collided with one of two Chinese F-8 fighter jets shadowing it on Sunday. The plane made an emergency landing on Hainan Island, located off the southern coast of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 160.91 points to close at 5,446.82.

Affected by a drop in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,521.99 and continued to go down due to selling pressure caused by the depreciation of both the Japanese yen and the NT dollar. The index fluctuated between 5,538.09 and 5,439.4 during trading.

A total of 1.91 billion stocks worth NT$69.89 billion (US$2.12 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.19 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$75.99 billion (US$2.32 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile issues moving down the most at 4.8 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 4.1 percent, construction stocks at 4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 3.7 percent, cement stocks at 3.3 percent, electrical shares at 3.1 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.5 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 1.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 490 to 47, with 42 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved down 151 points to close at 5,470, with 7,816 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May lost 161 points to finish at 5,478, with 173 contract transactions, while June futures fell 178 points to close at 5,502, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,621 for April, 5,639 for May, 5,680 for June, 5,678 for September, and 5,678 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
April TE futures lost 7.9 points to finish at 268.1, with 2,279 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved down 10.9 points to close at 268.6, with 45 contract transactions.
December TE futures fell 11.05 points to finish at 269, with 23 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 9.2 points to close at 751, with 761 contract transactions, while May TF futures fell 13 points to finish at 750, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.038 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 32.900.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 32.921 and was traded between 32.860 and 32.980.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$523.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTS OF ROC AND LIBERIA SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor signed a joint communique Tuesday calling on all nations to resolve international differences through dialogue, negotiations and other peaceful means.
Taylor and his entourage met their host for a final round of opinion exchanges before leaving Taipei, ending a weeklong visit.
In the communique, the two leaders also urged all governments to strive for democracy, human rights and the rule of law in order to maintain world peace and security.

Taylor reiterated his thanks for the Republic of China's economic and humanitarian assistance to Liberia since the two nations restored diplomatic relations in 1989 following a hiatus of 12 years when the West African nation switched to diplomatic ties with Beijing.
In turn, Chen pledged in the communique to be a trustworthy partner in Liberia's national development and reconstruction process.
Taylor praised the Republic of China's advances in democracy and economic liberalization, and he formally invited Chen to visit Liberia.
Chen accepted Taylor's invitation, adding that the exact dates will be determined through diplomatic channels in the near future.

Regarding the specific areas of bilateral exchanges and cooperation to be outlined in a draft agreement, Chen said that further consensus can be formed at a year-end meeting to be held between ROC and Liberian government officials.
Taylor and his delegation departed Taipei in the afternoon. He was accorded military honors, including a 21-gun salute, in a farewell ceremony presided over by Chen earlier in the morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS OUTGOING SENEGAL AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with outgoing Senegal Ambassador Ahmed Tijane Kane Tuesday, saying that he will sincerely welcome a visit by Senegal President Abdoulaye Wade to Taiwan and that two-way ties will be further cemented through exchanges of visits by ranking officials.

Lamenting that he was not able to pay a visit to Senegal on an African tour in August last year, Chen told Kane that he is happy that Wade will have the opportunity to visit Taiwan in July and that the Republic of China government will greet him with the warmest reception.

On behalf of the ROC government and its people, Chen praised Kane for his outstanding contribution to the promotion of bilateral ROC-Senegal relations during his two-year-and-a-half tenure in Taiwan, encouraging him to continue working for friendship between the two countries even after leaving his current post Sunday.

Chen also hailed Kane as one of Senegal's best diplomats, who had not only witnessed his rise to the presidency from his reelection defeat in the 1998 Taipei mayoral race, but had also experienced Taiwan's democratic and economic progress over the past few years.

Although many people were concerned about that the ROC's first power transition on May 20 last year would have an impact on the nation's foreign policy, Chen said that facts have proved that Taiwan's foreign policy is consistent and stable despite the change in the central government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FULFILLING COMMITMENT TO TELECOM LIBERALIZATION: MOTC

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reaffirmed Tuesday that Taiwan has faithfully fulfilled its commitment to liberalize its telecommunications market as part of its bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The officials said the pace of liberalization is actually ahead of schedule and there is no reason for the U.S. to find fault in this regard.

The officials made the remarks in response to U.S. criticism of Taiwan in its annual review of telecommunications trade practices in which it said Taiwan's restrictions undermine the attempts of new entrants to compete in the domestic telecommunications market and called into question the country's commitment to liberalize the sector.

During a visit to Taiwan last month, a U.S. trade delegation asked Taiwan to open its fix-lined and undersea cable industries. This was the latest time that the U.S. complained that Taiwan has not moved quickly to open its telecommunications markets under the WTO rules.

The officials said that Taiwan, responding to the request by the United States, actually decided to open its undersea cable businesses last year, and agreed to review to expand rental access to other than fix-lined operators.

On the U.S. requests that Taiwan ease its regulations on fix-lined operations, the officials noted that a telecommunications liberalization task force is now reviewing all related issues, and should have a report ready by the end of June.

Meanwhile, on U.S. criticism that the threshold for setting up a fix-lined business is too high at a minimum capital investment of NT$40 billion (US$1.21 billion), they noted that the local telecom giant Chung Hwa Telecom Co. has a current yearly surplus of NT$60 billion. If new operators want to compete with Chung Hwa Telecom, capital of NT$40 billion cannot be considered too high, they said.
They stressed that Taiwan has carried through with its commitment to open up the telecommunications market, and there is no reason for the U.S to find fault with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INTERESTS MAY BE COMPROMISED IN EP-3 INCIDENT: ROC LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: A number of Republic of China lawmakers warned Tuesday that ROC interests may be compromised as a result of the forced landing of a U.S. surveillance plane in mainland Chinese territory following a mid-air collision with a mainland fighter.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislator Chou Cheng-chih, a retired lieutenant general, told reporters that he believes mainland China will take the opportunity to carefully study the U.S. aircraft's advanced electronic warfare capabilities and develop ways to counter them.

He went on to say that this would be very disadvantageous for Taiwan if the United States were to decide to sell the island the same EP-3 or the similar P-3 anti-submarine warfare surveillance aircraft at the upcoming arms sales talks in Washington.
Chou claimed that he has privately obtained assurance that the United States is ready to sell Taiwan the P-3 planes it has requested, and perhaps even the more advanced EP-3.

He speculated that Washington and Beijing are unlikely to go to war over "a little airplane," and that the United States would certainly join forces with other nations to pressure mainland China to return the crew members and the plane.
However, Chou warned that if Washington and Beijing were to decide to exchange conditions when negotiations over the EP-3 begin, Taiwan's interests will be the first to be sacrificed.

In exchange for the safe return of the U.S. crew and aircraft, Washington might promise Beijing that it will not sell Taiwan the state-of-the-art Aegis destroyers or diesel-electric submarines that Taiwan has requested, Chou added.
On the other hand, he continued, if the two sides maintain a hostile attitude, the United States might decide to sell Taiwan "just about any weapon."

Meanwhile, opposition New Party legislator Elmer Fung said at a legislative session that the government should quickly convene a national security meeting because this incident cannot be treated carelessly.
KMT legislator Chao Erh-chung added his warning that Taiwan should be vigilant in monitoring the upcoming Washington-Beijing negotiation process to prevent being "sold out" without its knowledge.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR 'SOFT APPROACH' TOWARD BEIJING

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu Tuesday called for the adoption of a "soft approach" toward Beijing and urged mainland China to take care of its people rather than deploying missiles aimed at Taiwan.

Lu said Taiwan is a small island, but that "we are not afraid while confronting mainland China's threats because of our 'soft national strength' -- the respect for human rights, democracy, peace, love and high technology."

Stressing that Taiwan has always been a peace-loving country and has never been an "invader" or posed any threat to mainland China, Lu said that many Taiwan people now reside in the mainland for study, business and travel purposes, and that it is indeed unnecessary for Beijing to deploy hundreds of missiles along its coasts targeting Taiwan.

The vice president made the remarks while receiving a 25-member 1delegation of the Association of World Citizens (AWC), which has been celebrating its 11th World Citizen Congress in Taipei over the past five days.

Describing Taiwan as "a distant relative and a close friend" of mainland China, Liu said the island has transformed itself into a diversified and democratic nation through a lengthy process. She asked the AWC delegates to relay Taiwan's peaceful message to the mainland and push it to stop aiming its missiles at Taiwan in order to promote peaceful co-existence between the two sides.

Commenting on the recent incident of a mid-air collision over the South China Sea between a U.S. spy plane and a mainland Chinese fighter, Liu voiced her hope that the two sides will be able to resolve the matter peacefully and wisely.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC JOBLESS RATE MORE THAN DOUBLE OFFICIAL FIGURE AT 8.4%: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The real domestic jobless rate is 8.4 percent, more than double the official figure of 3.73 percent, according to a recent survey.
Legislator Huang Yi-chiao of the opposition People First Party (PFP) and the magazine Biznews unveiled the results of the latest survey in a press conference Tuesday.
The survey was conducted March 21-23, with 1,074 effective samples gathered from 1,931 people aged 20-64. The poll's carries a margin of error of three percent.
The survey also showed that 12.4 percent of the respondents said they are willing to work overseas, and among them, nearly 70 percent chose mainland China as their most desired destination.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said recently that domestic unemployment had increased to a record high of 3.73 percent in February, with the some 364,000 jobless workers in Taiwan.

But as the DGBAS had mainly targeted farmers, workers hired by the government, employers, and self-employed workers for its survey, some analysts say that its unemployment figure may be an underestimation.

The new survey excluded military personnel, civil servants, teachers, farmers, employers, housewives and retirees -- or those who are considered low-risk jobless groups -- and found that the jobless rate for people who have the ability to work but have been unable to find jobs for more than six months has reached 8.4 percent.

The survey also found that most of the jobless either are more than 50 years of age, have middle high school educations, or are male laborers from places other than northern Taiwan. This is seen as an indication of a structural transformation of Taiwan's industries.
The survey also found the less education one has, the higher one's chances of being unemployed. Among the jobless, males outnumbered females by 65.3 percent to 34.7 percent.
The jobless situation is more serious in central and southern Taiwan than in the northern region, the survey showed.
It also found that the households of 43 percent of the jobless are already in financial dire straits.

The survey found that 12.4 percent of respondents do not rule out working overseas, and nearly 70 percent chose the mainland as their most desired destination, followed by the United States, Canada, Europe, Japan and Singapore.
Legislator Huang said that the employment market shows Taiwan's structural problems and urged the government to review the overall situation and work out measures to deal with the problem.
Meanwhile, DGBAS officials said the latest survey can only be seen as a public poll, adding that its definition of "jobless" was vague and the poll was not conducted scientifically.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION DOWN IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Amid a continuously sluggish economy at home and overseas, Taiwan's manufacturing production in March was down 7.38 percent from the same time last year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.

Chang Yao-chung, director general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, said that manufacturing output in March was up 10.97 percent from the previous month, showing that the economy may be turning around, but whether or not it has bottomed out remains to be seen.

Chang noted that the economic chart this year will not resemble a "V," but rather a "U." He said he will have to continue to watch export orders and the production of the manufacturing sector before predicting when the economy will begin to rebound.

He attributed the drop in manufacturing to this year's sluggish economy. In addition, the annual increase in manufacturing production last year was in the double digits, presenting a higher basis for comparison, he said.

Looking ahead, Chang said that as Taiwan relies a lot on the U.S. market, which is obviously slowing, there is no reason for optimism from that market. But he said that as 50 percent of Taiwan's exports now are taken by the Asian market, the mainland economy continues to grow, and trade with Hong Kong is still brisk, the prospect of an economic rebound here is more likely than in the United States.
Chang said that the second quarter could not be worse than the first quarter in Taiwan, and that an economic rebound would occur in the third or fourth quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING TAIWAN LAWMAKERS TO MEET WITH BEIJING'S VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: A group of visiting legislators from Taiwan's People First Party is slated to meet with Beijing's Vice Premier Qian Qichen Tuesday afternoon after calling on officials of the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation.

The PFP lawmakers' Beijing trip has been full of twists and turns. At first, the group's number was reduced from 16 to 6 after one of its female members was hospitalized after being beaten by another lawmaker in the Legislative Yuan, and then the delegation's itinerary was subject to further changes. Even the schedule of the Qian meeting, which will be the culmination of their trip, was changed from Tuesday morning to Tuesday afternoon.

The visiting group is trying to woo Beijing's support for its plan to define direct shipping links between the two sides as a special shipping route rather than an international shipping lane, as the Taiwan administration prefers, or internal links, as Beijing has advocated. However, they have found their proposal a hard sell in Beijing.
Meanwhile, the PFP lawmakers met with a group of Taiwan businessmen operating in Beijing to listen to their problems.

The businessmen said they appreciated the PFP's efforts to help open direct transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and complained about the education problems facing their children because Taiwan does not accredit mainland Chinese schools.
Legislator Liu Sung-pan, who is heading the delegation, promised to refer their problems to Taipei's Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S Q-1 CAR SALES POST ANNUAL DROP OF 19.7%

TEXT.P: The number of domestic cars sold in Taiwan during the first quarter of this year totaled 100,525, down 19.7 percent from the same period last year, according to statistics released Tuesday by Taiwan's automotive industry.
The statistics showed that China Motor Corp. sold the most cars at 23,609 units in the first quarter of this year, a decrease of 17.3 percent from the same period of last year.

Meanwhile, during the same period, Hotai Motor Corp. sold a total of 19,243 cars, a year-on-year decline of 28.1 percent; Yulon Motor Co., Ltd. sold 18,346 cars, an annual of 9.6 percent; Ford Lio Ho Motor Co., Ltd. sold 11,498 units, a year-on-year drop of 29.6 percent; and San Yang Industrial Co., Ltd. sold just 7,564 cars, down 61.1 percent from the same period last year.

The statistics also showed that 37,310 Taiwan-made cars were sold in March this year. China Motor also ranked in first place on the list of the number of cars sold in that month, with 6,892. During the same month, Hotai's sales reached 6,019 units, Yulon sold 5,634 cars, Ford Lio Ho sold 3,639 units, and San Yang Industrial sold 2,233 cars.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 4, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in a Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: U.S. Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy and his wife leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
1999: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan urges Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.
2000: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi reiterates that his country's stance of supporting the Republic of China in international forums will never change.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WISHES YOUNGSTERS HAPPY CHILDREN'S DAY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung wished the country's youngsters a happy Children's Day Wednesday, expressing the hope that all the children from around Taiwan lead safe and enjoyable life during their formative years.
Chang stressed the government's determination in protecting Taiwan children's welfare and interests, as well as in bolstering the youngsters' opportunities and improving their living environment.

The premier, meanwhile, reminded the Taiwan public that April 4th is Children's Day, rather than "Women and Children's Day," and instructed the Government Information Office to clarify the misunderstanding that has been prevalent for the last few years. He noted that there is no term in the ROC's administrative statutes referring to the holiday as "Women and Children's Day."
Meanwhile Tomb-Sweeping Day, a national holiday according to government statues, falls on the day after Children's Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TEST-FIRES ANTI-SHIP HARPOON MISSILE FROM F-16

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force has successfully test-fired an anti-ship AGM-848 Harpoon missile from its F-16 jet fighter, the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) said Wednesday.

According to AFGH officials, the Air Force No. 6821 F-16 jet fighter test-fired the Harpoon missile Tuesday in an air force-navy combined drill under the ongoing Hankuang No. 17 military exercise in southern Taiwan.
It was the first time in the world that an air-launched Harpoon missile has been successfully fired from an F-16 fighter jet, Air Force officers said.

"The AGM-848 Harpoon missile fired from F-16 fighter accurately hit the target -- a decommissioned destroyer -- off the Chiupeng bay in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung," said an AFGH official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Military sources said the Air Force 401 Wing conducted a combined maritime drill with the Navy's Hsiungfeng II missile-equipped Kangting-class (originally named Lafayette-class) frigates off the Chiupeng bay Tuesday.

In the drill, the sources said, the participating air force and navy personnel practiced strategies and skills for fighting mainland China's Russian-made Sovremennyy-class destroyers, including the test-firing of an air-launched, anti-ship Harpoon missile.

The ROC armed forces began their annual combined services training exercise, codenamed "Hankuang No. 17," at the beginning of April. The massive-scale military exercise will be held in two stages. One stage features live-fire drills while the other will focus on cyberwar games.
Military sources said attacks by mainland Chinese M-class missiles will be scenarios to be presented in the cyberwar games and that the civil defense system will be tested.
Taiwan's first military cyberwar unit, launched in January, makes its debut in the current Hankuang exercise.

Market turnover amounted to NT$69.52 billion (US$2.11 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES CHINESE STUDIES' REFERENCE MATERIAL TO ITALIAN UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 3 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative in Italy on Tuesday presented a set of valuable Chinese studies' reference material to the Istituto Universitario Orientale, Napoli, on behalf of the ROC government.

Representative Lin Chi-cheng and his wife were warmly welcomed by Pasquale Ciriello, the vice principal of the Italian university, and all the professors and staff of the department of Chinese studies when they arrived at the university for a visit.

In remarks given after a book-offering ceremony, Lin said that he hopes the Italian university will interact with Taiwan colleges on the academic and cultural level. In reply, Ciriello said Taiwan's students are welcome to study at the Napoli-based university.

The set of Chinese studies' reference material, published by the ROC Ministry of Education, includes research books, voice-recorded data and VCD's. The collection will be kept in the university's library for use by students of Chinese studies.

The Instituto Universitario Orientale is the oldest school of oriental studies in Europe. It was founded as the "Chinese College" by a missionary in the early 18th century. The institute was then converted into a state university in 1957.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPY PLANE ISSUE SHOULDN'T AFFECT ARMS SALES TO ROC: EX-U.S. AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: Former U.S. ambassador to Beijing James Lilley said Tuesday that the Bush administration should decide what weapons to sell Taiwan based on the latter's self-defense needs and not on considerations related to issue of the U.S. surveillance plane and crew being held by mainland China.

He told Voice of America radio station that the United States and Communist China have an opportunity to prevent the current crisis from derailing bilateral relations. If the two sides can handle the surveillance plane issue discreetly and as quickly as possible, they can move on to dealing with normal bilateral business.

The decision on arms sales to Taiwan will, "of course, be influenced if (the Communist Chinese) put these 24 people on trial, if they make an obvious effort to ransack the airplane, etc.," the former U.S. representative to Taipei said.

If this were to occur, Lilley pointed out, the United States might feel compelled to sell higher quality weapons to Taiwan. But he added that he is convinced that Washington and Beijing can work together and negotiate their way out of the spy plane crisis.
The former ambassador explained that Communist China tends to act pragmatically, and good negotiators should be able to resolve this issue in a few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 40.97 points to close at 5,405.85.
Affected by a continued downward streak in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,386.59 and fluctuated between 5,455.52 and 5,345.6 during trading.

A total of 1.96 billion stocks worth NT$69.52 billion (US$2.11 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.91 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$69.89 billion (US$2.12 billion).
Only one of the eight major stocks categories gained ground, with construction stocks edging up 0.4 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with textile issues moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.9 percent, pulp and paper issues and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 1.2 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.9 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 303 to 205, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS OF FORMER KMT GOV'T BASHED FOR SPATE OF VISITS TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party legislator gave officials of the former Kuomintang administration a bashing Wednesday for their roles in whipping up a new wave of "mainland fever" in Taiwan's business and trade sectors, which he said has led to a flight of Taiwan capital to mainland China in recent years.

In a Legislative Yuan interpellation session, Legislator Chiu Chui-chen ridiculed the spate of visits to mainland China in recent months by ranking officials of the former KMT administration, questioning the propriety of the large number of visits and asking Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi how he views the situation.

Saying that he has no views concerning Chiu's accusation, Lin reiterated the stance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) that while the government is readjusting Taiwan's "go slow" policy toward mainland China, it is at the same time strenuously working out coping measures to regulate mainland-bound Taiwan investments.

The Mainland Affairs Council, Taiwan's top governmental agency responsible for formulating mainland China policy, is currently in charge of the task, and the MOEA and the Ministry of Finance are offering support, Lin noted.

Legislator Chiu bashed the former officials, including Presidential Secretary-General John Chang, Transportation and Communications Minister Liu Chao-shuan, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang and Finance Minister Paul Chiu, for visiting mainland China one after another in recent months and creating a new wave of "China fever" in Taiwan's business and trade sectors.

Chiu's accusation, however, drew protests from KMT Legislator Liao Wan-ju, who demanded that Chiu not mislead the general public by making biased allegations and accusations during legislative sessions.
Liao, in turn, asked Minister Lin whether he has visited mainland China and whether he is for or against Republic of China officials visiting mainland China.

Lin replied that he has visited mainland China several times and that he personally favors ROC officials visiting the mainland to gain a better understanding of it's systems, administration proficiency and related policies on attracting foreign investment.

Meanwhile, Lin, in response to questions raised by other legislators about the upcoming APEC ministerial-level meeting to be held in Shanghai, said it is hoped that ROC officials will be able to discuss matters concerning investment guarantee agreements between Taiwan and mainland China with their Beijing counterparts during the APEC meetings to be held in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PITCHES FOR EARLY SOLUTION TO MIDAIR COLLISION INCIDENT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday the Republic of China sincerely hopes that the United States and mainland China can resolve their military aircraft collision incident peacefully, rationally and properly.

"For the sake of maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, we are hopeful that Washington and Beijing can quickly and properly resolve the issue regarding a recent midair collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland fighter in line with the international regulations and practices," Chang said during a weekly Cabinet meeting.

It was also the first time that the ROC premier has spoken on the issue since the collision in the South China Sea forced the U.S. plane to make an emergency landing on mainland China's Hainan island on Sunday.

Chang further expressed his hopes that the United States continues honoring its commitment to furnishing Taiwan with adequate defensive weapons in accrdance with the provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and Taiwan's practical defense needs. The TRA is the U.S. law that regulates relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Meanwhile, Chang directed all relevant government agencies to keep high alert on whether mainland China would take advantage of this incident to force the United States to compromise on its stances or make any concessions at the ROC's expense.

"All relevant government agencies should closely monitor the developments in the incident and keep abreast of the latest information," the premier urged, adding that trelevant agencies should hammer out countermeasures to cope with possible U.S.-mainland China interaction in the wake of the collision incident.

Commenting on a Hong Kong newspaper report that mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) has entered the top-level combat readiness since the happening of the incident, military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said the ROC military has been fully monitoring mainland China's military movement.
Huang said the military has so far found no signs of unusual PLA movement.
"Mainland forces, including the Second Artillery which controls the missiles deployed opposite Taiwan, have been conducting only routine drills," Huang explained.
On the other hand, Huang added that the ROC's own combat preparedness drills have been going on as usual and have not been affected by Sunday's incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CONTINUE MEDICAL COOPERATION WITH SENEGAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan on Wednesday passed a proposal put forth by the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs to extend a medical cooperation agreement with Senegal for an extra three years.

The ROC signed a five-year medical cooperation agreement with Senegal in 1996, promising US$700,000 in financial support to the African country each year during that period, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The agreement, which already expired Jan. 2, 2001, helped Senegal construct more medical facilities, purchase higher quality medicine, send domestic medical staff abroad for higher education, and hire more doctors and caregivers.

Through an exchange of diplomatic notes between the ROC Embassy and the Senegalese Foreign Ministry in Dakar, Senegal's capital, the two countries extended the cooperation agreement for an additional three years, the MOFA said.

Meanwhile, ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao on Wednesday honored Senegal Ambassador to the ROC Ahmed Tijane Kane with a medal in recognition of his contributions toward relations between the two countries. Tien presided over the ceremony which was attended by many officials and foreign ambassadors.

Kane, who has been Senegal's ambassador to the ROC since 1998, had also served as the ambassador to many different countries, including mainland China, South Korea, Thailand, and Australia, prior to assuming his present post.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved down one point to close at 5,469, with 7,103 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose one point to finish at 5,479, with 72 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,470 for April, 5,478 for May, 5,502 for June, 5,527 for September, and 5,527 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also reported mixed results.
April TE futures rose 0.8 points to finish at 268.1, with 1,988 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved down 2.6 points to close at 266.8, with nine contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 3.6 points to close at 747.4, with three contract transactions, while May TF futures fell 4 points to finish at 746, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA NOT ON 1ST-LEVEL COMBAT ALERT: MND

TEXT.P: A Republic of China military spokesman discounted reports Wednesday that mainland Chinese forces have been on first-level combat alert since Sunday, when a U.S. surveillance plane made an emergency landing on Hainan island after a collision with a mainland fighter jet.

Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said during a telephone interview that the mainland Chinese military, including the Tri Forces and the Second Artillery, which controls the missiles deployed opposite Taiwan, have been conducting only routine drills.

Huang made the remarks in comments on reports by several daily newspapers in Hong Kong that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) have been placed on red alert due to the escalating tension between Beijing and Washington over the mid-air collision.

Noting that mainland forces have shown no signs of unusual movements over the past two days, Huang said the ROC military is fully monitoring the situation and the movements of the PLA. He asked the general public to be at ease and have confidence in the ROC forces.
He added that the ROC's own combat readiness drills have been conducted as usual and have not been affected by Sunday's incident.

The Hong Kong reports sparked new jitters in Taipei's stock market Wednesday, with the weighted price index shedding 40.97 points to close at 5,405.85. The Taipei stock market has tumbled a cumulative 7 percent over the last three days.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WARY OF POSSIBLE IMPACT OF COLLISION INCIDENT ON WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is warily watching whether the collision of a U.S. surveillance aircraft and a mainland Chinese fighter jet will affect Beijing's and Taipei's admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO), a senior official said Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the remarks during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Economic and Energy Affairs Committee on the ROC's WTO entry and protection of Taiwanese investments on the mainland.

Opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chou Hsi-wei asked Tsai at the meeting whether the forced landing of a U.S. spy plane on mainland China's Hainan Island after colliding with a mainland fighter over the South China Sea Sunday will delay Beijing's negotiations for its WTO accession terms and consequently hinder Taiwan's WTO entry.

According to a tacit understanding among WTO members, Taiwan and mainland China should be admitted to the organization simultaneously. Although Taiwan has long finalized all negotiations over entry terms, it has to wait for the mainland to complete its WTO trade concession talks and formalities.

Responding to Chou's question, Tsai said relevant ROC government agencies are still evaluating the possible repercussions of Sunday's collision and that it would be premature to make any judgment at present.
"Whether the incident will affect our WTO accession will depend on the developments in the U.S.-mainland China negotiations over relevant matters," Tsai explained.

The ROC's top mainland policy planner further said that information from mainland China shows that the Beijing authorities do not want to see further ramifications of the incident because they have many internal issues on hand and their main work agenda for 2001 focuses on economic and domestic reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TECO REP STRESSES CANADA AND TAIWAN'S COMMON VALUES

TEXT.P: Thomas Tung-pi Chen, new representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada, stressed Tuesday that Canada and Taiwan share the common values of freedom, democracy and human rights.

He told hundreds of Canadian guests and Chinese and Taiwanese community leaders that both countries have common concerns over peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region and have a common interest in promoting their bilateral trade and investment, Chen said.

During a reception welcoming Chen and his wife to Ottawa, the former scholar and lawyer noted that two-way trade between Canada and Taiwan now exceeds C$6 billion (about US$3.8 billion) a year, adding that more than 150,000 people from Taiwan visit Canada and tens of thousands of Taiwan immigrants bring billions of dollars into Canada each year.
Taiwan is Canada's eighth largest trading partner, he said, emphasizing the central role his office will play in promoting bilateral relations between Canada and Taiwan.

He said that both Taiwan and Canada are his home countries, noting that he was born and raised and received his education up until university in Taiwan and later earned his master's and doctoral degrees in the U.S. before coming to Canada to launch his professional career. He retired from Queen's University, Ontario, and remains a professor emeritus of the prestigious Canadian university.

Chen urged Canadian and overseas Chinese and Taiwanese friends to help him promote bilateral relations between Canada and Taiwan. Among those welcoming him were three members of Canada's Parliament who had graduated from Queen's University Law School, including his one-time student and partner Derek Lee of the Liberal Party.
