Dozens of members of the House of Commons and the Senate, along with leaders from think tanks, business institutions and local universities, and members of the diplomatic corps, applauded when he said his appointment as Taiwan's top representative in Canada was due to Taiwan's democratization.

John McKay, chair of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Association, lauded Taiwan's democratization, calling last year's first-ever peaceful change of government in China's or Taiwan's 3,000-year history as an "enormous accomplishment" that his association is very proud of.
He said that Taiwan's example demonstrates that the transformation of an Asian country from a single-party to multi-party government "can be done."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 100 MEMBERS OF U.S. CONGRESS CALL FOR AEGIS SALE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: More than 100 members of Congress on Tuesday called on the Bush administration to support the sale of destroyers equipped with the advanced Aegis combat system to Taiwan.

In two similar letters sent to President George W. Bush, 83 House members and 20 senators said: "We strongly support and recommend that your administration recognize the legitimate need for Taiwan to acquire the Arleigh Burke Aegis destroyers".
The letters were sent at a critical juncture in U.S. relations with mainland China, although the timing is coincidental. The drafts have been circulated on Capitol Hill in the past few weeks.

Meanwhile, Secretary of State Colin Powell said he did not think the current standoff with Beijing over the fate of a U.S. surveillance plane and its crew should be linked to considerations of arms sales to Taiwan.
The arms sales question, he told reporters, is examined "in the context of our obligations to Taiwan under the policies we followed with respect to Taiwan and their defensive needs."
"So I would like to keep the two issues separate," Powell added.
However, some members of Congress and their aides said they believe that Beijing's handling of the spy plane incident will have an impact on the arms sales debate.

"This is a serious event in Sino-American relations and may be a very important negative event in our relationship," said Rep. Doug Bereuter (R-Neb.), a member the House Select Committee on Intelligence and former chairman of the House Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific.
"The requested sale of Aegis-class destroyers becomes more likely" as Beijing continues to hold the 24-member crew of the U.S. SP-3 surveillance plane, he said.

Beijing has so far refused a repeated U.S. demand for the release of the crew members and the aircraft after the plane collided with a Chinese fighter jet and made an emergency landing on the island of Hainan on April 1.
The letters were drafted by Rep. Christopher Cox (R-Calif.), Taiwan-born Rep. David Wu (D-Ore), and Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC).

Beijing has warned the United States not to approve the sale and has indicated that any such transfer would cause "serious problems" for the bilateral relationship. The administration is expected to make a decision later this month.
Taiwan is believed to have asked to purchase four Aegis-class destroyers from the United States at an estimated cost of around $1 billion each.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.079 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 32.979.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 32.889 and was traded between 32.889 and 32.995.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$378 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGED TO SEEK PARITY BETWEEN POWER AND ABILITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was urged Wednesday by former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Shih Ming-teh to "move fast" to allow parity between his powers and his ability.
The outspoken politician urged Chen not to wait until the year-end elections but accelerate his efforts to find a balance between his ability and his power as president "before it's too late."

Shih, currently an independent legislator, said that if Chen were wise and shrewd enough, he should have taken advantage of a favorable situation upon his election victory last March to reshape the Republic of China's political landscape by forming a coalition government.

Shih lamented that the situation in Taiwan since Chen was sworn in as the new ROC president last May shows that he lacks wisdom and judgment as a national leader, resulting in the continual defeat that his administration now faces.
He added that Taiwan is now mired in a crisis of "no ideals and no passion," a situation resulting from the fact that no one is playing his or her own role correctly.

In an interview with a local radio channel, Shih said that in today's Taiwan, the ruling party is not acting like a ruling party, while the opposition parties are not doing an efficient job as a balancing force. "Even now, we have yet to see the president acting like a president," Shih noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WORKERS PAID 3.5 TIMES MORE THAN MAINLAND CHINESE COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan workers in the industrial and service sectors earned an average annual income of NT$502,488 in 2000, 3.5 times that of the average NT$147,390 for mainland Chinese workers, according to the results of a recent survey.

Against this backdrop, an increasing number of ranking Taiwan officials in mainland-based Taiwan-funded companies are being replaced by their mainland Chinese counterparts, according to the survey jointly carried out by the Taiwan-based ctcareer.com and the mainland-based chinahr.com.
However, demand for qualified business management personnel is still high in mainland China, as a result of an insufficient supply of locally trained talent, the survey found.

Amid rising unemployment in Taiwan, mainland China has become the major outlet for Taiwan jobless people to seek a new lease of life. Average incomes in Shenzhen, Shanghai and Guangzhou are the three highest compared with other major cities in the mainland.

In terms of occupations, business management experts, stock analysts, telecommunications engineers and salesmen are the best paid professionals in mainland China, with an average annual income of between NT$197,280 and NT$168,000, according to the poll.

In Taiwan, business management personnel are also the top salary earners, with an average annual income of NT$698,076. Telecommunications engineers, financial analysts and accountants, salesmen, and computer researchers and developers followed, with an annual average incomes ranging from NT$638,000 to NT$566,000.

The survey also discovered that the average personal income for male workers in mainland China is 1.14 times that of their female co-workers, while the gap in Taiwan is 1.3 times, with the manufacturing sector posting the largest imbalance of 1.5 times.

According to the website chinahr.com, mainland Chinese female employees are usually more satisfied with their salaries than their male colleagues, while according to career.com, most Taiwan career women contend that their capacities are not fairly judged in the workplace, with 45 percent of them saying that they do not like their current jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES OIL PRICE REDUCTIONS

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced Wednesday an average 2.57 percent reduction of its prices, effective Thursday.
The spokesman said the lower prices are in response to a fall in international crude oil prices.

He said that despite the fact that Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) had begun reducing their daily production by one million barrels, it has not caused a sharp increase in international oil prices, mainly due to the decrease of demand for heating oil with the coming of spring.
The new CPC prices are as follows:
-- 95 octane unleaded gasoline, NT$20 (US$0.61) per liter;
-- 92 octane unleaded gasoline, NT$18.9 per liter;
-- Premium diesel, NT$14.3 per liter; and
-- Ordinary diesel, NT$13.1 per liter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS `CHILD PAINTERS' ON CHILDREN'S DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian encouraged local children Wednesday to love nature, learn from nature and dedicate themselves to environmental protection.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with the winners of a children's painting contest aimed at promoting the establishment of greener, cleaner communities around the island.
As April 4 is Children's Day in Taiwan, Chen took advantage of the occasion to wish local youngsters a happy festival.
The president said he was impressed by many of the prize-winning paintings, which featured the beautiful landscapes their young creators yearn to live in.
Chen encouraged local schoolchildren to serve as "green angels" or seed members of a work force that could make their communities into "green pastures."
Noting that nature can teach just like a book, Chen also encouraged youngsters to learn from nature, particularly the basic principles of maintaining a balanced environment.

"When nature loses its balance, natural disasters or calamities will follow. Therefore, we should seek balanced development in our daily lives, as well as in our social and economic development," he explained.
Also present at the meeting were the parents of the prize-winning children and Hao Lung-pin, director-general of the Environmental Protection Administration.
Meanwhile, the Presidential Office opened its doors to the young children of its staff members Wednesday as part of the Children's Day celebrations.

Many of the youngsters showed great curiosity about the interior design and decoration of the Presidential Office. They also showed keen interest in Chen himself, seizing every opportunity to shake hands, chat with him or take pictures of him.

From Friday, the Presidential Office will sponsor a series of exhibitions featuring unique cultural and folk art developments in various parts of the island. Hsinchu County, which hosts a large Hakka community, will take the lead in showcasing its grassroots cultural achievements at the Presidential Office art gallery.
The Presidential Office is scheduled to host a news conference Friday to brief the press on its two-month folk arts and grassroots cultural exhibition program.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPES U.S.-MAINLAND CHINA DISPUTE CAN BE RESOLVED DIPLOMATICALLY

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Presidential Office said Wednesday that the Republic of China government hopes that Washington and Beijing will resolve the plane collision dispute through diplomatic channels.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the Presidential Office, said that Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen made an oral report on the accident to President Chen Shui-bian at a breakfast meeting earlier in the day.
Yu quoted Wu as saying he believed that the mid-air collision was an accident and should not affect U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.

In addition to Wu and Yu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and Chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Tsai Ing-wen were also invited to the breakfast meeting, which focused on the accident and its ramifications.
Yu said that Chen did not comment on Wu's report.

Concerning local media reports that the ROC government had offered information to the United States regarding the collision between a Beijing jet fighter and a U.S. spy plane, Yu said that the information, gathered from radar detection, confirmed the U.S. findings.
Yu also admitted that the accident has already had an impact on cross-Taiwan Strait stability and the peace of the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDIA URGED TO TAKE UP MISSION FOR A BETTER SOCIETY

TEXT.P: Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the largest charity organization in Taiwan, urged the media Wednesday to take on a more responsible mission and report on the "truth" and the "beauty" of society.
Master Cheng Yen made the appeal in a forum sponsored by the Central News Agency at the Taipei branch of the foundation.

CNA President Bill Wang, presiding over the forum, said that several incidents recently have shown "worrisome" phenomena in Taiwan's society, which some observers have attributed to an overabundance of "negative" news and the media's relentless or meticulous reporting on them.
He expressed the hope of striking a balance between the people's right to know and the interest of society, as well as more reports on the positive side of society.
National Chengchi University Professor Hsu Chia-shih and media leaders from various television, newspaper and broadcasting companies also attended the forum.
Master Cheng Yen urged everyone to "speak good words, do good deeds, walk a good path, and think with a good will," uniting together to push for society's "goodness."

She also said as the society relies a lot on the media, the media should report on the "truth" and "beauty" of society. She noted that there are many good people in society, so the media would have ample sources for its reporting.

She expressed the hope that the seed of love could be sown in the hearts of the people, citing the example of Tzu Chi members, who are all over the world, both responding to the natural disasters in India and El Salvador, and also the recent car accident involving Taiwanese students in the U.S. state of Texas.

She said that Tzu Chi members do good deeds voluntarily, and if there is a seed of love in the heart of everyone, it will grow and flourish and become an indomitable power. She said the sun in the Tzu Chi world is never setting.
Master Cheng Yen said that the media has its mission, just like Tzu Chi, and news reports should be "true" and display "beauty," which she said would lead others to the path of "goodness."
Several participants in the forum also echoed her views, saying that the media needs spiritual reform.

Liao Chun-chieh, vice president of Broadcasting Corporation of China, said that the media should take on the responsibility of educating the people, and journalists should report on the many touching stories in society.

Lin Chang-sung, vice president of China Television Company, also said that though Taiwan media has made great strides over the past years, progress has not been enough. Lin added that many media organizations have taken to reporting "porno news," adding that self-discipline among the media is an urgent task.
Hu Wang-ling of Formosa Television said that the media should try to report news in a professional way, showing the truth in various aspects and cutting "sensationalism" to a minimum.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAT'L SCIENCE COUNCIL REVEALS RESULTS OF STUDY INTO MEDICINAL PLANTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) announced Wednesday that its ongoing research has yielded significant results in the area of medicinal plants, including several anti-tumor varieties.

This was the first time that the results of the research have been formally made public since the NSC began a national agriculture biotechnology project three years ago in cooperation with the Council of Agriculture (COA) and Academia Sinica, the nation's highest academic institution.

According to the NSC, local companies have already expressed interest in 23 out of a total of 25 techniques developed during the project, which is expected to help establish Taiwan as a regional center of biotech industry research.

Tsai Hsin-sheng, a senior agronomist at the COA's Taiwan Agriculture Research Institute, said that his team's cooperative research into a particular variety of the orchid family has shown that extracts of Anoectochilus formosanus Hay. -- often taken in the form of a medicinal tea -- exhibit antioxidant, anti-fungal, anti-bacterial and anti-tumor characteristics.

He added that the same herbal extract is also able to improve diabetic conditions, lower blood sugar levels, prevent atherosclarosis and osteoporosis, and stimulate brain cell growth so as to prevent memory loss.
Tsai said that another medicinal plant, the protein-rich Chinese yam, is lethal to tumor cells, can prevent the growth of breast cancer cells, and is able to strengthen the body's immune system.

Meanwhile, Wu Jung-tsan, director of National Yang Ming University's Graduate Institute of Pharmacognosy Sciences, presented the results of his research into a particular species of dendrobium, another member of the orchid family.
Wu said that his research proved extracts of the species can stimulate liver cell growth and retinal epithelial cell growth, thereby leading to improved eyesight.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD MEETS WITH GRANDDAUGHTER OF ROC FOUNDER

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan met with Dr. Sun Shui-feng, granddaughter of Republic of China founder Dr. Sun Yat-sen, to discuss the "Three Principles of the People" Wednesday.

Upon meeting Lien, Sun immediately gave him a memorial book about her grandfather. The KMT head presented her in kind with a whole set of "Sun Wen's Theories" in a gesture to show the importance the KMT attaches to her grandfather.

Lien also stressed that when the "Three Principles of the People" -- the centerpiece of the "Sun Wen Theories" -- could be openly talked about in mainland China, it would be the right time for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to unite.

Asked about her feelings about a KMT advertisement featuring her grandfather prior to her meeting with Lien, Sun particularly praised one phrase in the advertisement and said that it is time for the 107-year-old political party to stand up on its feet and strive to recover from its past errors and defeats.
"Repentance will bring about incredible strength," she said.

The KMT became Taiwan's leading opposition party after losing the presidential race in March last year. Lien finished a distant third to the present President Chen Shui-bian and former Taiwan Governor James Soong.

Sun also paid a visit to the Legislative Yuan and called on Speaker Wang Jin-pyng. Sun's father -- Sun Fo -- served as the first legislative speaker after the KMT-led government moved to Taiwan from mainland China in 1949 at the end of a civil war against the Chinese Communists.

In that meeting, Sun lamented that the "Three Principles of the People" are no longer taught in Taiwanese schools and colleges. Wang gave her his personal appraisal of the national founder's political thoughts and told her that students in local colleges can still take optional courses in "Three Principles of the People."
Sun, who returned to Taiwan late last month for a visit, now resides in Hawaii.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT NOT TO PRESIDE OVER ANNUAL HANKUANG MILITARY DRILLS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will not preside over an upcoming tri-service military anti-landing exercise as part of the ongoing Hankuang No. 17 military drills in consideration of the sensitive times, military sources said Wednesday.
According to the military official, Chen was originally slated to oversee the exercise to be held in southern Taiwan April 20.

However, the official added that Chen and the General Staff Headquarters decided against the plan as a precaution against inadvertently escalating tensions in the Taiwan Strait, particularly in the wake of the mid-air collision of a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter, which has served to escalate tensions in the Asia Pacific region.
Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Cheng-hsiang will preside over the drill instead.

According to the Ministry of National Defense, this year's annual Hankuang exercises, which began last month with war game simulations and air superiority drills, are classified as a comprehensive combat readiness appraisal of the military's streamlining and modernization.

Meanwhile, an army general told reporters that live-fire testing will be conducted for the military's newly acquired vehicle-mounted Avenger and lightweight Dual Mount Stinger air-defense missiles at a military base in southern Taiwan as part of the Hankuang exercises.

U.S. Hawk missiles and locally produced Tien Kung missiles will also be fired to test the island's air defense capabilities, the general said, adding that the military's Patriot anti-missile systems will be tested separately.

According to air force officials, an air force F-16 jet fighter successfully test-fired a sea-skimming anti-ship Harpoon missile Tuesday in a combined drill with the navy as part of the Hankuang exercises.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES OIL PRICE REDUCTIONS, FPG FOLLOWS SUIT

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced Wednesday that the firm will cut its prices by an average 2.57 percent, effective Thursday.
The spokesman said the lower prices are in response to a fall in international crude oil prices.

He said that despite the fact that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) has reduced its daily production by one million barrels, there has been no corresponding increase in international oil prices, mainly due to the decrease in demand for heating oil with the coming of spring.
The new CPC prices are as follows:
-- 95 octane unleaded gasoline, NT$20 (US$0.61) per liter;
-- 92 octane unleaded gasoline, NT$18.9 per liter;
-- Premium diesel, NT$14.3 per liter;
-- Ordinary diesel, NT$13.1 per liter;
-- Low-sulphur (0.1 percent) fuel oil, NT$6,521 per liter;
-- Low-sulphur (0.5 percent) fuel oil, NT$7,052 per liter.

Following the CPC announcement of its price reductions, the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) said it will also cut prices of its 95 octane unleaded gasoline, 92 octane unleaded gasoline, premium diesel and low-sulphur (0.5 percent) fuel oil to the same level as the new CPC prices.
FPG's oil price cuts will also be effective Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA MEETS WITH PFP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama met with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in Taipei Wednesday to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.

Soong told reporters afterwards that the Dalai Lama mentioned during the talks that all political parties, despite their different views, should place the common welfare of society before partisan interests.
The PFP chief said that he welcomes the Dalai Lama's "religious trip" to Taiwan to give "spiritual encouragement" to the people of the island at a time when they are facing lots of problems.
Soong said that as a religious leader, the Dalai Lama has special views on peace and the future of Tibet.
The Dalai Lama reiterated during the talks that he is not pursuing independence for Tibet, according to Soong.
Soong said the exiled Tibetan leader questioned him about his opinions on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

He said he told the Dalai Lama that the PFP's policy is to uphold a middle-of-the-road policy and a reasonable attitude, as well as regarding the cross-strait issue as a competition between systems, rather than an argument between ethnic groups.
The Dalai Lama arrived in Taipei March 31 for a 10-day trip at the invitation of the Chinese Buddhist Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL PLAYS DOWN QIAN'S IDEA OF DIRECT LINKS

TEXT.P: Beijing Vice Premier Qian Qichen's proposal to form direct transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China was dismissed as "not constructive" by a Taiwan official Wednesday.

Shi Hwei-yow, secretary-general of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, made the remarks in response to Qian's suggestion that bilateral transportation links between the two sides be negotiated through private carriers interested in operating the shipping links. Shi said Qian's suggestion is just a ploy to deny Taiwan the parity it deserves.

Establishing transportation links, including direct flights and maritime shipping, is not "children's play," Shi said, adding that it should be negotiated in public rather than in secret and by authorized government agencies rather than private firms.
Officials of private firms, without a mandate from the government, could not conclude accords that would bind other people, let alone the authorities, Shi said.
He dismissed Qian's idea as nothing but part of Beijing's attempts to isolate the administration of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) by courting Taiwan's opposition parties.
It only indicates Beijing's reluctance to resume a dialogue with Taiwan, let alone establish contacts with the DPP administration, Shi said.

Shi made the comment after Qian reportedly told a group of Taiwan opposition legislators visiting Beijing Tuesday that if Taiwan is reluctant to commit to the "one China" principle, the island can conduct negotiations with Beijing on direct bilateral links through private firms.
In that way, Qian was quoted as saying, the two sides could open shipping links without defining them as either domestic or international.

The dispute blocking the establishment of the direct links stems from Beijing's insistence that Taiwan is a part of China and that the links should be defined as internal, a claim unacceptable to Taiwan.

Beijing has shut down all channels of communications with Taiwan authorities ever since former President Lee Teng-hui characterized the island's ties with mainland China as a "special state-to-state" relationship in July 1999.

The mainland has kept up its political boycott of the administration of Lee's successor, President Chen Shui-bian, claiming that he has backed away from the "one China" principle. According to Beijing, both sides committed to that principle in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTORTIONISTS TARGET 50-ODD CRAM SCHOOLS IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: More than 50 private cram schools in Taoyuan have reportedly become the targets of extortionists since two days ago, when a man threw a Molotov cocktail into a Taoyuan arithmetic school, killing two and wounding another 19.

Police received complaints from several supplementary school operators Wednesday that about 50 such educational centers in Taoyuan have received anonymous letters demanding payment of NT$50,000 (about US$1,538) to avoid being attacked by petrol bombs similar to the one that was thrown at Chiayin Mental Arithmetic School on Monday.
The letters instructed recipients to put the cash into specified bank accounts before April 10, or "someone will come forward to make trouble" -- meaning similar arson attacks.
The letter also demands NT$10,000 for each day delay in payment following April 10.
Police said they are working with financial institutions in an attempt to identify the owners of the bank accounts specified in the threatening letters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZULU KING VISITS TAINAN COUNTY HALL
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan County, southern Taiwan, April 4 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: South African Zulu tribe King Goodwill Zwelithini visited Tainan County Hall Wednesday to exchange views with officials there on issues of mutual concern.
Zwelithini was warmly welcomed by Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan upon his arrival.

Chen and Zwelithini exchanged views on both countries' political and economic climates. Chen said he hopes that South Africa will consider resuming a diplomatic relationship between the two countries.
Chen indicated that both Taiwan and South Africa have experienced the same situation -- a peaceful transfer of power after presidential elections followed by worsened political and economic climates.

Zwelithini said that although South Africa is now ruled by blacks, people's lives are not as good as before. The most important thing for the South African government to do is improve people's lives, he said.
Zwelithini added his hope that Taiwan businessmen will increase their investments in South Africa to stimulate the recovery of South African industry and commerce.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD LEAVING FOR U.S. TO ATTEND HIGH-TECH SEMINAR

TEXT.P: Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), is expected to leave Thursday for Los Angeles to attend the Taiwan-U.S. Scientific Technology Development Seminar.
Chen will deliver a keynote speech titled "The Challenge and Priority of the Knowledge-based Economic Development in Taiwan" at the seminar, which will close on Saturday.
Panel discussions on scientific technology development, aviation and national defense, Taiwan's economy, and environmental protection will be held during the three-day seminar.
Wu Rong-yi, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, will also attend the seminar. Chen is scheduled to return to Taiwan Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA LAUDS DEMOCRATIC ACHIEVEMENT OF ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The visiting Dalai Lama, spiritual leader of the Tibetans, lauded the democratic achievements of President Chen Shui-bian during an interview with a local cable television.
The Dalai Lama made the remarks on the eve of a high-profile meeting with President Chen.

Asked if he would prefer to serve as the Dalai Lama or be a common person -- if such a choice were available -- the Tibetan spiritual leader said he is most suited to spiritual activities, and he would choose to be the Dalai Lama without hesitation.
On the current sluggish economy and the rising suicide rates in Taiwan, he encouraged Taiwan people to have self-confidence and be optimistic.
The charismatic spiritual leader also said that he would return to Tibet during his lifetime.
The Dalai Lama arrived here last Saturday for a 10-day religious trip. During his stay, the charismatic leader has attracted a large following wherever he has gone.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT SAID TO SOUND OUT POSSIBILITY OF JAPANESE VISA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 4 (CNA) (By Mike Change & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui is reportedly to sound out the possibility of obtaining an entry visa from the Japanese government, the Nihon Keizai Shinbum reported Wednesday.
The former ROC head of state is scheduled to visit the United States at the end of April and plans to visit Japan on his way home in May, the paper said.

The Japanese daily said that Lee's main purpose in making the trip to Japan is to have his heart checked after an operation last year, and if every thing goes smoothly, Lee will be in Tokyo in early May. The Japanese government's reaction will become the focus of the issue, the Nihon Keizai said.
Officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Tokyo said that their office has not yet received any information about Lee's application for a Japanese entry visa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEEK SPONSORSHIP OF 2007 INTERNATIONAL SPORTS EVENT

TEXT.P: The National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) announced Wednesday that Taiwan will seek the sponsorship of the 2007 Universiade, an international multi-sport collegiate event that takes place every two years.

In 1998, Taiwan sought the sponsorship of this year's games but failed largely due to mainland Chinese intervention. Beijing abruptly applied for and won the rights to sponsor the games, and will be holding the 21st Universiade from Aug. 22 to Sept. 1.

The NCPFS instructed the Chinese Taipei University Sports Federation to provide a report by June on available facilities, financial preparations, events to be held and assessments of athletic ability.
The NCPFS will then submit a formal application for sponsorship next January.

According to the Brussels-based International Sports Federation, which organizes the Universiades, the events are open to competitors between the ages 17 and 28 who are university students or graduated from university within the year prior to the event.
Ten designated sports are featured at each Universiade, plus two to three optional sports to be designated by the host city.
Over 6,000 athletes from over 130 countries attended the 20th Universiade, held in Palma de Mallorca, Spain.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG HOPES TO BE 'LAST VICTIM OF POLITICAL PROSECUTION'

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), said Wednesday that he hopes he was the "last victim of political prosecution and suppression."

Soong made the remarks after the Taiwan Prosecutors' Office turned over new evidence of a financial deal involving Soong -- commonly known here as "The Chung Hsing Bills Finance Corp. scandal" -- to the Taipei Prosecutors' Office for further investigation.

Soong said that as far as he knows, the Taiwan Prosecutors' Office did not ask for a renewed probe into the case, but simply acted on the report of Chuang Po-lin, who was commissioned by the opposition Kuomintang to press the embezzlement charges against Soong in the first place.

Soong said he still remembers vividly the embezzlement charges against him during the heat of presidential campaign in early 2000. He said that they cost him the presidency because he was far ahead of other candidates before the charges came to light.
Soong said the case is a naked political smear campaign and added that the government is using a national machine to violate his human rights.

He noted that the Prosecutors Office of the Taipei District Court had dropped the charges, and said that Taiwan Prosecutors' Office confirmed Tuesday that it had closed the case because the KMT -- which originally pressed the charges -- decided against pursuing them.
But the decision to turn the case over to the district court after Chuang's so-called "fresh incidence" was an "unnecessary appendix," Soong said.
He said that he was willing to look forward, hoping that he will be the "last person" to undergo political prosecution and suppression.

Soong said that the district court has vindicated his innocence, but it will be hard for it to give back justice because the presidential election can not be held again. He added that many have said the scandal was the main cause of his loss in the presidential campaign.

The case arose from a huge amount of cash stashed in a secret bank account controlled by Soong. When the hidden bank account came to light during the peak of the presidential election, Soong, who ran in the race as an independent, claimed the funds were put in his charge by then-KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui to finance secret political operations.

Soong said he took charge of the funds while serving as the KMT secretary-general but had no chance to return them to Lee after the two fell out over Soong's insistence on joining the race for the presidency.
But Lee angrily denied this, denouncing it as "nonsense" and the KMT filed a complaint with the prosecutor's office against Soong for alleged embezzlement.

Soong claimed that he was framed by the KMT and called the complaint a smear campaign against him. He offered to give NT$248 million (US$US$7.51 million) back to the KMT and place it with the courts in escrow.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA PREACHES BUDDHA'S TEACHINGS

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama expounded on "The 37 Practices of a Bodhisattva" at suburban Taipei's Linkou Stadium Wednesday, saying that one should not harm other people for the sake of self interest.
He said that if a person has no intention of benefiting or respecting others, anything that person does will have negative consequences and lead to a bad outcome.
In the three preceding days, the Dalai Lama had explained the meaning of the Prajna Paramita (Heart Sutra) to the audience.
He changed the theme to the 37 practices of a Bodhisattva Wednesday, because the people want "to gain happiness, while departing pain."
He said that the 37 practices are in fact the way a Mahayana Bodhisattva must practice.

The exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, who arrived in Taipei March 31 for a 10-day visit, pointed out that a Bodhisattva should not care about his or her own interests only, but should strive for the benefit of all people.
Besides preaching the Buddha's teachings, the Dalai Lama's activities Wednesday included a meeting with People First Party Chairman James Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRCRAFT COLLISION WILL NOT AFFECT ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN: ROC EXPERT

TEXT.P: The collision of U.S. and mainland Chinese aircraft over the South China Sea might affect ties between those two countries but will have no bearing on Washington's arms sales to Taiwan, said a former Taiwan representative to Washington Wednesday.

However, Stephen Chen cautioned that if the dispute between Beijing and Washington is not resolved rapidly but instead drags on and deepens, it might have a negative impact on Taiwan's ties with mainland China.

The former diplomat, who now serves as a researcher at a Kuomintang think tank, cited as an example Washington's 1999 declaration of displeasure with then-Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui's surprise claim for Taiwan statehood in his engagement with Beijing, which did not influence the U.S. decision on arms sales to Taiwan.

Similarly, Chen said he believes the friction between Beijing and Washington over the collision between a mainland fighter jet and a U.S. reconnaissance plane will not impact Washington's pending decision on arms sales to Taiwan.

Branding the collision as an accident, Chen predicted that Beijing would not gain much from it in spite of Beijing's attempts to milk the issue for all its worth. He said there is no question of the issue escalating into war.
He said it is his belief that Washington will dispatch an envoy to Beijing to calm mainland Chinese outrage over the incident and resolve the dispute.
He urged the Taiwan authorities to keep a close eye on the dispute but to stay away from it and refrain from making any comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO SUBSIDIZE TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES TO CURB UNEMPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) plans to subsidize firms in domestic traditional industries as part of its policy to improve the island's deteriorating unemployment situation.

The CEPD subsidies will first go to employers in the traditional industries who hire unemployed laborers, and will be appropriated according to the number of new employees in the firms, said CEPD Vice Chairman Lee Kao-chao Wednesday.
The government will earmark about NT$900 million (US$28.12 million) for this purpose, Lee said.
Lee said the CEPD is now reviewing the results of various past measures to stimulate the island's traditional industries, and will put forth further related policies as necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The main opposition Kuomintang unveils partial list of candidates for year-end elections.
The China Times:
The United States expresses regret over mainland China's loss in the midair collision.
The United Daily News:
Washington, Beijing continue blaming each other for military aircraft collision.
The Liberty Times:
White House tells China no apology forthcoming.
The China Post:
U.S. rejects Beijing's apology demands.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. makes unrepentant stance official.
The Taipei Times:
Taiwan hopes arms not a victim in U.S.-China spat.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG URGES PFP LAWMAKERS VISITING M'LAND NOT TO BE USED
DOC.DATELINE: Tianjin, April 5 (CNA) (By Fang Hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from Taiwan's opposition People First Party (PFP) who are currently on a visit to mainland China were urged by PFP Chairman James Soong to be "careful" of not being used by Beijing regarding certain cross-strait issues.
In a telephone conversation with Soong, who is in Taipei, PFP Legislator Shen Chih-huei said Beijing has now softened its stance on the issue of direct links with Taiwan.

According to Shen, mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen, in a meeting with visiting PFP lawmakers in Beijing Tuesday, said that the "one China" term could be omitted from all bilateral transportation documents if Taiwan feels uncomfortable about it.

"If Taiwan wants to sidestep the thorny issue of `one China', the island should take its cue from the aviation negotiations between Taiwan and Hong Kong in 1996 and conduct talks with Beijing through private channels," Qian was quoted as having said.
"Government officials could still take part in the talks as executives of the private firms involved," Qian said.

PFP Legislator Liu Sung-fan, head of the visiting Taiwan group, said afterward that Qian's statement indicated a softening of Beijing's previous position that the "one China" principle must be a prerequisite to any talks on transportation links and that transportation between the two sides is a Chinese internal affair.

Commenting on this, PFP Chairman Soong reminded Shen and Liu and other PFP lawmakers, who proceeded to Tianjin from Beijing Wednesday, to be careful of not being used by Qian and other mainland Chinese authorities, at least not on the "one China" issue.

Soong told Shen over the phone that while Beijing seemed to be "softening" its stance on the "one China" issue over talks with the Taiwan legislators, Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency continued to stress in its Tuesday night reports that matters concerning the opening of direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait are "internal affairs."

On Wednesday, the PFP legislators visited the harbor in Tianjin, one of the biggest harbor cities in mainland China. They also visited an industrial processing zone located in the nearby Tanggu Port District and a manufacturing plant of the Dingxin Group, a Taiwan enterprise which operates one of the largest instant noodle businesses throughout mainland China.
The lawmakers are scheduled to proceed to Xian Thursday for a one-day visit before returning to Taiwan Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG STORES MUST APPLY TO SELL RU486: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) stressed Thursday that RU486, an abortion pill, will only be sold in drugstores that have first applied to do so and have received approval.

DOH officials said that in order to prevent the abuse of RU486, the DOH's National Bureau of Controlled Drugs has adopted the measure that calls for all operators and medical institutions that manufacture, import, export, sell or purchase RU486 to apply and get approval on a batch-by-batch basis.
Those who have received approval to sell RU486 will have to give a list of their selling conditions to local health authorities, the officials added.

As the selling of RU486 via the Internet has become rampant, with sellers using their mobile phones to sell the pills, the National Bureau of Controlled Drugs said it will occasionally monitor the Internet and report to police for help in investigating any irregularities. Telecommunication operators will also be asked to terminate services to violators.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 5, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents, is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea who refused to return to the Chinese mainland take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as U.S. chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded U.N. forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years earlier.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders U.S. Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung pays a visit to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party, to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SAYS U.S.-PRC STANDOFF WON'T INFLUENCE ARMS SALES TO ROC

TEXT.P: The White House made it clear Wednesday that President George W. Bush's final decision on U.S. arms sales to Taiwan will not be affected by the current Washington-Beijing standoff over the American surveillance plane and crew being held on mainland China's Hainan Island.

When asked if the four Arleigh Burke destroyers Taiwan wants will in any way be used as a bargaining chip in the current standoff, White House spokesman Ari Fleischer told a routine press briefing that "the ultimate decision the president makes will be based on his review of the defense needs of Taiwan."

The spokesman was also asked whether there was any indication during the recent visit to the United States by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen that Beijing may adopt a tougher line toward the United States. He responded by saying that Bush and Qian "focused on the cooperative and positive aspects" of the relationship between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE FOREIGN MINISTRY MUM ON POSSIBLE VISIT BY LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 5 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs kept mum Thursday on reports of former President Lee Teng-hui's sounding out the possibility of obtaining an entry visa from the Japanese government.

Japanese foreign affairs officials declined to make further comment on the possibility of Lee's visit to Japan, only saying that Japan's stance at present is "a blank sheet" -- meaning it has no stance, Japanese media reported Thursday.

On Lee's possible application for a visit to Japan, mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan on Wednesday reiterated Beijing's consistent opposition to such a visit during a talk with visiting Japanese Justice Minister Masahiko Komura in Beijing.
The Nihon Keizai Shinbum reported Wednesday that Lee is scheduled to visit the United States at the end of April and plans to visit Japan on his way home in May.

The Japanese daily said that Lee's main purpose in making the trip to Japan is to have his heart checked after an operation last year. The Japanese government's reaction will become the focus of the issue, the Nihon Keizai said.
Officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Tokyo said Wednesday that their office has not yet received any information about Lee's application for a Japanese entry visa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ILLUSTRATORS' WORKS ON DISPLAY AT BOLOGNA CHILDREN'S BOOKS FAIR
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 4 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: The works of six children's books illustrators from Taiwan are being displayed as masterpieces at the 2001 Bologna Children's Books Fair in Italy being held April 4-7.

The Republic of China's representative to Italy, Lin Chi-cheng, and his wife hosted a cocktail party Wednesday to congratulate the six Taiwan illustrators. Italian diplomatic officials and about 150 exhibitors from Europe, America and Asia also joined the celebration.
The six female illustrators being honored at the 36th Bologna Children's Books Fair are Wang Pao-chu, Chang Iou-jan, Pang Ya-wen, Min Yu-chen, Wu Yueh-o and Wang Mei-lin.
Taiwan's publishers have participated at the internationally renowned children's books fair since 1993 and have made remarkable displays each year.
Fifteen Taiwan publishers, including the Mandarin Daily News and the Hsin Yi Foundation, are also participating in the annual event in northern Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE MIGRANT WORKERS FEEL THE PINCH IN MAINLAND CHINA (I)

TEXT.P: They seem to belong to both sides, but in fact, they belong to neither. While working in mainland China, they often miss their families in Taiwan. When they are in Taiwan, they miss their careers on the mainland. The question they are most likely to encounter on either side -- "when will you return?" -- sums up the plight of Taiwanese migrant workers on the mainland.

The so-called Taiwanese migrants are mainly management staff working in Taiwan-funded companies in mainland China. The driving forces that lure Taiwanese executives to move across the Taiwan Strait lie in their desire to earn more money, seek a major career breakthrough, or even the opportunity to launch their own business ventures someday.

However, in reality, it's no easy thing to be a Taiwanese worker in mainland China. As the country transforms into a world-class manufacturing base with a vast potential market, it has attracted not only capital but also talent from around the globe.

Taiwanese migrant workers tend to find out quickly that the international competition they face in Shanghai is no less than that of Taipei. Worse yet, they also face the threat of being replaced by increasingly competent mainland workers. And if they falter on the mainland and return to Taiwan, they face equally gloomy job prospects.

In the meantime, the gap between salaries for management staff posted on the mainland and their Taiwan-based counterparts is gradually narrowing. Six years ago, a mainland-resident management executive was paid double the salary of a manager of the same ranking back in Taiwan. But now the ratio has shrunk to between 1.2 times and 1.6 times.

Even though migrant management executives are usually better paid on the mainland, they still find it difficult to save money as homesickness and nostalgia often prompt them to lead gregarious, extravagant lives there.

As for finding fresh business opportunities to make big sums of money, it often turns out to be a pipe dream. The chief of a Taiwan-financed electronics factory in the Kunshan industrial zone near Shanghai recalled that he had the idea of launching his own business when he first arrived on the mainland.

"However, the longer I stay here, the more cautious I become. Running a business in mainland China is not as easy as many people imagine. In Taiwan, you can use US$1 to do business worth US$3. In contrast, you can do only US$1 worth of business in the mainland for every US$3 of capital. That's because unexpected risk costs and overhead are very high here," he explained.

According to this executive, Taiwan-funded companies are losing their edge in management and technology. "Their survival on the mainland mainly relies on their capacity to raise capital and receive orders fostered over the years in Taiwan, and this ability cannot be forged solely by the efforts of an individual staff member," he noted.

As a result, most Taiwanese migrant workers have complicated feelings about their mainland career lives. On the one hand, they have to become more down to earth and minimize their career ambitions, and on the other they must cope with the crisis of being replaced by equally qualified mainland competitors willing to work for less salary.

Chen Chih-yung, a senior adviser with Taipei-based Polaris Securities Co., who often lectures on the mainland, said that for Taiwanese who choose to work on the other side of the Taiwan Strait, "mainlandization" is not a goal. "Their choice just marks the first step to place themselves in the ever more competitive global talent market," he observed. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE MIGRANT WORKERS (II)

TEXT.P: Chen pointed out that mainland China presently most needs three kinds of professionals -- those who can assist it in the process of globalization, management and marketing specialists for high-tech ventures, and management experts with rich experience in various service industries.
In his view, Chen said, Taiwanese migrant workers should endeavor to enter these professions to reduce the possibility of losing their mainland jobs.

Moreover, Chen said Taiwanese who want to work on the mainland must be capable of learning new knowledge, expertise or technology on the Internet because information remains limited in many mainland areas.

In the face of competition from foreign and mainland skilled workers, Taiwanese professionals still enjoy certain advantages as they can speak Mandarin Chinese and can easily integrate themselves into the mainland market.

A Taiwanese management executive attending a doctoral program at a university in Beijing said migrant workers from Taiwan can use their leisure time to pursue advanced studies at selected mainland universities or graduate schools.

"By so doing, you can more quickly familiarize yourself with the general mainland lifestyle and social customs. Moreover, you'll have a better chance of developing human connections in mainland society," said the executive with a Taiwan-funded electronics firm in Beijing, identifying himself as Mr. Chu.
Chu said Taiwanese migrant workers, like traditional local businesses, should think of themselves as an integral part of the global division of labor and capital flow system.

"Keep this in mind, then you can make your mainland working experience a plus for your career and free yourselves from the quagmire of being denied jobs on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chu added.

The most common feeling shared by Taiwanese migrant workers is that they must "stand ready to work around the clock." For them, work and life are the same thing. Consequently, they usually opt to return to Taiwan on holidays.

The chief manager of the liaison office of a Taiwan securities firm in Shanghai recalled that when he began to work there, he had a beautiful plan to visit all the major tourist attractions in neighboring mainland provinces.

"However, after two years of working here, I have come to find that the most familiar landscape I have seen is the scenery along the road from my office to the Shanghai airport," he said with a lonely smile.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIPEI DECLARATION' TO BE INCLUDED IN U.N. ARCHIVE

TEXT.P: The "Peace Declaration" made and endorsed by the 2001 World Citizens Assembly (WCA) in Taipei earlier this week will be presented to the United Nations for inclusion in the U.N. archive, Taiwan organizers of WCA activities said Thursday.

A copy of the "Peace Declaration," which mainly espouses an end to nuclear threats and global peace, will be presented to the U.N. headquarters in New York April 13 by Dr. Rashmi Mayur, director of the International Institute for Sustainable Future and one of the four WCA 2001 Commission chairpersons who jointly endorsed the "Taipei Declaration."

It will be the first time that a document expressing Taiwan people's voices for peace to be included in the U.N. archive since the Republic of China on Taiwan was expelled from the United Nations in 1971, the event organizers said.
The WCA, a non-governmental organization affiliated with the United Nations, was established 26 years ago in San Francisco and dedicated to promoting world peace.

After the WCA's three-day meeting in Taipei, the first of its kind ever held in Taiwan, four WCA representatives -- WCA Chairman Douglas Mattern, Dr. Charles Mercieca, executive vice president of the International Association of Educators for World Peace, an NGO organization under the UN, Dr. Hong Tao-tze, president of Tai Ji Men Qigong Academy in Taipei and Dr. Rashmi Mayur -- jointly endorsed the declaration.
According to the declaration, one year into the new millennium, the threat of nuclear war remains a terrifying possibility and the militarization of space threatens to ignite a new nuclear arms race.
The full text of the declaration follows:
"Whereas, a peaceful sound has not been received in every corner of the world into everyone's heart; and

Whereas, through globalization, a widening division between rich and poor has been created, with 20 percent of the world's population owning more than 80 percent of the world's wealth and the same rich 20 percent consume 80 percent of the world's resources; and

Whereas, scientific studies indicate that the present depletion of the world's resources and climate warming have imperiled the ecological system, biodiversity and many corporations, along with the weapons industry, have produced unlimited toxic waste which exterminated countless thousands of species and imperiled the entire life system of the planet;

Therefore, be it resolved that it is imperative to abolish all nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction and the sale of weapons for profit. The survival of the human race depends on eliminating the war system with its economic, cultural and political implications. Future conflicts among peoples must be settled within the peaceful framework of international law,

Be it further resolved that globalization must be democratic to benefit all people, leading to the eradication of poverty and ending the mass destruction of the world's resources, and not allowing our technologies to out distance our humanity.

Be it further resolved that the United Nations must be supported by both governments and people and be made more democratic and representative including a People's Assembly to provide moral and spiritual values alongside the General Assembly of nations. Furthermore, the Security Council needs to be restructured so as not to allow any nation to make the world hostage through its present veto power, and become the institution that provides security to all the people of the world.

Be it further resolved that to overcome the culture of war that ravaged the 20th century, we must create a new culture of peace as specified by the United Nations 53rd Session of the General Assembly, and its plan of action. This could be the foundation of a new civilization based on respect toward all life, with peace in our hearts and love of the world, with better communication among human beings, through cultural exchange programs, through peace education, and where human progress is measured not merely in economic gain, but through compassion and caring for others.

Be it further resolved that as responsible citizens of the world, we call up all peoples, all governments, international institutions and the United Nations to achieve these goals during the first decade of the new millennium."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HOLDS AMIABLE TALKS WITH DALAI LAMA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian held amiable talks with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, in a landmark encounter at the Presidential Office Thursday.

President Chen and the Dalai Lama chatted like old friends, with the Dalai Lama dressed in a maroon robe and sandals and President Chen wearing a long white silk scarf called "hada" -- a gift from the visiting Tibetan spiritual leader.

Chen, a stalwart from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said he appreciates the Dalai Lama's consistent support for his position that Taiwan's future should be determined by the people of Taiwan.

Chen, who assumed office last May in the Republic of China's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties, also thanked the Dalai Lama for sending a large delegation of the Tibetan government-in-exile to attend his inauguration.
The human rights lawyer-turned-politician lauded the Dalai Lama for his long pursuit of freedom and democracy for his communist Chinese-ruled Himalayan homeland.

"I know you have endured extreme hardship over the past five decades for striving for Tibet's freedom and democracy, and I deeply admire your fortitude and perseverance in facing the tall order," Chen told his guest.

For his part, the Dalai Lama said democratization is Taiwan's greatest achievement. In his view, the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize winner said peace and reason are critical to both political and economic development.

The Dalai Lama praised Chen for his efforts to uphold justice and impartiality in his governance of Taiwan. He further said he has always followed the principles of fairness and reason in handling Tibetan affairs.

"And when I encounter difficulties, I face them with compassion and wisdom," the Dalai Lama said, adding he finds that President Chen has done well in this regard and has managed to place the top priority on overall national interest and the common well-being of the people of Taiwan.
Touching on Tibetan affairs, the Dalai Lama said that as the world is changing, the views of mainland Chinese leaders should change along with the global trends.
The Dalai Lama has gone into exile since a failed uprising in Tibet in 1959, and Beijing has so far rejected the Tibetan spiritual leader's demand for greater autonomy for Tibet.
During his talks with President Chen, the Dalai Lama said optimistically that the world's concern for Tibet make him hopeful about the future of his homeland.
The Dalai Lama also reaffirmed his belief in democracy, saying he hopes the Tibetan government-in-exile in the northern Indian city of Dharamsala can develop a solid democratic system.

In his view, the Dalai Lama said all Cabinet ministers of the Tibetan government-in-exile should all be elected by Tibetan people in order to gain their trust and support. The Dalai Lama himself already announced in 1992 he will no longer assume any political duties and will dedicate himself to religious and charity missions.

Turning to an appeal by local Buddhist nuns for gender equality, the Dalai Lama told President Chen that he personally cannot resolve the issue. "It should be discussed by all nuns and monks," he said, adding that he thinks Taiwan can sponsor an international Buddhist meeting on the issue.
At the end of their hour-long talks, Chen said he hopes to meet with the Dalai Lama again during the Tibetan spiritual leader's stay in Taiwan.

The Dalai Lama arrived at the Presidential Office at 8 a.m. on the traditional Chinese Tombsweeping Day -- a time to remember deceased ancestors -- in an effort to tone down the sensitivity of his meeting with President Chen. The Tibetan spiritual leader and Chen rank high on Beijing's list of distrusted leaders. Beijing has been watching for signs that the two would team up against it.
The Dalai Lama has stressed that his current 10-day visit to Taiwan is purely religious in nature. He made his first trip to the island in 1997.
During their pleasant meeting, Chen presented the Dalai Lama a copy of his biography and a wooden Buddha sculpture as gifts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTS BUSH NOT TO GIVE IN TO PRESSURE FROM BEIJING

TEXT.P: Taiwan expects U.S. President George W. Bush to make good on his election promise to not give in to mainland China's pressure tactics, an adviser to President Chen Shui-bian visiting India said Thursday.

Professor Michael Hsiao, national policy adviser to the president of the Republic of China (ROC), made the comment while talking with the Hindustan Times about the Washington-Beijing standoff over the American surveillance plane and crew being held on mainland China's Hainan Island.

He said that Taiwan was closely watching the situation as the standoff has implications for the island, stressing that "we do not want the triangular relationship (among Washington, Beijing, and Taipei) to be confrontational."

"If China postpones sending the detained U.S. plane and its crew back, it will only jeopardize its relations with the United States. Besides, Beijing's candidature to host the 2008 Summer Olympics will be decided in a few months and any prolonged confrontation will not be helpful," he pointed out.
At the same time, delays will only make it easier for U.S. President Bush to make up his mind on selling defensive weapons to Taipei, Hsiao noted.

Meanwhile, the professor said that it would be in Bush's interest to hold on to his election promise of being more firm than former President Bill Clinton was with mainland China because he cannot afford to show any signs of weakness in the first few months of his presidency.

Speaking about mainland China-Taiwan relations, Hsiao said the President's Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations had recommended the enhancement of bilateral relations and the advocacy of a "One China" policy in line with the ROC's Constitution.

On India-Taiwan relations, the professor said that although the political relationship cannot be strengthened for obvious reasons, mainland China should not worry if the two countries develop stronger technical, business, academic, and cultural relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY PROTESTS WHITEWASHING BY JAPANESE HISTORY TEXT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Foreign Ministry has lodged a protest against Japan for adopting a middle school history textbook that include whitewashed accounts of the Japanese invasion of China and Taiwan, a ministry spokeswoman said Thursday.

Katharine S.Y. Chang, director-general of the ministry's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, said that the Foreign Ministry first expressed "concern" and "regret" toward the Japanese government in February when it decided to use the textbook.
"History must not be distorted," she added.
Written by right-wing academics, the contents of the textbook underwent some revisions after South Korea and mainland China also denounced Japan's decision to adopt it.

However, the revised textbook still contains passages justifying Japan's colonial past while excluding or minimizing its atrocities. It was once again approved for inclusion in Japan's middle school curriculum in a decision announced Tuesday.
Chang said that the Foreign Ministry immediately urged the Japanese government to rectify the textbook's content so as to avoid adverse repercussions on bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIDNAPPED TAIWANESE GARMENT DEALER RESCUED IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A female garment dealer from Taiwan, who was kidnapped in the southeastern mainland Chinese province of Fujian in early February, has been rescued by mainland police authorities, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Thursday.
According to CIB officials, the garment dealer, identified only by her family name Chu, was rescued in the Fujian port city of Xiamen late Wednesday night.
CIB agents said mainland police also arrested a Taiwan man identified as Chang She-chi, and two mainland Chinese men in Wednesday's operations on suspicion of their involvement in the abduction.

CIB agents said they offered tips to Xiamen police earlier this week on the place where Chu was kept hostage. Acting on the tips, the mainland police rescued Chu and arrested the three suspects responsible for monitoring her.
CIB officials said they have asked mainland police through the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation to repatriate both Chang She-chi and Chu, also a fugitive wanted by local courts.

Initial investigations showed that Chu, 45, owed some NT$9 million (US$272,727) to a pawn shop in Sanchung, Taipei County. She fled Taiwan to Hong Kong and Singapore, finally ending up in Fujian last year. She has been wanted in Taiwan since her creditor filed a fraud suit against her with the Taipei District Court last year.

In early February, Chu's creditor allegedly hired mainland criminals to break into her residence there and force her to repay her debt by holding her hostage. Chu's family in Taiwan then received a phone call from her creditor asking for quick debt repayment, and then lost contact with Chu. Chu's husband reported the kidnapping to both mainland and Taiwan police authorities Feb. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: PLEASE REPLACE PARAGRAPH 7 IN CEP ITEM 12 WITH THE

TEXT.P: Speaking about mainland China-Taiwan relations, Hsiao said the President's Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations had recommended enhancing bilateral relations, handling cross-Strait disputes, and responding to mainland China's advocacy of the "one China" policy according to the ROC Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-MAC CHIEF SEES GRIM PROSPECTS FOR RESUMPTION OF DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A former Republic of China official in charge of mainland China-related affairs said here Wednesday that he sees grim prospects for resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait this year.
Su Chi, who headed the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs council (MAC) during the Kuomintang government era, made the remarks in a speech delivered at American University.
Su said the ROC's current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government has failed to take any initiative to facilitate resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

As Taiwan is now troubled by serious economic doldrums and the DPP government' approval rating has plunged a record low level, Su said, he does not think that mainland China has any interest in resuming talks with Taiwan to help the DPP administration improve its poor operational records.
As to whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait could resume talks next year, Su said it will depend on the results of Taiwan's year-end elections for legislators and local government chiefs.
Su also criticized President Chen Shui-bian's plan to make large arms purchases this year.
"You can't consider arms procurement deals just from the viewpoints of military," Su said, hinting that Chen was not wise enough to come up a long arms shopping list this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIALS HONOR CHIANG KAI-SHEK

TEXT.P: Former Kuomintang (KMT) Central Committee Secretary-General John Chang Thursday paid homage to his grandfather former Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek on the 26th anniversary of the former president's death during a visit to Chiang's mausoleum in Tzuhu, Taoyuan County.

Chang was born out of wedlock as the son of Chiang Ching-kuo, who died in 1988 while serving his second term as president of the Republic of China. In response to press queries, Chang said he does not insist on changing his family name to Chiang, but merely wants his ID card to carry Chiang Ching-kuo's name as his father.
Chang later headed to Chiang Ching-kuo's resting place in Touliao in observance of the Tomb-Sweeping Day.
Others who paid homage to Chiang Kai-shek by visiting his mausoleum included former Premier Hao Pei-tsun, other KMT officials and supporters of the opposition New Party.

The anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek falls on Taiwan's traditional Tomb-Sweeping Day, when families clean their ancestors' graves and present offerings of meat, fruit and wine in front of the tombs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN AIRLINES-SPONSORED DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Eyeing Taiwan's rife trade opportunities, a trade-promotion delegation sponsored by American Airlines is slated to pay a visit to Taiwan April 22-27.

In a code-sharing joint venture with the Taipei-based EVA Airways Corporation, American Airlines began operating one weekly Taipei-San Jose flight Tuesday with Boeing 777 airplanes connecting the two hi-tech strongholds.
The route will shorten travel time for the many Taiwan businessmen heading for the Silicon Valley and other American cities, such as Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Phoenix and New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER ANNOUNCES REASSIGNMENT OF VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Education Minister Ovid Tseng on Thursday announced that one of his vice ministers will be reassigned to a lower position as punishment for his part in a public verbal dispute with another vice minister.

Tseng said that Administrative Vice Minister Lin Chao-hsien's position will be "adjusted" because Lin had adversely affected the ministry's image and internal unity by lashing out at another vice minister in public, and that Lin has yet to clarify allegations aimed at his ownership of a piece of real estate in a possible case of conflict of interest.
The ministry is currently searching for a candidate to fill Lin's vacated post, Tseng added.
However, Lin announced later in the evening that he will not accept the lower post offered him and will instead submit a letter Monday expressing his wish to retire.
Lin explained that he does not believe in the need to return to a position he had already held in the past because it would not add to his personal growth and experiences.

Regarding another possibility of arranging for him to serve as a Cabinet adviser, Lin, 63, said that being an adviser is not his area of expertise, and that the position is perhaps best left for "younger people."

Meanwhile, political Vice Minister Fan Sun-lu was only verbally reprimanded for what Tseng said was a "disruption of internal harmony" for her public accusation that "certain education ministry officials" have formed special interest groups with "a certain private school."

Fan's allegation was an insinuation that Lin had financial involvement with the controversial Jin-Wen Institute of Technology Board of Directors case, in which it has been alleged that several legislators and organized crime figures have been involved in interest-peddling and collusion.
Fan's remarks led Lin to strike back, publicly calling her a "bossy amateur."

Adding to the entangled accusations surrounding the complicated case, Fan then criticized Lin for failing to avoid possible conflicts of interest by buying an expensive mansion in a development project tied to the private Jin-Wen school.
However, Lin explained that there was no issue of a possible conflict of interest when he bought the house, and that he had bought it after considering only whether he could afford it.

The Jin-Wen case had led to a scuffle in the legislature late last month in which one lawmaker attacked his female colleague for what he alleged was her accusation that he had ties to organized crime and was involved in the board of directors financial and power dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD MAINTAIN LOW KEY AMID U.S.-MAINLAND CONFLICT: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan should maintain a low key amid the current tension between the United States and mainland China but take all necessary precautions for the possible consequences, Republic of China lawmakers said Thursday.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee, lawmaker Fan Yang-sheng said that maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait is the ROC government's top priority and that Taipei should pay close attention to subsequent developments following the mid-air collision between a U.S. surveillance airplane and a mainland Chinese fighter jet over the South China Sea.

As the Bush administration has adopted a tougher stance toward mainland China than its predecessor, Fan said mainland China has come under strong pressure from the United States. He predicted that Beijing is unlikely to act against Washington out of consideration of its huge trade surplus chalked up every year from the U.S. market.
"The possibility of a military conflict between the two countries is slim," he said.

According to the lawmaker, Beijing should have purposely sparked the tension between the two countries in the hope of using anti-war elements among the U.S. public to bring pressure to bear on Washington as a means of gaining more bargaining chips for the negotiating table.

Fan said although some people think that the Beijing-Washington spate would benefit Taiwan, he suggested that the government keep in mind that peace across the Taiwan Strait is the most important issue.
Echoing Fan's remarks, lawmaker Kuan Wo-nuan said that the incident seems to be an about-face.

Although Kuan contended that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is also facing an escalating pressure from the mainland Chinese people, he said Jiang has already made a noticeable compromise by allowing U.S. officials to meet the 24-member crew, who were detained by mainland Chinese authorities after their emergency landing on Hainan Island following the collision.

According to Kuan, it will be hard for Taiwan to benefit from the incident, because mainland China is likely to use the opportunity to attempt to force a Washington decision to stop selling arms to Taiwan.
"The whole matter could be a Beijing plot to prevent U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, " he noted.
Kuan urged President Chen Shui-bian to maintain a low profile but to take all necessary precautions, including placing the military on the first-level combat alert.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIANG CHING-KUO'S WOULD-BE ASSASSIN TO BE NAMED AMBASSADOR-AT-LARGE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will nominate a man who once tried to assassinate the late Taiwan strongman President Chiang Ching-kuo to serve as a Republic of China ambassador-at-large, according to a local newspaper report Thursday.
Huang Wen-hsiung is one of 12 nominees to serve as the island's envoys with no specified posting, said the China Times.

The paper quoted a Presidential Office official as saying that Wang was awarded the honor because of his association with various international human rights organizations. He is the most suitable person to speak out for the island, with the exception of well-known dissident writer Po Yang, also known as Kuo Yi-tong, who was not chosen due to his old age and poor health, the official added.
Huang was one of two would-be assassins who tried to kill then-Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo in 1970 at a Washington hotel when Chiang was there on an official visit.
Huang fired the only shot in the assassination attempt, which was unsuccessful. Huang and his accomplice were arrested at the time but jumped bail later and fled the United States.
He returned to Taiwan in 1996 after the statute of limitations on his charges had expired and was greeted as a hero by local pro-independence activists.
