Huang was not among the nine ambassador-at-large nominees initially suggested by the Foreign Ministry but President Chen added him to the list along with two others at the last minute.
The posts were introduced by former President Lee Teng-hui in the hope of tapping the talent and experience of the appointees to enhance the country's international profile.
Lee gave the positions to business magnate Jeffrey Koo, retired ambassador Loh I-cheng, and Chiu Hungdah, a well-known scholar of international law.

President Chen is expected to renominate both Koo and Loh. Chiu, who resigned in 1999 after President Lee deviated from the Guidelines for National Unification by claiming that the ties between Taiwan and mainland China were a special state-to-state relationship, was not on the list of new nominees.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LACKS NT$20 BILLION IN AGRICULTURAL AID FUNDS

TEXT.P: Coming under criticism from lawmakers, Council of Agricultural (COA) Chairman Chen Chih-huang admitted Thursday that the government lacks the NT$20 billion in funds allocated for agricultural subsidiaries after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Calling it a "serious matter," Chen said the COA needs to earmark a government fund of at least NT$30 billion to subsidize local farmers' losses in the first year following Taiwan's entry into the world trade regulatory body.

But due to government financial strain, Chen said the COA has up to now allocated only NT$14.1 billion for the fund. Meanwhile, COA officials are reserved about whether the COA would be able to earmark an additional NT$20 billion next year in order to reach the NT$30 billion threshold.

Several lawmakers from central and southern agricultural areas have voiced strong discontent about the situation, asking the COA to seek a solution as soon as possible. The agricultural sector is expected to be hit hard by competition from foreign imports after the country is admitted into the WTO.
The lawmakers warned the government of instability in rural areas should it fail to protect local farmers by handling the issue properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COMPLETES ITS FIRST GARDEN MAZE

TEXT.P: Taipei has completed its first large-scale garden maze and will open it to the public Saturday, the city's director of cultural affairs said Thursday.

Lung Ying-tai said that she and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will be leading all interested people on a bicycle ride through the city Saturday, and they will ride to the garden maze located in Hsin-sheng Park along the banks of a river.
"The garden maze is a little heaven that is full of infinite imagination, where children and their dreams can run free," she said.

The almost one-hectare labyrinth boasts 58,000 waist-high shrubs, and at the center are two trees planted by Ma and Nobel Laureate Gao Xingjian, Lung added. Construction of the maze began last November.
After making the announcement, Lung led a group of 20 children and their parents to be the first to explore the maze.
Lung invited would-be participants of the bicycle excursion to meet at 1:30 p.m Saturday at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall. The cycling tour takes off at 2 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHIEF TRAVELS TO U.S. FOR CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chen Po-chih left for Los Angeles Thursday to attend the "Taiwan-American conference on science and technology."
He will deliver a speech on Taiwan's plan to develop its knowledge-based economy at the conference and attend a press conference to explain the Taipei government's economic strategies.

Chen told reporters before his departure that he wants to enlist the cooperation and investment from American businessmen and Taiwan businessmen residing in the United States in the development of Taiwan's knowledge-based economy.

Talking about the increase in Taiwan's unemployment rate, the CEPD chief said that the government has begun taking various measures to create more job opportunities and to improve the abilities of Taiwanese workers.
He also encouraged industries that are strongly competitive to keep their roots in Taiwan so as to help sustain the island's economic development and to help reduce unemployment.

Chen cautioned that the rise in Taiwan's investment in mainland China could create problems, saying that Taiwan firms' accumulated investment in mainland China now accounts for two percent of the island's gross domestic product, about 20 times higher than U.S. and Japanese investment there.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA CALLS FOR CULTIVATION OF AWAKENED MIND

TEXT.P: Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama Thursday spoke of the importance of cultivating an "awakened mind," describing it as a way to gain happiness and part pain.

The Dalai Lama continued to preach the teachings of the Buddha at suburban Taipei's Linkou Stadium Thursday afternoon following his visit to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office earlier in the day.

He told the audience through an interpreter that he has brought no customary gifts to the people of Taiwan during the current trip, but he wants to share with them the study of the cultivation of an "awakened mind."
The Dalai Lama has been preaching the Buddha's teachings at Linkou Stadium since the second day of his arrival in Taiwan March 31.
His schedule for Friday will include a meeting with former President Lee Teng-hui.
The Dalai Lama will conclude his 10-day "religious trip" to Taiwan April 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD ACCUSED OF PULLING STRINGS BEHIND PROBE INTO POLITICAL FOE

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh was accused Thursday of pulling strings to force the re-opening of a judicial probe into alleged embezzlement by People First Party (PFP) leader James Soong.
Legislator Chiu Chuang-liang of the PFP claimed that the so-called "new evidence" put forward by lawyer Hsu Kuo-yung to prosecutors in a motion for a new probe was actually provided by Hsieh.
Chiu disputed Hsieh's claims that he doesn't know Hsu, saying that Hsu was Hsieh's supporter and financed his branch office in Taipei's Nangang district in 1992 while Hsieh served as a legislator.

In an interview with a local radio station, Chiu accused Hsieh of being the mastermind behind a ploy to alienate Soong's PFP from the major opposition Kuomintang and to dampen Soong' popularity during the run-up to the yearend legislative election.

He made the accusation after the Prosecutor's Office of Taiwan High Court confirmed Tuesday receiving new evidence from an unidentified source and referring it to a Taipei District Court prosecutor for review with an eye on re-opening the investigation into Soong.

Although the prosecutors didn't reveal who provided the new evidence, Chiu pointed his finger at Hsieh, claiming that it was a preemptive political move to prevent the PFP and Kuomintang from cooperating in the yearend election.

The controversy stemmed from a Kuomintang charge at the height of presidential election campaign in 1999, that Soong siphoned off huge amounts of cash from the party coffers while serving as its secretary-general.

A prosecutor assigned to probe Soong cleared him of the charges on January 20, 2001, and the Kuomintang waived its right to ask for a re-examination because it was trying to reconcile with Soong's PFP at the time.
The detente between the Kuomintang and PFP resulted in a common front made up of the two parties in the Legislative Yuan to force the DPP government to reverse its decision to scrap a nuclear plant.
Soong denounced the re-opening of the case as a political ploy with a judicial appearance Thursday, claiming that he is the victim of a dirty political maneuver.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT CRITICIZED FOR BEING 'UNGRATEFUL'

TEXT.P: A high-level National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) official on Thursday criticized former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui for "not knowing how to be grateful."
NTUH vice president Lin Fang-yu made the criticism in reaction to what he sees as Lee's inappropriate remarks about NTUH doctors' medical skills.
Lee has expressed many times in public that his heart disease was diagnosed and cured by Japanese doctors, writing off the NTUH doctors' contributions to his health.
Lin said Lee has also said he was not totally satisfied with the performance of the NTUH medical team.

Lin, who joined the medical team for Lee last year, slammed Lee for "lacking a grateful mind," being "unlike a Christian," and being "unfair to NTUH doctors and Dr. Lien Wen-pin, convener of Lee's medical team."
Lin said in a news media interview that he did not care whether his remarks would anger Lee, because "Lee Teng-hui really was wrong" this time.
Lin said that NTUH doctors invited Japanese doctors to Taiwan late last year for a joint cardiac catheter operation for Lee.

Lin said that in fact, Lee's heart disease was not very serious but the NTUH invited Japanese doctors to join the operation to be careful. Lin said that Lee gave high appreciation to the Japanese doctors while writing off NTUH doctors' contributions to his health. This gave the medical official the feeling that Lee judges things with a "Japanese style of thinking."

Meanwhile, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a Japanese newspaper, reported Thursday that Lee is sounding out the possibility of making a stopover in Japan for a medical examination after his planned trip to the United States in late April.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 6, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath, which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose goal was to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: U.S. naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing or injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester B. Pearson.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Beijing.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people onboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.
1998 Citicorp merges with Travelers Group Inc., becoming the largest corporation in the world in terms of assets. The new firm is worth more than US$70 billion.
1999: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie assures visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Shih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bien says that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them is to betray them."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFESSOR FROM JAPAN BECOMES NATURALIZED ROC CITIZEN

TEXT.P: A Japanese professor at National Chengchi University who said she loves Taiwan so much that she wanted to become a naturalized citizen of the Republic of China, finally had her wish granted recently.

Prof. Shizue Fugii, who has taught at Chengchi University's Department of Japanese Language and Literature for more than 20 years, said she is thrilled that she has finally been granted permanent residency by the ROC government after a five-year painstaking process in both Taiwan and Japan.
A daughter-in-law in Taiwan, Fugii said her official Chinese name now is Fu Chi-yi, phonetically similar to her Japanese surname.

Fugii, who came to Taiwan at the age of 25 to study history and later married a National Taiwan University (NTU) law professor, Hsu Chieh-lin, after obtaining her doctoral degree, vowed that she would "live and die" with Taiwan now that she is an ROC citizen.

She said she decided to apply to become a naturalized citizen of the ROC in 1996 at a time when people in Taiwan were jittery and eager to emigrate to a foreign country and there was an evident flight of capital after Beijing conducted live-ammunition and missile firing tests in the Taiwan Strait in an attempt to intimidate voters and influence the outcome of the ROC's presidential election.
The naturalization application process that took some five years to complete was bumpy and difficult, she said.

According to ROC law, she first had to give up her Japanese citizenship before applying to become an ROC citizen. Her efforts to give up her Japanese citizenship hit a snag in 1997 when the Japanese government refused to take up the application on the grounds that Japan maintains no formal diplomatic relations with the ROC on Taiwan.

With her application efforts in Japan thwarted, she turned to the ROC authorities. Working with her husband, whom was then the dean of the NTU College of Law, she managed to influence legislators who passed an amendment to the ROC nationality and naturalization law.

By early 2000, the Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the related statutes, enabling individuals, like Fugii, who have suffered "uncorrectable" factors preventing them from forsaking their original citizenship, to be naturalized as ROC citizens.

A historian known for her research in the history of Taiwan during the period of Japanese colonial rule, in modern historical relations between Japan and China, as well as in Asian women's history, the 52-year-old Fugii strongly criticized the comic book "On Taiwan," authored by Japanese right-wing cartoonist Yoshinori Kobayashi, for the book's inaccurate accounts concerning the people of Taiwan.

Only recently, she joined other Taiwan academics in signing an appeal calling for the Japanese government not to condone the tampering with and falsifying of historical facts by educational authorities of textbooks to be published and used for the 2002 academic year.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTED LUXURY CAR SALES NOT AFFECTED BY COOLING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Sales of imported luxury cars in Taiwan appeared unaffected by the island's slumping automobile market over the first quarter of this year.

Despite the slowdown in the Taiwan economy over the first three months of 2001, sales of Germany's Mercedes-Benz automobiles showed no signs of decline, maintaining a level comparable to that for the same period the previous year.

Meanwhile, Toyota's Corolla, an upgraded four-door sedan that has been promoted in Taiwan by the Hotai Motor Co., Ltd. since last month, topped the sales list of locally manufactured cars with nearly 6,000 orders in some 20 days as other Taiwan-manufactured automobiles struggled over the impact of the cooling economy.
Hotai officials predicted fierce competition among other car manufactures if the hot sales of the Toyota Corolla do not trigger sales of other similarly priced automobiles.
Market sources said that the drop in sales of Taiwan-manufactured cars and booming imported luxury sedan sales indicate a growing gap between rich and poor in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS NOT HEIGHTEN COMBAT ALERT OVER 'COLLISION' INCIDENT: MND

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said Friday the Republic of China military has not heightened its combat alert after a midair collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland Chinese fighter in the South China Sea last Sunday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan plenary session, Wu said the ROC armed forces have maintained its original combat readiness in the wake of the U.S.-mainland Chinese military aircraft collision.

Wu also denied a newspaper report that President Chen Shui-bian has canceled his plan to review the ongoing Hankuang No. 17 combined services military training exercise simply because of the "collision" incident.

"The report was incorrect," the minister said, adding that the military has not arranged for President Chen to attend the current training exercise in the first place. "The president's absence from the military training drill has nothing to do with the 'collision' incident," Wu stressed.

He further explained that the annual Hankuang exercise covers two stages -- live-fire training drills by various military units at their bases and cyberwar games to be held in Taipei later this month.
Wu said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has directed relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of National Defense (MND), to keep a close watch on the developments in the "collision" incident.
"We are hopeful that the United States and mainland China can properly resolve the 'collision' issue in accordance with the general international regulations and practices," the minister noted.

Asked whether similar incidents could happen in the sky of the Taiwan Strait, Wu said the military has ordered all ROC air force pilots to refrain from taking any provocative actions while performing their flight duties.
Wu also said the ROC government has not held any special military meeting in the wake of the U.S.-mainland Chinese military aircraft collision incident.

Market turnover amounted to NT$82.98 billion (US$2.53 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNAN MEETS WITH DRUG GIANTS TO PLAN STEPS AGAINST HIV/AIDS

TEXT.P: U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan on Thursday met in Amsterdam with representatives from six of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies to discuss what further steps need to be taken to improve access to better health care, HIV medicines and HIV-related medicines for developing countries.

According to a joint press release by the United Nations and the World Health Organization, Annan met with CEOs and senior executives from Abbott Laboratories, Boehringer Ingelheim, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Glaxo Smith Kline, Hoffman-La Roche, and Pfizer.
The meeting was also attended by Gro Harlem Brundtland, director-general of WHO, and Peter Piot, executive director of the joint U.N. Programme on HIV/AIDS.

The companies have made significant progress individually in providing an expanded number of drugs to combat AIDS, including antiretrovirals and treatments for opportunistic infections. Prices have also come down substantially as a result of the companies' individual actions. Annan urged the companies at the meeting to continue and accelerate these actions.
Special emphasis was placed on the world's least developed countries, particularly those in Africa, as well as on the need for continued country-by-country negotiations in other developing countries.

All those attending the meeting recognized that qualified non-governmental organizations and appropriate private companies offering health care to employees and local communities in these nations should also be considered for increased accessibility to HIV/AIDS medicines.

"We need to combine incentive for research with access to medication for the poor," Annan said in a statement released the same day, adding that intellectual property protection is key to bringing forward new medicines, vaccines and diagnostics urgently needed by the world's poorest people.
He called for a major mobilization of political will and significant additional funding to enable a dramatic leap forward in prevention, education, care and treatment of HIV and AIDS.

In a number of countries, decades of development are being reversed by the effects of HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Some 36.1 million people are living with HIV or AIDS worldwide, with 5.3 million being infected during 2000 alone. Also in 2000, 3 million people died of AIDS, bringing the total number of deaths since the start of the epidemic to 21.8 million.

The spread of the epidemic and its devastating impact on humanity has alarmed the United Nations and prompted it to convene a Special Session of the General Assembly on HIV/AIDS at the highest political level, to be held June 25-27 in New York City.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOV'T EXPRESSES CONDOLENCES TO MISSING CHINESE PILOT'S FAMILY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top envoy to Canada said Thursday that the ROC government would like to express its condolences to the family of missing Chinese pilot Wang Wei whose jet fighter went down after a collision with a U.S. surveillance plane Sunday.
Thomas T.P. Chen, who recently assumed the post of representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, Canada, also expressed his home government's regret over the unhappy incident.

During a live interview with the Canadian Broadcasting Corp., Chen urged both sides to resolve the situation quickly by diplomatic means as a prolonged standoff could have a major impact on peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region.
He added that Taipei hopes, and expects, that the mid-air collision will not affect the U.S. plan to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan.

On the root cause of the incident, Chen said Beijing has been boosting its military power aggressively and intimidating Taiwan verbally and militarily. This kind of behavior has affected peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific, prompting the U.S. to beef up surveillance in the area, he noted.
Therefore, he said, the best solution would be for mainland China to stop its threats of an armed attack against Taiwan.

On cross-straits relations, he repeated President Chen Shui-bian's statements that the ROC government is willing to talk with Beijing on any topic, including trade, cultural exchanges and even political integration, if Beijing does not set any pre-conditions for such talks and stops its threatening strategy.

Beijing has insisted it will enter into negotiations with Taipei only if the latter agrees to the so-called "one China" principle. Beijing has also insisted on its right to use military force to settle its dispute with Taipei if the latter delays talks indefinitely.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MP URGES GOV'T TO CONDEMN BEIJING FOR SUPPRESSING BELIEVERS

TEXT.P: Scott Reid, a Canadian Alliance federal legislator from Ontario, urged his government Thursday to co-sponsor a United Nations resolution that would censure Communist China for its human rights abuses.
"Canada must join the growing international community in condemning China for its treatment of Falun Gong practitioners, Tibetan Buddhists and Christians," Reid said.

During a press conference, Reid cited the case of Prof. Kunlun Zhang, who was recently released from a jail in mainland China, as "proof that the Chinese government will bend to international pressure and that a Canadian involvement can effect the struggle to promote human rights in China."

If Canada fails to support a U.N. motion to censure Communist China, it is tantamount to suggesting that it is acceptable to mistreat peaceful citizens for exercising their freedom of conscience, he said.
"I call on the Canadian government to do the honorable thing, and lend its voice to the growing international community opposed to China's treatment of its Falun Gong practitioners," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE DEMOCRATIC LEADER CALLS FOR RELEASE OF PLANE AND CREW

TEXT.P: U.S. House Democratic leader Richard A. Gephardt on Thursday urged Beijing to immediately release the U.S. Navy's SP-3 surveillance aircraft and its crew being held on mainland China's Hainan Island.

In a statement in response to the ongoing situation regarding the collision between the U.S. Navy aircraft and a Communist Chinese fighter jet, Rep. Gephardt (D-Mo.) pointed out that "part of the problem here is that the government in Beijing "does not have a tradition of adherence to the rule of law and fundamental human rights."

"The current situation is further evidence that we must continue to press for China's compliance with the rule of law and global standards if it intends to work constructively with the international community," he added.

Calling the mid-air collision "an unfortunate accident that occurred in international airspace," the congressman from Missouri said that as President George W. Bush has noted, "it is regrettable that China lost a pilot and his aircraft in this inc ident."

"I hope that given these circumstances, the Chinese government will release our aircraft and our service men and women as soon as possible so that they may be reunited with their families. The tough talk of the past few days is no substitute for the determined diplomatic steps that are needed to ensure the expeditious return of our crew and aircraft," Gephardt added.
But he emphasized that based on the information he received about the incident and relevant international laws, "I do dot believe that an apology is warranted in this situation."
Gephardt called for a positive solution to this situation consistent with international law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 109.28 points to close at 5,515.13.
Encouraged by a surge in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,570.71 and fluctuated between 5,584.14 and 5,508.81 during trading.

A total of 2.29 billion stocks worth NT$82.98 billion (US$2.53 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.96 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$69.52 billion (US$2.11 billion).

All of the eight major stocks categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.9 percent, electrical shares at 2.6 percent, construction stocks at 2.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2.3 percent, cement stocks at 2.1 percent, foodstuff shares at 1 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 460 to 74, with 62 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO PROMOTE REASONABLE BROKERAGE FEES FOR FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will work to promote reasonable brokerage fees for foreigner laborers by using the level of a country's brokerage fees to determine how many workers to introduce from a particular country, CLA Chairman Chen Chu said Friday.

Chen made the remarks after receiving clergy members from the Chunan Holy Family Catholic Church, which has asked Chen to help solve the problem of Vietnamese workers being charged exorbitant brokerage fees.

Peter Nguyen Van Hung of the Chunan Holy Family Catholic Church, who sheltered Vietnamese workers and thus became entangled in a dispute with the Vietnam Economic Cultural Office in Taipei, called on the CLA for assistance.

Chen said that foreign laborers in Taiwan will have a legal channel to make complaints if they are unfairly treated and that the CLA appreciates the efforts made by the church to protect the foreign laborers.
But Chen also noted that the nation will not tolerate foreign laborers running away from their jobs, noting that if they do so and are caught, they will be repatriated.

Father Nguyen said that Vietnamese workers not only have to pay a brokerage fee of about US$3,200, they also have to pay an extra fee of 12 percent of their monthly salary to the brokerage companies in Vietnam each month, which he said was quite unreasonable.

Chen said that the charging of unreasonable brokerage fees has been going on for a long time and that the CLA hopes a direct employment system via the two countries or a system operated by non-profit groups will be established to make brokerage fees more reasonable.

She also said that the countries exporting labor to Taiwan should protect their own nationals and that the council will use the level of a country's brokerage fees as a reference when deciding how many workers to introduce from a particular country.
She said that if the brokerage fees being asked of nationals of a particular country are too unreasonably high, then Taiwan may stop introducing laborers from that country into its labor market.
According to the clergyman, the Vietnamese government has an aversion to the Catholic Church and has told Vietnamese laborers before they come to Taiwan to stay away from the Catholic priests.

Chen said that she will convey to the Vietnamese government the fact that foreign laborers have religious freedom in Taiwan and that the Vietnamese government cannot restrict the activities of its laborers while they are in Taiwan.
She also said that during the period of disputes between foreign laborers and their employers, religious groups can legally shelter foreign workers if they first file with the CLA.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved up 61 points to close at 5,530, with 6,445 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 41 points to finish at 5,520, with 75 contracts traded.
September futures increased 4 points to close at 5,530, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,469 for April, 5,479 for May, 5,501 for June, 5,526 for September, and 5,526 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
April TE futures rose 4.85 points to finish at 273.75, with 1,488 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 10 points to close at 276, with four contract transactions.
December TE futures fell 12.8 points to finish at 271, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 2.8 points to close at 744.6, with 549 contract transactions, while May TF futures rose 7 points to finish at 753, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER RESIGNS OVER JIN WEN INSTITUTE CORRUPTION SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Minister without Portfolio Chang Yu-huei offered to resign Friday in the wake of implied allegations of his involvement in a corruption scandal involving a technology institute in Taipei.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Friday approved the written resignation submitted by Chang, who has been a minister without portfolio since May 20, 2000 when the new Democratic Progressive Party-ruled administration took office.

Acknowledging Chang's resignation, the premier noted that law enforcement authorities will investigate the alleged loan and corruption scandal involving the privately-run Jin Wen Institute of Technology "based only on facts and evidence, rather than on who the alleged accused are."
The premier invited Chang to be an adviser to the Executive Yuan, to which Chang did not express acceptance or refusal as of Friday noon.

In his resignation statement, Chang, a senior Kuomintang member who has held various governmental posts, including secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, in his 38-year stint working as a public functionary, stressed his innocence and said he has never accepted bribes or made personal gains from the Jin Wen scandal.

Chang, who had been chairman of state-run Taiwan Aluminum Corp. and Taiwan Sugar Corp. between 1990 and 1997, said he believes that the judicial system will serve justice by finding out the truth in his favor.

Chang's resignation marked the second time a Cabinet-level official has been affected by the Jin Wen scandal. Vice Education Minister Lin Chao-hsien submitted his resignation Thursday, which was approved by Education Minister Ovid Tzeng the same day.

The Jin Wen scandal was not unearthed until March 28 after Independent Legislator Lo fu-chu physically assaulted a female legislative colleague, Diane Lee, resulting in her being hospitalized and the scandal being brought to light. It has been alleged that in the Jin Wen scandal, several legislators, ranking government officials and organized crime figures have been involved in interest-peddling and collusion.

Since the scandal came to light last week, one of Chang's sons has been found to be the owner of a resort house in Taipei County which was developed by the Jin Wen Institute of Technology and was given to the junior Chang for almost nothing.
In his resignation, Chang said that the house was bought by his son legally and that his brother-in-law, who handled the purchase several years ago, will make a public explanation shortly.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 TAIWAN MEN ARRESTED IN MEXICO ON CHARGES OF GREENBACK SMUGGLING
DOC.DATELINE: Mexico City, April 5 (CNA) (By Chen Chang-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Mexico said Thursday it is negotiating with Mexican law enforcement authorities over the arrest of three Taiwanese men at Mexico City's international airport earlier this week.
Mexican police arrested the three Taiwan businessmen Tuesday evening on charges of attempting to smuggle a large amount of hard currency out of Mexico.

The ROC representative office in Mexico City said it has sent staff members to contact Mexican law enforcement authorities over the issue. "We'll also offer all necessary assistance to our three expatriates," said a representative office official.

The three arrested ROC nationals were identified as Tseng Ching-mu, Lee Shih-chung and Yang Jui-liang. The trio jointly manage Penmex Co., a Mexico City company specializing in producing pens and relevant accessories. Among them, Tseng is the boss.
As Lee Shih-chung holds passports from the ROC, the United States, Argentina and Chile, the case has caused concern from the U.S., Argentine and Chilean embassies here.

The three men were leaving for San Francisco when they were spotted by Mexican police at the airport. Extensive body searches discovered that the trio were carrying a total of US$445,000 (about NT$14.7 million) in cash and traveler's checks.

According to Mexican customs regulations, each departing passenger is limited to carrying US$20,000 out of the country, so Mexican police are treating the case as a serious crime. The matter also caught the attention of major Mexican television stations, as the trio had tied the money onto their bodies, a practice rarely seen in Mexico.
Mexican prosecutors said they may indict the three men Friday on charges of money laundering.

As Mexico imposes stringent restrictions on outbound capital remittances, many Taiwanese working in Mexico reportedly often resort to illegal ways to take hard currency out of the country in order to evade taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MARCH CONSUMER PRICE INDEX DROPS BY 0.27 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Friday said that the consumer price index (CPI) for March dropped 0.27 percent from that of the previous month.
The CPI stood at 102.96 points in March, an increase of 0.44 percent compared with the same month of the previous year, according to the DGBAS.
The average monthly CPI during the first quarter of this year rose by 0.58 percent from the same period in 2000, the DGBAS added.
The DGBAS cited excessive production of vegetables and fruits as a factor in the consumer price decline from February to March.
Meanwhile, March's wholesale price index hit 95.91 points, a 0.30 percent decrease from that of the previous month and a 0.20 percent drop compared with that of March 2000.
The average wholesale price index for the first quarter this year increased by 0.58 percent from that of the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND WITCH HEALER APPEALS FOR DISMISSAL

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese witch doctor Zhang Ying, who has been prohibited from leaving Taiwan since January on charges of fraud and engaging in illicit medical practices, appealed Friday for the Taipei Prosecutors Office to dismiss the case and let her leave Taiwan.
Zhang asked the Taipei prosecutors for her release so that she can return to the United States, as she is five months pregnant and feels miserable living in limbo in Taipei away from her relatives.

A crying Zhang, believed to be in her late 30s or early 40s, said she hates living in her current state of limbo. She asked for a quick resolution of the charges that she illegally practiced medicine in Taipei followed by an early release on parole, with which she said she would fully cooperate and return to Taiwan for further questioning whenever she is subpoenaed.

On Zhang's appeal, Taipei prosecutors ruled out an immediate dismissal for her on the grounds that there are still some facts that she must clarify. They added that law enforcement authorities are still conducting chemical analysis on the medicine that she claimed she had produced from mid-air during her public performances of healing magic in Taipei.

Zhang, who claims to be able to see through people's bodies and diagnose their diseases, caused a sensation in Taiwan in January after displaying her so-called "power" at a local television station by "snatching pills out of thin air" and handing them out to her "patients."
Taiwan reporters said that Zhang was certified by the government of mainland China as a "person with miraculous power" and that she charged between NT$6,000 and NT$10,000 for each magic "treatment."

However, one of her performances in front of TV cameras on Jan. 5 was challenged by a local magician, who attended Zhang's performance and pointed out that her so-called "supernatural power" was nothing more than a simple sleight-of-hand trick.

Zhang failed to produce any more medicine during her Jan. 5 performance after being disrupted by the magician, giving the convenient excuse that she could not concentrate her power in the presence of someone who doubted her abilities.
A few days later, she was summoned to the Taipei Prosecutors' Office for questioning and consequently was prohibited from leaving Taiwan.

Zhang, who lives in the United States, arrived in Taiwan in late December with her Taiwan-born husband for a short visit. She now lives alone at her mother-in-law's home in Taipei, since both her husband and the mother-in-law have been living in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.039 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 32.940.
The local currency opened Friday at 32.948 and was traded between 32.890 and 32.948.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$556 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CLOSELY WATCHING MAINLAND PRESIDENT'S LATIN AMERICA TOUR

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is closely watching mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's current six-country tour of Latin America, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Jiang's 12-day visit will take him to three major MERCOSUR countries -- Brazil, Argentina and Chile -- as well as to the neighboring nations of Uruguay, Cuba and Venezuela.

"As Latin America has been the ROC's diplomatic stronghold, many of our diplomatic allies in the area fully understand the advantages of making friends with us," Chang said, adding that bilateral relations between the ROC and its individual Latin American allies have been solid and cordial.
Chang said ROC embassies and representative offices in various Latin American countries have full information about Jiang's itinerary and agenda for his current tour.

Chang also unveiled a detailed report on steps taken by mainland Chinese authorities from May 2000 through January this year to deny the ROC's sovereignty, downgrade its international status, sabotage its relations with diplomatic allies and interfere with its substantive exchanges with other countries.

In addition, Chang said, mainland China has spared no effort to hinder the ROC embassies and representative offices from staging National Day and presidential inauguration celebrations as well as to block Taiwan's participation in international activities and organizations and ROC officials' overseas travel plans.
Chang further said mainland China has stepped up its efforts to court overseas Chinese groups and drive wedges between the ROC and overseas Chinese communities in various countries.
Nevertheless, Chang said ROC diplomats will not be daunted by mainland China's constant diplomatic offensive against Taiwan and will redouble their efforts to expand the country's external ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRESIDES OVER COMING-OF-AGE CEREMONY IN PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bien presided over a traditional coming-of-age ceremony held Friday at a school in Pingtung County.
Fifty-four youths from the county in southern Taiwan attended the ceremony before climbing to the top of Tawu Mountain to declare their adulthood.
Chen, who was accompanied by Pingtung County Governor Su Chia-chuan, arrived at Taiwu elementary school Friday morning for the ceremony to initiate the youths into their adulthood.

Speaking to the youths, President Chen noted that the ceremony has become one of the most famous "new rituals" in southern Taiwan through promotion by the Pingtung County government. He said he would like to expand this special ritual to a national level with the help of the National Cultural Association.

"Becoming an adult is an important milestone in one's life, and the process of walking toward adulthood is not an easy one," the president said. "It is the same for everyone as well as for our nation and society," he continued, stressing that "we need to help each other out hand-in-hand and heart-to-heart in order to overcome any obstacles we may face and reach our goals."

"The new government, faced with many challenges while making its first steps toward its goals, is willing to exert the strongest spirit to explore a better future for Taiwan and its people," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PM SAID MULLING VISA FOR FORMER PRESIDENT LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 6 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Japanese daily newspaper reported Friday that Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori has instructed the Foreign Ministry to consider granting a visa to allow a visit to Japan by former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui.

The mass circulation Mainichi Shimbun said Mori made the instruction partly for humanitarian reasons and partly out of dissatisfaction with Beijing for its persistent use of the issue of Lee's attempted visit to Japan as a diplomatic bargaining chip against Japan. Mori offered to resign from his position Friday.

According to the Mainichi Shimbun report, Lee hopes to visit Japan for the main purpose of having his heart checked in early May on his way home from the United States, where he will revisit his alma mater Cornell University in late April.
Through informal channels, Lee has already begun to sound out the possibility of obtaining an entry visa from the Japanese government, the Mainichi Shimbun report said.

Lee, who received Japanese education during his formative years in Taiwan and later went on to study at the prestigious University of Kyoto, wanted to attend an Asia Outlook forum in Japan last autumn. However, that plan was aborted owing to Beijing's opposition and intervention.
Later on Friday, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda dismissed the Mainichi Shimbun report, describing it as untrue and groundless.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REMAINS WORLD'S 4TH LARGEST FOREX RESERVES HOLDER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$100.63 billion as of the end of March this year, an increase of US$551 million from that at the previous month's end, according to statistics released Friday by the Central Bank of China.
However, the foreign exchange reserves figure at the end of March was US$2.36 billion less than that at the end of last March, the CBC's statistics showed.
However, Taiwan remained the world's fourth largest foreign exchange reserves holder, next to Japan, mainland China and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DIPLOMACY ACADEMY' PLANNED TO HELP NGO ACTIVITIES: MINISTER

TEXT.P: The government is planning to set up a "diplomacy academy" to help provide "resources, training and coordination" for the private sector to take part in international non-governmental activities.
Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao made the remarks while answering questions from Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Tso Chi-hung on the issue.

Tien pledged that his ministry will do its best to provide assistance and coordination to local non-governmental organizations that wish to participate in international activities now that it is its legal responsibility to do so.
According to Tien, his ministry receives more than 400 applications each year for financial assistance, a vast majority of which are aimed at activities sponsored by non-governmental organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS WIDE SUPPORT FOR RESTRICTIONS ON MAINLAND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people support government restrictions on mainland China-bound investment, a senior mainland affairs official said Friday.
"This is the finding of a recent opinion poll sponsored by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC)," said MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin.

Lin said the council commissioned National Sun Yat-sen University last month to survey local people's opinions whether the government should impose strings on investment across the Taiwan Strait as the Cabinet is mulling how to adjust the present "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy to meet market demand.

Quoting the results of a telephone survey of 1,077 randomly selected adult residents, conducted from March 25-28, Lin said that as much as 82.5 percent of those interviewed support enactment of government regulations to control mainland China-bound investment.
Only 15 percent said they don't think that the government should impose restrictions on launching investment projects on the mainland.

Poll results also showed that 55.6 percent of the respondents want the government to impose even more stringent restrictions on mainland investments; 26 percent said the government should moderately ease current restrictions; and 4.1 percent said they see no need to adjust the existing "no haste" policy.

Asked about their views on the direct cross-strait transport links, 83.2 percent said the government should open direct cross-strait shipping and air links under certain conditions, such as the principles of national security, dignity and parity; but 8.9 percent said they think direct cross-strait transport links should be opened unconditionally.

In addition, 53.6 percent said they agree with the concept that opening direct cross-strait shipping and air links may affect national security; while 36.9 percent said they disagree with such an idea.
The same survey further found that 73.9 percent oppose mainland China's "one country, two systems" unification scheme, roughly same as the average level recorded in previous MAC surveys.
Meanwhile, 16.1 percent threw support behind the "one country, two systems" proposal, slightly higher than the percentage registered a similar MAC survey conducted in May 2000.

As for local people's stances on Taiwan's future, 87.78 percent support the roughly defined concept of "maintaining the current status quo," including those who want to see permanent maintenance of the status quo or prefer to move toward unification or independence after a certain period of time.
Compared with the findings of previous surveys, the percentage of those who support the proposal of "moving toward unification after maintaining the status quo for sometime" increased slightly.

Touching on the development of future cross-strait ties, 37.1 percent said they think that cross-strait relations will ease; 26.4 percent said they expect no change in bilateral Taiwan-mainland China ties; and 16.7 percent said they think that cross-strait ties may become more tense.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INVESTORS IN MAINLAND CHINA APPEAL FOR GOVERNMENT ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: Some 100 Taiwan investors in mainland China appealed for Republic of China government assistance Friday at a public hearing held at the Legislative Yuan.

Among their appeals, they urged the government to include Taiwan-funded companies in mainland China into the list of targets eligible for assistance under the government-sponsored professional counseling service system.
The mainland China-based business people also pushed the government to allow local banks to set up representative offices and branches on the mainland to offer them easier financial services.

Other appeals included resolving double taxation problems faced by Taiwanese investors on the mainland; allowing entry of mainland-produced semi-finished goods for assembling into finished products for export purposes; helping them resolve intellectual property rights infringement issues; allowing mainland spouses to work in Taiwan and allowing Taiwanese schools on the mainland to offer senior high school courses.
The public hearing was co-sponsored by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chu Feng-chih and a private association for promoting the development of Taiwan-funded firms in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA CALLS ON FORMER ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama called on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui Friday and expressed his gratitude for Lee's promotion of increased Taiwan-Tibet exchanges during his term in office.
The Dalai Lama also expressed respect for Lee's contributions to democratic reforms.
This was the third meeting between Lee and the Dalai Lama. The two first met in 1997 during the Dalai Lama's first visit to Taiwan.

They met again last October in the Czech Republic, where they attended the Forum 2000 conference, a gathering of noted personalities and former heads of state from around the world at the invitation of Czech President Vaclav Havel.

The Dalai Lama is scheduled to meet Saturday with Vice President Annette Lu and Venerable Dharma Master Hsin Tao, head of the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Foundation and founder of the Museum of World Religions currently under construction in Taiwan.
The Dalai Lama is also slated to complete an empowerment blessing ritual, a two-day ceremony that began earlier in the day with cleansing preparations.
Followers were ceremoniously cleansed of their deeds, words and thoughts by applying a small amount of "blessing water" to their heads, faces and hands.
A total of 15,000 sets of essential preparatory items -- two blades of grass, a red silk rope and a red blindfold -- were handed out.
The Dalai Lama urged local Tantric and Exoteric Buddhists not to be overly superstitious about the benefits of the ritual.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER DISMISSES REPORTS OF CETRA LAYOFFS

TEXT.P: Chen Ruey-lung, vice Economic Affairs Minister, dismissed reports that the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will undergo a major personnel reshuffle.

Chen made the remarks when he presided over the ceremony that saw Huang Chih-peng replace Kao I-hsin to serve as the CETRA secretary-general. Huang was the director general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center before the new post, while Kao will serve as the counselor for the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

As the chairman and secretary-general of CETRA have been changed over the past three months, sources within the trade promotion body have said that a large-scale layoff could begin late in the year or 2002 at the latest.
The sources also said that the ministry would merge its 37 footholds around the world to save NT$600 million (US$18.23 million) in yearly expenses.
CETRA workers have become jittery in past days over the reports of layoffs and mergers of overseas footholds, but Chen dismissed the reports and urged the workers to relax.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LARGE-SCALE INVESTMENTS DECREASE SHARPLY IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's domestic large-scale investments decreased sharply in March due to low investor sentiment and the rapid relocation of local factories abroad, according to statistics published Friday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The MOEA statistics show that the number of new investment projects worth over NT$200 million (US$6.08 million) reached only four in March, with a total value of NT$23.8 billion.
The March figure represented a decrease of hundreds of millions of NT dollars since January and February, and a reduction of 15.77 percent over the same month last year.
The number of large-scale investments in January reached five, with a combined value of NT$68.1 billion; while in February the number reached six projects worth a total of NT$95.1 billion.
In aggregate, the value of large-scale investments in the first three months reached NT$187.1 billion, in comparison with NT$306.8 million in the 117 projects during the same period last year.
MOEA officials attributed last year's large figure mainly to the remaining construction work on the nation's sixth naphtha cracker plant.

However, the officials admitted that considering the domestic investment figures over the last two years, large-scale investments projects are getting larger, but fewer in number as small- and medium-sized enterprises have stopped making large-scale investments. The officials reminded the government to consider this as a warning sign and take measures to face it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES MEXICO TO TREAT ARRESTED ROC NATIONALS FAIRLY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Friday that its representative office in Mexico has already urged local law enforcement authorities to treat three arrested ROC nationals fairly, without bias and according to the law.

Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Katharine S.Y. Chang said that Mexican prosecutors have told the ROC representative office that the three men were arrested at Mexico City's international airport earlier Tuesday for allegedly violating Mexico's National Security Law.
According to the law, which was promulgated March 1, anyone entering or leaving Mexico with over US$10,000 must declare the amount through customs, Mexican prosecutors said.

The three men were allegedly found to be carrying US$445,000 in U.S. dollars and travelers checks, which they had bundled to their bodies. Mexican police arrested the men on suspicion of illegal money laundering.

Chang said that the Foreign Ministry will closely watch further developments. She also urged ROC nationals to pay close attention to the announcement of new laws when leaving or entering other countries in the future.

The three arrested ROC nationals were identified as Tseng Ching-mu, Lee Shih-tsung and Yang Jui-liang. The trio jointly manage Penmex Co., a Mexico City company headed by Tseng that specializes in pens and relevant accessories.
As Lee holds passports from the Republic of China, the United States, Argentina and Chile, the case has also aroused the attention of the U.S., Argentine and Chilean embassies in Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCB BASEBALL TEAM TO ATTEND SHANGHAI INVITATIONAL TOURNEY

TEXT.P: The baseball team of Chinatrust Commercial Bank (CCB) will fly to mainland China April 9 to attend the Shanghai Baseball Invitational Tournament scheduled for April 11-16 in Shanghai.
The CCB baseball team will play three games each with mainland Chinese Shanghai, Guangdong and Fujian teams and two games with a team jointly formed by Shanghai and Guangdong.
The CCB ball club will also visit mainland Chinese baseball authorities while in the mainland.
The CCB team will be the first Taiwanese professional baseball team to be invited to a contest in mainland China.

A Beijing baseball team came to Taiwan in October 2000 for a contest with teams in Taiwan, and two Little League teams from Shanghai and Tianjin, respectively, were in Taiwan in December 2000 for an international tournament. More recently, a Tianjin baseball team came to Taiwan in February 2001 to engage in friendly contests with Taiwanese players.
Mainland China is now actively cultivating and training baseball players in a bid to strive for the sponsorship of the 2008 Olympic Games.

Thirteen mainland Chinese baseball teams will compete to enter a group of the top eight teams in a selective tournament slated to be held in Shanghai in May in order to compete at the all-mainland China baseball tournament in late November.
The CCB baseball team is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX DOWN SLIGHTLY IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) in March decreased by 0.27 percent compared to the previous month due to slower consumption amid the sluggish economy, according to a government statement.

Statistics released by Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Friday indicated that the consumer price index registered 102.96 in March while the wholesale price index in the same month reached 95.91. The wholesale price index represented a decline of 0.3 percent over February's figure and the first negative growth in 17 months.

DGBAS officials attributed the drop in wholesale prices to the low international prices for crude oil, plastic and chemical materials, machinery, optical instruments and pulp, which drove the average import price down by 5.75 percent in March compared to the same month of last year.

In aggregate, the consumer price index increased by 0.58 percent in the first quarter over the same period of last year. Asked if the continued low consumer prices signifies slowing consumption or deflation, the DGBAS officials said they cannot say until the release of May's statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COUNTY CHIEF URGES REGULATORY REVIEW OF 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Chief Chen Shui-tsai Friday urged the central government to review the existing regulations over the "mini three links" between Taiwan-controlled offshore islands and certain mainland Chinese ports.

Pointing out that there is a huge gap between the policy goals and the present situation of the partial trade, shipping and postal links between the two sides, Chen voiced his hope that the central government in Taipei would adjust the current measures so as to efficiently improve bilateral relations.

According to Chen, the goals of the "mini three links" policy are correct, but ineffective regulations and barriers from the mainland Chinese side have created a situation in which the desired links across the Taiwan Strait are not truly established.

Chen made the remarks at a county-level meeting called to examine the results of the first-stage "mini three links," which were established in the beginning of this year between the Republic of China-controlled Kinmen and Matsu islands and selected ports of mainland China's Fujian province.

Over the past three months, two-way regular cargo and passenger shipping services have remained intact, and a total of 1,401 Taiwan passengers and 91 mainland Chinese travelers have visited the opposite side on irregular shipping services.

During the same period, only a single mainland Chinese cargo ship has made the trip, carrying 400 cubic meters of gravel to Kinmen, with no such vessels from either Kinmen or Matsu having sailed across the strait.

Under mounting public pressure, local opinion leaders have expressed strong doubts that the opening of the "mini three links" will benefit local people and boost local development. They blamed the Kinmen county authorities for the current situation.
Clarifying the misunderstanding, Chen said the central government and the mainland Chinese side, rather than the local authorities, should be held accountable for the alleged failure.

Analyzing opinions from all parties concerned, including central government officials stationed in Kinmen and local private groups, Chen urged the central government to take concrete measures quickly to build Kinmen into a cross-strait trade and fishing center as well as develop the island into a business management center for mainland-based Taiwan businessmen.

In addition, he pointed out that regulations governing bilateral trade, academic, and humanitarian exchanges should be further relaxed as a way of helping create a positive relationship between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS CALL ON JAPANESE DIET SPEAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A group of legislators led by Yao Eng-chi, vice president of the Legislative Yuan, called Friday on Tamisuke Wataneki, speaker of the Lower House of Japan, to exchange views on bilateral relations between Japan and the Republic of China.
In addition to Yao, other members of the delegation included legislators Liu Sheng-liang, Fan Yen-sheng, Huang Mu-tien, Chiu Ching-chun and Huang Tu.
During the 30-minute meeting, Yao presented a personal letter from Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng to Wataneki inviting the Japanese official to visit Taiwan at his convenience.
Wataneki expressed his gratitude for the invitation and said that he will seriously consider visiting Taiwan at a proper time.

Wataneki told his Chinese visitors that he will promote parliamentary diplomacy that will not be affected by administrative diplomacy. He also expressed his concern over the construction of the Taiwan High-Speed Railway and the fourth nuclear power plant.

In return, Yao said that both Taiwan's ruling and opposition political parties are now learning cooperation instead of confrontation. Yao expressed the hope that Wataneki will continue to speak for Taiwan at important meetings in the Asian-Pacific region.

Later in the day, the group called on Sadanori Yamanaka, president of the "Japan and ROC Dietmen's Council" and Yamanaka hosted a luncheon party in their honor. Takeo Hirazawa, Japan's minister of Economy, Trade and Industry; Chikage Ogi, minister of Land, Infrastructure and Transport; and some 10 chief officials of the council also attended the party.
Yamanaka said that the council will continue to promote relations between Taiwan and Japan.
Yao in return thanked members of the council for their efforts in promoting Taipei-Tokyo ties in past years. He said he hopes that a ministerial official would visit Taiwan in the near future.
They arrived in Tokyo Thursday and they held a symposium with overseas Chinese community leaders in Tokyo and Yokohama Thursday night.

The delegation will be in Tokyo Saturday and Osaka Sunday in order to attend two annual conventions of the Hakka Tsungcheng Association. While in Osaka, they will also attend the 13th Convention of the Chinese Associations in Asia on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC ANNOUNCES POSITION CHANGES

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Friday announced several position changes of department-level officials as part of the council's efforts to cope with increased cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.

Tsai Jy-jon, present director of the MAC's Department of Hong Kong and Macao Affairs, will be promoted to become the representative of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau. He will take over that post from William W. Li, who will return to Taipei to serve as a MAC counselor.
At the same time, Chang Yung-shan, incumbent director of the MAC's Department of Information and Liaison will replace Tsai, while Chang's deputy, C. H. Chen, will be promoted to take his place.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-DEPRESSION ORGANIZATION TO BE FORMED

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese Society of Psychiatry (TSP) has announced that it will form an organization to fight psychological depression and suicide.

In a symposium on depression, TSP President Lee Ming-ping said the Anti-depression Union is in the process of being formed. He noted that the World Health Organization (WHO) lists depression, cancer and AIDS, as the three top killers of the 21st century.

The WHO estimates that about 400 million people around the world suffer from the mental disorder, which involves intense moods of sadness, grief, disappointment and loneliness. In extreme cases, the disease leads sufferers to harm or kill themselves, according to Lee.
Citing statistics prepared by the Department of Health, Lee said suicide, a symptom of depression, is the third leading cause of death among Taiwanese youth aged between 15 and 24.

A survey conducted jointly by National Chengkung University and Kaohsiung Medical School in southern Taiwan found that 37.7 percent of people aged 65 and above in the survey had suffered from various mental disorders within a month before they were interviewed, said Lee.
That figure include 15.3 percent suffering from slight depression, 5.9 percent from serious depression, and 0.7 percent from schizophrenia.

Lee said the elderly and teenagers are at the highest risk from depression and suicide. Their vulnerability to suicide highlights the fact that mental treatment and mental health are vital parts of the health of the whole body, he added.

He warned his audience that depression, dementia and suicide come along with the aging process of people; and self-harm, suicide and substance abuse among teenagers are set to be major challenges facing humanity in this century.
In an unrelated event, famous Ho Lo Opera performer Sun Tsui-feng made public at a press conference Friday her own experiences of depression and her subsequent recovery.
Sun said her experience with the disorder has improved her knowledge of the disease and has helped her realize that health and life are invaluable.

Citing her own case as example, the smiling Sun told a packed room that she experienced long periods of fatigue, fear and sadness during the previous year, and was diagnosed with depression rather than what she initially suspected was a heart condition.

With the help of medication prescribed by doctors and the support of her family, Sun said her disorders are now well under control. She encouraged people who suffer from similar symptoms to come out of the shadows and seek medical treatment.

At the press briefing, Sun also unveiled a television commercial she shot for the Department of Health. In the commercial Sun urges the public to accept and help depressed people, stressing that the disorder can be cured.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST PATROL BOATS RUSH TO LOOK INTO SUSPECTED FOUL PLAY AT SEA

TEXT.P: Two patrol boats from the Coast Guard Administration rushed into the South China Sea Friday to look into the mysterious disappearance of the captain of a Taiwan fishing boat operating there.

A duty officer at the administration's situation room said the captain of Pingtung-registered fishing boat Ching Hung Cheng No.2 reportedly disappeared Thursday morning while the ship was operating on seas east of the Philippines.

The ship's chief engineer Chen Lien-chen secretly radioed the Coast Guard Administration at 5:30 p.m. Thursday after he found blood stains near Captain Kung Chin-ji's quarters and suspected foul play.
He said on the radio that all the ship's eight crewmen are mainland Chinese, except the captain and himself.
Scuffles between Taiwan ship officers and mainland Chinese crewmen are not unusual, and casualties have been reported before.
The duty officer said the administration's boats are expected to reach the ship, which is operating some 400 nautical miles away from Taiwan, Friday night or Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Minister Chang Yu-hui resigned over snowballing Jin-Wen Institute kickback scandal.
The China Times:
U.S.-mainland China talks on release of spy plane crew has made progress, says Bush.
The United Daily News:
Washington and Beijing exchange views on how to end the military aircraft 'collision' incident.
The Liberty Times:
U.S. proposes joint probes into the 'collision' incident.
The China Post:
Bush sees forward movement on surveillance plane standoff.
The Taiwan News:
First lady condemns sinking Legislature.
The Taipei Times:
Minister out amid uproar over Jin-Wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH TO MAKE `ROBUST' DECISION ON ARMS SALE TO TAIWAN: CAMPBELL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 6 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Kurt Campbell, a former U.S. defense official in charge of Asia Pacific affairs, said at a recent seminar that he believes the new U.S. administration will make a "robust" decision to sell arms to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.

He said at a seminar in Atlanta Wednesday that the United States should regard Asia security issues as vital factors in its global strategic considerations instead of merely considering its trade interests in Asia as it did in the past.

Campbell, a deputy assistant secretary of defense in the Clinton administration and now senior vice president of the Washington-based think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies, added that the United States supports Taiwan security because of the island's democratic and economic developments.

He added that because Asian countries -- including the Republic of China -- do not want to see the United States and mainland China in conflict, the Bush administration should continue to engage Beijing and establish bilateral communication mechanisms so as to avoid possible misunderstandings and conflicts that will lead to regional instability.

At the same seminar, which was co-sponsored by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Atlanta and the Georgia Institute of Technology, the ROC representative in Atlanta, Andrew J.C. Kao, urged mainland China to resume dialogue with Taiwan without preconditions.
He added that Taiwan needs to purchase defensive weapons in the meantime for its own security.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 7, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by U.S. aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other locations around Taiwan to begin handling traffic violation cases.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Guofeng as premier and to depose Deng Xiaoping as deputy premier after riots in Beijing.
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting Communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure against Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho urges the government to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.
2000: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party announce their decision to drop out of the party because they say that the party has completed its mission.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SAYS PRAYER AT FIRST NATIONAL PRAYER BREAKFAST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said a prayer for the people, the government, the nation and the world Saturday at the Republic of China's first national prayer breakfast, which was organized by local Christians.
Chen told the some 800 local and foreign participants at the breakfast that he hopes the nation will be able to manifest the God-given qualities of justice, peace and compassion.

Also in attendance were Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, former Premier and opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman Vincent Siew, foreign ambassadors and representatives, as well as legislators and religious representatives from the United States, Australia, Britain, Canada, Germany, Japan, South Korea and South Africa.

According to the organizers of the prayer breakfast, the event was meant to bring together political and business leaders of all stripes to pray for the troubled nation amidst widespread political and economic anxiety.
The breakfast was modeled after the U.S. and South Korean versions and was the brainchild of Father Kao Chun-min, a presidential adviser.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO INVESTIGATE TAIWAN COMPANIES' ALLEGED PATENT INFRINGEMENTS

TEXT.P: The U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC) voted Wednesday to investigate alleged infringements of patents for certain network interface cards and access points by 14 companies, including Taiwan's Acer NeWeb Corp. and D-Link Corp.
The investigation is based on a petition filed on March 9 by Proxim Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., and subsequent supplements filed on March 29.

Proxim charged that Acer NeWeb, D-Link and 12 other companies infringed upon three of its patents on network interface cards and access points for use in direct sequence spread spectrum wireless local area networks.
The products at issue in this investigation are used to construct wireless computer networks so that computer users can access networked resources and share data from mobile workstations.
The U.S. firm has requested that the ITC issue a permanent exclusion order and permanent cease and desist orders to those companies.

Taiwan's Acer NeWeb, D-Link and their U.S. sister companies, Acer America Corp. of San Jose, Calif., and D-Link Systems Inc. of Irvine, Calif., are among those that have been listed as respondents in this investigation.
The ITC has assigned Paul J. Luckern, an administrative law judge, to make an initial determination as to whether there has been a violation of section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930.
The initial determination is expected to come out in nine months, and will be subject to review by the commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS TO VISIT M'LAND AS PART OF EXCHANGE PLAN

TEXT.P: About 100 high school students from Taipei will travel to major cities in southern mainland China this summer for exchanges with high school students there under a program sponsored by Taipei City's Bureau of Education.
Bureau of Education Director Lee Hsi-chin will lead the group of students from Taipei's prestigious high schools to Shanghai, Nanjing, Suzhou and Hangzhou for a 12-day educational and academic visit.
The Taipei students will have the opportunity to experience a different school environment and lifestyle at the esteemed mainland high schools and also to pay a visit to the Shanghai City Government.

Meanwhile, the students will also get the chance to study the culture, customs, local relics and political systems of the various cities and cement sisterhood ties with the local schools, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: MISS GUAM TO PARTICIPATE IN TAIPEI'S OUTBOUND TOUR FAIR

TEXT.P: The 12th Outbound Tour Fair will be held April 13-16 at the Taipei World Trade Center, with Miss Guam Universe 2000 participating in the event.
In an attempt to attract more Taiwan tourists to the country, Guam's tourism bureau has decided to send Miss Guam Universe 2000, Lisa Marie Perez Quinata, to Taiwan on a "good-will mission."
