Quinata, a 22-year old bachelor of biotechnology candidate from Santa Rita, Guam, will formally invite Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to the island for a visit on behalf of the government of Guam, according to a news release from Guam's tourism bureau.
Guam, located in the Pacific Ocean about 2,100 kilometers east of the Philippines, has an area twice that of Taipei. A flight between Guam and Taiwan takes approximately 3.5 hours.
Outbound Tour Fair 2001, organized by Blanca monthly magazine and Top-Link Exhibition, will have more than 100 stalls to accommodate participants from different countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA DONATES US$ 150,000 TO TAIWAN'S EARTHQUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama announced Saturday that he will donate US$150,000 toward the reconstruction of the region in central Taiwan that was ravaged by a killer earthquake in September 1999.
Of that amount, US$100,000 will come from religious contributions by the Dalai Lama's local followers, while the remaining US$50,000 will come from the Dalai Lama himself.
The Dalai Lama made the surprise announcement during an empowerment blessing ritual attended by over 20,000 followers.

The "Thousand-armed and Thousand-eyed Bodhisattva of Mercy Empowerment Ritual," a two-day ceremony that began Friday with spiritual cleansing preparations, was held at the indoor stadium of the National College of Physical Education and Sports in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County.
The ceremony, which the Dalai Lama had also performed once before during his previous visit to Taiwan in 1997, drew in local crowds that hoped to be blessed by the Tibetan spiritual leader.
However, the Dalai Lama repeated his warning that a single empowerment ritual would not necessarily free one completely from worldly shackles and worries.
Instead, he urged his followers to embrace bodhicitta -- an enlightened mindset based on the belief of moral consequences -- and to obey the commandments of Buddhism.

DOC.HEADLINE: FARMERS TO FACE EMPLOYMENT DIFFICULTIES AFTER TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY: COA

TEXT.P: Some of Taiwan's farmers will face difficulties in changing their line of employment after the island becomes a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO), the chairman of the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan said Friday.

COA Chairman Chen Chih-huang stressed that the council will take the responsibility of assisting farmers who grow bananas, tobacco and sugar cane in finding new employment, adding that some 20,000 to 30,000 farmers in different fields will have to find different occupations after Taiwan joins the WTO, expected some time later this year or next year.

Chen added that the production of sugar cane, bananas and tobacco was formerly managed by the Taiwan Sugar Corp., the Taiwan Province Fruit Marketing Cooperative and the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board under the supervision of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Finance, respectively.

Predicting that Taiwan will obtain WTO membership as soon as the end of this year, Chen said that the three government-controlled organizations have been trying to pass to the COA the "hot potato" of helping domestic farmers find new jobs at a time when Taiwan's agricultural sector is facing the imminent challenges set to materialize when the island joins the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN CARVING OUT NICHE IN MAINLAND CHINA (I)

TEXT.P: They can be tough and they can also be tender. This is the best portrayal of Taiwan women seeking reunion with their better halves or career achievements in mainland China.
And if every Taiwan businessman has endured hardship in his mainland career adventure, the stories of Taiwan women who have moved across the Taiwan Strait are even more touching and impressive.

The greatest impetus that prompts Taiwan women to take residence in mainland China lies in their drive to assist their husbands in business operations or simply to live together with their spouses. Still, some more career-minded women have traveled to the mainland to seek better job opportunities or pursue advanced study.

The boss of a Taiwan-funded corporation in Shanghai, identified himself as Mr. Ho, said that with the quality of mainland college students upgrading steadily, he finds no difficulties recruiting qualified mainland factory and administrative management staff.
"But I have not bothered to find a financial manager here on the mainland. I feel at ease entrusting the management of company finances only to my wife," said Ho.

For her part, Mrs. Ho said she had often worried about her husband's daily life before she came to Shanghai two years ago. "Of course, I worried that he might develop extramarital affairs," she admitted frankly.

"Nevertheless, two years after I have arrived here, I still cannot find true ease because my teenage son remains in Taiwan. I have frequently flown back to Taipei to see my son," she explained, adding she is hopeful that the Taiwan-funded school now under construction in Kunshan near Shanghai can be inaugurated soon so that her son can move to the city and the family can finally be reunited.
Ms. Chang came to the mainland three years ago for reunion with her newly-wed husband, a senior manager with a Taiwan-financed firm in Guangzhou in the southern mainland province of Guangdong.

"But life here was too boring and monotonous. I had few friends. I found it very difficulty to adapt myself to the mainland lifestyle. At last, I found a way out -- I opened a fashion boutique on Guangzhou's bustling Beijing Road," Ms. Chang recalled.

And the boutique turned out to be a success. "It's a big surprise to me. I didn't expect this bonanza in the first place. The shop now earns more money than my husband's salary. And I'm planning to open a second store here," an elated Chang said.

Ms. Chang attributed her success partly to her resilience, fortitude and perseverance. "Compared with their male counterparts, Taiwan businesswomen can more easily win mainland people's support and assistance," she observed.

Despite her business success, Ms. Chang said she still feels Taiwan women's lives in mainland China are not much fun. "At home, they must be empathetic toward their husbands' emotions and the pressures they face from their business operations. Outside, they must work as hard as men while retaining their femininity," she noted.
The owner of a Taiwan-funded electronics company in Beijing, who identified himself as "Old Chen," said he has become increasingly fond of hiring female management staff from Taiwan.

"For one thing, I can save a big sum on `socializing' costs by employing female managing executives. Mainland officials are less likely to ask for entertainment at bars with hostess services when our female managers play host to dinners or other public relations programs," he said.
Moreover, Mr. Chen said, female executives are less likely to let their personal love affairs or emotions affect their career lives.
However, it remains a tall order for a Taiwan woman to carve out a niche in the not-yet-fully-opened mainland market. Numerous challenges and stumbling-blocks stand in the way. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN CARVING OUT NICHE IN MAINLAND CHINA (II)

TEXT.P: "Many mainland people still have a hard time imagining that a woman can be the chief executive officer of a business firm," said Ms. Lee, who launched a venture in Shanghai three years ago.
Ms. Lee recalled how she was mistaken as a secretary when she made her first visit to a mainland company with a male staff member to discuss a trade deal.
Ms. Lee, who had had seven years of business experience in Taiwan before relocating to the mainland, said that working in Shanghai, she has inevitably felt pressure because of her gender.

"I must endeavor to do everything well in order to win the confidence and trust of my subordinates as well as my mainland customers and partners," said the female executive, who was reluctant to explain why she had chosen to launch her own venture on the mainland, but apparently took pleasure in detailing her joys and hardships in doing business there.

Ms. Lee said that although female Taiwan migrants may have better job promotion opportunities in mainland China than their peers back in Taiwan, they should have the resolve and capability to adapt themselves to lonely and dull lives as well as heavy work pressure there.
"I think that Taiwan women intending to pursue a career in mainland China had better live here for sometime before making a final decision on whether to leave their homeland," suggested Ms. Lee.

Meanwhile, Ms. Lee said anyone who wants to succeed in mainland China must avoid making any mistakes. "And the best way to avoid making mistakes is to abide by the law and never opt for `backdoor' or illicit methods," she stressed.

Ms. Lee explained that although insisting on following legal ways may exact higher operational costs in many cases, the practice can help minimize legal risks. "By so doing, we can still speak loudly once we encounter problems," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES TALKS TO GO AHEAD AS SCHEDULED: ROC DE FACTO REP TO U.S.

TEXT.P: The annual arms sales talks between Taipei and Washington will go ahead as scheduled, Taipei's de facto ambassador to the United States said Friday.

C.J. Chen said the arms sales talks will not be affected by the ongoing discussions between the United States and mainland China over the mid-air collision between a U.S. Navy surveillance plane and a Communist Chinese fighter jet on April 1.
U.S. President George W. Bush said that progress has been made on bringing home the 24-member crew of the U.S. surveillance plane being held on mainland China's Hainan Island since the collision.

Ari Fleischer, White House spokesman, said at a press briefing Friday that a U.S. decision on arms sale to Taiwan is not part of the discussions being conducted with Beijing over the release of the U.S. service men and women.

U.S. Sen. John Warner, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said that he shares Secretary of State Colin Powell's view that arms sales to Taiwan should not be linked to issue of the surveillance plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BREAKTHROUGH IN U.S.-CHINA IMPASSE EXPECTED BEFORE JIANG RETURNS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 6 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A political scholar from Taiwan said Friday that there will not be any significant breakthroughs in the U.S.-mainland China impasse over the collision of a U.S. Navy surveillance plane and a Chinese jet fighter anytime before Jiang Zemin returns to Beijing from his current visit to Latin America.
Su Chi, former head of Taiwan's top mainland China policy planning body, made the remark at a seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait relations held Friday at Columbia University.

The seminar, titled "Transformation from a One-Party Dictatorship: The New Taiwan Government and Cross-Strait Relations," was jointly sponsored by the East Asian research institutes of National Taiwan University and Columbia University.

Besides Su, former Republic of China Legislator Hsieh Fu-sheng, Professor Ger Yeong-kuang of National Taiwan University, Director Wu Ruey-kuo of the Taiwan opposition People First Party's International Affairs Department, and Professor Chou Yang-sun of the Chinese Culture University were also present at the seminar.
At the seminar, Su also described the Republic of China government's mainland China policy since May 20, 2000, as "a half cup of water."

For those people who had worried about a strained cross-strait relationship after the Democratic Progressive Party took power, the past year has brought comfort because "there is still a half cup of water," he said, adding that to those who had hoped the transfer of power would bring about a rapprochement between the two sides of the strait, the past year has been a disappointment for the very same reason.

Although he said he believes there won't be a significant breakthrough in the U.S.-mainland China standoff prior to mainland Chinese President Zemin's return to Beijing, he added that both sides have shown restraint so far.

Noting that U.S. President George W. Bush and Secretary of State Colin Powell have both expressed regret over the incident and that Beijing has welcomed the U.S. gesture, Su said he believes the prospects of a solution to the impasse have improved, although Beijing still insists on an U.S. apology for the incident.
He added that he feels Washington and Beijing will not become deadlocked over this issue and will be able to find a way to break the impasse.

Andrew Nathan, a political science professor at Columbia University, who acted as a commentator at the seminar, said the message revealed by Beijing in this incident is that if the U.S. side still sells Taiwan the weapons it has requested, this will surely anger Beijing and affect the triangular relationship between Washington, Beijing, and Taipei.
Nathan said he thinks the upcoming arms sales talks between Taiwan and the United States scheduled for later in April is the factor complicating the present U.S.-mainland China impasse.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ENVOY LEAVES FOR MACAU

TEXT.P: New Republic of China Representative to Macau Tsai Jy-jon left for Macau Saturday to assume office.

Tsai, who originally headed the Department of Hong Kong and Macau Affairs under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said prior to his departure that he will do his utmost to further strengthen the steadily growing Taiwan-Macau relations.

Tsai took over the post of head of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau, which represents ROC interests in the mainland China-ruled territory, from William W. Li in a changeover ceremony held in Taipei Friday.
This was the first high-profile personnel reshuffle since the ROC representative office in Macau was inaugurated in December 1999. Ending his Macau stint, Li has been appointed an MAC counselor.

Li returned to Taipei Thursday evening for Friday's changeover ceremony, which was chaired by MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong. Chen said the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, has conducted an overall review before making the personnel reshuffle. Chen said the MAC will conduct another round of personnel transfers in the future.

Li's job relocation came as a surprise to his family. Li's wife, Li-Ken Kuei-fang who is a member of the Taipei City Council, said she feels that Li's departure from the Macau post was a loss to the ROC.

Reports from Macau also said that many Macau people were surprised by the abrupt change of the leadership at Taiwan's representative office in Macau. Nevertheless, most of them do not think that the personnel reshuffle will affect Taiwan-Macau exchanges.

An influential Macau resident who had often helped Li forge contacts and connections with Macau celebrities was quoted as saying that Li's successor, Tsai Jy-jon, also has extensive connections in Macau.

"Tsai is no stranger to Macau affairs. He has extensive connections. I believe that the communication channels between Taiwan's representative office and the Macau government will remain open and continue to function well," he said.
The staff of the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office in Macau also said the latest personnel transfer will not have any adverse impact on the office's operations.

Meanwhile, an official with mainland China's liaison office in Macau was quoted as saying that so long as Taiwan's representative office abides by the "seven principles" outlined by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen, its relations with Macau will not be affected simply because of the personnel reshuffle.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY PROTESTS WHITEWASHING BY JAPANESE HISTORY TEXT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday it has again lodged a protest against Japan for adopting a middle school history textbook that includes whitewashed accounts of the Japanese invasion of China and Taiwan.
The ministry said in a press release that it ordered the Republic of China representative office in Tokyo Saturday to convey the protest to the Japanese government.
It was the third time that the MOFA has expressed "concern" and "regret" over the issue to the Japanese government since February when Japan decided to use the textbook.

"History must not be distorted or tampered," the MOFA said in its press statement, adding it hopes that the Japanese government will quickly correct all whitewashed accounts in its newly compiled textbook which will be used from April 2002.
Written by right-wing academics, the contents of the textbook underwent some revisions after South Korea and mainland China also denounced Japan's decision to adopt it.

However, the revised textbook still contains passages justifying Japan's colonial past while excluding or minimizing its atrocities. It was once again approved for inclusion in Japan's middle school curriculum in a decision announced earlier this week..
The MOFA said Japan's unrepentant attitude toward its wartime atrocities has hurt the feelings of the people of Taiwan and other neighboring Asian countries.
The ministry added it will continue pushing Japan to rectify its textbook's content so as to avoid adverse repercussions on bilateral relations.
Meanwhile, a group of lawmakers, writers and history scholars called a joint press conference Saturday, condemning Japan's attempt to tamper with history.

They said Japan should immediately rectify its textbook's whitewashed accounts of Japan's invasion of China and its wartime atrocities, including forcing Taiwan and other Asian women into working at its military brothels during World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS MEETING ON ECONOMIC, FINANCIAL ISSUES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called a meeting of senior economic and financial officials Saturday to discuss feasible ways to upgrade Taiwan's competitiveness and improve Taiwan's overall investment climate.

Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Vice Premier Lai Ing-jaw, Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, National Security Council Secretary-General Chuang Ming-yao, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, and other relevant officials attended the meeting.

As both sides of the Taiwan Strait are expected to be admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO), the meeting agenda included topics related to Taiwan's banking reforms, telecommunication market liberalization, labor market adjustment in preparation for its WTO entry.
Sources close to the Presidential Office said President Chen is very concerned about the impact of WTO entry on Taiwan's job market, and industrial and agricultural development.

The sources said Saturday's meeting was mainly aimed at strengthening coordination and communications among different government agencies in formulating major financial and economic policies to maintain Taiwan's niche in the global market. No conclusion was reached at the meeting, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMITTEE TO BE FORMED TO PROMOTE MANAGEMENT OF INDUSTRY KNOWLEDGE

TEXT.P: A committee for promoting the management of industry knowledge will be formed in the near future to help upgrade domestic industries and heighten their competitiveness, sources with the preparatory committee said Saturday.
Members of the committee will include celebrities from the business, government and academic circles, the sources said.
Speaking at the preparatory committee meeting, former Premier Vincent Siew said that continued competitiveness stemming from unceasing innovation is of utmost importance to domestic industries.

Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of China Productivity Center, which initiated the committee's formation, stressed that the committee will introduce, promote and expand knowledge management in domestic industries in three phases within five years.

Major tasks of the committee will include the establishment of an industry knowledge web, the construction of a Taiwan-based global operations center and the development of a knowledge-based service industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT, PREMIER MEET WITH DALAI LAMA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu held talks with Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama Saturday to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Lu told the Dalai Lama that in many cases, Taiwan's elected lawmakers and government officials have failed to honor the promises they made during their election campaigns.
"The news media can play a very important role in overseeing whether officials have honored their promises and whether they have abused their power," replied the Dalai Lama.
Other topics raised during their discussion included family values, ethics and morals, gender equality, Taiwan investment in mainland China, and Tibetan-Chinese cultural exchanges.
Lu invited the Dalai Lama to attend the inauguration of the World Museum of Religions in suburban Taipei on Nov. 9.
She also presented NT$1 million, collected during the recent "Sending Love to Tibet" campaign, to the Dalai Lama, who said that "it will contribute much to the education of Tibetans."
The Dalai Lama held talks with Lu after his second meeting with President Chen Shui-bian.
The winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize also paid a visit to Premier Chang Chun-hsiung at the Executive Yuan Saturday afternoon.
Chang expressed appreciation on behalf of the ROC government and the people of Taiwan to the Dalai Lama for spreading "wisdom and compassion" to the people of Taiwan during his current trip.
The Dalai Lama, who arrived in Taipei for a 10-day visit March 31 at the invitation of the Chinese Buddhist Association, praised Taiwan's outstanding achievements in democratization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS IN M'LAND HAVE SPIRIT OF ADVENTURE (I)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese businessmen who have traveled to the mainland amid "westward fever" over the past decade must have a spirit of adventure in their veins.

After all, Taiwan firms on the mainland, estimated to be at least 40,000 by the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, have no reliable information to use as an investment guide, and information in the mainland is still not particularly transparent.
Maybe the only thing they can be sure of is that politics is off-limits, especially after the latest incident involving Taiwan business tycoon Shi Wen-lung.

Recent media had reported that Shi's Chi Mei petrochemical plant in Zhenjiang, Jiangsu province, had been forced to shut down under pressure from Beijing, which has voiced strong dissatisfaction about Shi's comments quoted in a comic book by Japanese comic book writer Yoshinori Kobayashi that Taiwanese women joined the Japanese military brothels "voluntarily" during World War II. The reports of the factory's closure were later proven false.
Shi has in the past raised the ire of Beijing because of his support of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which has advocated Taiwan independence in the past.

Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, has openly said several times that the mainland would oppose Taiwanese who reap economic profits in the mainland while supporting the Taiwan independence movement.

Taiwanese businessmen are betting that although Beijing would probably not use its political clout to force Taiwanese it deems politically questionable to close their plants, authorities there certainly could use administrative measures to disrupt their operations.

Susan Chen, chief operating officer of Netease, a major mainland Internet portal, said that as Taiwanese have traveled to the mainland to conduct business, they should definitely refrain from politics. Chen is believed to be the highest-level Taiwanese woman serving in the mainland.

Moreover, Taiwan businessmen have made up their decision to go to the mainland for two reasons. One is that the mainland has become a center of worldwide manufacturing with its cheap and young labor force. This is forcing many traditional businesses in Taiwan to invest in the mainland in order to maintain their competitiveness.
The second reason is the vast potential domestic market in the mainland, which boasts a population of 1.3 billion.
The Economic Bureau under the Taiwan Affairs Office of State Council said that at least 40,000 Taiwan businesses have invested a combined total of around US$40 billion in the mainland.
Among the 40,000 Taiwanese firms, about 10,000 are located in the southeastern coastal province of Guangdong. The most dense area is in Donguan, with 3,800 Taiwan businesses.

In terms of industries and markets, export-oriented Taiwan manufacturers such as Hon Hai Precision Industry, Acer, and Lite-On Technology have mostly set up plants in Donguan, Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Suzhou. These locations provide not only cheap labor but also proximity to international harbors at Hong Kong and Shanghai, which facilitate exporting.

But mainland-oriented Taiwan manufacturers and distributors, such as rice cracker manufacturer Want Want and electronics products maker Tsann Kuen Enterprises, have mostly chosen Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Shanghai, Beijing, Chongqing and Wuhan, in order to take advantage of the huge populations of these cities, all of which contain at least six million consumers.

Meanwhile, Taiwanese traditional manufacturers with capital of less than US$10 million have mostly converged on densely populated areas like Donguan, Xiamen, Ningpo, Fuzhou, Chongqing, Chengdu, Shanghai, and Shenzhen. An estimated 70 percent of Taiwanese companies on the mainland fall into this category.

During the early stage of economic reforms in the early 1990s, around 70 percent of Taiwanese businessmen in the mainland encountered problems related to their personal safety, making security their major concern.

But with the changing investment environment and preparation for WTO entry, the mainland has begun to constrain its trade and economic policies, which had been more generous and set fewer restrictions in the past in order to entice foreign investment. For example, the mainland used to allow wholly-owned overseas companies to be in the service sector, but later changed this policy to allow only joint ventures to engage in service industries.
The major issue facing Taiwan businessmen has thus shifted from personal safety to how to run a viable buSINESS.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTORS (II)

TEXT.P: Export-oriented Taiwanese manufacturers in the mainland have encountered major problems related to its unreasonable customs regulations. It is known that at least 30 Taiwan businessmen and executives in Guangdong province alone have been arrested on charges of smuggling.

Taiwan businessmen also face demands of heavy additional "fees" imposed by local authorities. A conservative estimate put these payments at about double the amount of the taxes paid to the central government. Local authorities also think of numerous ways to collect money, and as Taiwanese executives have to rely on the cooperation of local officials, they usually have to comply with these requests.

Taiwan manufacturers there also face a steep tax of around 40 percent if they decide to sell their products in the mainland instead of exporting them abroad, which hinders their ability to compete in the mainland market.

As the mainland imposes strict foreign exchange control measures, hindering the inflow and outflow of foreign exchange, Taiwan businessmen suffer from exchange rate losses and remittance processing fees. Taiwan businessmen also cannot get loans from mainland banks.
Mainland China also sets strict restrictions on the kinds of investment allowed, such as cell phone manufacturing, and goes so far as to ban certain types.

For Taiwan businessmen in mainland-oriented manufacturing or distribution, there are also many issues that await resolution. Regulations regarding selling in the mainland are chaotic, with too many restrictions placed on investments in service industries. Even if the mainland joins the World Trade Organization, it is expected that the situation will not be improved for at least another five years.
Moreover, many Taiwanese manufacturers in the mainland are operating at relatively low technology levels, making it easier for mainland people to copy their businesses and become their rivals.
The mainland China also sets high capital requirements in the insurance and banking and trading sectors, effectively shutting out Taiwan businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT INTERVIEWED FOR SECRET CONTACTS WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui was interviewed April 3 by members of the Control Yuan over his decision to contact Beijing secretly through his confidants during his tenure as head of state.
It is the first time that the head of the Republic of China has ever been interviewed by the nation's supreme watchdog, said the China Times, which published the story on its front page Sunday.

With full respect for the former ROC president, Lee was interviewed at his Taipei residence by three Control Yuan members charged with the investigation, instead of being summoned to the Control Yuan for questioning as is usual under the law.

Lee was quoted as saying that he was approached by Beijing authorities in the early 1990s shortly after he had assumed the presidency and that he responded to Beijing's offer for secret meetings by sending his personal secretary Su Chih-cheng to make contact with messengers from Beijing in Hong Kong with the purpose of giving momentum to the cross-strait relationship, which had become stagnate by that time.

He said Su met with Beijing's point man in his capacity as the personal representative of the ROC president and later reported to Lee the contents of the discussion. Lee noted that Su never divulged any state secrets nor compromised the island's security in any way during his meetings with his Beijing counterparts.

Before calling on Lee, the three-member panel from the Control Yuan, with Lee Shen-yi as its head, had already interviewed Su and Cheng Shu-min, one of Lee Teng-hui's cronies who accompanied Su on many of the secret missions.
The panel had also consulted Ting Yu-chou, director of the National Security Bureau before talking with Lee Teng-hui.
The China Times quoted Lee Shen-yi as saying that his panel is inclined to clear Lee Teng-hui of any charges of irregularities in connection with his secret contacts with Beijing.
The incident came to light last July after an man who claimed to have brokered the first secret meeting came clean to a local news weekly on his role as a go-between for such contacts.

Lee Teng-hui's critics at the Legislative Yuan immediately asked the Control Yuan to look into the revelation, claiming that the former president had violated existing laws which prohibited senior government officials from visiting mainland China and that Su might have betrayed national secrets during his talks with Beijing emissaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T VOWS TO FIGHT LEGISLATOR-INITIATED "PORK-BARREL" BILLS

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will take pains to scuttle five bills pending in the Legislative Yuan which will tax the government's coffers, said Lin Chuan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan.

In an interview published by the China Times on Sunday, Lin branded the five legislator-initiated bills as pork barrel politics, saying they are controversial, unfair and deviating from social justice because they are aimed at benefiting constituents of legislators who face elections at the end of the year.
He warned the five bills will cost the government about an extra NT$5 trillion (US$153.84 billion), which he said will only worsen the government's already tight budget situation.

The bills the Executive Yuan is aiming to sink include one to compensate government employees who retired after 1970, one to dredge the Keelung River, a bill to compensate landlords whose land was appropriated for roads, an anti-cancer bill which will require the government to earmark NT$2 billion (US$62.5 million) per year for the prevention and treatment of cancer, and a bill to offer pensions to veterans of the mainland Chinese shelling of Kinmen on Aug. 23, 1958.
He blamed legislators for initiating bills aimed at winning the hearts of their constituents with an eye on the scheduled year-end elections.
As a result, Lin said, the capital outlay is accounting for an ever-shrinking share of the government's budget which will inevitably damage the country's economy and competitiveness in the long term.
Lin warned that the country's finances could collapse if the five bills in their present form are approved by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WTO ENTRY'S NEGATIVE IMPACT ON AGRI-SECTOR SAID UNDERESTIMATED

TEXT.P: The impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization on the island's agricultural sector will be far more serious than originally estimated, the nation's top agricultural official said Sunday.

Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA), said Taiwan's bid to enter the WTO will lower the value of the island's agricultural production, with losses due to WTO entry surpassing the original estimate of NT$50 billion (US$1.51 billion).

Chen said that "the actual number will probably go beyond" the original estimate, and that if the situation goes on, Taiwan's agricultural sector could face unprecedented challenges in four or five years time.

The COA, in anticipation of the nation's entry into the world trade regulatory body, has mapped out a strategy and an assessment of the overall impact and also the impact on individual industries. It recently revised these assessments again.

Chen also estimated that within four years of Taiwan's WTO entry, at least 100,000 people in the agricultural sector will have to shift to other forms of employment, stressing that agricultural sector workers having to shift to new jobs has occurred in Taiwan in the past without posing too many problems.

But he did say he still has some concerns about the joblessness that will occur in the agriculture sector, saying he laments the fact that this sector's role of releasing workers for or absorbing workers from traditional industries has disappeared with the transformation of Taiwan's social and agricultural structure.

As a result, he said, with the present sluggish economic situation, those who now lose their jobs in tradition industries will not be able to shift to agriculture which, along with the estimated 20,000 to 30,000 who are expected to lose their jobs in the agricultural sector with Taiwan's WTO entry, will result in more alarming jobless rates

Chen said that he has observed that Taiwan's economy has entered into a very dangerous situation and that if no "high doses of medicine are administered" and if no drastic measures are applied, then the economy will likely fall into a quandary that will not be able to be reversed.

Chen's remarks followed a meeting convened by President Chen Shui-bian Saturday during which he invited financial and economic leaders to discuss the current economic situation and national economic development directions and policy. Those attending also discussed Taiwan's financial sector, foreign laborers, and the expected increased jobless rate after WTO entry.
The COA was also invited to attend the meeting to present its ideas on Taiwan's economy and agricultural sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL PITCHES FOR TAIWAN'S KNOWLEDGE ECONOMY PROGRAM
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 7 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The knowledge economy program laid down by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) will make Taiwan a fully-developed country within ten years, said CEPD head Lin Po-chih in Los Angeles Saturday.

In a speech at a Taiwan-United States forum on science, Lin said the program launched in January is aimed at tapping the experience and skills of many talented Chinese living in Taiwan or the United States for the economic development of the Republic of China.

Noting that Taiwan businesspeople have invested more than US$100 billion in mainland China, Southeast Asia and other places around the world, Lin said Taiwan authorities are working hard to make a network out of these Taiwan businesspeople's production points and to harness it with international capital to develop a knowledge economy.
Taiwan's efforts to make the island a global logistic center is part of the knowledge economy program, said Lin.
He urged the symposium attendants, mainly ethnic Chinese scientists and technologists, to help upgrade Taiwan's economy with their expertise.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA LAUDS CONTRIBUTIONS MADE BY MASTER CHENG YEN

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama on Sunday praised the contributions Buddhist Master Cheng Yen has made to society through her compassion, mercy and fearless care for the needy.

The Tibetan leader made the remarks while meeting with one of Taiwan's Buddhist leaders, Master Cheng Yen, who is also founder of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, in a hospital patronized by the foundation in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.

More than 100 Tzu Chi Foundation volunteers, doctors and nurses of the hospital, excited by having the chance to meet simultaneously the two religious leaders, rushed to welcome the Dalai Lama and Master Cheng Yen in the lobby of the hospital.
Some people said emotionally that they felt very fortunate to have the opportunity to meet the two Buddhist leaders at the same time.
After hearing a report made by the hospital's president about the work done by the hospital and the Tzu Chi Foundation, the Dalai Lama said he saw the mercy in all the work done by the foundation.

He added that he had always thought Catholicism had made more of a contribution to Taiwan society than Buddhism, saying he has a new outlook after finding out about the work of the Tzu Chi Foundation.

The foundation, which takes charity, medicine, education, and culture as its four main missions, extends love and substantial assistance to wherever it is needed through its hundreds of thousands of volunteers scattered around the world.

Although obtaining handsome financial support from all walks of life, the prestigious nun and her followers still earn money cent by cent, making hand-made craft products such as candles and baby shoes to maintain their living.
Now Tzu Chi has branches all over Taiwan and has opened liaison offices in more than 20 countries and areas around the world.

Master Cheng Yen told the Dalai Lama that she began her charity work by offering financial support to the poor but later found the poor and the sick are always linked closely, so she said she later had the idea of establishing hospitals for the poor and needy.

The Dalai Lama noted that Tzu Chi has made contributions that go beyond religion, race and national borders, saying he is happy to see the mercy which Tzu Chi shows through its charitable work. The Tibetan leader also praised the efforts Tzu Chi has made towards environmental protection, which he said is an area few people pay attention to.
The Dalai Lama arrived in Taipei March 31 for a 10-day "religious trip" at the invitation of the Chinese Buddhist Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN WARNS BEIJING AGAINST REFUSING TO RETURN CREW
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Henry Hyde (R-Il), head of the U. S. House International Relations Committee, warned Beijing Saturday that the crisis will intensify if it refuses to return the 24-member crew of the U.S. surveillance plane that collided with a mainland Chinese jetfighter.
Commenting during a CNN talk show, Hyde said that "if we get into the middle of next week and the personnel are still being held, the intensity of this and the danger escalates."

Hyde was referring to the collision that occurred a week ago over the South China Sea that forced a U.S. Navy aircraft to make an emergency landing on Hainan Island. The plane and its crew are now being held by mainland Chinese authorities.

He claimed that "I don't think expressing regret over the death of the pilot, the Chinese pilot, shows weakness. It shows humanity. I think we have many ways of showing that we're not weak. One of them is the weapons that we are going to provide Taiwan with in a couple of weeks. They don't want the Aegis system sold and other weapons. We can do that."

"We can slow down the process whereby China wants to be admitted to the World Trade Organization. China wants the Olympic Games in 2008. There are resolutions in Congress objecting to that. There are lots of things we can do if we are driven to do them. I just think that China ought to calm down and end this," Hyde added.

"I think our responsibility under the Taiwan Relations Act is to provide Taiwan with adequate and appropriate assets to defend itself against a possible attack from mainland China. And that obligation persists, whether or not our 24 crewmen get returned or not. I think that decision should be made independently of what is going on in Hainan right now," the congressmen pointed out.

When asked whether the decision should be positive as far as selling the Aegis destroyers to Taiwan, Hyde replied that "I do, but I would leave that to the technical people. And I don't think what's going on in Hainan right now is very encouraging in terms of discouraging us from selling them the more sensitive equipment."

Regarding the question of whether he will oppose the United States maintaining permanent normal trade relations status for mainland China if Beijing fails to meet the requirements for entrance into the World Trade Organization this year, Hyde said his inclination is to oppose it now.

"I have supported it in the past, in the expectation that China would reduce its human rights abuses and that things would improve. I don't see that happening at all. On the contrary, I see them exacerbated. Therefore, I would need some persuasive arguments to move me to support again most-favored-nation status for China.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEART FULL OF PLEASURE BEST ANTI-CANCER MEDICINE: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that a heart full of pleasure is the best medicine against cancer.
Chen made the remarks while attending the inauguration of Taiwan's Anti-Cancer Federation on Sunday.
He called on the public to love life, exercise, and eat five kinds of fruit and vegetables every day to guard against cancer.

Seventeen local anti-cancer groups on Sunday launched an anti-cancer rally at the plaza in front of the Taipei City Government quarters. Those participating chanted slogans such as "eat five types of fruit and vegetables every day" and "Go! Go! Go!"
Rally activities included free checkups and the providing of free anti-cancer information. More than 1,000 citizens participated in the rally.

Cancer has been among the top ten killers in Taiwan for each of the past 19 years. In order to provide local people with anti-cancer information, 17 local anti-cancer groups, including the Taiwan Cancer Foundation, the Liver Disease Prevention Foundation and the Kangtai Medical and Educational Foundation, formed the Taiwan Anti-Cancer Federation.

Sunday's activities hit at climax at about 1:30 p.m. with President Chen Shui-bian presenting an anti-cancer federation flag to Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, in his capacity as board chairman of the Taiwan Cancer Foundation.
The rally participants then paraded through the main streets of Taipei to pray for the health of the people of Taiwan.

In related news, Prof. Lin Jen-hun of the Medical College of National Taiwan University said at the Fifth Asian Clinical Tumor Academic Convention that Oolong tea, which contains theasineesin, can be helpful in stopping cancer cells from multiplying in the body.
Meanwhile, Prof. Han Jui of China Medical College in mainland China said that Ginseng is effective in preventing cancer from occurring.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFITABILITY OF STATE-OWNED FIRMS QUESTIONED ON EVE OF BUDGET REVIEW

TEXT.P: A legislator from the opposition New Party (NP) pointed out Sunday that the overall profit rate of state-owned enterprises has dropped sharply over the years.
NP Legislator Lai Shyh-bao made the remarks on the eve of the review of the budget of state-owned enterprises for this fiscal year by the Legislative Yuan.

Lai said that state-owned enterprises have accumulated unpaid debts of nearly NT$700 billion (US$21.27 billion) and that their operational losses have surpassed NT$100 billion (US$ 3.04 billion). Of the 36 state-owned enterprises, 19 recorded a profitability of less than five percent.

Lai said that state-owned enterprises used to be a major source of government funds but have turned from a cash cow to a money pit in recent years, with more than 90 percent of them actually becoming a drain on government coffers. He added that the government needs to address the problem.

Lai urged the ruling party not to set its eyes only on the "lucrative" state-owned enterprises, but to also take on the debt-ridden state-owned enterprises, such as Taiwan Chung Hsing Paper Corp., Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp. and China Shipbuilding Corp., to display its management abilities. Elections of the board directors and supervisors for these enterprises should also be made more transparent, Lai added.

He noted that the unpaid debts of the 36 state-owned enterprises have run up to NT$687.7 billion so far this year, noting that this is up NT$113.2 billion over that of the end of last year. Among the 36 enterprises, more than one third have suffered from long-term losses.

He also pointed out that the profits of state-owned enterprises have continued to slip, with the accumulated profits dropping to NT$208.6 billion this year from NT$325.4 billion last year and falling to 7.49 percent of total government revenues from 11.1 percent in 1995.

Moreover, most of those profits, or 79 percent of the total, have come from the mostly monopoly state-owned enterprises such as the Central Bank of China, Bank of Taiwan, Taiwan Power Co. and Chung Hwa Telecom, showing that the rest of the state-owned businesses have been incapable of replenishing government coffers.

He also noted that total expenditures by state-owned enterprises are forecast to be NT$2,530 billion in the new fiscal year, saying he intends to slash about NT$143.2 billion, or 5.6 percent, from that bloated figure.
He pointed out that public relations and advertising fees have become bloated and that personnel costs should also be slashed.

Lai also questioned the budget presented by Taipower concerning the fourth nuclear power plant, saying that the budget states NT$3.5 billion (US$106.38 million) was lost during the almost four-month plant construction hiatus but that the budget has ballooned to NT$208.3 billion from the original estimate of NT$169.7 billion.
Lai pointed out that Taipower has failed to explain why it needs to increase the budget by NT$38.6 billion, saying he will rigorously review the budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA CONCERNED ABOUT TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama Sunday expressed the hope that political leaders of Taiwan will strengthen their cooperation in promoting economic development.

The Tibetan spiritual leader made the remarks when he met with Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh in a Buddhist temple near the city. He pointed out that the current economic situation is quite different from four years ago, when he visited Taiwan for the first time.

The Dalai Lama said he also expressed his concern about Taiwan's economy to President Chen Shui-bian and Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, when he visited them a few days ago. He arrived in Taipei on March 31 for a ten-day "religious visit."
The Tibetan spiritual leader is scheduled to leave Taiwan Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 9, or the 16th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the U.S. Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary U.S. citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the U.S. Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
2000: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center is inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA ENDS 10-DAY VISIT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama departed from Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung Monday for India after concluding his 10-day visit in Taiwan, the second of its kind since March 1997.
In a brief interview with reporters before boarding his early morning flight, the Dalai Lama described the past 10 days in Taiwan as a happy journey.

He said he found that Taiwan is a genuinely free and democratic society where not only politicians, but businesspeople and citizens of all walks of life truthfully voice their ideas and feelings about both "good and bad things."
The Tibetan god king, however, reminded people in Taiwan that whenever they state their views, their words should not run counter to their "moral obligations."
During his high-profile stay, the Dalai Lama preached the teachings of the Buddha at a two-day ceremony, which also featured an empowerment blessing ritual.

More than 20,000 people attended the ceremony, during which the Dalai Lama stressed the importance of cultivating an "awakened mind," describing this as a way of gaining happiness and parting with pain.
Although his trip was labeled as "strictly religious in nature," the Dalai Lama met with many political figures in Taiwan during his visit.

The Dalai Lama met with President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, former President Lee Teng-hui, and chairmen of Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang and People First Party for discussions on a wide range of topics.
He told President Chen that he is looking forward to having Tibetan students come to Taiwan to study Mandarin Chinese and to translate Tibetan Buddhist works into the language.
The Dalai Lama donated US$15,000 to the Taiwan public to help with reconstruction work in the area of central Taiwan that was ravaged by a devastating earthquake in September 1999.

He also met with prominent religious leaders in Taiwan, including Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation; Master Sheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist group Dharma Drum Mountain; and Dharma Master Hsin Tao, founder of the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Foundation and the Museum of World Religions.

Unexpectedly and pleasantly, the Dalai Lama received from the Central News Agency a set of file photos that included pictures of himself and the Tibetan people over the past sixty years. One of the pictures contained within the set shows the infant Dalai Lama in the arms of his mother along with his father and elder brother.
