DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 113.3 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 113.3 points to close at 5,401.83.
Market turnover amounted to NT$54.68 billion (US$1.66 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR DELINKING OF 'COLLISION' AND ARMS SALES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he earnestly hopes that the current U.S.-mainland China standoff over the military aircraft collision incident will not have any adverse impact on the U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with visiting U.S. Senator John D. Rockefeller (D-W.Va) at the Presidential Office.
"We are concerned about the 'collision' incident and are hopeful that the weeklong Washington-Beijing standoff over this matter can come to a close very soon," Chen told his guest.

It was the first time that President Chen has publicly touched on the issue regarding a midair collision between a U.S. EP-3 surveillance plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter over South China Sea April 1.
Chen expressed his hopes that the U.S. government can use wisdom to resolve the issue peacefully through diplomatic channels in the shortest possible period of time.

As the Republic of China and the United States are scheduled to discuss Taiwan's arms procurement plans for 2001 later this month, President Chen said he looks forward to see delinking of the "collision" incident and ROC-U.S. arms deals.

Chen went on to say that although Washington and Beijing have engaged in close exchanges over a long period of time and have taken some confidence-building measures (CBM), the military aircraft collision incident still took place.

"The event has given us a great lesson. As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has not forged any CBM, the consequences could be very grave if such a similar incident were to happen in the Taiwan Strait," Chen said, adding that he sees an urgent need for Taiwan and mainland China to craft out a CBM mechanism.

Chen further said he is very happy to see Rockefeller visit Taiwan again. He also expressed gratitude for Rockefeller's contribution to peace and security in the Taiwan Strait on behalf of the ROC government and people.

Noting that Rockefeller has often stood up for Taiwan's national cause at critical moments, Chen said the ROC government and people are grateful for the U.S. senator's contribution to Taiwan Strait peace and stability.
Chen said he is hopeful that Rockefeller can continue supporting the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer.
"When the WHO holds its annual congress in Geneva later this year, U.S. Congress members can exercise their clout to push other WHO member states to support our observer status bid," Chen said.
For his part, Rockefeller said he is also worrying about possible adverse effects of the ongoing U.S.-mainland China standoff over the "collision" incident on Taiwan-U.S. arms deals.
Rockefeller said he has expressed his concern to the U.S. executive branch and urged the Bush administration not to link arms sales consideration to the "collision" incident.

The senator further said he is willing to play an intermediary role between the United States and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and work for the development of constructive Taiwan-U.S.-mainland China relations.

Also present at the meeting were Raymond Burghardt, head of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, and ROC Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 113.3 points to close at 5,401.83.

Affected by negative reports concerning Motolora, the bourse opened at 5,476.75 and continued to go down due to a prevailing wait-and-see attitude on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 5,476.75 and 5,391.09 during trading.

A total of 1.63 billion stocks worth NT$54.68 billion (US$1.66 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.29 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$82.98 billion (US$2.53 billion).

All of the eight major stocks categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 3.5 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 2.5 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2.1 percent, electrical shares at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 428 to 111, with 48 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved down 111 points to close at 5,419, with 4,960 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May lost 105 points to finish at 5,415, with 82 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,530 for April, 5,520 for May, 5,562 for June, 5,530 for September, and 5,587 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
April TE futures lost 5.95 points to finish at 267.8, with 1,163 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved down 9.2 points to close at 266.8, with six contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 19.4 points to close at 725.2, with 525 contract transactions, while May TF futures lost 25.4 points to finish at 727.6, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISM INDUSTRY FACING UNBALANCED DEVELOPMENT: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan said Monday that Taiwan's tourism industry is now facing the problem of unbalanced development.

Noting that the number of Taiwan tourists visiting abroad is more than double the number of foreigner tourists visiting the island, the CEPD said the government should not only establish a partnership with the people in order to boost investment in tourism, but also ease related laws to allow the tourism sector contributing to the island's economic development.

According to the CEPD, Taiwan has focused almost exclusively on the development of sightseeing areas, while neglecting the potential of the island's rich culture and natural beauty in attracting foreign tourists.

Developing Taiwan's recreation industry would boost businesses related to transportation, communications, entertainment, sightseeing, dining, and accommodations, all of which would have a positive impact on the island's economic growth and also on its employment rate, according to CEPD.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC VICE PRESIDENT PASSES AWAY

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Vice President Shieh Tung-min passed away Sunday night at his home in a suburb of Taipei from cardial infarction. He was 95.

Shieh was sent to Veterans General Hospital this past Chinese New Year Eve, which fell on Jan. 23, because of a mild cardial infarction and upper respiratory tract infection. His condition had fluctuated between good or bad, but he lapsed into coma and his heart stopped beating after congenic shock Sunday. His condition then steadily worsened despite emergency treatment.

After communicating with the hospital, Shieh's family decided to check him out voluntarily and return him home as is the custom of most Chinese. He passed away peacefully, surrounded by his family members and monks who recited Buddhist scriptures at his bedside.
Doctors at Veterans General Hospital said that Shieh used to suffer from high blood pressure, diabetes, gout and mild renal insufficiency.
President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, and other KMT leaders all paid their respects to Hsieh's family after hearing the news.

The president and vice president lauded Shieh as the embodiment figure in Taiwan's construction history and said that his contributions would remain in the hearts of the people of Taiwan. They especially noted that during his tenure as the Taiwan provincial governor, he advocated cottage industries, supported the domestic processing of agricultural products, took care of low-income families, and cracked down on superstitious beliefs.

Shieh, who was the first Taiwanese to serve as Taiwan provincial governor and vice president, played a major role in Taiwan's modern history. He was born Jan. 25, 1907, in Changhua, central Taiwan. He went to the mainland to study in his youth because Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial rule at the time. He only returned to Taiwan after the island returned to the fold of its motherland in 1945.

Mild, graceful and unassuming, he had served at different times as Kaohsiung county magistrate, director of the Department of Civil Affairs, and speaker of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly. The time he served in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly was a major factor in catapulting him into a career in politics.

Shieh was assigned to serve as Taiwan provincial governor in 1972 by then Premier Chiang Ching-kuo, thereby becoming Taiwan's first civilian governor. Before him, all Taiwan provincial governors had come from military backgrounds.

As Taiwan provincial governor, he advocated the development of grass-roots level politics. In order to listen to the voice of the people at the grass-roots level, he would often make sudden visits to local places, heading to almost every small town and village in Taiwan at one time or another during his six-year tenure.

A package bomb sent to his office Oct. 10, 1966, blew up, breaking his left hand and injuring his right hand. The man who sent the bomb to highlight the cause of Taiwan independence was Wang Sing-nan, presently a legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Considered as one of the elites of Taiwan, he assumed the position of vice president in 1978 to help then President Chiang Ching-kuo. After stepping down from that post in 1984, he continued to command respect from within the then ruling Kuomintang. Shieh was one of the KMT heavyweights who often helped coordinate the fierce intraparty strife over different policy lines and ideals during President Lee Teng-hui's reign as the party chairman.

Shieh's son, Shieh Mung-shiung, and daughter-in-law, Helen Lin (Lin Chen-chi), are now also active in politics, with the former serving as a member of the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, and the latter serving as the first female vice chairman of the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN TRADE DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A 20-member investment and trade promotion delegation led by Governor Rosihan Arsyad of Indonesia's South Sumatra Province is scheduled to arrive in Taipei Tuesday for a three-day visit.

The delegation, consisting of provincial government officials and entrepreneurs, will hold a briefing on trade and investment opportunities in South Sumatra at the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) the following day.

Members of the delegation will also visit the Taiwan fisheries Research Institute in Keelung, the Taiwan Livestock Products Research Institute and other agricultural and industrial facilities in Ilan County during their stay in Taiwan.
The group will leave for Singapore Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER WARNS OF POSSIBLE LAYOFFS, PAY-CUTS, CLOSURES

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi called for debt-ridden state-owned enterprises to accelerate the rejuvenation of their operations and structures in order to survive competition.
"Otherwise," Lin noted, "I do not exclude the possibility that they may face possible layoffs, salary cuts and even closures as a result of their business failures."

The economics minister made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan at a Budget and Final Accounts Committee hearing, where legislators reviewed the budget of state-owned enterprises for this fiscal year.

In addition to Lin, who is chairman of the Commission of National Corporations (CNC), CNC Vice Chairman Lin Wen-yuan and chairmen and executive directors of the 12 state-run enterprises under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) were also present at the budget review session.

In response to criticism lodged by New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao Sunday that 90 percent of state-run enterprises have become a drain on government coffers, CNC Vice Chairman Lin Wen-yuan said most of the 36 state-owned enterprises have begun their respective rejuvenation plans.

For example, he noted, staff and employees of China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) have agreed to have their salaries cut and also to have some workers laid off, while Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp. (TMMC) has agreed to be merged with money-making China Steel Corp. Under the merger plan, China Steel Corp. will take in some 170 TMMC employees, according to Lin.

He said personnel salaries and payments are the major cost of every state-owned business in Taiwan, noting that CSBC spends twice as much in this area than its privately-run counterparts and eight to 10 times more than its mainland Chinese counterparts.
Lowering personnel costs is the first step for CSBC in sharpening its competitive edge, he noted.

In a budget review meeting held Sunday, New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said state-owned enterprises used to be a major source of government funds but have turned from a cash cow to a money pit in recent years.

Lai said that state-owned enterprises have accumulated unpaid debts of nearly NT$700 billion (US$21.27 billion) and that their operational losses have surpassed NT$100 billion (US$3.04 billion). Of Taiwan's 36 state-owned firms, 19 recorded a profitability of less than 5 percent, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS MINISTERS OVER ELECTION IRREGULARITIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met with various ministers Monday for discussions on how to eradicate money politics and vote-buying from Taiwan and on ways to prevent gangland figures from being elected to public office.
Chen said one of the major tasks of his administration since he assumed office in May 2000 has been to improve Taiwan's "macroenvironment."

To achieve that goal, he noted, the government should draw up concrete measures and effective strategies to correct disputable election irregularities, eradicate vote-buying and bar underworld figures from taking part in politics.
Completing the tasks this year is essential, he went on, as the important legislative, mayoral and county chief elections are scheduled to be held in December.

The president made the remarks during a breakfast meeting with Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, Coast Guard Administrator Wang Chun, Central Election Commission Chairman Huang Shih-cheng and Hsu Chen-kuang, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE SHIP MAKES 1ST DIRECT VOYAGE UNDER `MINI 3 LINKS' PROGRAM

TEXT.P: A privately owned ship made a direct voyage from the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen to the southeastern mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen Monday, marking yet another step forward in the "mini three links" program.

It was the first time that a private boat had been allowed to sail directly to Xiamen since Taiwan opened direct trade, mail and shipping links between its two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian Province -- commonly known as the "mini three links" -- at the beginning of this year.
The 3,500-ton Kinmen Marine Transport Co.-owned ship carried 295 Kinmen residents to Xiamen for a five-day package tour, which also includes paying respects to their ancestors.

Since Jan. 1, Kinmen county government-run ferry boats have made 10 direct voyages to Xiamen. Lin Chen-cha, director of the county government's Tourism Bureau, said he is very pleased to see a private shipping firm join the direct Kinmen-Xiamen shipping service.
"We believe that the move will help turn a new page for the development of the `mini three links' program," Lin said.
As mainland China has been reluctant to take active steps to facilitate the Taiwan-initiated program, most local private shipping firms have stayed on the sidelines and have not entered the market.

Kinmen Marine Transport Co. Chairman Yang Su-yuan said many obstacles still stand in the way of direct Kinmen-Xiamen shipping services. For one thing, he said, mainland China has not yet given the green light to regular direct shipping services and has instead approved relevant applications on a case-by-case basis only.

Moreover, Yang said, current ROC regulations demand that all Xiamen-bound visitors abide by the principle of "group in, group out," while Kinmen is still banned from acting as a "transit center" for indirect transport services between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"These restrictions have discouraged private ship owners from edging into the Kinmen-Xiamen direct shipping market," Yang explained, adding he hopes that Taiwan and the mainland can sit down to hammer out a mechanism to let the "mini three links" program really take off.
Even though mainland China approved the privately owned ship's direct voyage to Xiamen, it rejected entry permit applications from two of those who had hoped to make the trip.

The two prospective visitors were Kinmen County Councilor Chen Shui-su and Chen Chang-chiang, a commissioner of the ROC's Fukien Provincial Government Commission, which oversees civilian affairs administration on Kinmen and Matsu.
Chen Chang-chiang said he believed mainland China rejected his visit mainly because he is a member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, also the ROC's current ruling party.

For his part, Kinmen County Councilor Chen Shui-su said he had no idea why his application had been denied, as he had already made a direct voyage to Xiamen along with a county council delegation early this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW EPA DEPUTY ADMINISTRATOR APPOINTED

TEXT.P: The head of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced Monday that he has picked a university professor to be his deputy in charge of administrative affairs.

EPA Administrator Hao Lung-ping told a press conference that Premier Chang Chun-hsiun verbally approved last Friday the nomination of Chang Tzu-en, deputy dean of National Cheng Kung University's (NCKU) College of Engineering and that he will assume his duties when the relevant paperwork is complete.

Chang, 50, has done considerable research in waste disposal, recycling and water pollution control. He received his bachelor's and master's degrees from Cheng Kung University's Department of Civil Engineering and later earned his doctorate in the same field in Japan. He has served as the deputy director of the Comprehensive Planning Bureau under the EPA and has been teaching at NCKU for 20 years.

At the press conference, Hao pointed out that Taiwan has had a long-term waste disposal problem due to incomplete laws regarding waste control and management. He added his hope that several newly established garbage disposal sites can become operational by next April.
Hao also said that the approximately 170 illegal garbage dumps and disposal sites must be brought under control, adding that he is looking forward to Chang's help in solving the problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CALLS FOR `BILINGUAL ENVIRONMENT' FOR CITY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Monday called on the city government to create a "bilingual environment" for Taipei by adding English to the signs in Taipei's bus stations, parks and government facilities.

The Taipei city government has also proposed enhancing the bilingual environment by establishing Chinese-English official websites. Under the plan, the name plates of all Taipei city government officials should be bilingual; important regulations and city government activities should be explained in English brochures; and different departments of the city government should have English-speaking personnel to answer inquiries from foreign nationals.

Describing translation work as being "as complex as editing a dictionary," Ma said the city government should emulate the work already done in this area by the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. and the Taipei Fine Arts Museum.
Ma added that from September, Taiwan children are to begin learning English from third grade.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SPOUSES CAN APPLY TO WORK FROM WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) unveiled Monday a package of regulations governing work permit applications by mainland Chinese spouses of Republic of China citizens.
A CLA spokesman said the council formulated the package based on a revised bill to the existing statute governing relations between the people of Taiwan and mainland China.

The revision, promulgated by the Executive Yuan Feb. 20, allows mainland spouses of local citizens to work in Taiwan under certain conditions. In the past, mainland spouses were completely banned from taking jobs here.
The spokesman said the CLA will begin to accept work permit applications by mainland spouses from Wednesday, as long as the applicants have legal residency status.

Moreover, the applicants must produce official documents proving that their Taiwan spouses come from low-income families, are aged 65 or older, are mentally or physically disabled, or are suffering from serious diseases or injuries.
The CLA unveiled the new regulations after opposition lawmakers recently criticized a continued police crackdown on employed mainland spouses, even after the Cabinet promulgated the revised bill.

Opposition New Party Legislator Lai Shyh-bao quoted Bureau of Immigration statistics as showing that from Jan. 1 to March 19, 346 mainland spouses were expelled for working illegally in Taiwan. Among them, 68 were expelled after Feb. 20, when the Executive Yuan promulgated the revised bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO ADOPT RELAXED CURRENCY POLICY

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) will not follow Japan in adopting a zero interest rate, but it will adopt a more relaxed currency policy since domestic prices are stable and domestic demand has yet to fully recover, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said Monday.
Perng made the remarks as he fielded questions in the Legislative Yuan, where the committees were reviewing the part of the CBC budget under the overall review of the central government budget.
Legislators Lin Wen-lang and Chien Hsi-chieh expressed concern about the slowdown in the economy and expressed the hope that the CBC will adopt substantial measures to deal with the situation.
Perng noted that the CBC has cut interest rates four times since the end of last year to stimulate the economy, but he said that it may take some time to see the effects of the moves.
The depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar was also a focus of concern among the legislators.
Perng said that with the fluctuation of the global financial situation, the exchange rate should be kept flexible to avoid the risk of being ambushed by speculators.
He also said that the CBC will let the exchange rate of the new Taiwan dollar be decided by market demand and that the CBC will only intervene when there are seasonal, occasional or erratic factors.

Perng said that there are three favorable factors that will help stabilize the local currency -- the balance of payments is good; foreign currency deposits in the private sector amount to between US$34 billion and US$35 billion; and importers have made big purchases of U.S. dollars in anticipation of the depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar, while local demand for foreign currency is not strong at present.
Perng also dismissed fears that the CBC's plan to issue NT$2,000 bills will trigger inflation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM PRESIDES OVER OATH-TAKING CEREMONY FOR NEW OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao presided over an oath-taking ceremony Monday for three newly appointed officials.

The officials are Charles Teng, director-general of the Records & Data Processing Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA); Liu Chen-kun, ROC representative to Nigeria; and Felipe Wang, ROC representative to Uruguay.
Teng, a graduate of National Chengchi University, is a career diplomat who has held many important posts, including ROC representative to Austria and ROC representative to New York.

Liu, a graduate of National Taiwan University, obtained a master's degree in diplomacy from Georgetown University in the United States. He is a former deputy director-general of MOFA's African Affairs Department.
Wang who obtained a master's degree on diplomacy from National Chengchi University, is a former counselor in political affairs at the ROC embassy in Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO `DECIDE FOR ITSELF' ON VISA FOR FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Tokyo will decide for itself whether or not to issue a visa to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, a spokesman for the Japanese government said Monday.

Speaking at a news conference, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda said that he has no knowledge about any information related to a visa application by Lee. "But if Lee files such an application, the Japanese government will make a decision on the issue `subjectively,'" he said.
Sources close to outgoing Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori have said that the Japanese government, through unofficial channels, is studying the possibility of Lee visiting Japan.

There have also been media reports that the former ROC president wishes to visit Japan for medical treatment for heart problems after he returns from a visit to his alma meter -- Cornell University in the United States -- late this month.

The sole major barrier to Lee's Japan visit is Beijing, which has repeatedly demanded that Tokyo deny a visa to the former head of state of Taiwan, which it considers a part of mainland China's territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PROSECUTION DROPS CHARGES AGAINST CAL STAFF OVER 1994 CRASH
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japanese prosecutors have once again decided to drop criminal charges against four Japan-based staff members of Taiwan's China Airlines (CAL) over a 1994 plane crash at Nagoya airport in central Japan, sources said Monday.

According to the sources, the Nagoya District Prosecutor's Office has informed relatives of Japanese victims of the crash of a CAL Airbus A-320 of its decision to stop its probe into alleged malfeasance charges against four staff members at CAL's Nagoya office.

After extensive investigations, the prosecutor's office said it could not find sufficient evidence to justify negligence or malfeasance charges against the CAL ground service staff over the crash, which killed 264 passengers and crew members. Only seven people aboard the ill-fated plane survived.

Japanese investigators said in March 1999 that they found the pilot and co-pilot of the plane had committed crucial errors that resulted in the crash. However, as both of them died in the crash, Japanese prosecutors decided not to indict them posthumously.
The prosecutor's office then began to probe whether four CAL staff members, including Chang Kuang-feng, then-deputy head of the CAL Nagoya office, should be held responsible for the tragic incident.
In January 2000, the prosecutor's office decided for the first time not to indict the CAL staff on the grounds that no convincing evidence could be found that would prove their roles in the tragedy.
However, higher-level Nagoya prosecution authorities disagreed with the decision and demanded that the district prosecutor's office reopen its probe into the case.

After an additional year of investigations, Nagoya prosecutors came to the conclusion recently that there are practical difficulties involved in probing the CAL staff's responsibilities in the crash and that this time, the decision to drop charges against the CAL staff would be final, prosecution sources said.
The CAL office in Nagoya declined to comment on the decision, saying that it has not received formal notice from the Nagoya District Prosecutor's Office.

Relatives of about 160 Japanese crash victims have filed a suit with the Nagoya District Court seeking some US$257 million in damages from CAL. The court is still handling the case -- the biggest single damages suit in connection with an air crash in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO SPEND US$ 403.1 M TO SUBSIDIZE RICE FARMERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is to spend just NT$12.9 billion (US$403.1 million) this year to help local rice farmers cope with Taiwan's World Trade Organization (WTO) entry, COA Chairman Chen Hsi-hung announced Monday.
Chen made the announcement at the Legislative Yuan while briefing legislators on the compiling of the budget for departments attached to the COA.
The Legislative Yuan later passed the fiscal 2001 budget plan for departments attached to the COA.

However, the COA, Taiwan's top agriculture policy planning body, estimated that during the first year of Taiwan's WTO membership, NT$40 billion will be needed to subsidize local farmers for the losses they will suffer due to imports of foreign agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD STRENGTHEN HOT SPRING PROMOTION: VP

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Monday that Taiwan's hot spring industry should strengthen international exchanges so as to bring the industry to the attention of the international community.
Lu made the remarks while receiving Guy Ebrard, honorary president of the Federation Mondiale Du Thermalisme Et Du Climatisme (FEMTEC) and Vice President Jean-Luc Thonnat at the Presidential Office.
They are in Taiwan for an eight-day visit at the invitation of the Taiwan Hot Spring Association.
Noting that FEMTEC is a non-government organization recognized by the World Health Organization (WHO), Lu called on her visitors to help Taiwan's hot spring industry join FEMTEC as soon as possible.
She said that the Taiwan hot spring industry is an important source of revenue for the tourism industry but still has great untapped potential.

She stressed that the local hot spring industry should cooperate with the government to promote international exchanges and praised efforts made by FEMTEC to promote the medical properties of hot springs.
Meanwhile, Chen Chun-ting, deputy general secretary of the Taiwan Hot Spring Association, said that Taiwan is expected to join FEMTEC within the next two years.
Founded in 1938, the organization originally included hot springs in Europe and did not expand to a world-wide organization until 1976. FEMTEC now has some 30 country and regional members.

Ebrard and Thonnat will take part in a national hot spring meeting Wednesday and will hold a symposium with officials of the Cabinet-level Department of Health and the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transport and Communications Friday. They will deliver a speech on hot springs and their curative properties Sunday and will also visit a number of local hot springs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT LINKS NOT `DOMESTIC ROUTES': PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Direct links between Taiwan and mainland China could be designated as "cross-Taiwan Strait" routes rather than the term "domestic routes" as previously demanded by Beijing, People First Party (PFP) lawmaker Liu Song-pan said Monday.

Speaking at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan to report on a recent six-day fact-finding trip to mainland China by a PFP delegation, Liu said that this was the consensus reached during a round of talks with mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

Liu, heading a six-member PFP delegation, returned to Taipei last Friday following visits to Beijing, Tianjin and Xian to gauge mainland China's position and viewpoints regarding the establishment of full trade, transport and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China.

According to the power broker who served as the former legislative speaker, the PFP lawmakers, through arrangements by Beijing's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, also discussed the "full three links" issue with many mainland Chinese officials from different government organizations.

But he pointed out that no agreement or consensus was made until the meeting with Qian, as the mainland Chinese side had until that point insisted on making the two-way "direct three links" a domestic issue under the "one China" precondition.
Liu said the PFP delegation expressed its refusal to accept the "one China" stance and achieved a breakthrough on the issue when Qian finally agreed not to insist on the "difficulty."

According to Liu, vessels of either side sailing between Taiwan proper and mainland China would not have to fly any flags in the future. He noted that the establishment of the so-called cross-strait transport links could be handled based on the Hong Kong model, under which bilateral negotiations can be commissioned to the private sector.

As to the question of Taiwan's fear that farm products from mainland China will have a heavy impact on the local agricultural industry after both sides join the World Trade Organization, Liu said Qian also agreed to consider a proposal that mainland China could take the initiative to set up a quota system to limit its agricultural exports to Taiwan.

As one of Taiwan's main opposition parties rather than the ruling party, however, the PFP has no authority to make policy decisions with mainland officials, so the consensus reached with Qian was purely hypothetical.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR DROPS CHARGES AGAINST FORMER PRESIDENTIAL AIDES

TEXT.P: Two confidants of former President Lee Teng-hui were cleared Monday by a local prosecutor of giving away state secrets.

The prosecutor said in her ruling that there is no evidence Su Chih-cheng, Lee's personal secretary, and Cheng Su-ming, a former executive at a local television station, gave away state secrets during secret encounters with Beijing emissaries in Hong Kong and mainland China.

Su had allegedly told his Beijing counterparts during one such encounter that Taiwan would agree to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) under the name of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu Customs Area.

Su's critics at the Legislative Yuan accused him of leaking the government's bottom line in its pursuit of WTO access, a crime punishable under the Criminal Code, and that his visit to mainland China was prohibited by the National Security Law owing to his senior rank in the government hierarchy.

However, the prosecutor accepted Su's arguments that the fact that Taiwan would settle for WTO membership with the name of a customs zone rather than its official name was made public in early 1990, well before his meetings with Beijing's point man in Hong Kong.
"Classified information, once divulged, is no longer secret or protected under the Criminal Code," said the prosecutor, citing a decision by the Supreme Court as grounds to dismiss the charge.

As for the National Security Law which prohibits officials of Su's rank from visiting mainland China, the prosecutor noted that it was promulgated in 1996, and thereby cannot be applied retroactively to activity that took place prior to 1996.

Acting on the orders of then-President Lee, Su met with Beijing representatives secretly in Hong Kong and mainland China between September 1987 and December 1993, in the hope of creating a climate favorable to open bilateral dialogue, according to the prosecutor's investigation.

Secret contacts through emissaries is normal diplomatic practice followed by many states and a vital means toward easing the tension between Taiwan and mainland China in light of the long-standing rivalry and the absence of official ties between the two sides, the prosecutor said in her ruling.
She also noted that Lee was interviewed in late March as a witness in the case and that his testimony substantiated Su's protestation of innocence.
Cheng, who accompanied Su on his secret mission as a cover, was also acquitted of the charges.

Lee's secret contacts with Beijing leaders came to light in July 2000 when a self-proclaimed go-between claimed credit for brokering the encounters and broke the information to a local magazine, creating an outcry among ROC politicians.

Lee's political rivals from the island's pro-reunification camp, which are often denounced by Lee's supporters as traitors, turned the tables on Lee by accusing Su and Cheng of selling out the island with Lee's connivance.
They filed a complaint against Su and Cheng with the Taipei Prosecutors' Office, and asked the Control Yuan for an investigation into the former president for good measure.
Although the Control Yuan has yet to finish its probe, Sunday's China Times quoted a Control Yuan official as hinting that it intends to clear the former president of any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA WILL ACT TO REMOVE OBSTACLES TO INVESTMENT, SAYS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday that his ministry will set up an ad hoc committee this week to work out measures to encourage more investment in Taiwan.
"The new committee will be convened within one week to discuss measures for removing obstacles to investment," Lin told the Budget Committee of the Legislative Yuan.

Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chu Li-lun said at the Budget Committee meeting that the government should establish a cross-agency committee to attract more investment at a time when the island's economy is facing stagnation.
He even suggested that the minister head a mission abroad to woo foreign investment.
Lin later told reporters that the ad hoc committee is being formed by the Industrial Development and Investment Center and the Investment Commission, both under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

The new committee will communicate with foreign business organizations such as the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and the European Council of Commerce and Trade and will work out measures to reduce obstacles to foreign investment, Lin went on.
The minister noted that major local investment by domestic manufacturers this year is expected to reach NT$620 billion, of which NT$500 billion-worth of projects will be completed within this year.

Regarding investment by foreign businessmen, Lin said that the government will act to improve investment conditions, including labor quality, infrastructure and administrative efficiency, to compete with Singapore, Hong Kong and Thailand and attract more foreign investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTY HEADS CALL FOR LIFTING OF BAN ON MAINLAND CHINESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Heads of local governments in central Taiwan urged the central government Monday to lift a ban on mainland Chinese tourists as a way to boost the flagging local economy devastated by the Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake.

During the "Summit of Central Taiwan Leaders," staged in Nantou, heads of Nantou County, Taichung County, Changhua County and the deputy head of Taichung City joined business leaders from their constituencies in calling on the government to ease legal restrictions on mainland Chinese travelers to Taiwan.

Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien said that allowing mainland tourists to visit can deepen their understanding of Taiwan, while the cash they bring in would give the local economy a badly needed shot in the arm.
However, one of the priorities of the local governments is to restore fully the natural beauty of attractions in central Taiwan, such as Mount Ali and Sun Moon Lake, in order to draw in tourists.
He also called for the central government's help in the conclusion of sisterhood ties between Sun Moon Lake in Nantou and Xihu (West Lake) in Zhejiang Province, central China.

Changhua County Magistrate Juan Kang-meng blamed the central government's "long-standing neglect" of the island's central region for contributing to the area's faltering economy as much as the earthquake.
Chen Ta-chun, deputy mayor of Taichung City, called on the central government to open industrial zones in central Taiwan to mainland firms, to help local people upgrade their livelihoods.

In a related development, meanwhile, Huang Jung-chun, an executive director of the Sept. 21 Quake Aftermath Reconstruction Commission under the Executive Yuan, estimated at a symposium on promoting Nantou tourism that the tourism industry suffered damage worth more than NT$30 billion (US$937.5 million) in the 1999 earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELEGATES TO COUNCIL OF ASIAN OVERSEAS CHINESE GATHER IN OSAKA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chuan held a dinner party in Osaka Monday to welcome nearly 400 delegates to the conference of the Council of Asian Overseas Chinese.
The one-day conference was scheduled to take place Tuesday with the theme: "Greeting the new century, recognizing our country, serving the Chinese community, promoting diplomacy."
Written messages from ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will be read at the opening of the conference.

At the dinner party, Lo, on behalf of ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, expressed the ROC government's appreciation to overseas Chinese for their support for the government's efforts to promote external relations.
He also said that under Chen's leadership, the ROC government will continue to insist on engaging in cultural and economic exchanges with mainland China on the principles of democracy and equality.

Lo urged Beijing to pursue balanced development and to give up its arms race, and added that if the mainland fails to speed up the pace of its democratization, it will not be able to win the support of the Chinese people.

Other speakers at the dinner party included Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chairwoman Chang Fu-mei, Japanese Lower House member Akira Sato and officials from the Osaka Prefectural Government and Osaka City Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO REMOVE MINES FROM FRONTLINE ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Kinmen Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai urged the government Monday to do more to clear the thousands of mines scattered over Taiwan's offshore frontline islands.

In an interview with CNA, Chen said that mine clearing is a global trend, adding that with the advent of the cross-Taiwan Strait "three mini links," the government should consider more aggressive mine clearing operations to illustrate to the international community the Republic of China's determination to seek peace.
Chen said that the laying of land mines in Kinmen had its background in the era of cross-strait confrontation. However, he added, the mines have caused many deaths and injuries over the years.
Now that the cross-strait relationship has thawed, he went on, it is necessary for the government to review the issue of the mines.

Troops stationed on Kinmen began removing the mines in 1996 after the government ended the military control of the civil administration. Most recently, Kinmen County Hall entrusted a foreign de-mining company with the removal of land mines in order to build a cross-sea bridge and a port at Shuitou, but Chen said these initiatives were insufficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALER CLAIMING SUPERNATURAL POWERS INDICTED

TEXT.P: Taipei prosecutors on Tuesday indicted a mainland Chinese woman claiming to have supernatural healing powers on charges of fraud and practicing medicine without a license.

Zhang Ying, who arrived in Taiwan with her locally born husband last December, has been barred from leaving the island since January, pending an end to the preliminary investigations that began when prosecutors were alerted to her claims that she can see through bodies to diagnose diseases and can snatch pills out of thin air.

Taipei District Prosecutor Director Chang Wen-cheng said that Zhang is suspected of violating the Medical Practice Law and the Criminal Law for providing medicine to nearly 10 "patients," who were led to believe that she had supernatural powers.
According to the prosecutor's office, between Dec. 28 and Jan. 5, each person who asked for Zhang's services allegedly paid her US$200 per visit or treated her to a meal.

The bill of indictment stated that Zhang is suspected of hiding a pinch of powder containing Chinese medicine ingredients in the palm of her hand or under a table during her "treatment" sessions. In a sleight of hand trick, she would then rub the powder into a pill, the prosecutors alleged.
Hsieh Szu-tao, a local woman who helped introduce patients to Zhang, was also indicted for allegedly violating the Medical Practice Law.
In an interview with local television reporters after the indictment, Zhang held to her claim that her supernatural powers are real.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 10, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in-chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo-chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possess moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO SET 'SUNSET CLAUSE' ON FOREIGN LABOR

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday it plans to adopt a "sunset" clause to gradually retrieve foreign laborer import quotas from individual companies in order to protect local people's working rights and opportunities.
If the plan goes smoothly, the CLA said, individual companies will no longer enjoy foreign laborer import quotas nine years later.
"By then, the CLA will decide whether to reopen the local job market to foreign workers based on the domestic employment situation," said a CLA official.

According to the official, the CLA has come up with the "sunset clause" proposal after holding a series of meetings with labor unions executives and grass-roots labor affairs administrators in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan late last year to solicit their views on the government's foreign labor policy and feasible ways to curb a steady rise in the domestic unemployment rate.

"The CLA has completed a report on the results of those meetings," the official said, adding that county and city governments and labor unions around the island presented a total of 67 recommendations for lowering the unemployment rate and increasing job opportunities for local citizens.
"And foreign laborers-related proposals account for 11 of the total," the official noted.

Among others, the Hsinchu County labor union suggested that the government more accurately and effectively control the number of migrant workers to prevent them from elbowing local workers out of the domestic job market.

Noting that the "substitute effect" of the entry of migrant workers has surfaced, the Hsinchu labor union complained that some local employers have quietly laid off local workers shortly after they hired foreign laborers.

Worse yet, it said, those companies usually declined to give local workers any layoff documents because under current regulations, a decline in the number of local citizens employed by a specific firm would result in a decrease in the number of foreigners it could legally hire.

The county government of Taoyuan, which boasts the largest number of migrant workers among local counties and cities, said the influx of migrant workers have not only affected local people's job opportunities but also affected the general living environment and quality in grass-roots residential communities in the county.
It suggested that the CLA imposes a ceiling on the number of migrant workers each county or city can accommodate.

The Taoyuan labor union also said many local employers have regarded "hiring foreign laborers" as a panacea for lowering their personnel costs. Against this backdrop, some companies have either set strict age limits or offered lower working terms to discourage local citizens from taking jobs at their factories.

The Ilan County Government suggested that the CLA set a "sunset" clause to stop employment of foreign workers in six to eight years and gradually cut the annual quota for foreign laborers to increase local people's job opportunities.

In response to all those suggestions, the CLA has reaffirmed its policy of cutting the number of legal migrant workers by 15,000 per year. In addition, the CLA said it has been promoting various measures to stamp further growth in migrant work force. For instance, the CLA has tightened screening of applications for hiring foreign caretakers and has demanded that the manufacturing sector slash the number of foreign workers by 10 percent annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AUTOMOTIVE SALES PROFITS DECLINE IN 1ST QUARTER OF 2001

TEXT.P: Taiwan automobile sales dropped significantly in the first three months of 2001 due to the cooling economy, according to March and first quarter financial reports released by publicly listed automobile companies Tuesday.
The reports say that the automobile industry is now looking forward to a sales rebound in the second quarter of this year.

According to the reports, Yulon Motor Co. Ltd. collected sales profits totaling NT$3.56 billion (US$0.11 billion) for March, a 20 percent drop from the same month last year. The company's profits for the first quarter totaled NT$14.26 billion (US$0.44 billion), representing a 3.9 percent decrease over the same period last year.

China Motor Corp. earned NT$3.66 billion (US$0.12 billion) in March, for a 30 percent decline over the amount earned the previous March. The company's automobile sales profits for the first quarter of 2001 totaled NT$14.52 billion (US$0.45 billion), marking a 14 percent decline over the same quarter last year.

San Yang Industrial Co. Ltd. made profits totaling NT$2.35 billion (US$73.4 million) in March, representing a 26 percent drop over the figure for March 2000, while its first quarter profits totaled NT$6.25 billion (US$0.19 billion), down a significant 33 percent from the same period in 2000.

Hotai Motor Co. Ltd. earned NT$4.2 billion (US$0.13 billion) in March, a 21 percent decrease from the same month the previous year. Its sales profits for the first quarter of this year totaled NT$13.08 billion (US$0.40 billion), marking a 16 percent drop over the same period in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO BLAIM FOR DANGEROUS MID-AIR CONFRONTATION: DEFENSE NEWS

TEXT.P: Beijing is largely to blame for the dangerous cat-and-mouse confrontation between a U.S. Navy surveillance plane and two mainland Chinese jetfighters off the coast of Hainan Island on April 1, according to an editorial in the latest issue of Defense News.
The editorial published in the weekly said that the central issue is Communist China's refusal to support a code of conduct for all forces and nations operating in the South China Sea.

The collision that occurred was an accident waiting to happen, and likely will be followed by even graver international incidents if rules of engagement are not codified and accepted by all nations with a military and commercial presence in the region, the editorial said.

Professional investigators should be allowed to determine whether the lumbering U.S. EP-3 reconnaissance plane rammed the Chinese F-8 fighter in airspace belonging to mainland China as claimed by Beijing or whether the F-8 jetfighter recklessly disrupted a routine U.S. patrol in international waters as asserted by the U.S. Pacific Command, the editorial said.

Of larger consequence to U.S.-mainland China relations and the stability of the region at large, the editorial pointed out, are the conflicting views regarding national sovereignty versus the territorial integrity of international waterways and airspace of the South China Sea.

Beijing claims the entire area as its backyard basin, with official mainland Chinese maps depicting the nation's borders extending to the coastlines of the Philippines, through the Paracel and Spratly islands, and around Malaysia.

"This is unreasonable and unacceptable," the editorial emphasized, saying that Beijing has repeatedly stymied attempts by the United States, members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and other interested countries in the region, including Japan and Australia, to address the issue through multilateral channels.

Defense News said that ASEAN and observer nations to the ASEAN Regional Forum, which deals with security affairs, should insist that Communist China forsake its unrealistic territorial claims and present a reasonable map for expert, international consideration.

As for the immediate crisis as a result of the collision, the weekly added, a joint board of inquiry, staffed with legal and technical experts from ASEAN countries, would be a fitting way to put six years of intensive U.S.-mainland Chinese bilateral military-to-military cooperation to the test.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 48.33 points to close at 5,353.5.

Encouraged by a rebound in U.S. stocks prices, the bourse opened at 5,432.96 and began to go down later due to a plunge in pulp and paper issues as well as the poor performance of electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 5,506.1 and 5,349.14 during trading.

A total of 2.06 billion stocks worth NT$73.83 billion (US$2.24 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.63 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$54.68 billion (US$1.66 billion).

Three of the eight major stocks categories posted gains, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.1 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 0.8 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3.3 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 1 percent, and bank and insurance shares and construction stocks, both at 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 349 to 152, with 95 stocks remaining unchanged.
