DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO FREEZE OR RELAX LABOR STANDARDS LAW

TEXT.P: A scholar on Tuesday urged the government to freeze or relax the Labor Standards Law to help ease the worsening unemployment situation.

National Taiwan University professor Wu Chung-chi made the remarks at a public hearing held at the Legislative Yuan. The opposition Kuomintang invited its party legislators, officials and scholars to attend the public hearing on helping unemployed laborers.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) recently reported that the jobless rate in February hit 3.7 percent and that the jobless rate among laborers hit 4.74 percent for the first time, or almost double the figure among white-collar workers.

Professor Wu said that although a rising jobless rate is unavoidable with the bursting of Taiwan's economic bubble, the main culprit behind the increasing unemployment rate is the regulation concerning the minimum wage, currently at NT$15,840 (US$480) per month, in the Labor Standard Law.
Wu said that this has resulted in the labor market's self-adjustment mechanism becoming rigid.
Wu said that the government should address the jobless problem, not wipe out the jobless situation, adding that the Labor Standard Law should be frozen or relaxed.

Hong Yuh-chin, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said that laborers should have the right to be free from the prospect of losing their jobs, adding that to help the employment situation, the KMT will work with the government for an employment promotion bill and submit such a bill for review next month in the hopes of protecting domestic workers by revising the law.

Lin Tsong-ming, director general of the Employment Vocational Training Administration under the Council of Labor Affairs, said that revision of the law would certainly help ease the unemployment problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY MAYOR OF HO CHI MINH CITY WOOING TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: A delegation from Vietnam led by the deputy mayor of Ho Chi Minh City met with business leaders in central Taiwan Tuesday at a meeting held at the Taichung World Trade Center to brief potential investors on the investment climate in Vietnam.
Taichung is one of four legs on the delegation's itinerary, which will also take the visitors to northern and southern Taiwan.
During their stay in Taichung, Tran Ngoc Con, the deputy mayor of Vietnam's capital, and his delegation paid a call on Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying and Deputy Mayor Chen Ta-chun.

Tran said that Taiwan's business investment in Vietnam constitutes 22.1 percent of all foreign investment in his country, making it Vietnam's second largest source of foreign investment after South Korea.

He said Ho Chi Minh City, with better social order than any other city in Vietnam, offers Taiwan businesspeople a privileged investment environment. However, he acknowledged that the city is still trying to overcome a power shortage problem -- a drawback to the city's efforts to attract investment by high-technology companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND LABOR UNION AND MEDIA WORKERS VISIT NANTOU

TEXT.P: A group of labor union and Media workers from mainland China's Gansu and Liaoning provinces visited the Nantou County Council Tuesday to learn more about Taiwan's democratic process.
Accompanied by the chairman of a Nantou labor union, the group observed a meeting of the council, which was in a temporary session.

Cheng Wen-tung, Nantou County Council speaker, expressed his gratitude for the visitors' concern over reconstruction work in the county, which was hit by a major earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999. He asked the group to help promote Nantou's tourism industry in mainland China.

The mainland group's joint leaders, Zhang Iong-fu from Liaoning and Liang He-sheng from Gansu, also called for increased tourism exchanges and urged Nantou-based enterprises to invest in northeastern and northwestern parts of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T LEADERS MOURN PASSING OF FORMER ROC VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian, government officials and political leaders of all stripes on Tuesday visited the home of senior presidential adviser and former vice president Shieh Tung-ming to mourn his passing.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung noted after paying his respects that Shieh, who was 95 when he passed away Sunday night, was the first Taiwan-born provincial governor and vice president.
Chang praised Shieh for his contributions to the country, adding that Shieh's life can be considered a condensed history of Taiwan's progress.

Also present included Vice President Annette Lu, Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, Environmental Protection Administrator Hau Lung-bin, People First Party Chairman James Soong, former vice president Li Yuan-zu, former premier Lee Huan and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Vincent Siew.
Shieh's daughter-in-law, KMT Vice Chairwoman Helen C.C. Lin, said that the family will abide by Shieh's will to conduct only simple memorial services.

Thanking all political parties for putting aside their differences to recognize Shieh's lifelong contributions, Lin turned downed separate offers from the presidential office and the KMT to establish an honorary ad hoc committee to help carry out funeral arrangements.

Lin said that the Shieh family has already decided not to hold an elaborate public funeral service but will instead cremate Shieh's remains Saturday and conduct a memorial ceremony April 22 at the concert hall of Shih Chien University, a private university that he founded.
Shieh's ashes will then be returned to Changhua County and laid to rest beside those of his wife, Lin added.

Shieh was vice president under the former KMT administration from 1978 to 1984. As the first non-military provincial governor of Taiwan, he advocated the development of grass-roots politics and would often visit small towns and villages across the island to listen to the voices of the people.

A package bomb mailed to his office while he was serving as provincial governor exploded in his left hand, forcing an amputation. Wang Hsing-nan, the man who mailed the bomb to highlight the cause of Taiwan independence, served 13 years in prison and is presently a legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.009 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 32.927.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 32.934 and was traded between 32.914 and 32.986.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$347 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANKUANG EXERCISE ENTERS STAGE OF LIVE-FIRE TRAINING DRILLS: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday that the ongoing "Hankuang No. 17" military exercise has entered a stage of live-fire training drills aimed at verifying the effectiveness of various anti-landing and air and naval defense strategies.

Military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng further said at a routine MND news conference that the live-fire drills will include three sections -- combined services air and naval combat training as well as combined services anti-landing exercises.

"The annual large-scale Hankuang exercise began March 22 this year and will last through April 22," Huang said, adding that the first stage of the maneuvers, which ended last week, was focused on cyber war games.

"The live-fire stage is mainly designed to examine the results of the restructuring of military units and various personnel training programs under the MND's 10-year troop reduction plan aimed at establishing an elite deterrent force," Huang explained.

With the participation of all newly restructured or recently formed army, naval and air force units, Huang said, the live-fire drills will also assess the military's battlefield management efficiency and test the adaptability of its new generation of weaponry and the effectiveness of the present combined battlefield command mechanism.

"The results of the training exercises will serve as reference for improving and augmenting the combined combat capabilities of the three branches of our armed forces," Huang noted, adding that the Army, Navy and Air Force General Headquarters are responsible for organizing various combined services combat training drills.

For instance, Huang said, the Army General Headquarters will play a leading role in a live-fire combined services anti-landing training exercise to be held in waters off southern Taiwan's Pingtung County on April 20. The Air Force's F5E squadron and Navy's missile speed boat fleet will also take part in the upcoming anti-landing exercise.

Meanwhile, Huang said, the military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology-developed RT-2000 artillery multiple-launching rocket system (AMLRS) will be test-fired for the first time in the April 20 anti-landing drill.

Huang declined to make any comments on reports that the Navy's anti-ship Hsiungfeng II missiles failed to hit the projected target and the Army's vehicle-launched Avenger air-defense missiles and shoulder-fired Stinger missiles either overshot the target or were forced to give up shooting due to a failure to position the weapons within the required time limit.
He merely said that the main purposes of the training exercise are to find deficiencies and drawbacks so that operations can be improved.

Huang further stressed that the test-firing of the "Patriot PAC-2 plus" anti-missile defense system has not been included in the current Hankuang No. 17 exercise. "The timing for Patriot test-firing has yet to be decided," he added.

Huang also said the MND has not arranged for President Chen Shui-bian to preside over the present military exercise from the very beginning, denying the report that Chen canceled his plan to chair the exercise amid the ongoing U.S.-mainland China standoff over a military aircraft collision in South China Sea.
As to the issue regarding confidence-building measures between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Huang said the MND would be very pleased to forge such a mechanism.

"However, it takes two to tango. We can't solely reach that goal without the cooperation of mainland China," Huang explained, adding that the MND's regular issue of defense white papers and unveiling of a detailed schedule of its military training drills at the beginning of every year are part of Taiwan's efforts to increase military transparency and minimize possible miscalculations by the mainland military.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY BLASTS STATE ENTERPRISES FOR ALLEGED BUDGETING PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party Tuesday blasted government enterprises for a series of alleged budgeting problems ranging from deliberately low or high income projections and reliance on property sales and accrued interest to stay in the black.

Chang Shih-liang, the deputy convener of the party's legislative caucus, charged at a press conference that for six out of the 40 state-run enterprises, the difference between their original budgets and final tabulations of income and expenditures actually exceeds 100 percent.
He went on to cite Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp. as the most blatant transgressor in this regard, charging that when the company says it can make NT$100, it actually only makes NT$21.7.

Chang also accused other state-run companies of intentionally lowering their income estimates to make annual operational goals easier to attain. Any amount beyond their income estimates then bring in additional bonuses for the "excess" productivity, he added.

He fingered Central Deposit Insurance Corp., Chinese Petroleum Corp. and the Central Trust of China as the worst examples of this practice, budgeting 54 percent, 37 percent and 23 percent short of their actual annual incomes, respectively.
He urged the government to punish any company and its supervisory government agency that continues to show a difference of greater than 10 percent between its projected and actual income.

Chang also alleged that over two-thirds of government enterprises rely on property sales and interest income. If these sources of income were not taken into consideration, the number of state-run companies in the red would jump from five to 11, he added.

He urged the government to seek out the help of professionals and scholars and work out ways to lower costs for these companies or even close them before they become excessive burdens to the taxpayers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL GROWTH OF IMPORTS, EXPORTS MAY HIT NEW POST-FINANCIAL CRISIS LOW

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) predicted Tuesday that growth in exports this year might only amount to 0.5 percent, while imports might actually shrink, setting new lows since 1997'S regional financial storm.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF Department of Statistics, said that with the closure of domestic plants and the exodus of domestic industries, import demand and domestic investment have both been hit hard. The situation has been compounded by the sluggish world economy, so foreign trade growth is likely to slow, he said.

Hsu made the remarks after the MOF published figures showing that exports in the first quarter hit US$31.71 billion, and imports in the same period reached US$28.41 billion, down 3.5 percent and 10.0 percent respectively from the same period last year.

The MOF noted that the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) has predicted that exports this year would grow by 4.21 percent, while import growth will be 3.39 percent. But with the sluggish economy in Taiwan and other parts of the world, the DGBAS in May might sharply slash its forecasts for export and import growth this year, the MOF said.

The MOF said that exports in March totaled US$117.4 billion, down 1.8 percent from the same period last year, while imports in March totaled US$10.03 billion, down 13.1 percent from the same period in 2000. Taiwan's trade surplus hit US$1.71 billion in March, the highest monthly surplus since June 1999.
March imports and exports both surpassed the US$10 billion mark, showing that though trade has decreased slightly, it is still in good shape.

The MOF said that exports to Hong Kong and Europe actually increased slightly in March, but this was offset by decreased exports to the United States, Japan and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Imports from the major regions, such as the United States, Japan and ASEAN, also decreased.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO ALLOW MAINLAND FISHERY WORKERS TO ENTER PORTS

TEXT.P: More than 100 fishermen from Taipei County and the neighboring port city of Keelung appealed Tuesday for the assistance of the Legislative Yuan to push the government to allow mainland Chinese fishery workers to enter local ports.

The petitioners said at a public hearing in the legislature that they most hope the government will allow mainland crew members working on their fishing boats to come ashore to help them unload their catches of fish. The hearing was co-organized by a group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislators.
"Or at least, the government should allow mainland fishery workers to enter local ports," said Chen Yu-heng, a senior executive with the Kungliao Fishermen's Association in Taipei County.

At present, the Republic of China government permits local fishing boat owners to hire mainland sailors to work on their ships, but bans mainlanders from entering Taiwan ports or coming ashore. As a result, mainland fishery workers have to stay aboard ships moored offshore.
Chen said the government should ease the restrictions. "Otherwise, local ship owners have a hard time unloading fish catches and repairing fishing nets," he explained.

Chen claimed that the operations of the local fishing industry have been seriously affected since the National Coast Guard Administration intensified a crackdown on boats carrying mainland fishery workers into local ports late last month.

Responding to the fishermen's appeal, Sha Chih-yi, deputy director of the Fishery Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), said that the government currently only allows fishing industry firms to hire mainlanders to work on the high seas in consideration of the especially harsh working environment, which makes it difficult to attract domestic employees.
"This is a special favor for local fishermen," Sha said, adding that there is still no legal basis to allow mainland fishery workers to land on Taiwan or enter local ports.

Meanwhile, COA Chairman Chen Hsi-huang said during a Legislative Yuan plenary session that the COA is reviewing current regulations and will work out a new package of measures to better regulate the employment of mainland fishery workers on Taiwan-owned fishing boats.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA URGES ADEQUATE HANDLING OF TAIWAN, TIBET ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 9 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Tibet's spiritual leader the Dalai Lama urged Beijing Monday to handle the Taiwan and Tibet issues based on historical and realistic facts.

The Dalai Lama said that the status of Taiwan and Tibet are two completely separate issues to Beijing. He added his refusal to recognize Taiwan as a province of mainland China is irrelevant to the Tibet issue.
The Dalai Lama made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the Voice of America prior to his departure from Taiwan following a 10-day visit to the island-state.

The top Tibetan Buddhist monk told the Voice of America that the major purpose of his visit to Taiwan was to search for educational training opportunities and assistance for Tibetan people exiled in India and to seek job opportunities for Tibetan people residing in Taiwan.

Regarding the Falun Gong movement in mainland China, the Tibetan spiritual leader contended that the Chinese communist regime has overreacted to the issue, causing huge damage to the image of the People's Republic of China.
The Voice of America is slated to broadcast its interview with the Dalai Lama to its audience in mainland China in Mandarin Chinese Monday evening at 9:00 p.m. Taipei time.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRONG SANDSTORM TO THREATEN TAIWAN'S AIR QUALITY IN COMING DAYS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) warned Tuesday that the fallout from a strong sandstorm in Mongolia will threaten Taiwan's air quality in the next two days. The agency cautioned people with respiratory problems to take precautions.
The EPA, citing weather forecasts from Japan, said repeated sandstorms have roared across the Mongolian area, with strong winds repeatedly stirring up dust and sand in recent days.

These sandstorms have hit Inner Mongolia and other northern and northeastern areas of mainland China, and even affected Korea and Japan, with clouds of suspended sand particles spreading across some 3,000 or 4,000 square kilometers.
The fallout from the current sandstorm, the strongest in recent years, will arrive in the Taiwan area as early as Wednesday night or early Thursday morning, the EPA said.

EPA officials said the sandstorm will greatly affect the air quality of the entire Taiwan area, warning people with respiratory problems, the elderly and children to avoid going outside or engaging in heavy outdoor activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAIT STABILITY ROC'S TOP MAINLAND POLICY GOAL: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Maintaining stability in the Taiwan Strait is the Republic of China's top mainland policy goal, a visiting ROC official in charge of mainland China affairs said in Osaka Tuesday.

Addressing a meeting of overseas Chinese community leaders in the Asia-Pacific region, Chen Ming-tong, vice chairman of the ROC's Mainland Affairs Council, said although cross-strait talks have been stalled, bilateral trade and cultural exchanges have become ever brisker.

"The cross-strait relations have made progress quietly over the past year, and we see a silver lining on the horizon for further development in bilateral ties in the future," Chen said, adding it's a remarkable achievement of the 11-month-old administration of President Chen Shui-bian.
Chen went on to say that Taiwan has never ceased its preparations for the reopening of regular dialogue with mainland China.
"When the time is ripe, we can resume talks with mainland China on various kinds of topics of mutual concern and work together to improve bilateral relations," Chen said optimistically.

Noting that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should forge a framework for long-term steady development of bilateral ties on a cooperative and reciprocal basis, Chen said all overseas Chinese are welcome to pool their wisdom and energy to assist the ROC government in promoting friendly, constructive cross-strait interaction.

Chen further pointed out that Taipei's and Beijing's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) will certainly trigger a significant change in the general environment for cross-strait interaction.

"This is a challenge that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should face. And we look forward to discussing relevant issues with mainland China as early as possible," chen said, adding that it is very important for the two sides to forge orderly exchanges based on the principles of market economy and political democratization.

In preparation for Taipei's and Beijing's WTO accession, Chen said, the ROC hopes to hammer out a mechanism for cross-strait interchanges in line with the principles of openness and national security.
Touching on the sensitive "one China" issue, Chen said the ROC cannot accept Beijing's "one China" principle because it deliberately ignores the ROC's existence.

"President Chen said in his inaugural speech that the two sides should cultivate a climate favorable for cross-strait cooperation in dealing with the issue regarding a 'future one China,'" Chen said, adding that the declaration signifies the ROC's positive, active and constructive attitude on resolving bilateral disputes through peaceful dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM ORDERS PROBE INTO SLAUGHTER OF RARE ANIMALS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, shocked by reports that large numbers of wild animals have been slaughtered in the mountains of Central Taiwan, ordered a probe Tuesday into the deaths.

Under the premier's instructions, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) began to look into the killings, offering NT$1 million as a cash reward for clues leading to the apprehension of the perpetrators.

Chang's directive was prompted by a report by a local TV station, whose "Taiwan Records" program disclosed the discovery of the carcasses of Formosan sambars, Formosan Reeve's muntjacs and long-haired goats in a recent expedition deep into the mountains of the Central Range.

It was the first time that dozens of wild animals endemic to Taiwan were found dead at the same time in the same close region -- the Dandah Forest Reservation Area located in the Central Range around the headwaters of the Choshui River -- Taiwan's longest -- and the Nantou County and Taitung County border.
According to the TV report, dozens of the carcasses were found in brushwood near a brook.

The dead animals are believed to have been killed by non-aboriginal hunters shooting for fun rather than for economic purposes, since all the corpses were left behind and only the antlers and genitalia of the male sambars were removed, according to the TV report.
The Dandah Forest Reservation Area is one of the most important habitats for wild animals in Taiwan and is home to the largest number of Formosan sambars.

In related news, meanwhile, the COA's Taiwan Endemic Species Research Institute has found that another endemic animal -- the Formosan macaque -- has been excessively hunted or killed by farmers islandwide.

Although the number of Formosan macaques is estimated at only around 250,000 islandwide, the monkeys are widely hunted by longan and bamboo shoot farmers so as to protect their crops, according to COA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA TOPS CREDIT CARD ISSUANCE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of credit cards issued by VISA in Taiwan exceeded 19 million as of Monday, outnumbering other credit cards circulating locally, VISA International officials announced Tuesday.

According to the officials, 19,041,659 cards were issued with the average transaction value reaching NT$2,552 (US$77.5), which also reflects the fact that Taiwan people tend to use their cards mainly for small purchases.
In terms of cash withdrawals using VISA cards, the figure reached NT$4.430 billion in February, representing 69.6 percent growth over the same month of last year, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT PRESENTS APPLICATION FOR JAPANESE VISA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Katherine Chang said Tuesday that former President Lee Teng-hui had applied for a Japanese visa so that he can visit the country later this month for medical treatment.
She expressed the hope that the Japanese government will grant Lee a visa, as he holds no government posts and is therefore technically free to visit any country he wishes as a private citizen.

According to Chang, Lee presented his application to the Taipei office of the quasi-official Japan Interchange Association, stating that he wants to undertake treatment for heart illness before April 24.
An invitation to Lee from an attending surgeon in Okayama Prefecture was attached to the application to indicate that Lee is required to undertake the treatment before April 24, said Chang.
She noted that the ROC representative office in Tokyo will be instructed to negotiate with the Japanese government for visa issuance.
As a free and democratic country, she pointed out, Japan should not be influenced by another country, including mainland China, into rejecting Lee's application.
It remains to be seen whether the Japanese government will grant a visa to Lee, who has been labeled by Beijing as a splittist and an advocate of Taiwan independence.
Some foreign reports indicated that outgoing Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori intends to help Lee realize his long-cherished wish to visit Japan.
But Mori will be replaced as president of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party on April 24 and he will be relieved of his premiership two days later.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ANNOUNCES 2001 `BASEBALL YEAR' FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian announced Tuesday that 2001 will be "Baseball Year for Taiwan" as part of an effort to revitalize the sport.
Chen made the announcement while receiving members of the Chinese Taipei Baseball Team, which recently won the Asian Championship for the first time in 12 years.

He praised the team's performance at the 21st Asian Baseball Championship Tournament held at the Hsinchuang Stadium in suburban Taipei last month and stressed that baseball should distance itself from the corruption that the local game has become perhaps best-known for. Only clean, good performances and competitive tournaments will attract baseball fans back to the stadiums, Chen noted.

In line with Chen's "baseball year," the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association will also sponsor three world-class events this year -- the Asian Baseball Championship, the World Baseball Championship Tournament and the World Youth Baseball Championship Tournament.

Noting that baseball is popular in Taiwan and claiming that "the great majority of adults in Taiwan" would wake up at midnight to watch a baseball game until the sport became tainted by corruption, Chen said the plans for this year are the most remarkable international activities devised by Taiwan under its adverse diplomatic situation.

Chen expressed hope that local amateurs and professionals will cooperate to form a strong team to compete in the upcoming World Baseball Championship Tournament scheduled to be held in Taiwan this September. In addition to Taiwan, 15 teams from five continents will compete in the competition.
He also expressed the hope that the national team will help the government to upgrade and promote little, junior and big league baseball.

In return, Peng Cheng-hao, board chairman of the Chinese Taipei baseball Association, voiced appreciation for Chen's support and promised that the association will form a strong team to take part in the September tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAD PEOPLE APPRECIATE ROC ASSISTANCE: COMMERCE MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: N'Djamena, April 10 (CNA) (By H.Y. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Every Chad citizen knows the contribution that the Republic of China has made to the African country and is grateful for its assistance to local society, Chad Commerce, Industry & Crafts Minister Kalzuede Tahini said Tuesday.

Stressing that the Chad government hopes to further strengthen bilateral cooperation in the textile and cement industries, Tahini said there is ample room for two-way cooperative ventures in a wide range of fields.

He made the remarks while receiving a 31-member delegation from Taiwan composed of small business owners in the biochemical, electronics, Internet, kitchen furniture, construction and medical equipment sectors. He noted that Chad is rich in natural resources, but lacks technology and skilled workers.

Making it clear that Chad needs Taiwan's assistance to improve its economy, a straight-talking Tahini said Chad hopes to upgrade its economic strength by sharing with Taiwan its development experience.

Led by Day Sheng-tong, head of the ROC Association of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises, the trade-promotion team arrived in Chad Monday on the first leg of a four-nation, 11-day African tour. The local business community mobilized hundreds of people to give the delegation a warm welcome and a performance of traditional folk dances.
The trade-promotion mission is slated to call on Chad President Idriss Deby Wednesday and will attend an investment seminar organized by local businessmen later in the day.
According to ROC Ambassador Chiu Jong-jen, the local media have carried extensive reports about the delegation's visit to Chad for the past week, in the hope that Taiwan firms will invest here.

Chiu also said that the Chad people are very thankful for Taiwan's assistance, especially with infrastructure developments such as building bridges, setting up oil refineries and digging wells for potable water.
Following its stay in Chad, the delegation will proceed to Burkina Faso, Gambia and Senegal before returning to Taiwan April 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH TO BE FURTHER READJUSTED DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall economic growth is likely to be lowered further than previous government estimates, due mainly to sagging private sector consumption, an official from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

With the growth rate in private sector consumption dropping to 4 percent in the first quarter, the annual overall economic growth will have to be readjusted downward this year, said CEPD Vice Chairman Lee Kao-chao.

According to CEPD tallies, Taiwan enjoyed a trade surplus of US$3.3 billion in the first quarter of this year, marking a whopping increase compared with the NT$1.3 billion posted in the same period of last year.

Although the Q-1 trade surplus has contributed to the country's economic growth, the annual economic growth is unlikely to be as good as previously estimated as long as consumption in the private sector continues to slump, Lee noted.

Lee attributed the sagging private sector consumption to rising unemployment and a weak Taiwan stock market, which began to lose steam late last year and caused most of the investors to lose up to half of their fortunes.
Previously, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics estimated that Taiwan's Q-1 growth would top 4.02 percent, while the annual growth would reach 5.25 percent.
Lee forecast that the overall economic growth rate will not be as high as 5.25 percent for 2001.

Meanwhile, Wu Chung-shu, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics, quoted his institute's estimate as indicating that Taiwan's Q-1 growth will be around 3 percent, while the Q-2 performance is expected to be no better. The economy is likely to bottom out from Q-3 but the subsequent jump will not be remarkable, Wu forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PARTICIPATE IN NEW ROUND OF WTO AGRICULTURAL TALKS

TEXT.P: An official with the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Tuesday that Taiwan will participate in the second-stage agricultural talks of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Geneva from next month.
The official noted that three rounds of such talks will be held respectively in May, July and next February, with the topics being focused on quota controls, export subsidies and export restrictions.
In order to protect the interests of the country, he said, Taiwan will attend the talks as an observer, although it has not yet been admitted into the world trade regulatory body.
WTO began holding first-stage agricultural talks from March of last year. Taiwan also participated in those talks as an observer.
The official said that COA Vice Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung is heading a cross-agency task force to monitor the progress of the talks and work out relevant measures.
In the first-stage round of talks, which were concluded last month, WTO member countries submitted 44 proposals and three technical reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TBS TO PROVIDE FOREIGN WORKERS WITH MOTHER TONGUE PROGRAMS

TEXT.P: Taipei Broadcasting Station (TBS) introduced Tuesday a series of new programs for April and a new catchphrase in Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka and aboriginal languages.
The new programming was made possible with new budgeting for the Taipei City Council compiled by the Taipei city government. TBS is under the jurisdiction of the Taipei city government.
The 40-year-old radio station has been in dire financial straits in recent years because of repeated budget cuts.

King Pu-tsung, director of the Information Department of the Taipei city government, said TBS will provide audiences in the greater Taipei area with another choice in addition to profit-oriented commercial radio stations.

The station will broadcast news programs provided by the British Broadcasting Corp. (BBC), various music programs, a program to explain and publicize the city administrative affairs, and a show called "News Media e Talk," as well as a program for foreign workers in the greater Taipei area titled "Hello Taipei," which will be aired in Tagalog, Indonesian and Thai.

"Hello Taipei" is scheduled to be aired from 9 p.m.-11 p.m. on Saturdays and from 9 p.m.-10 p.m. on Sundays and will provide foreign workers with labor regulations, foreign exchange rates, culture showcases, hometown news and "new activities."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE IN ASIA MEETING OPENS IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opened Tuesday in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.

The participants agreed unanimously in a declaration to stand united in support of the Republic of China and to render their assistance to help the ROC government promote relations between the ROC and nations in the other parts of the world.
The one-day meeting was chaired by Tsai Chung-chiu, president of the Confederation of the Overseas Chinese Associations in Japan.

Special guests included Yao Ing-chi, vice president of the ROC Legislative Yuan; Chang Fu-mei, minister of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission; Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and Lo Fu-chuan, ROC representative to Japan.
A written message from ROC President Chen Shui-bian was read at the gathering in which he said that building Taiwan into an "intellectual technology island" is one of his government's priorities.

"The government will build Taiwan into a green silicon island based on `service to the people and seeking progress' and `patiently seeking a cross-Taiwan Strait goodwill compromise and positive cooperation as well as an everlasting peace,'" Chen noted.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung lauded overseas Chinese in a written message for their help in promoting relations between the ROC and their countries of residence. The premier also briefed the participants Taiwan's economic development plan for the upcoming ten years.

OCAC Minister Chang called on overseas Chinese around the world to be alert to Beijing's united front scheme. Beijing plans to hold a "peaceful Chinese unification convention" in July in Tokyo with the aim of dividing overseas Chinese communities, she claimed. She also called on overseas Chinese to help the ROC government expand its international activities.
She added that the government's policy toward overseas Chinese will not be changed or neglected as a result of the first peaceful power transition in the ROC.
The gathering decided to cable respects to the president and premier and to hold its next meeting in Manila in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO JAPANESE VISA APPLICATION BY FORMER PRESIDENT: AIDE

TEXT.P: An aide to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui denied Tuesday a ROC Foreign Ministry report that Lee had applied for a Japanese visa.
Su Chih-cheng said that he did not know why the Foreign Ministry announced that Lee had submitted an application with the Taipei office of the Japan Interchange Association.

Earlier, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Katherine Chang called a press conference to confirm a report that Lee had presented his visa application and urged the Japanese government to grant Lee -- now a private citizen -- an entry visa.
Chang told reporters that the Foreign Ministry called the press conference after getting confirmation from the ROC representative office in Tokyo that Lee had presented his application.

Meanwhile, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official told CNA's Tokyo Bureau that his ministry had contacted the Japan Interchange Association over the matter and found that it had not received any application from Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 11, or the 18th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 114.25 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 114.25 points to close at 5,467.75.
Market turnover amounted to NT$80.99 billion (US$2.46 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES BULLDOZER TO PANAMA CITY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 10 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government Tuesday donated three forklifts and a bulldozer to the Panama city government to help in the development of the city's infrastructure.

Panama City Mayor Juan Carlo Navarro received the key to the bulldozer from ROC Ambassador to Panama David C.Y. Hu in a gift-offering ceremony, which was witnessed by over 50 officials and guests. The mayor expressed appreciation on behalf of Panama City to the ROC government for the gifts, which are valued at about US$100,000.

Navarro said that he looks forward to visiting Taipei at an appropriate time. Earlier this year, he met with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou when the latter visited Panama. The two mayors shared their experiences in city and infrastructure planning.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 114.25 points to close at 5,467.75.

Encouraged by a surge in U.S. stocks prices, the bourse opened at 5,470.67 and began to go down later due to selling pressure, but a better performance by electronics shares caused stocks prices to go up again toward the end of the session. The index fluctuated between 5,474.17 and 5,362.43 during trading.

A total of 2.16 billion stocks worth NT$80.99 billion (US$2.46 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.06 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$73.83 billion (US$2.24 billion).

Three of the eight major stocks categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.2 percent, and construction shares at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 3 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 1.3 percent, textile issues at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.1 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 279 to 209, with 100 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL SECRETARY BLASTS JAPANESE REFUSAL TO GRANT LEE VISA

TEXT.P: Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Chen Che-nan blasted the Japanese government Wednesday for its refusal to grant former President Lee Teng-hui an entry visa, which Lee applied for to visit Japan later this month for medical treatment.
Chen, in response to questions at the Legislative Yuan, said the Japanese government has no reason to refuse to grant a visa to Lee -- now a private citizen -- to have his heart checked in Japan.
Stressing that he supports Lee's desire to visit Japan for medical reasons, Chen said Tokyo is seriously "sinophobic" and has "intentionally politicized the issue."

While Chen noted that Japan has no reason to refuse Lee a visa, Kuomintang Legislator Liu Kuang-hua said the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) also has no reason to lodge an official condemnation of the Japanese government for such a decision.

Meanwhile, MOFA spokeswoman Katherine Chang confirmed Wednesday that Lee presented his application Tuesday to the Taipei office of the quasi-official Japan Interchange Association, stating that he wanted to undertake treatment for heart illness before April 24.

Noting that MOFA officials stationed in Japan are currently negotiating with Japanese authorities for the issuance of a visa for Lee, Chang expressed the hope that the Japanese government will grant the visa based on humanitarian considerations as well as on the fact that Lee holds no government posts and is therefore technically free to visit any country he wishes to as a private citizen.

In Lee's application, according to Chang, an invitation to Lee from an attending surgeon in Okayama Prefecture was attached to indicate that Lee is required to undertake the treatment before April 24.
Chang called for the Japanese authorities to "simplify" the whole matter and free themselves of political considerations, which are unnecessary and improper.
Chang, meanwhile, pointed out that she has no idea why the Japan Interchange Association said it had not received Lee's application as of Tuesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally higher on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved up 174 points to close at 5,495, with 11,170 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 184 points to finish at 5,505, with 394 contract transactions, while June futures remained unchanged at 5,530, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,321 for April, 5,321 for May, 5,350 for June, 5,425 for September, and 5,475 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
April TE futures rose 12 points to finish at 274, with 2,912 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 10.5 points to close at 273, with 88 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures increased 13 points to close at 730, with 690 contract transactions, while May TF futures gained 12 points to finish at 732, with 18 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHOR OF TIANANMEN PAPERS URGES M'LAND LEADERSHIP TO "FACE HISTORY"

TEXT.P: A former mainland Chinese civil servant and Communist Party member who secretly compiled "The Tiananmen Papers" has urged the Communist Chinese leadership in an essay to "face history" and redress the Tiananmen Square Massacre of June 4, 1989.
Radio Free Asia said it has obtained exclusive worldwide Mandarin-language rights to the essay by Zhang Liang, and it began daily broadcasts of excerpts in five parts Tuesday.
The essay commemorates the 12th anniversary of the death of former Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang and coincides with the April 15 publication in Mandarin Chinese of "The Tiananmen Papers."

Zhang Liang wrote in the essay, titled "Commemorating Yaobang, Thinking of (Zhao) Ziyang, and Messages to Jiang (Zemin) and Li (Peng)," that nobody expected that the "nationwide mourning activity" that followed Hu's sudden death in 1989 "would evolve into a movement to expand democracy (and) severely punish corrupt officials, incurring a bloody massacre."

But he pointed out that, to mainland Chinese youths of today, June 4, 1989, "is a blurry and distorted picture, or even a blank. To their elders, June 4 is a scar from a healed wound that is no longer painful. Some enthusiastic students and teachers, who readily answered the call to gather, have simply forgotten about it."
"Making money has prevailed in society for the past 12 years. It has destroyed people's spiritual belief, confusing right and wrong, and good and evil. The intellectual has become numb," Zhang wrote.

"Being extremely disappointed about the (Communist) party and government, more and more people turn to gods and Buddha for help. Common people are unable to report their situation or get their wrongful treatment redressed," he said.
"Falun Gong arises as an inevitable result of the loss of social belief." The Communist Party "is no longer a party that serves the people," Zhang noted.
He also criticized mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin for his heavy-handed treatment of dissent and for his pursuit of economic policies that have led to massive layoffs.

"Though you come from an intellectual background, you are not a mentor or a friend of the intellectual. You know what the intellectual needs the most: Freedom of thinking! Freedom of speech! And you have always stifled public opinion and repressed freedom of speech," wrote Zhang.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH CALLS BEIJING'S WHITE PAPER A "WHITEWASH"

TEXT.P: Human Rights Watch said Tuesday that Beijing's new "White Paper" on human rights is clearly aimed at the ongoing session of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva and is part of the same lobbying strategy that brought mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to Latin America.
The current session of the U.N. Human Rights Commission opened March 19, and Communist China's human rights record is expected to be discussed later this month.
Sidney Jones, Asia director of Human Rights Watch, said that the "so-called White Paper is a whitewash of China's human rights practices."

"But we've seen this combination before: high-level visits to Latin America to get allies for the (U.N.) Commission, together with the release of a report which boasts that China's human rights record has never been better."

Beijing published its first white paper on human rights in November 1991 at a time when the memories of the Tiananmen Square massacre were still fresh and pressure was building toward a resolution on Communist China at the 1992 U.N. Human Rights Commission session. Another white paper was published in March 1997 and yet another came out in February 1998, Jones pointed out.
The New York-based human rights group director said there is also a precedent for high-level visits to Latin America in the period just prior to U.N. Human Rights Commission sessions.

In late 1995, with a view to the 1996 session of the U.N. Human Rights Commission, then mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng went to Peru and Mexico. Before the 1997 session, Li visited two key commission countries, Brazil and Chile, and Beijing's senior trade official Wu Yi visited six Latin American countries, all but one of which were to be members of the commission that year, said Human Rights Watch.

Jones noted that of the six Latin American countries on Jiang Zemin's current itinerary -- Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil, Cuba and Venezuela -- all but Chile are members of the current commission. Some of these countries might be inclined to join with the United States, if not in sponsoring a resolution, then in trying to defeat Beijing's efforts to ensure it will not come to a vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, HOLLAND AGREE TO STOP DOUBLE TAXATION

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan signed an agreement Wednesday with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
The Republic of China had been negotiating with the Dutch Ministry of Finance over the issue of bilateral tax regulations since 1992.
The agreement was reached in the Hague, the Netherlands, June 29, 2000 and was signed by ROC Representative to the Netherlands Ku Chung-lien and NTIO Representative S.K. Schuur Feb. 27 this year.
The agreement sets forth tax regulations applicable to ROC government facilities and people in the Netherlands as well as those applicable to Dutch government facilities and residents in the ROC.
The regulations involve taxes on sales profits, shipping, enterprises, stock revenue and interest, property trade income, personal income, pensions and royalties.
