DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.007 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 32.920.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 32.980 and was traded between 32.881 and 32.980.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$427 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SANDSTORMS TO REACH TAIWAN EARLY THURSDAY: SPO

TEXT.P: Residue from the violent sandstorms which have ravaged northern China over the last week are expected to reach Taiwan early Thursday, officials from the National Space Program Office (SPO) said Wednesday.

The SPO, which is under the Cabinet-level National Science Council, has closely monitored the sandstorms with its state-of-the-art ocean color-imaging (OCI) system over the past few days and has estimated that the sandstorms, which blew up in the deserts of northern China, will reach the Taiwan area at around 2 a.m. Thursday.
China's northern regions have had an average of 15 sandstorms a year over the past 50 years, making it one of the four major areas in the world that sandstorms are most likely to occur.
Airborne sand from China-originating sandstorms affected Taiwan in late January and early March this year.

The latest sandstorms were whipped up by a cold air mass coming from Siberia and Mongolia and have swept through the drought-stricken and dusty north-central mainland Chinese province of Gansu before gradually traveling south and east to Hong Kong, Taiwan and the Philippines.

IPO officials said the sandstorms make the air extremely bad, causing harm particular to the eyes and respiratory system. They urged people in Taiwan to avoid outdoor activities during days when sandstorms are affecting the local atmosphere.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TRADE UNION LEADERS VISITING KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A group from Hong Kong comprised of leaders and officials of the Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions (HKCTU) and other related labor unions are visiting Kaohsiung at the invitation of the Kaohsiung Confederation of Trade Unions (KCTU).
The group is led by HKCTU Chairman Lau Chin-shek, a member of the Hong Kong Legislative Council, and another Lagislative Council member Lee Cheuk-yan.

While in Kaohsiung, the Hong Kong group will pay a call on Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and meet with leaders of the Kaohsiung labor unions for an exchange of views on the roles played by labor movement in both cities.
A discussion session is to be held by the HKCTU and the KCTU in Kaohsiung to talk about the issue of labor rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN INVITED TO INVEST IN SOUTH SUMATRA

TEXT.P: The leader of an investment and trade promotion delegation from Indonesia's South Sumatra Province making a three-day visit to Taiwan told businessmen Wednesday that "a lot can be done" in the province.

In a briefing on trade and investment opportunities in South Sumatra at the Taipei World Trade Center, Governor Rosihan Arsyad pointed out that the main purpose of the trade mission, consisting of provincial government officials and entrepreneurs, is to meet with local businessmen to promote South Sumatra's economic resources.
Arsyad said that since January this year, the provincial government is allowed to deal directly with potential foreign investors who are interested in conducting business in South Sumatra.
Arsyad noted that his government has committed to:
-- Provide all information on economic potential, socio-cultural aspects, laws and regulations, and "any other information required by investors;"
-- Simplify all procedures and mechanisms for conducting legal business within the area of the province; and
-- Maintain political stability to ensure that all economic activities can be protected.

Concerning South Sumatra's economic potential, Arsyad said that his province still has a large acreage of arable land to support agriculture and that there are varied investment opportunities in the agricultural sector.
He added that since the province also has large deposits of coal, his government is looking for investors interested in establishing coal-fired energy plants.
Oil and natural gas are also major products of South Sumatra, along with gold and silver, Arsyad said.
He also introduced investment opportunities in other sectors, including tourism.
"South Sumatra is not far from Taipei. Therefore, it should be considered as a tourist destination for people in Taipei," he said.

Members of the delegation, who arrived here Tuesday, will leave Taipei for Keelung Thursday to visit the Taiwan fisheries Research Institute. They will also tour the Taiwan Livestock Products Research Institute and other agricultural and industrial facilities in Ilan County before leaving for Singapore Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC TO BEGIN CONSTRUCTION OF WAFER PLANT IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) announced Wednesday that groundbreaking for a 12-inch wafer plant in Singapore will take place Thursday, with production scheduled to commence in the third quarter of next year.

The US$3.6 billion project will be the company's second 12-inch wafer plant outside Taiwan and the first 12-inch wafer foundry in Singapore, which holds a 15 percent stake in the plant through the investment arm of its Economic Development Board.
Germany's Infineon Technologies holds a 30 percent stake, while UMC, which is the world's second-largest contract chip manufacturer, holds the majority 51.95 percent.

According to the company, first stage production capacity will reach 20,000 wafers per month. At the end of the second stage of construction, slated for the fourth quarter of 2003, capacity will double to 40,000 wafers per month.
Located in the Pasir Ris Wafer Fab Park, the plant will focus on system-on-chip products built on 0.13-micron and 0.10-micron process technology jointly developed by UMC, IBM and Infineon.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE KINMEN DELEGATION VISITS XIAMEN

TEXT.P: A large delegation from the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen took advantage of the "three mini links" Wednesday to launch its first direct cultural and academic voyage to mainland China.

The 192-member delegation left Lianlo Harbor aboard a vessel run by Kinmen County government for the mainland port of Xiamen for a weeklong visit, which is expected to add momentum to the direct trade, postal and transport links -- commonly known as the "mini three links" -- between Kinmen, Matsu and mainland China implemented since Jan. 1, 2001.
The delegation, including a 53-member group led by Chang Chun-chuan, director of Kinmen County Cultural Center, will attend cultural and tourism activities in Xiamen.

In addition, the delegation also includes Kinmen officials currently studying in a program at National Sun Yat-sen University, who are scheduled to have academic exchanges with Xiamen University. As this is the largest Kinmen group of officials since Kinmen magistrate Chen Shui-tsai led a delegation on the first direct voyage to the mainland early this year, it has aroused media attention.
Meanwhile, as a Xiamen trade fair on export commodities to Taiwan opened Thursday, the delegation also includes 26 Kinmen business council directors and supervisors.

Other members of the delegation belong to private tourist groups. Tourist agencies said that more than 20 tourists were unable to make the trip because it was fully booked, showing that although tourist arrivals have to be reviewed on a case-by-case basis by the Xiamen authorities, traffic has become smoother, giving a needy shot in the arm to the tourism industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY CHIEF ON U.S. VISIT FOR ROUTINE CONSULTATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Navy Commander-in-Chief Adm. Li Chieh is currently on a visit to Washington, D.C. at the invitation of the U.S. government, naval sources said Wednesday.
Officials with the Navy General Headquarters (NGH) said Li will hold routine consultations with the U.S. Department of Defense on Taiwan's naval defense needs.

NGH officials said the U.S. government usually invites the commander-in-chief of an ROC military branch to visit the United States each year. They stressed that Li's visit has nothing to do with the April 23 ROC-U.S. meeting on Taiwan's arms procurement plans nor with the current U.S.-mainland China row over their military aircraft collision over South China Sea early this month.
Sources said Li is expected to deliver a report on details of his U.S. visit to the Defense Committee of the Legislative Yuan after his return.

Meanwhile, a CNA report from Washington said the U.S. State Department confirmed Tuesday that the ROC navy chief "is in the United States for routine consultations in the context of our regular discussions about Taiwan's defense needs."

Navy officials said Li left for the United States last Friday after presiding over a combined services naval defense drill off the eastern Taiwan coast as part of the ongoing "Hankuang No. 17" military exercise.
Li first visited the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii where he exchanged views with American military officials on the Taiwan Strait situation, military sources said.
He arrived in Washington, D.C. Sunday for a five-day visit. While there, Li will hold routine consultations with Pentagon officials on Taiwan's defense needs.
Li will also visit the Norfolk naval base in Virginia to have a look at the Aegis radar-equipped destroyer, one of the advanced weaponry systems that Taiwan wants to buy.

Naval sources said Li was originally scheduled to visit the United States late last year, but postponed the trip because the navy was then reopening a probe into the murder of Captain Yin Ching-feng and was also busy with handling previous warship procurement scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITALIAN FATHER VOWED TO BE '7-ELEVEN' NANNY TO FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: Italian Catholic father Bruno Ciceri, who calls himself the "7-Eleven" nanny to foreign laborers in Taiwan, sometimes works around-the-clock in his Kaohsiung office to serve the foreign workers and sailors who take temporary shelter in Taiwan.
Working 365 days a year, Ciceri has made Kaohsiung's Apostolatus Maris Service Center a lighthouse for foreign nationals who are lost or need help in Taiwan.

Ciceri is particularly familiar with Filipinos and their affairs as he worked for 10 years in the Philippines serving sailors and refugees before coming to Taiwan seven years ago when Taiwan began to introduce Filipino laborers to help out the island's households and manufacturing industry.
Ciceri says he was frustrated during his first two years in Taiwan because he spoke no mandarin Chinese, which made it difficult for him to communicate, particularly with public offices in Kaohsiung.

As the number of Filipinos coming to Taiwan to work increased, his workload and responsibilities soared, which both tired and pleased him, although his Kaohsiung center is always desperately short of funds to maintain its ever-expanding operations.

The center provides help not only for foreign laborers and sailors in Kaohsiung, but for foreign workers from all around the island. Whether they have been unfairly treated or sexually harassed by their Taiwanese employers, or physically abused by their Taiwanese husbands, they go to the Apostolatus Maris Center for help.
There they can find a "free lunch," while Ciceri and his helpers offer free accommodation to help tide them over difficulties until they can find new employment.

Facing an increasingly heavy financial burden at the center, Ciceri is calling for substantive help. He said that since the Taiwanese authorities require Taiwan companies hiring foreign workers to put aside a certain amount of money to be used as employment security funds, they should also extend some help to centers like Apostolatus Maris.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO STRENGTHEN MILITARY SOFTWARE AID TO TAIWAN: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The United States is expected to beef up its sales of military software to the Republic of China over the next 10 to 20 years, a military researcher said Wednesday.

Huang Hsiao-hsiang, head of the mainland China affairs research division of the Graduate Institute of Political Science of military-run Fuhsingkang College made the remarks at a seminar on national defense issues.

Huang said U.S. military experts have not hesitated to point out in their assessment reports that Taiwan must strengthen integration of the combat capabilities of its various military branches and weaponry systems as well as further intensify personnel training.
According to Huang, the U.S. Defense Department has evaluated Taiwan's capacity to withstand a pre-emptive first strike from mainland China and its overall defense capabilities.
"The Pentagon assessment says Taiwan's military operational system and its command-control-communication-intelligence mechanism can hardly pass practical warfare tests," Huang explained.
In addition, Huang said, the Pentagon has also pointed out that there is still room for Taiwan to improve integration of combat capabilities among its various military units and weaponry systems.
Huang went on to say that mainland China generally understands the performance and tactical functions of nearly all weapons that the United States has sold to Taiwan.

From the tactical viewpoint, Huang said, mainland China does not really care about Taiwan's purchases of normal defensive arms. "But it has consistently paid close attention to whether Taiwan acquires offensive weapons and its capability to integrate various weaponry systems," he noted.

Huang further said mainland China has recently assessed the ROC Air Force's combat capability, particularly how its automatic "Strong Net" early warning, command and control system will integrate with the operations of the Air Force's warplane command center, the Navy's combat operation center, the Army's surface-to-air missile bases, the Air Force's anti-aircraft artillery command center and the Civil Aeronautics Administration's airborne control center.
"In other words, mainland China is especially concerned about the efficacy of Taiwan's unified air-defense command system," Huang explained.
Meanwhile, Huang reminded local people not to be overly optimistic about the results of the annual ROC-U.S. meeting on Taiwan's arms procurement plans scheduled to open in Washington, D.C. April 23.

Noting that the U.S. policy toward Taiwan remains flexible and uncertain, Huang said the United States will certainly safeguard as much as possible its own national interests in the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. MAY IMPOSE ANTI-DUMPING TAX ON TAIWAN CD MAKERS: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) on Wednesday urged local compact disc manufacturers to be prepared for the possibility that the European Union will impose temporary anti-dumping tariffs on them in mid-June.
BOFT officials said that there are precedents for the European Union to begin imposing such taxes during the first 60 days after the start of anti-dumping investigations.

The officials added that E.U. trade officials will draw random samples Saturday from the 16 Taiwan CD makers accused of dumping by their competitors in Germany, France, Italy and Holland. The companies selected will then be asked to answer surveys and cooperate with other investigations.

Taiwan is currently the world's largest CD manufacturing center, exporting a total of US$1 billion of compact discs last year. Europe is the island's largest export market, importing US$460 million worth of compact discs from Taiwan last year.

BOFT officials said that the temporary anti-dumping tax requested by the four European CD makers is between 20 to 30 percent, and that if the European Union does indeed impose anti-dumping measures on Taiwan at such a high tariff rate, the local CD makers will be severely affected.
Officials added that many of the CD manufacturers are determined to see through to the end of the lawsuit and are prepared for a long fight.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEND ALTERNATIVE CONSCRIPTS TO CENTRAL AMERICA AND AFRICA

TEXT.P: Starting this year, Taiwanese draftees selected for alternative military service will be sent to Central American, Caribbean and African countries to assist the Republic of China's technical and medical missions there.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Wednesday that the country's technical and medical missions stationed abroad are facing the problems of an aging and insufficiently small workforce. The policy of allowing draftees to engage in alternative military service at diplomatic missions is one of the ministry's six major tasks this year, they added.

MOFA officials said a total of 35 eligible conscripts with related abilities will be sent abroad late this year after undergoing five weeks of military training and three months of technical and language training.

New military conscripts will be able to apply for alternative military service at diplomatic missions starting Wednesday, the MOFA officials said, adding that the selected draftees will begin their various training programs between July and December.
The conscripts serving in these missions will enjoy medical and travel insurance paid for by the agencies with which they serve, and will be granted 14 days of leave after serving for six months.

If this program works well, the Foreign Ministry will consider extending the alternative military service to draftees with backgrounds in foreign languages and international relations for service in the MOFA's overseas embassies and representative offices.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT AMENDMENT AIMS TO GIVE VP LIFETIME PENSION

TEXT.P: Retired Republic of China vice presidents might enjoy a lifetime monthly pension in the future with the legislative committee approval Wednesday of a draft amendment agreeing with the implementation of the payment scheme.
The Legal Affairs Committee under the Legislative Yuan gave the green light to a series of draft amendments to the current law governing the treatment of retired presidents and vice presidents.

Under the terms of the draft amendments submitted by the Executive Yuan, retired vice presidents would enjoy a lifetime monthly pension, as do retired presidents at present. In addition, they would also be entitled to take part in national ceremonies, as well as having the use of vehicles and enjoying medical treatment and security guards provided by the state.

Although one of the added draft amendments -- which stipulates that retired presidents will receive a monthly pension even though it is higher than the monthly salary of the incumbent president -- drew strong protests from opposition lawmakers, the meeting chairwoman, Kuomintang lawmaker Yu Yueh-hsia, still approved the measure.

In the meeting, lawmaker Feng Ting-kuo of the opposition New Party blasted the measure, as it would grant a monthly pension of more than NT$800,000 (around US$25,000) to former President Lee Teng-hui.

Lee's monthly pension would then be higher than the NT$400,000 monthly salary of current Present President Chen Shui-bian, who voluntarily decided to cut his monthly salary to NT$400,000 from the previous level of NT$800,000 last year shortly after assuming the presidency in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPTICAL TELECOM PRODUCTION VALUE EXPECTED TO REACH US$ 225 M.

TEXT.P: The value of Taiwan's optical telecommunications manufacturing is expected to reach NT$7.2 billion (US$225 million) in 2001, an increase of 44 percent over that of last year, according to a research report released Wednesday by the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).
Taiwan's optical telecommunications production value stood at NT$5.0 billion in 2000, up from NT$2.3 billion the previous year.

The rapid development of the Internet in recent years has prompted strengthening of Taiwan's telecommunications infrastructure, including significant growth in research, development and manufacturing of optical telecommunications products.
The optical telecommunications industry is considered a rising star with high development potential in the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ENVOY SPEAKS ON TAIPEI-WASHINGTON-BEIJING TIES

TEXT.P: The U.S.-mainland China row over the recent military aircraft collision has once again indicated that any major event between Washington and Beijing could affect Taiwan-U.S. relations, a retired career diplomat said Wednesday.

Stephen Chen, a former Republic of Chian representative to the United States, made the remarks in a report on the new U.S. administration's Asia policy delivered at a weekly meeting of the opposition Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee.
Chen said the mid-air collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland Chinese fighter over the South China Sea early this month was basically an accident.

In his view, Chen said, the event signifies that any new development in U.S.-mainland China relations can indirectly affect ROC-U.S. relations and the future direction of interactions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Against this backdrop, Chen said, the ROC government should make every possible effort to forge a cross-strait dialogue channel or mechanism.
According to Chen, no responsible government would sit idle and let the current cross-strait stalemate continue.

Chen further said he is worried that several factors may adversely affect future Taiwan-U.S. relations, including the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's position on the ROC's national status, its policy toward traditional overseas Chinese communities in the United States and the ever changing international situation.

Meanwhile, Chen said he is convinced that incumbent U.S. President George W. Bush will be firmer than his predecessors in upholding the principle that the Taiwan Strait issue should be resolved by peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN DENIES FORMER ROC PRESIDENT HAS APPLIED FOR VISA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda Wednesday joined an aide of former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui in denying that Lee had applied for a Japanese entry visa, contradicting the ROC Foreign Ministry.

Fukuda said at a press conference meeting that Japan had not received any application for a visa from Lee, despite the fact that the ROC Foreign Ministry had earlier issued a statement claiming that Lee had indeed applied for a visa to visit Japan in order to seek treatment for a heart ailment.

According to Fukuda, the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association (IA), a semi-official organization set up to handle Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two sides, told the Japanese Foreign Ministry that Lee had not presented a visa application.
He also denied a news report that the Japanese Foreign Ministry had instructed IA officials not to accept a visa application from Lee.

The Japanese government has been at the brunt of strong criticism from several Japanese newspapers, which see the Japanese government's denial of the visa application issue as a cover-up pandering to pressure from Beijing.

It had been reported that soon-to-be-ousted Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori had originally agreed to grant Lee a visa but that Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono was opposed to the move as he is afraid of offending Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES FORMER MILITARY ATTACHE OF S. AFRICAN EMBASSY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told a former military attache of the South African Embassy on Wednesday that the former South African official and his family members had displayed an "incredible" amount of "love" and "courage."

The president made the remarks at the Presidential Office when he received McGill Alexander, his wife Anne and daughter Christine, all of whom were held at gunpoint on Nov. 18, 1997 in their suburban Taipei residence by Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's then-most wanted criminal.

The ordeal of Alexander, his wife and their three children gripped the whole nation after the drama was played out live on television that night. Chen was Taiwan's most wanted criminal at the time, having committed several murders, including the kidnapping and subsequent murder of the daughter of local TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping. Chen was later arrested, tried and executed.

Alexander, a devout Christian, said he has written a book based on that nights' ordeal with the intention of sharing "love" with more people. The president lauded him for bravely walking through "the valley of death" and displaying the beauty of human nature.
Chen said that Nov. 18 is also a special day for him, since his wife Wu Su-chen was hit by a car on the same day, resulting in paralysis from the waist down.

The president added that Alexander's courage was an amazing display of character in the face of a crisis. Chen added that after his wife was paralyzed by the car, the couple had to utilize the same love and courage in order to face each other and their ensuing lives.
Alexander, who retired and returned to South Africa in 1998, is visiting Taiwan to attend a breakfast meeting Saturday to pray for the island.

The president said that only true love will bring true peace, adding that he hopes that with the help of Alexander's prayers, Taiwan will become a place of true love and everlasting peace for both sides of the Taiwan Strait. "We will not only be the children of Taiwan," but also the "children of peace," he added.
The president also recalled that Christine, only 12 years old at the time, had drawn a heart-shaped picture to express her love of God, her family and the arrangement of fate.

Alexander expressed his appreciation to Taipei City government and Taiwan's people for their love and concern for his family. He also thanked Frank Hsieh, then a lawyer who now serves as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party and Kaohsiung City mayor, and HO You-yi, former head of Criminal Investigation at the Taipei City Police Headquarters, who helped negotiate with the notorious Chen for the safe release of the family. He added that Taiwan people's love had given him more confidence in human nature.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'FULL THREE LINKS' UNAVOIDABLE: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: In terms of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and both sides' coming entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), the opening of the "full three links" between Taiwan and mainland China is unavoidable, a ranking Republic of China official said Wednesday.

While seeking to promote the establishment of direct trade, transport and postal links between Taiwan and mainland China, the government must hammer out a package of related measures to minimize the possible adverse impacts on local society, said Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's top policy-making body toward mainland China.

Should Taiwan unilaterally decide to open the direct "full three links" without adequate negotiations with the mainland Chinese side, the domestic agricultural and traditional industries would be seriously threatened, Tsai said. She added that an increased two-way interflow of professional personnel and resources will also fuel the pace of local industries relocating to the mainland.
As the "full three links" will have a far-reaching impact on Taiwan, the government is poised to promote the task gradually at a proper time in line with the overall cross-strait climate, she said.

According to the MAC head, the government will seek to advocate direct trade between the two sides in accordance with regular international norms in the first phase of the links after both sides enter the WTO. The MAC will then move to examine measures to allow greater imports of mainland Chinese goods and greater mainland investment in the local service sector, she said.

As to second-phase exchanges between the two sides, Tsai said the government will have to set up a flexible security mechanism through bilateral negotiations to effectively regulate two-way merchandise, capital, personnel and shipping ties as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS DISCIPLINE FOR TAIPOWER DESPITE PANEL'S JUDGEMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered that disciplinary actions be taken against Taiwan Power Company Wednesday despite a government panel report that cleared the utility company of any fault in a recent nuclear accident.
A government report released Wednesday said that the power outage at the island's No. 3 Nuclear Plant on March 18 was more of a electrical equipment failure than a nuclear accident.

The report, authored by a panel led by head of the National Science Council Wei Che-ho, vindicated the claims of Taiwan Power Company, which operates the nuclear plant, that the reactor was not affected by the accident and no radiation was released into the surrounding environment.

Although Taipower delayed reporting the accident to the National Energy Council, which supervises the operation of the island's three nuclear plants, the company is not otherwise to blame for its handling of the accident, according to the report.

The accident took place when a high-tension cable transmitting power from the plant short-circuited because of damage to its insulators caused by corrosion. As a result, two generators at the nuclear plant automatically shut off, leaving the plant in darkness.

The two backup generators that were supposed to supply electricity to the nuclear plant in a power outage failed to kick in, forcing the reactor to fall back on battery power for its water cooling system, which keeps the reactor from melting down.
Fortunately, another backup system was hooked up and a crisis was avoided before the depletion of the battery, which can last only eight hours.
The accident was given the second most serious rating for risk, on a scale of four categories of the riskiness of nuclear accidents.

The panel, consisting of experts from related government agencies and two electrical equipment specialists from overseas, determined that the incident was really a mechanical breakdown rather than a nuclear accident.

The panel said Taipower should strengthen the maintenance of its electrical equipment and power transmitting grid, replace the ceramic insulators on pylons with ones better able to resist the corrosion caused by salt buildup which plagues the nuclear plant because of its vicinity to the coast.
Currently, Taipower uses helicopters to flush the salt off its insulators.
The accident could not have come at a more ironic time, with the island still reeling from a bitter struggle over the construction of its fourth nuclear plant.
The Executive Yuan ordered the abolishment of the partly finished plant on Oct. 27, 2000, only to be forced to resume the construction on Feb. 13 under pressure from the opposition parties.
The March 18 accident has boosted the anti-nuclear forces' arguments that accidents are inherent in any nuclear plant no matter what safety measures are taken.
Meanwhile, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung was quoted as ordering Taipower to conduct a thorough examination of its three nuclear plants in addition to addressing the problems pointed out in the report.

Hu Ching-piao, chairman of the Atomic Energy Council quoted Chang as saying after receiving the report that Taipower and its immediate supervisory government agency, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, should come up with measures to prevent a repeat of the incident.
Taipower was asked by the premier to take disciplinary actions against officials deemed responsible for the accident.
Taipower President Kuo Junne-Huey has already stepped down in the wake of the incident and was replaced by Lin Ching-chi, one of his deputies.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO ALLOW DIRECT HIRING OF FILIPINO WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has finally achieved a breakthrough in its longtime efforts to promote direct hiring of foreign laborers to avoid the problem of excessive brokerage fees.

CLA officials said that the Republic of China and the Philippines have reached an agreement on the recruiting and contracts of Filipino laborers in the industry, and will allow manufacturing and construction firms to directly hire Filipino laborers starting May 1.
Direct hiring of Filipino household laborers will have to wait until August 1, because the ROC and the Philippines have yet to agree on their working hours and wages.

The Philippines no longer insists that the salaries of foreign laborers working in industries should include meals and accommodation, instead leaving such terms up to the laborers and employers themselves. It is expected that the employers will no longer provide meals and accommodation, as long as the workers and employers reach agreement.
In terms of foreign household laborers, the CLA is in favor of deciding maximum daily wages and mandated leaves of absence by keeping such terms in line with the Labor Standards Law.

The officials said that even if after Aug. 1, when direct introduction of Filipino laborers will be in full force, the system will not replace the current brokerage system, but rather will give employers another option.

According to the content of recruitment contracts, Taiwan employers will be able to get information through Philippine overseas employment agencies, and their recruiting expenditures will be limited to travel expenses for interviewing the laborers within the Philippines. Otherwise, employers could hire Filipino workers through written information in Taiwan.
CLA officials said that as household employers usually have no time to select their workers in person, they predicted that direct hiring will be more commonly used by industrial employers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN `GLADDENED' BY UPCOMING RELEASE OF STRANDED U.S. AIR CREW

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Wednesday that the ROC government was "gladdened" by reports that the 24 stranded U.S. air crew members in mainland China will soon be released.

MOFA Spokeswoman Katharine S.Y. Chang made the brief remark in response to the apparent end to the 11-day standoff between the United States and mainland China, which began after an April 1 mid-air collision between a U.S. reconnaissance plane and a mainland fighter jet over the South China Sea.

However, she refused to speculate how the turn of events will affect an upcoming meeting in Washington, in which U.S. officials are slated to decide on Taiwan's request for arms sales this year. She also refused to speculate on how Washington-Taipei-Beijing relations will be affected.

Beijing has repeatedly called for Washington to apologize over the incident. But the Bush administration has consistently refused to do so, saying that the blame does not rest with the U.S. air crew, which made an emergency landing in mainland territory.

In a gesture taken by Beijing as a sign of its victory in the diplomatic confrontation that followed, Joseph Prueher, U.S. ambassador to mainland China, delivered a carefully worded letter of regret to the mainland's foreign minister. The letter revealed an apparent agreement to hold a meeting starting next Wednesday to discuss the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INTERESTS COULD BE AT RISK AFTER U.S.-MAINLAND CRISIS: MAC

TEXT.P: Government officials are on guard against the possible sacrifice of U.S. support for Taiwan amid reports that the crisis between the United States and mainland China over the crew of a U.S. spy plane ended peacefully Wednesday.
Officials at the Mainland Affairs Council expressed concern that Washington might cool its ties with Taiwan or shelve Taiwan's requests for arms to avoid further escalation of tensions with Beijing.

Although Taipei's Foreign Ministry heaved a sigh of relief at the resolution of the crisis, the MAC officials are privately worried that Washington might reduce the quantity and quality of arms it sells to Taiwan to avoid offending Beijing.
Instead of benefiting from the quarrel between the two powers, the officials said they were bracing for cooler relations with Washington in the wake of the dispute.
The crisis stemmed from the midair collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter April 1. The fighter crashed into the sea and its pilot is missing and presumed dead.
The 24 crew members of the crippled U.S. plane were detained by China after their emergency landing on Hainan, an island in southern China.
Beijing held onto the crew and demanded a full apology from Washington, which the United States refused to issue, contending that the accident was not its fault.

The crisis took a dramatic turn Wednesday after U.S. ambassador to Beijing sent a letter to Beijing's leader, expressing his sorrow for the loss of the Chinese pilot. Although Washington has denied that the message was an official apology, Beijing said the letter met its demands and agreed to release the U.S. crew.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE FIND SUSPECTS IN SLAUGHTER OF RARE ANIMALS

TEXT.P: A task force on the protection of wild animals in central Taiwan's Nantou County found several rare animal carcasses in the homes of two brothers Wednesday. The police say they suspect that the two were involved in a recent slaughter of rare animals in the area.

Acting on a tip, the wildlife protection and investigation task force on Wednesday visited the homes of Chen Yiu-shen, 60, and his brother Chen Yiu-fang, 62, in Chusan village, Nantou County. In addition to the slaughtered rare animals, the police also found the heads and feet of macadues and goats, as well as parts of some unknown animals.
The police seized the evidence and will investigate whether the two brothers were involved in the recently discovered killings of rare animals.

A local TV station disclosed Monday the discovery of the slaughtered carcasses of several rare species, including Formosan sambars, Formosan Reeve's muntafacs and long-haired goats in the Dandah Forest Reservation Area. This conservation area is located in Taiwan's Central Mountain Range around the headwaters of the Choshui River near the border of Nantou and Taitung Counties.
The owner of the carcasses said he had killed the animals a long time ago. He also claimed that someone lent him the animal parts for safe keeping and he had forgotten that person's identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GIVES 120,000 HATCHLINGS, AQUACULTURE EQUIPMENT TO VIETNAM
DOC.DATELINE: Bac Giang Province, Vietnam, April 11 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Legislator Lin Feng-hsi, on behalf of the ROC, donated 120,000 baby fish to Vietnam on Wednesday as part of the ROC's efforts to implement a bilateral fishery cooperative agreement with Vietnam.

The donation ceremony was held at the provincial hall of Bac Giang, a town some 60 kilometers north of Hanoi, with Hu Chia-chi, ROC representative to Vietnam, Nguyen Van Loc, deputy governor of Bac Giang, Nguyen Viet Thang, Vietnamese vice fishery minister, and other Vietnamese officials witnessing.
Besides the 120,000 hatchlings, Lin also donated several pieces of aquaculture equipment.
Speaking at the ceremony, Hu Chia-chi said the 120,000 fish, all of which are mouth breeders, were a symbol of the friendship between the two sides.
In turn, Bac Giang Deputy Governor Nguyen Van Loc thanked the ROC for providing the donations, adding that the gifts will be a big help to the development of Vietnamese aquaculture industry.

Vietnamese Vice Fishery Minister Nguyen Viet Thang lauded the ROC as one of the world's nations having most highly developed aquaculture industries, adding that he hopes the two countries will further strengthen cooperation in the fields of aquaculture management and exporting fishery products.
