DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 12, or the 19th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: `FLYING ANTELOPE' DRUMS UP SUPPORT TO SAVE CONVICTED DECATHLETE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's veteran female athlete Chi Cheng, who earned the nickname "the flying antelope" for breaking records at world track and field events, voiced support Thursday for former decathlete Ku Chin-shui who was convicted in connection with a mid-air explosion on a passenger jet.

Chi, who earned the glorious nickname for repeatedly breaking 100-meter and 200-meter sprint world records in the 1970s, initiated a "Save Ku" drive Thursday in an attempt to seek justice for the decathlete and have him exonerated of what she called a false conviction.

Ku, who won the decathlon gold medal at the Sixth Asian Track and Field Championships in Jakarta in 1985, was sentenced last week to 10 years in prison for his role in an explosion and fire on a UNI Airlines jet some two years ago.

Ku, who had been a physical education teacher at a junior high school in Taipei County until the explosion incident in August 1999, was convicted by judges of the Hualien District Court on charges of violating the civil aeronautics code. The explosion resulted in the death of Ku's older brother and injuries to several other of his relatives on board the plane.

Former Olympic silver medalist Chi said at a press conference marking the initiation of the "Save Ku" campaign that what the Hulien judges described of Ku is not the Ku that she and other athletes know.

Chi said the verdict that the judges delivered is not acceptable because the judges delivered their verdict on Ku in accordance with the indictment compiled by prosecutors from Hualien District Prosecutors Office, but without direct evidence.
She said the verdict is unjustifiable as the accused had no motives behind the "crime," and the "original scene" in the aftermath of the incident was damaged by "first line" people.
Ku is an aboriginal Taiwan citizen from the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien.
The Hualien judges said Ku gave his nephew a bag containing explosive goods, including gasoline, before the latter boarded the MD-90 jet from Taipei to Hualien city Aug. 23, 1999.

The bag, according to the judges, exploded when the plane was in mid-air, killing Ku Chin-chih, the retired athlete's brother, and causing serious burns to Ku's mother, his sister-in-law, and nephew, who were sitting near the luggage rack where the explosion occurred.

According to the judges, Ku had put the gasoline into two plastic bleach bottles. The gasoline leaked during the flight and exploded when it caused a short-circuit in a motorbike battery in a nearby overhead luggage compartment.

Ku said while being questioned in 1999 that he was originally scheduled to take the same flight but canceled the trip for business reasons and assigned his nephew to carry the items that his mother had ordered him to buy in Taipei.
Preliminary investigation reports in 1999 indicated that the blast was caused by two bottles of household bleach.

Ku, who said he will appeal, claimed that the two bottles did indeed contain bleach rather than gasoline and that he had no reason to kill his own kin. He has also alleged that UNI Airlines might bear some responsibility for the blast.
Chi said that together with the "Save Ku" drive, a "Save Ku" support group will also be established to continue to drum up support for Ku and to appeal for justice for the aboriginal athlete.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1 DEAD, 2 INJURED IN GAS EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: One man was killed and two others were injured in a gas explosion Thursday morning at a dormitory for foreign laborers located in northern Taiwan, firefighters said.
Firefighters from Chungli, Taoyuan, reported that they were informed at 2:50 a.m. that the dormitory of Gold Circuit Electronics had experienced a gas explosion.

They rushed to the scene and found three Philippine laborers in serious condition. The trio were sent to hospital, but one of them died enroute. The other two laborers suffered burns to the face and hands.
The cause of the gas explosion is presently under investigation, with firefighters not ruling out the possibility that a heater was the culprit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 65.47 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 65.47 points to close at 5,533.22.
Market turnover amounted to NT$90.88 billion (US$2.76 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: NP LEGISLATOR FILES SUIT AGAINST FORMER PRESIDENT'S AIDE AGAIN

TEXT.P: A legislator from the opposition New Party (NP) filed a lawsuit against a confidant of former President Lee Teng-hui again on Thursday.
NP Legislator Elmer Feng cited the finding of "new facts and evidence" as the reason for filing the suit after the Taipei Prosecutor's Office dismissed a previous suit against Su Chih-cheng.

Prosecutor Wu Chun-li recently dismissed the case filed by Feng, saying that Su, who acted as the "secret envoy" of the former president in contacts with mainland authorities, had not divulged any national secrets nor compromised national security.

Former President Lee said earlier that he was approached by Beijing authorities in the early 1990s shortly after he had assumed the presidency and that he responded to Beijing's offer for secret meetings by sending his personal secretary Su to make contact with messengers from Beijing in Hong Kong with the purpose of giving momentum to cross-strait relations, which had become stagnant by that time.

Feng filed the suit with the Taipei Prosecutor's Office Thursday, citing as the reason the fact that Su had admitted during the investigation period that he had destroyed all the conversation records during his meetings with high-ranking mainland officials.

Feng said that by doing so, Su had evaded supervision by others and that the move of destroying the records was destruction of evidence and therefore involved the breaching of national file law and laws related to the damaging of documents under the Criminal Law.

Feng said that Su's record of his secret meetings constituted a major document of the nation that belonged to the people and should have been properly preserved, adding that its destruction was "damaging to the public or others."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAILS POSITIVE DEVELOPMENT IN 'COLLISION' INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China welcomes the latest positive development in the incident regarding a recent midair collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter, a Presidential Office spokeswoman said Thursday.

Kuo Yao-chi, director of the Presidential Office Public Affairs Office, was responding to Beijing's release of the 24 American EP-3 aircraft crew members after the U.S. government expressed "double sorry" for the incident.
"We are pleased to see the incident resolved peacefully and rationally through diplomatic channels," Kuo said.
Nevertheless, Kuo went on, as mainland China has yet to return the highly sophisticated EP-3 surveillance plane to the United States, the curtain has not yet completely fallen on the incident.
"Therefore, various ROC government agencies will continue keeping close track of new developments in the incident," Kuo stressed.

Asked whether the United States has compromised Taiwan's national interests in negotiations with mainland China for the release of EP-3 crew, Kuo said she believes that the U.S. government has enough wisdom to avoid mix-up of two irrelevant things.

As to whether the incident would affect U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, Kuo said President Chen Shui-bian had already made a public appeal for "delinking" of Taiwan-U.S. arms deals with the U.S.-mainland China "collision" incident.
Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue reiterated Thursday that the ROC is happy over an end to the U.S.-mainland China standoff over the military aircraft collision incident.
Chang declined to make any comment on whether the incident would have any impact on the U.S. arms sales to Taiwan and the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular ties.

Chang only stressed that U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell has said on many occasions that the "collision" incident and U.S. arms sales to Taiwan are irrelevant things and will be handled separately.
ROC and U.S. military officials are scheduled to meet in Washington, D.C. April 23 to discuss Taiwan's arms procurement plans for 2001.

A senior Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the ROC has adopted a pragmatic attitude toward the "collision" incident and has hammered out several measures to cope with the possible developments in the incident.

"We'll keep a close watch on the follow-up developments in the incident," the official said, adding that the impact of the incident on Washington-Beijing ties and interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can be gauged by several events to take place in the coming months.

Those events include the results of the upcoming ROC-U.S. arms procurement meeting, the development in the Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games and whether U.S. President George W. Bush would attend the informal leadership meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum to be held in Shanghai in October.

The United States ended an 11-day crisis with mainland China Wednesday by saying it was "very sorry" a mainland pilot died in a collision with its EP-3 plane over South China Sea and "very sorry" the U.S. plane landed on the mainland without permission.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 65.47 points to close at 5,533.22.

Encouraged by an end to U.S.-mainland China standoff and a surge in U.S. semiconductor stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,521.93 and continued to go up. The index fluctuated between 5,563.51 and 5,503.11 during trading.

A total of 2.41 billion stocks worth NT$90.88 billion (US$2.76 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.16 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$80.99 billion (US$2.46 billion).

Three of the eight major stocks categories posted losses, with bank and insurance shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.8 percent and textile issues at 0.6 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 2.1 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.5 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 326 to 164, with 98 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved up 25 points to close at 5,520, with 6,825 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 14 points to finish at 5,519, with 745 contract transactions, while December futures decreased 49 points to close at 5,600, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,495 for April, 5,505 for May, 5,350 for June, 5,599 for September, and 5,649 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
April TE futures rose 3 points to finish at 277, with 2,109 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 3.5 points to close at 276.5, with 118 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 7.4 points to close at 722.6, with 445 contract transactions, while May TF futures lost 6.6 points to finish at 725.4, with 17 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN PASSES SUSPENSION OF `THUG LAWMAKER'

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Thursday overwhelmingly passed a resolution proposed by the legislative Disciplinary Committee to suspend the rights of independent Legislator Lo Fu-chu for six months as a penalty for his assault on a female colleague.
In an extraordinary session, 155 out of the 160 legislators who were present at the session voted for Lo's suspension for six months, with three voting against the suspension and two abstaining.
The legislative Independent Alliance, of which Lo is a member, proposed earlier in the session that Lo be punished with a three-month suspension rather than a six month suspension.
The Independent Alliance legislators withdrew en masse from the voting session after their amendment proposal was rejected 153-1.

The six-month suspension, the most severe of its kind in the Legislative Yuan's history, was resolved by the Discipline Committee April 3, several days after Lo physically attacked People First Party (PFP) Legislator Diane Lee, which resulted in Lee being hospitalized with a light concussion and injuries to her hands, neck and shoulder.

The physical altercation, which occurred at a legislative Education Committee meeting March 28, began with Lo banging on Lee's desk with his fist and lambasting her for implying that he had connections to organized crime and that he was involved in the alleged corruption and collusion scandal surrounding the Board of Directors of the private Jin Wen Institute of Technology.

A videotaped recording showed that while Lee argued that she never named Lo as an organized crime figure, Lo punched Lee several times and pulled her hair and that Lo's aides physically restrained Lee's male aide, preventing the aide from defending Lee during the scuffle.

On the overwhelming vote for Lo's six-month suspension, Lee, a former television anchorwoman who is now one of the hardest-working and most outspoken lawmakers, expressed her appreciation to her colleagues for passing the proposed punishment for Lo. She said she hopes that this incident will help eradicate the pollution of violence from the Legislative Yuan once and for all.

Lee also said she hopes that the incident is now over and there will not be any more wars of words. "Now it's time for the Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of Education to seriously look into the Jin Wen scandal," Lee added.

Commenting on the passage of his suspension, Lo, who did not show up at Thursday's voting session, said via a written statement issued at around noon by his office that he completely accepted the result, adding that he nevertheless feels that he is the victim of "political wrestling" in the Legislature.
Lo, meanwhile, called for relevant government agencies to find out what individuals have been involved by means of "fraud" or "via gangland channels" in the Jin Wen scandal.
Lo stressed that the government must act to unearth the truths about the scandal and return justice to society.

The Jin Wen scandal was not brought to light until March 28 after Lo violently attacked Lee. It has been alleged that several legislators, Taipei city councilors, ranking government officials and organized crime figures have been involved in interest-peddling and collusion.

Last week, Minister without Portfolio Chang Yu-huei resigned in the wake of implied allegations of his involvement in the scandal. Shortly before Chang resigned, Vice Education Minister Lin Chao-hsien also offered to quit. Both Chang and Lin's resignations were accepted by their superiors and took effect immediately.

Commenting on the Legislature's Thursday vote in favor of suspending Lo, the opposition New Party lauded the legislators who cast "yes" votes, saying that the result indicates that the Legislative Yuan is still capable of examining itself.

The Kuomintang (KMT), the major opposition party which holds the majority of seats in the Legislature, announced later in the day that it welcomes the result. The KMT, however, said its legislative caucus will discuss later whether the three KMT legislators who cast "no" votes against Lo's being suspended should be dealt with in accordance with party discipline.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVAL FLOTILLA COMPLETES GOODWILL VISIT TO CENTRAL AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 11 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Navy flotilla is sailing back to Taiwan, heading through the Panama Canal on Wednesday, after completing a month-long goodwill visit to Central America.

The flotilla, comprised of a 17,000-ton supply ship numbered 530, a Perry-class missile frigate, and a French-built Lafayette missile frigate, passed through the Panama Canal early Wednesday morning on its way to Taiwan's naval base.

Crewed by 400 officers, cadets and sailors, the flotilla made port calls in Guatemala, Honduras and the Dominican Republic in March. Local residents and overseas Chinese were allowed to tour the ROC naval vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES CALL FOR PAY-SCALE REVISION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run enterprises Thursday called for a pay-scale revision and an early end to salary calculations based on seniority, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Lin Wen-Yuan, the vice chairman of MOEA's Commission of National Corporations (CNC), said that China Shipbuilding Corp. and Chinese Petroleum Corp. will be the first to implement the revision, with Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) and the Taipei, Kaohsiung and Taiwan provincial water companies to follow.

Lin also said that the state-run chemical and agricultural businesses in Kaohsiung will be privatized, with shares being released to the public, adding that the companies will be able to determine their pay scales on their own.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp. is now discussing the issue of capital sales to China Steel Corp., which is free to determine the pay scales of both companies.
In order to maintain water utility rates, the ROC government has had to divert more funds to the water companies to make up for the company's deficits over the years.
CNC has proposed privatizing Taipower at the end of 2005, Lin added.

He also suggested that the Chinese Petroleum Corp. should begin the revision of the company pay scale based on seniority ahead of schedule and that Taipower should cut personnel costs to prevent deficits.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS SITUATION TO BE CONSIDERED IN EASING OF 'GO SLOW' POLICY: MAC

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official in charge of mapping out Taiwan's mainland China policy said Thursday that the high unemployment rate on the island will have an effect on the timing and scale in which the government eases the current "go slow, be patient" policy toward investing in mainland China.

John Deng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by a Taipei business executives' association on the problems of Taiwan investors in mainland China.

Some participants voiced their worries about rising unemployment in Taiwan. They said that if the government chooses to ease the "go slow, be patient" policy now, it will induce more Taiwan enterprises to move to the mainland, making the bleak domestic employment market even worse.
Deng responded by saying that the plight of the jobless will be taken into consideration when the government eases the "go slow" policy concerning investment in the mainland.
He said that the timing and scale in which the policy is eased may change because of the worsening jobless situation in Taiwan.

The government initiated the "go slow" policy in 1996, citing the mainland's ongoing hostility toward Taiwan. The policy bans Taiwan businesses from investing in mainland infrastructure construction and subjects each investment project to a cap of US$50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAS NOT LIED ABOUT LEE'S JAPANESE VISA APPLICATION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has not lied about former President Lee Teng-hui's application for a visa to visit Japan for medical purposes, ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Thursday.
Despite repeated denials from the Japanese government, Chang reiterated that Lee indeed has already applied for a visa to go to Japan to receive treatment for a heart problem.
Noting that Lee's reason for wanting to enter Japan is very simple, Chang once again urged Japan not to complicate or politicize the issue since Lee is now just a private citizen.

Chang further said the MOFA has kept close contact with the Republic of Chian representative office in Japan over the issue. "We are hopeful that Lee's visa application can receive a favorable result as soon as possible," she added.
Japan's Foreign Ministry Wednesday repeated a statement it made Tuesday that the former ROC president had not applied for a visa.
Chang declined to comment on whether the stark difference between MOFA's statement and that of its Japanese counterpart would have any adverse impact on future bilateral relations.
She said only that the MOFA's stance on the issue has been consistent. "We will not recall our previous statement concerning the issue. And of course, we are unlikely to lie about the issue."

Lee's planned trip to Japan has drawn a great deal of attention in Taiwan and Japan, with many speculating that the Japanese government is coming under Beijing's pressure not to grant Lee an entry visa. Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.

Nearly all major Japanese newspapers, including the Yomiuri Shimbun, Mainichi Shimbun, Asahi Shimbun and Sankei Shimbun, have editorialized on the issue in the past couple of days, unanimously urging the Japanese government to grant Lee a visa.

The Japanese dailies said Japan has no convincing reason to reject Lee's application for entry for the purpose of medical treatment now that he is a private citizen. They urged their government not to take political factors into consideration.

The Sankei Shimbun also reminded the Japanese government that if it rejects Lee's visa application under a foreign country's pressure, Japan's national dignity and interests would be impaired because the international community would look down upon its poor handling of the issue.
Despite Beijing's vocal opposition, Lee managed to visit Britain and the Czech Republic after he stepped down from the presidency last May.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.N. SPECIAL SESSION ON HIV/AIDS TO BE HELD IN LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: The United Nations will hold a Special Session on HIV/AIDS in New York City June 25-27 to galvanize leadership at the highest levels, intensify international action and mobilize the resources needed to combat the epidemic.
The special session, to be held at the U.N. Headquarters in New York, will be the first ever to address a public health issue.
At the session, U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan and high level government delegations will address several key points:
--The importance of political leadership in developing effective responses and in decreasing the stigma associated with HIV/AIDS.
--Encouraging all sectors of society to play a major role.
--Increasing resources for treatment, prevention and care.
--Preventing new infections and alleviating the social and economic impact of the epidemic.
--Access to care and the development of new technologies and treatments that are both effective and affordable.
According to the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS, governments are expected to adopt a "Declaration of Commitment" setting targets and timetables.

In addition to statements at the plenary session, four interactive round tables will be held for discussions on human rights, international funding and cooperation, prevention and care, and the socio-economic impact of HIV/AIDS. These will involve participants from non-government organizations, the private sector and other concerned groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. MUST PRESS BEIJING FOR HUMAN RIGHTS IMPROVEMENT: GEPHARDT

TEXT.P: The United States must press Communist China to comply with international standards for human rights, trade and security practices, House Democratic leader Richard A. Gephardt said Wednesday.

In a statement issued after learning that Beijing agreed to release the 24 crew members of a U.S. Navy surveillance plane detained on Hainan Island, Congressman Gephardt said that although he is pleased with Beijing's decision to allow the 24 American crew members to return home, the United States must sill press Beijing to improve its human rights record.

Gephardt (D-Mo.) also expressed his concern about the U.S. surveillance plane, saying that "there appears to be no legitimate reason for the Chinese government to retain possession of a U.S. plane or its equipment under these circumstances."
He said that he hopes that the follow-up discussions with Beijing officials that the Bush administration has agreed to will result in the prompt return of the U.S. Navy aircraft and its equipment.

The manner in which Beijing has handled this incident "reinforces my ongoing concerns about China's lack of adherence to the rule of law and accepted international standards. I hope the administration will seek and obtain China's acceptance of international standards governing such incidents so that we may avoid similar events in the future," pointed out the congressman.

Gephardt added that "U.S.-China relations were clearly in jeopardy over the past few days. I am pleased that the Chinese government has apparently concluded that moving beyond this incident was imperative in order to pursue a constructive dialogue with the United States.

"These events clearly demonstrate, however, that our ongoing dialogue with China must include diplomatic pressure to bring about its compliance with international standards in the human rights, trade and security arenas," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.011 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 32.909.
The local currency opened Thursday at 32.915 and was traded between 32.867 and 32.941.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$498 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY FIGURE IN NAVY SCANDAL RETURNS TO ROC, IS 'WILLING TO COOPERATE'

TEXT.P: A key figure in a Navy murder and bribe scandal has returned to Taiwan for the first time in seven years, claiming that she is willing to cooperate with investigators "without any conditions."
German-based arms broker Cheng Chuen-chu, better known as "Mrs. Tu," returned to Taipei Wednesday, reportedly to visit her sick elderly mother.

Mrs. Tu, who fled Taiwan in late 1993 immediately after Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng was found murdered, had previously claimed that she would return to Taipei only when the Taiwan police authorities could ensure her personal protection.

Since her flight from Taiwan, Taiwan law enforcement authorities had met with Mrs. Tu only once, in Singapore in 1994, in order to probe the truth surrounding Yin's murder as well as a scandal involving bribery in the sale of German minesweepers.

State Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa said there is no question that Mrs. Tu's security during her stay in Taiwan will be fully protected. Lu, however, declined to confirm whether she will be "kept" for questioning.

Lu also declined to confirm whether a meeting will be arranged for Mrs. Tu and Navy Commander Kuo Hsi, former officer of the Navy's Weaponry Acquirement Program, "to confront each other for questions." Seven years ago, Kuo personally informed Mrs. Tu that Yin was found dead, leading her to flee the country immediately.
While Mrs. Tu said she will fully cooperate with the investigators concerning the Yin murder, rumors have said that she would be "taken in" for questioning.

Mrs. Tu, who has been living in Germany for the past seven years, is believed to have been a close friend of Yin, whose body was found floating in Suao Harbor in eastern Taiwan on Dec. 9, 1993 -- several days after he had been collecting evidence about alleged irregularities concerning the Navy's procurement of four German-made minesweepers and six French-made frigates.
Tu was the broker between the suppliers of the German-made minesweepers and the Navy Weaponry Acquirement Program office.

The four German-made minesweepers were commissioned into Naval service in March 1995. The four ships have since been operating in Taiwan waters, disguised as oil exploration ships with crews outfitted in nonmilitary uniforms. The low-profile operations are intended to honor the contract the Navy signed with the German maker.
Yin's murder and the related kickback scandal have never been resolved, despite the fact that several Navy officers and private arms brokers have been questioned, indicted or jailed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SAYS IT IS READY FOR COOPERATION WITH PFP IN YEAREND ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: An official of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced Thursday that his party has completed all necessary preparations for cooperation with the People First Party (PFP), also an opposition party, in the yearend elections.
Chao Sho-po, director general of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, said that it would be best if the two parties discussed their cooperation by May 5.

Lin Fong-cheng, secretary general of the KMT's Central Committee, said that his party will contact PFP staff to discuss matters of cooperation, and that if necessary, KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong can also meet for discussions.
The KMT has confirmed that it will not hold primaries in two cities -- Keelung and Hsinchu -- and eight counties -- Taipei, Taoyuan, Changhua, Yunglin, Tainan, Penghu, Taitung, Kinmen, and Hsinchu.
In races expected to be hotly contested, including Taichung City, Pingtung County, and Tainan City, the KMT said it will continue to coordinate matters in the hope of avoiding primaries.

Chao had said earlier that there is room for cooperation in cities and counties in which the KMT will not hold primaries, raising concerns about the progress of cooperation between the two largest opposition parties.

On PFP Deputy Secretary General's Chin Chin-sheng's announcement that he intends to run as the party's candidate in Taipei County's magistrate election and PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung's change of attitude toward not running in Taoyuan County, Chao said that there is a nomination procedure for each party, and that the procedural differences will not affect cooperation between the KMT and PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SANDSTORMS WORSEN TAIWAN'S AIR QUALITY

TEXT.P: A cloud of dust particles stirred up by turbulent sandstorms in northern mainland China arrived over Taiwan Thursday, seriously worsening the island's air quality, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said.

According to EPA officials, residue from violent sandstorms that hit Inner Mongolia April 7-9 reached northern Taiwan early in the morning, and the density of suspended dust particles in the atmosphere surged to a peak around noon.

EPA officials said although particulate matter in the air in northern Taiwan gradually receded in the evening, the island is not expected to be clear of the influence of the latest mainland sandstorms until Saturday. Worse yet, they said, dust particles from mainland sandstorms will begin to affect southern and eastern Taiwan Friday.

EPA tallies showed that suspended dust particles in the northern port city of Keelung reached 380 micrograms per cubic meter at 8 a.m., 78 micrograms in the offshore island of Matsu, 261 micrograms in Wanli on Taiwan's northeastern coast and 197 micrograms on Yangmingshan. "All of the figures are eight to 10 times the normal levels in those areas," said an EPA official.
He urged local people, particularly children, elderly citizens and those who suffer from respiratory diseases such as asthma to refrain from outdoor activities these days for health reasons.
The official further said local drivers are likely to find that their cars are covered by a light coating of yellow dust in the coming days.
Airborne dust from sandstorms in mainland China have affected Taiwan's air quality at least six times so far this year, according to EPA data.
EPA officials said mainland China's northern regions have had an average of 15 sandstorms a year over the past half century, making it one of the four areas in the world most prone to sandstorms.

The officials further said the latest sandstorms were stirred up by a cold air mass coming from Siberia and Mongolia and have swept through the drought-stricken and dusty north-central mainland Chinese province of Gansu before gradually traveling south and east to Hong Kong, Taiwan, the Philippines, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: UMC BUILDS NEW 12-INCH WAFER FAB IN SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 12 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) began building a US$3.6 billion 12-inch wafer fabrication plant in Singapore Thursday.
At the project's groundbreaking ceremony, UMC Group Chairman Robert Tsao said that his company's globalized management was taking another step forward by beginning the plant's construction.

Located in the Pasir Ris Wafer Fab Park, the project is Singapore's first and UMC's third 12-inch wafer fabrication plant. The world's second-largest contract chip manufacturer has one other 12-inch plant in Japan and another in Taiwan.
Less than 10 plants of this kind currently exist in the world.

Singapore Trade Minister George Yeo said at the ceremony that his country is glad to receive a vote of confidence in the future of Singapore's semiconductor industry from UMC and Germany's Infineon Technologies, which holds a 30 percent stake in the project.
Singapore holds a 15 percent stake in the plant through the investment arm of its Economic Development Board, while UMC retains a majority 51.95 percent.

Yeo said that the UMC plant is the single largest manufacturing industry investment item in Singapore's history. He said it would create jobs for an estimated 1,800 Singaporeans and increase the island-nation's annual wafer production by 20 percent.
He added that Singapore is planning to develop a fourth 60-hectare wafer fabrication park because its three existing parks, totaling 200 hectares, will reach full capacity in the next few years.

According to UMC, wafer production at the new plant is scheduled to commence in the third quarter of next year, and first stage production capacity will reach 20,000 wafers per month. At the end of the second stage of construction, slated for the fourth quarter of 2003, capacity will double to 40,000 wafers per month.
The plant will focus on system-on-a-chip products built on 0.13-micron and 0.10-micron process technology jointly developed by UMC, IBM and Infineon.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-SOUTH AFRICAN HOSTAGE PUBLISHES BOOK ON TAIPEI ORDEAL

TEXT.P: The Chinese-language edition of a book by a retired South African diplomat on his family's hostage ordeal in Taipei in November 1997 hit the bookstores Thursday.
McGill Alexander, former military attache at the South African Embassy in Taipei and author of "Hostage in Taipei," said he is very pleased to see the publication of the Chinese version of his book.
Alexander, his wife Anne and daughter Christine all attended the presentation of the translation, which is titled "True Love" in Mandarin Chinese.

Alexander said he and his family are filled with gratitude because they had not only managed to emerge alive from the hostage ordeal but also have managed to overcome their psychological trauma from the terrible experience.
Alexander, his wife and their three children were all held at gunpoint on Nov. 18, 1997 in their suburban Taipei residence by Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's then-most wanted fugitive.

The ordeal of Alexander and his family gripped the whole nation after the drama was played out live on television that night. Chen was Taiwan's most wanted criminal suspect at the time, having committed several murders, including the kidnapping and subsequent murder of the daughter of local TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping. Chen was later arrested, tried and executed.

Alexander, a devout Christian, said he wrote "Hostage in Taipei" to describe that night's ordeal, with the intention of sharing "love" with other victims of crime in Taiwan and other parts of the world.
During his more than two-year stay in Taiwan, Alexander recalled that he deeply enjoyed Taiwan people's friendship, warmth and hospitality.

"Therefore, I have always want to do something for the people of Taiwan, particularly after the island was hit by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21, 1999," Alexander said, adding that he hopes the Chinese edition of his new book can help Taiwan's crime victims find peace of mind.
A devout Christian, Alexander said he is convinced that only true love, not hate, can bring happiness and peace to mankind.

Alexander and his family arrived in Taipei last week to attend a national prayer breakfast. He met with President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday, and will also give lectures to prison inmates during his stay here.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION, PANAMA INK AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 11 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China agricultural mission stationed here and the Panamanian Agriculture Ministry signed a "good seed" agricultural cooperation accord Wednesday to pave the way for continued agricultural development in this Central American country.

ROC Ambassador David C. Y. Hu and Panamanian Agricultural Minister Pedro Adan Gordon clinched the agreement on behalf of their respective governments at a local agricultural college. More than 100 representatives from the Panamanian Education Ministry as well as Youth, Children, Women and Family Ministry were also present on the occasion.

The ROC agricultural mission also displayed a variety of vegetables and fruits at the signing revenue and exhibited a series of charts, photos and written reports to introduce its work and the results achieved so far.

Both Hu and Gordon hailed the signing of the cooperation accord, with the two stressing the importance of persistent agricultural development. They also toured a guava plantation operated by the ROC agricultural mission.

S. P. Lin, head of the ROC agricultural mission, said they began providing plant seeds, agricultural machines and technology to local units in 1988 in conjunction with a "self-sufficiency" plan initiated by the Panamanian Agriculture Ministry to help improve malnutrition of poor people in rural areas.

Over the past decade, the mission has sent out a large amount of seeds to different local organizations, Lin said, but adding that relevant Panamanian authorities had not noticed of its financial and expertise assistance in this country's agricultural development, given the fact that the service was free and seeds were directly given away to all in need.

But due to the mission's tight financial budget in recent years, it decided to promote the "good seed" agriculture cooperation project jointly with the Panamanian authorities in the hope of being able to continue providing its assistance to local people, Lin explained.

Under the terms of the agreement, Lin said that the mission and Panamanian agricultural authorities will jointly be in charge of collecting seeds, and that a national committee will be responsible for the examination of the seeds.

In the future, all the people who need seeds will have to buy them at local branches of the Agriculture Ministry, and proceeds from the sales will be used to set up a fund to continue carrying out the plan, he pointed out, noting that his mission is planning to transfer all its know-how to the Panamanian side within three year to allow it to take in charge of the plan independently.

According to Lin, the mission has set up a seed-collecting and a teaching center in Panama, which jointly can produce around 1,000 kilograms of seeds each year. The Panamanian Agriculture Ministry and it also jointly sponsor a variety of teaching and training courses for local farmers to help them achieve the "self-sufficiency" goal, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO OPEN REAL ESTATE MARKET TO MAINLAND INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is considering the timing and conditions for a possible opening of its real estate market to mainland Chinese investors, an official said Thursday.

Fu Don-cheng, director of the Department of Economic Affairs under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the comment at a seminar on the effects of opening the real estate market to mainland Chinese investors. Fu added that the MAC is currently evaluating such a move, and a report is expected to be released in May.
Fu predicted that the results of the report will allow subsequent developments to move in a "positive" and "open" direction.

In the seminar, which was sponsored by the ROC Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, Fu indicated that the MAC has not excluded the possibility that the date of the opening of the real estate market to mainland Chinese investors could coincide with Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The official said the government decided to open its real estate market to foreign and mainland Chinese investors during a national economic development conference in January.
The official said as soon as the Cabinet approves the change, there will be no limitations on foreign investment in the local real estate market.

However, he said opening the realty market to mainland investment would require more evaluation and perhaps some revision of existing regulations that prohibit mainland Chinese enterprises from investing in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATION TO ARRIVE FOR 3-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: A U.S. congressional delegation led by Senator Phil Gramm (R-TX) will arrive in the Republic of China Saturday for a three-day visit, according to a Thursday press release from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

During their stay, delegation members will call on President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao and other ROC government officials, to exchange views on issues of mutual interest.
Gramm is chairman of the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs and is serving his third Senate term.
Other members of the delegation include Senator Bob Bennett (R-UT), Senator Jim Bunning (R-KY) and Senator Mike Crapo (R-ID), all of whom are members of the Senate Banking Committee.

Bennett is also the immediate past chairman of the Senate's Republican High-Tech Task Force, while Bunning serves on the Senate Committee on Armed Services and Crapo is on the Committee for the Environment and Public Works.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS WITH VISITING NEW ZEALAND PARLIAMENTARIANS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao met Thursday at the Foreign Ministry with a visiting New Zealand parliamentary group led by Peter Dunne, chairman of the United Future Party.
Tien exchanged views with his visitors on bilateral ties between Taiwan and New Zealand in particular and international relations in general.

The nine-member delegation arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a five-day visit during which they are expected to call on Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, vice president of the Legislative Yuan Yao Ing-chi, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development Chen Pao-chih, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council Lin Chong-pin and board chairman of the Sino-New Zealand Economic Association Pan Wen-yen.
They are also scheduled to visit the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the Taipei World Trade Center.
The visitors will also observe Taiwan's economic development, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and social and cultural development.
Dunne, who is described as "very friendly" toward Taiwan, visited the island in 1992 and again in 1993.

At a press conference following the meeting, Tien, questioned by reporters, said that former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's plan to visit Japan was "an issue for the nation" and that his ministry will do whatever it can to help him realize his visit.

Officials of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan were consulting with the Japanese authorities on the issue and the Japanese government was reported to be discussing the issue, Tien said.

Tien also "confirmed" that Lee presented a visa application to the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association on Tuesday, although this has been repeatedly denied by everyone involved, with the exception of the ROC Foreign Ministry.

Tien pointed out that Lee's visa case has attracted attention and support from the Japanese media and "other sectors," which he claimed has put pressure on the Japanese authorities to allow Lee to visit the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES NOT ON AGENDA OF U.S.-MAINLAND CHINA TALKS ON SPY PLANE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Washington's arms sales to Taiwan is not on the agenda of scheduled April 18 talks between Beijing and Washington over the return of a U.S. spy plane stranded on Hainan island, a State Department spokesman said Wednesday.

Answering questions at a regular press briefing, the spokesman said arms sales to Taiwan and the spy plane are separate issues and will not be mixed in the April 18 talks agreed by Beijing and Washington in a deal wherein Beijing agreed to release the 24 crew members of the plane.

The spokesman said the United States decides its arms sales to Taiwan based on an assessment of the island's need for defensive weapons and it is long-standing U.S. policy not to consult with Beijing on the issue.

The spokesman's statement was consistent with Secretary of State Colin Powell's remarks on the issue during the peak of the crisis over the collision between a U.S. spy plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter.

In a related development, U.S. Representative Henry Hyde, chairman of the Committee on International Relations and a Republican from Illinois, said the Bush administration should meet its obligations under the Taiwan Relations Acts by providing the island with the arms it needs to defend itself, irrespective of the spy plane incident.

In a statement issued after Beijing agreed to release the crew, Hyde said the incident exposes Beijing's stance and will harden Congress' attitude toward the communist regime, although its long-term impact on bilateral ties remains to be seen.
He praised the Bush administration's handling of the crisis, which ended with the release of the plane's crew, and supported U.S. military surveillance flights in international airspace.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE: This is to replace CPE0024, which was sent in error.
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 11 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China agricultural mission stationed here and the Panamanian Agriculture Ministry signed a "good seed" agricultural cooperation accord Wednesday to pave the way for continued agricultural development in this Central American country.

Meeting at a local agricultural college, ROC Ambassador David C. Y. Hu and Panamanian Agricultural Minister Pedro Adan Gordon clinched the agreement on behalf of their respective governments at a local agricultural college. But he added that relevant Panamanian authorities had not noticed its financial and expert assistance in the country's agricultural development, which he said was because the service was free and seeds were given directly to anyone in need.

But due to the mission's tight financial budget in recent years, the mission decided to promote the "good seed" agricultural cooperation project jointly with the Panamanian authorities in the hope of being able to continue providing assistance to local people, Lin explained.

The Panamanian Agriculture Ministry and the ROC mission also jointly sponsor a variety of teaching and training courses for local farmers to help them achieve the "self-sufficiency" goal, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PROCUREMENT OF DEFENSIVE WEAPONS MEANT TO AVOID WAR: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland China policy making body said Thursday that the island seeks to purchase advanced defensive weapons from the United States in order to maintain sufficient defensive ability to avoid war.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said at an American Chamber of Commerce China business committee seminar, attended by some 80 corporate and trade representatives from the United States, Europe and Japan, that the weapons would help provide the island with the ability to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait differences through peaceful means.
Taiwan military officials are slated to attend a meeting in Washington later this month to persuade the U.S. administration to sell advanced weapons to the Republic of China.

Touching on upcoming negotiations between Beijing and Washington on the return of a U.S. reconnaissance plane still in mainland Chinese possession after an April 1 mid-air collision with a mainland jet fighter and an emergency landing in mainland territory, Tsai said that whether Taiwan's interests might be sacrificed during the negotiations will need to be closely monitored.
She added that the ROC government was glad to see the safe return of the 24 detained crew members of the U.S. aircraft earlier in the day.
Turning to the government's trade policy toward mainland China, Tsai said that although the mainland market is full of potential, the high risks cannot be ignored.

She went on to say that the ROC government has no intention of delaying further liberalization of its cross-strait economic policy, but added that all factors, including the timing and degree of liberalization, must be carefully balanced against each other.
Tsai said that the process to establish a new order of exchanges should be pragmatic and gradual.

She pointed out that the government is evaluating various concrete measures, including the resumption of bilateral negotiations and the gradual liberalization of bilateral trade limitations, as well as the planning and establishing of direct bilateral trade, postal and transportation links.
Bilateral investment policy and laws related to increased cultural and social exchanges are also being evaluated, she added.
Tsai said that the government hopes normalization of trade relations with the mainland can lead to normalization of bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST IBM-LINUX DEVELOPMENT CENTER INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: In order to help promote the local use of Linux and upgrade local Linux technology, an IBM-Linux Development Center was inaugurated Thursday in Taiwan.
The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.

According to statistics compiled by Tower Group, the number of Linux users had surpassed 10 million as of 2000 with the number of installed units reaching 8.8 million, making Linux the fastest-growing operating system in the server market.

The same statistics also show that Linux is expected to grow 28.4 percent between 2000 and 2004, a higher rate than either Windows NT or Unix, indicating that Linux will be widely used in information appliances (IA) in the future.

In order to match this trend, IBM promised last September to invest US$200 million in seven IBM-Linux Development Centers in Asia. In addition to Taipei, centers will also be built in Shanghai, Beijing, Seoul, Tokyo, Bangalore and Sydney in the next four years.
Hsu Chu-sheng, general manager of IBM (Taiwan), said that the establishment of the IBM-Linux Development Center in Taipei will greatly help Taiwan's industry transformation.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ENERGY CONSUMPTION INCREASING SLOWLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's energy consumption in the first two months of this year grew slightly by 4.1 percent over the same period of last year, due mainly to the slowing economy, government officials said Thursday.

According to statistics compiled by the Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the nation's energy consumption in January and February totaled 13.93 million kiloliters and among all the sectors, only the electric, electronic and machinery industries registered high levels of energy consumption growth, with combined growth of 19.6 percent.

The energy-intensive industries such as steel, cement and chemical materials registered an energy consumption growth of 2.9 percent, 4.1 percent and 5.2 percent, respectively, in the same period, while the energy consumption in the paper-making industry decreased by 7.9 percent, according to the statistics.

MOEA officials said that while the energy consumption grew only slowly, the energy supply increased by 11.3 percent over the same two-month period of last year. They attributed this increase to the fact that the Formosa Group entered the petroleum product market late last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SEMICONDUCTOR MAKERS IMPRESSED BY MAINLAND CHINA TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, April 12 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Many semiconductor manufacturers from the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park were impressed by their recent fact-finding trip to mainland China, said Hsinchu Enterprise Managers Council President Hsu Chin-jung.

Hsu, who headed a council delegation on a visit Beijing, Shanghai, Kunshan and Suzhou at the end of last month, suggested that the Taiwan government begin encouraging high-technology manufacturers to establish factories in mainland China.

Speaking at a press conference organized by the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration, he said the mainland's efficiency in assembling semiconductor manufacturing machinery is very high, citing that installation of related machinery can be completed in 105 days there.

Hsu noted that mainland China is a big country with promising business potential, and suggested that the government take lead in encouraging local manufacturers to move to the mainland and lease land there for Taiwan-owned manufacturing plants.

Chang Chih-yuan, assistant manager of a semiconductor maker, also voiced his impression of the mainland trip, saying that he believes the development of mainland China's semiconductor manufacturing industry will have a solid foundation in a period of three to five years.

Two officials from the science-based industrial park's administration went to the mainland together with the delegation. They said that mainland China has a large market with a good potential in the development of high technology.
But they added that the political system there remains unstable and the mainland's ability in production and marketing are weak.
They pointed out the advantage of engaging in cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in the development of high-level technologies.

After hearing the reports, Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park Administration Director Huang Wen-hsiung expressed his hope that he will be able to visit the mainland to see the development there with his own eyes.
A mainland trip by officials of his level is subject to government approval, however. (By Victor Lai)

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH DELEGATION TO LOBBY FOR TAIWAN'S WHO MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Thursday the formation of a delegation to lobby for Taiwan's membership of the World Health Organization (WHO) during the 2001 WHO general assembly slated for May 14-22 in Geneva.
The delegation, to be led by DOH Director-General Lee Ming-liang, will also include more than 20 members from the local medical sector, a DOH official said.

In cooperation with representatives from Republic of China diplomatic allies, the delegation will stage activities outside the meeting venue to arouse the attention of representatives from across the world during the general assembly, the DOH official said.
It will be the fifth mission of its kind to be formed by Taiwan to lobby for the country's admission into the international organization since 1997.

A spokesman for the local medical sector said Taiwan's lobbying efforts have won widespread recognition and support by many WHO member nations. As the WHO general assembly will coincide with an annual Geneva art festival, he added, a Taiwanese pianist and violinist are also expected to perform on "Taiwan Night" as part of the campaign for Taiwan's WHO membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATION TO ARRIVE FOR 5-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) is expected to arrive in the Republic of China Friday at the head of a four-member delegation for a five-day visit, according to a Thursday press release from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

During their stay, Wu and his entourage will call on President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao and other ROC government officials.
They will also visit several cultural and economic establishments of the ROC.

Besides meeting with ROC government officials, they will also call on Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Wang Yung-ching, chairman of Formosa Plastics Group and other ROC business tycoons.
Born in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Wu's family emigrated to the United States when he was seven. He graduated from the Law School of Yale University in 1982 and practiced for 10 years.

Wu, 46, was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998 and is currently serving his second term. Although he has made several visits to Taiwan, this will the first time he has visited the ROC since being elected to the House.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AT DISADVANTAGE IN ANY ARMS RACE WITH MAINLAND CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) warned in a study released Thursday that Taiwan would be at a disadvantage if it were to be involved in an arms race with mainland China.
According to the study, mainland China's defense spending is seeing two-digit annual growth at the same time that the island's military budget is decreasing.

However, Taiwan's top mainland policy planning agency officials believe that Beijing will continue to focus on economic development and is unlikely to take the "head-on collision course" of an arms build-up.

The study goes on to note that it is still too early to say whether Taipei and Beijing will engage in an arms race -- where the mainland continues to deploy ever-more missiles against Taiwan while the island continues to bolster its anti-missile defenses.

In regard to Beijing's vocal opposition to the possible sale of advanced U.S. Aegis-equipped destroyers and Patriot Configuration-3 missiles to Taiwan at an upcoming arms sales meeting in Washington, the study speculates that Beijing is primarily against the sale because the two weapons systems are elements that can make up a Theater Missile Defense system.

With guided missiles the mainland's "trump cards" for military intimidation of Taiwan, the study continues, Beijing is naturally against the sale of such equipment, especially since such sales might also imply a new level of military cooperation between Taiwan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY FUND LOSES NT$18.4 BILLION IN STOCK OPERATION

TEXT.P: The National Stabilization Fund suffered losses of NT$18.4 billion (US$ 560 million) on the local stock market as of the end of first quarter of this year, Lin Tsung-yung, vice finance minister and executive secretary of the fund, said Thursday.

Lin said that the fund was down NT$36.9 billion because of stock market losses at the end of 2000, but managed to reduce the losses by making NT$18.3 billion in the first quarter on bonds and securities.
Lin divulged the figures at the 13th meeting of the administrative board of the national security fund.

The fund went into operation last year with total funds of NT$500 billion and has so far cast NT$173.2 billion into the stock market, Lin said, adding that he expects the losses to be recovered when the stock market bounces back.

Lin also joined Vice Premier Lai Ing-chaw in denying news reports that the fund will pull out of the stock market within three years, but added that a mechanism should be set up to decide when the fund should pull out of the stock market.

During the meeting, the participants also discussed several proposals for deciding when the fund should be pulled out of the stock market, such as when block trade occurs or exchangeable bonds or certificates are issued.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN SHOULD ISSUE VISA FOR FORMER ROC PRESIDENT: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Japanese Vice Foreign Minister Seishiro Eto "confirmed" Thursday that former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui has applied to enter Japan and said that the Japanese government should issue him a visa.
However, Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda continued to claim that Japan has received no visa application from Lee.

Eto told a press conference that he phoned the Taipei Office of Japan's Interchange Association (IA) the previous night and that officials there confirmed that they had indeed received a visa application from Lee, which was in the hands of the director of the IA's Taipei Office.

Eto also said that he had asked Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori to consult with Foreign Minister Yohei Kono to resolve the issue as soon as possible. He added that Japan should grant Lee a visa as he is now a private citizen.
However, Fukuda later criticized Eto's statement at a press conference and claimed once more that Japanese authorities had received no application from Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS: NO WATER SHORTAGE IN TAIWAN WITHIN 20 YEARS

TEXT.P: A water resources development program devised by the government will ensure sufficient water supplies for the island for the next twenty years, even without building a controversial reservoir, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw said Thursday.

After a meeting on the island's water supplies by the Finance and Economy Panel under the Executive Yuan, Lai told a press conference that Taiwan is becoming "the 18th country in the world" on the threshold of a water shortage because of its growing population and the shift of its industrial structure.
This looming water shortage could become a bottleneck to the island's economic development and hinder the sustained growth of the economy, he warned.

However, he went on, the water resources development program recently worked out by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , which features the maintenance, repair and remodeling of the island's existing waterworks, together with the development of 23 new water resources around the island, will meet the island's water demands until 2021.

The controversial Meinung Reservoir in southern Kaohsiung County was originally tapped as a new water resource. But the project was put on hold, despite Executive Yuan approval in 1992, because of fierce opposition from local residents and a boycott by the local government of Kaohsiung County on the grounds that the projected reservoir would straddle a geological fault, said Lai.

Noting that former Premier Vincent Siew promised not to start its construction unless its opponents' concerns were addressed, Huang Chin-shan, acting director of the Water Resources Bureau under the MOEA said at the press conference that the current government has no plans to start construction at present.

Given the fact that large areas of rice paddy in southern Taiwan will be converted to other grain crops -- that require less water -- after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, about 100 million tons of irrigation water per year will become available for domestic or industrial use at the time, Huang said.
That, combined with the government program, will ensure sufficient water supplies for the island, even without the Meinung Reservoir, until 2021, added Huang.
President Chen Shui-bian has already pledged to deliver his presidential campaign promise not to build the reservoir.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAD PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIPEI IF RE-ELECTED IN MAY
DOC.DATELINE: N'Djamena, Chad, April 12 (CNA) (By Chou Hui-ying & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Chad President Idriss Deby said Thursday that if he is re-elected in a May election, he will visit the Republic of China in September.
Deby made the remark while meeting with a Taiwan business delegation headed by Tai Sheng-tung, president of the ROC Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises Association.
He expressed his appreciation for the ROC government's assistance in his country's economic and trade development and stressed the importance of maintaining relations with Taiwan.
Deby said that he was deeply impressed by ROC President Chen Shui-bian's official trip to Chad last summer not long after his inauguration.

In order to encourage more Taiwan enterprises to invest in his impoverished African country, Deby said the Chad government will consider extending more preferential taxation treatment to Taiwan investors.
The Taiwan mission consists of 31 members from various fields.
