DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 13, or the 20th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig. Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the first European and also the youngest person ever to win the U.S. Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1995: The Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
2000: The World Trade Organization ranks Taiwan as the world's 14th-largest exporting country and the 15th largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999.
2000: The International Monetary Fund ranks the people of Taiwan as the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 in 2000.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 37.75 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 37.75 points to close at 5,495.47.
Market turnover amounted to NT$92.5 billion (US$2.82 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CORNELL UNIVERSITY WELCOMES FORMER ROC PRESIDENT'S VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 12 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Cornell University spokesman said Thursday that the university has always welcomed former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui to return to his old school anytime but added that there is no information concerning his proposed upcoming visit.

Linda Grace-Kobas, director of the Cornell University News Service, said that the school reunion this year is scheduled for June and that if Lee plans to visit the university, he should come before that time.

She said that the school's long-standing stance of welcoming Lee to visit has not changed, but she pointed out that the university is not going to send an invitation to Lee. She added that it will depend on the former president and that if his application for a visa is approved, then Cornell University is ready to welcome him with open arms at any time.
But she said the university is unaware of whether Lee has applied for a visa and that they have no further information to confirm if he will visit Cornell in the near future.

Grace-Kobas pointed to Lee's visit to the school in 1995 when the State Department only notified the university after it had approved Lee's visa application, which she said happened only 12 days before the visit took place.
Judging from this, if Lee plans to visit Cornell University, the school will only be notified shortly before his visit, she added.
Concerning reports that Lee will present a large donation for the construction of a new building at the university, Grace-Kobas said that there is no building on the campus named after Lee.

Friends of the former ROC president and Cornell University alumni donated US$2.5 million to establish a Lee Teng-hui Professor of World Affairs forum in 1994, but there have been no additional donations since then.
Lee is currently awaiting visa approval from the Japanese government to visit Japan for the treatment of his heart problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: `SNAKEHEAD' OPERATORS BUSTED

TEXT.P: Two members of a cross-strait snakehead ring have been nabbed for allegedly smuggling mainland Chinese women into Taiwan to work in the sex trade, sources from the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported.

The two Taiwan men, identified as Kao Mu-shan and Chen Ming-chi, were apprehended by CIB agents Thursday in the northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu on charges of being involved in arranging false marriages between mainland Chinese women and Taiwan men and then forcing the women to work as prostitutes in Taiwan.

The CIB agents arrested Kao and Chen after they received a complaint filed by a Taiwan friend of a mainland Chinese woman, surnamed Wan, from Sichuan Province's Chungqing City, saying that she was among six women from mainland China being forced to work as prostitutes in an underground brothel in Hsinchu.
CIB agents also raided the underground brothel and rescued Wan and another mainland Chinese woman, surnamed Tsai.
According to Wan, she became acquainted with Chen and Kao last June in Chungqing. Wan married Chen in December and had their marriage officially registered in both Chungqing and Taiwan.

Chen brought Wan to Taiwan in March of this year but did not take her to his home. Instead, according to Wan, she was taken directly to Hsinchu by Kao, who arranged for her to live with five other mainland Chinese women in an apartment, forcing them to work as prostitutes. Wan claims that she had been forced to take customers 42 times since late March.
The police found that the other four mainland Chinese women, some of whom are college graduates, were also taken to Taiwan in a similar manner and were forced into prostitution.
According to Kao and Chen, the snakehead ring is actually operated by a man surnamed Hsu, whom the police are actively tracking down.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR ADJUSTING 'GO SLOW' POLICY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the government has not set any timetable for the adjustment of the present "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan plenary session, Chang said the government is now reviewing the "go slow" or "no haste" mainland investment policy and evaluating the pros and cons of the opening of full-fledged direct "three links" across the Taiwan Strait.

"The evaluation is expected to be finalized by the end of June," Chang said, adding that the government must consider Taiwan's security and its industrial sector's overall competitiveness. "We cannot mull the issue only from the viewpoints of economics."
Chang further explained that the adjustment of the "go slow" policy must take into consideration cross-strait interaction and Taipei's and Beijing's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
"Basically, the 'go slow' policy needs adjustment mainly because of the prevailing trend of globalization," Chang said, adding that the timing for adjustment must be carefully chosen.

While easing current restrictions on the lines of buisness local companies can legally invest on the mainland, Chang said, the government intends to simultaneously forge a mechanism for the return of capital from the other side of the Taiwan Strait and protect the well-being of local industries as well as Taiwan's national security and competitiveness.

Noting that the current general international economic situation is different from the climate seen in the mid-1990s when the "go slow" policy was formulated, Chang said the policy must be reviewed from time to time and make necessary adjustment at an appropriate time.

The premier further said the government currently does not rule out the possibility of Taiwan being admitted to the WTO this year. "But if this goal cannot be realized, the government would not sit idle. We may delink such issues as the adjustment of 'go slow' policy and the opening of direct cross-strait 'three links' from our WTO accession," he noted.

If Taiwan's WTO entry is postponed indefinitely, Chang said, the government may still adjust the "go slow" mainland investment policy or open the direct cross-strait trade, mail and transport links ahead of the WTO accession so long as Taiwan's security and economic competitiveness can be ensured.

The premier also defended the Cainet-initiated NT$810 billion (US$24.7 billion) public investment package, saying that all projects included in the package were mainly designed to stimulate domestic demand and bolster domestic economic development.

Stressing that some of them are follow-up projects in connection with major infrastructure construction programs launched by the previous Kuomintang government, Chang reiterated that the pump-priming package has nothing to do with the year-end elections for legislators and local government chiefs.

Chang further dismissed as "unfounded" and "unfair" the allegations by some opposition lawmakers that many projects included in the NT$810 billion investment package were designed to give favors to some local political forces or factions in exchange for their support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidates in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 37.75 points to close at 5,495.47.

Encouraged by an upward streak in U.S. stocks, the bourse opened at 5,592.3 but began to go down later due to profit-taking selling pressure. The index fluctuated between 5,601.49 and 5,492.3 during trading.

A total of 2.56 billion stocks worth NT$92.5 billion (US$2.82 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.41 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$90.88 billion (US$2.76 billion).

Two of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.4 percent. Plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 5.5 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.3 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.2 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.9 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 279 to 226, with 82 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SAYS NO SECRET DEALS MADE WITH BEIJING OVER U.S. CREW

TEXT.P: The White House emphasized Thursday that there were no secret deals with Beijing concerning the release of the 24 crew members of the U.S. Navy surveillance plane and that President George W. Bush believes the framework for a productive U.S.-mainland China relationship remains in place.

White House spokesman Ari Fleischer said when briefing the press tat there were no secret understandings reached with Beijing and that the only issues discussed in the days of negotiations over the release of the crew members were those mentioned in the U.S. letter to Communist China that provided the breakthrough.

In the letter, the United States said it was "very sorry" that Communist China lost a fighter pilot in the April 1 collision between his jet fighter and the U.S. aircraft, and that the damaged surveillance plane landed on Hainan Island without verbal clearance.
However, Fleischer added that U.S. surveillance flights near mainland China in international airspace are vital and necessary for regional security and "will be ongoing."

White House aides, meanwhile, said President Bush was pleased that the release of the 24 crew members was resolved calmly through diplomatic channels and that the framework for productive U.S. relations with Communist China has been preserved.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SPY FLIGHTS AIMED AT MONITORING M'LAND BUILDUP: COMMENTATOR

TEXT.P: A Canadian commentator said Thursday that the reason the Americans are flying surveillance planes along the mainland Chinese coast is to monitor the unprecedented peacetime buildup of Communist Chinese naval and air forces deployed against Taiwan.
David Warren of the Ottawa Citizen said that "it is also the reason why the Chinese military has become so sensitive about being monitored."

This view echoes that of Dr. Thomas T.P. Chen, new representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, Canada, who said the root cause of the air collision of April 1 is mainland China's increasing threat to Taiwan.

During a recent interview with the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC), Chen said mainland China has deployed more than 300 guided missiles in an area facing Taiwan. He noted that Beijing has been aggressively boosting its military power and intimidating Taiwan verbally and militarily.

"This kind of behavior has affected peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, prompting the U.S. to beef up surveillance in the area," and therefore, he said, the best solution would be for mainland China to stop its threats of an armed attack against Taiwan.

Warren said the air incident off Hainan Island was a "symbolic token" of the real collision between Communist China and the West. "It is something that has been building for the length of the Clinton administration and is now just maturing," he noted.
"The issue, the trigger, is going to be Taiwan, and we ought to be preparing for it," he advised his Canadian readers.

The columnist said the West has the entirely false impression that Communist China's aggressive stance toward Taiwan is a response to that island's increasing tendency toward independence, as if it were not already free, and even a response to its electoral process, which saw the creation of the first multi-party democracy in the whole history of the Chinese people.

He termed as "ludicrous" the view that the recovery of Taiwan is some kind of nationalist imperative. The real and only pressure for Communist China is its survival in a world that is much freer than it was before the Berlin Wall was dismantled and before the students in Tiananmen Square were "barbarically gunned down," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY FIGURE IN NAVY SCANDAL TO MEET PRESS

TEXT.P: A key figure in a Republic of China Navy murder case and related kickbacks scandal who has returned to Taiwan for the first time in seven years, finally agreed to meet the press later Friday to "clarify her innocence."

German-based arms broker Tu Cheng Chuen-chu, better known as "Mrs. Tu," who returned to Taiwan three days ago, said that she succumbed to the press only after becoming tired of being hounded by the media, claiming that most of the media reports about her have been far from the truth.

According to Hsieh Tsung-min, a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) adviser, Mrs. Tu, who returned to Taiwan to visit her sick elderly mother, has not been able to go to the hospital to see her mother since her return because of fears of being mobbed by reporters and camera crews.

Mrs. Tu, who fled Taiwan in late 1993 immediately after ROC Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng was found murdered, had previously claimed that she would return to Taipei only after police authorities in Taiwan could ensure her personal protection.

Tu was the broker between the suppliers of four German-made minesweepers and related parts and components and the ROC Navy's Weaponry Acquirement Program (WAP) office, of which Capt. Yin was director.

Although it is widely believed that she is not directly connected to Yin's murder, the return of Mrs. Tu, a close friend of Yin, is expected to significantly help police paint a clearer picture of the murder case and related kickbacks scandal.

Neither the kickbacks scandal nor murder case has been resolved over the past seven years, despite the fact that more than 10 ROC Navy officers and private arms brokers have been questioned, indicted or jailed. Among them is Kuo Li-heng, Yin's colleague at the WAP office, who is currently serving a life sentence in prison.

Mrs. Tu, who has been living in Germany for the past seven years, is believed to have been a close friend of Yin, whose body was found floating in Suao Harbor in eastern Taiwan on Dec. 9, 1993 -- several days after he had been collecting evidence about alleged irregularities concerning the Navy's procurement of four German-made minesweepers and six French-made frigates.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were generally lower on Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved down 59 points to close at 5,461, with 5,827 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May lost 53 points to finish at 5,466, with 931 contract transactions, while June futures gained 145 points to close at 5,520, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,520 for April, 5,519 for May, 5,375 for June, 5,624 for September, and 5,600 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
April TE futures lost 5.3 points to finish at 271.7, with 1,876 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved down 3.6 points to close at 272.9, with 184 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures increased 3.6 points to close at 726.2, with 783 contract transactions, while May TF futures gained 1.6 points to finish at 727, with 65 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC MISSILE DEPLOYMENT DEADLY THREAT TO TAIWAN: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Mainland China's increasing deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan poses a deadly threat to the island, a local scholar said Friday.

Chen Wen-hsien, a deputy research fellow at the Institute of International Relations, National Chengchi University, said mainland China's build-up of short-range ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan has buttressed the threat to Taiwan, militarily, politically and psychologically.
Mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) is the major and most frightening threat to Taiwan, Chen said.
Noting that the number of PLA missiles targeting Taiwan have grown at 50 a year to about 300 this year, Chen said the threats should not be ignored.
Any military conflict -- caused by either Beijing or Taiwan -- would be disastrous to the peace and stability of the Taiwan Strait, he continued.

Chen made the remarks in a paper titled "Taiwan's crisis management in U.S.-China-Taiwan relations" delivered at a symposium sponsored by the Taiwan Security Guarantee Association and the non-profit International Cultural Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INSTITUTIONAL INVESTORS KEEN ON TAIWAN REAL ESTATE MARKET

TEXT.P: A real estate leader said Friday that around 20 foreign institutional investors, including Merril Lynch and Standard & Poor's, are keen to invest in the Taiwan real estate market.

Lai Cheng-yi, president of the Federation of Taiwan Architecture and Investment Association, said that among the institutional investors that are currently inspecting the real estate market in Taiwan, Merril Lynch has made the fastest progress.

Lai said that Merril Lynch had sent officials to Taichung and Kaohsiung to conduct an inspection and had selected investment targets, saying that Taichung should be the first priority with its brisk business and high standard of living.

He said that Merril Lynch officials told him that Taiwan's real estate market had dropped by more than half since 1993, and that this is the best time to make inroads into the real estate market, especially since direct trade, postal and transport links -- commonly known as the "three direct links" -- between Taiwan and mainland China "will be enforced within a year." By that time, he went on, many foreign investors will be working with local real estate operators.
Lai said that foreign investors will mainly eye business real estate, meaning office buildings, hotels, resort and leisure centers and shopping malls.

As the government is now evaluating the timing and conditions for the opening of mainland investors to the local real estate market, Lai predicted that mainland investors will come to Taiwan within a couple of months, which should help stimulate the slumping real estate market.

He noted that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin said explicitly in late January that he hopes Taiwan will allow mainland investors to invest in the Taiwan real estate market. Lai added that he believes that as long as Taiwan opens the door, mainland investors will "scramble" to get into Taiwan's real estate market.
He said that from a political point of view, mainland investors in Taiwan's real estate market would help ease cross-Taiwan Strait tension and facilitate the "direct three links."

In addition, he continued, the exodus of Taiwan businessmen in recent years has resulted in the loss of foreign currency and the opening of the local real estate market to mainland investors will help redress the balance of capital flight to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE: BUSH WILL DECIDE ON ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN IN DUE COURSE

TEXT.P: U.S. National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice said Thursday that President George W. Bush hasn't even looked at the issue of arms sales to Taiwan yet and that he will make a decision on the matter in due course.
U.S. and Taiwan representatives are scheduled to meet in Washington, D.C., on April 23 for their annual discussions on U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.

In a interview on the CBS television program "Early Show," Rice denied that the Washington-Beijing standoff that followed the mid-air collision between a Communist Chinese jetfighter and a U.S. surveillance aircraft is going to affect the U.S. decision on arms sales to Taiwan.
"I can tell you that no one who has responsibility for making a decision has even looked at the Taiwan arms issue just yet," Rice said.
She said that President Bush is presently receiving recommendations about the issue and will make a decision in due time.
"I'm certain that he will consider it in the context of what it takes to help Taiwan defend itself through the Taiwan Relations Act," she pointed out.

In another TV interview with the ABC show "Good Morning America," Rice made it clear that the United States had no plans during the standoff this month to abandon surveillance flights near Communist China's coast despite protests from Beijing.
Rice said such "reconnaissance missions" are part of a broad U.S. national security strategy aimed at peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region and at protecting the United States and its allies.

"We're happy to talk to the Chinese government about how we might avoid such an accident in the future. But we're going to continue to do what is most effective for our national security strategy," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.001 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 32.908.
The local currency opened Friday at 32.898 and was traded between 32.865 and 32.925.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$191 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MISLED BY PLA ON MID-AIR COLLISION: EXPERT

TEXT.P: A noted American China expert said Thursday that the Communist Chinese military damaged itself in the eyes of its Communist Party masters by misleading the government about the circumstances surrounding the mid-air collision between the Chinese jetfighter and the U.S. Navy surveillance plane April 1.
Larry Wortzel, director of the Asian Studies Center at the Heritage Foundation, said that this may have unpredictable consequences on the internal power struggle to decide Beijing's next leadership.

He commented that the Communist Chinese government will use propaganda at home to paint the outcome of the incident as a victory, but he added that he does not see the outcome as an international propaganda victory for Beijing.

In the wake of Beijing's release of the 24 crewmembers of the U.S. Navy EP-3 surveillance plane that made an emergency landing on mainland China's Hainan Island without first getting clearance, Wortzel said follow-up talks are critical.

The United States must insist on its right to conduct surveillance flights and to transit South China Sea waters. "Rules of the road for military aircraft and ships operating near each other must be established and agreed upon," emphasized the former U.S. Army attache in Beijing.

"It is important to note that we had such talks with the Soviet Union and managed to conduct reconnaissance flights and air intercepts (or sea intercepts for ships) for years with a minimum number of incidents," said Wortzel, adding that the U.S. cannot accept blame for the collision and should not make reparations for either the lost jet fighter or its pilot.

America's Asian allies have been supportive of this approach, the China expert continued. He said the countries that have territorial disputes with Communist China are very happy that the U.S. stood up against Beijing and denied its "expansionist" territorial claims in the South China Sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW-PROFILE ACTIVITIES TO MARK PRESIDENT'S 1ST ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is planning to invite media executives and editors-in-chief to travel with him around the island next month to celebrate the first anniversary of his May 20 inauguration, presidential aides said Friday.
The aides said that the trip will herald a series of low-profile activities to mark Chen's first anniversary in office.
The aides said that the first stop on the May 10-11 trip will be to witness the commissioning ceremony of a Mirage 2000 at Hsinchu Air Force Base.
The presidential plane will also visit several other places around the island, during which the president is also expected to be interviewed by the media executives.
The aides said that the celebration will also include music recitals May 16 by five local musicians that have won prestigious international awards.
The aides also said that the Presidential Office is evaluating whether to call a press conference on May 20 despite reports that said no such press conference will take place.
After the May 20 anniversary, Chen is expected to visit five allies in central and southern America before returning to Taiwan June 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA SANDSTORM CONTINUES TO AFFECT TAIWAN'S AIR QUALITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's air quality remained hazardous Friday because of the effects of turbulent sandstorms originating in northern mainland China, according to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
Data recorded by EPA air quality observation stations throughout the island showed that the density of dust particles suspended in the air remained at harmful levels.

EPA officials said that although the particle density had gradually declined from a peak of more than 300 milligrams per cubic meter at Thursday noon to about 150 milligrams Friday morning in northern Taiwan, the density remained at around 200 milligrams in southern Taiwan.

The officials said the impact on Taiwan's air quality from the latest mainland sandstorms would gradually recede Friday evening and that the whole island would be clear of the sandstorms' effect Saturday, when a cold front from southern mainland China is forecast to hit Taiwan.

Taiwan's air quality had remained hazardous since Wednesday evening when clouds of dust particles stirred up by violent sandstorms that struck mainland China's Inner Mongolia April 7-9 reached northern Taiwan.
EPA tallies show that the density of dust particles suspended in the island's atmosphere had surged to eight to 10 times the normal levels in the past few days.

Noting that sandstorms are a seasonal meteorological phenomenon, a senior EPA official said Taiwan is most likely to be affected by mainland China-originating sandstorms between March and May each year.

He said local people, particularly children, the elderly and those who suffer from respiratory diseases such as asthma should refrain from outdoor activities whenever residue from mainland sandstorms arrives in Taiwan's atmosphere.
Many local drivers have found their cars covered by a light coating of yellow dust in the past few days.
According to EPA data, airborne dust from sandstorms in mainland China has affected Taiwan's air quality at least six times so far this year.
The EPA officials said mainland China's northern regions have had an average of 15 sandstorms a year over the past half century, making it one of the four areas in the world most prone to sandstorms.

The officials further said the latest sandstorms were stirred up by a cold air mass coming from Siberia and Mongolia and swept through the drought-stricken and dusty north-central mainland Chinese province of Gansu before gradually traveling south and east to Hong Kong, Taiwan, the Philippines, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMS PURCHASES RESULTS PREDICTED TO BE BETTER THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 12 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei should be able to acquire most of the weapons it wishes to purchase from Washington this year, Republic of China Deputy Representative to the United States Lee Ying-yuan said Thursday.

Expressing optimism about the prospects of U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, Lee said he is confident that the ROC government will acquire better weapons from the United States this year. But he also pointed out that this does not mean that Taiwan will obtain all the weapons it hopes to this year.
In addition to arms procurement, Lee said, the ROC government also hopes to strengthen personnel training and software development with the United States.
At the same time, bilateral Taipei-Washington communication channels are open and smooth, allowing each side to fully express its opinions to the other, Lee noted.
Lee made the remarks in Boston during a speech to an ROC students' association at Harvard University.

As to the recent collision between a U.S. spy plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter, Lee contended that the stance adopted by certain U.S. media -- that Washington's arms sales to Taiwan should be linked to Washington-Beijing ties -- is a positive development for Taiwan.

Turning to the political situation in Taiwan, Lee admitted that some disorder emerged in the initial stages of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rule. Describing this disorder as some "small episodes" on Taiwan's path toward democratic development, he said he is still optimistic that the country will continue moving toward an institutionalized democracy.

Regarding the coming legislative election slated for the end of this year, Lee predicted that it will be a three-way battle among the DPP, the Kuomintang and the People First Party, with none of them being able to control a majority of seats in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE OFFICIAL CONTINUES TO WOO TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Visiting Vietnamese officials continued Friday to court Taiwan businessmen to invest in Vietnam.

A Vietnamese delegation led by Ho Chi Min City Deputy Mayor Tran Ngoc Con held a symposium for business and industrial leaders in the Kaohsiung area at the Kaohsiung Office of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).
During the meeting, Tran briefed local investors on the investment climate and incentives adopted by his city government.

In order to lure more foreign investors to his country, Tran said that the government has amended many outdated trade regulations and laws and has signed trade and investment agreements with foreign countries so as to assure the investors' interests. Vietnam has attracted more than 2,790 foreign investment cases worth US$36 billion in the past 11 years, Tran added.

He expressed the hope that foreign investors who establish operations in Ho Chi Min City will use local raw materials and only import if the local supplies are insufficient. The government will not levy taxes on such materials used for export purposes and will provide "cheap and convenient" public facilities, he went on.

At present, some 2,000 Taiwan investors are operating in Vietnam, behind only Singapore in terms of investment value, Tran said, adding that Taiwan would top the list of foreign investment if total investment cases were counted.
Representatives of Taiwan investors in Vietnam said that two-way trade between Vietnam and Taiwan has averaged US$1 billion per year since Vietnam opened up its market to foreign investors.

They cited cheap and skilled local labor, as well as loose controls of foreign currency as good reasons to invest there, with foodstuffs, machinery, cement, textiles and ready-made garments the most suitable areas in which to invest.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS, SCHOLARS PUSH JAPAN TO REVISE TEXTBOOKS

TEXT.P: A group of Republic of China legislators and scholars launched a campaign Friday to urge Japan to rewrite school textbooks that gloss over its wartime role and atrocities.

Chu Teh-lan, a researcher with Academia Sinica's Sun Yat-sen Institute for Social Sciences and Philosophy, told a news conference that more than 60 local college professors had signed an open letter protesting whitewashed accounts in a new set of history textbooks for Japanese high school students to be used from next April.
Chu said local scholars will cooperate with their South Korean and Japanese peers in publishing an international version of history textbooks to offer the correct accounts of major historical events.

Speaking on the same occasion, opposition New Party Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta said she will launch a national campaign urging local people and legislators to sign an open letter to the Japanese general public and parliamentarians pushing for revisions to the whitewashed Japanese textbooks.

Government authorities and private groups in Taiwan, mainland China and South Korea have repeatedly asked Japan to rectify the "inappropriate content" in its new high school textbooks since Japan's Education Ministry approved in late March the draft of the textbooks written by historians with nationalist leanings.

Many sections of the new textbooks give whitewashed accounts of Japan's colonial past and wartime atrocities, particularly those regarding the "Nanjing Massacre," in which at least 300,000 civilians are said to have died when Japanese troops overran the central mainland Chinese city in December 1937. The Japanese textbook does not include casualty figures in what it refers to as merely the "Nanjing Incident."

The textbook also fails to give a faithful account of many of the Japanese atrocities committed during World War II, including the forcing of some 200,000 women from Taiwan and other Asian countries into sexual slavery in military brothels.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER URGES JAPAN TO APPROVE VISA FOR FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung, Mike Chang and Huang Kuei-mei)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged the Japanese government Friday to approve former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's application for a visa to visit Japan to undertake treatment for a heart condition.
Chang said in response to a lawmaker's interpellation at the Legislative Yuan that the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs is currently negotiating with the Japan over the issue.
He added that Japan should regard Lee's reason for the visit "with importance" and grant the visa because it is a decision that a democratic nation should make.

Lee's planned trip to Japan has drawn a great deal of attention in both countries, with many speculating that the Japanese government is under pressure from Beijing not to grant the former president an entry visa.

Lee complained of chest pains after a trip to the Czech Republic last October and in November underwent successful coronary angioplasty surgery in an operation overseen by the same Japanese doctor he plans to visit in Japan for continued treatment.

Meanwhile, a group of 16 ROC legislators who studied in Japan announced that they plan to deliver an open letter to the Japanese government Saturday through the Taipei office of the quasi-official Japan Interchange Association.

The lawmakers said that they will urge Japan to grant Lee a visa on humanitarian grounds and because he is now a private citizen. The Japanese government has no reason to deny entry to civilians seeking medical treatment, the legislators added.

Aside from the urgings of ROC officials and lawmakers, private ROC citizens groups in both Taiwan and Japan began calling for a massive letter-writing campaign to persuade Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori and Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono to approve Lee's visa.
Major Japanese newspapers have editorialized on the issue in the past few days and have been unanimously in favor of granting the visa.

The dailies criticized the Japanese government for maintaining an excessively weak diplomatic profile, with the Sankei Shimbun reminding the government that a rejection of Lee's visa application under "foreign pressure" will impair Japan's national dignity and interests because the international community will look down upon its poor handling of the issue.
Over 60 Japanese lawmakers came together the previous day to call on their government to grant Lee a visa. Earlier Friday, five members of Mori's Cabinet made the same call at a Cabinet meeting.

However, Foreign Minister Kono stood by the official claim that his ministry had yet to even receive an application from Lee, despite Kono's deputy, Vice Foreign Minister Seishiro Eto, confirming the previous day that Japan had received a visa application from Lee.

Noting that Eto's claim exposed his ministry's attempt to avoid making a decision, the Japanese dailies charged that the Foreign Ministry and Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda want to delay resolving the issue so that Lee will be forced to give up his application.

Earlier in the day in Tokyo, after a meeting with Mori, Kono said that the prime minister instructed him to "continue gathering data" on the issue. Kono added that if necessary, the Japanese government might consider sending a physician to Taiwan to treat Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-AMERICAN CONGRESSMAN WU ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) arrived in the Republic of China Friday at the head of a four-member delegation making a five-day visit.
Wu and his entourage were greeted at the airport by Kao Shuo-tai, director general of the Department of North American Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
After a short rest, the group visited the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) where they heard an hour-long brief by AIT officials.
Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank and Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, hosted a lunch to entertain Wu and his entourage.
In the afternoon, the delegation called on Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., and Chang Jung-fa, chairman of Evergreen Group.

During their stay, Wu and his entourage will also call on President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao and other ROC government officials.
Born in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Wu emigrated to the United States with his parents when he was seven. He graduated from Yale University Law School in 1982 and practiced as a lawyer for 10 years.

Wu, 46, was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998 and is currently serving his second term. Although he has made several visits to the ROC, this is his first visit since being elected to the House.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC VICE PRESIDENT TO BE CREMATED

TEXT.P: The body of senior presidential advisor and former Vice President Shieh Tung-min will be cremated Saturday at Taipei's second municipal funeral parlor.

Out of respect for Shieh's last wishes, his family turned down offers from the government and the opposition Kuomintang to form an ad hoc committee to take care of Shieh's final journey and to hold a public funeral for him.
Shih Chien University, which was founded by Shieh, will sponsor a concert April 22 in memory of the Republic of China's first Taiwan-born provincial governor and vice president.
Following the concert, his remains will be taken back to his hometown in central Taiwan's Changhua County, where his wife is buried.
Shieh died Sunday at his Taipei home from cardiac infarction. He was 95.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE CABINET MEMBERS WANT VISA FOR FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 13 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: At least five Japanese Cabinet members expressed hope Friday that Japan will issue an entry visa to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui as soon as possible.

A local news report identified the Cabinet members in question as Minister of Land and Transport Chikage Ogi, Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Livestock Takeo Hirazawa, Director of the Self-Defense Agency Toshitsugu Saito, Minister of Economics and Finance Taro Aso, and Minister of Science and Technology Takshi Sasagawa.

At a Cabinet meeting, they said that Lee should be granted a visa on the grounds that he is now a private citizen and his trip is for the purpose of medical treatment. Foreign Minister Yohei Kono said that he would carefully and seriously handle the case, while Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori and Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda made no comment, according to the local media.

Mori had earlier instructed Kono to collect more information about the former ROC head of state's visa application, although the Japanese Foreign Ministry continued to insist that Lee had not presented any visa application.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DHARMA MASTER INVITED TO JOIN WORLD PEACE SUMMIT BOARD

TEXT.P: Bawa Jain, secretary general of the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, is slated to arrive in Taiwan Sunday to formally invite Dharma Master Hsin Tao to join the summit's international advisory board.

According to Jain's office, the board will be responsible for identifying key regional religious leaders around the world to participate in the ongoing initiatives of the summit. The board will also offer advice on upcoming agendas, topics such as eradicating poverty, refugee care and conflict resolution.

Master Hsin Tao was the only religious leader from Taiwan to deliver a prayer at the summit's first meeting, held at the United Nations last August. Over 1,000 religious leaders from around the world came together at that summit to proclaim a declaration for world peace.

Jain is scheduled to attend a national assembly of the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Foundation during his visit, during which he will invite Master Hsin Tao to serve on the summit board with other religious figures, scholars and diplomats.
In response, Jain will be invited to serve as an honorary adviser of the Museum of World Religions, which Master Hsin Tao founded. The museum is slated to be inaugurated in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC GIVES OPTIMISTIC FORECAST ON FUTURE OF MINI 3 LINKS

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday that exchanges between mainland Chinese coastal cities and Taiwan's offshore islands of Kinmen and Matzu will increase in the future.

MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said that despite mainland China's reluctance to cooperate, direct travel and shipping have gradually increased since the ROC launched the Kinmen-Xiamen and Matzu-Mawei links three months ago.
Speaking at the MAC's weekly press conference, Lin announced that MAC officials have completed an initial evaluation report on the "mini links," which the ROC government implemented on Jan. 1, 2001.
According to the report, a total of 21 direct voyages have been carried out under the new policy, with the Kinmen side initiating 19 voyages and the mainland sending out two.

Meanwhile, a total of 2,374 people crossed to the opposite side of the strait, with 2,283 Taiwanese crossing directly to the mainland and 91 mainland Chinese visiting Kinmen and Matzu, the report revealed.
The MAC report emphasized that when a mainland freighter carrying 400 tons of gravel made a port call at Kinmen on March 31, it did not fly mainland China's national flag.
The officials expressed optimism for the future of the mini links, predicting that Beijing will increase its exchanges with the offshore islands in consideration of economic interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 PERCENT OF TAIPEI POLICE HAVE CONSIDERED SUICIDE: POLL

TEXT.P: About 50 percent of Taipei police feel that they are under heavy pressure because of their duties, and some 23 percent of them have gone so far as to consider suicide, according to the results of a survey released Friday.

According to the poll, 48 percent of Taipei municipal policemen surveyed complain about the irregularities of their jobs. Of the discontented respondents, around 58 percent attributed the problem to the complexities of their jobs, 22 percent expressed frustration with their long work hours, and 13 percent blame what they see as unfair work arrangements.
About one-half of the policemen questioned said they have to endure heavy on-the-job pressure, and some 23 percent admitted that they have thought about killing themselves, the survey found.
Taipei City Councilwoman Chen Hsueh-fen made public the results of the poll of 3,400 Taipei policemen during an interpellation session at the Taipei City Council.
Taipei Municipal Police Department Director Wang Cho-chun voiced his surprise about the high percentage of police officers who have thought of committing suicide.

Stressing that the municipal police authorities are planning to set up a consultation unit to help policemen deal with the stresses of the job, Wang said that personal emotional and financial problems have been the major reasons for previous police suicides.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI OFFICIALS TO ARRIVE FOR SONGKRAN FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, April 13 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of Thai Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare officials will arrive in the Republic of China Saturday to help sponsor a series of programs to celebrate Songkran, the Thai New Year festival, which began Friday and will last through Tuesday.

Sakul Boonkom, spokesman of the Thai Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare, said Deputy Director of Employment Bureau Sakul Boonkom will lead a delegation to Taiwan to celebrate Songkran along with officials of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office in Taipei.
A series of festivities, including the traditional water-throwing, will begin Saturday in Taipei, southern Taiwan's city of Kaohsiung, and northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County.

Sakul said representatives of the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare will visit Taipei's CBS radio station to appear on a Thai-language broadcasting program to answer questions filed by Thai workers in Taiwan.
They will also call on some Taiwan employers of Thai workers and express their sincere concern for Thai workers working in Taiwan.
A total of about 130,000 Thais are working in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEY FIGURE IN NAVY SCANDAL TO COOPERATE WITH INVESTIGATORS

TEXT.P: A key figure in a 1993 navy murder and kickback scandal case said Friday that she was willing to cooperate with investigators to shed light on the case "when time allows."
Tu Cheng Chuen-chu, better known as merely "Mrs. Tu," returned to Taiwan for the first time in seven years Wednesday and met the press Friday to declare her innocence in the high-profile case.
Tu said that she was in Taiwan primarily to visit her ill mother, and that time constraints might keep her from meeting with investigators during this trip.

Tu, who has lived in Germany for the past seven years, left Taiwan in a hurry on Dec. 10, 1993 -- one day after the murdered body of Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng was found. He reportedly had been collecting evidence about alleged irregularities concerning the Navy's procurement of four German-made minesweepers and six French-made missile frigates.

Although it is widely believed that she was not directly connected to Yin's murder, Tu's return was expected to paint a clearer picture of the circumstances surrounding the case and of the related kickback scandal.

Tu, who is believed to be a close friend of Yin, explained that she did not leave the island on her own will. Rather, she said that she left because Navy Commander Kuo Hsi, a former Weaponry Acquisition Program (WAP) staff officer who worked with Yin, told her that the military was "no longer able to protect" her.

Furthermore, having finally helped Luerssen Werft, the German company that supplied the minesweepers and related components, to secure a promise from the Navy to send out a bidding invitation, she decided to return to Germany, she said.

Since her flight from Taiwan, Taiwan law enforcement authorities had met with Tu only once, in Singapore in 1994, in order to probe the circumstances surrounding Yin's murder as well as a scandal involving bribery in the sale of the minesweepers.

Contradicting news reports on her profession, she asserted that she is not an arms broker. Rather, she said that she had come to Taiwan to resolve contract issues between Luerssen and the Republic of China Navy.

Tu said that she is a longtime acquaintance of Luerssen's CEO, who sought help from her husband's legal firm to deal with the ROC Navy's alleged intention of not carrying out a particular contract with the company.

That was the reason she went to former ROC legislator Chu Kao-cheng for help, she said, adding that she was only in contact with Yin and Kuo during her stay in Taiwan and did not contact any other military officials.
She denied reports that she had evidence that would have been unfavorable to Yin, asserting that most media reports about her have been far from the truth.

Neither the kickback scandal nor the murder case has been resolved over the past seven years, despite the questioning, indictment or jailing of more than 10 navy officers and private arms brokers. Among them is Kuo Lee-heng, Yin's colleague at the WAP office, who is currently serving a life sentence.
Tu said that she does not know the man but is willing to face him for cross-examination with investigators.
Meanwhile, Yin's sister Yin Hsing-wen filed charges against Tu at the Taipei District Prosecutors Office at the same time that Tu's press conference was taking place.
Yin accused Tu of being an accomplice in the murder of her brother, along with Kuo Hsi and Kuo Lee-heng.

DOC.HEADLINE: SONGKRAN FESTIVITIES TO BE HELD IN TAOYUAN, NORTHERN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan, April 13 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A series of programs celebrating Songkran, the Thai New Year, will be put on at Taoyuan County Stadium Sunday, sources with the county government said Friday.
There are some 70,000 foreign laborers working in Taoyuan County, of whom 30,000 are from Thailand, the sources said.
Taoyuan County Hall has sponsored festivities to celebrate Songkran for many years, to help ease Thai workers' homesickness.
This year's programs will include the chanting of Buddhist scriptures, performances of Thai traditional dance and a beauty pageant.
The beauty pageant will be the climax of the festival, with organizers choosing the top ten contestants from among the employees of Taiwan firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% OF M'LAND'S IT PRODUCTS SAID FROM TAIWAN-INVESTED FIRMS

TEXT.P: A senior Beijing trade official said Friday that 72 percent of the value of the mainland's computer products last year came from Taiwan-ivested companies.

Wang Xiaozhuan, deputy director of the Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau Department under Beijing's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, said that the huge mainland market has attracted more and more investment from Taiwan electronics firms and this trend "has reached the point of no return."

Speaking at a seminar in Xiamen on cross-strait electronics and industrial machinery cooperation and development, Wang said most of Taiwan's major information technology (IT) makers have move to the mainland and this trend is only going to widen. The practice of taking orders in Taiwan but producing on the mainland is also gradually increasing, he said.
Wang also revealed that more and more Taiwan computer makers are setting up research centers in Xian and Shanghai.

According to unofficial statistics, mainland China produced US$25.5 billion worth of computers and related equipment last year, of which Taiwan investment accounted for US$18.5 billion or 72 percent, Wang said.

Wang further said that mainland China's IT industry has already surpassed Taiwan's in terms of production and value, projecting that the mainland will surpass Japan this year to become the second largest computer-hardware producing country in the world.
The fifth Xiamen and Taiwan Trade Exchange Exposition opened Wednesday in Xiamen, with some 100 Taiwan electronics and electrical equipment makers and traders participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of Education plans to unveil grade scale for junior high school academic exams.
The China Times:
Former Combined Service Force officer commits suicide over kickback scandals.
The United Daily News:
Evergreen Group plans to invest in container wharf construction at mainland port of Xiamen.
The Liberty Times:
Bush says mainland coastal surveillance flight will continue.
The China Post:
Bush pledges firm, respectful PRC line.
The Taiwan News:
U.S. crew says jet pilot at fault for collision.
The Taipei Times:
Bush pledges a firm China line.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR COLLISION ADDS UNCERTAINTY TO U.S.-MAINLAND CHINA TIES

TEXT.P: Local scholars claimed Saturday that although "the curtain has fallen" on the U.S.-mainland China standoff over the recent collision between their military aircraft, the incident's impact on long-term relations will not recede soon.

The scholars presented their views on the possible repercussions of the incident on the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular relations at a seminar jointly organized by several local private think tanks.

The seminar was convened to discuss the April 1 incident in which a U.S. spy plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter collided in mid-air, forcing the U.S. plane to make an emergency landing on Hainan Island and leaving the mainland pilot missing, presumed dead.

Although intensive diplomatic activity saw the 24 U.S. crew members released from detention April 12, the plane remained in mainland Chinese hands and the diplomatic battle to have it returned to the United States was only just beginning.

Almost all the participating academics agreed that the collision incident will add to uncertainty to long-term U.S.-mainland China relations and that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should adopt confidence-building measures (CBM) to prevent any military "miscalculation."

Lin Cheng-yi, director of the Institute of European and American Studies under Academia Sinica, said he is convinced that the incident will affect the scope of military exchanges between the United States and mainland China.

"And their long-term relations are also expected to become more uncertain," Lin predicted, adding his belief that U.S.-mainland China cultural, educational and commercial exchanges will not be affected.
Lin further said he believes that Washington-Beijing security dialogue will continue, but that the United States will increasingly regard mainland China as a "potential competitor."
"I think that the United States will become more reserved on anti-nuclear proliferation and human rights issues," Lin explained.

As for the incident's possible impact on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Lin said Taiwan and mainland China should learn from the "linguistic diplomacy" of the United States, particularly its expression and wording concerning specific issues.
Moreover, he went on, Taiwan and the mainland should forge a CBM mechanism in the military field.
Speaking on the same occasion, National Taiwan University professor Chang Lin-cheng said U.S.-mainland China ties will remain at a low ebb in the wake of the collision.

Nevertheless, Chang went on, past experience shows that Washington-Beijing ties will continue to forge ahead despite the ups and downs. "I believe that they will continue engagements in various fields based on their own national interests," she observed.

National Chengchi University professor Chao Chun-shan said Taiwan's government authorities should be more forward-looking and should adopt a panoramic perspective when formulating diplomatic and mainland policies.

"In handling diplomatic and cross-strait affairs, the government should shed the shackles of near-sighted mentality and avoid adopting tactics that can only lead to short-lived political gains," Chao said, adding that the two sides should develop a mechanism to ensure that they can hold effective dialogue should a similar collision take place in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 14, or the 21st day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1889: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and author of a 12-volume work entitled "A Study of History," is born.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1912: The Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic, killing 1,500 people.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1945: US bombers pound Japan's Imperial Palace during World War II.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1971: The new Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1973: President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam leaves Taipei for home after a three-day visit.
1973: Dr. Jesus Soto Amesty, chairman of the Venezuela Senate Foreign Policy Committee, arrives in Taipei for a ten-day visit.
1975: Sikkim abolishes its monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1976: A total of 3,460 students from 642 middle schools compete in the Taiwan Area Games.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case at that time.
1988: The Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say that they want to be men.
1994: Two US F-15 fighters shoot down two American helicopters over northern Iraq killing 26 people.
1999: Pakistan test-fires a 2,000-km range ballistic missile.
2000: Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno, the new Sao Tome and Principe ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN POLICE CRACK RECORD SMUGGLING CASE

TEXT.P: Kinmen authorities caught a total of 34 mainland Chinese fishermen and porters in an anti-smuggling raid Saturday, marking the largest ever apprehension of mainland Chinese citizens illicitly operating in Republic of China territorial waters.

Along with the 34 mainland Chinese people, police seized some 5,000 kg of fresh mushroom shoots, the largest ever single seizure of smuggled mainland Chinese goods since Taiwan initiated the "mini three links" with the mainland Jan. 2 this year, according to sources from the Kinmen County Police Station.

Kinmen County police, acting with the support of patrol forces from the Coastal Guard Administration's Kinmen division, nabbed a mainland Chinese gravel ship and two fishing boats, which had approached the mouth of the Chaishan Tunnel in Kinmen's Kukang Village at around 2 a.m. Later, the 34 men from the three mainland vessels began to unload the smuggled goods.
Kinmen police handed the 34 mainland Chinese people, including skippers Wang Deli and Wang Dongshui, to the Kinmen Prosecutors Office for interrogation.
The smuggled mushroom shoots, meanwhile, were confiscated and will be incinerated along with quarantine standards, the police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATIONS VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A four-member U.S. Senate delegation led by Sen. Phil Gramm arrived in Taipei Saturday to begin a three-day visit.

Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Chiou Jong-nan, who received Gramm's delegation at the airport, said that the influential Republican senator from Texas is here to meet with ROC officials to discuss matters of mutual interest to Taiwan and the United States.
Chiou added that many members of the U.S. Congress are taking advantage of the current recess on Capitol Hill to visit other countries.

Gramm is the chairman of the U.S. Senate committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs. Other members of the Republican delegation, who are all members of the same committee, include Sen. Bob Bennett of Utah, Sen. Jim Bunning of Kentucky and Sen. Mike Crapo of Idaho. Bunning also serves on the Senate Armed Services Committee, and Crapo serves on the Environment and Public Works Committee.
Later in the day, a four-member U.S. House of Representatives delegation led by Rep. Loretta Sanchez is also slated to arrive here to begin a five-day visit.

Along with her chief of staff, her business adviser and the funding coordinator to Rep. Ed Royce, Sanchez will call on ROC President Chen Shui-bian, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Deputy Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin and other government officials during her visit.
She is also slated to attend the inauguration of a national women's group confederation and a series of related seminars.
Sanchez, a California Democrat, is a member of the U.S. House National Security Committee and the House Education and the Workforce Committee.
Royce is a Republican from the same state.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SENATOR EXPRESSES SUPPORT FOR AEGIS SALE TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator George F. Allen said Friday that the recent midair collision between U.S. and mainland Chinese military aircraft has made him even more certain that the United States should sell the Aegis radar warning system to Taiwan.
Allen told the Central News Agency prior to a meeting with U.S. President George W. Bush at the White House that Taiwan should be allowed to acquire the defensive weaponry it needs.

He said that even before the collision incident, which further raised tensions in the Asia Pacific region, he had been an advocate of arms sales to Taiwan because of mainland China's increasing deployment of missiles directly across from the island.

Meanwhile, the Republican senator from Virginia and other lawmakers have been preparing a bill that would grant citizenship to Gao Zhan, a permanent U.S. resident and a political science scholar at Washington's American University, who has been detained on charges of spying in Beijing since February.
Allen said that the U.S. Congress will press the administration to continue pushing Beijing for Gao's release.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL CITIZENS SPEND MORE FREE TIME WATCHING TV THAN STUDYING: POLL

TEXT.P: Many Taiwan people spend their leisure time studying, but watching television remains the most favored pastime on the island, according to a report on general social trends released Saturday.

The report by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) was based on the findings of a poll conducted earlier this year of about 15,000 local citizens over 15 years of age.
According to the DGBAS report, about 4.85 million local people said they spent at least some of their free time studying or conducting research over the past year.

Nevertheless, the report reveals that watching TV remains the most popular pastime in Taiwan, with each resident spending an average of two hours and 19 minutes in from of the tube each day -- or 40 percent of his or her total daily free time.
In contrast, the report said, local people spend only an average of 25 minutes of their leisure time studying or doing research every day.

According to the survey, 55 percent of those interviewed said they watch TV between 8 p.m. and 9 p.m. each day; 50 percent said they watch TV between 7 p.m. and 8 p.m.; and 45 percent watch between 9 p.m. and 10 p.m.
Poll results showed that local people spend an average of 50 minutes of their daily free time meditating or getting together with their families.
Reading newspapers or magazines as well as surfing Internet websites account for about an average of 22 minutes of local people's daily leisure time.
The DGBAS report further said about 28.7 percent of local citizens use their leisure time to study or do research, slightly lower than Japan's 30.5 percent.
Among those who spend some free time studying, 52.7 percent said they study computer and other information technology-related courses, while 40. 4 percent said they study languages or literature.
The survey found no significant gender differences among those who spend their free time studying, with a 28.5 percent ratio for men and a 28.9 percent rate for women.

According to the poll, younger and better educated people are more likely to use their free time learning new skills or expertise. Some 58.4 percent of college graduates said they use some of their free time studying, and 43.4 percent of respondents aged between 15 and 24 said they take extracurricular courses during their leisure time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR PRESCRIBES HEAVY FINES TO STOP FORGERY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou suggested Saturday that the government impose fines of up to NT$30 million (US$911,854) on makers of counterfeit municipal garbage bags, saying that imposing heavy fines is the only effective way of stopping the illicit practice.
According to Ma, Taipei City Hall has decided to take "abject" measures to crack down on a recent spate of plastic garbage bag forgery cases.

Some of the fake garbage bags look so similar to the ones that were made under the city government's authority that officials from Taipei Bureau of Environmental Protection could not tell the difference between the fakes and the genuine bags at a press conference held Friday.

Speaking at another press conference Saturday, Ma said the city government has drafted a proposal that would raise fines for garbage bag forgery from the current NT$30,000-NT$100,000 to NT$300,000-NT$30 million and impose jail terms of 3-7 years on counterfeiters. He said the strict measures are intended to deter the illegal practice once and for all.

According to Ma, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration has agreed to support a legislative amendment to related waste management and cleaning statutes so as to legitimize the heavy cash penalties for garbage bag counterfeiting.
Taipei City is the first and so far the only city in Taiwan to adopt a garbage fee collection system, in which residents are charged a fee for every bag of garbage they discard.
Since Taipei's new garbage collection system was implemented last July, the city's average daily garbage volume per person has dropped to 1.1 kg, compared to some 3.3 kg before.

The garbage fee collection system, which earns the city about NT$1.2 billion a month, has also attracted makers and suppliers of counterfeit garbage bags. According to Taipei City police headquarters, they received information on 56 cases of bag counterfeiting over the last several months and have cracked 14 of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT ATTENDS MEETING OF WOMEN PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday at a professional women association's national congress that women should devote themselves to work and actively strive for their rightful equality in society.
She praised the participants of the Soroptimist International national chapter meeting as outstanding women and role models who show that women can do more than stay home to cook and do the laundry.
Women can also be national leaders and can call for the prevention of wars, said the Republic of China's first female vice president.

Former vice president Lien Chan was also invited to speak at the same meeting, where he praised Soroptimist International, a global organization with nearly 100,000 members in 119 countries, for its community volunteer services, which include caring for minority groups.
The opposition Kuomintang chairman went on to thank the meeting participants for their support and encouragement during his unsuccessful presidential campaign last year.

Lamenting that Taiwan is facing "immense and difficult challenges" for the first time in 50 years -- referring to broad economic and political changes in recent months -- he urged the participants to do their part to allow Taiwan to "stand tall" despite the difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED YEAST RICE SAID TO BE GOOD AGENT TO LOWER BLOOD CHOLESTEROL

TEXT.P: Red yeast rice, a traditional ingredient in Chinese cooking, is believed to be effective in lowering abnormal blood cholesterol level and preventing cardiovascular diseases.

Health food made of red yeast rice, an ingredient in delicious dishes such as hong tsao chi (red yeast rice chicken) and hong tsao man (red yeast rice eel), is now available in Taiwan markets, helping to lower consumers' blood cholesterol and blood fat levels so as to prevent cardiovascular diseases.

According to Dr. Chiang Pi-ning, a physician at Veterans General Hospital, one of Taiwan's leading medical centers, red yeast rice has been scientifically proved to be effective in lowering levels of blood cholesterol and fat because it is rich in the reductase enzyme, or HMG-GOA, which is a natural agent for maintaining a balanced level of cholesterol in the blood of mammals.

Chiang, formerly the personal doctor of former Presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo, said the "safe" level of cholesterol in a healthy person's blood is lower than 200. Although a reading between 200 and 250 is medically acceptable and does not require treatment, cholesterol levels should not be allowed to increase, he added.

Regular exercise and a well-controlled diet are the best ways to prevent cardiovascular diseases, Chiang said, adding that even people who exercise regularly and eat balanced diets are better able to keep cardiovascular diseases at bay if they take some additional reductase enzyme supplement such as the red yeast rice pills.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REITERATES STANCE ON JAPANESE TEXTBOOKS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reiterated Saturday that it has issued three protests since February over the whitewashed accounts of Japanese wartime history in that nation's controversial new textbooks, and is now waiting for a formal response from Japan.
MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue made the remarks in response to criticism by opposition lawmakers and scholars that the MOFA's manner in handling the issue was too low profile.
Chang said the ministry has consistently paid close attention to developments in the Japanese textbook issue.

"Immediately after learning that the Japanese Education Ministry might approve the draft of a new set of history textbooks for junior high schools to be used from next April, we expressed our serious concern about certain inappropriate content of the Japanese textbooks," Chang recalled, adding that the MOFA's concern was conveyed to the Japanese government on Feb. 26 through the Republic of China's representative office in Tokyo.

When the Japanese government unveiled the officially approved version of the new high school textbooks April 3, Chang said, the MOFA ordered the ROC representative office to express Taiwan's protest on the issue the following day.

"This time we enclosed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with our protest letter," Chang explained, adding that the MOU clearly demanded that Japan rectify certain whitewashed or distorted accounts of its colonial past and wartime atrocities in its new textbooks.

Chang said the ROC is particularly concerned about the Japanese textbooks' misleading and whitewashed accounts of the "Nanjing Massacre," its army's "comfort women" and Japan's colonial aggression in the first half of the 20th century.

The MOU reminded the Japanese government that at least 300,000 civilians are believed to have died when Japanese troops overran the central mainland Chinese city of Nanjing in December 1937. The tragedy is commonly known as the "Nanjing Massacre." However, the new Japanese textbooks do not include casualty figures in what they refer to merely as the "Nanjing Incident."

The MOU also expressed regret over the textbook's failure to give a faithful account of many Japanese atrocities committed during World War II, including the forcing of some 200,000 women from Taiwan and other Asian countries into sexual slavery in military brothels.

In addition to reaffirming the ROC's stance on the issue, the MOU also urged the Japanese government to face up to historical facts and stop hurting the feelings of people in its neighboring Asian countries by correcting the inappropriate content of its new history textbooks.

Chang said that as Japanese authorities gave a vague and evasive response to the ROC's April 4 protest, the MOFA again directed the ROC representative office in Tokyo to express its stance on April 7.
"And we are now waiting for Japan's concrete response to our demand," Chang said.

Noting that the ROC consistently believes that history should not be distorted, tampered with or glossed over, Chang said the MOFA has never wavered from its stance of pushing Japan to educate its younger generation with the correct historical viewpoint.

Chang further said the MOFA will continue to press Japan to resolve the issues of the comfort women, textbook revision and former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visa application as soon as possible to avoid affecting the traditionally cordial ties between the two countries.
In addition to Taiwan, mainland China, South Korea and several other Asian countries have also voiced strong protests against the new Japanese history textbooks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO POSITION ITSELF IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), one of Taiwan's most powerful foreign trade arms, is considering establishing liaison offices in mainland China to explore the potential of the huge mainland Chinese markets for Taiwan businesses.

Mindful of Taiwan and mainland China's expectant admission into the World Trade Organization (WTO), CETRA authorities decided to accelerate their move to position Taiwan in the mainland Chinese markets, which are seen as a "sponge" for made-in-Taiwan products and mainland Chinese products produced by Taiwan-financed manufacturers.

CETRA, which has failed in previous similar efforts, will begin by founding Taiwan product exhibition centers in mainland China, and if that proceeds smoothly, liaison offices will ensue, said newly-appointed CETRA Secretary-General Huang Chih-peng.

Planning to apply for an entry permit from mainland Chinese authorities under the name of Taipei World Trade Center, CETRA will engage in operations in trade services only, but not in investment in mainland China, Huang noted.
Before heading to the mainland, Huang said, CETRA will first have to obtain official approval from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and then get an approval from the mainland authorities.
CETRA, a driving force behind Taiwan's brisk foreign trade development in the last three decades, maintains 37 operations and service centers in major cities around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, SCHOLARS PITCH FOR INTENSIVE INTERNET ETHICS EDUCATION

TEXT.P: A group of local scholars and experts urged the Ministry of Education Saturday to strengthen Internet ethics education to prevent local students from violating copyright laws.
