They made the appeal at a seminar on intellectual property rights (IPR) protection organized by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

The KMT said it sponsored the seminar to signify its concern about the human rights of the 14 National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) students who allegedly infringed upon copyright law by downloading music files from the Internet.

The Tainan District Prosecutors' Office raided NCKU student dormitories Wednesday and took custody of 14 computer hard disks containing pirated MP3 files. Prosecution authorities are scheduled to summon the 14 student owners of the seized disks for questioning next week.
The KMT Youth Affairs Department reminded law enforcement authorities to respect and protect the students' legitimate human rights in the performance of their official duties.
The department urged prosecutors to strictly abide by the "secret and closed-door" principle prescribed in the current code of criminal procedures in handling the NCKU student case.
"Prosecutors should refrain from playing up their campus search and follow-up investigative operations," said a KMT youth department official.
He said the KMT youth department is willing to offer counseling services to the 14 NCKU students to help them ease pressure from the prosecution authorities' action.

Speaking at the seminar, National Chengchi University professor Huang Cheng-chung said prosecutors must be very cautious and prudent in launching raids on campus or searching student dormitories for any criminal evidence.
"They would infringe upon students' human rights if they conduct a high-profile search on campus," Huang noted.

He further said Wednesday's raid indicated that law enforcement authorities have failed to adopt any complementary administrative measures to increase students' awareness about intellectual property rights.

Professor Lin Yi-lung of Central Police University said music and computer software piracy is rampant in local college and university campuses, indicating that local students have poor IPR awareness and knowledge.
"Education authorities should step up IPR education, particularly Internet-related ethical principles and behavioral standards, to help local students avoid violating IPR laws," Lin urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM STRENGTHEN AQUACULTURE COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Hanoi, April 13 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Visiting Republic of China Legislator Lin Feng-hsi said Friday that Taiwan and Vietnam will continue to strive for bilateral cooperation in aquaculture so that newer fish breeding technology can help increase the incomes of Vietnamese farmers.

Lin, who donated 120,000 mouthbreeder hatchlings to Vietnam Wednesday on behalf of the Republic of China, told Doan Duy Thanh, chairman of the Vietnamese Chamber of Commerce and Industry, that bilateral relations have already entered a stage in which the agriculture and labor agreements signed since 1999 are bearing results.
To illustrate his point, he cited the completion of training for 60 Vietnamese aquaculture workers out of an agreed-upon 100 and the 11,000-some Vietnamese workers currently employed in Taiwan.
He went on to say that after the 120,000 baby fish have grown up in eight months, the breeding ground in Bac Giang Province could serve as a sample aquaculture farm for other breeders in Vietnam.
Lin added that the mouthbreeders can be a good source of nutrition for the Vietnamese people.

In response, Doan thanked Taiwan for the donated fish and the technical assistance. He also invited the island's aquaculture industry to inspect and invest in other nearby locations suitable for fish farming.

Lin also took the opportunity to urge Vietnam to pay attention to the importance of environmental protection at the very beginning of economic development instead of having to look back 20 or 30 years from now and devote even greater resources and finances to return the environment to its original state.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS SALES ISSUE HAS BEEN POLITICIZED: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said Saturday that the Republic of China does not have the upper hand in handling arms deals with the United States because the issue has been "politicized."
Wu made the remarks in a radio talk show aired by the opposition Kuomintang-owned Broadcasting Corp. of China.
The minister pointed out that whether the United States would sell Taiwan the highly advanced Aegis radar-equipped destroyers is not purely a military issue.

Noting that any decision on the Aegis deal would involve many complicated considerations, Wu said the ROC must conduct a comprehensive strategic review before deciding either to buy Aegis-equipped destroyers or the Kidd-class destroyers.
According to Wu, the ROC's military general staff headquarters is still evaluating which destroyer should be put on the top of the weaponry shopping list.

Asked whether the recent midair collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter would affect U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, Wu said the U.S. government has on several occasions stressed that it would not link the "collision" incident to its arms deals with Taiwan and would decide its sales list based on Taiwan's defense needs.
"We believe that the U.S. government would make a wise decision on its sales list," Wu stressed.
ROC and U.S. military officials are scheduled to meet in Washington, D.C. April 23 to discuss Taiwan's arms procurement plans for 2001.

Meanwhile, Wu said he does not think that a similar military aircraft incident would happen between Taiwan and mainland China because the ROC has demanded its warplanes and warships to maintain "proper distance" from their mainland counterparts.

Asked whether Taiwan would extend a helping hand should a mainland warplane or warship crashes in the sea, Wu said the ROC military would certainly assist in rescue operations in line with international customs and practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: RP PRESIDENT ORDERS GREATER HELP FOR FILIPINO WORKERS ABROAD

TEXT.P: Philippine President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo has authorized the release of P30 million (US$15 million) in government funds to bolster the capabilities of the Legal Assistance Fund for migrant workers and overseas Filipino workers.

The president's approval of the release had been recommended by Presidential Management Staff chief Vicky Garchitorena, in accordance with the Republic of the Philippines' Migrant Workers and Overseas Filipinos Act of 1995.

The act provides for the appropriation of the money as the Presidential Social Fund's contribution to an assistance fund for overseas Filipino workers, migrant workers and their families facing legal problems.

"The expenditures to be charged against the Fund shall include fees for foreign lawyers hired by the Department of Foreign Affairs' to represent migrant workers facing charges abroad, bail bonds to secure the temporary release of workers under detention, court fees and other charges as well as other litigation expenses," she said.

Garchitorena also said that the law mandates the establishment of the Legal Assistance Fund in the amount of P100 million, of which half should come from the Office of the President's Contingency Fund, P30 million from the Presidential Social Fund and P20 million from the Welfare Fund for Overseas Workers.
To date, a total of P50 million has been released to the Department of Foreign Affairs by the Department of Budget and Management for this purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 WATER FESTIVAL HELD IN CHUNGHO, NORTHERN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Chungho, Taipei County, April 14 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Water Festival activities were held for Thai workers and ethnic Chinese from Burma Saturday in the city of Chungho, Taipei County, with some 2,000 local people, Thais and Burmese participating.

Ushered in by orchestral music and performances of kung-fu dance and Thai volleyball, the festival formally began when Taipei County Magistrate Su Chen-chang, Chungho Mayor Lu Fang-yen, and several dignitaries arrived at the venue aboard a float at 10:30 a.m.
Upon their arrival an ROC Army Honor Guard performed a rifle drill, which was followed by a blessing by monks from Thailand.

Speaking at the celebration, Su stressed that Taipei County Government has included a series of programs to celebrate the Thai, Burmese, Lao and Cambodian New Year holidays into its "cultural calendar" to promote cultural amalgamation among different people.

The festival reached its climax when Magistrate Su and Mayor Lu pushed a button starting water sprinklers that splashed water on the crowd. Water-sprinkling is New Year tradition in Thailand, Burma, Laos and Cambodia, where people believe the water disperses the evils of the past year and brings good luck to them after they remove their damp clothes.

Revelers at the festival also drenched each other with water using dippers and water guns. Traditionally, anyone splashed with water should not get angry, because the wetter a person gets, the better his or her luck will be.
A series of programs, including the performance of traditional Thai and Burmese dances, were also staged simultaneously with the water-throwing activity. The festival ended at 3 p.m.
The Water Festival, or Songkuran in the Thai language, is the most important festival in the four Southeast Asian countries, having been practiced there for more than 1,000 years.
This was the third time that Taipei County Government and Chungho City Government have jointly sponsored Songkuran festivities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT ASKS U.S. TO PROVIDE ADVANCED DEFENSIVE ARMS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Saturday stressed Taiwan's need for advanced defensive weapons to safeguard security in the Taiwan Strait.

Meeting with a delegation of the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, Chen said that maintaining the security of the Taiwan Strait is important not only to Taiwan's interests, but also to U.S. interests in the Western Pacific.

As the existing military balance across the strait is likely to shift in favor of the mainland in 2005, the president urged Washington to provide advanced defense weapons to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act and other related commitments.
Chen praised U.S. President George Bush for his handling of the recent collision of a U.S. naval reconnaissance plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter over the South China Sea.
He also expressed his appreciation that Bush had disconnected the incident with U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
Chen told the visitors that since his inauguration in May last year, his government has placed top priority on the maintenance of peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
He said that he has on several occasions displayed good will and sincerity calling for a resumption of cross-strait negotiations and exchanges.
"Taiwan is not a trouble-maker, but a peace builder, and is an advocator and builder of Asia-Pacific peace and security," Chen added.

The president said he believes that relations between Taipei and Washington will be further strengthened in the future because the two sides share common values of democracy, freedom and human rights, have common expectations on peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, and maintain close economic and trade ties.

During the talks, Chen also indicated his hope that the U.S. government will relax restrictions on trips to the United States by ranking Taipei officials and on Taiwan visits by U.S. officials in charge of security, diplomatic and defense affairs.
Members of the U.S. Senate delegation included committee chairman Phil Gramm (R-TX), Robert Bennett (R-UT), Jim Bunning (R-KY) and Mike Crapo (R-ID).
They said they would continue to do their utmost to promote Washington-Taipei relations and expressed their support for the ROC's efforts to join international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Kuomintang successfully sorts out inner-party fight for party candidate in race for magistracy of Taichung County.
The China Times:

The United Daily News:
Powell hints that Beijing's contentions over spy plane may help prompt Washington to sell Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan.
The Liberty Times:
Powell: Washington might sell Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan if Beijing keeps on bashing the United States over spy plane accident.
The China Post:
President Chen Asks U.S. for advanced defensive weapons.
The Taiwan News:
Chen lauds Bush on collision response.
The Taipei Times:
Chen urges US senators to sell arms.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE SLEEP LONGER: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan people slept an average of eight hours and 42 minutes each day in 2000, an increase of five minutes from average sleeping hours in 1994, a recent government survey has found.

According to the poll conducted by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on social trends in the Taiwan area last year, Taiwanese people slept nearly one hour longer each day than Japanese and noticeably more than Canadians and Australians.

At the same time, it also discovered that local people dedicated less time to household affairs every day, with Taiwanese spending 20 minutes to one hour less on such activities than people in other countries.

In terms of age, the people aged 65 or over slept the most, with an average daily sleeping time of nine hours and 33 minutes; while those aged 15-19 slept the least, snoozing an average of eight hours and 24 minutes each day.
However, young men aged between 15 and 24 liked to make up their slumber time by sleeping an average 10 hours on weekends, the poll indicated.

In addition, about 83.4 percent of Taiwanese went to bed before midnight on weekdays, a figure that fell to 80 percent on weekends. The DGBAS said this is an indication that local people are increasingly fond of "nocturnal life."

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL PLIGHT TRIGGERS DELAYED HEALTH INSURANCE PAYMENTS

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien stressed Sunday that his county did not intend to delay payment for the nation's health insurance programs, but has been forced to do so because of lack of county government finances.
Yu lamented that the finances of Taiwan's cities and counties are in extremely dire straits, adding that they even have difficulties paying their personnel expenses.

He cited his own Kaohsiung County as an example, saying that personnel expenses hit a high of NT$16.6 billion (US$504.55 million) this year. He complained that the Central Government recently added to his headaches by approving a 3 percent pay raise for civil servants.

Yu was responding to Friday's remarks by Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party. Lai said that as of the end of March, the labor, farmer, and national health insurance programs have failed to collect overdue premiums of NT$55 billion (US$1.67 billion).
Lai put most of the blame for the situation on local governments, which have failed to meet payments of NT$44.1 billion, or about 80 percent of the entire shortfall.

Lai said the shortage of money in the health insurance program will directly impact its normal operations. But according to related regulations, the central government can do nothing about those local governments that refuse or delay payment.
Lai suggested that the government act to revise the law by deducting its subsidies to local governments that fail to make the payments, or else by finding other sources of financing.

Responding to Lai's criticism, Yu criticized the Central Government as continuing to unveil new tax cut measures without opening up new sources of financing. He complained that the division of national revenue between the central and local governments is not reasonable and only serves to compound the situation, adding that local governments often find themselves in financial difficulties because of the Central Government's instructions.

Yu said that the budget law stipulates that the implementation of any policy must be buttressed by reliable sources of financing, and the Central Government can not shift the burden of financing onto local governments.

Yu also said that before the streamlining of the Taiwan Provincial Government in 1999, it had owed around NT$4.5 billion in unpaid premiums, which he claimed was the reason for the local governments' delayed payments.
The Legislative Yuan is scheduled to review the budget for the labor, farmer and national health insurance programs this coming week.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER ASKS FOR TALKS WITH INDUSTRY ORG. OVER MP3 ISSUE

TEXT.P: Education Minister Ovid Tseng said he has asked his staff to contact the International Federation of Phonographic Industry, Taiwan (IFPI), which represents the music industry, over legal problems arising from local students' rampant downloading of music files from the Internet.

In an attempt to calm the student backlash against local prosecutors' recent crackdown on downloading music from the Internet without authorization, Tseng said the Department of High Education under his ministry will talk with the IFPI in an attempt at mediating the dispute outside the courtroom.

Noting that music piracy is illegal, the minister called on the students not to challenge the law by organizing protests against the crackdown, adding that academic freedom should not be used as an excuse to shield campuses from judicial procedure.

However, Tseng added that computer users downloading music without authorization is a worldwide phenomenon and only recently have law enforcement officials acknowledged it as an infringement on intellectual property, so it will take some time for awareness of the practice's illegality to sink in.

The dispute was caused by a judicial search of the dormitories of National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City on April 11 and the seizure of several students' personal computers, on which MP3 music files were stored.

Enraged by the prosecutor's raid on their dormitories, the university's students staged a sit-in protest on campus the next day, and threatened to stage an islandwide rally of university students to condemn what they called the prosecutor's trespassing on their campus and to demand that the government allow MP3 files to be downloaded for personal use.
Not surprisingly, IFPI Taiwan has thrown its weight behind the prosecutor's crackdown, and has gone so far as to vow to take any person who illegally copies music to court.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou recommended that the National Cheng Kung University students accused of piracy settle their dispute with the IFPI out of court, instead of protesting in conjunction with students of other universities.

Ma, who listened to the students' complaints after delivering a speech at the university Saturday, defended the prosecutor's search as "not obviously going beyond the law" in technical terms despite the fact that it was not well-considered.
The students' claims that they didn't know they were violating the law could be a strong argument in their defense, said the former justice minister and graduate of Harvard Law School.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL HEAVYWEIGHTS TURN OUT FOR FUNERAL OF KMT SENIOR FIGURE

TEXT.P: A public funeral for former presidential senior adviser Chen Li-fu was held Sunday in Taipei, with many important political figures participating, including Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian.

Chen Li-fu, who died on Feb. 8 at 102 years of age, had served as secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, member of the presidium of the KMT's Central Advisory Council, and senior adviser to the president.

Heavyweight officials of a variety of political stripes came out to honor Chen, including ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung of the Democratic Progressive Party; People First Party Chairman James Soong and Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung; New Party leader Hsieh Chi-ta; and several legislators.
Amid a solemn atmosphere, the ROC national flag and KMT party flag were placed on Chen's coffin to honor the man who contributed so much to the KMT and the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF TO CHOOSE BANK TO HANDLE COMPUTERIZED LOTTERY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will select a single bank from among five candidates interested in issuing computerized lottery tickets starting Jan. 1, 2002.

The Bank of Taiwan, Taipei Bank, the United World Chinese Commercial Bank, Chinatrust Commercial Bank and the Bank of Kaohsiung are all competing to win the rights to handle the new lottery. Whichever bank wins the bid will then chose a computer company to cooperate with it in managing the game.

According to local business sources, the world's top four computerized lottery companies have already been negotiating with local companies on possible joint ventures in order to gain a share of Taiwan's annual NT$150 billion lottery market.
An MOF official said that the bank that wins the bid will enjoy the rights to issue computerized lottery tickets for five years, from Jan. 1, 2002 to Dec. 31, 2006.

The official further pointed out that in order to maintain the current traditional lottery, in which players have two chances to win prizes, the bank will also be responsible for selling traditional lottery tickets.

If the new lottery proposal is approved, a player will be allowed to select six numbers between 1 and 45 at computerized lottery posts scattered around Taiwan. Grand prize winners of the weekly contest will receive NT$15 million to NT$30 million, and prize money will accumulate in the event there is no winner in any single week.
Holders of tickets that bear three of the six lucky numbers will win NT$1,000, the official added.

Perhaps the biggest winners of the new lottery will be the firms that obtain the rights to handle it. The bank that wins the bid will enjoy annual revenues of NT$2 billion, while the computer firm chosen to operate it will earn NT$6.5 billion per year, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP NOT TRYING TO UNDERMINE NP: JAMES SOONG

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP), denied Sunday that his party is trying to undermine the New Party.

Soong made the remarks in the wake of scathing criticism by Wang Chien-shien, an NP founding member, who said Friday that he was "insulted" by reports that the PFP is trying to recruit three NP heavyweights, including himself, to run on the PFP ticket for at-large legislative seats in the yearend elections.
Wang also voiced his contempt for NP Legislator Feng Ting-kuo, who is reportedly considering a possible defection to the PFP camp to seek re-election.

Wang said that though the NP is at a low ebb compared with the three other major parties -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the PFP, and the Kuomintang -- the quality of the NP members is simply better than any other party. He said this claim has been substantiated by past media evaluation.
He pointed out that the other three parties all have links with organized crime, or "black gold," stressing that only clean multi-party politics can provide a better future for Taiwan.

Soong, who has kept a low profile on cooperating with other parties in the yearend elections, responded by claiming that he has not contacted any of the NP top brass or tried to lure them into his party's fold.
Soong said that if necessary, he would not rule out the possibility of meeting with Wang to explain this to him personally.
But he also said that exchanges of talent would be good for both sides, adding that the PFP's principle of remaining open to all talent from other parties will not change.

Soong, a former KMT heavyweight who formed the PFP last year after bolting his former party and running an unsuccessful presidential campaign, said that the PFP has relied on talent from all sides, including the DPP, KMT and NP. He said he hopes to forge a mainstream force in Taiwan, adding that his policy of openness will not change in the future.

Soong stressed that an opposition party has to be an effective force to check the ruling party. Since the PFP has only 19 seats in the legislature, it does not have such power and has to cooperate with other parties that share similar ideals, he said.

Soong also admitted that NP Legislator Feng is in fact considering joining the PFP at present because the PFP's nomination procedure requires pre-registration, but he said Feng was responding to calls from his constituency.

But Soong said he has not contacted the NP top brass on the recruitment issue since Hao Lung-pin, former convenor of the NP, left the party to serve as head of the Environmental Protection Administration.

Soong said he appreciated Wang Chien-shien and Hsieh Chi-Ta, the convenor of the NP, for their support during his campaign for president in March 2000. He admitted meeting with Hsieh recently, but said Hsieh only wished to express her views about the NP and they did not discuss anything related to the two parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 DEAD AND 40 INJURED IN TAICHUNG BUS ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: At least four persons were killed and more than 40 injured in an accident involving two buses near Encore Garden in Taichung, central Taiwan Sunday, according to police officials.

The accident occurred at 1:24 p.m. when a bus, overloaded with passengers returning from a large-scale excursion, collided with an oncoming bus in the opposite lane while driving down a steep mountain slope. Both buses belong to the Jen Yio Transport Co.
A witness in the downhill-headed bus said the vehicle's brakes failed as the driver was turning the steering wheel.
The collision smashed the front ends of both buses, leaving drivers and several passengers trapped in the wrecks and some passengers stuck underneath the vehicles.

Taichung Fire Department sent more than 200 rescuers to the scene to care for more than 40 injured persons who were soon taken to hospitals. The list of dead and injured people had not been confirmed as of press time.
Other witnesses said traffic around Encore Garden was seriously jammed for several hours after the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO ENLARGE COA STRUCTURE

TEXT.P: In a bid to cope with the impact of Taiwan's upcoming entry into the World Trade Organization, the government is showing initial signs of a restructuring plan to upgrade the Council of Agriculture (COA) to the ministerial level after thorough study.

COA Chairman Chen Chih-huang, who has been actively promoting the plan since assuming his post with the inauguration President Chen Shui-bian last May, said 21 draft organization bills related to the COA's structural adjustments have been completed and are pending approval by the Legislative Yuan.

Chen expressed his hope that the planned structural adjustments will give the COA a new lease on life and transform it into a service-oriented policy-making organization, leaving technical issues to be handled solely by the COA's affiliated branches.
According to the COA plan, departments of agricultural policy and technology affairs will be set up in the future, while its fishery and animal industry departments will be consolidated or merged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPY PLANE INCIDENT MAY PUT PRESSURE ON U.S. REGARDING ARMS SALES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: U.S. State Secretary Colin Powell indicated Friday that the recent incident involving the collision of a U.S. reconnaissance plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter might create political pressure that would affect U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
According to the Department of State, Powell made the remarks in Ireland on his way back home from a trip to the Balkans.

"Obviously, when the environment for such (arms sales) decisions becomes heated as it is right now as a result of the Chinese response to this incident of the airplane, it creates political pressure that we'll have to take into account," Powell noted.
During the April 1 incident, the U.S. naval reconnaissance plane made an emergency landing on Hainan Island, while the pilot of the mainland Chinese jet fighter remained missing.
Although the 24 crewmen aboard the spy plane were allowed to return to the United States 12 days later, the plane remains in the hands of mainland China.
The Republic of China government hopes that the U.S. government will disconnect the spy plane incident from the forthcoming Taipei-Washington negotiations on arms sales.

ROC President Chen Shui-bian told a delegation from the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs in Taipei Saturday that Taiwan needs advanced weapons to protect the peace and security across the Taiwan Strait.
He stressed that the security of the Taiwan Strait is important not only to the interests of Taiwan, but also to the U.S. interests in the Western Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE BUSINESSMEN IN VIETNAM ASK FOR ROC GOV'T LOANS
DOC.DATELINE: Ho Chi Min City, Vietnam, April 14 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese businessmen in Vietnam Saturday asked the Republic of China government to provide them with loans and help resolve the problem of educating their children.

They voiced their appeal at a symposium held with four visiting four ROC legislators. Hu Chia-ling, ROC representative to Vietnam and Wu Chien-kuo, director of the Ho Chi Min City Office of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office, also attended the symposium.

Legislators Hung Tu (KMT), Fan Yang-sheng (KMT), Kuan Wo-nuan (KMT) and Lin Feng-hsi (DPP), all members of the Foreign Relations and Overseas Chinese Affair Committee of the Legislative Yuan, are currently on a visit to observe the activities of Taiwanese businessmen in Vietnam.
During the meeting, participants presented a six-point appeal to the ROC government, which included asking for the financial help and educational assistance for their children.

Speaking on the education problem, participants urged the government to expand the new military service substitution program so as to allow conscripts to assist in overseas education for Taiwanese students and to help teachers at overseas Chinese schools secure jobs when they return to Taiwan.
They also asked the government agencies concerned to change the current eight-year limitation for overseas Chinese students to enjoy the privilege of studying in Taiwan.

They also asked the ROC to establish a foundation jointly invested by Taiwan's universities and enterprises and operated by Taiwanese businessmen in Southeast Asia that would offer scholarships for Southeast Asian students to study in Taiwan.

During the meeting, participants also blasted Eva Airways and China Airlines for their high air ticket prices. They urged Eva and CAL to cut their air ticket prices to the same level as those charged by Vietnam Airlines.

Legislator Lin Feng-hsi (DPP) agreed that it is unfair that Eva Airways and China Airlines charge 20 percent more than Vietnam Airlines, adding that he would like to lead the businessmen in a protest in front of the Taipei headquarters of both Eva Air and CAL, Lin said.
The trip will also bring the four legislators to Cambodia and Thailand before they return to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 CREDIT CARD SPENDING SET NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Credit cards spending in the Taiwan area set a new high of NT$719.8 billion (about US$22 billion) in 2000, up 20.1 percent from the 1999 level, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Sunday.

About NT$660 billion of the figure was spent at home, a 21.1 percent from last year, while the remaining NT$59 billion was spent abroad, up 13.2 percent from a year ago, according to DGBAS statistics.

As of the end of 2000, a record high of 32.42 million credit cards had been issued in Taiwan, up 36 percent on a year-to-year basis, and some 18.28 million credit cards were in active circulation, representing an annual increase of 34.6 percent.

With the Taiwan people increasingly getting used to spending with credit cards, the number of credit card transactions grew by 31.9 percent to total 272.28 million, the DGBAS said. The average transaction value was NT$2,643, a decrease of 8.7 percent from the 1999 average level, it added.

According to DGBAS tallies, Taiwan's credit card spending accounted for 12 percent of private sector consumption in 2000, up 1.4 percentage points from the 1999 ratio. In addition, Taiwan's savings rate stood at 25.2 percent last year, lower than the 26.7 percent level in 1996 and 29.4 percent rate in 1991, the figures show.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS BROKER PROVIDES CLUES TO INVESTIGATORS IN YIN MURDER CASE

TEXT.P: Tu Cheng Chun-chu, a Germany-based arms broker, met with investigators Sunday and provided some clues in the 1993 murder case of former ROC Navy officer Yin Ching-feng, said Justice Ministry consultant Hsieh Tsung-min.

Hsieh, who had accompanied Mrs. Tu since her arrival in Taipei last Wednesday, told reporters that he could not disclose what she had told the investigators because he has to abide by rules of secrecy regarding the investigation.

In addition to meeting with the investigators, Mrs. Tu also had a face-to-face encounter with former Navy officer Kuo Hsi Sunday morning through the arrangement of the investigators to present their views on some questionable points.
After that, she traveled to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and left the country aboard a Cathay Pacific flight in the afternoon.
Yin was murdered in 1993, a crime apparently connected with a scandal involving the ROC Navy's purchases of German-made minesweepers and French-made Lafayette frigates.
Mrs. Tu is believed to have some information regarding the scandal. She fled Taiwan for Germany in late 1993, and this was her first return to Taiwan since then.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOULD UNDERSTAND IF U.S. REJECTS ARMS REQUESTS: MOFA HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, 14 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan would understand if Washington rejects its request for the purchase of destroyers equipped with advanced Aegis battle management radar systems, according to the Republic of China foreign minister.

In an interview with the San Jose Mercury News, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao said it will not be the end of the world if Taiwan's request for four Aegis-equipped Arleigh Burke-class destroyers is denied, since other weaponry can also be used to counter Beijing's military buildup.

Noting that his statement will ease pressure on the Bush administration amid its ongoing dispute with Beijing over a U.S. spy plane, the paper quoted Tien as saying that Taiwan would understand if Washington decides not to sell it the destroyers because of possible negative reactions by Beijing.
Given the great importance of the ROC's friendship with the United States, it would be unwise to damage the relationship over weapons sales, Tien pointed out.
Taiwan knows that Washington might not grant its every request for arms, and would take it in stride if its requests are not fully met, Tien said.

Tien also said Taiwan would welcome the establishment of a mechanism between Taiwan and mainland China to enable the two sides to communicate with each other in case of accidents involving pilots or sailors from either side.

In light of the lingering tension in the Taiwan Strait caused by the collision of a U.S. spy plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter over the South China Sea on April 1, a mechanism of communication is vital to ensure that any accident involving Taiwan and mainland China would not get out of control, Tien was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEN SHOULD NOT DOUBT WOMEN'S NAT'L ADMINISTRATIVE ABILITY: LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Sunday that nobody doubts that women are able to manage family affairs and women should not let men doubt that they can handle national administrative affairs as well.
Lu, a champion of women's rights in Taiwan, made the remarks when she addressed the founding ceremony of the Confederation of Women's Associations in Taiwan.
Some 60 women's associations across Taiwan have joined together to form the confederation with the aim of promoting women's rights and interests as well as equality of the sexes.
Lu pointed out that in the past, women were regarded as second-class citizens. "How pitiful are we?" Lu asked rhetorically. "We should substitute competition with cooperation."

In the past, women were accustomed to being led by men but now women should accustom themselves to being independent, she said, adding that women have ability to distinguish the right path from the wrong one.

She stressed that since men do not doubt women's ability to handle family affairs, they should not doubt a woman's ability to run the nation. "Do not allow men to use the excuse that women cannot handle national administrative affairs."
If it is true that behind every successful man is a powerful woman, then a successful woman also needs a group of men to support her, she said.

Meanwhile, Attorney Yu Mei-nu was elected to chair the newly-founded women's group, and delegates from the United States, Canada, Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, New Zealand and the Marshall Islands also witnessed the founding ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS SPONSOR WATER FESTIVAL ACTIVITIES FOR THAI LABORERS

TEXT.P: Crowds of Thai workers and local people came together to celebrate Southeast Asia's New Year Water Festival, or Songkran in the Thai language, in Kaohsiung City and Taoyuan County Sunday.

Upon their arrival at the celebrations in Kaohsiung, Mayor Frank Hsieh and Fang Lai-chin, director of Bureau of Labor Affairs, were immediately smeared with white powder and drenched in water by Thai laborers as a gesture of good luck.

Noting that Kaohsiung's Nan-tzu area boasts the majority of Thai laborers in Taiwan, Hsieh said the celebration of Songkran in this city is very significant. He said that anyone who rejects getting covered in white powder and water in the festival rejects luck, as Thai people believe that getting drenched in water disperses the evils of the past year and brings good luck to them.

Noting that the Water Festival, which falls on April 13-15 this year, is the New Year tradition in Thailand, Fang said that Kaohsiung City Government's sponsorship of the festivities with the participation of local residents is aimed at alleviating cultural misunderstandings among the different peoples and reducing the Thai laborers' homesickness.
Meanwhile, some 30,000 Thai laborers in Taoyuan County descended on Taoyuan Stadium for water-throwing as well as a beauty pageant and other activities sponsored by the county government.

The organizers invited Thai monks to chant Buddhist scriptures, and an international Thai dance group put on a performance. But the festival reached its climax with the beauty pageant, in which the winner was determined by the number of balloons received from spectators as well as her answers to judges' questions.
After a fierce one-hour contest, the winner went to a Thai girl of Chinese descent who works in a foreign labor brokerage company in Taipei. She received a prize of NT$15,000 (US$460).
The Taoyuan Fire Department also participated in the festival, splashing water from high in the air to allow the Thai laborers to enjoy a different kind of water-throwing ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT DISPUTES SPECULATION ABOUT HIS TRIP TO JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui reiterated Sunday that he wants to visit Japan solely to see a cardiologist for his heart condition, and not for any political purpose.

In his first press conference since he stepped down last May, Lee disputed speculation that he wants to visit Japan in order to thumb his nose at Beijing, which has been trying to prevent him from making the trip even though he is no longer Taiwan's leader and has no official role in its government.
Lee said he is slated to visit the United States in May and would like to have his heart thoroughly checked in Japan before his U.S. journey.

The former president said his heart disorder dates back to 1972, adding that his condition deteriorated in 1999, when the island was hit by a 7.3-magnitute earthquake. The same year's presidential election campaign further taxed his health when he took to stumping for his protege Kuomintang candidate Lien Chan, sometimes seven times a day, he said.
Lee recalled that he could hardly walk a hundred steps without a break last May when he visited Britain after leaving office.

Although he underwent a coronary angioplasty in October last year to open a narrowed coronary artery, his condition has not improved much. He still feels chest pain and has to take medicine three times a day, Lee said.
Noting that Japanese cardiologist Kazuaki Mitsuto is a specialist in this disease, Lee said he would like to see him for treatment.
He confirmed that his application for a visa was presented to the Japanese representative office in Taipei on April 10.
Lee revealed that he will go to Cornell University in upstate New York on May 4 to attend the ground-breaking ceremony for a nanotechnology laboratory named after him.

An alumnus of Cornell University, Lee visited the school in 1996 while serving as president of the Republic of China despite Beijing's painstaking attempts to block his visit. Lee said that visit was a culmination of his longtime efforts to enhance the island's international profile.
Lee's Sunday statement will inevitably turn up the heat on Japanese leaders, who are currently divided over how to handle Lee's visa application.

As an illustration of the dilemma, the four candidates for head of Japan's ruling Liberty Democracy Party (LDP) were split evenly over whether the government should grant Lee a visa when they appeared in a televised interview Sunday.

Shizuka Kamei, chairman of the LDP Party Policy Research Council, said there is no reason to turn down Lee's application. He demanded the removal of current Foreign Minister Yohei Kono and Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda, who oppose Lee's visit out of concerns over arousing Beijing's anger.
Another candidate, Taro Aso, said Lee is entitled to a visa on humanitarian grounds.
Meanwhile Ryutaro Hashimoto, leader of the biggest faction within the LDP and Junichiro Koizumi, the former leader of the second biggest LDP faction, expressed reservations on the issue.
Hashimoto said Taiwan and mainland China should not take their dispute to Japan, and Tokyo should carefully steer clear of the Taipei-Beijing quarrel.
Koizumi said the issue should be resolved after considering the overall three-way ties between Beijing, Taipei and Tokyo.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 16, or the 23rd day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY OF COMATOSE M'LAND RESEARCHER IN TAIPEI IN NEED OF HELP

TEXT.P: The family of a mainland Chinese molecular science researcher who has been in a coma since being hit by a car in Taipei last year is now in desperate need of help to cover his extensive medical bills, a New Party legislator said Monday.

Mainland Chinese physicist Zhang Jingmin, who came to Taiwan last July under a short-term algae spectrology-photosynthesis research program financed by the Academia Sinica's Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences, was hit by a drunk driver Oct. 14 while riding his bicycle home near the Academia Sinica's dormitory in Nankang, a suburb Taipei.

Sustaining serious injuries to his head, Zhang has been in a coma ever since the accident, according to New Party Legislator Elmer Feng, who accompanied Zhang's wife and daughter at a press conference Sunday.
Feng called on the Taiwan public to extend humanitarian help to Zhang and his family, who are now facing grave psychological and financial difficulties in the wake of the accident.

According to Feng, Academia Sinica's management did not arrange any insurance policies for Zhang and his family on the grounds that Zhang was only in Taiwan for a short-term stay. Without National Health Insurance policy coverage, Zhang's wife needs a huge sum of money to foot Zhang's medical bills, Feng noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Ex-President Lee Teng-hui stresses no political purposes for his Japan travel plan.
The China Times:
Former President Lee warns ties will worsen if Japan denies his visa.
The United Daily News:
Ex-president blasts Japanese government for rejecting his visa application simply for fears of offending Beijing.
The Liberty Times:
Ex-president urges Japan not to give in to Beijing's pressure.
The China Post:
Japan is a cowardly nation, says Lee.
The Taiwan News:
Life is a 'nightmare,' says Lee Teng-hui.
The Taipei Times:
Lee denies politics behind Japan visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
