DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 63.19 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 63.19 points to close at 5,432.28.
Market turnover amounted to NT$45.04 billion (US$1.37 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 63.19 points to close at 5,432.28.
The bourse opened at 5,490.42 and began to go down later due to a prevailing wait-and-see attitude on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 5,490.42 and 5,409.05 during trading.

A total of 1.37 billion stocks worth NT$45.04 billion (US$1.37 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.56 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$92.5 billion (US$2.82 billion).
Only one of the eight major stocks categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up 0.7 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.2 percent, electrical shares and cement stocks, both at 1 percent, and textile issues at 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 413 to 119, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved down 38 points to close at 5,423, with 3,169 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May lost 64 points to finish at 5,402, with 1,434 contract transactions, while June futures fell 38 points to close at 5,482, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,461 for April, 5,466 for May, 5,520 for June, 5,565 for September, and 5,541 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
April TE futures lost 1.1 points to finish at 270.6, with 976 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved down 2.8 points to close at 270.1, with 391 contract transactions.
September TE futures increased 4.75 points to finish at 277.45, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 18.2 points to close at 708, with 500 contract transactions, while May TF futures gained 15.6 points to finish at 711.4, with 194 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATION BUREAU SEIZES SMUGGLED AMPHETAMINE IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice seized 42 kilograms of smuggled amphetamine at Kaohsiung's beach area late Sunday.

The investigation station in Kaohsiung County sent investigators to the beach area after receiving calls reporting suspected drug smuggling activity. They then seized the 42 kilograms of amphetamine which was already packed into bags and mixed with tea leaves.

Two suspects were caught during the seizure, according to the investigation station. Another two Taiwan residents and a mainland Chinese citizen were arrested for drug smuggling on the mainland this February.
The seizure of amphetamine at Kaohsiung's beach area represents the bureau's second drug seizure this April. The bureau also intercepted another 66 kilograms of smuggled amphetamine last Thursday.
According to officials in the bureau, the drug smugglers used fishing boats to transport the "goods" to the southern Taiwan beach area.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS WITH L.A. COUNTY SUPERVISOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met with Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors Chairman Mike Antonvich Monday to briefly introduce Taipei's infrastructure, saying that the city's current quandary is a shortage of financial resources.

While introducing Taipei's rapid transit system, Internet development, and cultural exchanges with other countries, Ma said to Antonvich and accompanying officials from Los Angeles County cities that Taipei's annual infrastructure budget last year showed its greatest negative growth in the last 20 years.

Ma added that the budget decrease was the result of the central government's downward revision of Taipei's budget allotment and also due to Taiwan's overall economic sluggishness. He also speculated that the budget will decrease again next year.

Los Angeles County, the largest county in the United States, is comprised of 88 cities with a total area of 4,083 square miles and a population of nearly 10 million. The annual budget for L.A. County exceeds that of 43 other American states combined, sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FISH BREEDING EXPERTS HELP HONDURAS BOOST FISH EXPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, April 15 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: A group of fish breeding experts from the Republic of China on Taiwan has successfully used its fish culturing know-how to help Honduras gain profits from fish exports.

Since 1992, the ROC technology group stationed in Honduras has used the technique of culturing fish in meshed wire cages placed in the Yojoa River, about 160 kilometers north of Honduras' capital Tegucigalpa.
Last year, the method enabled Honduras to boost its exports of fish filets to the United States to some 68,181 kilograms, according to Julia Suazo, the Honduran deputy agricultural minister.

ROC experts pointed out that an expansion in fish breeding programs is under way in areas in southern Honduras and that the central American country now expects to make fish filets one of its major export items.
They also noted that in addition to the fish culturing program, the ROC technology group has successfully carried out a plan to grow vegetables and fruits in Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREZ LEE INVITED BY CANADIAN CITY ON MEMORIAL OF MACKAY

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui has been invited by a Canadian city to attend a ribbon-cutting ceremony marking the establishment of a monument to Dr. George Leslie Mackay, a doctor-missionary who died in Taiwan 100 years ago.

Mayor John Geoghegan of the city of Woodstock, Ontario, has sent an invitation to Lee, inviting him to attend a ceremony slated for June 2 in Zorra Village in Ontario's Oxford County, marking the establishment of a monument to Mackay, founder of the Mackay Memorial Hospital, one of the most prestigious hospitals in northern Taiwan.

According to sources from Toronto's Presbyterian Church, Woodstock decided to invite the former ROC president to Canada based on at least three reasons -- that President Lee Teng-hui is an alumna of Tamkang High School in Tamshui, Taipei county, a school established by Mackay more than 110 years ago; that Lee is now a resident of Tamshui, a coastal township that Mackay spent most of his years in Taiwan in from 1872; and that Lee is a devout member of the Presbyterian Church, of which Mackay was a missionary.

In addition, the sources said, the first hospital that Mackay established in Taiwan was located in Tamshui. Still standing and operating is Oxford College, located near Tamkang High School in the hilly Tamshui, established by Mackay in memory of his Canadian hometown of Oxford County.

Whether Lee will be able to make the time in his tight schedule to visit Canada in early June remains to be seen, the sources from Toronto Presbyterian Church said. They added that the likelihood of him visiting will increase if Lee's plan to visit Cornell University in the United States in May proceeds smoothly.

A Toronto overseas Chinese community leader said that although Canada firmly recognizes the "one China" policy, Canadian authorities should not have any reason to not grant an entry visa to Lee, now a private citizen who holds no official government posts.

Dr. George Leslie Mackay came to Taiwan in 1872 at the age of 28 as a missionary from the Canadian Presbyterian Church. He preached, educated and provided medical services to the people of Taiwan throughout his 29 years in Taiwan until he passed away in 1901 in Tamshui. His grave is located at Oxford College in Tamshui.
Mackay married a Taiwan woman with whom he had several offspring whom are now living in Canada or Taiwan.

Tamkang High School, Mackay Memorial Hospital and other establishments related to Mackay in Taiwan are also planning to hold similar activities in commemoration of the 100th anniversary of MacKay's death, which falls on June 2, a Mackay hospital spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY UNVEILS NOMINATION LIST FOR TAIPEI'S SOUTHERN DISTRICT

TEXT.P: The tiny opposition New Party announced Monday that it will field three candidates in metropolitan Taipei's southern constituency for the yearend parliamentary elections.

Two of the nominees are incumbent Legislators Lai Shyh-bao and Elmer Feng and the third is incumbent Taipei City Council member Chin Li-fang, according to New Party Convener Hsieh Chi-ta's press conference announcement.

Hsieh, herself an incumbent legislator, said all three candidates have individual styles and different support bases. "As their 'vote banks' do not overlap, we have decided to nominate all of them to run in the yearend elections," she noted.

Hsieh said that although the New Party has encountered several setbacks recently, such as the "defection" of New Party Legislator Feng Ting-kuo to the opposition People First Party (PFP), all party members and supporters maintain a strong consensus and are focused on winning as many Legislative Yuan seats as possible.

Both the New Party and the PFP are splinter groups from the main opposition Kuomintang, which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until last May and still controls a comfortable majority in the Legislative Yuan. The New Party has seen its popular support dwindling in favor of the PFP since the latter party was founded last year. The New Party is the only domestic political party that unequivocally advocates unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The New Party must garner at least 5 percent of the votes cast in the regional legislative elections to qualify for securing at-large legislative seats. "We are confident that our party will be able to attain this goal," said Hsieh, a judge-turned-lawmaker.

Asked whether she would meet with PFP Chairman James Soong to discuss a recent squabble between the two parties over a report that the PFP plans to "recruit" three New Party stalwarts to run on its ticket for at-large legislative seats, Hsieh said the New Party is not in a position to take any initiative on the issue.
"My top priority at the moment is to focus our party affairs on consolidating our grass-roots support," stressed Hsieh.

Commenting on the report that the PFP is planning to "draft" incumbent independent lawmaker Chu Hui-liang to run on its ticket for a regional legislative seat in the Hsinchu City constituency, Hsieh said if Chu really accepts such an offer, she will wish the legislator success.
The New Party expelled Chu from its ranks after she ran for the vice presidency as the running mate of independent candidate Hsu Hsin-liang in last year's presidential election.
Hsieh said the New Party has several members who are very qualified to run in the Hsinchu constituency. "We have full confidence that we will win at least one seat in that district," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.023 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 32.931.
The local currency opened Monday at 32.904 and was traded between 32.904 and 32.945.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$259 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL CONCERNED ABOUT M'LAND RESEARCHER'S MISFORTUNE

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has proposed that insurance for all visiting academics, scholars and specialists from mainland China be made mandatory for the period of their stay in Taiwan, a MAC official said Monday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan Interior and Ethnic Affairs Committee that he is gravely concerned about the situation of mainland Chinese molecular science researcher Zhang Jingmin, who is now lying comatose on a Taipei hospital bed after being hit by a car in Taipei last year.

To express his concern, Chen said he will donate 10 days' of his own salary to Zhang's family in an effort he described as "casting a brick to attract jade" -- or making a gesture to encourage more people to extend humanitarian help to Zhang and his family, who are now facing grave psychological and financial difficulties in the wake of the accident.

Zhang, who came to Taiwan last July under a short-term algae spectrology-photosynthesis research program financed by Academia Sinica's Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences, was hit by a drunk driver Oct. 14 while riding his bicycle home near the Academia Sinica dormitory in Nankang, a suburb Taipei.

Zhang sustained serious injuries to his head and has been in a coma ever since the accident, according to New Party Legislator Elmer Feng, who held a press conference on the issue Sunday along with Zhang's wife and daughter.

Feng brought the Zhang case to the legislative Interior and Ethnic Affairs Committee Monday for discussion, during which MAC official Chen noted that his agency has already submitted a proposal to the Executive Yuan demanding that all mainland Chinese academics, scholars and specialists be covered under insurance policies while they are visiting Taiwan.
Chen added that the MAC will also contact relevant officials from Academia Sinica in the hope that Zhang's case will be handled more soundly.

In response to Feng's criticism that Academia Sinica's management had failed to arrange insurance for Zhang and his family on the grounds that they were only in Taiwan for a short-term stay, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said the institute's General Affairs Department has done all it can to help Zhang in the wake of the accident. Lee denied that Academia Sinica has ignored or neglected the matter.

Feng said that without National Health Insurance coverage or any other private insurance, Zhang's wife now needs a huge sum of money to cover his medical bills from Tri Service General Hospital, where he is still comatose.

Zhang, whose research program expired at the end of 2000, was hit by a Taipei man identified as Lin Chang-kuo, who was driving a car while intoxicated on the night of Oct. 14. The police have as yet failed to track down him.

DOC.HEADLINE: TASK FORCE MEETS TO DISCUSS MP3 DISPUTE

TEXT.P: An intra-government agency task force said Monday that it will sort out the problems arising from the university students charged with downloading music files from the Internet before contacting the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, Taiwan (IFPI).

The task force was formed at the instruction of Premier Chang Chun-hsiung who expressed concern about last Wednesday's move by the Tainan Prosecutors' Office to search a National Cheng Kung University student dormitory and seize several computers on which MP3 music files were stored.

The task force participants agreed on several resolutions during the meeting. They suggested that colleges and universities form emergency teams to contact the Judicial Ministry, the Executive Yuan form a task force to deal with piracy and the practice of downloading, the Education Ministry establish a legal counseling team, and campuses increase their education on the protection of intellectual property rights (IPRs).

Vice Education Minister Fan Hsun-lu, presiding over the first meeting, said that the public should respect intellectual property rights, adding that her ministry will step up its IPR awareness campaign so that the students will be aware of the regulations.

She said that students, while free to exercise their rights on the Net, should not forget their self-discipline, adding that Education Minister Ovid Tseng will write an open letter to Taiwan's university students on the subject.

Fan said that IFPI had provided a "blacklist" of 45 illegal sites on university computer systems from which students could download MP3 digital music files, of which 25 had been shut down. She added that the ministry will investigate the remaining sites.

In light of the MP3 controversy, the ministry has invited National Cheng Kung University President Kao Chiang and the school's Student Association president for a briefing. She said that as long as the school thinks it can handle the case, the ministry will only provide assistance, but otherwise the ministry will contact the IFPI after sorting out the dispute.
Officials from the Government Information Office, Justice Ministry, Information Industry Institute, and Taiwan Bar Association also attended the meeting.

Lawyer Hsiao Hsiung-lin, an IPR expert at the Taiwan Bar Association, said that the association will discuss whether the search of the school campus was itself legal and whether downloading digitized information for personal use violates the law.

Meanwhile, as the incident unleashed a heated online and campus-wide debate, the 14 students whose computers were seized by the Tainan Prosecutors' Office issued a joint statement through the Students' Association Monday, stressing that they had absolutely no intention of burning the downloaded MP3 files onto CD-ROMs to sell for profit.
The Students' Association also appealed for the IFPI to refrain from filing suits against the students.

The 14 students said that from the moment the prosecutors entered the dormitory, National Cheng Kung University has been in the limelight. The media reports had misled the public, the reputation of the school has been tainted, and they have lived under the shadow of fear, they lamented.

They swore that they did not engage in online piracy for profit, adding that reports about prosecutors "catching them red-handed" were "ridiculous." They asked for full support and assistance from the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSSIBLE REJECTION OF LEE'S VISIT WOULD DAMAGE TAIPEI-TOKYO TIES: FM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said Monday that relations between the Republic of China and Japan will be damaged if the Japanese government rejects former ROC President Lee-hui's application to visit that nation for medical purposes.
Noting that Lee is now a private citizen, Tien said there is no single article in current Japanese law that would justify a rejection of Lee's entry for medical reasons.

"Against this backdrop, if the Japanese government fails to screen Lee's visa application on humanitarian grounds and insists on denying his entry, Taipei-Tokyo relations will definitely be damaged," Tien explained.

The minister made the remarks after Lee said at a press conference Sunday that he has to go to Japan to receive treatment for his heart problems. The outspoken former ROC president also criticized the Japanese government for tip-toeing around the issue, calling Tokyo "more timid than a mouse." Lee stressed that his Japan travel plan has no political meaning.

In response to a press query about his views on Lee's visa application, Tien said he is hopeful that Japan will handle the issue properly and refrain from bowing to mainland Chinese pressure to block Lee's visit.

Meanwhile, Michihiko Komatsu, a department chief with the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), said the Japanese government is carefully studying the issue and will make a final decision in the near future.
The JIA is a quasi-official organization that handles Japanese relations with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Komatsu said major factors to be mulled by the Japanese government in deciding whether to approve Lee's visa application will include humanitarian considerations, Japanese public opinion and the views of foreign countries.

Commenting on Lee's statement at his Sunday news conference that he had filed his visa application with the JIA Taipei office on April 10, Komatsu said from procedural viewpoints, Lee's application was not "formal." He declined to elaborate on the matter.
In his first formal press conference since stepping down from the presidency last May, Lee said that if the Japanese government claimed that he didn't apply for a visa, "it amounts to lying."
According to foreign wire service reports, Japan hinted Monday that it might accept Lee's visa application, a move that could strain its diplomatic ties with mainland China.
"If the purpose of Lee's visit is for medical reasons, we could consider it from a humanitarian standpoint," top Japanese government spokesman Yasuo Fukuda told a news conference in Tokyo.
The issue has split Japan's Cabinet, with some members anxious not to ruffle feathers in Beijing at a time when regional tensions are on the rise.
Fukuda reiterated Japan's official stance that it had not yet received a visa application from Lee and that the government would soon make a final decision on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ORGANIZATION SIGNS AGREEMENT WITH 6 CENTRAL AMERICAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: China Textile Institute and six central American republics signed an agreement on cooperation Monday in a ceremony marred by a brief protest incident.

El Salvador Ambassador Francisco Ricardo Santana signed the mutual assistance agreement on behalf of six central American nations, also including Belize, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras. Yao Hsin-chuan, president of China Textile Institute also signed the pact.

But the signing ceremony was interrupted when two people, who had gained entry by posing as interested spectators, held up protest signs and began shouting slogans to criticize Taiwan firm Nien Hsing Textile Co. The protest was triggered by a labor-management dispute in a Nien Hsing plant in Nicaragua late last year.

The protest lasted only half a minute before the two were asked to leave. Nien Hsing Chairman Chen Jung-chiu, a guest at the ceremony, declined to comment on the incident, which left him with a somber expression.

China Textile Institute said that the agreement is aimed at promoting friendly relations between the ROC and its allies, adding that the protest was "regretful." The institute also extended an apology to the distinguished guests.

As Central America has become an important foothold for Taiwan textile companies to make inroads overseas, the signing of the agreement will assist the nations' textile technology development and help Taiwan businesses take root there.

China Textile Institute officials are scheduled to visit Central America in May to collect market information and plan for the establishment of textile design, information and employee training centers in Central America.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER U.S DEFENSE MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN IN JUNE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 16 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former U.S. Defense Secretary William Cohen will visit Taiwan this summer to exchange views with local officials on cross-strait relations and the situation in Asia.

Cohen served as Defense Secretary from 1997 until this January, when he stepped down along with the Clinton administration and established his own business consultancy focused on international strategy.
This will be Cohen's first visit to Taiwan over the past four-and-half years. He last visited Taiwan in mid-November 1996.
Cohen told CNA that he visited Taiwan several times while serving in the U.S. Congress, but has not visited Taiwan since taking the post of defense secretary.
Aides to Cohen said that he will visit Asia in June and Taiwan is on his agenda. His complete itinerary has yet to be worked out, but he will reportedly visit officials and make speeches.

The 60-year-old Cohen served six years in the U.S. Congress and 18 years in the Senate. He mostly focused on national defense, information, military and foreign affairs during his 24-year congressional career.

Cohen has been friendly to Taiwan, and supported the island's military moderation. But he also advocated active engagement with mainland China, including increased military exchanges to cut down on the risk of misjudging the other side's capabilities.

Cohen has also written two poetry books, three books of prose, and three detective stories. He has frequently appeared on major TV networks to comment on current events since stepping down from his defense post.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PITCHES FOR ASIA-PACIFIC ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu urged Asia-Pacific countries Monday to form an alliance to facilitate manpower, capital and cultural exchanges, as well as to promote human rights and regional peace.
Lu made the appeal in a speech delivered at the opening of the "Asia-Pacific Forum: Women and Power," organized by the Institute for National Development, a local private think tank.
Addressing female parliamentarians and scholars from nine Asia-Pacific countries, Lu said the ROC's existence is "critical to Southeast Asia."

In her view, Lu said, if Taiwan were to be swallowed by mainland China, communism would probably spread to other Southeast Asian countries. "And the 300-plus M-class missiles installed along the southeastern mainland coast and targeting Taiwan might also be deployed against other Southeast Asian nations," she suggested.

The outspoken vice president went on to say that although Taiwan has faced Beijing's military threat for the past half century, it has not been daunted because it has five "soft-touch" strengths -- human rights, democracy, peace, love and high technology.
Lu said the international community should recognize the ROC's achievements in political democratization and economic development despite Beijing's constant military threat.
Stressing that the people of Taiwan should not have to fear the mainland threat, Lu said the people of Taiwan have "used their willpower" to resist Beijing's missile threat.

She appealed for closer cooperation among Taiwan, South Korea, Japan and the Philippines to promote regional stability, prosperity and peace. She also urged Canada, the United States, New Zealand and Australia to strengthen cooperation with Asian countries for the mutual benefit of all concerned.
To reach this goal, Lu said major cities in Asia-Pacific countries could first form an alliance to boost civic exchanges and lay a foundation for official cooperation.
Meanwhile, Lu said she will push for the formation of an alliance of women politicians around the world.
In related news, she also said Monday at a seminar on religion, world peace and spiritual enlightenment that "precautionary measures are needed to ensure regional and world peace."

Lu urged Beijing to remove all the missiles from the southeastern mainland coastal areas and spend more of its financial resources on improving welfare service projects for its 1.3 billion people than on military expansion programs.

For the well-being and security of the 23 million Taiwan people, Lu said she will seek the assistance of United Nations-affiliated non-government organizations to hold a world peace promotion program in Taipei on Aug. 14 this year.
She said anybody who wants permanent world peace must take concrete action to boost this lofty goal.
The seminar was organized by the Dharma Drum Mountain Cultural and Educational Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODEL YOUTH FROM U.S. SHARES EXPERIENCE WITH TAIWAN PEOPLE

TEXT.P: A young Korean-American who is regarded as a model for U.S. teenagers visited the Republic of China Legislative Yuan Monday.

Danny Seo also presented copies of his book, titled "Heaven On Earth: 15-Minute Miracles to Change the World," to several legislators. He expressed the hope that people will transform their desire to do good deeds into action in the international volunteer year.

The 23-year-old established Earth 2000 -- a youth organization -- with his friends using a startup of only US$10 when he was just 12 to promote environmental protection. The organization now boasts 20,000 young members.

Seo said that although many people are concerned about society, they usually feel they have little time to help others. But as he says in his book, good deeds actually need not take much time and only 15 minutes a day can create miracles.

He said that he did not expect such enthusiastic response to his book and that he was elated to learn that after turning their thoughts into action, many readers not only now help others, but also feel good about themselves.
Seo, who was invited to Taiwan by a publishing house and a local foundation, said that he hopes to share his experience in voluntary service and extol its advantages.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWERFUL MAN TO RESOLVE PEOPLE'S BITTERNESS WITH RELIGIOUS MOOD: VP

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu has urged powerful people to resolve the bitterness of the people in a deeply religious way.
Lu made the remark Monday when she delivered a keynote speech at a symposium on regional and world peace as well as environmentalism sponsored by the Buddhist Dharma Drum Mountain Foundation.

In line with the Taiwan visit of Bawa Jain, secretary general of the U.N. Millennium World Religious and Spiritual Leaders Summit Meeting, the foundation sponsored the symposium in response to calls made at the recent U.N. summit in New York.
Master Sheng Yen, founder of the foundation, extended his warm welcome to the Chinese and foreign participants.

In addition to the vice president, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, and Interior Minister Chang Po-ya were also invited to attend the gathering. Leaders from local enterprises, academia, and Buddhist, Catholic, Christian and Taoist organizations also attended.

Discussions were centered on how to safeguard world peace and nature as well as how to eliminate religious discrimination and racial confrontation. The attendees also issued a joint declaration on world peace.

Lu said that after 50 years of concerted efforts between the government and the people of the Republic of China, Taiwan had brought about a kind of religious miracle by promoting religious freedom and peaceful coexistence among the island's various religions.
Lu further pointed out that recent natural disasters and man-made calamities here have taught humility to formerly arrogant people, and mercy to the formerly brutal.

Lu also called for Beijing to take down all the missiles it has deployed along the coast opposite Taiwan so as to reduce the chance of war. She also called on the United Nations to pay attention to Beijing's behavior.

Jawa Jain said religious and spiritual organizations will continue to play a very important role in future human development. He also expressed the hope that the recent U.N. religious summit in New York will help relieve cross strait relations.
He also said that more regional religious committees will be set up around the world to promote world peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN PHYSICS OLYMPIAD TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 2001 Asian Physics Olympiad will be held in Taipei from April 22 through May 1, with some 90 students from 13 countries participating.

President Chen Shui-bian will give a speech at the April 23 opening ceremony at the Government Employees Manpower Development Center, following which Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh will announce the commencement of the contest.
Each country can send up to eight students to the competition, the questions for which will be screened by the International Physics Olympiad and translated into eight languages.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will be present at the April 30 closing and award ceremonies, while Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will host a luncheon later that day for the participants.

The Republic of China, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia, Mongolia, Kazakhstan, Jordan, Israel, India and Brunei will take part in the competition, while Japan and Qatar will send observers.
The Asian Physics Olympiad is being jointly sponsored by the Ministry of Education, the National Science Council and the National Taiwan Normal University.
The ROC will also select five of its competitors to take part in the 2001 International Physics Olympiad to be held in Turkey in July.
The ROC hosted the International Mathematics Olympiad several years ago and will also hold the 2003 International Physics Olympiad.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI FOUNDATION MARKS 35TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: Master Cheng Yen urged the people of Taiwan to build a society based on "good deeds" with compassionate hearts and concerted efforts Monday, the eve of the 35th anniversary of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation.
The charity organization founder said that the Tzu Chi world is built upon benevolent actions and seeks to build a harmonious society in which everyone has love at the forefront of his or her mind.

Although Taiwan is a small island, she encouraged people from all walks of life in the country to bear in mind that "good deeds are the treasure of our society" and to do their best to transform Taiwan into a highly loving place.

The foundation based in the eastern city of Hualien will launch a series of activities to mark its 35th anniversary, including mountain climbing, sermons, the delivery of assistance and an exhibition featuring the four main themes of Tzu Chi activity -- mercy, medicine, education and culture -- to introduce its services to the public. Manuscripts prepared by Master Chen Yen in her early religious life will also be on display.
Master Cheng Yen said the foundation's results in the four areas are only the basis for it to continue its mission in the pursuit of a peaceful, beautiful and benevolent world.
In the 35 years since its founding, Tzu Chi has offered assistance to a total of 60,952 households and has set up more than 130 liaison offices in over 30 countries.

In addition to four hospitals and a university, a technical college, high school and elementary school, it set up a pioneering bone marrow bank in 1993, persuading 211,177 people to volunteer bone marrow samples for the databank and to donate bone marrow when a match is found. Some 263 patients, 112 at home and 151 from abroad, have received successful bone marrow transplants with Tzu Chi's help.

The charity group has also taken charge of the reconstruction of 50 schools damaged in the 1999 Sept. 21 earthquake, with 22 of the schools near completion, 17 of which are slated to be completed by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR GREATER WOMEN'S RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu called Monday for greater women's rights and proposed the formation of a non-governmental "Alliance for Asian Women Politicians."

Lu made the proposal at an Asian forum sponsored by a local foundation at the Taipei International Convention Center during a speech on "Women and Power." Scores of representatives from nine countries took part in the event.

Stressing that the pursuit of greater rights in a wide range of areas for women is aimed at reducing the possibility of war and "mistakes," rather than challenging men, Lu told the audience that the goal must be achieved step by step, saying "Rome was not built in a day" and that the international community should pay greater heed to the issue.
Lu also revealed that she will launch a campaign on Aug. 14, the final day of World War Two, to promote world peace in a bid to remind the people not to make the same mistakes of the past.

Pierrette Venne, a parliamentary member from Canada, said that although women's rights have been improved over the past decades, the female population still has to struggle for social, economic and political rights comparable to the same rights enjoyed by their male counterparts.
Monique Guay, also from Canada, said women should play and active role in politics. She urged her female peers not to be stymied by their families or children in their pursuit of a political career.

Marie Hasler, a parliamentary member from New Zealand, pointed out that women are still unfairly treated in the workplace and in politics, although their performances have been proved to be equal to those of men.
Setting herself as an example, Hasler that said that it is harder for a woman than a man to become a public opinion leader and that social and economic rights enjoyed by women are fewer.

U.S. Congressman Roscoe Bartlett admitted that women "fit in" better than men in certain fields and contended that women should not be discriminated against in social, economic and political activities. He expressed the opinion that women should be given the same opportunities in society and that their performances should be fairly recognized.
South Korean parliamentarian Kim Jung Sook highly praised Lu for her political achievements, saying that the ROC vice president has set up a model of success for all women in the political domain.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN TO CONSIDER `HUMANITARIAN PRINCIPLE' IN VISA DECISION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda said Monday that the Japanese government would consider "humanitarian principles" regarding a visa for former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui.

The spokesman for the Japanese government made the remark while commenting on a statement by Lee at a Taipei press conference the previous day that his Japan visit would be purely for medical reasons and would carry no political intent.
Fukuda told the media that the Japanese government would consider public opinions, humanitarian principles and "other factors" when deciding whether to issue a visa for Lee.
He added that the government would listen to the views of the Foreign Ministry and make a decision in line with Japanese government policy.
At the same time, Japanese Vice Foreign Minister Yutaka Kawashima said that his ministry would base its decision on whether to grant Lee a visa on "humanitarian and political considerations."

He admitted that it would not be easy to resolve the conflict between "humanitarian consideration" and respect for the "Japan-(mainland) China Joint Statement" signed when Tokyo and Beijing normalized their diplomatic relations in September 1972.

Some Japanese newspapers suggested that Fukuda's remarks showed a softening of the Japanese government's position on issuing a visa to Lee, while Kawashima's comment indicated a cautious attitude on the part of the Foreign Ministry.

Lee said Sunday that he presented his visa application through a friend April 10 and expressed the hope that he would be able to undergo post-heart operation treatment at a Japanese hospital around April 24.
The case has developed into a delicate triangular problem between Japan, mainland China and Taiwan.
A mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman reiterated Monday that Beijing opposes Lee's Japan visit for whatever reason and wants Japan to stop him from entering the country.
She described Lee as the creator of "two Chinas," claimed that he is not an ordinary citizen and said that his Japan visit is not a "humanitarian issue," but a "political issue."

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTER ISSUES OPEN LETTER TO STUDENTS OVER MP3 DOWNLOADS

TEXT.P: Education Minister Ovid Tzeng promised Monday to defend the interests of students, but called on them to respect intellectual property rights and abstain from downloading music files from the Internet without authorization.

The minister said in a letter posted on the ministry's website that he supports the students' advocacy that law enforcement officials and police should be "very careful" about raiding campuses and should refrain from any "unnecessary act."

In an attempt to calm the students, who were infuriated by a prosecutor's search of the student dormitories of National Cheng Kung University, Tseng said he will retain lawyers for students who have trouble with the law in the case.

Noting that the rapid development of technology often exposes the shortfalls of existing laws, Tseng said the protection of intellectual property rights is an issue facing not only Taiwan but the whole world.
He urged the students to enjoy the benefits of rapid communication and information-sharing made possible by modern technology but to fully respect intellectual property rights.

Rather than challenging intellectual property rights, Tseng said, the students of Cheng Kung University should join forces with his ministry and calmly face the legal issues arising from the incident.

Tseng also called on the prosecutors and police to carefully exercise their powers of search and refrain from any excessive acts. He assured the students that his ministry will defend their interests even more vigorously hereafter.
The minister later met with the president and a student representative of Cheng Kung University.
Student representative Chiang Hsing-ti quoted Tseng as promising that there will be no more searches of schools by prosecutors.
However, the minister urged the Cheng Kung University students to follow the law, said Chiang.

Meanwhile, an executive from the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) Taiwan office said Monday that his group will await the outcome of the prosecutor's investigation before determining whether to press charges in the case.

Lee Jui-ping, secretary of the IFPI Taiwan office, said it is still too early to say whether the IFPI will institute any litigation before the prosecutors determine that the rights of any IFPI members have been violated by the students.
The incident was triggered by an April 11 judicial search of dormitories of the university. Prosecutors, acting on a tip-off, seized 14 personal computers on which MP3 music files were stored.

Angered by what they called trespassing on campus, the students staged a sit-in the next day and appealed to students of other schools to protest in solidarity to counter the law enforcement officials' crackdown on the downloading of music files from the Internet, which is widespread among university students.
They also condemned the search as trampling on the "freedom of academia" and questioned its legality.
The IFPI Taiwan office immediately backed the prosecutors and vowed on April 13 to pursue anyone downloading music files from the Internet without authorization.
In a four-point statement, the IFPI said it will settle for nothing less than a conviction against the offenders.
Meanwhile, Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan admitted Monday that the search of the university "departed somewhat from the guidelines for such moves," although he said the search was legal.

Judging from press reports, Chen said the prosecutor from the Tainan Prosecutor's Office did not exceed his authority but appeared to fail to report to his superiors in advance as required by the guidelines.

Chen declined to comment on the investigation, but he emphasized that prosecutors should direct their energy to more serious crimes, given the scarce resources the Justice Ministry has to fight crime.
He echoed the opinions of Tseng, saying that prosecutors should be very careful in exercising their search powers.
Chen said that his office has asked the Tainan Prosecutor's Office to explain whether its search was conducted according to the guidelines on judicial searches.
The guidelines, laid down in November with the purpose of avoiding abuse of power, obliges prosecutors to seek their supervisors' approval before carrying out a search.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS URGE JAPAN TO ISSUE VISA TO FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and other Republic of China leaders urged the Japanese government Monday to issue an entry visa for former President Lee Teng-hui to undergo medical treatment in Japan.

Asked by the media to comment on the issue after attending a symposium, Lu said that Lee is an ordinary citizen and added that it would be "shameful" for all Japanese if Tokyo refuses to issue Lee a visa because of pressure from Beijing.
Chang, who was asked to voice his view when he visited an industrial zone in Changhua in central Taiwan, pointed out that Lee's Japan visit is for medical reasons and has no political intent.

He expressed his hope that Japan will allow Lee to visit Japan based on the "humanitarian spirit" and added that he has asked the Foreign Ministry to continue negotiating with the Japanese side over the issue.

Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh, a former ROC representative to Japan, called on the Japanese government to issue a visa for Lee, noting that Lee has already stepped down from the presidency and the Kuomintang chairmanship.
Hsu said that Lee is now an ordinary citizen and that Japan should allow him to seek medical treatment in Japan if he so wishes.
Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said Monday that the issue was still being negotiated, but warned that if Japan rejects Lee's visit, it might adversely affect relations between Taiwan and Japan.

Opposition People First Party Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung, former director of the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital-Linkou, said that a patient has the right to choose the best medical treatment he can find and that Lee's wish for treatment in Japan must be respected.
Meanwhile, several legislators visited the Taipei office of the quasi-official Japan Interchange Association Monday morning to present an open letter to the Japanese government.
The letter urged Japan to follow the examples of British and Czech authorities and issue an entry visa for Lee.
Some legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party urged Taiwan tourists not to visit Japan if Lee is denied a visa.

However, not everyone in Taiwan supports Lee's Japan visit. Some physicians claimed that "Taiwan doctors are as good as Japanese doctors" and added that there is no need for Lee to go to Japan simply for post-heart surgery examination.

More than 10 citizens visited the Taipei Office of the Japan Interchange Association Monday and asked the Japanese government not to allow Lee to visit Japan, claiming that Lee was only "pretending to be sick."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER AFFIRMS CONTRIBUTIONS OF TAIWAN RELIGIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Monday affirmed the outstanding contributions at home and abroad by Taiwan's religious groups.
He made the remarks while speaking before a symposium titled "Religions, World Peace and Mind Purification" organized by the Buddhist Dharma Drum Mountain.
Chang said that almost all religions in Taiwan are able to accommodate each other and co-exist peacefully, especially since the lifting of martial law in 1987.
He noted that all religious groups on the island have made outstanding charitable and relief contributions, not only in Taiwan, but also in foreign countries.
The premier cited the rescue and relief operations after the devastating Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake at home and the recent relief missions for quake victims in El Salvador and India.
Chang also lauded Taiwan's religious organizations for establishing hospitals, universities and publishing firms to engage in medical, educational and cultural work.
He asserted that "peace among religions is the foundation stone and power base for world peace, social harmony and progress."

Prominent participants at the symposium included Vice President Annette Lu, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Bawa Jain and Dena Merriam, secretary and vice chairperson, respectively, of the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religions and Spiritual Leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT URGES U.S. TO PROVIDE TAIWAN WITH DEFENSIVE ARMS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian called Monday on the U.S. authorities to provide Taiwan with the defensive weapons it needs to ensure its security and democracy.
Chen made the remarks while David Wu, a Chinese-American member of the House of Representatives, at the Presidential Office.
The ROC head of state lauded Wu as "a son of Taiwan, the glory of Taiwan and a friend of Taiwan" and said that democracy is Taiwan's strongest protection.

"The democratic outcome of Taiwan will be certainly ensured if the United States provides Taiwan with necessary defense weapons in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) or if the U.S. Congress passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) currently being debated," Chen said.

Chen also expressed his heartfelt thanks to Wu for his firm support for the cause of the ROC and his assistance in calling for the easing of limitations on visits to the United States by Taiwan's leaders and for providing Taiwan with necessary defense weapons. "You are worthy of being described as a real friend of Taiwan," Chen said.

Chen said that he was moved when Wu and Lin Chao-liang, a Chinese American violinist, visited their home town of Hsinchu last week and said he hopes it will connect Taiwan's "silicon village" -- Hsinchu -- with "silicon forest" -- Oregon -- so as to build Taiwan into a "green silicon valley" in the 21st century.

In return, Wu praised Taiwan's democratic achievements highly. He said that history is written by brave individuals and that Chen and Vice President Annette Lu are included among those history-making individuals. "Liberty, democracy and human rights are not bestowed by heaven but must be strived for through hard labor," Wu said.
Taiwan's implementation of the first peaceful power transition is a common glory for the whole of Asia and history will record these events, Wu continued.
Chen replied that it was also a glory for Taiwan for a Taiwan-born person to became a member of the U.S. House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: INNER QUARRELS HINDER TAIWAN DIPLOMACY AS MUCH AS BEIJING: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: conflicting opinions within Taiwan about the country's identity hinders the island's diplomacy no less than Beijing's attempts to isolate it diplomatically, a Foreign Ministry official said Monday.

Lo Chih-cheng, director of the Research and Planning Board under the Foreign Ministry, told a symposium in Taipei that the lack of consensus among the people of Taiwan has added difficulties to the island's efforts to break through Beijing's containment.

Citing the island's bid for U.N. membership as an example, Lo said some call it "entry into the United Nations", implying that the island is a new member rather than a former member, while others insist it is a "return to the United Nations."
The conflicting advocacy only confuses the country's few allies in the United Nations and renders the country's diplomats at a loss as to the politically correct way to profess their claims, said Lo.

He branded Beijing's all-out efforts to exclude the island from any international occasion as a hysteria which is so serious that mainland Chinese diplomats have even tried to shut Taiwan representatives out of international trade fairs and non-governmental gatherings.
Lo also criticized some pro-Beijing Taiwanese for "debasing themselves" by hosting Beijing visitors while turning a blind eye to Beijing's pressure on Taiwan.

He warned his countrymen against the thinking that by accepting Beijing's "one China principle," all disputes between the two sides would be solved, saying that it would only downgrade the island into "another Hong Kong."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUPPORT FOR ROC WTO ENTRY STANCE UNCHANGED: U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. diplomat said here Monday that the United States' stance toward Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) remains unchanged.

The United states has made all-out efforts to help Taiwan enter the WTO, said Raymond Bughardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), a semi-official organization set up to handle U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations.

Bughardt made the remarks in a keynote speech delivered at the 25th Congress of the ROC-USA Economic Council, which opened at the Headquarters of Chinatrust Commercial Bank chaired by Wang Chung-yu, board chairman of the council.
Bughardt pointed out that one should judge Taiwan's economic globalization from the viewpoint of the Taiwan market being globalized and Taiwan's market competitiveness.

Mentioning that the United States would benefit from Taiwan's economic globalization program, Bughardt said he believes Taiwan's continued strong economic growth will help it become a good market and a good trade partner for U.S. companies.

He further pointed out that the United States will strengthen its cooperation with Taiwan in the fields of finance, energy, medicine and telecommunications. However, he also said that Taiwan should further relax its trade barriers on the service industry and U.S. commodities.
Bughardt also said that Taiwan should pay more attention to intellectual property rights protection so as to help it be deleted from the "special 301" watch list.
He said that Taiwan could enter into cooperation with U.S. biotech, telecommunications, energy and medicine fields.

He added that maintaining a common economic prosperity between Taiwan and the United States is a pillow of the Taiwan-U.S. relationship, adding that the United States treasured Taiwan very much because it is an important trade partner of the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 17, or the 24th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging U.S. protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
1999: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returns to Taipei after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
2000: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference is held in Taipei with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.
2000: The Republic of China Finance Ministry allows two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER DENIES RECEIVING GE COMPENSATION CLAIM OVER N-PLANT

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) denied Tuesday that General Electric Co. (GE) of the United States has demanded a US$50 million damage award for a 110-day suspension of construction on the island's fourth nuclear power plant.

Huang Shou-ching, director of Taipower's nuclear and thermal power generation engineering department, made the denial in response to a newspaper report that GE has asked Taiwan's state-owned power company to compensate it US$50 million for its financial loss due to Taiwan's abrupt decision to halt construction on the new nuclear power plant.
Huang debunked the report, saying that GE has not yet produced data concerning its financial loss caused by the power plant construction hiatus nor has it presented a compensation claim.
Huang said he has no idea about the possible source of the newspaper report. "It's a surprise to me," he noted.
According to Huang, the earlier GE submits its financial loss report, the greater the benefit for it.

"After we receive GE's compensation claim, we'll conduct a comprehensive assessment with the assistance of relevant consulting firms and accounting experts as well as send staff members to GE for discussion," Huang explained, adding that if the two sides are far divided over the compensation amount, Taipower will not rule out the possibility of seeking commercial arbitration.
GE is Taipower's largest contractor for its fourth nuclear power plant, and its foreign contractors for the project also includes Japan's Mitsubishi Co. and Hitachi Co.
Bowing to pressure from the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan, the Republic of China government announced its decision to resume construction on the controversial plant on Feb. 14.

"And Taipower informed the three foreign contractors of the decision the following day," Huang said, adding that Taipower also asked the three firms to present their financial loss reports for its reference.
However, Huang said, none of them have so far furnished Taipower with relevant data or made any compensation claims.

Huang said GE once told Taipower that its financial loss estimates require data from its 100-plus subcontractors. "I think that the GE's delay in producing a financial loss report may be related to the large number of its subcontractors," he added.

The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led ROC government abruptly announced a halt to construction on the partially built nuclear power plant last October, sparking a fierce political fray with the opposition-dominated legislature. Although the DPP has never wavered in its anti-nuclear stance, the Cabinet gave in to opposition pressure and agreed to resume construction on the plant on Feb. 14.

According to Taipower's own estimate, Huang said, the 110-day hiatus incurred a financial loss of about NT$3.48 billion (US$106.1 million), including compensation claims from its foreign contractors as well as Taipower's own loss.
In Taipower's assessment, Huang said, GE-related loss is estimated at NT$1.3 billion.
