DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 0.33 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index edging down 0.33 points to close at 5,431.95.
Market turnover amounted to NT$41.11 billion (US$1.25 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 PROSECUTORS TO STUDY IPR LAW AT CHIAO TUNG UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has scheduled a screening session to choose 20 prosecutors to be sent to National Chiao Tung University for a month-long course on intellectual property rights and computer crime laws this May.

The training program for the prosecutors is expected to improve the professionalism of law enforcement regarding technology and computer crimes that violate intellectual property rights, according to a MOJ press release.

Noting that unlawful Internet usage and computer crimes have become rampant, with new tricks coming out everyday, the ministry has formed a special team to discuss the feasibility of amending computer crime regulations.
The MOJ is also cooperating with National Chiao Tung University for a three-year training and study program on computer related crimes.

According to the cooperation agreement, the university's graduate school of technology law will appoint professors specializing in intellectual property rights related to computers and technology to teach the prosecutors chosen by the MOJ. The graduate school will also assist in investigations when needed.

Meanwhile, the agreement states that the MOJ will provide Chiao Tung University with textbooks on newly-developed technology crimes and help prosecutors promote relevant intellectual property rights litigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging down 0.33 points to close at 5,431.95.
Affected by a drop in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,404.76 and fluctuated between 5,458.73 and 5,391.25 during trading.

A total of 1.18 billion stocks worth NT$41.11 billion (US$1.25 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.37 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$45.04 billion (US$1.37 billion).

Two of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 0.1 percent. Pulp and paper issues and electrical shares both remained unchanged.

The other major categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, and textile issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 269 to 204, with 115 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved up 17 points to close at 5,440, with 3,150 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 41 points to finish at 5,443, with 5,466 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,423 for April, 5,402 for May, 5,482 for June, 5,527 for September, and 5,503 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
April TE futures rose 2 points to finish at 272.6, with 972 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 3 points to close at 273.1, with 1,375 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures remained unchanged at 708, with 350 contract transactions, while May TF futures lost 1.6 points to finish at 709.8, with 446 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO PAY PRIVATE VISIT TO CORNELL UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 17 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former President of the Republic of China Lee Teng-hui will pay a private visit to his alma mater Cornell University in early May, Linda Grace-Kobas, a spokesperson for the university said Monday.

Grace-Kobas told the Central News Agency that Lee will visit his granddaughter Lee Kun-yi who is currently studying at Cornell and will also announce the establishment of a professorship in his name during the visit.

She said that reports that Lee will preside over a groundbreaking ceremony for a graduate school in his name at Cornell are untrue, adding that there is presently no graduate school nor building on campus that is named after him.
She said that Lee will announce a new donation during the visit, mainly to set up a professorship in scientific research. Cornell would not reveal the size of the donation.
Lee's friends and several Cornell alumni donated US$2.5 million to the university in 1994 to establish a Lee Teng-hui Professorship in World Affairs, which has focused on global economy research.
Reports about Lee planning to visit Cornell in 2001 surfaced last December, but the school did not begin to arrange for such a visit until about a month ago.

Grace-Kobas said that Cornell is encouraged by Lee's planned visit, but added that the university could not announce it officially. It is understood that Lee has yet to apply for a visa and that Cornell officials will have to check with Lee's staff for details.
Lee is scheduled to visit the university for two or three days, for about the same length of time as his first return visit in 1995. That visit infuriated the mainland Chinese leadership.

Cornell students will be taking their final term exams during Lee's visit. As mainland Chinese students mobilized a petition campaign last month to protest against Lee's expected visit, it is expected that they may stage a protest during the former ROC president's visit.
Grace-Kobas said that the stance of the school is that as long as it is done in a peaceful manner and does not affect the movement of others, students can express their views freely.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANYA JUNIOR HIGH, TAS PROMOTE BILINGUAL, CULTURAL INTERACTION

TEXT.P: Ninety foreign students from Taipei American School (TAS) met Tuesday with students of Lanya Junior High School (LJHS) in Tienmu, Taipei, for an English-Chinese language and cultural exchange.

Lanya Junior High School sent 102 students to the fifth annual activity of its kind held by both schools. The event is aimed at improving TAS students' Chinese-speaking abilities as well as their LJHS counterparts' English-speaking skills.

Welcoming their English-speaking friends, students from the junior high school jokingly asked the foreign students to perform a Mandarin tongue twister. Unable to accomplish the task, the TAS students still earned applause and cheers for trying.
One student from Lanya Junior High School acknowledged that the event not only helped him and his classmates learn some practical English, but also allowed them to make new friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL OF LABOR AFFAIRS WORKING TO HELP TAIWAN WOMEN FIND JOBS

TEXT.P: The chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs under the Executive Yuan said Tuesday that the council is working to help Taiwan's middle-aged women find jobs by making available to them positions that are presently offered to foreign females.

Chairwoman Chen Chui, presiding over a panel discussion on women's job opportunities held in Taichung, said Taiwan women will have more employment opportunities if the some 100,000 jobs offered to foreign female workers, such as housekeeping, baby-sitting and caregiving positions, are made available to local women.
With Taiwan's high unemployment rate and the over 320,000 foreign workers currently occupying job positions on the island, middle-aged women are having a hard time finding work, Chen added.
She called for better policy-making to increase the employment rate among Taiwan's middle-aged females and for the reserving of occupations for the women of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE TO COMMISSION MIRAGE WING MAY 10

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force's Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter wing will be formally commissioned into service May 10, marking yet another step forward in the ROC's military modernization, military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.
Huang told a routine press conference that with the commissioning of the Mirage wing, the ROC Air Force's combat capability will enter a new stage.
"It will also help boost our military's morale and the general public's confidence in our overall defense capabilities," he noted.

Speaking on the same occasion, Hsiao Yung-hua, deputy head of the Air Force General Headquarters' operations department, noted that the Air Force took delivery of the first of 60 Mirage 2000-5s purchased from France in May 1997, and that its officers and men have been thoroughly trained on the jets.
The ROC's first Mirage squadron was formed in December 1997 and a second squadron was founded in November 1998 when the delivery of the entire order of 60 Mirage fighters was completed, Hsiao said.
"After finalizing our intensive replacement training programs, the new Mirage wing will begin to flex its muscles and assume air defense missions from May 10," Hsiao said.
He also announced that a grand ceremony marking the commissioning of the Mirage wing will be held at the Air Force base in the northern Taiwan county of Hsinchu.

The ceremony will consist of a flyover by the new jets as well as a ground display of the Mirage fighters, Hsiao said. A total of 24 Mirages will fly past the review stand in formation and another 18 aircraft will be reviewed on the ground, together with pilots and relevant technical personnel, he said.
Hsiao further said that the Air Force is scheduled to hold previews of the Mirage flyover on April 18, April 26, May 3 and May 8, respectively.

"For the previews, partial airspace controls will be imposed between 9 a.m. and 11 a.m. on the above-mentioned days. As the controlled areas do not fall on flight routes, the ban will not affect domestic and international flights," he explained.
The Mirage fighters, along with the ROC's 130 locally built indigenous defense fighters (IDFs) and 150 U.S.-made F-16 jet fighters, form the backbone of the nation's second generation warplane fleet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TELECOM MARKET REACHED US$ 3 BILLION LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Driven by the vigorous mobile phone market, the production value of Taiwan's telecommunications sector grew to nearly US$3 billion last year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Tuesday.

MOTC officials said that thanks to the opening of the domestic telecommunications market, the production value of Taiwan's telecom industry hit US$2.85 billion in 2000, with wireless equipment taking the lion's share, with annual sales of US$1.25 billion.

The mobile phone market, which accounted for one-third of the entire telecom sector, registered a five-fold growth last year and helped drive the production vale of the industry up by an annual 165.9 percent in 2000, the statistics show.

Noting that the mobile phone industry is now focused on new technology development and the sales of mobile phone accessories and parts, the MOTC predicted that the sector will continue to prosper and help improve the island's economy as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.005 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 32.926.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 32.929 and was traded between 32.908 and 32.950.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$275.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBET, TAIPEI TO INCREASE CULTURAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan representative of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, reached an agreement with a Taipei City Government cultural official to increase cultural exchanges Tuesday.

Tenzin Phuntsok Atisha, accompanied by his secretary Kunga Tashi, called on Lung Ying-tai, director of the Taipei Cultural Affairs Bureau, on Tuesday morning. In accordance with Tibetan customs, Atisha presented her with a traditional Hada, and a Tibetan Buddha statue.

Lung told Atisha about her experience with the Dalai Lama during her four meetings with the Tibetan leader. She also expressed the hope that during the Dalai Lama's next visit to Taiwan, he will attend a seminar arranged by the bureau to meet with local art and literary figures for a cultural dialogue to increase mutual understanding.

Atisha responded by noting that a Tibetan performance group recently come to Taiwan to take part in the Miaoli International Mask Festival in northern Taiwan. He added that he hopes more Tibetan art and literary figures as well as performance groups will be invited to Taipei to promote the understanding of Tibet here.
He also said that Tibetans in exile used to have a certain degree of misunderstanding about Taiwan, but the situation has greatly improved because of the recent bilateral exchanges.

On two-way cultural exchanges, Lung said her preliminary plan includes asking members of the Tibetan art world to serve as exchange artists in Taipei. She said they would be able to give speeches and create art as well as give Taipei residents a chance to learn more about Tibetan arts and culture.

She stressed that the bureau will provide pavilions to showcase Tibetan culture during an Asian cultural festival scheduled to be held in Taipei in July. The Dalai Lama concluded his second visit to Taiwan recently. Just as he had done during his visit in 1997, the charismatic Tibetan leader attracted a wide following during his more recent 10-day religious visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAYS OF CROSS-STRAIT INTEGRATION OPEN FOR DISCUSSION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the methods for implementing integration between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are open for discussion.

The premier said that the idea of his predecessor Vincent Siew about forming a common market between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is one method of integration, and it should be open for discussion.

He noted that President Chen Shui-bian had earlier expressed the hope that the two sides could start with cultural and economic integration before moving toward political integration, but Chen had not touched on the method of integration. This method is still open for discussion, the premier added.

Chang made the remarks during a question and answer session in the legislature, in which Legislator Chen Chuan-tsan of the opposition Kuomintang asked about his thoughts on Taiwan's situation after Shanghai has overtaken Tokyo and New York as a world commercial center in the future. The lawmaker noted that some officials advocate the establishment of a common market across the Taiwan Strait after both sides join the World Trade Organization.

The premier said that the efficiency of the Beijing administration is indeed very attractive to Taiwan businessmen and is worthy of emulation, but also highlights the fact that the rule of law governs Taiwan while the rule of man administers the mainland. Beijing's system also entails risks for Taiwan businessmen investing in the mainland, he stressed.

Meanwhile, the premier noted that there will be an estimated 10 mergers among local banks this year. He added that if the legislature passes the financial holding company law during the first half of this year, at least five applicants are expected to apply to set up financial holding companies.
He also promised that he would map out a tax reform proposal by the end of the year, but stressed that it will not necessarily be implemented by that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPERT TO HELP PROTECT ENDANGERED FORMOSAN BLACK BEARS

TEXT.P: David Garshelis, a world-renowned U.S. bear expert, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan next Monday to study the Formosan black bear, an endangered species endemic to Taiwan, the Taiwan branch of the Jane Goodall Institute (JGI) said Tuesday.

Garshelis, a University of Minnesota professor, will travel to the Tafen wildlife research base on Jade Mountain in central Taiwan to conduct a field study along with his student, Huang Hsiu-mei, who is known to local aborigines as the "Mother of Formosan Black Bears" for her dedication to tracking the life and plight of the species in the island's mountain regions.
Huang, who is now working on a doctoral dissertation under Garshelis' guidance at the University of Minnesota, has helped arrange for her mentor's upcoming visit to the island, said the JGI.

The JGI said that although the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and the domestic academic community have devoted a lot of money and manpower to the study of the Formosan black bear, the actual number of surviving animals is unknown.
It was Huang who took the initiative to track the endangered species' whereabouts on the island.

"I have believed that the bear is the soul of the mountains ever since I studied at National Taiwan Normal University's Department of Biology and later at the Graduate Institute of Zoology at National Taiwan University," Huang recalled.

In July 1998, Huang said she returned to Taiwan after learning a repertoire of bear-catching skills in the United States. "I have since traveled between Taiwan and the United States to pursue the study of Formosan bears."
Over the past few years, Huang has often traveled deep into Taiwan's mountain regions by herself to track the Formosan black bears and study their activities.
"During the period, I have managed to plant computer chips and detectors on 15 Formosan bears to allow us to follow their lives by satellite," Huang said.
According to Huang, Formosan black bears face the threat of extinction. "Seven of the 15 bears I tagged have had their palms amputated as ingredients for Chinese medicine and cuisine," she lamented.

Huang said recent media reports of the poaching of some endemic wildlife, such as sambar deer, have worried her. "I therefore asked Prof. Garshelis to come to Taiwan to use the satellite monitoring system in order to check whether the 15 Formosan bears are still alive and healthy."
Huang recalled that when she began to track Formosan bears, many aborigines had advised her to drop her plan and stay away from the species for the sake of her personal safety.

"But with love and concern, I have managed to ease the long-existing tension between mankind and wild animals," Huang said proudly, adding that she has developed intimate relationships with baby bears and even bulky male bears.

When Jane Goodall, a renowned British primatologist known as the "Mother of Chimpanzees" visited Taiwan last year, she lauded Huang's courage and dedication to the study of Taiwan's endangered bears. Huang is now locally known as the "Jane Goodall of Taiwan," a testament to her achievements in studying and protecting the endangered Formosan black bears.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC MAY EASE RESTRICTIONS ON VISITS BY MAINLAND CHINESE PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is studying the feasibility of easing entry restrictions on mainland Chinese professionals intending to visit Taiwan, an MAC official said Tuesday.
Chou Ching-sheng, an MAC economic researcher, made the remarks at a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan on the promotion of commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

In response to appeals by legislators, travel agents and business executives with investments in mainland China to ease restrictions on visits by mainland professionals, Chou said the MAC is mulling the issue along with the opening of Taiwan's doors to mainland business executives and tourists.

Chou said he disagrees with claims by some critics that the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, will back off from its earlier promise to open the doors to mainland tourists in July.
In fact, he went on, the MAC is studying the issue together with the possible relaxation of entry terms for mainland technological and other professionals.

Noting that opening the country's doors to mainland tourists involve many complicated issues, Chou said the government must make a comprehensive evaluation and work out feasible measures to minimize the new "open-door" policy's adverse impact on Taiwan's national security.
According to Chou, an average of 80,000 mainland people now stay in Taiwan each day to visit ailing relatives or attend family reunions.

"The number will definitely surge once we open our doors to mainland tourists," Chou said, adding that for the sake of maintaining national security and social stability, the MAC must work out many preventive measures to curb overstays or illegal working by mainland visitors.

Chou further said the MAC is assessing the pros and cons of extending the maximum stay by mainland technological professionals to three years, as well as allowing the entry of mainland businessmen in preparation for Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization.
He added that the evaluation of all those issues is scheduled to be completed by the end of June.

Meanwhile, MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen was quoted by the local press as having told lawmakers Monday that the government indeed intends to open Taiwan's doors to mainland tourists from July 1 as originally scheduled.

Nevertheless, Tsai reportedly admitted that the program is still hampered by mainland China's refusal to resume dialogue with Taiwan's semi-official intermediary body -- the Straits Exchange Foundation.
Sources said the Cabinet may allow the MAC to hold talks with mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office to discuss issues related to Taiwan's opening of its doors to tourists from the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITIBANK, N.A. LAYOFF PROGRAM NOT TO AFFECT TAIPEI BRANCH PERSONNEL

TEXT.P: Although Citibank, N.A. recently announced large-scale layoffs, personnel at the Taipei Branch will not be affected, a Citibank official said Tuesday.
He said that the announced layoffs will only hit personnel working in the bank's investment department.

With Wall Street's tailspin this year and a slowing world economy, banking institutions have been reporting reduced revenues in comparison with previous years. This has forced Citibank, N.A. to carry out the layoff program, the official said.

Noting that some Taipei Branch staff members voiced disagreement on changes in the bank's credit card sales policy that will affect their pay, the official explained why the bank had to adjust its credit card sales strategy.

Changing the strategy was necessary in order to readjust the payroll structure and the bonus system, he said, adding that a great majority of staff members agreed with the company's changes when they were consulted in accordance with regulations stipulated in the Labor Basic Law. The allowance, personnel welfare and vacation systems will remain unchanged, he added.

Bank authorities will continue to consult with any employees opposed to the new policy and will help them transfer to departments that maintain the original credit card sales system if they desire, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN DENIAL OF LEE VISA `UNIMAGINABLE' SAYS ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian described as "unimaginable" Tuesday the idea that one nation can dictate the affairs of another and force that nation to refuse a visa to a private citizen seeking medical attention.

Commenting for the first time on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's plans to visit Japan later this month to receive post-surgery treatment for a heart condition and the Japanese authorities' apparent "struggle" on the issue, Chen said Beijing has been ranting and raving over the matter, an attitude he described as "unacceptable and unbearable."

Chen accused Beijing of intervening in Japan's internal affairs and sovereignty, adding that Beijing's performance is harmful and a humiliation to the spirit of human rights and no borders in the field of medical and health services.
He added his belief that such a thing "could not occur" in the United States.
He made the remarks when he met with U.S. Congresswoman Loretta Sanchez (D-Calif.) at the Presidential Office.
Meanwhile, sources from Tokyo reported that the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs was still pondering the visa issue.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman said that the ministry is still carefully considering public opinion, humanitarian principles and other factors in deciding whether to issue a visa for Lee.
Declining to say when exactly the Japanese Foreign Ministry will make a final decision, the spokesman noted that the decision will be made "of Japan's own will."
Also in Japan, a number of Cabinet ministers spoke up for Lee, urging the Foreign Ministry to grant him a visa.

Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono said the Lee visa issue should be handled carefully and with vigilance and he questioned the justification of "intervention" by Taiwan's president and Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Japan's decision over a visa for a "private citizen."
He added that further investigation is needed to find out whether Lee's insistence on visiting Japan is for purely medical reasons.
In Taipei, Foreign Affairs Ministry spokeswoman Katherine Chang again called for the Japanese government to issue a visa for Lee based on humanitarian considerations "as quickly as possible."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSPECTS CENTRAL TAIWAN QUAKE ZONES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that post-earthquake reconstruction programs should give top priority to the repair or rebuilding of traffic systems.
Chen made the remarks while making an inspection tour of mountainous regions of central Taiwan that bore the brunt of a devastating earthquake that rattled the island on Sept. 21, 1999.
Chen said he is pleased to learn that repair of a section of the Central Cross-Island Highway damaged in the 9-21 earthquake can be completed by mid-July.

"By then, traffic between Tungshih and the scenic Lishan area will be able to run smoothly again," Chen said, adding that reopening the road is critical to the recovery of the battered local tourist industry.

Earlier in the day, Chen inspected a construction project aimed at reinforcing the Tehchi Reservoir, which had its power-generating functions affected after a nearby dam was damaged by the earthquake.

Chen later visited the scenic Lishan area, where he was briefed on a mudslide prevention project and a long-term program to reclaim hillside land from private farmers whose land leases with the government have long expired.
Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang told the president that the council will reclaim 800-plus hectares of hillside land from private operators by the end of 2003.

In response, Chen said overuse of land resources has caused serious environmental problems in the region, including mudslides. "We should try to seek a balance between protecting the environment and improving farmers' livelihoods," he said.

Accompanied by several central and local government officials, Chen also visited Lishan Elementary School to show his concern about the school's operation after its campus was partially damaged in the earthquake. Chen was all smiles when he learned that all the damaged classrooms have been repaired. He presented more than 300 children's books to the school, many of which are biographies of noted religious leaders, politicians and artists.
During the inspection tour, Chen also confirmed that his only daughter, 26-year-old Chen Hsing-yu, will marry in September.
"I'm very glad to see my daughter find her life partner. I wish them a happy marriage," Chen smiled.
The future son-in-law of the first family is a 29-year-old doctor from National Taiwan University Hospital, Chao Chien-ming. The bride-to-be is a dentist at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES REPORTS ABOUT NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan categorically denied Tuesday that his party will launch a no-confidence vote against Premier Chang Chun-hsiung in May.

Stressing that scholars with KMT-affiliated think tanks have only been studying the case of the so-called "minority government" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) since last May, Lien said that now is not the right time to advocate the move.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said that the party has no intention of starting a no-confidence motion and added that although some party members might have voiced such intent, they are merely personal views and by no means a consensus reached within the party.

Lien and Lin made the remarks following a meeting with a KMT subgroup in the Legislative Yuan which expressed its concern over the issue, based on information provided by DPP Central Standing Committee member C.P. Kao.

A leading local newspaper also reported that a top-secret document circulating within the KMT suggests the party launch a no-confidence motion against the premier May 20, the first anniversary of the DPP-led government and pass the vote in June in order to shift the legislative election to August from December.
Lin said he has no knowledge of any such document.

KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang also denied the report and accused the ruling DPP of leaking the news to the media, a move which Wang said would only further provoke public concern and affect social stability.

Echoing Lin's words, Wang said it is true that some scholars have in the past broached the proposal to the KMT authorities, but only as personal opinions. He pledged that the KMT will never start a no-confidence motion to achieve its own interests, but he also pointed out that neither will it sit idly by in the face of the present political disorder and economic recession.

Wang claimed that the KMT has commissioned a group of experts to study the Republic of China Constitution in a bid to bail the nation out of the disorder produced by the DPP's lack of respect of the ROC's constitutional system.
Stressing that the "no-confidence vote" suggestion was only one of many proposals made by the experts, Wang charged the DPP for intentionally misguiding the public in that direction.

The KMT spokesman also denied speculation by Kao that a KMT assessment task force has recommended him to take part in the Taipei County magistrate election slated for December. He called the speculation "groundless" and said he is happy with his current job.

Shen Chih-hui, legislative whip of the opposition People First Party (PFP), said the PFP is suspicious about the media report. She added that her party will not agree with a no-confidence measure at a time when Taiwan needs political stability to upgrade its competitiveness.

The DPP Central Standing Committee also issued a statement later the same day calling on all political parties to refrain from seeking their own interests and to instead work together for a bright national future.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEEP LAUNCHES CAMPAIGN TO HELP TIBETAN CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu urged local private organizations Tuesday to support a fund-raising campaign to help exiled Tibetan children in India.

Lu made the appeal in a speech delivered at the opening of a seminar on women volunteers and social services, sponsored by the ROC National Women's League in celebration of its 51th founding anniversary.

Lu said she was moved by the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama's donation of US$150,000 to help the victims of a devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999. The Dalai Lama made the donation during his recent visit to Taiwan.
Noting that thousands of Tibetan people flee to India annually from their Chinese communists-ruled homeland, Lu said many young Tibetan exiles do not have opportunities to receive education.

"Therefore, I plan to launch a campaign to pool resources in the private sector to help build schools in the northern Indian city of Dharamsala, also the seat of the Tibetan government-in-exile, to let Tibetan children receive formal education," Lu said.

Meanwhile, Lu said she hopes that Taiwan residents can show more concern about the lives of those residing on Taiwan's offshore islands, such as Penghu, Orchid Island and the defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu.
Lu said she found after her recent inspection tours of those areas that there are both geographic and psychological "distances" or gaps between Taiwan and its offshore islands.

"Welfare services for elderly people in the offshore areas must be modernized and children there should be offered access to computer education," Lu said, adding that Taiwan residents should help boost the development of the offshore islands.

As the Taiwan economy has been mired in doldrums, Lu further urged local people to make pleasure trips at home instead of going abroad for sightseeing purposes. "By so doing, we can help accelerate the recovery of our tourist industry and overall economy," Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LAUDS CONTRIBUTIONS OF RELIGIONS TO ROC INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu lauded local religious groups Tuesday for their contributions to the promotion of Taiwan's relations with the international community.
She made the remarks while meeting with Bawa Jain and Dena Merriam, secretary-general and vice chairperson, respectively, of the Millennium Summit of World Religious and Spiritual Leaders.

Mentioning the to-be-established "Museum of World Religions" in suburban Taipei, Lu said that "the efforts of local religious groups have not only let Taiwan walk out, but have also let the world come in."
Bawa Jain noted that Taiwan is "a part of the world" and added that he is very concerned about peace across the Taiwan Strait.
He said that cross-strait exchanges and dialogue must be promoted through the efforts of both the private and official sectors.
Lu told the visitors that efforts must be made by all people around the world for the ideal of attaining everlasting peace without war.

Bawa Jain said the purposes of his Taipei visit are to seek cooperation among religious leaders in the Asia-Pacific region and to push forward peace work between the United Nations and the region through cooperation.

The visitors were in Taipei for a religious symposium organized by the Dharma Drum Mountain. They met with the vice president, accompanied by Master Hsin Tao of the Lingchiu Mountain and Dharma Master Kuo Hsiang of the Dharma Drum Mountain.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA PLANS TO RAISE EMPLOYMENT STABILIZATION FEE

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) plans to raise the employment stabilization fee for domestic employers hiring foreign workers to cope with the escalating unemployment rate, CLA Chairman Chen Chu said Monday.

The CLA, Taiwan's highest government organization in charge of labor-policy making, plans to set aside NT$6.2 billion (US$193 million) from the employment stabilization fund in 2001 to stimulate traditional industries, as well as help the reconstruction of quake-stricken areas and provide vocational training in the affected areas.

Lin Tsong-ming, director-general of the Employment and Vocational Training Administration under the CLA, said that the fund currently stands at NT$10.4 billion and added that if the unemployment continues to increase in the next year, the amount will probably shrink to NT$4.6 billion.
The CLA plans to raise the employment stabilization fund by 20 percent in fiscal 2001, which would bring in a total of NT$5.42 billion in the fiscal year, representing an increase of NT$1.15 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN `MIGHT' ISSUE VISA TO FORMER ROC PRESIDENT: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs might consider issuing an entry visa to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui if he restricts his visit to the western prefecture of Okayama, an ROC diplomatic source said Tuesday.

After a week of "brainstorming" since Lee filed an application with the Taipei office of the quasi-official Japan Interchange Association April 10 for a visa to visit Japan, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday that the ministry will consider Lee's application favorably if he agrees to confine his activities in Japan only to receiving medical treatment in a hospital in Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture, according to Lo Fu-chen, Taipei's top representative in Japan.

In his visa application, Lee stated that he wants to receive treatment for a heart condition at the Kurashiki hospital before April 24, with the treatment conducted by the same Japanese doctor who supervised Lee's heart surgery at the National Taiwan University Hospital last Oct. 6.
Lo said that with the latest condition offered by the Japanese Foreign Ministry, it is now up to Lee to decide whether he will honor this condition so as to enable him to receive a Japanese visa.

In two rounds of talks with Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori Tuesday, Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono said his ministry needs a better understanding of Lee's "real" reason for wishing to visit Japan, as he said he had heard that Lee also hopes to visit Kyoto University, his alma mater.
Mori, meanwhile, is supposed to have instructed during the talks that the Foreign Ministry must issue a visa for Lee based on humanitarian principles.

DOC.HEADLINE: NFTU HANGS OUT SHINGLE

TEXT.P: The National Federation of Trade Unions (NFTU) hung out its shingle Tuesday witnessed by several legislators of Taiwan's main political parties.

Later in the day, the NFTU announced that it plans to organize a grand parade May 1 -- International Worker's Day -- to urge the government to face up to the deterioration of the domestic employment market.
Besides the NFTU, several other labor organizations, including the Chinese Federation of Labor (CFL), will also stage parades on the same day for the same reason.
The CFL will call for a "ten-thousand-worker parade," to appeal for the implementation of an 84-hour biweekly working hour system.
Workers joining the parade will set out from the Chungshan Football Stadium and march to the square in front of the Presidential Office, where an award ceremony will be held for model workers.
Members of several trade unions under the NFTU umbrella will also go to their respective companies to stage protests over layoffs and salary cuts.

Workers attending the NFTU parade will gather later at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and march to the Legislative Yuan, where they will ask the caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the main opposition parties to take the NFTU's versions of amendments of three laws governing laborer rights into consideration while amending the laws.
Domestic unemployment has been increasing since last year, with many traditional, hi-tech and state-run enterprises laying off employees or even shutting down.
It is believed that with workers hoping the government will pay more attention to their rights, the May 1 parades will be the biggest of recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN SAYS HE WILL STICK TO HIS GUNS

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman David Wu, a Democrat from Oregon, said Tuesday that although he alienated many business groups by voting against permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) status for Beijing, keeping true to his campaign promises had regained him the support of the voters in his re-election campaign.

Currently in Taiwan to visit his birthplace, the first Taiwan-born U.S. representative admitted to a CNA reporter Tuesday that his opposition for granting PNTR to Beijing had offended many Asian-Americans as well as business groups in Oregon, which is developing its high-tech industry and is eager to explore foreign markets such as mainland China.

However, Wu said he preferred to deliver on his campaign promise by voting against PNTR for Beijing in solidarity with labor unions. His consistent political stance has earned him a reputation for honesty, which, combined with his successful efforts in seeking federal funding for research projects, medical centers and a light rail in Oregon, turned the voter tide in his direction when he sought re-election last year, he said.

As to the midair collision between a U.S. spy plane and a mainland Chinese jet fighter, Wu said he is glad the incident has been partially resolved with the release of the 24 American airmen involved.
"Some damage has been done, but at least it has been limited somewhat by the Beijing government's release of the individuals," said Wu.

He said the United States has undertaken the obligation to sell Taiwan all the appropriate defensive weapon necessary for Taiwan's defense, adding his hope that the administration will follow the relevant laws and consider exclusively the legitimate defense needs of Taiwan.
Wu attributed his political success to the openness of U.S. society, touting America as a "very open country and culture ... a society of opportunity ..."

Oregon voters elected him to represent them in Washington, "not because I was the best Chinese American candidate ... but because they are open-minded and the possibility that I might be the best candidate." Wu said.

The congressman who switched from medical school to law school at Harvard and went on into politics, offered valuable advice to parents in Taiwan that they should encourage their children to go into fields about which they are passionate.
It might be tough for parents to do so, Wu said, but added that young people are more likely to succeed in fields they feel great passion about than in fields their parents think are more secure.

He said he wants his children to learn Chinese while they are young, because keeping some ties with one's past is a very human need. The challenge, Wu said, is to keep a sense of roots in one's past but remain open to all sorts of other cultures and potentially different futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT TO MAKE STOPOVER IN NEW YORK MAY 21-22
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will make a stopover in New York May 21-22 on his way to Central and South American countries, a U.S. official said Tuesday.
The announcement was confirmed by ROC Representative to Washington Chen Chien-jen, who said that application for Chen's stopover had been presented to the U.S. government.
Chen also disclosed that former ROC President Lee Teng-hui plans to visit his alma mater -- Cornell University -- in New York State from April 30 to May 4.
Chen noted that Lee is now an ordinary citizen and added that his private trip to his alma mater will not adversely affect Washington's relations with Beijing.
The U.S. government is expected to approve both Chen's stopover and Lee's visit, according to political observers in Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT THANKS LOS ANGELES COUNTY FOR LONG-TIME SUPPORT FOR ROC

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian expressed gratitude Tuesday to a visiting Los Angeles County delegation led by Michael Antonovich, chairman of the county's board of supervisors, for their staunch support for the ROC.

Welcoming Antonovich and his entourage, Chen said that although the ROC does not maintain diplomatic relations with the United States, the substantive relations between the two countries are developing steadily based on the existing good relations. In addition to visits by central government officials and Legislative Yuan officials, the exchange of visits between the private sector of the two countries are rapidly increasing, Chen said.
Chen also took the opportunity to congratulate Antonovich on his sixth election victory.

Los Angeles County has always maintained good relations with Taiwan and entered into sisterhood relations with Taipei County in 1996, Chen said, adding his hope that the two counties will further strengthen their cooperation.

Chen also described Antonovich as a "sincere friend" of the ROC who has already made more than ten visits to Taiwan and who has also rejected Beijing's political pressure and continued to render his support to ROC diplomats in Los Angeles, Chen said.

Chen expressed hope that his visitors will visit economic establishments in the ROC during their stay in Taiwan and that relations between Taiwan and the United States will be further cemented in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING PARTY RESPECTS JUDICIAL DECISION ON TAINAN MAYOR CASE

TEXT.P: A senior official of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that his party will respect the judicial decision made in a corruption case involving Tainan Mayor Chang Tsan-hung.

Chang, who is accused of involvement in a corruption case centered around the compensation fund for a land purchase project, presented himself Tuesday to the Prosecutor's Office of the Tainan District Court for interrogation for the first time.
Prosecutor Chang Pei-chen requested that Chang be detained on the grounds that he might destroy the evidence.
Although the mayor's family said that he is the victim of what they described as "judicial violence," the DPP said that it will respect judicial investigation and will not comment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIPPLED CARGO SHIP TO BE SCUTTLED AS ARTIFICIAL REEF

TEXT.P: A Greek cargo ship that ran aground off the coast of southern Taiwan in January will be towed to international waters some 12 nautical miles away in June and scuttled as an artificial reef, the ship's owner said Tuesday.

About 40 percent of the coastline contaminated by fuel that leaked from the Amorgos' wreckage has already been cleaned up and marine life is returning to the inter-tidal zones affected by the thick fuel oil, said an official overseeing the cleanup.

Environmental authorities have set the end of May as a deadline for the ship owner to clear the ship of its remaining fuel as well as its 60,000-ton cargo of iron ore and prepare to tow the wreckage away in June.
The 35,000-ton ship, which was left high and dry after running aground, leaked some 1,100 tons of fuel, contaminating miles of pristine coastline in the Kenting National Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST CHARITY CELEBRATES 35TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation remembered its 35th founding anniversary Tuesday by publishing a four-volume history of the charity's development.
The foundation is the largest private charity in Taiwan and provides assistance at home and overseas to refugees and victims of natural disasters.
The four-volume book records the foundation's works in the four fields of relief, medicine, education and culture, which are the four areas the foundation was set up to promote.
The group later adopted a fifth area in which to work when it set up a pioneering bone-marrow data bank that can provide quick bone marrow matches, as well as donors for transplants.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RANKED WORLD'S 14TH-LARGEST CREDITOR NATION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has been ranked the 14th-largest creditor nation among 18 leading countries in the world, with its cross-border credit amount totaling US$48.79 billion, according to a recent survey.

According to the latest report by the Bank of International Settlement (BIS), Taiwan's holdings of international credit, including savings in international financial institutions and loans of all kinds to governments, individuals and corporations, was the 14th-largest among the 18 countries included in the BIS survey.

Germany, Japan and France were the top three nations, in that order, in terms of international creditor's holdings, with holdings of 17.6 percent, 11.76 percent and 8.03 percent, respectively, of the total of cross-border creditors' possessions owned by the 18 surveyed countries, according to BIS authorities.
Taiwan's holdings constituted only 0.64 percent of the total, the BIS report shows.
Other major creditor nations were Britain, Switzerland, the United States, the Netherlands, Belgium, Italy, Spain, Canada, Austria, Sweden, Denmark, Portugal, Ireland, and Finland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI BANK CHOSEN TO ISSUE CHARITY LOTTERY

TEXT.P: The Taipei Bank was chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) Tuesday to issue both traditional and computerized charity lotteries.
MOF officials announced their choice after the third meeting of a panel set up to chose an issuing authority for the government-sponsored lottery.

The panel, consisting of scholars, representatives of charity groups and officials of related agencies, rated the prospective issuers on their financial health, marketing and management capabilities, security and other factors.

A MOF official said that the winning bank will enjoy the right to issue computerized lottery tickets for five years, from Jan. 1, 2002 to Dec. 31, 2006. This will give the bank annual revenues of NT$2 billion, while the computer firm chosen to operate the lottery will earn NT$6.5 billion per year, according to analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 18, or the 25th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important evens that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born in Italy. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in northern China as several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Planes from a U.S. aircraft carrier bomb Tokyo for the first time. They were commanded by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, a Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane is shot down by U.S. warplanes over the Solomon Islands. He planned Japan's naval strategies during World War II, including the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: By a two-thirds majority, the first National Assembly approves temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti-Communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical base for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the Legislature, and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: The former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The ROC Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit Taiwan citizens to gather news and make films in mainland China.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion of separated families.
1999: A GIO-produced documentary featuring the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals in the Chinese Zodiac wins a gold memdal in the Houston Interantional Film Festival.
2000: Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University signs an academic cooperation contract with Japan's Kanazawa Industrial University.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on U.S. Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and the United States.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 76.66 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 76.66 points to close at 5,508.61.
Market turnover amounted to NT$75.24 billion (US$1.37 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAYOR DETAINED OVER GRAFT CHARGES

TEXT.P: The Tainan District Court approved Wednesday a prosecution request to hold Tainan City Mayor George Chang incommunicado over his alleged involvement in a governmental land-requisition scam.
The district court made the decision after hours of discussion among several judges.

Shen Yang-jen, the presiding judge of the court, said the decision was made out of several considerations, including that the land-requisition project violated the principles of "reasonability and necessity," all detained defendants claimed that Chang played a leading role in the scam and many relevant city government files carried Chang's written directives concerning the case.

Chang was accused of having ordered the requisition of certain plots of land in the southern Taiwan city in order to benefit Tainan City Council Speaker Huang Yu-wen, who has been detained over the scam.

Tainan prosecutors investigating the case said they believe that Chang had conspired with Huang over the land requisitions and that Chang is still hiding some related documents from prosecutors. Therefore, the prosecutors requested that Chang be hold in custody to prevent him from destroying evidence or collaborating with other witnesses.

Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Judicial Committee Wednesday that the Tainan prosecutors informed the Ministry of Justice of their decision to request for Chang's detention Tuesday. "Under current law, they do not need my approval to make such a request to the district court," he explained.
Chen told lawmakers that prosecutors have demanded Chang's detention mainly because they think it will facilitate their access to relevant city government files.
In addition to Chang, eight other people, including the speaker and deputy speaker of the Tainan City Council, have also been taken into custody over the land-requisition scam.
Chang, a scholar-turned-politician, was the fourth incumbent local government chief from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to be charged with corruption.

After Chang's detention, the Ministry of the Interior said Lin Ching-Tuei, chief secretary of the Tainan City Government, will serve as acting mayor for the time being. Chang has not appointed a deputy mayor after Tsai Wen-pin resigned from the deputy mayoral post over different political concepts with Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNIST CHINA'S CLAIM TO TAIWAN 'ABSURD': FORMER U.S. AMB. TO U.N.

TEXT.P: Communist China's claim to the island of Taiwan is "just too absurd" and "outrageous," according to former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations Jean J. Kirkpatrick.

"There is just no reason to stand by and permit the Chinese Communists to take them (the people of Taiwan) over," the director of Foreign and Defense Policy Studies at the American Enterprise Institute stated during an interview Saturday on the "Judicial Watch Report," a radio broadcast sponsored by Judicial Watch, a Washington-based legal watch group.

"I strongly believe that we committed a long time ago to selling Taiwan the technology and weapons which are necessary for their (the Taiwan people's) defense," Kirkpatrick said, adding that "we've been doing it in quite an inadequate way," the World Wide Web newspaper WorldNetDaily reported Tuesday.
"The Clinton administration dramatically increased the amount of technology and weapons provided to the mainland," she added.

As a result of the transfer of advanced weaponry, the U.S. commitment to adequately supply arms to Taiwan means a lot more than before Communist China "had all the missiles they have at the present time," she noted.

In response to speculation that U.S. President George W. Bush had agreed to refrain from selling Aegis-class destroyers to Taiwan in return for the release of the 24 American crew members recently held by mainland China, Kirkpatrick said that "I don't believe the president would, in that situation, offer some kind of guarantee that we weren't going to sell the Aegis" to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GOV'T URGED TO SELL AEGIS-EQUIPPED DESTROYERS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. Congressman Bob Stump, chairman of the House Armed Forces Committee, is urging Vice President Dick Cheney to support the sale of Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan, stressing that this would be a "clear, firm signal to China of the United States' commitment to seeing the Taiwan question resolved peacefully."

In an April 12 letter to the vice president, the Arizona Republican congratulated the Bush administration's astute handling of the Washington-Beijing standoff following the April 1 collision between a U.S. Navy surveillance aircraft and a Chinese jet fighter.

Stump said he was particularly struck by the administration's "consistent reference to the obligation the United States has, under the Taiwan Relations Act, to maintain Taiwan's self-defense capability," adding that "this obligation will not be compromised by demands from China."
In this regard, Rep. Stump wrote, "I respectfully recommend that the legitimate need for Taiwan to acquire Arleigh Burke destroyers outfitted with the Aegis battle management system be recognized."

"Discretion is clearly the order of the day on any decisions related to Taiwan. However, I firmly believe that if we do not provide Taiwan with the system today, the day might come when we will have to help Taiwan defend itself, just like we did in March 1996," noted the congressman.

Stump pointed out that Taiwan's need for the Aegis system is legitimate and that an indication from the (Bush) administration that this is so would be a clear and firm signal to Beijing of the U.S. commitment to seeing the Taiwan question resolved peacefully.

Meanwhile, the president of the Formosa Association for Public Affairs, Chen Wen-yen, said that the new administration has rightly focused on stability in East Asia as a key goal, and that it sees a strong Taiwan as, in Secretary of State Colin Powell's words, "the foundation of stability and security in that part of the world."
"The Aegis sale will buttress stability in the region and thus supports both the United States and Taiwan's interests," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 76.66 points to close at 5,508.61.

Encouraged by a rebound in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,479.47 and continued to go up due to the good performance of semiconductor stocks. The index fluctuated between 5,523.72 and 5,472.79 during trading.

A total of 1.91 billion stocks worth NT$75.24 billion (US$1.37 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.18 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$41.11 billion (US$1.25 billion).
Only one of the eight major stocks categories posted losses, with construction stocks edging down 0.1 percent. Plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares and cement stocks, both at 0.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent, and pulp and paper issues and textile issues, both at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 315 to 172, with 99 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for April moved up 87 points to close at 5,527, with 2,374 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May rose 96 points to finish at 5,539, with 6,478 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,440 for April, 5,443 for May, 5,499 for June, 5,544 for September, and 5,520 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
April TE futures rose 6.5 points to finish at 279.1, with 682 contract transactions, while May TE futures moved up 6.9 points to close at 280, with 1,820 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures fell 9.6 points to finish at 698.4, with 499 contracts trasactions, while May TF futures rose 6.2 points to close at 716, with 576 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: LISTED COMPANIES' PROFITS TOTAL NT$ 533.3 BILLION IN MARCH

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) reported Wednesday that the 523 listed companies included in its calculations for March gained profits totaling NT$533.3 billion (US$16.6 billion) last month, representing growth of 1.77 percent over the same month last year.
Two hundred and twenty-nine of the 523 listed companies, or 43.8 percent of the total, showed a growth in profits last month, with electronics companies' profits growing by 5.68 percent.
At the end of March, a total of 530 companies were listed On the TSE, but the statistics for the month only included 523 companies, according to the TSE.

Of the 530 listed companies, 10 were excluded because their statistics will not be available until the end of April. These companies are First Steamship, Evergreen Marine, Uniglory Marine, Sincere Navigation, U-Ming Marine, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp., China Airlines, ET Internet Technology Corp., Wan Hai Lines, and Taiwan Navigation.
An additional three technology firms that were listed for the first time this month were included in the statistics, bringing the total number of companies to 523.

The chemical engineering sector maintained the highest growth rate in profits among all sectors at 18.34 percent. Meanwhile, the growth rate among integrated enterprises dropped by 44.6 percent, marking the greatest drop in profits among listed companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION OF MATSU WORSHIPPERS LEAVES FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A delegation of 200 worshippers from Chaotien Temple in Peikang, southern Taiwan, left Wednesday for a six-day visit to Tianjing, mainland China, to attend the "Matsu Cultural Festival."

Chaotien Temple is dedicated to Matsu, the Chinese goddess of the sea. The temple's chairwoman, Tzeng Tsai Mei-tzuo, led the group, bearing statues of Matsu, to Tianjing to participate in the festival being held by Tianhou Temple, which is also dedicated to the Chinese goddess.

A statue of Matsu measuring three feet six inches high, as well as statues of Matsu's two mythological guardians -- Chien Li Yen, who has the ability to see for a thousand miles and Shun Feng Er, who can hear things from a thousand miles away -- are also being offered to the Tianhou Temple by the Chaotien delegation.
The group is also scheduled to visit Matsu temples in Meizhou and Quanzhou in Fujian Province before returning to Taiwan April 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT TO MAKE STOPOVER IN NEW YORK EN ROUTE TO LATIN AMERICA

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will make a stopover in New York May 21-22 en route to a five-leg visit to Latin America, government sources said Wednesday.

The layover will mark a breakthrough in substantive ROC-U.S. relations, according to diplomatic observers who pointed out that in the past, the United States only allowed the ROC president and vice president to make transit stops in West Coast cities such as Los Angeles and San Francisco.

The Presidential Office is scheduled to unveil Thursday the itinerary of Chen's second overseas trip since taking office in the ROC's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties last May.

Sources close to the Presidential Office said Chen is scheduled to leave Taipei May 21 for his five-country Central and South America visit aimed at shoring up the ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies in the region.
The tour will take Chen to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay and Honduras, the sources said, adding that the president is scheduled to end his visit June 3.

On his way home, the sources went on, Chen will make a stopover in Houston, Texas. Major Taiwanese groups in Texas are reportedly planning a variety of activities to welcome Chen. According to the sources, Chen will visit a museum and library dedicated to former U.S. President George Bush and the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) during his transit stay in Houston.

One of the major events on Chen's Latin American itinerary will be his attendance at a summit meeting between the top leaders of the ROC and its Central American allies, scheduled to open in El Salvador May 25.
During the summit meeting, Chen will exchange views with his Central American counterparts on the integration of Central American countries and major regional development programs.

Chen will also tour a new residential community built with the assistance of Taiwan's largest charity -- the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- after El Salvador was rattled by two devastating earthquakes early this year.

Chen's entourage will be composed of officials from the Presidential Office, the National Security Council, and agricultural and economics departments, as well as parliamentarians and business leaders.

Chen made his first overseas visit as ROC head of state last August, on a trip which took him to the Dominican Republic, Costa Rica and Nicaragua, as well as the African countries of The Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.
