The local currency opened Wednesday at 32.919 and was traded between 32.887 and 32.924.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$435.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN ASSIGNS NEW MOE, EPA OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Executive Yuan caucus confirmed Wednesday the appointment of two senior officials in the Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
A caucus official said Wu Tieh-hsiung has been appointed administrative vice minister of the MOE, while Chang Tzu-en has been appointed deputy administrator of the EPA.
Wu, 62, received his doctoral degree in educational psychology from State University of New York and previously served as a research assistant at the school.

Wu later became a professor at National Taiwan Normal University and served as chairman of the university's Department of Information Sciences before being appointed principal of the National Tainan Teachers College.
Chang, 50, received his masters degree in civil engineering from National Cheng Kung University and his doctorate in the same field from Japan's Tohoku University.

Chang is a former professor and chairman of National Cheng Kung University's Department of Environmental Engineering, a former dean of the College of Engineering of the same university and prior to his most recent assignment, served as deputy director of the Comprehensive Planning Bureau under the EPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF LABOR DISPUTES SETS NEW HIGH IN 2000

TEXT.P: The 8,000 labor disputes in Taiwan in 2000 represents a new high and involved 57,000 workers, according to statistics released recently by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

The two figures are 37 percent and 85.5 percent, respectively, higher than the 1999 levels, according to the DGBAS statistics. Meanwhile, nearly 5,000 factories were shut down for the whole of 2000, up 1,000 from the year-earlier level.

The tallies show that the number of jobless middle-aged and elderly workers was also on the rise, with the unemployment rate in these age groups growing from 7.8 percent in 1995 to 15.1 percent in 2000. In terms of educational backgrounds, the jobless rate of workers with junior high school education accounted for 30 percent of the total unemployed workers in 1995, a ratio that rose to 35 percent in 2000.

As a result of a plummeting demand for unskilled workers due to increased automation, DGBAS officials said that the number of unemployed grassroots laborers in the manufacturing sector increased by 10,000 to reach around 118,000 in 1999 on a year-to-year basis.
The officials predicted that the unemployment structure may worsen in the coming years with Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, fast-growing automation and an industry exodus.

A deteriorating job market since the fourth quarter of last year also had a negative impact on local employees, the officials added, noting that the average monthly salary of domestic workers was NT$42,000 (US$1,270) in 2000, a record low of 2.5 percent in terms of annual increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PART-TIME WORKERS GROWING: POLL

TEXT.P: The number of part-time workers on the domestic job market has grown to account for 5.9 percent of Taiwan's total workforce, according to the results of a recent survey by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

However, the ratio is still far lower than Japan's 24 percent or the 13 percent recorded in Europe and the United States, according to the poll, which discovered that only 12.4 percent of Taiwan enterprises have hired part-time workers and that only a slightly higher ratio of 12.6 percent of them are planning to do so in the coming year.

Attributing the leading reason behind the growth in part-time workers to an economic slowdown, the CLA noted that the moonlighting population has been steadily increasing and has spread from the labor sector to a wider range of areas such as office clerks and computer technicians.
The CLA also pointed out that the service sector has a greater interest in employing part-time workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY ONE ALLEGEDLY DANGEROUS U.S. DRUG MARKETED IN TAIWAN: DOH

TEXT.P: Only one of the seven U.S.-approved but allegedly dangerous pharmaceuticals has been marketed in Taiwan, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday.

"Of the seven unsafe prescription drugs mentioned in this year's Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative report, we have only approved the use of one of them in Taiwan," said Hu Yo-fu, director of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs.

"That drug is Propulsid, a prescription drug to treat gastro-esophageal reflux," Hu explained, adding that there has been no report of death confirmed to be linked to the drug here, as the DOH has adopted a stringent pharmaceutical security management system.

Hu said that as Propulsid is likely to cause arrhythmia, the DOH has required the supplier, Janssen-Cilag Co., to add a security warning on its packaging. "The DOH has also asked local physicians to exercise caution and prudence when prescribing the drug," he added.

Over the past two years, Hu said, the DOH had indeed received a report concerning harmful side effects suspected of having been caused by the use of Propulsid. "Nevertheless, there has been no convincing evidence proving a correlation between those side effects and the use of Propulsid," he noted.
Hu further pointed out that the Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative report, written by David Willman of the Los Angeles Times, contains an error.

"Propulsid has been marketed in the United States for more than 10 years, not just since 1993, as claimed by the American journalist," Hu said, adding that the drug was first marketed in Taiwan in 1991.

Other U.S.-approved unsafe prescription drugs mentioned by Willman included the digestive drug Lotronex, the weight-loss drug Redux, the antibiotic Raxar, the anti-hypertension drug Posicor, the painkiller Duract and the diabetes drug Rezulin. "None of those six drugs have never been marketed in Taiwan," Hu noted.
According to Willman's investigative report, the seven drugs could be linked to as many as 1,200 deaths in the United States over the years.

Hu urged local people not to go to the United States to purchase drugs that have not been legally marketed in Taiwan. He also advised local doctors to forget the "superstition" that American drugs are safer than Taiwan's own medicines.

DOC.HEADLINE: COALITION GOVERNMENT `INEVITABLE' AFTER YEAR-END ELECTION: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: A coalition government will be an "inevitable development" after Taiwan's year-end elections, scholars said in a seminar Wednesday.
The seminar on who should lead the coalition government was sponsored by the National Policy Foundation, an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) think tank.

The scholars said after the year-end legislative elections, no major political parties will garner more than half of the 220 seats in the legislature and that for the sake of political stability, the forming of a coalition government will be inevitable.
They also said that this coalition government should be led by the political parties that collect the largest number of seats in the Legislative Yuan.

Professor Kao Lang of National Taiwan University stressed that whether the opposition KMT, the People First Party and the New Party can cooperate will have a tremendous effect on the year-end election. If the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) does not want to become a minority government, it will also have to join forces with other political parties, Kao claimed.

The KMT, which was defeated by the DPP in the presidential election last year, is currently the dominant force in the Legislative Yuan. But the PFP, a party formed after former KMT heavyweight James Soong finished a close second in last year's presidential election, is trying to increase its legislative seats.

Wu Tung-yeh, a researcher at National Cheng Chi University, said that as a minority government, the DPP has ended up in an untenable political situation. For the long-term stability of the nation, he said, a coalition government will be inevitable if no party wins more than half of the seats.

Wu added that the DPP will want to make efforts to become the biggest political party in the election so as to take the lead in forming the Cabinet. But, he went on, if it fails to win half of the seats, it may still be able to operate as a minority government, making further chaotic political development unavoidable.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR SWIM MEET TO BE HELD IN KENTING

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee will hold a major swim meet next month at Kenting's South Bay in southern Taiwan, a committee spokesman said Wednesday.
The spokesman said that the three kilometer swim is aimed at promoting leisure activities, exercise and tourism activities in the southern beach resort.
The meet will take place May 27, mainly because the tide conditions will be gentle at that time, so that even if it is windy, it will still be perfectly safe for swimmers.
On the eve of the swim, the committee will also arrange a night gathering for the athletes so that they will be able to exchange their experiences.
A similar meet was held last year in Chengkung, Kenting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR CROSS-STRAIT RELIGIOUS SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he fully supports the proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait hold a religious summit to help boost mutual understanding and ensure permanent cross-strait peace.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with Bawa Jain, secretary-general of the U.N. Millennium World Religious and Spiritual Leaders Summit Meeting, and Dena Merriam, the summit's vice chairwoman.
Noting that religion can serve as an angel of peace, Chen said he is hopeful that spiritual faith can help build a "bridge of peace" between Taiwan and mainland China.
Chen said he fervently backs Bawa Jain's pitch for the holding of a cross-strait religious summit to forge rapprochement and lay a solid foundation of permanent peace in the region.
The president further said he is convinced that religions have infinite strength and can help "purify one's mind and heart."

"Religions should inspire political leaders of all countries around the world to promote economic prosperity, social progress and the well-being of mankind with compassion, sympathy and wisdom," Chen said.
Stressing that true peace can not tolerate war, Chen said tolerance, respect and forgiveness are needed to prevent war and safeguard peace.

"Only those who lack self-confidence would instigate a war or intimidate other people with bellicose rhetoric or live-fire military exercises," Chen said, adding he believes that anybody who has a compassionate heart will have no enemy and that anyone who has wisdom will feel no worry.
"And if everybody has mercy, compassion and wisdom, the world will be more harmonious, stable, and peaceful," Chen said.
In his talks, Chen also emphasized the importance of respecting biological, religious and cultural diversity.

"There should be no discrimination simply because of different religious beliefs, races, cultural backgrounds, languages or individual styles," Chen said, adding: "We should appreciate diversity which offers our world various possibilities."

For his part, Bawa Jain said religions can help increase mutual understanding and stamp out violence and armed conflicts. "This is why I have advocated the convening of a cross-strait religious summit to promote peace in the Taiwan Strait."

Bawa Jain noted that the U.N. Millennium World Religious and Spiritual Leaders Summit Meeting, held last year, passed a declaration renouncing the use of violence and military force. "The United Nations has endeavored to cash in on the strength of religions to promote world peace," he added.

Bawa Jain and Dena Merriam were among the attendees of a symposium on regional and world peace as well as environmentalism sponsored by the Taipei-based Buddhist Dhrama Drum Mountain Foundation, which is led by Master Sheng Yen.

All foreign and domestic participants to the seminar have signed a joint declaration on world peace. President Chen also signed the declaration during his meeting with Bawa Jain and Dena Merriam. Master Sheng Yen was also present at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CABINET RATIFIES TWO U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS TREATIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Executive Yuan ratified two U.N. human rights treaties Wednesday, 24 years after signing them while the nation was still a member of the United Nations.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said after his Cabinet ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights that the two treaties are the most representative U.N. resolutions on human rights.

Chang said that ROC President Chen Shui-bian has continually called on the Cabinet to urge the legislature to ratify the two treaties, which will serve as the formal legal basis of human rights in Taiwan.
Therefore, he added, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs should communicate with lawmakers to seek legislative ratification and acquire the final presidential signature.

However, as to depositing the instrument of ratification with the U.N. secretary-general to complete the process, Chang said that this may present a problem because the Republic of China is no longer a U.N. member.
He added that he will still ask the Foreign Ministry to handle the matter in a committed manner in order to demonstrate the government's determination to promote the protection of human rights.
Under normal circumstances, the covenants come into force for the state party that ratified them three months after the date of deposit.

Government spokesman Su Cheng-ping explained that the ROC government did not complete the domestic process of ratification after signing the two treaties in 1967 because of the sea change in international affairs that led to the 1971 transfer of the ROC seat in the United Nations to mainland China.
Ratifying these treaties now serves to act in coordination with the president's call for the nation to become a part of the international human rights community.

The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights recognizes the basic right of all individuals in the world to freedom, justice and peace. It condemns slavery, genocide, torture, cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment, and capital punishment for pregnant women or persons below eighteen years of age.
A total of 147 states have ratified the treaty.

The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights recognizes that all peoples have the right to freely determine their political status and freely pursue their economic, social and cultural development. The treaty, ratified by 144 nations, also recognizes the right to establish trade unions and go on strike.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO ENCOURAGE INVESTMENT IN ASEAN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the government will encourage Taiwan businessmen to invest in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

The president made the remarks when he received Taiwanese businessmen operating in the Philippines and Thailand. Investment in ASEAN nations should replace the previous administration's "southern strategy," Chen said.
During the meeting, the president also reaffirmed his determination to build Taiwan into a green silicon island and to brace for the coming of the new era of the knowledge economy.

He also said that the government will continue to assist domestic manufacturers to invest overseas. Taiwan's ample capital, superb technology and marketing experience can help it join forces with Southeast Asia, which has abundant natural resources and cheap human resources, so as to work to promote prosperity and progress in Asia on the basis of mutual reciprocity, he said.

He said that he has confidence in this land and in its 23 million people. Though the society may seem chaotic at times, the people have remained calm, demonstrating the historical significance of the political changeover and democracy.

The president also lauded Taiwan businessmen as being in the vanguard of foreign trade, and expressed the hope that the Taiwan businessmen will be able to pool together to fight for the survival and development of the nation.

The president said the everlasting development of trade is Taiwan's lifeline, adding that the island has flourished on its economy and trade. This is the reason that he recently advocated the "three priorities," meaning that the economy, investment and Taiwan will be priorities, he said.
ASEAN members include Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei, Vietnam, Laos, Burma and Cambodia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND INVESTMENT APPLICATIONS BY TWO HIGH-TECH FIRMS OK'd

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) finally made a decision Wednesday to allow two high-tech firms to realize their investment plans in mainland China.

The MOEA's Investment Commission said that it gave its approval to the investment applications of Asustek Computer Inc. and VIA Technologies following a detailed perusal of their investment purpose and capital use.

According to the commission, Asustek's application to remit US$25 million was a capital increment for a facility in Suzhou, while VIA's US$12.78 million capital remittance was aimed at setting up a retail shopping mall in the mainland.

Vice Minister Chen Ruei-long said the move was only a part of the MOEA's normal screening process for investment projects bound for both mainland China and other countries. He noted that the screening move does not mean that the government has made any changes in its mainland investment policy.

The approval of the two applications, filed in late March, has been viewed by the local business community as a benchmark index for gauging whether the government will further tighten its reserved mainland investment policy.

The possible tightening move follows a rumor that mainland China will close a Zhengjiang plant run by Tainan-based Chi Mei Corporation in response to its chairman's support for a Japanese comic book that whitewashed Japan's colonial rule in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WALL STREET FUND MANAGER BULLISH ON MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A Wall Street investment guru has predicted that the 21st century will be "mainland China's century," and that Shanghai will be the No.1 city in Asia in 10 years.
In a recent interview with the English-language Asiaweek, Jim Rogers, co-founder with George Soros of the multi-billion Quantum Fund, said mainland China is "the place to be."
"The 21st century will not be Asia's century, but China's century," an advance copy of the magazine released Wednesday quoted Rogers as saying.
Regarding the future of Hong Kong, he reportedly said: "I don't think China will need Hong Kong once Shanghai gets going."
According to the report, Rogers is bullish on the mainland. He agreed that there are "great things happening in India, but in very small pockets."
"Compared to China, where great things are happening all across the country, in India you can't get (a lot of things) even if you're willing to pay for them," he was quoted as saying.
Rogers also predicted that in 10 years there will be two great cities in Asia -- Shanghai and Singapore. The rest of Asia's cities, including Hong Kong, will be second-tier, he forecast.

"I don't think Hong Kong will be up there ... putting money in Hong Kong property is a waste of time. Hong Kong likes to think that China needs it for its people. There are plenty of smart Chinese in Shanghai and given time, they will outsmart people in Hong Kong," he was further quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY HOLDS 2ND PREVIEW FOR 'HANKUANG NO. 17' EXERCISE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China military conducted a second preview Wednesday for the "Hankuang No. 17" live-fire combined services training exercise in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung.

It was also the last preview for the annual massive-scale Hankuang training drill, scheduled to be held Saturday at the military's Haiko training field in Hengchun, Pingtung. The first preview took place Monday, with Army Commander-in-Chief Chen Chen-hsiang presiding.
Military sources said this year's Hankuang exercise will focus on testing the performance and effectiveness of the ROC's new generation weaponry systems for land, naval and airborne defense.
The military invited civilian officials and social celebrities in the Pingtung area to witness Wednesday's preview.

The powerful "Thunder 2000" multiple rocket launching system (MRLS), developed by the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST), the military's research arm, also made its debut in the preview.

The "Thunder 2000" MRLS is expected to help beef up the military's anti-landing combat capabilities. It can prevent invading troops from operating in waters up to 28 kilometers off the Taiwan coast, military sources said.

Many other newly acquired military hardware, including the Avenger air-defense missiles, shoulder-fired Stinger missiles and the CIST-developed Tienkung (Sky Bow) missiles will also be test-fired in Saturday's Hankuang exercise.
The Hankuang No. 17 exercise covers two stages -- cyberwar games and live-fire combined services drills. The cyberwar games were held in Taipei early this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN-BOUND TOURISM UNAFFECTED BY ROW OVER COMIC BOOK

TEXT.P: The number of tourists bound for Japan has remained unaffected by a recent spat in Taiwan society caused by a Japanese comic book that whitewashed Japan's colonial rule over the island, a local tourism industry association said Wednesday.
The Kaohsiung Travel Industry Association said domestic operators of package tours to Japan have not experienced much change since the controversy over the book "On Taiwan" broke out in early March.

An official of the association noted that politics have never had much impact on tourism between the two countries, and that the Japanese authorities have not been particularly picky about handing out visas to Taiwan tourists in the wake of the controversy.

However, a tourism agency based in this southern port city pointed out that the number of package tours heading to Japan has fallen by 10-20 percent since April, while business was quite good before March.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES U.S. WILL SELL DEFENSIVE WEAPONS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung expressed the hope Wednesday that the United States will help the Republic of China obtain defensive weapons and maneuvering space in the international community.
The premier made the remarks when he received visiting U.S. Representatives Roscoe Bartlett (R-MD), and Bob Shaffer (R-COLO).

Chang said that both the ROC and the United States hope to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait. He added that as peace has to be built on cross-strait equilibrium, He added that therefore, it is vital that the ROC obtains defensive weapons and maneuvering space in the international community to maintain a cross-strait balance.

The premier expressed the hope that the two representatives will exert their influence in Congress to help the ROC obtain defensive weapons and maneuvering space in the international community so as to maintain the cross-strait equilibrium and peace.
The premier also said that the United States is a pluralistic society, which he said makes it more flexible and less vulnerable to making mistakes.

Chang also extended his best wishes for the 24 returned crew members of a U.S. surveillance plane that landed on Hainan island in southern mainland after a mid-air collision with a mainland fighter April 1. The crew were returned last week.
Chang urged the two representatives to have more contacts with local people during their stay here.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND MAINLAND FREIGHTER MAKES DIRECT SAILING TO KINMEN

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese freighter sailed directly from the southeastern mainland province of Fujian to the Republic of China-held frontline island of Kinmen Wednesday, marking yet another breakthrough in the "mini three links" program.
The 198-ton mainland cargo ship transported 300 tons of gravel to Kinmen, which was ordered by a local construction firm.

It was the second mainland freighter to make a direct voyage to Kinmen since Taiwan opened its two offshore defense outposts -- Kinmen and Matsu -- for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links," at the beginning of this year.
On March 31, a Guangdong province-registered freighter, with 400 cubic meters of granite chips on board, made its maiden direct voyage to Kinmen.

With previous experience in handling customs clearance, Kinmen harbor officials and customs inspection officers operated all relevant affairs smoothly when the second mainland freighter arrived Wednesday.

Several Kinmen county officials and councilors turned up at the Liaolo port to welcome the arrival of the mainland cargo ship. Councilor Hsieh I-chang said as gravel from mainland China is 30 percent cheaper than Taiwan's, direct gravel import from the mainland will be a boon to Kinmen's infrastructure construction.
Hsieh said he is hopeful that other mainland construction materials and consumer products can also be shipped directly to Kinmen to make the "mini three links" program really take off.

Mainland China has been reluctant to take active steps to facilitate the Taiwan-proposed "mini three links" program. It now still approves applications for direct voyages by either passenger ships or freighters on a case-by-case basis.
"We hope mainland China can allow direct shipping services between our two offshore defense outposts and Fujian province on a regular basis in the near future," Hsieh added.
So far, Kinmen ships have made some 10 direct voyages to the mainland, carrying groups of Kinmen residents to the mainland for sightseeing trips or visiting relatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC SUSPENDS CONSTRUCTION OF NEW 12-INCH WAFER PLANT

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) President Tseng Fan-cheng said Wednesday that the construction of his company's 15th wafer fabrication plant will be put on hold indefinitely as a result of the sluggish economy.

Tseng likened the semiconductor manufacturing industry's inability to predict when market conditions will rebound to "a walk in the mists." He added that the recent industry-wide economic gloom has had far-reaching effects, but his company has no plans to lay off workers.

Tseng said that there is a global oversupply of many electronics products, and that many downstream clients are apprehensive of placing new orders. This signifies a lack of consumer confidence, he continued, adding that many companies made errors of judgment when the economy was hot, leading to overproduction.
He went on to say that although only about half of his company's production capacity will be used in the next few months, TSMC is unlikely to run into the red during this quarter at least.

He said that the 14th TSMC 12-inch wafer plant will continue construction as scheduled because it will take seven to eight months to complete it, and that "it may be too late" if the company were to shelve the construction until the economy picks up.
However, despite having already held a groundbreaking ceremony for the 15th plant, the company is putting its construction on hold.

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDERED EX-NAVY CAPTAIN GAINS POSTHUMOUS HONOR
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, April 18 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng received a posthumous honor Wednesday, with the Navy Headquarters conferring the Order of the Cloud and Banner of the sixth class on him in recognition of his contribution to the innovation of the ROC Navy's warships during his military service.
The conferring ceremony was held at the home of Yin's father Yin Dwo, who received the order on behalf of his son from Rear Adm. Lei Kuang-shu, Navy deputy chief of staff.
Yin was murdered in December 1993 in a crime that is generally believed to have been connected with his attempts to collect information to blow the whistle on a Navy procurement scandal.

Yin Dwo said that although this justice comes late, the conferring of the order is an affirmation of Yin's attempts to maintain the national interests during his lifetime. He added that he hopes the justice authorities can solve the case as quickly as possible.

Commenting on the possibility of posthumously promoting Yin to the rank of rear admiral, which has been requested by Yin's family, a ranking Ministry of National Defense official said the ministry's office in charge of armed forces personnel affairs is now actively studying its feasibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE P.M. CANDIDATES SUPPORT ISSUING VISA TO EX-ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 18 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Three of the four candidates running for prime minister in Japan said Wednesday that they support granting a visa to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui for humanitarian reasons.

Junichiro Koizumi, a former health minister, said at a joint press conference with the other candidates that Lee's visa application should be approved on both humanitarian and health grounds. He had earlier expressed reservations, saying that the issue should be resolved after considering the overall three-way ties between Beijing, Taipei and Tokyo.

Shizuka Kamei, chairman of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's policy research council, said that Lee "of course" should be allowed to visit Japan. He had suggested a few days earlier that Foreign Minister Yohei Kono and Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda be removed for their opposition to granting Lee a visa.

Meanwhile, Economics Minister Taro Aso, who is also running for prime minister candidate, said that as the owner of a hospital, he understands that the kind of surgery Lee needs is not simple. He added that the hospital Lee hopes to visit indeed has the best equipment, and that he believes the former president of the Republic of China should be allowed to visit Japan from a humanitarian standpoint.

The only candidate who expressed reservations was former prime minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who said that he has already pointed out on many occasions that the issue should not be overly politicized. Now that the issue has become too complicated, it will not be easy to resolve, he added.

Lee, who complained of chest pains after a trip to the Czech Republic last October and underwent successful coronary angioplasty surgery in Taiwan in November, plans to visit Japan for continued treatment by the same Japanese doctor who oversaw his operation.
However, the Japanese government, which has come under pressure from Beijing to deny Lee's application, has yet to announce its decision.

ROC Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said that Lee's reason for wanting to visit Japan is very simple, and that she hopes Japan will quickly make a positive decision out of a humanitarian spirit.

Chang was responding to incumbent Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori's statement earlier in the day at a press conference to announce his resignation that a decision on the issue will be made from a humanitarian standpoint together with other "international circumstantial considerations."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$1.52 MILLION LOTTERY TO BE STARTED NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Want to win NT$50 million (US$1.52 million) overnight? With the establishment of Taiwan's new lottery, you'll have the chance to be a millionaire starting next year.

Taipei Bank, which was chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to issue both traditional and computerized lottery tickets, announced Wednesday that it will start to administer three types of charity lotteries starting Jan. 20, 2002.

Liao Cheng-Ching, chairman of Taipei Bank, said that the three types of lotteries -- traditional, instant and computerized charity lotteries -- will offer winning rates of between 5 and 15 percent, 10 and 33 percent, and 1 and 5 percent, respectively.

Liao said that the traditional lotteries will only be run on special occasions six times a year, with the ticket sales period between one and two months. This type of lottery will target more conservative patrons who buy the lottery tickets out of nostalgia or the desire to win a fortune. One traditional lottery ticket will cost NT$100 (US$3), and the biggest prize will be 200,000 times that.

The instant lottery will be a new game with the sales period between two and three months. This lottery, 15 issues a year, will target patrons motivated by fun or curiosity, and tickets will cost NT$50, NT$100 and NT$150. The biggest prize will be 50,000 times the ticket's face value.

The computerized charity lotteries will be held two times per week, with 104 issues through the year and a ticket sales period of between three and seven days. Targeting speculative patrons who want to get rich overnight, the lottery's tickets will cost NT$50 and NT$100. The grand prize will be set at 500,000 times the ticket's face value.

Liao also announced the establishment of a lottery charity foundation that will channel 35 percent of net lottery profits to charities, so as to step up the caring for elderly and less privileged groups, provide support for youth, and nurture elite athletes.
He also said that the bank will set up a service center for less privileged groups to help them apply for lottery operation licenses.

Under the management of Taipei Bank, the lottery is expected to add more than NT$39 billion in tax revenues to the nation's coffers, as well as to help certain industrial sectors and the domestic employment market.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO VISIT CORNELL UNIVERSITY MAY 2-4
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 18 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Cornell University announced Wednesday that former President of the Republic of China Lee Teng-hui will make a private visit to his alma mater May 2-4.

Cornell said that Lee will visit his granddaughter, who is currently studying at the school, and announce the establishment of the Lee Teng-hui Institute for scientific research. Lee is not expected to make any public speeches or other activities during his stay there.
This will be Lee's second visit to his alma mater since he received his Ph.D. degree in agricultural economics in 1968.
Lee last visited Cornell while serving as ROC president in June 1995, during which he made a resounding speech titled "Always in My Heart."

Cornell said that the Lee Teng-hui Institute for scientific research will be housed in the US$62.5 million Duffield Hall. Several Taiwan companies have made generous donations, but Cornell would not divulge the exact figures until Lee's arrival.
Cornell earlier set up a Lee Teng-hui Professorship of World Affairs to pay tribute to Lee's outstanding achievements after his supporters in Taiwan donated US$2.5 million to the university in 1994.
Construction on Duffield Hall will start in late May and is expected to be completed in 2003.

David Duffield, founder of computer software PeopleSoft and another Cornell alumnus, donated US$20 million to his alma mater, so the building for nanotechnology research was named after him. Earlier reports that the former ROC president would preside over the groundbreaking ceremony of the building were unfounded.
Some 124 Taiwan students are now registered at Cornell University.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITA DIRECTOR GENERAL VISITS KINMEN

TEXT.P: Ranjit Gupta, director general of the India-Taipei Association (ITA), arrived at Kinmen Wednesday with his wife for a two-day private visit to the Republic of China's frontline island.

The Guptas called on Kinmen Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai immediately after their arrival on the island to gain a better understanding of the "mini three links" between Kinmen and the mainland Chinese city of Xiamen.

The so-called "mini three links" refer to direct transport, trade and postal connections between Kinmen and Xiamen, as well as between Matzu, another ROC frontline island, and the mainland Chinese city of Mawei.

On the development of the cross-strait "mini three links," Gupta said that seeking peaceful coexistence is now a world trend. He praised Taiwan's efforts in pushing for the implementation of the "mini three links," which started on Jan. 1, 2001.
Gupta said that the "one China" dispute should be solved through negotiations between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Beijing has until now shown a lukewarm attitude toward Taiwan's unilateral implementation of the "mini three links." Officials there now say that as Taiwan claims "one China" can only a topic on the agenda of cross-strait talks, the "mini three links" are local in nature and exchanges need to be ratified on a case-by-case basis.
Beijing insists that "one China" be considered the principle for cross-strait talks.
Accompanied by Kinmen County Government officials, the Guptas also toured some scenic spots in Kinmen, including a battlefield at Kuningtou, on the first day of their visit there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Caught between warning from mainland China and pressure from Taiwan, Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori sidesteps announcing decision on former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visa application.
The China Times:
Unexpected Fed interest rate cut sparks a strong rally on U.S. stock exchanges.
The United Daily News:
U.S. stocks skyrocket on latest Fed rate cut.
The Liberty Times:
On humanitarian grounds, Japan should grant Lee a visa, says Mori.
The China Post:
PM Mori says he will decide on Lee's visa as soon as possible.
The Taiwan News:
Tainan mayor detained over land deal.
The Taipei Times:
Tokyo cowers under Beijing pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 19, or the 26th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel Laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species," and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the China's first president under the new Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro-democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan-zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The SS Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing an historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 year.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and technological cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (WJIB) transform itself into a "Nationa Bureau of Investigation (NBI)."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO WELCOME DIRECTOR ANG LEE'S RETURN

TEXT.P: The director of the Oscar-winning film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" will make a return trip to Taiwan on April 22, and President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to visit him in their southern Taiwan hometown of Tainan.

Ang Lee is not only expected to receive a warm welcome from the president, but he will also attend a reward ceremony held by the Government Information Office (GIO) under the Executive Yuan to honor his achievement.

Garnering four Oscars, which are those for Best Foreign-Language Film, Cinematography, Art Direction and Original Song, the Chinese martial arts masterpiece proudly represents a new page in the Taiwan movie industry's development as well as in Lee's career.
Lee will attend a press conference scheduled to take place upon his arrival before he heads to Tainan to meet with his family.

President Chen, who graduated from the same high school as Lee, will pay a courtesy visit to Lee's father, who was the former principal of the school. The president will also meet with the director to congratulate him on his accomplishment in the movie industry.

Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan will present Lee with a medal April 25, recognizing his achievement. The GIO will also host a ceremony for Lee at the Grand Hyatt Taipei to present him and the Oscar-winning film's production company with a NT$4 million (US$125,000) reward.
Lee is scheduled to leave for Hong Kong April 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG FOLLOWERS DISAPPOINTED AT U.N. COMMISSION'S DECISION

TEXT.P: The Falun Gong spiritual movement expressed disappointment Wednesday over the U.N. Commission on Human Rights' decision not to discuss a U.S.-sponsored proposal to condemn Communist China's human rights record.

"It is a shame that some countries have turned a blind eye to China's horrible abuses," Falun Gong's overseas practitioners said in a statement which warned Communist Chinese President Jiang Zemin not to take this vote as a license to kill.

Tens of millions of followers of Falun Gong and other spiritual groups have been stripped of their basic rights, often illegally arrested, beaten, tortured, and even raped, according to the statement.
It noted that after China escaped censure by the same United Nations forum last year, the crackdown on Falun Gong escalated drastically, with killings increasing from 11 in 1999 to 193 in 2000.
During this year's U.N. human rights commission session in Geneva, the statement pointed out, at least 15 Falun Gong practitioners have been murdered while in custody in mainland China.
"There is no excuse for killing and brutalizing peace-loving citizens," it added.

"There is nothing China's leadership fears more than the world learning of its crimes, and, the vote aside, this is what has happened here in Geneva," said Erping Zhang from Geneva. He and Cindy Gu were in the Swiss city to monitor the U.N. commission meeting.

In the statement, they quoted Martin Luther King Jr., who in 1963 said that "we will have to repent in this generation not merely for the hateful words and actions of the bad people, but also for the appalling silence of the good people."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 99.89 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 99.89 points to close at 5,608.5.
Market turnover amounted to NT$128.05 billion (US$3.9 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUSIC STUDENTS IN EUROPE PERFORM IN HAMBURG
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 19 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: Over 40 Taiwan students studying music in different European cities have been performing together as a symphony orchestra at Hamburg's national theater since April 11, earning applause and affirmation from Hamburg's music circles.

With the help from the Republic of China representative office in Hamburg and also from overseas Chinese residing in the city, the Taiwan students studying in London, Paris, and several German cities came together in Hamburg last Wednesday for trainnings and performances.
The theater's choir director, Juergen Schultz, said he was amazed by the Taiwan students' deep-rooted music skills and their ability to pick up music pieces in a short period of time.
The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Education have jointly provided financial support for the young musicians for their 10-day stay in Hamburg.
The Taiwan students' symphony orchestra performance on April 15 was aired on Hamburg's famous music radio program Sonntakte.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINTAINING 5% GROWTH THIS YEAR A TOUGH TASK: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Thursday that it will be a tough task to try to maintain a five percent economic growth rate this year.
Lin made the remarks while fielding questions during a joint meeting of the budget and economic committees at the Legislative Yuan.

Lin said that the domestic economy has been sluggish over the past six months. As the economic growth rate in the United States, the major export destination of Taiwan products, is expected to be only 1.2 percent this year, with some predicting it to be as low as zero percent, the task of maintaining a five percent growth rate for Taiwan's economy will be a difficult one, he said.

In responding to an interpellation by Legislator Kuo Su-chun of the major opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Lin said the type of Taiwan businesses heading to mainland China to set up shop have shifted from those from traditional industries to those in high-tech industries, and from small- and medium-sized enterprises to large-scale enterprises. The nation needs to closely monitor the source of the capital and its outflow, he added.

Legislator Liu Sheng-liang of the KMT said that foreign investors have been deterred from coming to Taiwan because of the nation's wavering economic policy, citing the examples of Bayer's canceling of its plan to invest in Taiwan, the controversy surrounding the suspension of construction of the fourth nuclear power plant, and the suspension of a proposed reservoir project in southern Taiwan.

The most urgent task now, Lin said, is to improve the local investment environment, including land, capital, talent and tax incentives, adding that to do this will require cooperation from local governments.
Taiwan's tax incentives are not particularly "generous" or "competitive" in comparison with other countries, he noted.

He also said that since the five-day workweek was put into practice this year, some 12 percent of Taiwan's manufacturers have said that they would cut production, while some 21 percent have said that they will try to shift overseas, thereby demonstrating that the government needs to improve Taiwan's investment environment.

Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party also said that the economic minister can be considered the chairman of the nation's enterprise chairmen, and he asked whether the minister will take the lead in luring more foreign investment to the island.

Lin said that Industrial Development Bureau Director General Shih Yen-hsiang is currently visiting Japan to woo investors, and he would like to join Shih for the efforts when the talk comes to a crucial stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 99.89 points to close at 5,608.5.

Encouraged by a surge in U.S. stock prices after a surprise rate cut by the Fed, the bourse opened at 5,682.46, but it began to go down later due to profit-taking selling pressure. The index fluctuated between 5,683.63 and 5,602.79 during trading.

A total of 3.04 billion stocks worth NT$128.05 billion (US$3.9 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.91 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$75.24 billion (US$1.37 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by construction shares at 0.6 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent. Plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 2.5 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.5 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.3 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 292 to 202, with 101 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May moved up 89 points to close at 5,628, with 8,593 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June rose 39 points to finish at 5,625, with 20 contract transactions, while September futures increased 39 points to close at 5,670, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,539 for May, 5,586 for June, 5,631 for September, 5,607 for December, and 5,686 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
May TE futures rose 6.3 points to finish at 286.3, with 2,316 contract transactions, while June TE futures moved up 6.3 points to close at 286.3, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures increased 13 points to finish at 729, with 736 contract transactions, while June TF futures rose 47.6 points to close at 730, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO TRAVEL TO U.S. FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT TALKS

TEXT.P: A Republic of China military delegation will head to the United States Friday for talks with their U.S. counterparts on the ROC's weaponry procurement plans for 2001, military sources said Thursday.
The annual ROC-U.S. arms procurement meeting is scheduled to open April 24 in suburban Washington, D.C.

The ROC delegation will be headed by Vice Chief of the General Staff Gen. Hou Shou-yeh, and its members will include Chen Lan-chun, director of the Procurement Bureau of the Ministry of National Defense (MND), and officials from the General Staff Headquarters.
MND sources said the delegation has made full preparations for the upcoming meeting.
"We have carefully evaluated our defense needs and the weaponry items that the United States may agree to sell," said an MND official who preferred anonymity.
He said the military has also completed a detailed budget planning report in connection with this year's arms procurement project.
"The delegation will brief American negotiators on our shopping list and relevant budget planning," the official explained.
The U.S. government is now reviewing Taiwan's arms shopping list and will make a decision on it after discussion with the ROC delegation.
Judging from recent statements and actions taken by senior military officials, the advanced Aegis radar system-equipped Arleigh Burke-class destroyers remain at the top of the ROC's shopping package.

Nevertheless, senior military officials said they generally don't think that the U.S. government is likely to approve the sale to Taiwan of the Arleigh Burke-class destroyers this year. They said the Bush administration may instead agree to sell Taiwan the cutting-edge Aegis battle management radar system first and then sell the destroyers in the future.

As mainland China strongly opposes U.S. sales of Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan, military officials said it would be a nice alternative if the United States agrees to sell Taiwan the Aegis anti-aircraft and anti-missile radar system first and negotiate sales of destroyers to bear the Aegis system in the future.

In addition, MND sources said, the United States may take the initiative to suggest that Taiwan purchase four Kidd-class destroyers to upgrade its Navy's long-distance combat capability before purchasing the more advanced Arleigh Burke-class vessels.

As for the P3C anti-submarine aircraft, the sources said, the Bush administration may agree to sell Taiwan this type of warplane. Nevertheless, the ROC Navy's procurement principle is that the Aegis-equipped destroyers and P3C anti-submarine aircraft should be purchased simultaneously because they are designed to complement each other.

Meanwhile, military observers said if the United States rejects Taiwan's request to purchase the Aegis-equipped destroyers, it is likely to sell Taiwan diesel submarines, weapons that the island has long desired to buy.

Military experts said there may be one or two breakthroughs in the upcoming arms procurement talks. But they stressed that during the course of negotiations, the United States certainly will give the top priority to its own national interests.

Of course, the experts added, the United States will also take into account Taiwan's actual defense needs. And the general atmosphere of the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular ties is also expected to influence the results of the talks, they added.
