DOC.HEADLINE: EX-ROC PREMIER TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA TO PITCH FOR 'COMMON MARKET'

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said Thursday he will file an application with the government in the next few days for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.

Siew, also a vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said he tentatively plans to visit the mainland from May 8-15 in his capacity as chairman of the newly founded Cross-Strait Common Market Foundation. Siew will be accompanied by the foundation's directors and supervisors on his mainland visit.

In accordance with current ROC regulations, Siew must apply for a government approval of his mainland visit because he once served as a high-ranking political appointee with access to national security affairs.
Siew said he most likes to meet with relevant mainland Chinese scholars or think tanks to discuss his idea of forming a European Union-style cross-strait common market during his mainland visit.

Asked whether he will meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji, Siew declined to make any comment. He just said the itinerary of his planned mainland visit has yet to be finalized.
Earlier in the day, Siew explained in detail his cross-strait common market proposal at a seminar on mainland China-bound investment and protection of Taiwan investors.
Siew pointed out that the formation of a cross-strait common market can facilitate integration of Taiwan and mainland China under the current trends of globalization and regional cooperation.

"The establishment of a cross-strait common market is also expected to help ease tensions in the Taiwan Strait and open up a new era of cross-strait peaceful co-existence and development," Siew noted.

He went on to say that his cross-strait common market overture emphasizes the EU spirit. "I think that the EU development model of moving from economic integration to political integration can provide a lot of inspiration for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in developing a cross-strait common market."
In his view, Siew said, the foundation for promoting a cross-strait common market lies in the exclusion of political considerations.
Therefore, Siew said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should uphold their "1992 consensus," which allows both sides to "agree to disagree" on the definition of "one China."

Siew further said confidently that if the proposed cross-strait common market can be developed successfully, it will contribute much to regional economic development and stability and even bring new growth vitality to the global economy.

In addition to helping resolve their decades-old political and economic conflicts, Siew said, the formation of a cross-strait common market will also allow the two sides to move from economic integration to political integration and enable their people to enjoy prosperity and sustainable development.

Noting that the proposed cross-strait common market mechanism should be forged gradually, Siew said the two sides should promote normalization of bilateral trade and economic relations in the first stage.

In the second phase, Siew said, the two sides should form a "free trade zone" by harmonizing their economic systems. "In the third stage, the two sides should form a customs alliance, and in the fourth phase, they should complete all-out economic integration to realize the goal of cross-strait common market," he explained.
Siew urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to forge an official consultative mechanism and adopt confidence-building measures to accelerate normalization of cross-strait trade and economic ties.

Siew alo called for forward-looking adjustments of Taiwan's current "go slow, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment and the lifting of bans on direct trade, mail and transport links in line with the general new market trends.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN REPORTEDLY TO DECIDE WHETHER TO ISSUE VISA SOON

TEXT.P: Whether former President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China will get a visa to enter Japan is still not clear, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Thursday.
Chang said that the Republic of China is still waiting for the final word from Japan, and she expressed the hope that Japan will make its decision soon.

Reports from Japan said that after days of debate and deliberation, Japan's policy is that it will issue the visa in one or two days as long as the former ROC head agrees that he will only travel to the hospital in Okayama prefecture in central Japan for medical treatment for his heart problem and will not engage in any political activities.
Reports also said that Japan is now trying to learn whether Lee is willing to agree to such conditions.
Su Chih-cheng, Lee's former personal secretary, would not speculate on the possibility of Lee's visit to Japan.
Su said Japan might not submit conditions to Lee, noting that the former ROC president had categorically said that he would not sneak into Japan and would not sign any conditional papers.

Japanese media reporters had asked Lee earlier whether he would use Japan's policy that allows a 72-hour period of entry without a visa for ROC nationals to seek medical treatment. Lee responded by saying unequivocally that he will travel to Japan in an open manner as the former ROC head, and will not sneak into Japan.

According to friends arranging Lee's visit to Japan, the Japanese government has to issue the visa by Friday at the latest. Otherwise, it will be too late for Lee to visit Sunday, and the whole trip will have to be rearranged, they added.

Meanwhile, although Cornell University in upstate New York has announced that Lee will visit his alma mater May 2-4, Lee's aides would not comment on whether Japan's delayed issue of a visa will affect Lee's trip to the United States.
In related developments, several Taiwanese legislators suggested cross-party cooperation to revise the law so as to allow Japanese doctors to come to Taiwan to treat Lee.

Legislator Liu Kuang-hua of the opposition Kuomintang said that in case Japan denies the visa to Lee, one way to solve the problem would be to suggest that the Department of Health revise the law to allow in foreign doctors to treat local patients on a case-by-case basis. The other way would be to revise the regulations to allow the Japanese doctor treating Lee to Taiwan to provide treatment.

Liu also said that the Japanese doctor will be able to come to Taiwan as long as his suggestion is supported by all parties, passed in the Legislative Yuan, and signed into law by President Chen Shui-bian within one week.

Legislator Huang Yi-chiao of the opposition People First Party noted that under the current situation, all former ROC presidents, no matter what their party affiliations, have found themselves "confined" to Taiwan.
As other countries may excel in other medical fields, there is a need to revise the law so as not to compromise the health of the former presidents, Huang said.

Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the New Party said that he has confidence in Taiwan's medical care system, but the revision of the law would provide another choice for people more confident in the medical standards of other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES OFFICIALS TO INCREASE JOB OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said in a breakfast meeting Thursday that all officials should make their strongest effort to improve Taiwan's economic development and employment rate, even though the task is difficult in this period of global economic sluggishness.

Several government officials, including Vice Premier Lai In-jaw and Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, attended the 70-minute breakfast meeting held in the president's official residence to brief them on the government's attempts to increase employment opportunities and boost public investment.

Other officials attending the meeting were Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development; Chen Chui, chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs; Lin Hsin-yi, minister of economic affairs; Yeh Chu-lan, minister of transportation and communications; Chen Hsi-huang, chairman of the Council of Agriculture; and Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the President.

Chen Po-chih said that in order to raise Taiwan's employment rate, it is important to create job opportunities and woo investment, adding that the Council for Economic Planning and Development has made these two points its focus in promoting an economic revival.

The officials added that the government expects to create 100,000 more job opportunities through its expansion of public investment and its move to reserve jobs usually filled by foreign workers for Taiwan residents.

Meanwhile, the government has worked to improve the investment environment, bolster traditional industries and businesses, and host international business fairs in a bid to trigger growth in private investment and consumption, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARLIAMENTARY REFORM BILLS TO BE PASSED BY OCTOBER: DPP HEAVYWEIGHT

TEXT.P: Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday he will push for revisions of current laws to ensure smoother parliamentary operations.

Shen, also chief executive of the DPP's central policy coordination commission, said he has reached a consensus with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on revising the existing parliamentary organization law and the legislative power enforcement law to upgrade the parliament's operational efficiency and image.
Shen said current parliamentary operational laws contain many unreasonable and outdated rules that have hindered smooth operations of the country's legislative assembly.

For instance, Shen said that under current regulations, a single legislator can veto a decision to include a bill into the agenda for the legislature's plenary sessions or meetings of its standing committees. In addition, it needs only five lawmakers to form a subgroup in the legislature.

Shen said he has twice met with Wang to discuss the issue. "Wang has promised to ask the Legislative Yuan's legal affairs bureau to draft relevant revision bills," he said, adding that the DPP legislative caucus is also integrating various reform proposals and will work together with the legal affairs bureau and legislative caucuses of other political parties to come up with final versions of revision bills to existing laws.
Shen said he is confident that the legislature will be able to pass relevant revision bills before the next parliamentary session ends at the end of October.
If all goes smoothly, Shen said, the new Legislative Yuan, to be elected late this year, will operate more smoothly and efficiently.

Shen also stressed the importance of the functions of political parties in ensuring smooth parliamentary operations, claiming that independent lawmakers are often "the sources of disorder or chaos" in the parliament.

Commenting on a proposal by a DPP subgroup in the parliament that the number of parliamentary seats be halved, Shen said it takes time to complete necessary constitutional amendments to implement such a proposal.

"I don't think we have enough time left this year to push for the passage of a constitutional amendment to pave the way for halving the number of parliamentary seats," Shen noted, adding that it will take at least four years to complete legal preparations for implementing such a reform proposal that will have profound impact on the domestic political operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO U. S. HIT 24-MONTH LOW IN FEBRUARY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan exports to the United States sank to a 24-month low of US$2.56 billion in February, down 11.1 percent, or US$320 million, from the same month in 2000, according to the latest statistics released by the U.S. Department of Commerce.

The figure represents a fall of four consecutive months since last October, in which Taiwan outbound shipments to the United States hit a record high of US$3.7 billion, the government tallies show. They also indicate that February's level was also a drop of US$500 million from January.

On the other hand, Taiwan imports from the United States still registered noticeable growth, rising 10.9 percent to reach US$1.76 billion in February. That left the island with a trade surplus of US$800 million, down 36 percent from January, the statistics indicate.

Affected by declining exports to the United States since the end of last year, Taiwan was edged out by Holland as the ninth-largest source of U.S. imports. At the same time, Taiwan also became the eighth-largest source of the U. S. trade deficit, falling from its previous sixth spot.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. CHEN TO RIDE BICYCLE TO OFFICE FRIDAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will ride a bicycle to work Friday morning to take the lead in marking Earth Day, which falls on Sunday this year, Presidential Office sources said Thursday.

Accompanied by Hau Lung-pin, director general of the Environmental Protection Administration, Ho Cheng-tan, vice minister of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and several bodyguards, Chen will set off on the bike at 8:20 a.m. and pedal through the city's streets to the Presidential Office, the sources said.

Despite the presence of his bodyguards, Chen is expected to say hello cordially to people he meets in the streets. News media are also permitted to cover the story and interview Chen during his bicycle ride, the sources said.
Security and traffic authorities have completed all preparation work to make Chen's bicycle tour go smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CALLS FOR ROC-US COOPERATION TO CREATE `A BRIGHTER FUTURE'

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu called Thursday for closer cooperation between the ROC and the United States so as to jointly create "a brighter future for both parties in the 21st century."
Lu made the appeal during a tea party she hosted in honor of a 50-member delegation from Irvine City, San Francisco, which arrived in Taipei earlier this week for a goodwill visit.

The main objective of the delegation led by Irvine City Mayor Larry Agran is to sign with northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County an agreement on the establishment of sisterhood ties between the two sides, a move pushed for by Lu when she served as Taoyuan county magistrate.

Lu said that it was a great pleasure for her to receive the U.S. delegation in the Presidential Office as she did not expect to be able to meet with the distinguished guests in the capacity of ROC vice president.

She told the delegation members it was "really unimaginable" for a woman like her -- who had been jailed for the 1979 Formosa Magazine incident -- to become ROC vice president, while Chen Shui-bian, the lawyer for the victims of the incident, was elected president.

"This democratic miracle was jointly created by all the people of Taiwan," the first ROC female vice president stressed, adding that the democratic achievement should be cherished by all the compatriots of the island country.

Hailing Irvine City as "an ideal place to live," Lu said the Irvine authorities have focused their efforts on both environmental protection and the promotion of social well-being. The vice president voiced the hope that both parties can further boost bilateral cooperation.

For his part, Agran spoke highly of Taiwan's democratic achievements, saying that the inauguration of a new government represents the realization of a political ideal. He also said he expects both sides to strengthen exchanges and cooperation in the near future.
Also present at the meeting were Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan and Presidential Senior Adviser Yao Chia-wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITINERARY FOR ROC PRESIDENT'S SECOND TRIP TO LATIN AMERICA ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office announced Thursday the official itinerary for Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming second state visit to five ROC allies in Latin America.

Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Eugene Chien said at a press conference that Chen is scheduled to embark on his 14-day trip to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama, Paraguay and Honduras May 21, a day after his first anniversary in office.
He will be accompanied by his wife, local entrepreneurs and legislators, as well as national security, foreign affairs, economics, agricultural, science and labor officials.
Chien said that the president's visit is meaningful in three particular ways:

First, the president is slated to attend a summit meeting in El Salvador with leaders of the Republic of China's Central American allies. In addition to strengthening multilateral relations, the summit and the establishment of a strategic alliance with this region of the world will demonstrate Taiwan's ability and desire to participate in international society.

Second, because Chen and his wife's involvement in Taiwan's democracy movements, from the early days to the first peaceful transfer of political power to an opposition party last year, mirrors the island's democratic development progress, their visit to ROC allies will be an affirmation of Taiwan's democratic achievements that will garner widespread international recognition.
Third, as a sovereign nation, the Republic of China needs to step out into the international arena frequently to see the world and be seen by the world.

During his visit, Chen will also tour a new residential community in El Salvador built with the assistance of Taiwan's largest charity -- the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- after that country was rattled by two devastating earthquakes early this year.

Chen made his first overseas visit as ROC head of state last August, on a trip that took him to the Dominican Republic, Costa Rica and Nicaragua, as well as the African countries of The Gambia, Burkina Faso and Chad.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILLIONS OF PEOPLE IN TAIWAN SMOKE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Despite the hazards of tobacco to human health, millions of people in Taiwan still smoke, according to the findings of a recent survey.

The survey, conducted by National Taiwan University's College of Public Health, shows that 47.29 percent of males over 18 in Taiwan smoke, while the rate for female smokers in the same age group is much lower at only 5.23 percent.

Public health experts have estimated that about 4 million people in Taiwan smoke, or nearly one in every five persons. The average age for a first try of a cigarette is between 18.5 years and 19.9 years.

The findings show that 37.92 percent of male smokers smoke daily, while the rest smoke occasionally. Regular smokers make up 3.25 percent of the female smokers. The heaviest smokers consume 30 cigarettes a day, compared with the less than 20 a month for the lightest smokers.

The current smoking rate for men shows a slight decrease compared with the 50.07 percent recorded in 1993 and the 51.89 percent recorded in 1996. However, the present rate for women has increased in comparison with the 2.82 percent recorded in 1993 and the 4.63 percent recorded in 1996.
Public health experts have warned that smoking increases the risk of cancer of the lung, kidney, bladder and oropharynx, while it is also associated with heart disease and other serious illnesses.

They estimate that by 2025, some 10 million people in the world will die annually of smoking-related diseases, with 2 million being today's children and youths. In addition to human lives, the health costs of smoking-related diseases will also be tremendous, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER DECLINES TO CONFIRM MERGER OF 2 LOCAL BANKS

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang declined Thursday to confirm a reported merger of two local banks, saying only that there will be 10 financial business merger cases within the year, including insurance and securities companies.
He was responding to local media speculation that day that TAIPEIBANK might merge with the Far Eastern International Bank.
Yen said the Ministry of Finance (MOF) does not confirm any news concerning specific banks, especially as the banks involved in the report are listed companies.

He also said the MOF is studying whether to extend the period of supervision of the Chung Shing Bank, which was found following a financial check by the MOF to have made illegal loans to various individual customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORNELL TO ADOPT LOW KEY RECEPTION FOR FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 18 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Cornell University official said Wednesday that former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the university in May will be low key and private.

Vice President for University Relations Henrik N. Dullea said that during Lee's three-day stay at Cornell University, he will only meet with his granddaughter, who is studying there, and will not hold any public activities. He noted that Lee's coming visit to Cornell -- his alma mater -- will be very different from an earlier visit he made in 1995.

Dullea revealed that Lee had originally wished to make the visit in last December but was unable to do so because of his health condition. He also described as "untrue" a Taiwan media report that claimed Cornell University President Hunter R. Rawlings III had traveled to Taiwan in recent months to make arrangements for Lee's visit.

Dullea stressed that Lee's visit to Cornell University will be purely private in nature and that he will not take part in any public activities or hold any news conferences. But he pointed out that Lee will preside over a donation ceremony to Cornell University and will personally announce the establishment of the "Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research."
In recognition of Lee's outstanding contribution, Cornell University in 1994 set up a "Lee Teng-hui Professorship of World Affairs" which operates with a US$2.5 million donation by friends of Lee.
According to Cornell University, Lee is slated to fly from Los Angeles May 2 to Ithaca, where Cornell University is located, and to stay there until May 4.

Cornell University started to arrange for Lee's early May visit about a month ago and did not make public his itinerary until Tuesday after the U.S. State Department agreed to issue an entry visa for Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP URGES U.S. TO IMPROVE TREATMENT OF TAIWAN LEADERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu Thursday urged the U.S. government to improve its treatment of ROC leaders and to provide advanced defense weapons for Taiwan.
She made the appeals while meeting with House Representative Bob Schaffer and members of a mission consisting of U.S. women leaders.

Lu said that President Chen Shui-bian and she made stopovers in the United States on their way to and from Latin American countries last year, but noted that "unreasonable restrictions" were placed upon them during their stays there.
She expressed hope that the new U.S. administration will make "constructive improvements" on bilateral relations, especially during Chen's stopover in the United States next month.

During the talks, Lu explained the need for Taiwan to acquire advanced defense arms to deter the military threat from mainland China and urged the United States to be wary of Beijing's plot to block U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
She also said she expects that Washington will assist Taiwan in its bid for early entry into the World Trade Organization and the World Health Organization.
In response, Schaffer said that he believes the U.S. Congress will continue to show its concern about Taiwan's security and will support Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations.
Members of the women's mission said they will ask the U.S. government to improve its treatment of Taipei leaders in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTED DEATH OF FORMER COUNCILMAN IN MAINLAND UNCONFIRMED

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) is seeking to verify a report that former Changhua County Council Deputy Speaker Nien Chung-jen died in a car accident in mainland China, a CIB official said Thursday.

CIB commissioner Cheng Ching-sung told local reporters that the CIB had asked the Beijing authorities through the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation to help verify whether Nien, a most-wanted criminal who fled to the mainland in 1997, had really died while being chased by public security officials in connection with a blackmail case involving a local bar.
However, Cheng said that Nien's death had not been officially confirmed by the mainland Chinese public security authorities.

According to local news reports, Nien's car hit a safety island in Xiamen City while trying to escape pursuit by mainland public security forces, and Nien was reported dead after being rushed to a nearby hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP HOPES FAIR TREATMENT FOR PRESIDENT DURING U.S. STOPOVER

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed hope Thursday that President Chen Shui-bian will be "fairly treated" during his stopovers in the United States in May.
"The Bush administration should `treat fairly' the Republic of China president," Lu said while receiving a women's rights delegation from the United States.
Lu also vowed that she will not visit the United States in her capacity as a national leader unless she is treated "with respect and dignity."

The vice president said that she was not allowed to attend a party held by her friends at a Miami hotel last year during a stopover en route to Central America. Even the members of her entourage were not permitted to meet with their friends there, she noted.

During a transit stop in San Francisco on her way back to Taiwan, Lu recounted, a planned meeting with the presidents of Berkeley Universty, Cisco Systems and Hewlett Packard at a local hotel had to be canceled at the request of the U.S. State Department.

Lu also criticized Tokyo for hesitating in issuing an entry visa for former President Lee Teng-hui out of fear of annoying Beijing. Lee's planned visit to Japan is aimed only at receiving medical treatment for a heart problem, she said, adding that Tokyo should not bow to pressure from Beijing, which she described as a "dictator of the whole world."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO ENHANCE RELATIONS WITH LATIN AMERICA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that Taipei will continue to enhance its relations with friendly Central and South American countries.
He made the remarks while meeting with a delegation of journalists from major news organizations in nine Latin American countries.
Chang told the visitors that the ROC government will continue to strengthen cooperation and exchanges with its diplomatic allies in Central and South America.

He noted that President Chen Shui-bian's plan to visit Central and South American countries from May 21 -- one day after the first anniversary of his inauguration -- demonstrates the government's determination to improve its relations with friendly countries in the region.
The premier stated that strengthening relations with the ROC's Central and South American diplomatic allies has long been a priority of the government's foreign policy.
He also said that the government will provide assistance to promote cooperation and cultural, sporting, economic and trade exchanges.
In order to encourage local businessmen to invest in friendly Latin American countries, Chang went on, the government is offering a variety of incentives for prospective investors.
The delegation was made up of journalists from Panama, Guatemala, Grenada, Honduras, Paraguay, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, El Salvador and the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES LOCALS TO `OFTEN MIND OTHER PEOPLE'S BUSINESS'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian received U.S. teenage model volunteer Danny Seo Thursday and urged the people of Taiwan to learn from Seo's example and "often mind other people's business."

Sparing no efforts to advocate voluntary service in Taiwan, Chen praised Seo, "the most influential figure in the 20s generation in the whole of the United States," for the idea set forth in his book of simply spending a short amount of time each day doing good deeds.
Chen said he is very glad that Seo came to Taiwan to share the "volunteer spirit" with the people of Taiwan.

He noted that the ROC promulgated a law governing voluntary work early this year, adding that the 2001 international volunteer leaders summit and a seminar on voluntary service in Taiwan will also be held this year, showing Taiwan's connection with the international year of voluntary service.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS PROTEST GOVERNMENT'S HANDLING OF MP3 CAMPUS RAID INCIDENT (I)

TEXT.P: A group of university students protested Thursday the Ministry of Education's handling of student rights after a high-profile campus search last week ended with the seizure of 14 computers owned by students accused of downloading MP3 files.

Calling themselves the Taiwan Democratic Student Movement Alliance, the group of approximately 10 students gathered in front of the ministry and released a statement signed by various university student organizations and social movement groups from across the island.
In the statement, the alliance accused the ministry of allowing prosecutors to enter a college campus "illegally" and "arrest" students.

The students also accused the ministry of enforcing a large-scale crackdown on campus Web sites containing MP3 files, as if the ministry were a "police headquarters for the sole use of financial groups."

The statement was referring to the music industry, represented by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI), whose Taiwan branch office was quick to throw its weight behind last week's search operation and even went so far as to say that it will settle for nothing less than conviction of the offenders.

The student alliance went on to criticize the ministry for immediately judging that the 14 students were guilty of breaking the law when "society is still debating" whether the act of downloading MP3 files from the Internet is illegal.

The students also accused the ministry of threatening their rights to assembly by telling them not to band together to protest the search. Clearly asking the students to admit guilt, the ministry also urged the students to settle with the IFPI out of court even though the organization has yet to file a suit, the student alliance added.
The students called for a complete re-evaluation of copyright-related laws, particularly the aspects involving personal and educational use.

In an open letter to the Ministry of Justice, the alliance claimed that most countries are still debating whether corporate and organizational users should be included in the scope of punishment for intellectual property rights "violations." The debate has yet to expand to cover individual users, the alliance said.
Therefore, the students accused Taiwan's government agencies of "inappropriately" announcing that downloading MP3 files is illegal.

Meanwhile, a legal expert on intellectual property rights said at a seminar sponsored by the Ministry of Education to advocate intellectual property rights that if the process of creating an MP3 file does not involve permission from its copyright owner, it is illegal.

As for downloading that file, unless it is in line with the scope of "legally accepted reasonable usage," the act is still illegal, added Chou Tien, director of the Institute of Information Industry's Technology Law Center.

Chou said that current rulings on the legality of MP3 downloads are made on a case-by-case basis, but that the more these cases are ruled illegal, the easier it is for precedents to influence later rulings toward the same conclusion. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS PROTEST GOVERNMENT'S HANDLING OF MP3 (II)

TEXT.P: He added that the outcome of the case of the 14 National Cheng Kung University students has yet to be determined by looking into the computers confiscated by the prosecutors to see whether the quantity of MP3 files on those computers and other related factors constitute legal personal non-commercial use.

Chou also recommended that future amendments to the Copyright Law must take into consideration both the rights of copyright owners and those of users. He called for a strengthening of Copyright Law education and respect for self-disciplined autonomy on college campuses.

Meanwhile, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party voiced his support for the students, claiming that simply downloading music and videos from the Internet for personal or home usage constitutes normal, legal behavior that is similar to recording programs off cable or broadcast television for home viewing.
Legislator Su Huan-chih charged that the prosecutor's unprecedented search of student dorms heralds the coming of an era of "Internet white terror" for Taiwan.

He asserted that the students were not in violation of copyright laws because they did not burn the MP3 files onto CDs for commercial profit, and that the Web site operators who put the MP3 files on the Web for others to download were the real copyright violators.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 20, or the 27th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor, Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: The RAF drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li-jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Liberal Party Pierre E. Trudeau becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to communist China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY LEGISLATOR PROPOSES `CROSS-STRAIT THREE LINKS' BILL

TEXT.P: New Party Legislator Cheng Lung-shui proposed Friday that Taiwan initiate direct air and sea transport links with mainland China, or the "cross-strait three links," soon in order to accelerate business and trade exchanges.

Cheng said he will push to have his draft of the "cross-strait three links" bill, being submitted to the Legislative Yuan, screened next month, pointing out that he expects that a three-reading passage of the bill before the end of this year will enable Taiwan to formally implement the program Jan. 1, 2001.

Noting that two-way trade between Taiwan and mainland China reached US$30.5 billion last year while Taiwan became mainland China's fifth largest trading partner, Cheng said business interactions across the Taiwan Strait are now an undeniable and irresistible trend that should be properly guided rather than blocked.

In the draft bill proposed by Cheng, he calls for the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation to be authorized to be the presiding agency responsible for conducting direct working-level talks with relevant or counterpart mainland Chinese groups for the implementation of the "cross-strait three links" bill.

Under the bill, Cheng also proposes that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications publicizes before Jan. 1, 2002, the names of the Taiwan seaports and airports to be designated as locations for carrying out the "cross-strait three links" bill.

Commenting on Cheng's proposal, Fu Don-cheng, director of the Department of Economic Affairs under the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said whether the timing is now right for Taiwan to implement the "cross-strait three links" needs to be considered further.

Fu said that the "cross-strait three links" issue is one that both Taiwan and mainland China must face. As the opening of such links involves many issues in various different areas, the MAC is thoroughly assessing related plans in the hope that the links will be initiated at the right time and with adequate safeguards for the nation's security and the Taiwan people's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 11.87 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 11.87 points to close at 5,596.63.
Market turnover amounted to NT$84.42 billion (US$2.57 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS FORM 'CLEAN PARLIAMENT ALLIANCE'

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from both ruling and opposition parties formed a "clean parliament alliance" Friday to push for early passage of a package of bills aimed at reforming the Legislative Yuan and "purifying" campaign activities.

Legislators Lai Shyh-bao of the New Party, Ting Shou-chung and Lu Hsiu-yen of the Kuomintang, Shen Fu-hsiung and Chou Jung-tai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Chou Hsi-wei and Liu Wen-hsiung of the People First Party (PFP), and Chao Yung-ching of the Supra-party Alliance announced their decision at a joint press conference.

The lawmakers pledged to press for passage of a total of 51 bills in 13 categories related to parliamentary reforms and neutralization of civil service before the expiration of the tenure of office of the Fourth Legislative Yuan late this year.

Lai said the package of reform bills include those related to self-discipline of legislators and political parties, intraparty primaries, eradication of vote-buying, violence and organized crime from campaign activities.

According to Lai, seven categories of the bills are pending screening by the legislature's various standing committees and the remaining six categories are pending deliberation at the parliament's plenary sessions.

Under present regulations governing parliamentary operations, if those bills fail to pass relevant standing committees before the end of the last session of the current legislature, they would all be returned to their original initiators.

With a view to ensuring smooth and efficient parliamentary operations and upgrading the image of the legislative assembly, Lai said he and some of his colleagues feel compelled to press for the passage of all those critical bills before their terms of office expire.

"We are hopeful that the legislative caucuses of all political parties and factions will place the top priority on screening all those reform bills in order to wipe out money- and organized crime-linked politics, curb official corruption, purify campaign activities and maintain good order in the legislature," Lai urged.

The package of the parliamentary reform bills include revisions to certain existing statutes, such as the Public Officials Election and Recall Law and the Legislators Behavior Law and the Legislative Power Enforcement Law, as well as legislation of new laws, including regulations to govern political contributions, political parties, parliamentary lobbying, and neutrality of civil servants.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PEDALS TO OFFICE TO MARK EARTH DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian gave up his motorcade Friday and instead rode a bicycle to the Presidential Office to demonstrate his concern for the environment in the run-up to Earth Day, which falls on Sunday this year.
Although it began to rain early in the morning, the waiting media learned that the president's scheduled bicycle ride to work would still take place.

At 8:20 a.m., just minutes after the downpour started to peter out, the president, accompanied by Hau Lung-pin, director general of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA); Ho Cheng-tan, the vice minister of Transportation and Communications; and Chen's security staff, pedaled out of the presidential residence on schedule, all donning safety helmets.

Although it was only a five-minute ride from the residence to the Presidential Office, traffic had to be temporarily controlled to ensure the safety of the president. The vehicles jam-packed on both sides of the boulevard formed a striking contrast to the group of cyclists commuting to the office.
Chen said that it is good to cycle to the office and that he hopes a similar activity can be held every month. He added that he would ride his bicycle back to his residence in the afternoon.
The EPA director said that in consideration of Earth Day, the president took the initiative in suggesting the bicycle commute as a way of promoting energy conservation and pollution reduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASS'T MANAGER SHOT IN HEAD DURING ATTEMPTED BANK ROBBERY
DOC.DATELINE: Sanchung, Taipei County, April 20 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A man who attempted to rob the Sanchung branch of the International Bank of Taipei (IBT) at around noon Friday almost made away with more than NT$500,000 worth of cash.
The robber, identified as Chen, shot a bank assistant manager, surnamed Tsao, in the head when he was trying to escape with the loot.
While starting his motorbike outside the bank to make his getaway, the robber was subdued by a police officer who had rushed to the scene in time.
The robber is now in police custody and being interrogated.
The IBT assistant manager, who was rushed to a nearby hospital after the shooting, is in critical condition, hospital authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 11.87 points to close at 5,596.63.
The bourse opened at 5,645.11 and fluctuated between 5,645.11 and 5,590.87 during trading.

A total of 2.17 billion stocks worth NT$84.42 billion (US$2.57 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.04 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$128.05 billion (US$3.9 billion).

Two of the eight major stocks categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 0.3 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent. Cement stocks and electrical shares both remained unchanged.

The other major categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.9 percent, and plastics and chemical shares and textile issues, both at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 288 to 202, with 102 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR: INTER-CITY EXCHANGES NO SUBSTITUTE FOR DIPLOMATIC TIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the city's exchanges with other cities in foreign countries, no matter how successful, still provide no substitute for the Republic of China's diplomatic relations.

Receiving 38 diplomats-to-be from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs at his office, Ma acknowledged that the so-called city-to-city diplomacy may help the nation's diplomatic situation on a technical level by winning good-will from people in other countries. However, he said he would not expect the use of such exchanges to mend diplomatic fences, as some people would suggest.

He said Taipei's exchanges with cities in foreign countries are not primarily aimed at helping improve the nation's diplomatic situation, but are instead aimed at sharing experiences in city planning and development in order for mutual progress in these areas.
The mayor promised that he will work closely with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs when visiting any city in a foreign country in the future.
On the home front, he said the city government of Taipei will work to improve its contact with the some 53,000 foreign nationals living in the city.

Ma disclosed that to strengthen interactions with foreign nationals in Taipei, the city government has enlisted volunteer workers to offer needed services. The city has also sponsored various activities for the 30,000 foreign workers in the city and has provided them with legal protection and humanitarian treatment.

The mayor said that in doing so, the foreign nationals will carry many good memories about Taiwan with them when they return to their own countries one day. "This will be the best city-to-city diplomacy," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN DECIDES TO GRANT LEE VISA SOON WITH CONDITIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 20 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Japanese authorities have decided to grant former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui a visa for a visit to Japan to receive medical treatment, sources from the Japanese Cabinet said Friday.
Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono said he reached consensus with Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori that the Japanese government would grant Lee an entry visa under certain conditions.
Kono told reporters that the consensus he reached with Mori and Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda is that a decision on the Lee visa issue will be made "as soon as possible."

Kono, who had previously opposed issuing the visa because of concerns that it would anger Beijing, acquiesced to repeated demands by Mori that Lee be granted a visa on humanitarian grounds. He confirmed Friday that Tokyo will issue a visa for Lee with conditions attached.

The visa will be issued soon, as long as Lee agrees to confine his stay in Japan to fulfilling the purpose of receiving medical treatment in a hospital in Kurashiki City of the western prefecture of Okayama and to conduct no political activities, Kono noted.
If everything goes smoothly, the visa could be issued as early as Friday, according to Kono.

Meanwhile, on reports from Taipei that former ROC President Lee Teng-hui would choose not to visit Japan if conditions were attached, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yasuo Fukuda denied that the Japanese government has asked Lee to sign a written pledge promising that he will confine his visit to Japan to only Kurashiki, Okayama in exchange for granting visa.
Fukuda said the Japanese government has asked Lee to restrict his Japanese visit to medical activities in Kurashiki, Okayama, but has not demanded a signature on a written pledge.

Lee filed an application with the Taipei office of the quasi-official Japan Interchange Association April 10 for a visa to visit Japan before April 24 to have his heart examined and treated by the same Japanese doctor who supervised his heart surgery at National Taiwan University Hospital last Oct. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF `BLACK BAT' SQUADRON CREW TO BE TAKEN BACK TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker urged the Republic of China military Friday to assist in taking back the remains of the 14 crew members of an ROC surveillance plane downed by mainland China in 1963.

Legislator Chen Shei-saint made the call at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan. Also present were Lu Teh-chi, a former head of the military's 34th squadron, also known as the "Black Bat Squadron," and the bereaved families of the crew of the downed spy plane.
Chen said the ill-fated plane, flown by pilot Chou I-li, entered mainland Chinese air space on a nighttime surveillance mission June 19, 1963.

"Eight mainland Chinese MiG fighters scrambled to chase and intercept our spy plane, which was later brought down over Linchuan in the central mainland province of Jiangxi," Chen said, adding that Chou and 13 other crew members all died in the incident.

Their remains have since been buried in a graveyard on the outskirts of Linchuan, Chen said, adding that Chou's widow, Hsiao Chia-chen and the families of several other crewmen are scheduled to travel to Linchuan between late April and early May to take back the remains of their loved ones.

"About 40 years have passed since the `Black Bat Squadron' crew sacrificed their lives for our country. Now their remains will finally be taken home. The government, the military and even ordinary citizens should show more concern about the event and organize activities to welcome home the remains and souls of our national heroes," Chen urged.

For her part, Hsiao said that when her husband was downed in mainland China 38 years ago, their four children were all very young. "And now they have all grown up. My greatest hope over the years has been to take back my husband's remains. By so doing, I hope my husband's soul can finally find solace," an emotional Hsiao said.

Speaking on the same occasion, the former head of the "Black Bat Squadron," Lu Teh-chi, said the squadron conducted more than 800 spying flights over mainland China between 1953 and 1967. "Among them, 15 ROC planes were shot down, resulting in the deaths and injuries of 148 crew members," Lu said, adding that taking back the remains of killed crew for reburial can offer great comfort to their families.

In response, a military official present at the news conference said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and other relevant government agencies will do their utmost to assist the families in taking back the remains of the crew.

"Although the MND cannot send any servicemen to accompany the bereaved families on their mainland trip, it will direct the Air Force General Headquarters to help arrange for the reburial of the crew once they are taken home," the MND official said.
Under current ROC law, no military officers in active service can travel to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA AWAITING JAPANESE NOTIFICATION OF LEE VISA: SPOKESWOMAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) had not heard from the Japanese authorities as of Friday noon about a decision on whether it will issue an entry visa for former President Lee Teng-hui, according to MOFA spokeswoman Katherine Chang.

Chang declined to comment on news reports that the Japanese government had agreed to issue a visa for Lee only if he promises to confine his Japanese visit to receiving medical treatment at a hospital in the western city of Kurashiki and to conduct no political activities. She said only that MOFA will extend Lee every possible help if he is granted a visa.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, responding at the Legislative Yuan to Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chou Ya-shu, who questioned Chang's "ignorance" of the visa issue, said the Cabinet respects Lee's will and choice in regard to the issue, a thorny one for Japan and now for Lee too.
Lee and his office at the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) were not available for comment on whether he would agree to Japan's conditions.
Earlier in the day, local newspapers had reported that Lee was enraged by the conditions and said that he would rather not visit Japan if the visa were issued with conditions attached.
As of Friday noon, Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono had said the visa could be issued soon, as long as Lee agrees to confine his stay in Japan to receiving medical treatment in Kurashiki.
It could not be confirmed whether Lee had been asked to sign a written pledge promising that he would confine his Japanese visit to a Kurashiki hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.009 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 32.890.
The local currency opened Friday at 32.846 and was traded between 32.826 and 32.890.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$473.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STATE DEP'T ISSUES TRAVEL CAUTION ON M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department issued a public announcement Thursday cautioning Americans, particularly those of Chinese origin, to carefully evaluate the possible risk of being detained by Communist Chinese authorities before deciding to travel to mainland China.

The announcement pointed out that individuals who have at any time engaged in activities or published writings critical of Beijing's policies or who have traveled to Taiwan or been involved with Taiwan media organizations are particularly at risk of detention, even if they have previously visited mainland China without incident.

The State Department made the announcement in response to recent cases in which the Communist Chinese Ministry of State Security has, without offering any evidence to substantiate their allegations, taken American citizens or U.S. permanent residents of Chinese origin into custody on suspicion of espionage or engaging in activities damaging to Communist China's national security.
U.S. citizens planning to visit or live in mainland China are advised to consult the State Department's Consular Information Sheet on the People's Republic of China.
The announcement, however, does not apply to the Hong Kong or Macao special administrative regions, or to Taiwan, said the State Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONSERVATIVE GROUP URGES BUSH TO APPROVE AEGIS SALE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An American conservative organization Thursday urged U.S. President George W. Bush to authorize the sale of Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan promptly to help deter a potential Communist Chinese military attack against the island.

"The best way to avoid direct U.S. involvement in a cross-strait military conflict is to reinforce Taiwan's capability for self-defense," said Howard Phillips, president of the Conservative Caucus Foundation, in a full-page advertisement addressed to the U.S. president in the Thursday edition of the Washington Times.
The Virginia-based organization told Bush that "you need to read this report to focus on the facts about Red China which Clinton holdovers in your administration might prefer you ignore."

The Conservative Caucus Foundation report, titled "The Forward Defense of America's Vital National Security Interests: Addressing the Increase of Communist China's War Fighting Capabilities," pointed out that Taiwan is being increasingly isolated and that Communist China's campaign of military intimidation could lead to the capitulation of a Taiwan denied the purchase of U.S. defense equipment.

The report also noted that mainland China is systematically building its infrastructure and influence in the Western Hemisphere and that the Beijing-Moscow military alliance poses new threats to the United States and its interests.

The organization called on President Bush to consider withdrawing Communist China's most-favored-nation trade status, which last year gave the Beijing regime a US$84 billion trade surplus and helped subsidize its military buildup.

President Bush was also urged to oppose Communist China's bid to host the 2008 Olympic games and press the government of Panama to cancel the "corruptly concluded contract, which gave a Beijing-linked corporation control of the container ports on both the Atlantic and Pacific sides of the Panama Canal."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO IMPROVE INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT TO STIMULATE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lai In-jaw stressed Friday that the government will seek to expand public expenditure and improve the domestic investment environment to help promote domestic investment growth and economic rebound.
Lai made the remarks at a meeting of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce.

He said that as an export-oriented country, Taiwan has seen its economic growth impacted by the sluggish global economy, adding that economic growth in the United States, which was 5.1 percent last year, is predicted to drop to 1.2 percent this year.
Researchers have predicted that Taiwan's economic growth this year will also drop to around 5 percent from the 5.98 percent of last year.

Lai said that the government will do its utmost to tide the country over the difficulties, including working out substantial measures such as stepping-up promotion of the tourism industry, to stimulate the economy.

He also noted that the government has unveiled a NT$810 billion (US$24.62 billion) project to promote investment, hoping to lay a solid foundation for domestic infrastructure construction. In addition, he went on, the government will also attach special importance to transportation, and water and electricity supplies by keeping track of related issues every week.
He said the government has set up one-stop service counters in various industrial zones so as to lure private investment. The government is also completing the enactment of several financial laws.
Lai's remarks were made in the wake of a downward revision of this year's economic growth rate to 4.57 percent by the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, a domestic research institute.

The institute said that the effect of the strained economy seems to be far-reaching and extensive, adding that economic growth rate in the first quarter will be only 3.69 percent, followed by 4.14 percent and 4.33 percent, respectively, in the second and third quarters, with a more obvious rebound of 6.06 percent in the fourth quarter.

It continued that private consumer growth will be just 3.5 percent this year -- the lowest figure on record since 1960 -- showing that domestic confidence has yet to recover and that its impact on the economy will be great.

Domestic investment growth will be 1.69 percent, also representing rather sluggish growth. In foreign trade, commodities and service growth will be only 1.54 percent, while imports will decline by 0.83 percent this year.

Chung-Hua said that as the economy continues to be sluggish, consumer price growth will drop to 0.99 percent this year and the exchange rate of the Taiwan dollar to the U.S. dollar will be hover at around 32.88.
It also predicted that economic growth next year will be 5.77 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SALES OF DEFENSIVE ARMS CRITICAL TO ROC DEMOCRACY: ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that U.S. sales of defensive weapons are critical to the safeguarding of Taiwan's democratic way of life.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with two members of the U.S. House of Representatives, Roscoe Bartlett (R-Md.) and Bob Schaffer (R-Colo.), who are currently on their first visits to Taiwan.

Noting that the ROC needs advanced weaponry systems to defend its national security in the face of mainland China's intensified military buildup, Chen said the United States should sell Taiwan necessary defensive arms to help protect the island's democratic political system and lifestyle.

Chen went on to say that the ROC supports U.S. efforts to improve its relationship with mainland China. "Nevertheless, we are hopeful that the United States will pay heed to the voice of our people and respect their free will and choice while it conducts constructive engagements with the mainland," he added.
The president told his guests that he was very glad to meet them as they have long been staunch supporters of the ROC.

Chen said the people of Taiwan are grateful for the two American congressmen's consistent, firm support for the ROC's national cause, such as backing the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization as an observer, sales of advanced destroyers equipped with the Aegis battle management radar system and other cutting-edge military hardware.

Chen, who assumed office in Taiwan's first-ever democratic transfer of power between different political parties last May, said his administration is determined to uphold such universal values as democracy, freedom and human rights.
"Promoting human rights is one of our major policy goals," Chen told the American lawmakers, adding that Taiwan hopes to join forces with the international community in promoting human rights.

For their parts, Bartlett and Schaffer said that although they had never visited Taiwan before, they have never wavered in their support for the ROC. And their current visit has made them become even firmer in their backing of Taiwan's cause, they added.
Bartlett, a fifth-term House member, recalled that he voiced strong opposition when the U.S. government decided to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

"It was the wrong decision," Bartlett said, adding that it violated the democratic spirit of the U.S. constitution and the self-determination principle outlined in the U.S. Declaration of Independence.
Both Bartlett and Schaffer assured Chen that they will continue their support for U.S. arms sales to Taiwan to help safeguard peace and security in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUGAR CORP. TO HOST SIT ANNUAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan Sugar Corp. will host the Sugar Industry Technologists (SIT) annual meeting in Taipei May 7, to discuss new technologies for sugar production.

Over 120 experts and researchers from the United States, Japan, mainland China and European countries will gather at the two-day meeting of SIT, a private organization recognized internationally for its contributions to sugar-production technology and development.
The ROC acquired the authorization to host the 2001 SIT annual meeting five years ago and it is the first meeting of its kind to be sponsored by an Asian country.
SIT Chairman Chou Chung-chi and Taiwan Sugar Corp. Deputy Manager Chiou Chien-nan will jointly preside over the meeting.
Chou is manager of the Sugar Process Research Institute under the U.S. Agriculture Ministry. He formerly worked for Taiwan Sugar Corp. before emigrating to the United States in 1966.
The two representatives from the mainland will attend the meeting in the name of academic exchange.
Representatives are also scheduled to visit a sugar factory in Kaohsiung May 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW HEALTH INSURANCE CARDS TO BE ISSUED NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) signed an agreement Friday with the TECO group on the issuing of multi-purpose national health insurance cards.
BNHI CEO and President Chang Hong-jen and TECO Chairman Huang Mao-hsiung signed the agreement, which is worth NT$3.779 billion (US$114.86 million).
Noting during the signing ceremony that the new cards had a five-year pilot run in offshore Penghu County, Chang expressed his appreciation for Penghu residents.
Chang also expressed the hope the first new cards will be issued in July 2002, with the whole renewal process completed in May 2003.

The BNHI said that the new cards will replace the current cards, which allow for six BNHI-approved treatments and will be more convenient for the public as they will remain valid for between five and seven years.
An IC chip embedded in the new cards will also prevent the squandering of precious medical resources and cut the practice of padded medical expense applications, the officials said.

The new national health insurance card, part of the government's major information industry project, has been heavily promoted by Lee Ming-liang, director-general of the Department of Health and has also received support from Premier Chang Chun-hsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL AMERICAN ENVOYS COMPLAIN OF PARKING DIFFICULTIES

TEXT.P: Ambassadors and representatives of six Central American countries to the Republic of China paid a call on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Friday to complain of difficulties in finding parking spaces for their cars in the city.
They also urged the city to cease the practice of towing illegally parked cars bearing diplomatic plates.

Ma expressed regret for cases in which diplomats have had their cars towed and, unable to understand the chalk scrawls left by the tow truck companies advising owners as to where they can retrieve their vehicles, have had to suffer much inconvenience and time getting back their cars.

He said the city government will "try its best" to solve the problem by taking into consideration international custom, diplomatic reciprocity and the cordial relations between the Republic of China and the Central American countries in question.

The ambassadors who attended the meeting were Francisco Ricardo Santana Berrios from El Salvador, Oscar Alvarez from Costa Rica, Julio Roberto Palomo-Silva from Guatemala and Luis Wong from Nicaragua. Two representatives -- Lucia Mejia of Honduras and William Quinto of Belize -- also attended the meeting.
Ma said he is aware that the city suffers from a lack of parking spaces and disclosed that over the past two years and four months, even he has had to pay 11 fines for parking violations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC JOINS INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH ON CHIMP GENOME SEQUENCING

TEXT.P: A team of Republic of China researchers will join forces with counterparts in Japan, Germany, mainland China and South Korea in an effort to sequence the chimpanzee genome, a team spokesman announced Friday.

The ROC team is composed of research fellows from National Yang Ming University, Veterans General Hospital and the National Health Research Institute, said Yang Ming University Professor Tsai Shih-feng.
Tsai said Taiwan will invest NT$150 million (US$4.57 million) in the ambitious international research program, which may need an estimated US$100 million to complete.
According to Tsai, the ROC team will focus on the sequencing of the 30 million nucleotides in the chimpanzee's No. 3 chromosome.

"With our previous experience in sequencing the 10 million nucleotides in the human No. 4 chromosome, we believe the new chimpanzee research program will be conducive to our genetic research concerning certain diseases, including liver cancer, hepatitis B, AIDS and Alzheimer's disease," Tsai explained.
Noting that chimpanzees have 24 pairs of chromosomes, one pair more than humans, Tsai said the number of genomes is not necessarily related to the complexity of the cells from which they come.
In the history of evolution, according to Tsai, the chimpanzee is the animal most akin to humans.

"We hope that the new chimpanzee genome sequencing program can help us understand what makes human beings," Tsai explained, adding that the project is also expected to help answer basic questions about evolution.
Tsai said researchers in Japan and Germany have already begun sequencing the chimpanzee No. 21 chromosome and will later continue their research into the No. 23 chromosome.
Mainland Chinese and South Korean research teams will also play important roles in the joint reach program, Tsai said.

He further said participation in the program will enable Taiwan to establish cooperative ties with other genome research centers, to exchange experience and to improve its ability and skill through national collaboration.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY CONDUCTS LIVE-FIRE `HANKUANG' DRILL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Armed Forces conducted a live-fire anti-landing training exercise in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung Friday.

The combined services drill was the climax of the Hankuang No. 17 Exercise that began last month and has seen the staging of "cyberwar games" as well as air defense, anti-submarine and anti-ship drills.

A total of 2,700 troops from various military branches took part in the exercise, using a variety of anti-landing weaponry and supported by air-defense and naval defense weapons, including artillery, helicopters, jet fighters and warships.
The scenario for Friday's drill -- the largest military training exercise of the year -- had mainland Chinese forces passing the central line of the Taiwan Strait and moving toward the Taiwan coast.

F-5E fighters and naval missile boats were deployed against the invaders. Rockets, tanks and helicopters were all used in the one-hour exercise, which was supervised by army Commander-in-Chief Chen Chen-hsiang.

Hi-tech weaponry was the focus of the anti-landing drill, including locally-developed "Hsiungfeng I" ship-to-ship missiles, laser-guided "smart" bombs and the RT2000 artillery multiple launch rocket system, which made its local debut in the exercise.
Chen said the exercise was designed to test the feasibility and efficacy of combat programs for the southern Taiwan military region.

The drill was also aimed at testing the effectiveness of combined services training programs adopted after the completion of several military restructuring projects and the commissioning of new generation military hardware, Chen added.
He also pointed out that any shortcomings or deficiencies found in the training drill will be corrected in future military training programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL HOG-RAISING EXPECTED TO BECOME MORE DIFFICULT AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Agricultural officials said Friday that the cost of raising hogs in Taiwan is too high and that the industry will face even more difficulty when Taiwan enters the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The Council of Agriculture (COA) has predicted that in the first year of Taiwan's WTO membership, the cost of raising hogs will have to be cut to less than NT$46 per kilo and down even further to below NT$41 in the sixth year, if it is to be competitive.

Kaohsiung County government officials said that the scale of hog raising in Taiwan is not large or economically efficient, with costs of private hog raisers averaging between NT$40 and NT$42 per kilo, slightly higher than the auction price. However, even though hog farmers are usually one-man operations without extra personnel expense, they can barely make a living.

State-owned Taiwan Sugar Co., which is the largest hog raiser in Taiwan, has even higher costs, with an average cost of raising a hog calculated at NT$46.49 per kilo last year, with a target of below NT$45 per kilo this year.
The officials blamed Taisugar's high costs on the "bureaucratic mentality" of the Taisugar staff, which they said leads to a high fatality rate among its hogs and piglets.
Statistics show that Taisugar's death rates among hogs and piglets last year were 4.32 percent and 5.51 percent, respectively.

Since Chinese New Year, which fell on Jan. 24, the supply of hogs has outnumbered demand and the auction price of hogs in the market has averaged around NT$40 per kilo, leaving private hog farmers barely able to make ends meet.

In addition, the foot-and-mount disease (FMD) epidemic that hit Taiwan in 1997 was a devastating blow to Taiwan's hog industry, resulting in a ban on pork exports. Although the island's hog population was cut dramatically after the FMD outbreak, Taiwan still maintains about 10 million hogs, 2 million of which are located in Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY SEEKS CORRECTION FROM U.S. NEWSPAPER
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 19 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office here announced Thursday that it has demanded that a local daily correct a report that claimed the ROC foreign minister said Taiwan "could accept" a Washington decision to reject its request to buy Aegis-equipped destroyers.

The April 14 San Jose Mercury News front-page report quoted ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao as saying that "maintaining very friendly relations with the United States government is very important" to Taiwan, and that "damaging that relationship over one weapon system is not sensible."

However, a spokesman for the ROC representative office said that Tien had in fact pointed out that ROC-U.S. relations are multi-faceted, and that the Aegis system, as simply one item on the island's military procurement list, should not be seen as an indicator of bilateral relations.
The spokesman claimed that there were other discrepancies between the reported content and what Tien actually said, and that other quotes were taken out of context.
The spokesman added that Tien had originally arranged for a "background briefing," not a formal interview meant for publication, with the Mercury News Tokyo Bureau reporter who wrote the story.

The story came at a sensitive time in Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations, with the Bush administration slated to decide on Taiwan's arms shopping list next week amidst the usual protests from Beijing.

The report claimed that Tien's remarks are likely to relieve some of the pressure on the United States to sell the cutting-edge Aegis destroyers, which Taiwan has been seeking to purchase for several years to offset the threat of missiles deployed by mainland China opposite the island.

Some analysts in both Taipei and Washington have even taken the remarks attributed to Tien as a sign that Taiwan's determined stance to acquire the destroyers -- evident in the ever more vocal remarks by senior government officials in the days leading to the arms sales talks -- has softened considerably.

According to the ROC representative office, the San Jose Mercury News received the letter of complaint and forwarded it to the daily's parent company, Knight Ridder, which publishes 32 dailies in the United States and is responsible for the Tokyo bureau.
However, according the Mercury News, the editor in charge of international news at Washington-based Knight Ridder is currently on sick leave and unable to answer questions regarding the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADER CALLS FOR IMPROVEMENT OF INVESTMENT CLIMATE

TEXT.P: Mindful of Taiwan's future economic development, a prominent business leader urged the government Friday to focus on improving the domestic investment climate in order to keep the business sector rooted in the country.

Jeffrey L.S. Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC), made the remark while delivering a speech to a general assembly of the association, one of Taiwan's three major business organizations. The meeting was held at the Ambassador Hotel in downtown Taipei.

In a speech titled "Improving the Investment Climate in Order to Lay a Solid Foundation for Economic Development," Koo said that sustainable economic development is vital to Taiwan's presence in the international community, but it also hinges on a stable political situation.

Especially after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), expected by the end of this year, a stable political situation will be more important for the island country's economic development, Koo told CNAIC members present at the meeting.

Koo said he is deeply confident that most local enterprises are willing to stay rooted in Taiwan, as it is their homeland. However, he stressed, the business sector hopes that the government will speed up its improvements of the investment environment and seek to maintain political stability because "roots kept in Taiwan must be nourished by fertile soil."

Although Taiwan has enjoyed stable economic growth in recent years, the pace of growth has slowed considerably, Koo noted, adding that the economic slowdown can be mainly attributed to the continued deterioration of the domestic investment climate.

He said this includes a deterioration of social security, hikes in wages, a shortage of skilled manpower, fears caused by insufficient water and power supplies, tougher regulations on environmental protection, low administrative efficiency, imperfect preferential taxation measures and difficulties in obtaining land for business and industrial use.

Despite a slower U.S. economy last year, Taiwan's economy posted a 6-percent gain, he noted. But he stressed that last year's growth had lost its momentum, dropping sharply from 7.9 percent during the first quarter of 2000 to 4.1 percent during the fourth.

Most worrisome is that real investment by the private sector, influenced by the slowing export expansion and the sluggish economy, is expected to drop to 4.4 percent this year, far behind the 13.7 percent recorded in 2000, he said.
Slumping private sector investment will put pressure on overall domestic demand, making it more difficult for Taiwan's economy to bounce back, Koo said.

Consequently, he called on the government to accelerate the implementation of all relevant policies on expanding public investment and to improve the domestic investment climate efficiently so as to facilitate manufacturers' business operations in the country.

In addition, the government should also redouble its efforts to boost the development of the service industry, transform Taiwan into a pivotal global center for high technology development, build the island into a research and development center for traditional industries, and make the island into a global logistics and management center, the CNAIC head added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC GETTING READY FOR MAINLAND TOURISTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will complete its evaluation and preparations for the opening of Taiwan's tourism market to mainland Chinese residents by the end of June, after which it will submit a report to the Cabinet for approval, a ranking MAC official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Deng Chen-chung said the government supports opening Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists, adding that the MAC will complete the evaluation and programming by the end of June.

As for the issue of cross-strait deliberations on how to implement the policy, Deng replied that Taipei insists the talks be jointly conducted by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
SEF is a quasi-official organization that engages in negotiations in cross-strait issues with ARATS, its mainland Chinese counterpart.
Deng said the government's handling of the policy should stay in line with its overall mainland China policy and should take national security into account.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY LEADERS LEAVE FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT TALKS WITH U.S.
