TEXT.P: Vice Chief of the General Staff General Huo Shou-yeh left for Washington D.C. Friday to attend the annual negotiations on Taiwan's arms procurement from the United States.

Gen. Huo will lead the Taiwan delegation to the meeting slated for April 24 in suburban Washington D.C., and Lieutenant General Chen Lan-chun, director of the Arms Procurement Bureau of the Ministry of National Defense, and other ranking military officials will participate.

Military sources said that high on this year's procurement list will be four Arleigh Burke destroyers equipped with the Aegis combat system, which Taiwan wants to buy in order to counter the threat of missiles deployed by Beijing on the southeastern coast of the mainland, just opposite the Republic of China.
The sources said that to prepare for the meeting, the military has planned prudently and made an estimation of the results of the meeting, including which items the United States is likely to sell.
Other weapons that Taipei is vigorously attempting to persuade Washington to sell include submarines, P3C anti-submarine aircraft and M-1 tanks.
Meanwhile, naval officials, who asked not to be named, said that the United States is likely to sell four Kidd-class destroyers first to upgrade the ROC Navy's open-sea combat capability.
The U.S. administration is now intensively reviewing Taiwan's requests for advanced weapons and is expected to announce the items it is willing to sell to the island shortly after the meeting.
However, the officials would not comment on wire service reports that the U.S. administration may agree to sell Taiwan the peripherals of the Aegis system first and the destroyers in the future.
Beijing has frequently voiced its strong opposition to U.S. sales of Aegis-equipped destroyers and other sophisticated weapons to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU PRESIDENT WARNS OF DIVERSIFIED CRISES IN HIGHER EDUCATION

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) President Chen Wei-jao warned Friday that Taiwan's higher education system is facing multiple crises that have resulted in declining competitiveness for the country.

Chen claimed that the four major crises facing Taiwan's higher education are insufficient international competitiveness, a lax learning attitude on the part of students, negative effects caused by the influence of commercialization and dwindling respect for the sector from society.

Citing national competitiveness ratings compiled by the Lausanne-based International Institute for Management and Development, Chen said Taiwan was ranked 22nd in 2000, a fall of our notches from 1999 and behind Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan. The ranking of Taiwan's performance in any single technology also dropped from seventh place in 1998 to 12th last year, he noted.
In terms of national R&D budgets, Chen said Taiwan took 19th place, while the island's budget for basic research was far lower than that of mainland China.

Pointing out that the competitiveness of the higher education system serves as a index to gauge a country's competitiveness in this current knowledge-based era, Chen warned that an increasing imbalance in quality and quantity in the development of domestic universities in recent years has led to the declining national competitiveness. Taiwan's universities are gradually sinking into mediocrity, he said.

Deliberating on the so-called imbalance in quality and quantity with regard to Taiwan's higher education system, Chen noted that government spending allocated for each student at state-run universities has slid by 20 percent over the past decade, as the number of universities in Taiwan has grown from just 50 in 1991 to nearly 150 now.
Currently, average government subsidies for public university students are markedly lower than in neighboring Japan, Hong Kong and South Korea, he added.

In addition, the NTU president said that the average academic level of Taiwan university students is relatively low, as many of them just want to "fool around" during their four-year university career.
In contrast, Taiwan's neighboring countries have actively geared up their development of world-class universities, he noted, pointing to mainland China and South Korea as examples.

According to Chen, mainland China has selected nine of its roughly 100 universities on which it is focusing its efforts to catch up with the world's top academic standards, including Peking University, Tsinghua University, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Zhejiang University and the Harbin Institute of Technology.
At the same time, South Korea has also worked out its "Brain Korea 21" package as a measure to upgrade the academic levels of its universities, he said.

In the face of strong competition from these countries, Chen said the Ministry of Education has been promoting a five-year "academic excellence plan" since last year. Beginning next year, certain selected domestic universities will be able to enjoy a special government budget totaling NT$10 billion each year to support their cooperation in joint academic research.

In order to maintain academic independence and an environment free from outside political or ideological interference, Chen emphasized that high-level academic freedom must be fully respected, as the objective of advocating higher education is not simply to serve businesses.

He also suggested that relevant authorities take effective measures quickly to improve the English ability of local university students and that university authorities upgrade the threshold for academic performance and graduation requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC LOWERS MAJOR RATES

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) called an unscheduled news conference Friday to announce its decision to lower two major interest rates.
Shih Yen, director of the CBC's Economic Research Department, said that the bank has decided to lower its discount and accommodation rates, with each dropping 0.125 percentage points.
Shih also pointed out that the CBC is not planning to further reduce its bank reserve requirement, as capital supply remains loose in the local market.
Citing CBC statistics, Shih said the outstanding combined amount of the bank's convertible time deposits and fixed deposits totaled around NT$616.9 billion (US$20 billion) as of Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUDDEN PROSECUTOR PERSONNEL SHUFFLE DRAWS CRITICISM

TEXT.P: Vice Justice Minister Hsieh Wen-ting said Friday that the large-scale reassignment of 21 chief prosecutors announced the previous evening was meant to invigorate the personnel system and create a "new prosecutorial culture."
Hsieh said at a press conference to explain the sudden shuffle -- the second since last June -- that the decision was made out of "holistic and functional considerations."
He added that the shuffle is also expected to result in improved bilateral communications between chief prosecutors and prosecutors.

Regarding the reassignment of some chief prosecutors to actual case-handling prosecutor positions at higher-level offices, Hsieh said that they will be reassigned back to decision-making positions in the future as opportunities present themselves, "allowing the prosecution personnel system to be more alive, like a pond of moving water."

Hsieh denied reports that the reassignments were made in part due to Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan's alleged disapproval over how some chief prosecutors have handled several recent high-profile cases, including a controversial raid on a college dorm to seize computers with downloaded MP3 files, which prosecutors considered illegal.
Hsieh said that the reassignment decision was not made based any "single case" but rather on the chief prosecutors' overall abilities.

Claiming that the reassignments were detrimental to morale, a prosecutor at the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office criticized the decision as "improper and unnecessary with no sense of urgency (for the reassignments) evident at all."

Prosecutor Liu Cheng-wu also announced his withdrawal from a special task force established last year to fight "black gold," or illegal government financial ties to organized crime. He added that he will call on other prosecutors in anti-black gold task force groups across the island to quit their teams en masse.

He urged the Ministry of Justice to retract the reassignment order, saying that most of the chief prosecutors on the list -- including the chief prosecutor of Taipei District Prosecutor's Office -- are "chiefs who truly support independent prosecutor case handling."

Meanwhile, four prosecutors at the Tainan District Prosecutor's Office also announced their withdrawal from the local anti-black gold task force in protest of what they called a "morale-shattering move."

Lin Chao-yang, chief prosecutor at the Tainan District Prosecutor's Office, said that he believes the decision to reassign the 21 chief prosecutors -- including himself -- should be considered "routine."

Lin urged the public to give prosecutors more encouragement and less criticism, adding that he will urge the four prosecutors still under his command not to be so insistent about quitting their teams.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE MECHANISM URGED TO AVOID POSSIBLE CLASHES

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume consultations and establish a channel for talks to avoid possible clashes in the wake of the mid-air collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland fighter April 1, which has fueled nationalism in mainland China, experts and scholars said Friday.

They made the remarks during a consultative committee meeting of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which first listened to the MAC's Department of Legal Affairs on the effects that mainland Vice Premier Qian Qichen's recent visit to the United States might have on cross-strait relations.
They noted that though there are multiple channels for communications between Beijing and Washington, a cross-strait communication mechanism has yet to be established.
They said that therefore, the two sides should resume their stalled talks and establish a dialogue mechanism to avoid possible conflicts across the Taiwan Strait.
The MAC report said the main purpose of Qian's U.S. visit was to conduct talks on policy and improve relations, adding that Qian had maintained a low-key manner.

But it pointed out that mainland China's assistance to Iraq in laying fiber optic cable, the U.S. criticism of Beijing's human rights abuse, the defection to the United States of China's Senior Colonel Xu Junping, and the recent mid-air collision have all seriously eroded the mutual trust between the two countries.

The report also said that the stability of relations between Beijing and Washington depends on several factors, including the handling of the mid-air collision incident, U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, the International Olympic Committee's vote on whether to grant Beijing the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games, President Jiang Zemin's visit to Russia and U.S. President George W. Bush's planned visit to the mainland later this year.

The report concluded that as cross-strait relations are closely related to Beijing-Washington relations, Taiwan must monitor the twists and turns of Beijing-Washington relations and work out contingency plans to handle possible developments.

Consultative committee members also said that the current state of Beijing-Washington-Taipei ties will not remain unchanged permanently, and Taiwan should map out short-, medium- and long-term mainland policy to deal with the U.S.-proposed "interim agreement" and Beijing's cherished "one country, two systems" formula.

In related developments, a legislator proposed that a military delegation comprised of retired ROC generals visit the mainland to ease cross-strait tensions and take the first step toward establishing a "military mutual trust mechanism."
Legislator Elmer Feng of the opposition New Party made the proposal during a general interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan.

Feng cited his own experience, saying that he had in the past acted in his capacity as a private citizen to negotiate for the government with Beijing, showing that private individuals can also play crucial roles in cross-strait relations.
Feng suggested that Taiwan's military delegation go to the mainland to engage in discussions with military scholars there, adding that he would like to help bring about such a visit.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said that the government must still push for the two sides to resume their officially-endorsed communication channels, meaning Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, and that this mechanism can be used in tandem with private exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO VICE CHIEF HOLDS SEMINAR IN ISRAEL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has a desire to share its developmental and economic experience with other countries as feedback for the international community, Government Information Office Deputy Director-General P. N. Chang said recently in Israel.
According to a GIO press release, Chang made the remarks at a seminar with representatives of major media organizations Thursday in Tel Aviv with an aim to introduce the ROC's current progress.

Stressing that continued pursuit of democracy, peace and prosperity are the basic goals of the ROC's national development policy, Chang said that Taiwan will link its hi-tech industries with its national development plan in an effort to create a highly developed, environmentally sound island for future generations.
Chang hailed the achievements made so far by both Israel and the ROC, saying that both nations are small in size, heavy in population and lacking in natural resources.

Commenting on the situation across the Taiwan Strait, Chang said the ROC government attaches a great deal of importance to its relations with mainland China and to overall peace in the Asia-Pacific region.

While expressing his hope that Beijing's leadership will jump over current barriers and transform the mainland into a democratic regional power, Chang said that Taiwan will continue to strive to promote its presence in the international community in order to make a greater contribution to the whole world.
Chang is currently visiting Israel after arriving in the Israeli capital Wednesday, according to the press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE CLIMBING

TEXT.P: Unemployment is continuing to worsen as the result of the sluggish domestic and world economies, Republic of China economics officials said Friday.

The officials, asking to remain anonymous, said that the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics is scheduled to release domestic employment figures Monday, in which the unemployment rate for March is expected to hit a record 4 percent.
February's unemployment rate of 3.73 percent, which translated into a jobless population of 364,000, was the highest since 1978.
The officials attributed the worsening unemployment to the increasing number of business shutdowns and layoffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CHARITY GROUP TO VISIT QUAKE-STRICKEN INDIA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu Friday presented the national flag to an ROC charity delegation scheduled to leave for India next Monday to engage in humanitarian relief work for the victims of the devastating Jan. 26 earthquake.

Lu, who had launched a donation campaign aimed at helping the victims of a fatal temblor that jolted western India, said at the ceremony that she regrets that she is unable to visit India with the delegation because of political reasons.

However, Lu asked the delegation members to keep her informed of the situation in the quake-stricken areas in India. The vice president said that if necessary, she will launch a second campaign to assist the quake victims there.
Noting that there are no boundaries in humanitarian relief, Lu voiced the hope that the delegation will be able to accomplish its mission satisfactorily.

With an enthusiastic response from all levels of Taiwan's society, a total of US$700,000 in cash and US$300,000 worth of relief materials was raised during the humanitarian assistance campaign launched in early February. The funds were then delivered to quake-stricken areas in India.

The ROC delegation members, comprising representatives of private enterprises, will also visit the seat of the Tibetan government-in-exile in the northern Indian city of Dharmsala to get a better understanding of the needs of Tibetan children there.

During his recent visit to Taiwan, exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama donated US$150,000 to help the victims of a killer earthquake that rocked central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999. Moved by this act of compassion, Lu staged a fund-raising campaign to assist Tibetan children in India.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA MULLING EASING BURDEN OF EMPLOYERS OF FOREIGN WORKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, April 20 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on Friday expressed the hope that the Labor Standard Law will be amended to lower wages for foreign workers.
Chen Chu made the expression at a seminar in Taichung on how to improve Taiwan's economy.
Chen said she will coordinate with legislators to amend the Labor Standard Law so that only domestic workers enjoy the protection of the basic wage and wages for foreign workers are decreased.

Chen said that wages of foreign workers in Singapore and Hong Kong are lower than that of Taiwan. At present, only foreign workers in Taiwan enjoy the protection of the basic wage, which now stands at NT$15,840 (US$495).

She said that before the current law is amended, the CLA will adopt a policy in which foreign workers' accommodations and food will be included in their basic wage, thus leading to an average decrease of NT$3,000-4,000 in the monthly costs of employing them.
Additionally, the CLA also plans to curtail unreasonable brokerage fees that foreign labor brokerage companies charge foreign workers, so that they will be able to keep more of their wages.

However, Chen Shen-hsien, director of the CLA's Labor Conditions Department, said the CLA will not take the initiative of filing an amendment to the Labor Standard Law. Instead, the CLA may ease the burden of employers of foreign workers in other ways, such as including accommodation and food fees into their basic wage, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAT'L FLAG TO FLY AT HALF MAST IN MEMORY OF FORMER VP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior announced Friday that all government agencies and institutions will fly the national flag at half mast on April 22, when former Vice President Shieh Tung-min's ashes will be laid to rest beside those of his wife in Changhua County.

In recognition of Shieh's outstanding contributions to the country, the Executive Yuan ordered all government agencies and institutions to fly the national flag at half mast on April 22, the ministry said in a press release.

Meanwhile, a memorial ceremony will be held on the same day at a concert hall at Shih Chien University, a private institution founded by the late vice president. President Chen Shui-bian, premier Chang Chun-hsiung and other ranking government officials as well as leaders from domestic political parties will attend the event.
Shieh, the first Taiwan-born provincial governor and vice president, passed away on April 8 at the age of 95.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN AGREES TO ISSUE VISA TO FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 20 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announced Friday that Japan will issue a visa to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.

Kono said that Lee, 78, is slated to arrive in Osaka Sunday. He will stay at hotel in that city during his visit, seek necessary treatment at a hospital in nearby Kurashiki, and return to Taiwan April 26, the Japanese official added.
In response, the ROC Presidential Office announced that it welcomed the decision, which it said will have "positive signifance" on bilateral ROC-Japan relations.
ROC Vice President Annette Lu also praised the Japanese government for its "courage" in making the decision despite Beijing's protests.
ROC government spokesman Su Cheng-ping said that Taiwan is "gladdened" by Japan's decision. Officials of ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan also welcomed the decision.
While thanking the assistance of Japanese officials and media, ROC Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue denied that any agreements were signed with the Japanese government regarding the visa.
Kono had said that the decision was made on humanitarian grounds and only after Lee agreed not to engage in any political activities during his visit.

After picking up Lee's approved visa from the Taipei office of the Interchange Association, Japan's representative office in Taiwan, a close aide of Lee thanked the ROC administration, lawmakers and the public as well as the assistance of Japanese "friends" and media for their concern and support.

Lee began complaining of chest pains after a trip to the Czech Republic last October and underwent successful coronary angioplasty surgery in Taiwan in November under the supervision of the same Japanese doctor he will see in Kurashiki.
He applied for a Japanese visa last Tuesday, but the Japanese Foreign Ministry first claimed that it did not receive the application.

Only after local media and local politicians -- including three of four candidates running for prime minister and even one of Kono's deputy ministers -- stepped up pressure on the foreign ministry did it finally agree to grant the visa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono finally yields to public pressure and agrees to grant a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui on humanitarian grounds.
The China Times:
Japan issues visa to Lee for medical trip.
The United Daily News:
Ex-President Lee will leave for Japan Sunday to receive medical treatment.
The Liberty Times:
Lee receives Japanese visa with no conditions.
The China Post:
Japan issues visa to Lee, enrages PRC.
The Taiwan News:
Japan issues Lee visa -- with conditions.
The Taipei Times:
Minister defends moving prosecutors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 21, or the 28th day of the third month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ISSUES VISA TO FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 20 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The United States issued a visa Friday to Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, according to the State Department.

A State Department spokesman said the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in the absence of diplomatic relations between the two nations, had issued the visa.
Lee is scheduled to visit his alma mater, Cornell University, May 2-4.

Cornell University officials said days earlier that Lee will visit his granddaughter, who is currently studying at the school, and announce the establishment of the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research. He is not expected to make any public speeches or other activities during his visit.
This will be Lee's second visit to his alma mater since he received his Ph.D. in agricultural economics in 1968.
He last visited Cornell while serving as ROC president in June 1995, during which he made a resounding speech titled "Always in My Heart."

Cornell said that the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research will be housed in the US$62.5 million Duffield Hall. Several Taiwan companies have made generous donations, but Cornell would not divulge the exact figures until Lee's arrival.
Cornell earlier set up a Lee Teng-hui Professorship of World Affairs to pay tribute to Lee's outstanding achievements after his supporters in Taiwan donated US$2.5 million to the university in 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WELCOMES JAPANESE VISA FOR EX-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung welcomed Saturday Japan's issuance of a visa to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and expressed hope that the move will not cause a major impact on ROC-Japan relations or ties between Japan and mainland China.
Chang made the remarks while meeting the press before attending the opening ceremony of an international medical seminar at the Veterans General Hospital.
Chang said the issuance of a visa in response to a "humanitarian request" cannot be rejected in a democratic nation.
Lee is expected to leave Sunday for Japan, where he is scheduled to receive medical treatment for a heart condition.

Lee made a transit stopover in Japan in 1985 on his way back to Taiwan after a visit to South America, the only time a high-ranking ROC official had been allowed to make a transit stop in Japan since Japan severed diplomatic relations with the ROC in 1972.
In 1991, he had planned to visit Japan on the way to a visit to Central and South America, but this was canceled when the itinerary was leaked by the Japanese press.
He was invited to attend the opening ceremony of the 1994 Asian Games held in Hiroshima, but was forced to cancel the trip under strong protest and pressure from Beijing.
Also under protest from Beijing, Lee failed to participate in the 1995 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum held in Osaka.

In 1997, Lee had intended to attend the 100th anniversary of the founding of Kyoto University, but the university did not invite him on the grounds that he did not complete his studies at the university.
He also planned to attend an ROC-Japan seminar on Asia held last year in Japan after he stepped down as the president, but this attempt also failed.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA ISSUE HURTS CROSS-STRAIT TRUST: EX-MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The controversy surrounding former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's application for a visa to visit Japan has worsened cross-Taiwan Strait relations, a former official said Saturday.

Su Chi, a former chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, pointed out that Lee's Japan travel plan was originally a very simple issue.

"However, it has been complicated by the involvement of the ROC and mainland Chinese governments," Su noted, adding that as a result, the Japanese government's 11th-hour decision to grant Lee a visa will have an adverse impact on cross-strait relations.
"Cross-strait relations have long been in bad shape, and I think that the visa issue will further worsen bilateral Taiwan-mainland Chinese ties," Su warned.
Nevertheless, Su said the issue will probably not prompt mainland China to take military action to vent its anger at Lee's upcoming Japan visit.
"Nor will the issue deteriorate cross-strait ties to the level seen in 1995 when Lee made a private visit to his alma mater, Cornell University, in New York State," Su remarked.

Following Lee's U.S. visit in June 1995, mainland China conducted several rounds of live-fire military exercises on Taiwan's doorstep, including lobbing missiles into waters near the island, between the second half of 1995 and early 1996, to intimidate Taiwan.

Noting that Lee is now a private citizen, Su said his Japan visit is purely for personal reasons. "It is for his own health and has nothing to do with the ROC's international profile," he explained, adding that Japan's issue of a visa to Lee should not be interpreted as a "breakthrough" in Taipei-Tokyo relations.
Su also expressed his doubts about the wisdom of the ROC government getting so deeply involved in the process of Lee's visa application.

"While Japanese officials were still debating whether to issue Lee a visa, senior ROC and mainland Chinese officials all made public comments intended to affect Japan's decision," Su said, adding that in his view, such practices will only hinder the long-term development of cross-strait ties.

As for the latest U.S. decision to grant Lee a visa for a second visit to Cornell University in early May, Su said the move is not expected to further worsen Washington-Beijing ties, which have been at a low ebb since a midair collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland jet fighter over the South China Sea early this month.
Su said he thinks that the collision incident will make mainland China more cautious and prudent in handling its relations with the United States.

Su went on to point out that both the U.S. and Japanese governments granted Lee visas mainly because he has retired and has played no active role in any political activities over the past year. Lee ended his 12-year stint as ROC president last May.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY SUPPORT CUT IN SCHOOL SUMMER VACATION: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: Most people in Taiwan support a Ministry of Education proposal to cut the length of summer vacation for primary and secondary schools, according to the results of an opposition Kuomintang-commissioned survey released Saturday.
The results show that 62 percent of those surveyed support the proposal, although it comes as no surprise that most students are against the idea.

The telephone survey of 1,067 people, who were asked their opinions on the cutting of vacation days to make up for days lost due to the five-day workweek, also found that 26 percent of the respondents are opposed to the idea. Among students, on the other hand, 43 percent under the age of 15 oppose the change, while 40 percent agree with the proposal.
Thirty percent of the respondents said the summer and winter vacations are too long or "just about enough," while 41 percent of those under 15 years of age think the vacations are too short.

Meanwhile, 47 percent said they are not satisfied with the newly implemented diversified enrollment program for college candidates and the academic proficiency examination for high school entry, showing that improvements and corrections should be made to the two policies.
Over 50 percent gave credit to Education Minister Ovid Tzeng, who assumed his post last May, but 26 percent believe that he could have done a better job, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC URGED TO STEP UP INFORMATION WARFARE RESEARCH

TEXT.P: The Republic of China should step up its information warfare research and craft an effective battle management system in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, a group of scholars said Saturday.
The academics made the call at a seminar on the outlook of relations across the Taiwan Strait, sponsored by the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI), a local privately funded think tank.
The scholars said that whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait move toward an arms race or peaceful co-existence will hinge on mainland China's mindset.

The participating scholars agreed unanimously that only when the military option is no longer a priority resort for mainland China to resolve cross-strait disputes can the two sides co-exist and prosper peacefully.

Liao Hung-hsiang, a TRI research fellow, said at the seminar that the ROC's current combat preparations focus on the acquisition of advanced weaponry systems and that the military has not yet developed a comprehensive command-control-communications-information and intelligence management system.
"This failure marks a serious drawback in our combat preparedness," Liao said, adding that in any future military conflict, information warfare will play a very critical role.
Against this background, Liao said, it is imperative that Taiwan forge a battle management system in its military buildup plan.
Another TRI fellow, Tsai Ming-yen, said Taiwan should not dance to mainland China's tune in arms procurement simply in order to avoid a cross-strait arms race.

Noting that Beijing's ongoing military modernization plan is aimed at making mainland China a regional superpower, Tsai said Taiwan need not follow in mainland China's footsteps regarding arms procurement. If it does, Tsai said, Taiwan will face a heavy financial burden and may trigger a cross-strait arms race.

In Tsai's view, Taiwan's current defense strategy should focus on building up a strong deterrent force. "Taiwan should have a strong combat capability to deter mainland China's provocation, and then the two sides can gradually forge confidence-building measures," he explained.

Speaking on the same occasion, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung, also a military expert, said that even though Taiwan has purchased a great deal of advanced military hardware, the skills for operating those weaponry systems have not matured due to the high turnover of military officers and enlisted men.
Ting suggested that military units should request foreign arms suppliers to transfer relevant technology and expertise when they purchase foreign-made weapons or military equipment.
With information warfare expected to play a key role in any future war, Ting said military units should intensify research in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL URGES BEIJING TO GIVE UP MISSILE DEPLOYMENTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 20 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: An official of the Republic of China's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said here Friday that a mainland Chinese renouncement of missile deployments opposite Taiwan would have positive effects on Taipei-Beijing relations.

Tien Hsin, director of the DPP's International Affairs Department, said after delivering a speech at St. John's University that mainland China cannot continue to increase its military budget and the number of missiles aimed at Taiwan while doing everything it can to prevent the island from acquiring weapons for its own defense.

In his speech titled "The DPP's Place in Cross-Strait Relations," Tien speculated that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are unlikely to engage in military conflict in the next few years because mainland China currently lacks the ability to guarantee a successful invasion of Taiwan.

He added that because the mainland considers economic development to be a priority objective, is preparing to enter the World Trade Organization, is seeking to host the 2008 Olympic Games and will complete a leadership transfer next year, maintaining a temperate cross-strait situation conforms to Beijing's interests.

Tien said that many observers mistakenly believe the DPP is happy to see friction and conflict between Beijing and Washington. He explained that the Taiwan Strait is the most sensitive region in the Asia Pacific, and that any conflict between Beijing and Washington would undoubtedly involve Taiwan. Such a scenario would not be beneficial to Taiwan, Beijing or Washington, he added.

Many observers also suspected that the DPP would seek Taiwan independence in a radical manner after taking power last May, Tien continued, claiming that the events of the past year have demonstrated that ROC President Chen Shui-bian's mainland China policy "has not raised any further skepticism."
Chen also clearly stated that Taiwan will not pursue independence because the island is in fact "already a sovereign nation" complete with people, land and a legal government, Tien added.

Tien said that the DPP is willing to consider "sacrificing a certain degree of sovereignty" in exchange for lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait under "reasonable conditions." He said that precedents exist such as the European Union, the British Commonwealth or other forms of federation systems. These are all issues that can be discussed in cross-strait political dialogue, he added.

Tien criticized Beijing for insisting on its "one country, two systems" proposal, which he said is in fact Beijing's attempt to have Taiwan give up its sovereignty in exchange for "Beijing's so-called peace."
He stressed that Taiwan will not accept this type of surrender.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FEMALE AIDS PATIENTS REPORTING RATE LOW: HEALTH OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A health official in charge of disease control said Saturday that the low reporting rate of female AIDS patients in Taiwan is a serious situation that should not be taken lightly.

Twu Shiing-jer, director-general of the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health, said that just 241 out of the 3,044 reported cases of HIV infection in Taiwan as of March 15 are women, representing a female-to-male ratio that is much lower than the world average.

The first case of female AIDS infection in the world was not discovered until 1982, after which the figure for female infection has been rapidly on the rise, he said in a speech delivered at a seminar to mark the 10th anniversary of the Republic of China Sex Education Association.

Twu noted that as of June 2000, 44 percent of the 33.6 million AIDS patients in the world are women, despite the fact that the disease was spread among male homosexuals in the early days of its existence. Today, he went on, the disease is spread predominantly through heterosexual behavior.
Physiologically, women are more susceptible to HIV than men and should therefore learn how to protect themselves from the threat of AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases, Twu said.

He noted that HIV transmission exhibits two major patterns. The first, a web-like pattern, is seen in regions such as Europe and North America, where greater respect for women's rights has led to approximately equal numbers of sexual partners for men and women. The virus is more easily controlled because it spreads out in a one-to-three, three-to-nine pattern, he said.

However, Twu continued, in Asian and African regions where gender inequality has resulted in greater acceptance for men to seek out prostitutes while women are looked down on for having multiple sexual partners, the second pattern of radically explosive infections centers around sex industry workers and is marked by a very rapid virus transmission rate that goes from one to 100, and then from 100 to 10,000.
Therefore, Twu stressed, it is urgent and important to elevate the level of women's rights in Asia to fight the spread of AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA CHAIRMAN TO SIGN COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH KITA
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 20 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) is scheduled to arrive in Seoul Sunday to sign a cooperation agreement with the Korea International Trade Association, local trade sources said Friday.
CETRA Chairman Shea Jia-dong will lead a delegation of CETRA officials to Seoul to attend a four-day meeting of the World Trade Center Association to be held April 23-26.
Shea will also discuss cybertrade and business-to-business opportunities with representatives of the Korean electronics and investment sectors.
Republic of China Representative to South Korea Lin Tsun-hsien will brief Shea on the current political and economic situation in South Korea.
Shea will later pay courtesy visits to South Korean business leaders to exchange views on bilateral trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TOBACCO, WINE STATUTE MAY TAKE EFFECT BEFORE JULY 1

TEXT.P: A new statute on tobacco and wine may be implemanted before July 1, sources from the Ministry of Finance said Saturday.
Under the new statute, the price of rice wine is expected to surge to NT$100 (US$3.04) per bottle, and NT$5 per pack may be added to the price of local cigarettes.

MOF sources said Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi and Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang agreed during a recent meeting to separate the date of implementation of the new regulations from Taiwan's World Trade Organization entry.

MOF officials said the implementation of the new statute will be scheduled by the Executive Yuan in the near future and stressed that customs duty on imported alcohol will be lifted before the new statute becomes valid.

After the implementation of the new statute, privately run wine businesses will be authorized to make various types of wines, but MOF officials predicted that because of taxes, prices for privately produced alcohol will not be too low.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS, SCHOLARS DISCUSS LABORATORY MEDICINE TRENDS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Saturday at an international seminar on laboratory medicine that biotechnology is a major area of interest to the Republic of China government.
He went on to say that the government will join forces with industry and academia to help increase the competitiveness of locally developed biotech products on the international market.
Improving the quality of medical services while lowering medical costs through the use of limited public and private resources is another major area of concern, he added.

At the seminar, organized by the ROC Association of Laboratory Medicine, local experts and scholars met with their colleagues from the United States, Germany, Japan, South Korea and Singapore to discuss recent development trends in laboratory medicine.

Association Chairman Kao Chuan-liang said that Taiwan's future laboratory medicine practices will become more centralized, so that the results of laboratory tests can be uniformly handled by computer. He added that easy-to-use disposable palm-top instruments will also be developed for some forms of laboratory testing.

Meanwhile, Tsi Wei-ming, director of the Tri Service General Hospital's clinical pathology department, said that laboratory management should be standardized in order to improve Taiwan's laboratory medicine system.

Chen Chuan-cheng, chairman of Meditech Biotechnology Co., which manufactures laboratory equipment, urged the government to provide local biotech companies with assistance at the institutional level so that the firms can produce quality wares for the international market.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Clinical Pathology Association Chairman Lee Cheng-hua called for a solution to the urgent problem of public misuse of laboratory medicine resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-UNIFICATION GROUP URGES OPPOSITION PARTIES TO MONITOR GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: A pro-unification organization urged Taiwan's three main opposition parties Saturday to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
The association for promoting peaceful unification of China Chairman Liang Su-jung made the call at a congress to mark the third founding anniversary of the organization.

Liang criticized the DPP for what he said is its failure to improve the nation's political and economic climate, evident in the economic slump, increased unemployment and strained cross-strait relations. He also claimed that a "vast crowd of people" now "understand that the DPP no longer has the ability to rule."
He urged the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party (PFP) and New Party (NP) to monitor the government and jointly oppose Taiwan independence.
Also present at the gathering were former Premier Hau Pei-tsun, NP heavyweight Hsu Li-nung and the association's Honorary Adviser Ma Shu-li.
At present, the pro-unification group has 78 branches worldwide that hold occasional activities to advocate its "three principles for the peaceful reunification of China."
The three principles are as follows:
-- Using the "one China" principle as the basis in the process of promoting peaceful reunification;
-- Creating an equal footing for both sides of the Taiwan Strait in cross-strait talks and cross-strait peaceful co-existence; and
-- No Taiwan independence and no military attack by mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD BE `LUBRICANT' BETWEEN PRC AND NEIGHBORS: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan should endeavor to forge dialogue and cooperative ties with mainland China's moderate forces so that it can become a "lubricant" between mainland China and other neighboring Asian countries, a ruling party official said Saturday.

Yen Chien-fa, director of the mainland China affairs department of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the pitch at a seminar on the outlook for relations across the Taiwan Strait sponsored by the Taiwan Research Institute, a privately funded think tank.
Yen said changing global economic trends have made Taiwan more vulnerable in the face of mainland China's competition for investment capital and technological expertise.

"And mainland China's squeeze on Taiwan's economic resources is expected to intensify after both sides are admitted to the World Trade Organization in the not-too-distant future and the opening of direct cross-strait trade, mail and transport links," Yen noted.
Against this backdrop, Yen said, Taiwan should carve out a niche as a "lubricant or bridge" between mainland China and its Asian neighbors instead of becoming the "detonator" of an "ammunition dump."

Yen went on to say that as Taiwan's new ruling party, the DPP has held out olive branches to cultivate friendly ties with the mainland, which has been hostile toward the DPP's previous pro-Taiwan independence stance.

"We are more than willing to hold peaceful dialogue and enter constructive cooperative programs with mainland China," Yen stressed, adding that by so doing, Taiwan will be in a better position to protect its own interests and security.

Yen further revealed that the DPP is working on various forward-looking cooperative projects to help boost cross-strait rapprochement. "We are hopeful that mainland China will drop its recalcitrant one-China principle to facilitate the development of constructive cross-strait interaction," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT KEEPS LOW PROFILE ON LEE'S JAPAN VISIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Presidential Office kept a low profile Saturday on Japan's 11th-hour decision to grant former ROC President Lee Teng-hui a visa on humanitarian grounds.
"We welcome the favorable Japanese decision, but we have no intention of politicizing the issue," said a Presidential Office official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The official further said the ROC government did not regard the Japanese move as a breakthrough in the already substantive relations between Taiwan and Japan.

After a week of heated debate, the Japanese government finally agreed late Friday to issue Lee an entry visa so that he could travel to Japan Sunday to receive treatment for a heart condition at a hospital in Kurashiki, a city near Osaka.
The decision immediately drew a strong protest from mainland China, which threatened to recall its ambassador to Japan and suspend exchanges of visits by their senior officials in protest.
Commenting on the mainland reaction, the Presidential Office official said mainland China need not adopt a hostile, "zero-sum" approach in handling relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"We don't regard the Japanese decision as a `victory' for Taiwan, nor do we regard it as a `loss' for the mainland," the official explained, adding: "We are hopeful that mainland China will not over-react to the issue and will refrain from giving it too many political ramifications."
Quoting President Chen Shui-bian, the official said mainland China should give Taiwan the "breathing room, even though it intends to trap the island in a corner."

The official further said that the Japanese government decided to issue Lee a visa mainly on humanitarian grounds. "We believe its decision meets the expectations of the ROC and Japanese general public," the official said, adding that other countries around the world would also recognize Japan's move, as humanitarianism is a universal value of all democratic countries.

Since Lee is now a private citizen, the official said, mainland China should ease off on the issue. "We hope Beijing's leaders will cope with the issue from humanitarian and human rights standpoints."
The official also expressed his hope that Taiwan, mainland China and Japan can work together to maintain peace, stability and prosperity in East Asia.

Meanwhile, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Lee's visa application is just an isolated case and is not expected to have a profound impact on triangular Taipei-Tokyo-Beijing relations.

Hsieh, who is also mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, said he hopes mainland China can draw inspiration from the issue and embrace the prevailing world trend of respecting freedom and humanitarianism.

"We also hope that the issue will not affect cross-strait interaction," Hsieh said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should increase exchanges to forge peaceful ties on a goodwill and reciprocal basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT TO LEAVE FOR JAPAN SUNDAY

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui is scheduled to leave for Japan Sunday to receive treatment for his heart problems at a hospital in a city near Osaka, sources said Saturday.

According to the sources, Lee will be accompanied by his wife, security staff and personal aides, including his most trusted protege Su Chih-cheng, deputy head of the Taiwan Research Institute, a privately-funded think tank.

Lee and his entourage will take a Japan Asia Airways (JAA) flight to Osaka, which is scheduled to takes off at 3:05 p.m. Sunday. Lee will undergo medical checkups at a hospital in the city of Kurashiki near Osaka on April 24 and is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 26.
Taiwanese business tycoon Peng Jung-tsu, who has helped arrange for Lee's Japan trip, already left for Osaka Saturday to make some preparations, sources said.
Lee retired last May after a 12-year stint as the ROC's head of state. He has since refrained from taking part in political activities.

JAA Taipei office staff said although Lee is now a private citizen, they will treat him as a VIP and will send additional stewardesses to serve on its EG212 flight that Lee and his entourage will take.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. UNDECIDED ON ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A White House spokesman said Friday that U.S. President George W. Bush has not decided on which arms it will sell to Taiwan.
Sean McCormack, a White House National Security Council spokesman, told CNA that "the president hasn't made any decision with regards to arms sale to Taiwan yet."
Republic of China Vice Chief of the General Staff General Huo Shou-yeh is scheduled to lead a delegation to the annual arms sales talks slated for April 24 in Washington, D.C.

Bush's national security team, including Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, Secretary of State Colin Powell and National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice, met earlier this week to discuss the recommendations for Bush on arms sales.
According to the New York Times, they have advised him to defer sales to Taiwan of four Arleigh-Burke destroyers equipped with the Aegis combat system.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REPS URGE BUSH TO SELL AEGIS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Two U.S. House representatives visiting Taiwan have urged President George W. Bush to approve the sale of the Aegis system, missile defenses and submarines to Taiwan.

"If we are to avoid escalated conflict with China, America must take this opportunity to show Beijing and the world we are as committed to the causes of maintaining peace and supporting democracy as we are to increasing trade," wrote Rep. Bob Schaffer (R-Colo.) and Rep. Roscoe G. Bartlett (R-Md.) in a letter sent from Taipei Friday.

After meeting Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen and other leaders during their one-week visit, they claimed that "Taiwan's legitimate need for U.S. destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar and weapons system is urgent. In fact, these naval-based defense systems top the Taiwanese wish list."

"Contrary to your advisers, the U.S. Navy has recommended the sale of Aegis to Taiwan and the Department of Defense has concluded that the Taiwanese have the ability to operate and integrate the complex system," said the congressmen.

"The truth is," they added, "this sale is about more than standing firm in the face of recent Chinese aggression. It is about maintaining balance and security in the Far East. It is about maintaining U.S. credibility with our Asian allies. It is about honoring our promise under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act by which the United States agreed to sell Taiwan the weapons needed to maintain an adequate self-defense."

They told Bush that perhaps the best reason to stand beside Taiwan at this critical juncture and authorize the sale of the Aegis system "is the fact it will strengthen the island's vibrant democracy and free-market system. An independent Taiwan bolsters the cause of freedom around the world and provides stability to countries such as Indonesia struggling for their own systems of democracy."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE VISA FOR ROC FORMER PRESIDENT ENRAGES MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Japan's decision to grant former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui a visa for medical treatment drew an angry response from mainland China, Canada's national broadcaster reported Friday.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) said mainland Vice-Foreign Minister Wang Yi summoned the Japanese ambassador to Beijing and told him that the visa "disrupted and sabotaged relations."
The CBC noted that Lee, who retired a year ago, drew the wrath of Beijing for his efforts to break Taiwan out of diplomatic isolation during his time in office.

It quoted Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono as saying that Lee has agreed not to engage in any political activity while in Japan, but he admitted that "Mr. Lee is a very influential person politically -- I think we are about to enter a very difficult period in our diplomatic relations with China."

Mainland China's Xinhua news agency left little doubt about that, the CBC pointed out. Xinhua said: "Lee, formerly a troublemaker in China-U.S. relations, is now coming out in the open as a troublemaker in China-Japan relations and a troublemaker for Asia-Pacific peace and stability."
Lee is expected to arrive in Osaka Sunday night, receive medical treatment Tuesday and return to Taiwan Thursday, the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PRESIDENT HOPING TO CREATE `HEMISPHERE OF LIBERTY'

TEXT.P: The streets of the Canadian city of Quebec were quiet Friday as U.S. President George W. Bush arrived for the Summit of the Americas Friday.
Visiting Canada for the first time as U.S. president, Bush was joining 33 other Western Hemisphere leaders to discuss what could be the world's largest free trade zone.
He first met with Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien and the two leaders discussed various bilateral concerns.

"Our goal in Quebec is to build a hemisphere of liberty," Bush told a news conference at the White House before leaving for Canada. "We must approach this goal in the spirit of civility, mutual respect and appreciation for our shared values."

Thousands of anti-free trade demonstrators marched the streets of the old city peacefully soon after Bush's arrival and some 6,500 police and 1,200 troops were deployed to control protesting crowds, some of whom were said to have gear such gas masks with them.

Fears of violence like that seen at international summits in Seattle and Windsor, Ontario, led officials to take unprecedented security measures, most notably erecting four kilometers of three-meter-high chain-link fence around the summit site.

DOC.HEADLINE: NP STALWART SEEKING PARTY'S NOMINATION FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTION

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party heavyweight Yu Mu-ming announced Saturday his intention to seek his party's nomination to run for the position of Taipei City's northern constituency legislator in the year-end legislative election.

Yu made the announcement at a press conference held at the party's National Election and Development Committee in which he claimed that the NP has a "clean image" that is "untarnished by links to gangsters and bribery." It is only internal disputes that have caused the party's "decline from prosperity," he said.
Yu, one of the founding members of the NP, urged people who love the NP to continue their support of the party.

He said he agrees with the idea of the joint selection of NP heavyweight Wang Chien-hsuen by the three main opposition parties as candidate for Taipei County magistrate, adding that by supporting the best talent, the opposition alliance can cooperate in the local mayor and magistrate elections, also scheduled to be held at the end of the year.
Meanwhile, former NP Legislator Lai Lai-kun also announced his intention to run for the position of Taoyuan County legislator in the legislative election.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS TAIWAN'S LIVING ENVIRONMENT GETTING BETTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's environmental misery index dropped 1.93 points this year from last year's 77.98 points, indicating that the living environment is getting better, according to a survey report released Saturday by the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF).

The telephone survey of 1,081 adults living on Taiwan was conducted by Gallup on behalf of the foundation in mid-April. The randomly selected respondents were asked to answer 24 questions about Taiwan's environmental problems, EQPF Secretary General Liu Ming-lung said.

The survey used the respondents' judgment on the seriousness of these problems to calculate the misery index. The problems included various kinds of air and water pollution from various sources; the disposal of garbage and used plastic products, and such kinds of public nuisance as noise and foul smell.

Liu said the overall misery index reached 76.05 points this year, slightly lower than a year ago. The indicators of all environmental problems, except the problem of killing wildlife, showed signs of improvement, he added.

The survey also separately calculated the environmental misery index of Taiwan's eight most populous areas: Taipei City, Kaohsiung City, Keelung City, Hsinchu City, Taichung City, Chiayi City, Tainan City, and Taipei County. Taipei County topped the list with 77.7 points this year, Liu said.

The same survey found that 51.5 percent of the respondents were in favor of holding a referendum at the end of this year to decide whether the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant should be continued, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
New poll shows support for Kuomintang's latest reforms is growing.
The China Times:
A special anti-graft panel of prosecutors is to be inaugurated July 1.
The United Daily News:
Grassroots prosecutors appeal for the dropping of special investigation teams of prosecutors.
The Liberty Times:
Lee departs for Japan, to be greeted by Japanese ministers.
The China Post:
Lee to leave for Japan today for treatment.
The Taiwan News:
Premier hopes fallout over Lee visa limited
The Taipei Times:
Travel warning infuriates mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER TO OPEN CONTACT WITH JAPAN'S RULING PARTY

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker is trying to form a group with lawmakers from Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to open a new contact channel between the two ruling parties, a local daily reported Sunday.

The United Daily News quoted DPP Legislator Tang Pi-o as saying the proposed Taiwan-Japan Political Elite Group is designed to bring together younger lawmakers and party officials from the two parties.

Although there is already an LDP Dietmen's Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship, Tang said, it's members are mostly senior lawmakers aged between 60 and 70, and its Republic of China members are mainly opposition Kuomintang lawmakers, while the new group will consist of younger DPP lawmakers and their LDP counterparts.

Younger LDP lawmakers, who according to Tang do not share "the historical burden" that saddles their senior colleagues, are less accommodating to Beijing politically and will keep an more open mind to engagement with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONCERT HELD IN MEMORY OF LATE VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A concert in memory of late Vice President Shieh Tung-min was held in Taipei Sunday, bringing together officials including President Chen Shui-bian, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People's First Party Chairman James Soong, as well as former President Lee Teng-hui.
Lien and President of Examination Yuan Hsu Shui-teh were invited to deliver a speech at the beginning of the concert to pay respect to Shieh's contributions to the country.
Shieh, who served as Taiwan provincial governor before being elected Vice President in 1978 as a running mate of Chiang Ching-kuo, retired after finishing his six-year term.
He died April 8 at the age of 95 and was cremated April 14. His ashes were interred at his family's cemetery plot in Changhua Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR JAPAN

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, accompanied by members of his family and several aides, left for Japan Sunday for heart treatment.
Lee will stay at the Imperial Hotel, Osaka, from where he will take the Hsinkansen bullet train to Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture the following day for treatment for his heart condition.

A number of government officials and civic leaders, including President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng and Secretary-General to the Presidential Office Yu Shyi-kun, were on hand to see Lee off at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
He is expected to return to Taiwan April 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT POLICY BASED ON PARTY RESOLUTION: DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Sunday that his party will handle Taiwan's relations with mainland China in compliance with the basic stance of its resolution on Taiwan independence before an internal consensus is reached with other DPP factions.

Hsieh made the remarks amid questioning from the local press following reports that Tien Hsin, director of the DPP's International Affairs Department, said in a speech Friday at St. John's University in New York that the DPP is willing to conditionally compromise some national sovereignty in exchange for lasting peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Tien was reported as saying that the two preconditions are "rationality" and "worthy acceptance" by the people of Taiwan.
Tien's remarks caused a great stir in the DPP, prompting DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen to contact Tien urgently and later deny that Tien's speech implies any such meaning.

Reluctant to elaborate further on the issue, Hsieh stressed that he had no advance knowledge of Tien's speech and added that the DPP's cross-strait policy will remain based on the party's resolution regarding Taiwan independence until such time as an internal party consensus on the issue can be forged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR WORRIED STATE-OWNED FIRMS MAY BE FINANCIAL `BLACK HOLE'

TEXT.P: Legislator Chen Chao-jung of the opposition People First Party said Sunday that state-owned enterprises have become the nation's financial "black hole."
Chen made the remarks on the eve of a legislative review of the budget of state-owned enterprises.

He described the budget presented by state-owned enterprises as "shocking," adding that between the latter half of 1999 and November 2000, nine state-owned enterprises lost a total of NT$30.718 billion (US$933.67 million).

Statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that the nine state-owned enterprises each lost between NT$203 million and NT$12.693 billion during the period. Among them, the Taiwan Railway Administration was the chief culprit, losing NT$12.693 billion.

Chen said the government should urgently tackle the budget problem, adding that it would be better to submit a comprehensive policy to solve the problem rather than simply making an across-the-board 5 percent cut in the budget for state-owned enterprises, as was recently suggested by another legislator.

He cited the example of Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp. as an example, saying that the company's paid-in capital is only NT$500 million, but it loses between NT$2 million and NT$3 million a day and stands to lose twice its paid-in capital in a year. This problem, he went on, will not be solved by simply cutting a certain percentage of its budget.

He further said that while money-losing corporations are problematic, those that show profit on paper also have an even bigger hidden problem, citing Taiwan Sugar Corp., whose budget proposal shows that it made a profit of NT$260 million, when in fact it actually lost NT$8.2 billion.

He said that Taisugar, often billed as the biggest landowner in Taiwan, collected revenues of NT$1 billion from rentals and NT$7 billion from the disposal of its land and questioned how such an operation could be described as profitable.

Accountant Lin Ching-lung also brought up Taisugar's bloated budget proposal, criticizing the presented budget as false and the profits as bloated. The state-owned budget proposals also lack professional evaluation, while their reinvestments have been losing large sums of money, he said, adding that their public relations budgets, research and material costs are too high and their internal management is poor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CELEBRATES EARTH DAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan joined in worldwide Earth Day celebrations Sunday with a multitude of events and activities around the island.

The Environment Protection Bureau under the Taipei city government held a rally in Taipei in conjunction with several other government agencies and private groups to raise public awareness of environmental issues and what citizens can do to protect the environment.
Speaking at the rally, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said environmental protection is not an alien concept to Chinese, rather it is inherent in the Chinese culture.

Ma cited several examples, pointing out that Chinese of the past admonished against fishing with small-mesh nets and advocated logging only in autumn, when trees have become dormant for the winter, adding that these ideas mesh with the concept of environmental protection.

Hau Lung-bin, administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration, said Taiwan is facing serious contamination and the easiest way for everybody to contribute to the protection of the island is to conserve energy.

Meanwhile, the Eco Conservation Alliance, a coalition of environmental groups, encouraged people to use public transport for an Car-Free Earth Day. One local diving club urged local divers to help clean up beaches and coral reefs around the island, while the Taiwan No-nuke Group organized an open forum in a Taipei park to discuss the hazards of nuclear energy.

Founded in 1970, Earth Day was launched internationally in 1990. Some 5,000 groups in 184 countries around the world celebrated the day this year by holding rallies, fairs, conferences and other events to raise awareness of critical environmental issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE HONORED BY ALMA MATER

TEXT.P: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning was honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century Sunday in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by National Tsinghua University, his alma mater.

At a ceremony marking the university's 90th founding anniversary, Tsinghua President Liu C.L. presented a medal to honor one of the university's most well-known graduates, who graduated in 1942 and won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1957.
Liu lauded Yang as not only the pride of the university, but also the pride of all Chinese.
The ceremony was also attended by Wang Dazhong, president of Tsinghua University in Beijing, which is considered the origin of Tsinghua in Hsinchu.

Speaking at the ceremony, Wang said 50 students from Beijing's Tsinghua University will study at Tsinghua University in Hsinchu this autumn under a new student exchange program between the two sides while about 10 students from Tsinghua University in Hsinchu will go to Tsinghua in Beijing for a two-week period of practical training.
An exchange of teachers will begin next year, Wang added.
Liu attended a similar ceremony at Beijing's Tsinghua University earlier this month to mark the 90th founding anniversary of the school.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE CITY WELCOMES VISIT BY FORMER ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Kurashiki, April 22 (CNA) (By K. M. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Amid extensive media coverage, people of this Japanese city have welcomed former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's visit to receive a heart checkup here.

Local tourist associations said they welcome Lee's visit to Kurashiki because of the huge amount of publicity it has generated in the media. Some Kurashiki residents said they are not surprised that Lee chose to undergo medical treatment at a local hospital, which they said is a high-level medical institution famous for its cardiac, liver and rehabilitation departments.

Kirashiki, a popular tourist resort located about one-hour's drive from the major city of Osaka and some 600 kilometers west of Tokyo, attracts around 4 million tourists each year because of its traditional buildings located in the old city center.

Lee's plan to undergo a medical checkup for heart condition at the Kurashiki hospital has aroused strong protests from Beijing, which warned Tokyo that what it described as a "politically motivated trip" will undercut bilateral relations.

Despite fierce opposition from Beijing and disagreement from Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono, outgoing Japanese Premier Yoshiro Mori made a final decision late Friday to issue Lee a visa allowing him travel to Japan on humanitarian considerations.
Lee left for Japan Sunday afternoon and is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR JAPAN

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, accompanied by his wife and a group of aides, left Sunday for Japan to undergo treatment for a heart condition.

Lee took a Japan Asia Airways (JAA) flight to Osaka and was scheduled to arrive at Kansei International Airport Sunday evening. He will receive a medical checkup at the Central Hospital of Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture on Tuesday and is expected to return to Taiwan April 26.

Those on hand at the airport to see Lee off included President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Yu Shyi-kun, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and former Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Huang Kun-huei.
The former head of state declined to answer reporters' questions before departing.
The Japanese government issued an entry visa for Lee last Friday, drawing immediate criticism from Beijing, which has always been opposed to Lee making overseas trips.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS, EXPERTS SEE NO SIGN OF POLITICAL PARTY RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Local scholars and political experts said Sunday that there are no indications that Taiwan's political parties will undergo reshuffles prior to the year-end legislative elections.
However, they added, reshuffles might take place after the elections.
They further claimed that if the political parties undergo reshuffles, it will weaken the power of the opposition parties to monitor the government.

Legislator Lin Chih-chia (KMT-Taipei County) said that according to an unofficial estimate, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) might obtain 80 seats in the legislative elections, with the People First Party (PFP) taking 40 seats.
He added his opinion that if the tiny New Party cannot get sufficient votes, the domestic political map will be dominated by the KMT and the DPP with a PFP minority.
The pro-former ROC President Lee Teng-hui faction within the KMT will continue to support incumbent Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng for a second term, he went on.
Predicting that the KMT will win more legislative seats, Lin added that the chance of a coalition government between the KMT and DPP will be greater than the chance of a DPP-PFP partnership.
He also said it is unlikely that the KMT and PFP will cooperate in the year-end elections.
Legislator Chen Hung-chi (KMT-Taipei City) said that party reshuffle is still at the talking stage and if it were to occur, it would not be until after the elections.
Chen claimed that the current political instability is chiefly a result of the Chen administration's lack of confidence and the fact that the DPP-led government has always shirked its responsibility.

He cited Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan as an example, speculating that Chen's reshuffle of 21 chief prosecutors around the island was the result of pressure from the Legislative Yuan and adding that the Legislative Yuan should demand that Chen step down if the rumor is true. The domestic political unrest has come about because the DPP, as a minority, is trying to confront the majority in the legislature..

Former Taipei Mayor Huang Ta-chow pointed out that the opposition monitors the ruling party which is a normal situation in a democratic country. Huang further predicted that a party reshuffle would further weaken the opposition's power to monitor.
Professor Huang Teh-fu of National Chengchi University said that whether or not a reshuffle of political parties will be carried out will be decided by the election votes and not by the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECTOR ANG LEE RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: Taiwan director Ang Lee of the Oscar-winning film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" returned to Taiwan from the United States Sunday.

Lee was warmly greeted by Chiang Chuan-ching, director of the Motion Picture Affairs Department under the Government Information Office (GIO) and throngs of media upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
Lee brought with him the first Oscar ever won by a Taiwan film, telling local reporters that he wanted to share his joy with the people of Taiwan.

He said that "Crouching Tiger," which garnered four Oscars for best foreign-language film, best art direction, best cinematography and best original music, was the effort of many people and that he was proud to see so many Chinese mounting the stage to get their Oscars.

But he also said that although the Oscar ceremony was held in March, the campaign to win the golden statuette actually started much earlier, adding that his Oscar campaign actually started last August, when he began traveling to various places in the United States to take part in Oscar-related activities.
He described himself as an election candidate to explain the film's Oscar bid, adding that winning the Oscar is a "love and hate" experience.
Asked whether he will shoot another film with Oscar potential, he said he planned to shoot films "for himself and for his audience."

As for his failure to win the Oscar for best director, Lee said he had done his best, and did not care about anything else. He received the best director award from the Directors' Guild of America, which is usually won by the director who later goes on to win the Oscar.

Lee, whose film credits also include "The Wedding Banquet," "Sense and Sensibility" and "The Ice Storm," returned to his hometown of Tainan shortly after his press conference, where he will celebrate his mother's 76th birthday, visit his high school alma mater, National Tainan First High School and speak to the students there.
Lee will also donate to the school a check for NT$1 million given by the GIO to encourage film workers who win internationally prestigious awards.
President Chen Shui-bian, who also attended the same high school, is scheduled Tuesday to present Lee with an award for winning the Oscar.
Lee will leave Taiwan for Hong Kong April 27 to attend a film award ceremony in which "Crouching Tiger" has been nominated in 15 categories and is expected to be a big winner.
From Hong Kong, he will proceed to mainland China before returning to the United States to work on his new film "The Hulk," a high-tech action film filled with special effects.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FORMER PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN 0SAKA
DOC.DATELINE: Osaka, April 22 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui arrived Sunday at Japan's Kansei International Airport in Osaka, where he received a warm welcome from more than 1,000 well-wishers.
