Although Lee has been a private citizen since leaving office last May, the Japanese authorities are treating him as a very important person and he had a security detail to accompany him to his hotel.
Lee waved to people who turned out along the road from the airport, many of whom -- both Japanese and overseas Taiwanese -- bore placards to welcome the ROC former president.
Lee will have tight security throughout his visit, which is being covered by more than 200 reporters.

He is expected to visit a Japanese national flower show Monday before receiving a heart checkup Tuesday at the Central Hospital of Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture. Kawakira Mitzufuji, a renowned Japanese heart specialist, will conduct the examination.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD MULLING EXCLUSION OF FOREIGN LABORERS FROM WAGE PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The head of the nation's highest economic planning agency said over the weekend that he is working on proposals to take basic wage protection away from foreign laborers, a local newspaper reported Sunday.

China Times reported that Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Saturday that under his proposal, foreign laborers will no longer be protected by the nation's basic wage, which currently stands at NT$15,840 (US$481.45) per month.
Chen also said that a recently unveiled NT$810-billion government project to expand domestic demand will make it mandatory that domestic employers hire local laborers where possible.
Chen said that under the double strain of the changing international economic situation and shortened working hours, the domestic unemployment rate is high and might continue to rise.
He predicted boldly that the room for upward adjustment of wages for Taiwan low-technology workers will be limited, considering the fact that the nation is entering an information-led economic era.
He said that Taiwan workers now face steep competition from developing countries and added that "even if they work hard, they will not necessarily win."
Chen was echoing an earlier proposal by Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi earlier, who also urged the scrapping of the basic wage.

Chen said that the intention of the basic wage is to protect the basic rights of laborers, but considering the fact of high living cost in Taiwan, it is not unreasonable for local laborers to enjoy a minimum basic wage.

However, he went on, as the families of foreign laborers are mostly overseas where living costs lower than in Taiwan, there is "room for discussion" as to whether the foreign laborers should be given equal treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PHYSICIST AWARDED BY OCPA

TEXT.P: A physicist from Taiwan has been acclaimed as the 2000 winner of the "Outstanding Young Research Award" by the Overseas Chinese Physics Association (OCPA).

Ma Chung-pei, 34, told CNA in a telephone interview that she felt very happy to be awarded by the OCPA, which sponsors the event every year to encourage young overseas Chinese talent in excellent performance in physics.

Ma, who earned a doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and has been an assistant professor at the Pennsylvania State University since 1996, is slated to receive the prize April 28 in Washington from the OCPA, which is composed of outstanding Chinese physicists based overseas, such as Nobel laureates Yang Chen-ning and Lee Cheng-tao.

Ma has received various awards in the past, such as the Annie J. Cannon Award in Astronomy in 1997, and the Alfred P. Sloan Fellowship and Cottrell Scholars Award in 1999, in recognition of her remarkable research work. She was also the winner of the Lindback Award for Distinguished Teaching from among more than 1,000 teachers in Pennsylvania in 1998.
In addition to her advanced studies in physics, Ma is also an aficionado of the violin and won first prize in a Taiwan provincial violin competition at the age of 17.

Despite her busy schedule in the United States, Ma usually returns to Taiwan every three months to take part in a research project conducted by Academia Sinica's Institute of Physics, the results of which, Ma said, will be a major international breakthrough.
Born into a liberal family, Ma attributes her success to her parents, saying that ever since she decided at the age of 12 to be a physicist, both her parents fully respected her wishes.

Ma's father, Ma Chi-shen, is a well-known journalist, while her mother, Huang Chao-heng, is also a journalist who also had served as a member of the Republic of China Control Yuan, the nation's highest-level watchdog organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT TO BYPASS 'ONE CHINA' ISSUE: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has no intention to bypass the "one China" issue and is willing to talk with Beijing over the issue after an internal consensus is forged, said Tsai Ing-wen, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, Sunday.

Differences have always existed between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits over certain sensitive issues, sending cross-strait ties into stalemate, said Tsai in her speech delivered at Po Chung Foundation.

That is the reason that ROC President Chen Shui-bain has proposed that both sides shelve their disputes in accordance with the "1992 spirit" -- referring to a tacit agreement reached between Taiwan and the mainland -- so as to engage in dialogues ad communications, she added.

She urged Beijing to understand that "one China" is neither a slogan nor a simple concept, but rather it represents a very serious question -- the ROC has been existing, a fact that Beijing has been refused to face and admit.

Furthermore, Tsai added, internationally, Beijing has tried its best to boycott the presence of Taiwan in the international community. In the few international organizations that Taiwan is allowed to take part, Beijing has insisted that Taiwan's national name, constitution, official titles of its president and premier cannot appear in the official records of the organizations.
Analyzing Beijing moves, Tsai said it is attempting to "depoliticize" the ROC, and to turn it into a de facto economic or social entity.
Therefore, She added, Taiwan cannot but take certain immediate measures to counter Beijing's offense, otherwise, it will disappear politically.

She pointed out that the great differences over the political, economic and cultural developments of the two sides will inevitably bring about many misunderstandings and problems, which she said can only be minimized through negotiations by the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Ex-ROC President Lee Teng-hui arrived in Japan to hero's welcome by Taiwan expatriates.
The China Times:
Lee kept low profile as he arrived in Japan for medical trip.
The United Daily News:

The Liberty Times:

The China Post:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 23, or the first day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: American Professor Robert Polhill is released in Beirut after being held in captivity for 39 months by Islamic fundamentalist groups.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the situation across the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential vote.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS CALL FOR RATIONAL HANDLING OF MP3 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: A group of university students Monday called for the government and society to rationally deal with the April 11 MP3 campus search incident and its aftermath.

In a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, students from National Cheng Kung University, Fu Jen Catholic University, Tamkang University and Taipei Medical College called for a complete re-evaluation of copyright and Internet-related laws so as to adequately protect the interests of the original authors of software and the rights of users.

In a joint statement, the students explicitly expressed their dissatisfaction with Tainan prosecutors' entering Cheng Kung University campus April 11 and seizing 14 computers owned by students accused of downloading MP3 files.

They criticized related agencies, including the Ministry of Education, for immediately judging that the 14 students were guilty of breaking the law at a time when "society is still debating" whether the act of downloading MP3 files from the Internet is illegal.
The students voiced their opposition to law enforcement authorities "raiding" college dormitories before copyright and Internet-related laws are fully reviewed and amended.

They said if prosecutors or police have to enter a campus to conduct similar investigations, they must follow lawful procedures. Campus authorities should have the right to bar prosecutors or police from entering if they follow illegal procedures, the students added.

They also suggested that the Ministry of Education, education institutions and related companies team up to work out measures and policies serving to protect intellectual property rights as well as lessening students' financial burdens when using copyright-protected computer software.

Tainan prosecutors' April 11 raid on a Cheng Kung University dormitory to seize 14 computers with downloaded MP3 files, which prosecutors considered illegal, has focused public attention on the intellectual property rights issue, police enforcement procedures and the government's attitude toward the issue.

Another group of university students from around the island, which calls itself the Taiwan Democratic Student Movement Alliance, lodged a protest against the Ministry of Education last Friday, accusing the ministry of allowing prosecutors to "illegally" enter the Cheng Kung University dormitory and "arrest" students.

The alliance also accused the ministry of enforcing a large-scale crackdown on campus Web sites containing MP3 files, as if the ministry were a "police headquarters for the sole use of interest groups."

The "interest group" they were referring to was the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI), which represents the music industry. The IFPI's Taiwan branch office was quick to throw its weight behind the April 11 search operation and even went so far as to say that it will settle for nothing less than the conviction of the offenders.

In an open letter to the Ministry of Justice, the student alliance claimed that most countries are still debating whether corporate and organizational users should be included in the scope of punishment for intellectual property rights "violations." The debate has yet to expand to cover individual users, such as students, the alliance said.
In related news, three members of the Control Yuan, the top watchdog body in the Republic of China, traveled south to Tainan City to look into the campus search incident themselves.

The Control Yuan members will meet with Cheng Kung University President Kao Chiang, the 14 students accused of illegally downloading MP3 files and the Tainan prosecutors in order to further familiarize themselves with the situation.

Meanwhile, Kuomintang Legislator Mu Min-chu, who is the convenor of the Legislative Yuan's Education Committee, urged the Executive Yuan to accelerate the formation of an inter-division ad hoc group to exclusively examine and review the Copyrights Law and related statutes so as to prevent similar incidents from reoccurring.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 1.07 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 1.07 points to close at 5,597.7.
Market turnover amounted to NT$57.5 billion (US$1.75 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT'S JAPAN VISIT ANGERS BEIJING: CBC

TEXT.P: The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. reported Sunday that former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui has arrived in Japan for medical treatment and that "his visit has drawn anger from Beijing.
The CBC said Lee will undergo five days of medical examinations at a hospital in Kurashiki, about 600 kilometers west of Tokyo.
Beijing had urged Japan not to grant Lee a visa, the national broadcaster said, adding that "China is nervous he might try to promote the cause of Taiwan independence.
It quoted an editorial in the Saturday edition of mainland China's People's Daily as saying that permitting the visit would have strong repercussions.
"Allowing him to go to Japan will inevitably damage Sino-Japanese ties and further hurt the feelings of the Chinese people," the editorial said.
Relations between Tokyo and Beijing have been difficult at the best of times, but have become increasingly strained over the past few months, according to the CBC.
Trade disputes over cheap mainland Chinese vegetables and the knowledge that the ill-fated U.S. reconnaissance plane took off from a base in Japan have increased tensions, it noted.

But it is Lee, according to mainland China, that is the real cause of the disagreement, the CBC said, quoting the Xinhua news agency as saying that "Lee is the chief representative of Taiwan separatism and the saboteur of stability in the Taiwan Strait."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA MUM ON AIT PERSONNEL RESHUFFLE REPORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) declined to make any comment Monday on a local newspaper report that Douglas Paal, a former White House national security aide, may be the next U.S. representative to the Republic of China.
MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said it is the ministry's established policy to refrain from making any comment on speculation about any U.S. government personnel reshuffle.

Chang further said that the MOFA has not yet received any information about a possible shakeup of the leadership of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents U.S. interests in the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

The Taipei-based China Times daily reported Monday that Paal, who served as senior director of the Asian affairs department of the White House National Security Council during the era of former President George Bush, may replace Raymond Burghardt as the AIT Taipei office chief. Chang would not confirm the report, but she said that Paal is familiar with the ROC's general situation and maintains extensive ties with Taiwan's academic community.

Chang went on to point out that communication channels between the ROC and the United States have operated smoothly and that the new Bush administration has reaffirmed its commitment to upholding the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and honoring its relevant promises to the ROC. The TRA is the U.S. law governing relations with the ROC in the absence of official ties.
As to the outlook for the development of ROC-U.S. relations, Chang said the MOFA adopts a "cautious optimistic" attitude toward the future development of substantive Taipei-Washington ties.
A CNA report from San Francisco said U.S. government authorities have not confirmed the Taiwan media report about Paal's new post in Taiwan.
The China Times dispatch from Washington, D.C. said if all goes smoothly, Paal is likely to assume the post of the de facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan this summer.

According to the report, the Taipei assignment will be a stint full of challenges and opportunities for Paal. Paal reportedly has many friends in Taipei, including Kao Ying-mao, an adviser to the ROC's National Security Council.

Political observers said Paal is an active, sophisticated and quick-witted Asian affairs expert. Some analysts said Paal's active and no-nonsense working style may give Taipei some pressure if he takes office here. Nevertheless, they said Paal is basically friendly to Taiwan and concerned about Taiwan's development.

The China Times report said although Paal does not support immediate U.S. sales of the advanced Aegis radar-equipped destroyers to Taiwan, he has advocated the sale of diesel-powered submarines to the island.
The report further said Paal will be an active and competent U.S. representative to Taiwan and could even help break the current cross-Taiwan Strait stalemate.

Paal, now in his 50s, graduated from the Ivy Legaue school Brown University, with Asian history as his major. He first worked with the Central Intelligence Agency and then with the Department of State. He also once worked at the U.S. embassies in Singapore and mainland China. He joined the White House National Security Council in 1987 to take charge of Taiwan, mainland China and Asian affairs.

Paal left public services after former President Bush lost his reelection bid in 1992. He then set up a non-profit think tank focusing on Asian-Pacific policy research center. During the past few years, he has made several trips to Taiwan for attending seminars or delivering speeches. In addition to speaking mandarin Chinese, Paal is also versed in Japanese.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 1.07 points to close at 5,597.7.
The bourse opened at 5,607.46 and fluctuated between 5,612.69 and 5,562.67 during trading.

A total of 1.58 billion stocks worth NT$57.5 billion (US$1.75 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.17 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$84.42 billion (US$2.57 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with cement stocks moving up the most at 0.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.3 percent. Electrical shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories lost ground, with construction stocks and foodstuff shares moving down the most, both at 0.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent, and textile issues at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 265 to 237, with 85 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO PROMOTE TRADE WITH CENTRAL AMERICAN DIPLOMATIC ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has drawn up a plan to promote bilateral trade between the Republic of China and its Central American diplomatic allies, the Board of Foreign Trade under the MOEA said Monday.
In coordination with ROC President Chen Shui-bian's scheduled visit to Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America, the MOEA has mapped out a plan to enhance two-way trade and investment.

The Board of Foreign Trade and the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will also jointly host a food and agricultural products fair in The Mall in Taipei June 22 to introduce products from the Central American countries in the hope of helping boost their exports to the island, officials from the board said.

Officials added that bilateral trade between the ROC and Central American countries totaled US$2.8 billion last year, with ROC exports and imports amounting to US$2.15 billion and US$650 million respectively.

The bilateral trade plan is aimed at helping the Central American countries export their products to the ROC to help balance out the latter's trade surplus, which amounted to US$1.5 billion last year, according to the board.

Meanwhile, officials said a visiting delegation, comprised of delegates from El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Panama, the Dominican Republic, Belize and Paraguay, will participate in a food and beverage exhibition to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center June 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM'S FIRST QUARTER PRE-TAX PROFITS TOP NT$10 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Chunghwa Telecom Co. Ltd. gained pre-tax profits totaling NT$11.6 billion (US$362 million) in the first quarter of 2001, according to a report released Monday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The report, submitted to the technology and information committee of the Legislative Yuan, also predicted that the telecom company will reach its set goal for 2001 of NT$12.7 billion in total profits.

MOTC Executive Vice Minister Ho Cheng-tan said that as Taiwan's telecom sector has aimed at greater variety and as the market has been opened to greater competition, Chunghwa Telecom has also improved itself through a more effective marketing strategy, better customer service, and more reasonable rates.

According to the statistics, the telecom company's total revenue for the first quarter was NT$45.47 billion, nearly attaining the company's estimated target of NT$46 billion. The company's actual expenses for the first quarter amounted to NT$34.9 billion, surpassing the company's estimated expenses of NT$32.2 billion.
An additional NT$900 million in revenue covered the extra NT$400 million in spending. Both figures were excluded from the company's income and expense budget, according to the report.

The company's pre-tax profits were estimated at NT$12.7 billion, while the actual expenses totaled NT$11.6 billion, or 20.48 percent of the annual pre-tax profit budget, making the company confident it will meet its income goal for this year, Ho suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May moved up 56 points to close at 5,644, with 4,994 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June rose 59 points to finish at 5,649, with 13 contract transactions, while December futures increased 144 points to close at 5,800, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,588 for May, 5,590 for June, 5,650 for September, 5,656 for December, and 5,735 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally higher.
May TE futures rose 2.8 points to finish at 287.8, with 1,231 contract transactions, while June TE futures moved up 2.6 points to close at 288.9, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures increased 6 points to finish at 727, with 404 contract transactions, while June TF futures lost 2.8 points to close at 729.8, with one contract traded.
September TF futures rose 47.4 points to finish at 726.4, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIONS APPEAL TO PRESIDENT CHEN TO PROTECT LOCAL WORKERS' RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Members of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions appealed to President Chen Shui-bian Monday to consider allowing only local workers to be hired for government-sponsored infrastructure development projects.

The trade union representatives, joined by members of the Taiwan Unemployed Workers and Employment Promotion Alliance, took the issue of the plight of local workers to the streets, saying the problems facing local workers include rising unemployment as a result of the increasing number of foreign laborers being introduced into the Taiwan market.

At a rally in front of the Presidential Office, the protesters called for President Chen to give them a positive response May 1 to their appeal for the government to use only local workers in its NT$810 billion worth of public construction projects.
They appealed to Chen to honor his promise made during the presidential election campaign to see to it that the number of foreign laborers is reduced on a yearly basis.

The trade unions and unemployed workers' representatives called for Chen to offer a positive response to their appeals May 1, the first Labor Day since Chen was inaugurated as the ROC president on May 20, 2000, by announcing a cut by 15,000 in the number of foreign laborers beginning May 1.

Kuo Kuo-wen, secretary-general of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions, quoted the latest government tallies as indicating that Taiwan's unemployment rate surged to 3.89 percent in March, up 0.16 percent from the previous month, to a single-month record high.
According to an official from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan's jobless rate is expected to shoot up to 4 percent in the second quarter of this year, Kuo said.

He disclosed that members of the confederation will again join Unemployed Alliance representatives to stage a demonstration in front of the Presidential Office on Labor Day, calling for President Chen to face squarely the problem of rising unemployment and provide effective ways to solve it.

Kuo added that nearly a year after Chen took office, the Taiwan public has witnessed a rising unemployment rate and a slumping economy along with a plummeting stock market and ongoing political uncertainty.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR CRITICIZES GOVERNMENT'S DOUBLE-DEALING ON NUKE PLANT ISSUE

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) on Monday criticized the government for its double-dealing methods concerning the issue of the fourth nuclear power plant.
PFP Legislator Hsieh Chang-chief said that although the ruling government reluctantly announced the resumption of construction on the nuclear plant Feb. 14, work has not actually restarted.

Hsieh, speaking at a press conference where he called the move a government trick, said that such an approach will not only force the nation into facing steep compensation claims, it may even cause the nation's economy to collapse.

Chen Meng-jung, president of the Self Assistance Association of state-owned Taiwan Power Co., and Hsu Yueng, representative of Taipower's private shareholders, said at the same press conference that they went to the site of the partially completed plant in Kungliao, Taipei County last Thursday.

They said that when they arrived at their destination, they found the site empty, with no workers or machinery present. They also noted that construction was at the same stage as it was last October when the DPP government abruptly announced a halt to construction.

Legislator Chen also said that if several local contractors cannot resume work before May 12, then Taipower will terminate their contracts and ask for compensation. He noted that the new bidding process that would result would delay construction even longer, adding that foreign contractors might then want to claim even higher amounts of compensation from Taipower.

Chen said that the abrupt decision to halt construction unleashed pent-up political squabbling and also caused Taiwan's economy to worsen, adding that the government has still not learned a lesson and is still resisting resumption of construction on the nuclear plant despite its promise to restart work.

Meanwhile, legislators of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party have expressed their opposition to Taipower listing its NT$3.177 billion (US$96.56 million) in losses stemming from suspension of construction in this year's budget expenses.
KMT legislators Ting Shou-chung, Chao Erh-chung, Liao Hwu-peng, and Wang Tein-qing have all spoken out against Taipower listing the losses in its budget.
Taipower estimated that its losses amounted to NT$3.489 billion during the suspension of construction, including NT$312 million in interest payments.

Legislator Chao said that the government's decision to resume construction had demonstrated that halting construction was a mistake, adding that Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi did not voice a word of apology throughout the process, instead wanting Taipower to absorb the losses, which Chao added may also lead to rising electricity rates.
Other legislators echoed his words, saying that Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Lin must apologize.
As no consensus could be reached on the issue, the legislators have decided to send the issue of Taipower's losses of NT$3.177 billion listing in its budget to the legislative floor for discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH IN TAIWAN MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION HITS 26-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's manufacturing sector production fell by 4.95 percent in the first three months of this year as compared with the same period last year, marking the slowest growth since the first oil crisis struck the world in 1975.

Amid worldwide economic sluggishness, Taiwan's industrial and manufacturing production posted apparent reductions in the first quarter as a result of diminished foreign trade, said Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the Statistics Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Taiwan's manufacturing production figures are not expected to make a turn for the better in the second quarter. Chang noted that the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association of Philadelphia recently forecast that global trade will decrease further, consequently affecting Taiwan's industrial and manufacturing sectors.

According to tallies compiled by the MOEA's Statistics Department, export orders received by Taiwan exporters and manufacturers totaled US$12.5 billion in March, down 1.12 percent from the same month of 2000 but increasing by 16.79 percent from January this year.

In March, Taiwan's industrial production posted a reduction of 4.38 percent from the same month last year, while the figure for the first three months dropped by an annual 4.17 percent. Meanwhile, manufacturing production in March fell by 5.6 percent from the same month of 2000 but increased by 12.59 percent from February this year. Cumulatively, Jan.-March manufacturing production posted a decline of 4.95 percent from the same quarter of the previous year.

In a recent Taiwan manufacturing sector survey on export order prospects made by the Statistics Department, about 26 percent of manufacturers think export orders in April will be better in value and quantity than those in March, 44.16 percent say the business will remain unchanged in April, and nearly 30 percent say export orders will decrease in April.

Citing that Taiwan's foreign trade and industrial as well as manufacturing output are closely linked to the economic situations in the United States and Japan, Chang said the island's growth is expected to remain in a low ebb during the second quarter as there are no signs that the economies of Taiwan's two largest trading partners will recover in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA, IBM TO SIGN COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will sign a cooperation memorandum with IBM, the world's leading computer company, to develop industrial technology and new information appliances, the MOEA announced Monday.
MOEA officials said that by the end of 2000, Taiwan's IA production value had reached US$1.3 billion, which they predicted would grow by 63.3 percent by 2003.

While the global PC market growth has slowed, the Internet and telecommunications industries have been growing rapidly. The MOEA officials stressed that Taiwan's top-notch PC-making skills are extremely beneficial to the IA sector, which has become another major focus of the island's information technology and telecommunications development.
Under the terms of the memorandum, IBM will provide the technology when cooperating with Taiwan on IA research and development.

Meanwhile, IBM will also establish a research and exhibition center in Taiwan to help local IA manufacturers effectively utilize the new technologies, such as "embedded solution" software, when producing the high-tech information appliances.
Taiwan's people will be able to see the new IA products starting May 2, according to MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR CLOSES UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed unchanged at 32.890 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday.
The local currency opened Monday at 32.878 and was traded between 32.878 and 32.918.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$239 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew, business tycoon Morris Chang, and other high profile figures will visit mainland China next month, a major local newspaper reported Monday.

United Daily News said that Siew and Chang, chairman and CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), and others have launched a foundation to establish a common market across the Taiwan Strait and are planning to visit the mainland in their capacity as foundation officials.
They are scheduled to visit Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen before returning to Taiwan May 15.
Sources said that Siew is still consulting with related government agencies on the details of the trip.

Officials said that the Executive Yuan has no particular view on Siew's trip to the mainland. But they said that as Siew is currently the vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, they do want to communicate with him on the itinerary of his trip.

The officials added that the timing of Siew's trip should not be too close to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's current visit to Japan, in order to avoid sensitive issues during Siew's mainland trip and give added trouble to President Chen Shui-bian's planned visit to ROC allies in June.
Beijing has reacted angrily to Japan's granting of a visa to the former ROC president.
Reports also said that they hope Siew and the business leaders in the group will refrain from going to politically sensitive Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EXPECTS TO TAKE 82-100 LEGISLATIVE SEATS IN YEAREND ELECTION

TEXT.P: Officials of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Monday that the party expects to win 82 to 100 legislative seats in the elections scheduled to be held at the end of the year.

Speaking at an inner party meeting on the layout of the yearend legislative and local mayoral and magisterial elections, Chao Shou-po, head of the KMT's Organization Development Committee, gave the estimate of the number of seats the party expects to take. The meeting was convened by KMT Chairman Lien Chan.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, another KMT heavyweight predicted that the party could win 80 to 95 legislative seats in the elections.

Wang also confirmed that one or two KMT legislators are considering bolting from the party to join other political parties. The KMT is now actively working to persuade them to give up the idea, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI 3 LINKS' PROGRAM TO BE ADJUSTED: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The "mini three links" program will be properly adjusted to some extent to meet the demand of residents of the Republic of China-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, a senior official in charge of mainland China affairs said Monday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the remarks during an inspection tour of Kinmen aimed at soliciting the opinions of local government officials, elected representatives and civic leaders about the "mini three links" program.
Taiwan took the initiative to open its two offshore defense outposts for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian province at the beginning of this year.

Tsai said more than three months after the implementation of the "open-door" measure, commonly known as the "mini three links" program, some practical issues have surfaced. "Therefore, we must conduct an overall review and make necessary policy and technical adjustments to meet market demand and facilitate development of our two offshore islands."

Tsai assured Kinmen county government officials and councilors that the MAC will finalize its policy review as soon as possible. Nevertheless, she refrained from giving a concrete timetable for adjustments.

"In addition to evaluating the opinions of Kinmen officials and ordinary residents, we must also take into account the capacity of relevant administrative agencies and existing hardware and software as well as the current state and atmosphere of cross-Taiwan Strait relations," Tsai explained.

Responding to a demand by Kinmen lawmakers and officials that the central government unilaterally allow Kinmen and Matsu to serve as transit ports for mainland China-bound goods and passengers from Taiwan, Tsai said the MAC will give the proposal favorable considerations, particularly cargo transshipment.

Under current regulations, only those who have registered legal abodes in Kinmen or Matsu, both of which lie closer to Fujian province than to Taiwan, for at least six months can make direct voyages to the mainland.

Many Kinmen county officials and councilors have urged the central government to lift the ban to allow Taiwan residents to enjoy the same privilege of traveling directly from Kinmen to Xiamen. In response, Tsai said the government is worrying that once the ban is lifted, the two offshore islands may have a large number of "phantom population" which would in turn affect local politics.

Nevertheless, Tsai said the government may consider allowing Taiwan business people with investments in mainland China and elderly retired servicemen to make direct sailing from Kinmen or Matsu to the mainland.
Tsai denied allegations by some people that ideological thinking has hindered the government from taking bold steps to boost the "mini three links" program.

Stressing that the biggest obstacle to the program lies in mainland China's reluctance to adopt positive or coordinate moves, Tsai said the ROC government should not be blamed for slow progress in the program.

Until now, mainland China still declines to give the green light to regular direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matzu-Mawei shipping services and instead approves direct voyage applications on a case-by-case basis.

Noting that Taiwan has consistently adopted a pragmatic manner in carrying out the program, Tsai said that without mainland China's cooperation, the government must exercise caution and prudence in further easing "mini three links" regulations to prevent any possible adverse effects.

The top mainland policy planner further said it's still premature to claim that the "mini three links" program is a flop. "The program has at least allowed Kinmen and Matsu residents to legal direct voyages to the mainland," Tsai said, adding that the program has at least realized the goal of "decriminalization" of such practices. In the past, direct sailing between Kinmen and Xiamen was illegal.
Tsai also said the ROC government earnestly hopes that mainland China can make more favorable response to the project because it marks a critical step to improving cross-strait ties.

So far, more than 10 groups of Kinmen residents have made direct voyages to Xiamen, while only a delegation of elderly Kinmen natives who have been stranded in the mainland for nearly 50 years managed to make a direct voyage to Kinmen from Xiamen for a brief visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE PREDICTED TO EXCEED 4 PERCENT IN SECOND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Due to a deteriorating situation in the local job market, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) predicted Monday that unemployment will continue to worsen in Taiwan.

C. C. Chen, deputy director of the fourth DGBAS bureau, predicted that Taiwan's unemployment rate will surpass the 4-percent level in the second quarter of this year and will not fall until after September.
Chen also forecast that the country's jobless rate will average a record high of 3.9 percent for the whole of 2001, surpassing the 2000 level of 2.99 percent.

Statistics released by the DGBAS showed that the unemployment rate hit 3.89 percent in March, the second-highest monthly high in history and the highest jobless rate since Aug. 1985, when the figure stood at 4.11 percent. Of the 380,000 workers who lost their jobs last month, 260,000 were male, up 11,000 from February, while the number of jobless female workers increased 5,000 to reach 120,000.

At the same time, joblessness among women broke the 3-percent mark for the first time in March to reach around 3.04 percent, while the ratio of unemployed males continued climbing to a record high of 4.46 percent last month.
The average unemployment rate in the first three months of this year was 3.66 percent, up 0.84 percentage points from the same period a year ago.
The DGBAS tallies showed that the number of unemployed workers surged to a record high of 380,000 in March, while the number of people affected totaled around 939,000.
According to Chen, 162,000 people lost their jobs in March, up 19,000 from the February level, becuase of factory closures or business streamlining.

If the so-called "hidden unemployed population" -- those who are willing to work but have not yet found a job -- was added, the broad March unemployment rate would reach an historical high of 5.76 percent, an increase of 0.22 percentage points from February, he noted.

Meanwhile, the number of employed workers in Taiwan totaled 9.37 million in March, representing the third consecutive monthly drop, the DGBAS statistics indicated. Compared to the December level, the figure represents a drop of 171,000 employed people.
During the first quarter, the number of employed workers islandwide averaged 9.41 million, a fall of 25,000 from the same period in 2000, which marked the first decline in a decade.

In terms of academic backgrounds, workers of junior high school education level posted the largest unemployment rate of 5.07 percent, while the percentage of senior high school graduates also hit around 4.3 percent.

The jobless rate of nine cities and counties was higher than 4 percent in March, with Kaohsiung County posting the highest rate of 4.89, followed by Tainan City with 4.77 percent and Ilan County with 4.68 percent. Meanwhile, the jobless percentages registered in Keelung City, Hualien County, Tainan County, Nantou County, Taichung County and Kaohsiung City all were above the 4-percent level.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO PLAY ACTIVE ROLE IN ASIAN EDUCATIONAL DEVELOPMENT: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the Republic of China is willing to play a pivotal role in educational development in Asia.
Chen made the pledge in a speech delivered at the opening of the Second Asian Physics Olympiad.
Chen said the past century's progress in physics has had amazing effects on human life and that achievements in physics over the past 50 years have also contributed much to advances in material life.

However, Chen said, most major discoveries in physics have been achieved by Western countries. "Asian countries have been relatively weak in this regard," the president noted, adding that Asian countries should give priority to boosting scientific education and cultivation of talent in order to catch up with Western countries in scientific and technological development.

Chen said he is convinced that the Asian Physics Olympiad will contribute to the promotion and upgrading of scientific education in the region. "We are also hopeful that the event will help increase international cultural and educational exchanges and allow Asian youths to forge friendships in preparation for possible research cooperation in the future," he added.

The president also advised senior high school students participating in the current physics contest not to worry too much about the results of the race. "Winning or losing is just a fleeting event. Forging friendships is the most important thing," he stressed.
Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, echoed President Chen's views, saying that the outcome of the Olympiad competition is not very important.

"You just need to do your utmost. Posing questions and finding new answers are the driving force behind progress in scientific study, and scientific knowledge is accumulated through long-term research by a number of scientists," Lee said, adding that researchers in countries around the world should stop competing and opt for cooperation in order to resolve many thorny issues and enhance the well-being of mankind.

A total of 81 senior high school students from 12 countries are taking part in the current competition. The participating countries are Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Australia, Mongolia, Kazakhstan, Jordan, Israel, India and the host ROC. Additionally, Japan and Qatar have sent observers to the event.
Mainland China, which won the top prize in the first Asian physics Olympiad held last year, declined to participate in the race apparently for political reasons.
The results of the competition will be announced Sunday evening. The next Olympiad will be held in Singapore.
The ROC will select five students from its team to the ongoing competition to take part in an international physics Olympiad scheduled to be held in Turkey in July this year.
The ROC is scheduled to host the 2003 international physics Olympiad.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLY LOCAL WORKERS TO BE EMPLOYED IN NEW PUBLIC WORK PROJECTS

TEXT.P: The head of the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Monday that only local workers will be employed on a series of new public works projects aimed at lowering unemployment.
Chen Chu said the CLA's stance on the issue is resolute and has won support from the authorities.
CLA officials have estimated that the new projects, worth around NT$111.5 billion, will create a total of 50,000 job opportunities for local laborers hard-hit by the slumping domestic economy.

The official said local construction workers can go to their trade unions or employment service centers to register their desire to work on the projects, after which the CLA will inform applicants of upcoming job opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG COUNTY SPEAKER CHARGED WITH ATTEMPTED MURDER, CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: Taichung district prosecutors on Monday pressed charges of attempted murder and corruption on Taichung County Speaker Yen Ching-piao, who has been detained since Feb. 28 and had been allowed only hours before to be released on bail.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Justice's "black gold" investigation center special task force said that the prosecutors did not know about the day's earlier court ruling, which he said was invalidated by the filing of formal charges.

Taichung County Deputy Speaker Chang Ching-tang was also set to be released on NT$2 million (US$60,000) bail when the surprise announcement came. Arrested together with Yen and also held without visitation rights during the initial investigation period, Chang was charged with corruption.
Prosecutors believe that Yen and Chang were involved in padding a Taichung County Council expense account, which they allegedly used to cover expenses incurred at local bars with female hostesses.
Yen's secretary-general, Tsai Wen-hsiung, was also charged with corruption.
Meanwhile, Yen was charged with conspiracy to murder in a separate case.

Prosecutors are seeking a 20-year sentence, a NT$10 million (US$300,000) fine and a 10-year deprivation of civil rights for Yen. During the period, he would not be allowed to serve as a public official or a candidate for public office and would lose his right to vote.
In the indictment, prosecutors are also seeking a 12-year sentence and a NT$10 million fine for Chang and a 12-year sentence with a NT$2 million fine for Tsai.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS TO VISIT JAPAN TO PUSH FOR BETTER EXCHANGE MECHANISM

TEXT.P: A group of Republic of China legislators will leave for Japan Tuesday to thank Japanese officials and parliamentarians who helped push the Japanese government into issuing a visa for former ROC President Lee Teng-hui.

Legislator Tang Pi-o of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said at a news conference Monday that a number of Japanese parliamentarians of different political stripes had formed a supra-party alliance to press their government to approve Lee's visit to Japan for medical purposes.
"Therefore, we'll go to Japan to thank them and several other Japanese government officials for their efforts to help Lee realize his Japan travel plan," said Tang.
Other legislators expected to visit Japan along with Tang will include Yu Cheng-tao of the DPP and Chen Hung-chi of the main opposition Kuomintang.

Tang said she and her legislative colleagues are glad about the Japanese government's 11th-hour decision to ignore mainland China's "unreasonable and irrational opposition" and grant Lee a visa on humanitarian grounds.

"This indicates that protecting human rights is a universal value," Tang said, adding that Japan's approval of Lee's visit highlights this principle and should be recognized by the people of both the ROC and Japan.
Tang said she is convinced that the Japanese government decision will also have a positive effect on future relations between the two countries.

In view of mainland China's perennial diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, Tang said she and her colleagues will take advantage of their visit to discuss with their Japanese counterparts the establishment of an effective mechanism for exchanges and dialogue among ROC and Japanese parliamentarians.

In related developments, Chang Fu-mei, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), denied an allegation Monday that the commission had mobilized ROC expatriates in Japan to greet Lee upon his arrival in Osaka Sunday.

Opposition New Party Legislator Elmer Feng asked Chang at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's foreign and overseas Chinese affairs committee whether she knew that "many of those who turned out to greet Lee at the Kansai International Airport and a posh Osaka hotel were pro-Taiwan independence activists."
Feng, who has never hesitated to express his pro-unification stance, also expressed his suspicion that the OCAC had mobilized "pro-independence expatriates" in Japan to welcome Lee.

In response, Chang pointed out that as Lee's Japan visit is purely for medical reasons, the OCAC did not see the need to arrange for ROC expatriates in Japan to greet Lee at either the airport or the hotel. "All the well-wishers turned out voluntarily," she stressed.
Lee, 78, arrived in Osaka Sunday for his first visit to Japan since 1985, when he made a stopover on his way home after a visit to Latin America in his capacity as the ROC vice president.
On Monday, Lee took a stroll and visited the ancient Osaka castle in the company of a large crowd of security staff and journalists.
He avoided politics, sticking to polite remarks about the history of Japan, the sights of Osaka and cherry blossom, according to reports from Japan.
The former president is scheduled to go to a hospital in the city of Kurishiki Tuesday, about 600 kilometers west of Tokyo, for an expert medical evaluation of a heart condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE DISCOVER 37 WEBSITES SELLING MP3 MUSIC FILES ILLEGALLY

TEXT.P: Police officials announced Monday that they have arrested 32 suspects including five students allegedly involved in running some 37 websites selling MP3 music files online. They added that they had seized more than 36,000 compact discs (CD) on which MP3 files were stored.
The police have forwarded the case to the Prosecutor's Office of Taipei District Court for further investigation into possible violations of intellectual property rights.

A spokesman for the Criminal Investigation Bureau(CIB) said that Taipei District Prosecutor Chang Shau-ping, who is in charge of investigating computer related crimes, instructed CIB staff in March to shut down any websites engaged in illegally selling pirated music CDs, MP3 music files, or other files.
In the course of their investigations, the police discovered 37 networks and arrested 32 suspects including five students.
Seventeen of the sites allegedly offered illegal MP3 music CDs, while the remainder were engaged in illegal sales of pirated copies of CDs, police said.

Police found that all the operators of the sites were equipped with high speed CD burners. They added that a suspect surnamed Chow had 12 high speed CD burners, and used his site to sell illegal MP3 music CDs, MP3 music files, pirated music CDs and pornography.
Police estimated that Chow's site accumulated NT$5 million in profits since he began it in 1998. Chow successfully evaded police investigators three times in the past.

Meanwhile, police also forwarded the "Home of Little Lu" Website uncovered by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI) to Taipei District Court for further investigation. The site allegedly allows visitors to illegally download MP3 music files.
Police called on the public to observe intellectual property rights laws and related regulations so as not to violate the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PRAISES U.S. AND JAPANESE GOVERNMENTS FOR GRANTING LEE VISA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Monday that the U.S. and Japanese governments' issuance of visitor visas to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui has great meaning and should inspire Beijing to use new thinking in the new age.
Lu made the remarks during a meeting Monday morning with visiting president of the American Enterprise Institute, Christopher Demuth.

Lu especially expressed gratitude to the U.S. government, which granted Lee a multiple-entry visa for a period of five years and imposed no restrictions on Lee's activities during his planned early-May trip to the United States.

Lu indicated that it was quite a breakthrough for the Japanese government to allow former president Lee to visit Japan, which she said has previously succumbed to mainland China's demands because of its sense of guilt about its invasion of China. "It is gratifying that the Japanese government gave Lee a visa on humanitarian considerations," she said.
She said she hopes Japan's government and people can walk out of the shadows of history.

For his part, DeMuth said he agreed with Lu that Lee is now an ordinary citizen and has the right to travel anywhere he wishes, and certainly for medical purposes. He said the Japanese government doesn't have to explain why it issued Lee a visa, adding that Beijing authorities should not take irrational action against the Japanese government over this matter.

During their talks, Lu mentioned that she has always supported uniting Japan, Korea and Taiwan to form an Asia Pacific alliance. She said that such a regional organization would contribute significantly to the promotion of peace and stability in the region.

As to the U.S. role in cross-strait ties, DeMuth said Washington should not involve itself in the cross-strait dispute over reunification or independence, but should make it clear that the United States would not permit any solution involving force.
Referring to arms sales, DeMuth said the U.S. government should simply consider Taiwan's defense needs to ensure its people's safety.

Lu expressed the hope that the Bush Administration will adopt a more positive and friendly Taiwan policy. She suggested that the United States strengthen bilateral high-level visits and help Taiwan to quickly enter international organizations such as the World Trade Organization (WTO) and World Health Organization (WHO).

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT TO MEET WITH THINK TANK EXPERTS DURING U.S. TRANSIT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian told a visiting U.S. think tank expert Monday that he hopes to meet the institute's senior fellows for wide-ranging discussions during his U.S. transit stop in May en route to Latin America.

Chen told Christopher DeMuth, president of the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), that he would like to exchange opinions with AEI scholars on such issues as future Taipei-Washington relations and the current situation in the Taiwan Strait during his brief stopover.
Chen said that he has visited the think tank on many occasions in the past and he praised AEI for its long-term concern for and contributions to the security of the Asia Pacific region.

The president also expressed respect for AEI Senior Vice President John R. Bolton -- who has been nominated to serve as the new U.S. undersecretary of state for arms control, non-proliferation and international security in the Bush administration -- for his staunch vocal support of the Republic of China.
DeMuth pointed out that many other officials in the current U.S. administration, including U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney, once worked for the influential think tank.
He went on to say that these officials are all friends of the Republic of China and that he is certain that bilateral relations will undergo substantial improvements in the future.

Responding to DeMuth's suggestion that Taiwan should strengthen its financial reform initiatives, Chen admitted that Taiwan does indeed have many long-standing financial problems, the seriousness of which were "covered up" in the past.
Therefore, he continued, his government has given financial reform a top priority and is pushing for the completion of related legal measures during the first half of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC MULLING WAYS TO TACKLE SIDE EFFECTS OF `MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: In a bid to cope with the side effects of the "mini three links" on Taiwan-controlled offshore islands, a high-ranking Republic of China official said Monday that the government will adjust its current policy out of practical need.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the ROC's top government agency in charge of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks in a policy-review meeting here attended by local government officials and opinion leaders.

In response to a demand by local representatives that the central government ease its current rules on household registration in order to root out the increasing "ghost population" on Kinmen, Tsai promised that the MAC will review and adjust its measures on the "mini three links" by giving priority to people with special needs.
The "ghost population" refers to residents of Taiwan proper who fraudulently obtain Kinmen or Matsu household registration in order to allow them to travel directly to the mainland.

Admitting that the problem was unforeseen by the MAC while it was setting up the direct trade, shipping and postal links between Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China, Tsai said that lowering or abolishing the current household registration requirements will be very difficult in practice, out of consideration of social order, the local governments' administrative abilities and their hardware and software facilities.

The MAC head said that her council will make a move to improve its current measures based on practical needs and that legal residents of Kinmen and Matsu will not be the only people from Taiwan allowed to enjoy direct sailings to mainland China.

In the future, Taiwan businessmen who need to travel frequently between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and retired veterans may not be necessarily subjected to the clause that requires would-be travelers to the mainland through the offshore islands to be legally registered as resident of the islands for six months.

Blaming the emergence of the "ghost population" on the central government's establishment of the "mini three links," Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai claimed that the problem has had a negative impact on local development and public order.
According to Chen, the number of residents with legal abode on the island had increased to 55,153 as of the end of March, a growth of 3,270 people compared to the level posted a year ago.
Chen suggested that the central government relax the current six-month legal abode registration to 15 days in order to reduce the pressure from the "ghost population."

Kinmen County Council Deputy Speaker Hsu Yu-chao further pointed out that the invasion of the large amount of "ghost population" will seriously affect the "ecosystem" of Kinmen's politics, especially the legislative and county chief elections slated for December.
Hsu urged the central government to pay special heed to this phenomenon and warned that next year's election for local county councilors will be re-aligned by those "migrant troops."

Disagreeing with Chen's proposal, lawmaker Chen Ching-pao of the opposition Kuomintang contended that it would be better to simply not set any restrictions on household registration than lower the ceiling. New Party legislator Lee Chu-feng suggested that the MAC implement a quota system to first grant Taiwan businessmen and retired servicemen priority treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, E.U. TO RESUME TRADE TALKS IN BRUSSELS

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the European Union are expected to resume bilateral trade negotiations in Brussels in the second half of this year, officials of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Monday.

The BOFT officials, who made the announcement after meeting with visiting E.U. Executive Committee officials at the BOFT, added that BOFT Director-General Wu Wen-yea will lead the delegation to Brussels.

The E.U. is Taiwan's third-largest trade partner, while Taiwan is the E.U.'s 10th-largest trade partner. BOFT statistics show that Taiwan's exports to the E.U. last year totaled US$22.1 billion, a year-on-year growth of 16.3 percent. Taiwan's imports from the E.U. last year amounted to US$15.5 billion, representing a year-on-year increase of 7.3 percent.

E.U. Executive Committee officials visited the European Council of Commerce and Trade in Taipei last week and are expected to visit the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and other related Cabinet-level organizations Tuesday to gain a further understanding of Taiwan's economic and trade situation.
The last negotiations between Taiwan and the E.U. took place in April 1998 in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL SIGNS COOPERATION MEMORANDUM WITH IDB

TEXT.P: Computer chip giant Intel signed a memorandum of cooperation Monday with the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) and the Technology Department under the of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Under the terms of the memorandum, Intel, the IDB and the Technology Department will jointly tap the wireless telecommunications technology market, in particular wireless multimedia apparatus development, wireless online apparatus and applied technology.
It is the second technological cooperation agreement signed between Intel and the IDB, in a move designed to upgrade the technical quality of Taiwan's wireless telecommunications industry.

Ron Smith, senior vice president of Intel's wireless telecommunications department, IDB Director Shih Yen-hsiang and Technology Department Vice Director Ke Chih-kang signed the memorandum on behalf of their respective parties, witnessed by Vice Economics Minister Yiin Chi-ming.

Yen said that the export of local technology information and electronic products accounted for 50 percent of the nation's industrial products in 2000, making Taiwan a globally important production center.

The cooperation with Intel will help local manufacturers develop the smartphone -- a combination of cellular phone with PDA and local information appliances (IA) -- thereby upgrading competitiveness in international markets, Yen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC LOWERS DOMESTIC NATURAL GAS PRICES

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced Monday that it has cut the price of domestic and industrial natural gas by between 1.99 percent and 2.14 percent, effective Tuesday.
CPC officials said the move brings the price of domestic natural gas down to NT$13.7 per kilogram.

The new prices for the other natural gases sold by the CPC are as follows: mixed natural gas for industrial use reduced by NT$0.33 to NT$15.82 per kilogram; propane and butane down by NT$0.33 to NT$15.28 per kilogram; and mixed natural gas for car use down by NT$0.32 to NT$14.59 per kilogram.
The officials also said that the company's gasoline prices will remain unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF CRITICIZES `INCORRECT' XINHUA REPORTS

TEXT.P: Director-General Su Cheng-ping of the Government Information Office (GIO) Monday criticized reports by mainland China's Xinhua News Agency for making "incorrect reports" about Taiwan.
Su, who is also the government spokesman, said the GIO has recently received many complaints from the public about reports by the Xinhua journalists, saying they have been "incorrect" and "lies."
Taiwan opened its doors to mainland reporters on a regular basis late last year.
He cited several Xinhua reports to support his accusations.

First, he said, a Xinhua report dated April 21 from Taipei said that former President Lee Teng-hui was blasted by the public for using health reasons to apply for a visa to Japan in order to engage in political activities there.

Su said that Taiwan is free country in which everybody is allowed to air his or her voice, and it is understandable that some local people may have different views about Lee's ongoing Japan visit, but he claimed it is "doubtful" whether Lee's visit was strongly opposed or rapped by most local people.
Moreover, he went on, although the Xinhua reporters did interview certain local figures, their views would not necessarily represent the opinions of the majority of people.

Second, Su said, another Taipei-datelined Xinhua report on April 20 said that well-known Taiwan figures including former Legislative Yuan President Liang Su-jung and former Veteran Affairs Commission Chairman Hsu Li-lung had said political motives were behind Lee's bid to visit Japan.
Without denying the report, Su said that Liang and Hsu are just two well-known local figures and that the Xinhua reporters should contact more people before filing this kind of report.

He also cited a Xinhua report about the Dalai Lama's Taiwan visit on March 31 which said that "hundreds" of local people held an anti-Tibet independence protest in front of the Tibetan spiritual leader's hotel.
Su admitted that local people protested the Dalai Lama's visit, but claimed that the number of protesters was actually far less that what Xinhua had given.

Su said that the government has allowed the mainland journalists to work on the island in the hope that they will help promote mutual understanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and that he is worried that this kind of "incorrect reporting" will be detrimental.
Su termed the performance of the mainland reporters as "not professional enough," but he said the GIO would not take any disciplinary measures against them.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-CHINESE COMMUNIST OFFICIAL'S CONFESSIONS SHED LIGHT ON TIANANMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 23 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Bao Tong, a reform-minded senior Chinese Communist official who took the fall for being sympathetic to the student democracy movement of 1989, confirmed Monday that a leaked document containing his "confessions" appeared genuine.
Bao, who lives in Beijing after serving seven years in prison, told CNA in a phone interview that he did not personally read the document published that day in the Hong Kong Economic Journal.
However, he added, from what others told him, the 16-point confession indeed seemed to be the one he wrote in jail in 1989 after the bloody Tiananmen Square massacre.

Bao said that he did not know who provided the Hong Kong daily with the document, but joked that the fact Beijing leaders did not give him trouble over the leak could mean that "mainland China has made progress."

According to the Hong Kong Economic Journal, the unnamed person who provided the document claimed that Bao was willing to let the document come to light in order to follow in the spirit of the person who provided similarly revealing material for a recent book titled "The Tiananmen Papers."
Bao's confession gave a detailed look into his alleged part in the intra-party power struggle that finally led to the emergence of a hawkish faction and the resultant massacre.

The 16-point confession included Bao's admittance that in 1989, he criticized an April 26 editorial in the People's Daily denouncing the student movement. He called the editorial "overly rigid" and "lacking sufficient analysis."
Bao also "confessed" to twice mixing into the crowd of demonstrators before April 27, 1998, "to look around." He stressed that he met no one he knew and talked to no one.
Bao was at that time director of the now-defunct Central Research Institute for Political Reform as well as a senior adviser to then party General-Secretary Zhao Ziyang.
Zhao also sided with the students but was unable to prevent party hardliners from branding their protest a "counterrevolutionary riot" and bringing in tanks to suppress the movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 24, or the second day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated and dies at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on November 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1942: Barbara Streisand, American actress, director and singer, is born. She won an Oscar for her starring role in "Funny Girl."
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet Cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches "Tung Fang Hung" ("The East Is Red"), its first satellite, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the U.S. Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A train encounters a landslide while the train is on its way to Alishan in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: East and West Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgystan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
2000: The ROC National Assembly begins to fade into history after it downgrades itself to a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments during a third reading.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: INFLUENTIAL SENATOR PRAISES BUSH'S DEFENSE PACKAGE FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) praised Monday the Bush administration's approval of a robust arms sale package to Taiwan.
Helms said in a press release the move demonstrates that the United States, at long last, has an administration that is taking the critical matter of Taiwan's defense seriously.
"I congratulate President Bush and his administration for their courageous decision to approve the most significant defense package for Taiwan in at least nine years," Helms said.
The influential senator said he thinks that criticism of President Bush over the arms sale package is sure to follow.

"But those who would berate the President should first acknowledge that the President's action is well within the requirements of the law in terms of the United States' commitment to the defense of Taiwan," Helms said in the news release.

He went on to point out that the defense systems listed in the latest arms sale package "will go a long way toward helping our friends on Taiwan resist coercion from an increasingly belligerent Communist China."
For his part, Helms said, he is "unalterably persuaded that the sale of Aegis destroyers is also justified in light of the outrageous actions of the leaders in Beijing."

Helms further said now that a number of weaponry systems have been approved for sale to Taiwan, he looks forward to continuing his support of the Bush administration's work on other aspects of the U.S. defense relationship with Taiwan, such as communications and operational training.

Congressional aides said Bush administration officials informed Senate and House leaders, including Helms, Monday afternoon by phone that President Bush has approved the sale of four Kidd-class destroyers and 12 P-3 Orion submarine-killer aircraft to Taiwan, in addition to helping Taiwan purchase eight diesel submarines.

Meanwhile, Bush promised to decide in two years whether to sell Taiwan the highly advanced Aegis radar-equipped Arleigh Burke destroyers based on the development in mainland China's missile deployment against Taiwan.
