DOC.HEADLINE: GEPHARDT EXPRESSES CONCERN OVER U.S. DECISION NOT TO SELL AEGIS TO ROC

TEXT.P: U.S. House Democratic leader Richard A. Gephardt said Monday that he has serious questions regarding the Bush administration's decision not to sell Taiwan destroyers equipped with the advanced Aegis system "given the sizable buildup of military forces on the mainland side of the Taiwan Straits."

Expressing his full support for providing Taiwan with the assistance and equipment necessary for its self-defense, Gephardt said that "China's military buildup and other provocative acts demonstrate that the United States must have a comprehensive, focused and consistent policy toward that nation."

"Part of such a policy is clearly assisting Taiwan. But it also includes asserting our own security priorities, especially in the aftermath of the navy surveillance plane incident earlier this month," the Missouri Democrat added.

He said that he is disappointed that Washington has still not secured an agreement from Beijing for the return of the U.S. Navy surveillance aircraft. He also expressed concern over the fact that the United States has not resumed surveillance flights in the region, "if only to demonstrate our right to do so in international airspace."

Meanwhile, the congressional Deomcratic leader also noted that "our policy must also include calling on China to respect international human rights standards. Over the past several weeks, China has detained a number of U.S. citizens and residents who have been pursuing scholarly work," said Gephardt.

He urged the Bush administration to "press forcefully for the release of these individuals and compliance with the rule of law," saying that "the recent release of our navy air crew must not divert us from attention to these ongoing and troubling matters."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 0.36 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index edging down 0.36 points to close at 5,589.34.
Market turnover amounted to NT$77.65 billion (US$2.37 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS RECOMMEND ALTERNATIVE TO SOLVE AEGIS DILEMMA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Two senior U.S. officials recommended adding two Aegis destroyers to the U.S. Navy that could be transferred to Taiwan in the event that Beijing continues to heighten its military intimidation of the island, sources said Monday.

U.S. Deputy State Secretary Richard Armitage and Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz were quoted as recommending to U.S. President George W. Bush last week that he authorize the additional destroyers as an alternative to committing to a decision on the sale of such destroyers to Taiwan at the annual arms sales meeting scheduled for Tuesday.
Whether their recommendation was accepted was not immediately clear, sources added.

However, officials said that Bush has already made a decision on the arms sales package for this year and that the Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with the Aegis system that Taiwan has requested to purchase will not be on the list.

Instead, officials added, the decision to sell the Aegis destroyers will be deferred, and a future decision will be made in two years depending on the situation regarding mainland Chinese missile deployments across from Taiwan.

Destroyers and cruisers equipped with the cutting-edge Aegis combat management system form the backbone of the U.S. Navy, which currently has 31 Aegis destroyers in service and plans to build an additional 27 such destroyers.
If Bush were to decide to build two additional destroyers, the U.S. Congress would have to first agree to the additional budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 8.36 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 8.36 points to close at 5,589.34.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN PARLIAMENT VICE PRESIDENT VISITING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: German Parliament (Bundestag) Vice President Dr. Hermann Otto Solms is currently on a six-day goodwill visit in Taiwan.
Solms, leading a delegation of the German parliament, arrived in Taiwan Monday.
The delegation will be received by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh.

They will also visit several of Taiwan's cultural and economic points of interest, including the National Palace Museum, Kenting National Park, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd., before leaving Taiwan April 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER CALLS FOR MERGERS IN DOMESTIC INSURANCE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The minister of finance said Tuesday that those domestic insurance companies unable to maintain the minimum required amount of NT$2 billion (US$625 million) in capital should seek to merge with other companies in the sector.

Minister Yen Ching-chang said that although all domestic life insurance firms have been able to maintain the NT$2 billion minimum, some firms in the property insurance sector have not met the standard set by the ministry. He called for the merging of those companies as a means of maintaining the minimum capital requirement.
According to statistics released by the Department of Insurance of the Ministry of Finance, eight of the 31 domestic insurance companies do not meet the minimum capital requirement.

As several banks and securities firms merged after the Legislative Yuan passed a law on business mergers last November, the ministry reported that at least three mergers among Taiwan property insurance firms will take place this year.

An official at Fubon Insurance Co. Ltd., Taiwan's leading insurance company, told the press that the firm has recently contacted five or six of its counterparts to discuss possible business mergers, adding that a merger is expected to happen some time this year.
Although it leads the field in Taiwan's insurance sector, Fubon Insurance Co. Ltd. is ranked a lowly 55th among Asia's largest insurance companies, Yen noted.

He added that 630 mergers took place worldwide in 1999, a 15 percent increase over the number in 1998, forcing small- and middle-sized enterprises to follow suit in order to remain competitive with their larger counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging down 8.36 points to close at 5,589.34.
The bourse opened at 5,607.46 and fluctuated between 5,644.68 and 5,569.62 during trading.

A total of 2.04 billion stocks worth NT$77.65 billion (US$2.37 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.58 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$57.5 billion (US$1.75 billion).

Three of the eight major stocks categories posted losses, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 0.7 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.3 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares and construction stocks, both at 0.4 percent, electrical shares at 0.3 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 260 to 230, with 105 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May moved down 23 points to close at 5,621, with 6,945 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 23 points to finish at 5,626, with 17 contract transactions, while September futures decreased 6 points to close at 5,700, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,644 for May, 5,649 for June, 5,706 for September, 5,800 for December, and 5,791 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
May TE futures lost 1.2 points to finish at 286.6, with 1,488 contract transactions, while June TE futures moved down 3.2 points to close at 285.7, with eight contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures decreased 4.2 points to finish at 722.8, with 376 contract transactions, while June TF futures edged down 0.4 points to close at 729.4, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DEFERS DECISION ON AEGIS DESTROYERS SALE TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 23 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush has deferred a decision on selling Taiwan destroyers equipped with the state-of-the-art radar system while approving the sale of other weaponry requested by the island, a senior White House official said Monday.

But Bush also said he would review Taiwan's request for the Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with the Aegis radar system over the next two years in light of the threats posed by mainland China's deployment of missiles along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan, the official said.

On the eve of the arms sale meeting between Taiwan and the U.S. on Taiwan's purchase request list, the official from the National Security Council gave a background briefing on the arms that Bush had approved for sale to Taiwan. These include four Kidd-class destroyers, eight diesel submarines designed to counter blockades and invasions, 12 P-3C Orion Aircraft, and Paladin self-propelled artillery system.

But the U.S. deferred a decision on the sale of the four Arleigh Burke-class destroyers as well as Apache Long Bow helicopters and M1 tanks. As for the new PAC-3 version of the Patriot air defense missile, it is still in the research and development stage in the United States, and the White House will review the issue with Taiwan later, the official said.

The U.S. arms sale to Taiwan, which is worth more than US$4 billion, represents the largest single arms sale to Taiwan in nine years since the U.S. announced the sale of F-16 fighter jets to Taiwan in 1992 under the old Bush administration.
The senior official urged mainland China to ease tensions in the Taiwan Strait and reduce the number of guided missiles deployed opposite Taiwan, which now stands at about 300.

The official also said the Bush administration will review within the next two years Taiwan's request for the Aegis destroyers, which are able to perform search and missile guidance functions and can track 100 or more targets simultaneously.

For Taiwan, the major positive result of the Bush decision is the approval of the sale to the island of eight diesel submarines. It is understood that Taiwan has requested the 209 model designed by Germany and that General Dynamics of the United States will be in charge of construction and assembly, with the U.S. Navy taking stock of the submarines before delivering them to Taiwan.

Sources in Washington said that the White House leak of the arms sales decision by Bush Monday night was in consistence with the White House's promise not to have prior consultations with the mainland on the issue. They said it is hoped the information will ease the potential impact of the arms sale decision on relations between Washington and Beijing, already strained because of the recent incident involving a downed U.S. reconnaissance plane.
The White House will closely monitor the response from Beijing, Taipei and the U.S. Congress, hoping that the arms sale decision will not turn into another diplomatic crisis, sources added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICER'S DEATH REKINDLES DEBATE ON SAFETY OF RURAL POLICE STATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien County, Taiwan, April 24 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: An officer was killed in the line of duty at a rural Hualien County police station by a high-caliber bench-made bullet Monday night, rekindling a debate on how the safety of such short-handed stations can be improved.
Judging from his missing firearm and 24 bullets, police speculated that the suspect killed officer Lee Chien-nan, 44, for the purpose of making off with his standard police-issue pistol.

Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, who visited the murdered officer's family and the crime scene Tuesday, expressed her concern for the safety of small rural police stations that are manned by only three officers in the day and a single officer at night.

She went on to say that an experimental plan last year to have rural stations work together for easier coordination and force projection could not be carried out in certain areas -- including the station where Lee was killed -- due to local opposition.

Despite police reassurances to the contrary, residents in certain townships feared that their local stations would be merged with bigger stations under the proposed plan, or that their areas would be left with less police protection.
Chang said that she has already instructed the National Police Administration (NPA) to re-examine the issue.

NPA Director-General Wang Chin-wang, who accompanied Chang on the inspection visit, said that his administration will look into the safety issue for officers on duty and that Lee's family will receive approximately NT$11 million (US$334,000) in pension and other funds.

Police said that the custom-made bullet was 7.8 centimeters long and 2 centimeters in diameter and was fashioned out of solid steel. Tearing through the seated officer's chair, the bullet entered Lee's back and exited from the right side of his chest. It appeared to have been fired from outside a window, police added.
Investigators said that the bullet made a 15-centimeter-deep hole in the opposite wall and appeared undented by the force of the impact.

Lee, who was transferred to the rural post last February, was decorated 35 times during his 15-year service on the police force. He is survived by his 91-year-old father as well as his wife and three daughters, aged 22, 18 and 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAW FIRM, HIGH TECH COMPANIES FORM M'LAND CONSULTANT GROUP

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan's high technology companies formed a service team with a local law firm Tuesday to provide information on investment, technology and financial law in mainland China.

D-Link Taiwan Corp., a company that provides Internet apparatus installation, jointly established the high-tech service team with Einstein Technology Co. Ltd., Fast Technologies Inc., e-Gov Commerce Corp., Power Point, as well as Chen and Lin Attorneys-at-Law.

The firms will pool their resources to provide customers with computer systems integration consulting, ERP enterprise resource system management, Internet safety services, investment, and financial regulations in the mainland.
A spokesman for the team said it will focus on precise installation, stability, and quick maintenance, adding that complete information technology (IT) consulting services will also be available.

He added that the cooperative group will also provide major web assistance, cross-strait digital services, visual and acoustic resolution planning, enterprise information services, and consulting on cross-strait financial operations and law.

Meanwhile, maintenance and service centers have been set up in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Chengdu, Xian, Wuhan and Shengyang. The group says it expects profits of NT$1 billion (US$31.2 million) from providing the services to Taiwan businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC KEEPS LOW PROFILE ON U.S. ARMS SALE PACKAGE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government kept a low profile Tuesday on reports that U.S. President George W. Bush will approve a robust arms sales package worth more than US$4 billion to Taiwan.
Reports from Washington, D.C. said the Bush administration has almost finalized its arms sales package to Taiwan on the eve of the opening of an annual ROC-U.S. arms procurement meeting.

According to the reports, the U.S. government put off a decision Monday on whether to sell Taiwan destroyers equipped with the state-of-the-art Aegis radar system, instead deciding to offer Taiwan four Kidd-class destroyers, a dozen anti-submarine P-3 "Orion" aircraft and eight diesel submarines.

It is the biggest arms package for Taiwan since 1992 when the U.S. government agreed to sell the island 150 F-16 jet fighters. Observers said the new U.S. sale package would vastly improve Taiwan's naval defense capabilities.
Commenting on the reports, Presidential Office officials said the ROC government appreciates the positive U.S. response to Taiwan's requests, which they said were based on the island's defense needs.
The officials, however, would not touch on any specific item on Taiwan's arms shopping list.

Sources said that although Bush has deferred a decision on the sale of four Aegis radar-equipped Arleigh Burke-class destroyers, the ROC will continue negotiations for purchasing them, also the biggest prize on Taiwan's wish list.

Military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has not yet received any information about the results of annual ROC-U.S. arms talks, which opened Tuesday in suburban Washington, D.C.
According to Huang, the ROC has a tacit understanding with the United States that it will refrain from making any comments on the details of the U.S. arms sales package for Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Huang stressed that the ROC will do its utmost to acquire advanced military hardware and software to beef up Taiwan's defense capabilities and contribute to stability and security in the Asia-Pacific area.
Asked about his views on the U.S. decision to sell Taiwan four Kidd-class destroyers, Huang said the MND would not make any comment on the deal regarding any single weaponry item.
However, he added later that the ROC military has never said it would definitely purchase Kidd-class warships.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reaffirmed its stance on remaining silent on arms procurement issues.
"We have no comment yet. The talks are still going on and have not ended," MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said.

In view of the complexity and sensitivity of arms procurement issues, relevant ROC government agencies and officials have kept low profile and refrained from making any forecast on the outcome of the ongoing arms talks and details of the possible U.S. sales package.
Senior officials simply stressed that the ROC's arms procurement plans are mainly designed to safeguard Taiwan's security and maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SCHOLAR SAYS U.S. ARMS SALE DECISION BENEFICIAL TO RELATIONS

TEXT.P: A local scholar said Tuesday that an anticipated U.S. decision to sell Taiwan Kidd-class destroyers instead of Aegis-equipped destroyers will have positive significance for Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations in the short term.
However, Chang Wu-ueh, director of Tamkang University's Institute of Mainland Chinese Research, added that the long-term effects on trilateral relations are not so clear.

Chang said the reported list of weapons that the United States plans to sell Taiwan this year will satisfy the island's "bottom line" and will be acceptable to Taipei, Washington and Beijing despite the fact that none of the three will be fully satisfied.

He speculated that if mainland China were to continue developing its military to intimidate Taiwan or establish a military alliance with Russia and India, then the United States will likely consider further arms sales to Taiwan in order to prevent an obvious imbalance in the region.

Meanwhile, former foreign minister Jason Hu said that any decisions coming out of an arms sales meeting being held in Washington should not be seen as standing for support of Taiwan independence or any particular ideology.

The opposition Kuomintang deputy secretary-general added that he was optimistic about reports that the Bush administration is prepared to sell Taiwan several types of defensive weapons, including diesel-electric submarines.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.005 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 32.885.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 32.872 and was traded between 32.855 and 32.889.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$369.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODERATE QUAKE OCCURS IN EASTERN TAIWAN, NO CASUALTIES REPORTED

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.7 on the Richter scale hit eastern Taiwan at 3:38 p.m. Tuesday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.
No casualties were reported.
The CWB said the epicenter of the quake was 40.5 kilometers east of the seismological observatory at Yuli, Hualien, at a depth of 42.6 kilometers.

The same quake hit Chengkung in Taitung County with a magnitude of two, while Hualien County's Hungyeh Village, Hualien City, and Taitung City under the jurisdiction of Taitung County were shaken by a force of one on the Richter scale, the CWB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE GREETED BY CHINESE RESIDENTS IN KURASHIKI CITY

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui was greeted by pro-Taiwan overseas Chinese residents and students when he arrived at the Kurashiki Chuo Hospital Tuesday afternoon.
Local Chinese residents, Taiwanese students at a local university and friendly Japanese gathered at the hospital to welcome Lee, who was to undergo a post-heart surgery checkup at the hospital.
Lee's trip to the hospital attracted attention from the Japanese news media, and over 100 Japanese police were mobilized to help maintain order.
The hospital's other patients were astonished by the tight security imposed for Lee's arrival.

More than 10 students from mainland China displayed banners at the scene to express their opposition to Lee's idea of redefining cross-Taiwan Strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" and "Taiwan independence."
Several young Japanese said that they have come to know Lee through articles by Japanese writers and from the Japanese newspapers. They described Lee as a "respectable man."

Lin Cheng-hui, a 24-year-old girl born in Kurashiki City, was the only well-wisher who was able to shake hands with Lee at the emergency entrance of the hospital. "It was an unforgettable experience," she said.
Lee arrived in Osaka Sunday to have his heart examined after a heart operation conducted about six months ago. He came to Kurashiki City by car.
After the examination scheduled for Tuesday afternoon, the attending doctor was expected to give a briefing on the results later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST DIRECT REPATRIATION OF MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS FROM MATSU OCCURS

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese ferry boat sailed directly to the Republic of China-held frontline island of Matsu Tuesday to take back 201 illegal mainland immigrants.

It was the first time that a mainland boat has made a direct voyage to Matsu to take back detained illegal mainland immigrants. In the past, ROC boats first shipped illegal mainland immigrants to the middle line of the Taiwan Strait, where mainland ferries would wait to take back the stowaways.
Matsu officials said the new practice has made repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants smoother, safer and faster.

With the assistance of the Red Cross Society on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the mainland ferry, christened Haixia, sailed into Matsu's Fuao port for the first time at around 9 a.m. to take back the all-female group of illegal mainland immigrants.
On its first direct voyage to Matsu, the Haixia also shipped 10 Taiwan fugitives to the ROC's offshore defense outpost.

The 10 fugitives have been wanted for various criminal charges, including murder, fraud and counterfeiting mainland and foreign currencies. They fled to the mainland and were arrested by police authorities there recently. Their repatriation marked yet another achievement in cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation in cracking down on crime.
Among the repatriated fugitives was Cheng Shen-tien, allegedly the mastermind of a criminal ring specializing in counterfeiting the mainland Chinese currency and the U.S. dollar.

Cheng, 45 fled to mainland China after Taiwan police raided his bogus bank note manufacturing factory in Tainan County in November 1998. During the raid, police seized fake mainland currency with a total face value of 60 million renminbi as well as a large number of fake US$100 notes.

Cheng and his accomplices were accused of intending to ship the bogus bills to the mainland for laundering or to use them to purchase arms and illegal drugs for sale to Taiwan, the United States, Japan and South Korea.
After Tuesday's repatriation, there are still 200 illegal mainland immigrants at the Matsu detention center, who will be repatriated later.

"We believe that the establishment of a direct repatriation model will enable us to simplify preparations for sending back seized illegal mainland immigrants, who have become a financial burden for the ROC in recent years," said a Matsu official.

In related news, 36 mainland fishermen who four days ago were sentenced to one year in prison with a five-year suspension for smuggling farm produce to Kinmen, another ROC frontline island, were repatriated from Kinmen's Shuitou wharf Tuesday.
The mainland fishermen, led by Wang Dongshui, were arrested by ROC coast guard officers on April 14 while they were attempting to smuggle more than 5,000 kilograms of mushroom seedlings to Kinmen.

Under the arrangement of the Kinmen branch of the Red Cross Society, a Kinmen-registered fishing boat shipped the mainland fishermen to the middle line of the Taiwan Strait where a mainland boat was waiting to take them back.

Since the ROC has opened its two offshore defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu for direct trade, mail and shipping links with mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links" program, Kinmen officials said they hope a direct repatriation model can be implemented as soon as possible.

As Beijing has cold-shouldered the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links" program, the project has not yet proceeded smoothly. Mainland China still declines to allow regular direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Mawei voyages and instead approves applications for direct sailing on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIMITED ACCESS FOR MEDIA DURING LEE'S CORNELL VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 23 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Cornell University Vice President for University Relations Henrik Dullea said Monday that the media will be granted "limited access" to former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui during his forthcoming visit to the institution, his alma mater.

Dullea said that although the U.S. State Department has not imposed any restrictions on Lee's visit to Cornell University May 2-4, he told CNA that the university authorities have decided to put on a low-key reception for the former ROC head of state at the request of Lee's own office.

Dullea stressed that the visit will be private and low profile and that Lee will not give any public speech or hold news conferences. He added that the university will "properly" and "carefully" deal with possible protests from mainland Chinese students.

Dullea, who personally took part in the reception for Lee during his first return to Cornell in 1995, said that the former president had revealed his willingness to visit again last December. But the plan has been delayed until now due to his personal physical conditions, he noted.

Lee and his wife are scheduled to arrive in Ithaca May 2, and hundreds of ROC nationals residing in the eastern United States will welcome the couple at the local airport. Cornell University President Hunter R. Rawlings III will host a dinner banquet for the couple later the same day.

On May 3, Lee will meet with his granddaughter, who is currently studying at Cornell, tour the university's campus, and personally preside over a ceremony to mark the establishment of the "Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research."
According to Cornell authorities, the research center will be accommodated inside the newly built Duffield Hall and will operate with donations by friends of Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SAID MORE LIKELY TO COOPERATE WITH KMT AFTER YEAR-END ELECTION

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party is more likely to cooperate with the Kuomintang than with other political parties after the year-end legislative election, DPP Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said Tuesday.

Wu made the remarks against the possibility that no single political party would dominate the legislature after the year-end election, which would force the ruling DPP to form a coalition government if it wanted to get its policy implemented smoothly.
The DPP currently controls less than one-third of the 220 seats in the legislature.

Wu said that he had the idea of forming a coalition government a long time ago, adding that he believes that the KMT is the likeliest partner for the DPP. He stressed that the gap between DPP supporters and those of the People First Party, another opposition party, is too big.

As for the possibility of the DPP cooperating with other political subgroups, Wu said that though it is very important for the DPP to become a larger force in the legislature, the party must also consider its long-term image.
Wu said that some political parties have "a poor image, and a ferocious appetite," but added that their ability to gain seats in the legislature is certain.

He dismissed the possibility of cooperation between the KMT and PFP, saying that the KMT currently has more than 100 seats in the legislature, and could not cooperate with the PFP if all KMT legislators are nominated again this time.
He also claimed that there is no rule of order in the nomination processes in both the KMT and DPP, and those officials who are not nominated could well incite infighting within their own party.

As for the minor opposition New Party, Wu said its goal may be simply to garner a minimum 5 percent of all popular votes so as to ensure its legislator-at-large seats rather than to gain a greater number of seats in the legislature.

Wu also said the DPP will hold three seminars on the possibility of forming a coalition government after the year-end election, with the first to convene later this month. He said the meetings would be held in order to consult the views of DPP heavyweights, younger DPP members and other parties.

Wu said that it is still too early to speak of political alliances, as no one can predict the outcome of the election. There will also be uncertainty in the two-month period between the legislative election and the opening of the Legislative Yuan, he said.
He noted that there is still ample room for discussion on the form and possibility of cooperation.
The three seminars will be held April 29, May 5 and May 13, respectively, and will be presided over by DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS EXPRESS RESERVATIONS ON KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers expressed both praise and reservations on the U.S. arms sales to Taiwan Tuesday.

Legislator Lee Ming-kao (KMT-at large) said that the U.S. plan to sell Taiwan eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3 anti-submarine aircraft and four Kidd class destroyers will certainly upgrade Taiwan's defensive position, especially the submarines.

But he said that Taiwan should make an all-out evaluation on the Kidd class destroyers before the decision is made to buy them, as they are older and less sophisticated than the Aegis-equipped Arleigh Burke-class destroyers the ROC requested.
According to press reports, the United States has made the decision to sell Taiwan the other arms.

The former vice commander-in-chief of the Navy pointed out that an assessment of the logistics, port facilities, maintenance and capability of combat systems should be made before the government decides to accept the U.S. offer.
Legislator Tsai Ming-hsien (DPP-Taichung City) said he was not completely satisfied by the U.S. arms sales to Taiwan. Taiwan did not need to accept the entire U.S. offer, he said.
He said the Kidd class destroyer was built 20 years ago and has a displacement of 25,000 metric tons, making it an easy target for Beijing's military.
Tsai called on government agencies concerned to reconsider the offer before making a decision.
Meanwhile, Secretary General to the Presidential Office Yu Shyi-kun had no comment on the U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, saying only that the issue was still being discussed.
The Presidential Office is expected to make official comments shortly, after the list of items Taiwan will buy is set.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN PHYSICS OLYMPIAD KICKS OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Competition at the Second Asian Physics Olympiad kicked off Tuesday in Taipei with 81 senior high school students from 12 countries participating.

According to authorities at National Taiwan Normal University, the event's sponsor, the regional physics competition will be divided into theoretical and experimental categories over a four-day contest period.

The contest entries and questions, provided by 10 universities in Taiwan and Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, are all of doctoral standards and were recognized by the International Physics Olympiad before being distributed to the Asian contestants, the sponsoring authorities said.

The Taiwan team, which includes eight senior high school students from around the island, was described as a highly promising contender for at least one of the five gold medals the Second Asian Physics Olympiad is offering, as the mainland Chinese team, which took 1st place in a similar event last year, is absent from this year's competition.
Among the eight Taiwanese contestants, Lin Sheng-shuan, a 16-year-old from Taichung First High School, is the youngest competitor that Taiwan has fielded in the competition for the last seven years.

Members of the Australian team are apparently more ambitious and confident than their rivals in the current contest, claiming that they will take at least two golds home after the competition wraps up.

The Mongolian team of three boys and three girls is probably the most popular group in Taiwan. The Mongolian youths, dressed almost exactly the same as boys and girls of their age in Taiwan, said they are having wonderful experiences in Taiwan, including eating seafood for the first time in their lives.
Other participating countries are Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Kazakhstan, Jordan, Israel and India. Additionally, Japan and Qatar have sent observers to the event.
The results of the competition will be announced Sunday. The next Olympiad will be held in Singapore in 2002, according to National Taiwan Normal University authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTRY REQUIREMENTS EASED FOR VISITORS FROM SINGAPORE, SOUTH KOREA

TEXT.P: In an effort to bolster exchanges with Singapore and South Korea, the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Tuesday that it will ease visa requirements for visitors from the two countries, starting in May.

Beginning May 1, visitors from Singapore will be granted 14-day visa-free status and will be entitled to a 30-day landing-visa. Singapore will become the 21st country to be granted the privilege, according to a MOFA press release.

Visitors from Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Luxembourg, Macedonia, New Zealand, Holland, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Britain, the United States, Costa Rica, Italy, Greece and Switzerland already receive the treatment, the press release said.
Meanwhile, the period of validity of multiple entry visas issued to South Korean travelers will be prolonged from one year to three years.
Currently, ROC passport-holders can enjoy 14-day visa-free stay in Singapore, while those heading for South Korea are provided with 30-day visa-free treatment.

MOFA officials said that the measures have been effective in strengthening substantive ties with friendly countries since their adoption in 1993. They added that MOFA will consider including more countries under its special entry treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MEETS OSCAR-WINNING DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian got a taste of the glory of the Academy Awards Tuesday when he met with Ang Lee at the Oscar-winning director's home in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan.
"It's adorable," Chen said as he hugged the golden Oscar statuette Lee won for best foreign film at this year's Academy Awards, the U.S. movie industry's highest honor.
Rubbing the gleaming Oscar statuette close to his breast, Chen congratulated Lee on his achievement in becoming the first ROC national to win an Academy Award.
The president told Lee that he had twice watched Lee's prize-winning martial arts epic "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon."
Chen said he was impressed by its moving story of honor, obligation and unfulfilled love, as well as its gravity-defying fight scenes and swordplay.
Chen even told Lee that he drew inspiration from conversations between the two leading characters of the film in handling sensitive relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"I adapted the dialogue `if you close your hands, you'll have nothing; but if you open your arms, you'll have everything' into my Lunar New Year's Eve address," Chen recalled, adding: "At that time, I hoped mainland China could understand my message that goodwill dialogue, not fisticuffs, can resolve cross-strait issues."

Chen praised Lee as a "great promoter" of Taiwan's film industry, saying it is particularly inspiring that Lee drew acting and technical talent from major Chinese communities around the world, including Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong, to form the cast and production crew of the acclaimed film.
Chen further said Lee's road to success offers the best encouragement to local people -- "Keeping going at your ideals is the key to success."
For his part, Lee told Chen that he earnestly hopes the ROC government can take steps to help local filmmakers "win back audiences and create a cultural miracle."

In response, Chen said he will direct the Government Information Office, which administers Taiwan's movie industry development, to adopt innovative measures to boost the local film industry, which has languished for many years.

DOC.HEADLINE: COCKROACH DETERMINED TO BE MAJOR AGENT OF ALLERGIES

TEXT.P: The cockroach, one of the major sensitinogens to patients prone to allergy, has been determined by researchers at Mackay Memorial Hospital as one of the leading causes of allergies in Taiwan.
The cockroach is positively the second major sensitinogen behind the mite to allergy patients in Taiwan, particularly children.
According to Hsu Shih-tah, a pediatrician at the hospital, one out of every six children in Taiwan have been victims of cockroach allergy.

Biologists have found that eight to 13 sensitinogen agents can be found in a single cockroach, while cockroach secretions and excreta are the most prominent agents that cause children to suffer an allergic rash, Hsu noted.

Noting that one in every 10 children in Taiwan is an asthma patient and suffers from allergies, Hsu suggested that parents keep their households clean and cockroach-free, to lessen their children's exposure to cockroach contamination, while continuing to reduce mite contamination by washing bed linen in hot water and refraining from using carpets in the home.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AMONG ASIAN COUNTRIES WITH LOWEST CREDIT RISK
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 24 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong are listed among Asia's newly developed countries whose banking systems have the lowest credit risk, according to a report conducted by the credit rating company Standard & Poor's.

The report, published Tuesday, classifies mainland China, Indonesia and India as having the highest credit risk in Asia, while the Philippines, Thailand, South Korea and Malaysia have a medium level of credit risk.

The report notes that weaker banks in Asia's newly developed countries are less able to face the impact of regional economic slowdown mainly because of their increasing bad loans, insufficient capital and poor risk management systems.

Ian Thompson, managing director of Standard & Poor's responsible for financial service ratings, predicted that mergers among Asian banks will increase as the market cannot support so many banks. "The merger is one of the steps to integrate the market," Thompson added.

The report indicates that although mainland China, Indonesia and India are all populous countries, their banking systems cannot be compared with each other, as Indonesia's banking sector has not recovered from the 1997 financial crisis. The global economic slowdown has had a much more negative impact on Indonesia's banking sector than mainland China's and India's, the report adds.
According to the report, Indonesia's banking industry will need 10 years to recover.

The report says Malaysia's banking sector is more capable of facing changes. However, it warns that Malaysia's banking system should better resolve its bad loan problem while the country is still enjoying economic growth.

As for Singapore's banking sector, Thompson described it as well-qualified, enjoying profits and gigantic capital. He added that the only challenge it must face is how to continue its growth in the long run and make its operations more pluralistic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POSTAL SAVINGS BALANCE HITS NT$2.99 TRILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's postal savings balance reached NT$2.99 trillion (US$92 billion) as of the end of March this year, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Banking Department of the Central Bank of China.
The figure represents the highest level in 16 months, according to the statistics.
The figure was NT$11.9 billion more than at the end of the previous month and represented a year-on-year increase of NT$355 billion, indicating a loose capital market.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS REVEAL ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington D.C., April 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be offered the option to purchase destroyers, diesel-powered submarines and anti-submarine surveillance planes this year, according to several senior U.S. officials.
The unofficial list of the arms the United States is prepared to offer the Republic of China is as follows:

-- Four Kidd-class destroyers equipped with upgraded radar systems. A senior White House official said that the Kidds, available for delivery as early as 2003, would represent a "significant upgrade" to Taiwan's navy and air defense systems;

-- Eight diesel-powered submarines -- once Taiwan has the capability of housing and operating them. Since the United States no longer makes diesel submarines, Taiwan could choose for the United States to arrange for the purchase through a friendly third country, most likely a European ally, the administration officials said;
-- Up to 12 P-3 Orion sub-hunting surveillance planes;
-- The Palladin self-propelled artillery system;
-- MH-53E mine-sweeping helicopters;
-- AAV7AI amphibious assault vehicles;
-- MK-48 Mod-4 torpedoes, but not the most advanced version;
-- Submarine-launched and surface-launched Harpoon missiles;

Taiwan will also be given a briefing on the PAC-3 antimissile defense system -- an advanced version of current antimissile software -- under development for the Pentagon. If, after the briefing, Taiwan were to made a purchase request, the U.S. administration would consider whether to approve the sale, a senior official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR GROUP APPEALS FOR GOVERNMENT MEASURES TO HELP UNEMPLOYED

TEXT.P: An umbrella organization of labor groups urged the government Tuesday to address the surging unemployment amid statistics showing 3.66 percent unemployment in the first quarter compared with economic growth of only 3 percent for the same period.

Members of the Alliance for 84 Hours for Every two Workweeks went to the Executive Yuan Tuesday morning to urge the government to stop the privatization of state-run enterprises and the mergers of financial institutions, which they blamed for contributing to the swelling jobless population.

The group called for the enactment of bills curbing employers' power to lay off workers and subjecting violators to criminal punishment. They also called for the stabilization of public sector employment and for the government to fix employee quotas for each state-run company, which would have to be adhered to, irrespective of whether or not the company actually turns a profit.
Major public projects costing more than NT$200 million (US$6.25 million) should hire one-third of their workers from the jobless worker pool, said the group.

They also asked for expanding the scope of people eligible for unemployment payments, while payment of debts owed to jobless workers should take precedence over the payment of other debts. They also called for the rescheduling of loans taken out by jobless workers on the security of their houses, and the offer of interest-free loans to jobless workers to help them pay for their children's tuition.

The group urged the Executive Yuan to send back to the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) bills on trade unions, handling of labor disputes and group work contracts, saying that the council should consult with labor groups further to avoid any detriment to the interests of workers.
The alliance asked for the Executive Yuan's response to their requests by May 1 -- Labor Day -- when it will organize a labor rally and parade in Taipei to press for their requests.
The surging employment rate also drew fire from opposition lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan.

Opposition People First Party Legislator Chin Huei-chu criticized President Chen Shui-bian's plan to travel overseas on his first anniversary in office as a plot to deflect public attention from his poor performance at home.
She blamed Chen for offering generous aid to Taiwan's allies on his overseas journey despite the sagging domestic economy.
Speaking tongue in cheek, she begged the government to offer "a mite of food" to its people.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lin Kuo-lung cited party Chairman Lien Chan as saying that situation could hardly be worse if the government officials simply slept all day long and did nothing.

Independent Legislator Chen Chin-ting blamed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party for what he described as reneging on its campaign promise to reduce the number of foreign laborers by 15,000 per year. Instead, Chen said, the number of foreign workers in Taiwan increased by 30,000 in the past year.

Meanwhile, in an unrelated development, a group of technicians and janitors working for government agencies complained to legislators Tuesday that their pensions were reduced under the Labor Standards Law.
They claimed that the pension offered by the government before the implementation of the Labor Standards Law in 1998 is more generous than what is required under the new law.
As a result, they further claimed, the longer they serve in their jobs, the less pension they can claim.

However, a CLA official assured them that the Labor Standards Law provides for only the minimum pension for laborers and will not require employers who offer better pensions to their workers to drop their extra payments.

DOC.HEADLINE: LITTLE CHANCE OF TAIWAN JOINING WTO THIS YEAR: COA OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seen as having little chance to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) this year as its membership is so closely linked to mainland China's entry, government sources said Tuesday.

Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi and Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Chen Hsi-huang agreed in a meeting Tuesday that, affected by mainland China's continual postponement of its schedule for joining the world trade regulatory body, Taiwan's WTO entry has been deferred year after year.

Wei Ke-min, deputy director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, who was also present at the meeting on Taiwan's WTO admission and related issues, said there is little chance of Taiwan becoming a WTO member this year as a result of mainland China's deferment.

Economic Affairs Minister Lin seemed less pessimistic, though. He said "little chance" is not the same as "completely hopeless," adding that there could be a breakthrough in a WTO ministerial-level meeting to be held in Qatar at the end of this year concerning Taiwan and mainland China's WTO admission.
COA officials said Taiwan has been told that "the time is close" for the island to enter the WTO since 1998, when Taiwan completed bilateral WTO talks with the United States.

As WTO member countries, including the United States, have tacitly agreed that Taiwan and mainland China should enter the WTO almost simultaneously, albeit with Taiwan scheduled to join a little later than the mainland, Taiwan's WTO bid has been "technically" deferred by the WTO Secretariat since 1998, COA officials said.
Against that backdrop, they added, Taiwan has been prevented from holding its final multilateral WTO working meeting.

Meanwhile, Lin asked for cooperation and compromise from the COA on Taiwan's bid to join the WTO, saying that in addition to the mainland China implication, several WTO contracting members, such as Malaysia and the Philippines, have expressed dissatisfaction with Taiwan in regard to quarantine and quota policies on agricultural products.

If Taiwan's WTO bid is not separated from mainland China's, postponement of the issue will continue, as it is believed the chances of the mainland entering the WTO this year are becoming increasingly slim, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE COULD SHOOT UP TO 4.5 PERCENT: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: It is "inevitable and unavoidable" that Taiwan's unemployment rate will continue to shoot up while the country's industrial restructuring is too slow, a local scholar claimed Tuesday.

Professor Wu Chung-chi of National Taiwan University's Economics Department said no political party or administration will be able to stop the rising jobless rate in the face of the structural problem that the pace of workforce structure readjustment has always lagged behind that of the industrial structure readjustment.

Wu forecast that Taiwan's unemployment rate will continue to increase in the coming two to three years and predicted that the island's unemployment rate will surge to a record high of 4.5 percent this year.
High unemployment as a result of changing global economic trends, which necessitates readjustment of industrial structures, has been the norm in Western and industrially advanced countries, Wu noted.

He suggested that Taiwan emulate member countries of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development in formulating related measures to cope with high unemployment. These measures include cancellation of the basic minimum wage, cancellation of regulated working hours and changing of the retirement pension system into a "personal account system."

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUNKEN DRIVER RECEIVES HEAVY PENALTY IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Taiwan district court convicted a repeat drunken driver to one year and two months imprisonment and confiscated his truck Tuesday, a penalty considered heavy in Taiwan and an apparent warning to other drunken drivers.

Wu Yung-sung, chief justice of southern Taiwan's Pingtung District Court, said the defendant, surnamed Lin, had caused three accidents in 1998, 1999 and 2000, respectively, as a result of driving drunk.

Wu said the verdict was reached at a joint session of the court, which ruled that as the accused had repeatedly threatened the lives and property of other people, he should receive "heavier" punishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY IS TO EXPAND TSOYING NAVAL BASE TO HOUSE BIGGER WARSHIPS

TEXT.P: Republic of China naval authorities are planning to build a second facility at the Tsoying naval base that can accommodate bigger warships, including Kidd-class and Arleigh Burke-class destroyers, a senior naval officer said Tuesday.
The official, who spoke on condition of anoymity, said that the Kidd-class destroyer is as long as the Hsuhai landing craft but 10 meters narrower than the landing craft.
Seaports around Taiwan, including Suao naval port, Makung naval port, and Kaohsiung and Keelung ports, can berth warships of this size.

According to media reports, the U.S. government has decided to allow the sale of Kidd-class destroyers to Taiwan. The destroyers, which have a 10-meter draught, cannot berth at Tsoying, requiring the construction of the new facilities at the Tsoying base.

In order further to expand the port's facilities, the official said, those second-generation warships such as Lafayette-class frigates and Knox-class destroyers -- which are currently berthed at Tsoying -- will be deployed to other naval ports.

Meanwhile, Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Shui-sheng refused to comment on U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, saying only that the MND had not been informed about this year's weapons sales.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO PANAMA'S COLON FREE ZONE INCREASE SIGNIFICANTLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to Panama's Colon Free Zone reached a value of US$509 million in 2000, an increase of 34.1 percent over the year-earlier figure, according to statistics compiled by the Audit Department of Panama.
The statistics also reveal that transshipment trade of Taiwan exports via the Colon Free Zone reached US$13.26 million last year, a growth of 54.8 percent over the 1999 figure.
Taiwan's exports to Colon Free Zone accounted for 11 percent of the zone's total trading volume, compared with 4.29 percent for mainland China and 28.55 percent for Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT SUBMARINES WILL COST TAIWAN US$3 BILLION TO US$4 BILLION

TEXT.P: The eight diesel submarines Washington offered Tuesday to sell to Taiwan will dig deeply into the island's pocket, according to anonymous defense officials.
Although the sale will meet the island's long-held desire to boost its sea defenses, it will cost the island about US$3 billion to US$4 billion, according to the officials.

Given the fact that the United States no longer produces diesel submarines, the hulls of the eight submarines will be built in Germany in two batches of four, for assembly in the United States, probably with General Motors Corp. as the main contractor, the officials said.
In this way, the officials, who are familiar with the arms sales, said Bonn can sidestep its own prohibition of arms sales to Taiwan.
The United States will test the submarines before turning them over to the island and will be responsible for training Taiwanese crew to operate and maintain them, said the officials.
Taiwan listed the German 209/1400 submarines in its shopping list presented to Washington.

The submarine, with a displacement of 1,150 tons and a crew of eight officers and 27 enlisted men, is 61 meters long, 6.2 meters wide and can cruise at a speed up to 21 knots to a range of 10,000 nautical miles.
The ship can dive to 250 meters and remain underwater for 50 days, which is two to three times longer than an average traditional submarine.
Armed with eight torpedo launchers at its bow, the submarine can fire Tigerfish torpedoes or Harpoon anti-submarine missiles.
Defense officers said the submarine, currently used by dozens of countries around the world, has earned a reputation for reliability.

Taiwan already has several submarines in commission, but they are much bigger and hard to maneuver in the Taiwan Strait, which is basically a continental shelf between Taiwan and mainland China, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI TO SIGN COOPERATIVE MEMORANDUM WITH CANADA'S NRC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industry Technology Research Institute (ITRI) will sign a cooperative memorandum with Canada's National Research Council (NRC) Friday to accelerate the upgrading of domestic industries, an ITRI executive said Tuesday.
Lin Chun-hsin, a manager of ITRI's international cooperation department, said the cooperative memorandum will be divided into two aspects:
-- Strengthening exchanges and cooperation between the two nations' small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to expand trade opportunities through the liaison of Canadian Technology Net (CTN); and

-- NRC and ITRI will sign cooperative memoranda on mutual sharing intellectual property rights and patent rights, an effective way to promote bilateral cooperation in the research and development of new products.
Meanwhile, a two-day seminar on technology cooperation between the two nations was unveiled Tuesday, with 70 Taiwan SMEs participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT UNDERGOES MINOR SURGERY IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Kurashiki, Okayama Prefecture, April 24 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui received minor heart surgery at the Kurashiki City Hospital in Okayama Prefecture Tuesday.

Kazuaki Mitsudo, the surgeon in charge of the operation, told a press conference that the minor treatment was carried out on two coronary arteries and added that Lee was required to stay at the hospital overnight for observation.
Lee underwent a successful coronary angioplasty at National Taiwan University Hospital in Taipei last October under Mitsudo's supervision.
The surgeon said that four of the arteries fitted with supporting devices in last October's surgery are functioning well, but another had narrowed, requiring a coronary angioplasty surgery.
He went on that a supporting device was inserted into a sixth artery in the day's operation.
Because of the new operation, Mitsudo said, Lee will have to have another follow-up checkup in six months.
He said that the follow-up checkup could be conducted by other physicians, but added that he will respect the wishes of his patient regarding the matter.
Lee is scheduled to visit Cornell University in New York State -- his alma mater -- from April 30. Mitsudo said the minor operation should not affect that schedule.
Lee flew to Osaka from Taipei last Sunday after the Japanese government granted him a visa on "humanitarian grounds." He is scheduled to leave the hospital for Osaka Wednesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARITIES PLEDGE TO COOPERATE IN YEAREND ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Leaders of two of Taiwan's opposition parties pledged Tuesday to cooperate in the yearend elections of legislators and county chiefs.

Lin Fong-cheng, secretary-general of the Kuomintang and Chung Jung-chi, secretary-general of the People's First Party met Tuesday and confirmed that there is a need for the two parties to cooperate in the yearend elections if either of them are to have a chance of stopping the ruling Democratic Progressive Party from winning a legislative majority.
Huang Teh-fu, director of Lin's office, said afterward that the two party leaders pledged to cooperate on the basis of mutual trust, mutual respect and mutual accommodation.
They also agreed to work out detailed cooperation programs in a series of follow-up meetings, said Huang.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 25, or the third day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1719: Daniel Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe" is published in London. The novel was inspired by the exploits of a Scottish sailor and castaway, Alexander Selkirk.
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, California, to organize the United Nations.
1946: Foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1976: Mrs. Alen M. Schanel, national president of the Ladies Auxiliary of the American Legion, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio," and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH READJUSTED DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) on Wednesday readjusted Taiwan's overall economic growth rate for 2001 to 4.75 percent, about one percentage point lower than its forecast made in January.

The private economic think-tank forecast that economic sluggishness, which is seen as prevailing in the first and second quarters, is expected to bottom out toward the end of June, while real growth is expected to top 5 percent or even higher in the third and fourth quarters.

More precisely, TIER researchers forecast that Taiwan's economy will grow 3.33 percent in the first quarter, 3.91 percent in the second quarter, 5.14 percent in the third quarter and 6.53 percent in the fourth quarter.

TIER researchers predicted that the annual growth in private spending and consumption this year will be a low 4.54 percent, mainly as a result of the continuing plummet in the stock market which has not only caused most investors to lose up to half of their fortunes, but has also led to diminished spending and consumption.

Private sector investment predictions are even more gloomy, with the annual growth in this area expected to be around 2.32 percent for 2001, mainly as a result of the fact that the overall investment environment has not improved in the short term and small- and medium-size enterprises have found it increasingly difficult to obtain soft loans, researchers said.

In the foreign trade sector, the researchers predicted that Taiwan's exports of commodities and services will grow 2.93 percent for 2001, while its imports will grow 1.98 percent. Fortunately, they forecast, the island's trade surplus will reach some NT$10 billion (US$311 million) this year, which is expected to contribute to the island's overall economic growth.
Meanwhile, TIER researchers forecast that the New Taiwan dollar will have an average rate of 32.37 against one U.S. dollar for this year.

The consumer price index is expected to be around a low 1.05 percent for the year while the wholesale price index is expected to grow by a mere 0.75 percent, mainly as a result of economic sluggishness, they said.

In a recent survey of local manufacturers and companies on business prospects in Taiwan, the TIER found that the index of leading indicators, which is designed to forecast economic prospects three to six months in advance, dropped to 91.92, representing the seventh consecutive month to month decrease.

On business prospects for the following six months (from April to September), 31.5 percent of the companies surveyed said business will turn for the worse, compared with 17.5 percent in a similar survey conducted last month.
Meanwhile, 27.4 percent predicted that business prospects will turn for the better over the next half year, a noticeable slide from last month's 40.6 percent, the researchers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 73.14 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 73.14 points to close at 5,516.2.
Market turnover amounted to NT$60.05 billion (US$1.83 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO DEFENDING TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 25 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush has said in interviews with major news media that the United States has an obligation to help Taiwan defend itself in case the island being attacked by mainland China.
In an interview broadcast by ABC Television in its "Good Morning America" program Wednesday, Bush was asked if Washington had a duty to defend the Taiwanese in the event of attack by mainland China.
In response, Bush said: "Yes, we do ... and the (mainland) Chinese must understand that. Yes, I would."
Pressed on whether this mean invoking the full force of the American military, Bush said, "Whatever it took to help Taiwan defend itself."

The interview with ABC was taped Tuesday. On the same day, Bush also gave interviews to several other major U.S. news media, including CBS Television, NBC Television, and the Washington Post, as part of his efforts to brief the Americans on his major policy directions and measures in his first 100 days in office.

In all those interviews, Bush has consistently stressed that the United States is obligated to help Taiwan defend itself under the Taiwan Relations Act, the U.S. law governing engagements with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Bush further said in those interviews that although the United States and mainland China share many common interests, they are also divided over some issues.

"The (mainland) Chinese must understand that we've got common interests; but there's going to be some areas where we disagree and, evidently, one area where we disagree is whether or not the United States ought to provide defensive arms for Taiwan, which I have done," Bush said in an interview posted Tuesday on the Washington Post Web site.
In the interview with the Washington Post, Bush also said he would end a near 20-year U.S. policy of annually reviewing arms sales to Taiwan.
"We have made it clear to the Taiwanese that we will not have this so-called annual review -- that we will meet on an as needed basis," Bush said.
He also told the Washington Post that this year's arms sales package for Taiwan is the right decision and that the United States will keep its right to continue furnishing Taiwan with defensive arms.
