DOC.HEADLINE: LOTT DESCRIBES BUSH'S DECISION ON ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN AS `PRUDENT'

TEXT.P: U.S. Senate Republican leader Trent Lott on Tuesday described President George W. Bush's decision regarding this year's arms sales package to Taiwan as "prudent."
"This is a restrained package. I think the president has made the right decision in view of all the considerations that were on the table," the Mississippi Republican said.

As to the Communist Chinese warning that the proposed arms sales package is going to damage bilateral relations, Lott told reporters after a White House budget meeting that "I think the president was very measured in what he decided to do. China understands that we have some agreements with Taiwan; they have a need to be able to properly defend themselves."

The senator also noted that the approved package does include the four Kidd-class destroyers built in his home state of Mississippi, some submarines, and other important equipment that will be helpful to Taiwan.

As to the Aegis destroyers that Taiwan requested to purchase but will not get this year, Lott pointed out that the problem with the destroyers is "it would be eight to 10 years before they could actually be delivered."
In summary, he said, "this package actually can be helpful, but I think all things considered, the word I use once again is prudent."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ARMS SALE CONDUCIVE TO PEACE IN TAIWAN STRAIT: TECRO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in Washington said Tuesday it is convinced that the U.S. decision on this year's arms sales package to Taiwan is conducive to peace and stability in the Taiwan Straits and constructive cross-strait dialogue in the future.

On behalf of the ROC government, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) welcomed the U.S. arms sales decision made in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979 and Taiwan's security needs.

But TECRO pointed out that "military procurements are not the only guarantee of Taiwan's security. Through constructive dialogue and normalization of cross-strait relations, we can achieve a true and lasting peace."

Nevertheless, the office noted that Beijing has never been willing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, has continued to put off dialogue, and has even deployed additional missiles and forces across from Taiwan.
"Therefore, we have no choice but to acquire defensive weapons to safeguard the lives and property of our people," it said.

TECRO urged Beijing to change its ways so that the two sides can devote the resources being used for military purposes to instead promote stability, foster peaceful competition, and enhance prosperity for people on both sides of the Taiwan Straits and in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL LEADERS SUPPORT ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. House Republican Whip Tom Delay said Tuesday that the president's decision to provide the most robust arms sales package to Taiwan in over a decade "has made it crystal clear that the United States will not allow Communist China to dictate our foreign policy and that we are once again committed to our democratic allies in Taiwan."

Senate Democratic leader Thomas Daschle, meanwhile, noted that he has supported robust arms sales to Taiwan in the past and that he supported this one. "I think the majority of our colleagues in my caucus would support it as well," he said.

"We recognize that there is a delicate balance between ensuring the security of Taiwan and maintaining a good relationship with the government of China. I think this package reflects that," Added the South Dakota Democrat.

Rep. Delay (R-Texas) pointed out in a statement in response to President George W. Bush's arms sales package decision that "it is so encouraging that we now have a president who understands that we can best ensure peace through strength. As the leader of the free world, we have a moral responsibility to stand by our democratic allies and protect democracies."

"I am further encouraged that the administration has made it clear that other weapons requests, including the Aegis system, could be approved in the future if Beijing continues to threaten Taiwan with force. I look forward to working with the Bush administration to ensure that our democratic allies in Taiwan are given the weapons and defenses necessary to protect themselves from China," added the congressman.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBLESS RATE TO PEAK IN AUGUST BEFORE DECLINING: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate is expected to peak in August when a flood of new young graduates swamp the job market, but the rate will not go above 4.5 percent, a top government economic planner said Wednesday.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that although all relevant indices show that the island's unemployment rate had exceeded 4 percent by mid-April, the figure for the whole of 2001 will be effectively controlled and kept under 4.5 percent.

Chen noted that the jobless rate is expected to continue to climb in the following months and reach its apex in August with the number of new job seekers increasing sharply beginning at the end of June.
The jobless rate is expected to drop gradually after August in line with the regular trend seen in previous years, Chen added.
Meanwhile, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) voiced explicit concerns over the country's sliding economy.

KMT spokesman Wang Chih-kang, who was formerly economic affairs minister, said after a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting held Wednesday that the KMT demands that the Democratic Progressive Party-run administration see to it that Taiwan's overall economic growth for this year is maintained at or above 5 percent and the unemployment rate is kept below 4 percent.
Otherwise, Wang said, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and his Cabinet should resign en masse for failing to reach these "mediocre" goals.

On Wednesday, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) made public the figures for Taiwan's two-way trade, showing that imports in the first three weeks of April reached US$6.87 billion, down 13.8 percent from the same period a year earlier, while exports in the same three weeks amounted to US$7.16 billion, down 3.9 percent.
MOF officials attributed the evident decline in two-way trade mainly to the sluggishness of world markets and also to higher comparison bases laid last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 73.14 points to close at 5,516.2.

Affected by a drop in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,594.19 and continued to go down due to the poor performance of electronics shares. The bourse fluctuated between 5,601.35 and 5,500.97 during trading.

A total of 1.71 billion stocks worth NT$60.05 billion (US$1.83 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.04 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$77.65 billion (US$2.37 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with textile issues moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by cement stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.6 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemical shares as well as construction stocks, both at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 341 to 172, with 83 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May moved down 96 points to close at 5,525, with 7,221 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 123 points to finish at 5,503, with 67 contract transactions, while September futures decreased 100 points to close at 5,600, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,621 for May, 5,626 for June, 5,700 for September, 5,777 for December, and 5,768 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
May TE futures lost 5.7 points to finish at 280.9, with 1,970 contract transactions, while June TE futures moved down 5.7 points to close at 280, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures decreased 6.8 points to finish at 716, with 569 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET FORMS TASK FORCE TO PROMOTE WHO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu and Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered the formation of an inter-ministerial task force Wednesday to promote the Republic of China's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO).

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang said the task force should pool resources in both public and private sectors to realize the ROC's goal of becoming a WHO full member or at least an observer of the organization.
Chang said the head of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) should serve as convener of the task force and the minister of foreign affairs as co-convener.

The task force will be composed of officials from the DOH, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Mainland Affairs Council, the Government Information Office and the Council for Cultural Affairs, as well as private medical groups, overseas Chinese associations and ambassadors-at-large.
Chang said relevant government agencies should offer manpower and financial support for various WHO bid-related promotional programs.
He also directed the new task force to dish out working guidelines, detailed promotional programs and policy goals for different phases.
"The task force should supervise operations of various promotional projects and keep close contacts with relevant private organizations," Chang added.

The premier further reminded the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, to include the WHO bid-related issues into the agenda for dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, the U.S. House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved a resolution Tuesday, directing Secretary of State Colin Powell to initiate a U.S. plan to help Taiwan gain observer status at the WHO's annual summit to be held in Geneva next month.
The resolution, approved with a voice vote of 407-0, requires Powell to endorse and help obtain observer status for Taiwan at the upcoming WHO meeting.

The resolution, initiated by Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), is pending approval of the Senate. Once it passes the Senate floor, the resolution will be referred to President George W. Bush for signing into law.
Once the resolution becomes law, Powell will be required to submit a report to Congress within 14 days on how he will achieve the observer status for Taiwan.
The vote came on the same day the white House announced a package of weaponry sales to Taiwan.

Supporters of the resolution said the issue regarding Taiwan's WHO observer status went beyond international politics, arguing that Taiwan has made significant public health advancements and deserves a voice in global health planning and policy.

During Tuesday's House debate, Brown said Taiwan is prepared to contribute meaningfully to the global health efforts discussed at WHO assembly. "But without observer status, its delegates can't even enter the room," said the Ohio Democrat.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.023 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 32.908.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 32.878 and was traded between 32.878 and 32.911.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$333.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO BECOME `COMPETITIVE COUNTRY WITH KNOWLEDGE-BASED ECONOMY'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
He made the statement while delivering a speech at a rally in Taipei to mark the 25th anniversary of the introduction of IC technology into Taiwan.
Chen lauded the achievements of the island's IC-related industries in the past 25 years.

He said that the competitiveness of a country comes from the competitiveness of its industry and added that the semiconductor industry is an important sector that has stimulated major investment and promoted economic development in Taiwan.

Now that Taiwan has a significant share of the world's semiconductor industry, Chen said that "the government is determined to take long-term steps to improve the fundamental structure of the economy with a target of developing Taiwan into a global competitive knowledge-based country in five years."
The president attributed the achievement of Taiwan's development in the semiconductor industry mainly to the joint efforts of the government and the industry in the past 25 years.
In the past, he said, the government played an important role in providing capital for the development and transfer of IC technology.
Now, he went on, the government will focus more attention on the creation of a better investment environment so as to help enterprises employ new knowledge to renovate industry.

At the rally, attended by nearly 200 people, former Premier Sun Yun-suan and former Finance Minister K.T. Li were cited for their outstanding contributions to the introduction of IC technology into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO SAY `NO' TO U.S. SALE OF KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS

TEXT.P: Legislator Lee Ching-hua of the opposition People First Party (PFP) called for the Republic of China government Wednesday to say "no" to the United States on its offer to sell Taiwan four Kidd-class destroyers.
Lee called a press conference at the Legislative Yuan to announce his "12 reasons" why Taiwan should turn down the U.S. offer of Kidd-class destroyers.
Lee's reasons are:
-- That the DDG-993 Kidd-class destroyer is more than 20 years old and its structure and equipment are aged;
-- That with its huge size and low mobilization speed during wartime, it would be an easy target for Beijing's forces;
-- That its special design and specifications require expensive logistic and maintenance costs;

-- That its mechanical 3D radar system is less sophisticated than the Aegis radar system of the Arleigh Burke-class destroyers, which he claimed are the backbone of the U.S. Navy, while its air surveillance capability is not as good as that of early-warning surveillance aircraft;
-- That its Standard II anti-aircraft missile system is not capable of deterring missile attacks;

-- That the cost of NT$25 billion for four Kidd-class destroyers, plus costs for initiation of weaponry systems and related equipment, port reconstruction, logistics and personnel will be a mammoth expense for the government; and
-- That the United States tried twice in 1998 and 1999 to sell the four Kidd destroyers to Greece and Australia, but were turned down.

U.S. President George W. Bush approved a robust arms sales package worth more than US$4 billion to Taiwan Tuesday. The package, the largest since 1992 -- when the U.S. government agreed to sell Taiwan 150 F-16 jet fighters -- includes eight diesel-electric submarines, 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and four Kidd-class destroyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT DISCHARGED FROM HOSPITAL
DOC.DATELINE: Kurashiki, Japan, April 25 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui was discharged from the Kurashiki City Hospital Wednesday following minor heart surgery performed the previous day.
After assuring reporters outside the hospital that he "feels better," Lee returned to his hotel in nearby Osaka, followed by his attending physician Kazuaki Mitsudo.

Mitsudo performed a coronary angioplasty on Lee -- his second such surgery since last November -- to unclog two of his arteries. The previous operation, done in Taiwan, was also performed under Mitsudo's supervision.
A supporting device was inserted into one of Lee's arteries, requiring Lee, 78, to stay overnight at the hospital for observation.
Lee flew to Osaka from Taipei Sunday after the Japanese government granted him a visa on "humanitarian grounds."

DOC.HEADLINE: CSBC VOWS TO BUILD SUBMARINES FOR NAVY WITH FOREIGN COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) said Wednesday it will seek cooperation with foreign companies to win a bid to build eight diesel-powered submarines for the Republic of China Navy.
CSBC Chairman Yu Chen-nan said at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting that the CSBC is capable of building submarines, so long as it can acquire certain technical know-how from foreign shipbuilders.

The United States has unveiled the package of weaponry systems it has agreed to sell Taiwan this year, including eight diesel submarines. As the United States has not manufactured any diesel submarines for years, it may seek cooperation with a third country to supply the submarines to Taiwan.

Two of the possible U.S. cooperative partners -- Germany and the Netherlands -- have said they have no interest in cooperating with the United States in building submarines for Taiwan, as they are afraid such a deal would worsen their ties with mainland China.

Yu told lawmakers that when the CSBC was building Perry-class missile frigates for the ROC Navy between 1990 and 1998, the Dutch shipbuilding company RDM sent engineers to the CSBC shipyards to evaluate the firm's shipbuilding capacity and technological level.

"At that time, RDM technicians had said the CSBC has the capability and technical expertise to build submarines," Yu said, adding that the CSBC will ask the Ministry of National Defense and the navy to help it acquire technology transfers from the United States to facilitate its bid to build the eight submarines.
With experience accumulated from building more than 80 types of military and commercial vessel, Yu said, the CSBC is confident of its capability to build diesel submarines for the ROC Navy.
The eight submarines will be armed with advanced American weaponry systems.

A CNA report from Washington, D.C. quoted a U.S. Pentagon spokesman as saying Tuesday that the United States could facilitate a submarine purchase by Taiwan from other nations that build such vessels, including Germany, the Netherlands or Italy.
A Pentagon spokesman, Navy Rear Adm. Craig Quigley, further said this year's U.S. arms sale package for Taiwan will greatly upgrade the ROC's naval defense capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ARMS SALES AIMED AT KEEPING TAIWAN STRAIT PEACE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that U.S. arms sales to Taiwan are mainly aimed at safeguarding peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with German Parliament (Bundestag) Deputy Speaker Hermann Otto Solms, who is currently leading a German parliamentary delegation on a six-day visit to the Republic of China.
As Solms has long staunchly supported German arms sales to Taiwan, Chen especially mentioned in their talks a package of weaponry systems the United States has agreed to sell the ROC this year.
The biggest prizes in the new U.S. arms sale package are eight diesel-powered submarines that Taiwan has long wanted to buy.
Chen told his guests that the submarine purchases will not only help beef up Taiwan's underwater combat capability but will also contribute to Taiwan Strait peace and security.

Chen said he appreciates the favorable U.S. response to Taiwan's defense needs and that he is convinced there will be room for ROC-U.S. and ROC-Germany cooperation in "relevant fields." He did not elaborate.

The president further pointed out that the ROC's procurement of advanced arms is purely for defensive purposes and stressed that Taiwan also has no intention of engaging in an arms race with mainland China.

"We just want to defend our democratic way of life as well as safeguard Taiwan Strait security and Asia-Pacific regional peace and stability," he explained, adding: "Only when Taiwan's own security is ensured can its 23 million people have the confidence to open the island's doors wide for dialogue and negotiations with mainland China."

Noting that the ROC has been a peace-loving country and a peacemaker in the Asia-Pacific region, Chen said the ROC is forced to purchase defensive weapons in the face of mainland China's sharp increase in its defense budget and intensified military buildup and missile deployment along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan.

"So long as mainland China phases out its missiles targeting Taiwan, we'll be more than willing to largely cut our military spending and use the saved funds to improve the living quality and environment of our people," he stressed.
Chen further said he feels honored to receive the 2001 Prize for Freedom, sponsored by the London-based Liberal International, a worldwide federation of liberal political parties.

"I believe that the award marks a recognition of Taiwan's democratic achievement," Chen said, adding that it will be an irony if he can't freely travel to Denmark later this year to receive the award in person simply because of Beijing's opposition. Denmark recognizes mainland China.
As Solms' party is a member of the Liberal International, Chen asked Solms to assist in paving the way for his Denmark travel plan.
For his part, Solms said he fully understands that the ROC purchases weapons for self-defense and to maintain regional balance, not for provocation.

"As Germany endured two world wars and national division before it finally achieved its goal of national unification, I'm fully aware of the importance of possessing enough defensive weapons for self-defense purposes," Solms said.

Before the unification of West and East Germany, Solms said, the two Germanys had a total of 700,000 troops. "After unification, the number of German military servicemen has declined to 250,000," the German parliamentarian said, adding that he hopes peace will prevail permanently in the Taiwan Strait and other parts of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI-PHNOM PENH AIR SERVICE MAY OPEN THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: A Republic of China government official said Wednesday that regular air services between Taipei and Phnom Penh are expected to open within this year.
Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), made the remarks before the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee under the Legislative Yuan.
Four legislators of the committee, who recently visited Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand, proposed that the government ask EVA Airways to open the Taipei-Phnom Penh service as early as possible.
They pointed out that the existing three weekly flights between Kaohsiung and Phnom Penh operated by Taiwan-based Mandarin Airlines are unable to meet the increasing demand.

Chang told the lawmakers that under the ROC-Cambodia aviation agreement signed in March 1998, Taiwan's EVA Airways and Cambodia's President Airlines are authorized to operate the service linking the capitals of the two countries.
However, he went on, the agreement has not been put into practice because of political and "other" reasons.

The CAA official disclosed that EVA Airways has started negotiating with President Airlines on the opening of a regular service between Taipei and Phnom Penh and added that the project is expected to be realized within this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: OSCAR-WINNING DIRECTOR PLANNING PREQUEL OF `CROUCHING TIGER'

TEXT.P: Director Ang Lee had another hectic day Wednesday in his homecoming trip, starting with a discussion with a screenwriter of a prequel to his Oscar-winning film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon."

Lee held a three-hour meeting with screenwriter Hsia Mei-hua and producer Hsu Li-kung on the spirit the new film should try to project and its possible direction. Hsia said she has always admired Lee's "ebullience" in film making and that she learned a lot from the meeting.

Asked why Lee was not collaborating again with Wang Hui-ling, who received an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," Hsu explained that Wang is currently working on two other films and could not find the time to do its prequel.
According to reports, the prequel will center on the two Kung Fu masters portrayed by Hong Kong star Chow Yun-fat and Malaysian-born Michelle Yeoh in the original film.

Lee said that he was satisfied with the ending of "Crouching Tiger" -- in which the character played by mainland up-and-coming actress Zhang Ziyi jumps into a sea of clouds from a mountain -- and that there will be no sequel to the film.
Also that day, Lee met with Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang and later James Soong, chairman of one-year-old People First Party.

Lien presented Lee with an award for his achievement, noting that the picture drew together film workers from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China, making the Oscar and honor for all Chinese from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.
Lee said that "Crouching Tiger" is a testing and trailblazing work and that he will continue to work in the film industry.
"Crouching Tiger" won four Oscars -- best cinematography, best art direction, best original score and best foreign-language film.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN `VOWS TO QUIT' IF PARTY LOSES 3 SEATS IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh vowed Wednesday to step down from his post if the party loses three or more seats in the year-end legislative elections.
Hsieh, who is also Kaohsiung City mayor, made the remarks in a visit to the DPP legislative caucus Wednesday.
As to the topic of a coalition government, Hsieh refused to comment, saying only that it may be one of the possibilities in the future and needs further observation.

Meanwhile, DPP legislative caucus convener Chou Po-lun said the party would not predict any political possibility and agreed with Hsieh that the DPP will choose any cooperation partner that has a good image, is stable and has ideals close to those of the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION EMBARKS ON QUAKE-AID MISSION IN INDIA
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, April 25 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of lawmakers and volunteers from the Republic of China donated US$1 million in cash and relief goods to India Wednesday to help victims of an earthquake that rattled the Indian state of Gujarat Jan. 26.
The relief fund and goods, including 25 ambulances, were raised under a "With Love from Taiwan" campaign initiated by ROC Vice President Annette Lu earlier this year.

The 20-member delegation arrived in New Delhi Tuesday. Yu Kuang-shih, leader of the group, said the mission will travel to the earthquake-affected regions to look into what kinds of aid the Indian people most need and the ratios of cash aid and relief goods offered by other countries around the world.

Prior to their departure, Yu said, Vice President Lu had encouraged all mission members to show their concern and love for Indian quake victims to signify the strength of Taiwan's soft-power diplomacy.

Under the arrangement of the ROC representative office in India, the delegation met with Indian ruling party BJP Vice Chairman Madan Lal Khurana, and Ashok Koshy, representative of the quake-stricken Gujarat state in New Delhi, Tuesday afternoon.
During the meeting, Legislator Parris Chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party told his hosts that the delegation symbolizes the ROC people's love and concern for Indian quake victims.
"Give, care and share are the main purposes of our current visit," said Chang, who serves as an adviser to the delegation.
At least 30,000 people were killed and tens of thousands injured in the earthquake that hit Gujarat in January.
ROC Representative to India Chien Kang-tan briefed the delegation on the current state of substantive Taiwan-Indian relations Tuesday.
Chien said current ROC-Indian relations face many obstacles due primary to India's reluctance to develop official ties with Taiwan for fears of offending Beijing.

He also outlined the ROC representative office's priority work programs, including pushing for Taiwan-Indian direct airlinks, signing an investment protection agreement and a temporary customs clearance accord, as well as promoting exchanges of visits by high-ranking officials of the two countries.

After wrapping up its Gujarat visit, the delegation will travel to the northern Indian city of Dharamsala, the seat of the Tibetan government-in-exile. The delegation will study the feasibility of a proposal, initiated Vice President Lu, to help the Tibetan government-in-exile build a school for children of Tibetan exiles in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FORMALLY INFORMS ROC OF ARMS SALES DECISION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 25 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government has formally informed a Taiwan delegation on its decision regarding arms sales to Taiwan at the first round of an annual U.S.-ROC arms sales meeting.

Pentagon Spokesman A. Quigley said the government has agreed to offer Taiwan the option of buying four Kidd-class destroyers, eight diesel-powered submarines and 12 P-3 anti-submarines aircraft, as well as a range of other military equipment.
Quigley described this year's arms sales as "a robust package" aimed at upgrading Taiwan's naval combat capability.

Without mentioning the price tag for the arms sales, Quigley pointed out that Taiwan must evaluate cost, training and maintenance elements before informing the U.S. authorities of the items and quantities it is prepared to buy.

Quigley further pointed out that the U.S. authorities will adopt measures to resolve the problem raised by the fact that the United States has stopped manufacturing the diesel-powered submarines which are included in the arms sale list. He pointed out that there are a lot of countries in the world manufacturing well-designed diesel-powered submarines.

According to military observers, the United States will not reopen a production line for the diesel-powered submarines but might cooperate with a third party -- probably Germany or Holland -- to have the submarines built. The observers pointed out, however, that Beijing would be expected to put pressure on any country collaborating with the United States to build the submarines for Taiwan.
Although Quigley's reluctance to elaborate on the details of the arms sales, a well-informed source confirmed to CNA that the details of the arms sales package are as follows:
-- Four Kidd-class destroyers;
-- 12 P-3 anti-submarine planes;
-- Paladin self-propelled artillery system;
-- MH-53E minesweeping helicopters;
--AAV7A1 amphibious Assault vehicles;
-- Avenger surface-to-air missile system;
-- MK48 torpedoes without advanced capabilities;
-- Submarine-launched and surface-launched torpedoes; and
-- Aircraft survival equipment.
The United States refused to sell Aegis-equipped destroyers, MIAI tanks and Apache helicopters to Taiwan.
The package is the biggest one since Bush's father sold 150 F-16 jet fighters to Taiwan in 1992.
The Clinton administration turned down Taiwan's request to purchase submarines over the past eight years on the grounds that submarines are assault vessels.

According to congressional sources, the Bush administrative has clearly stated that whether or not the United States decides to sell Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan in the future will depend on the threat Beijing's military poses to Taiwan in the next two years.

Although a handful of right-wing congressmen criticized Bush's refusal to the sell the Aegis-equipped Arleigh Burke-class destroyers to Taiwan, the decision received praise from the vast majority in Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT COMMENTS ON U.S. ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that American arms sales to Taiwan are designed to uphold the democracy of Taiwan, rather than promoting an arms race with mainland China.

Meeting with Hong Kong-based novelist Chin Yung, Chen described the arms sales package announced by the U.S. government as the richest-ever and a new breakthrough in terms of U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
He said the latest U.S. arms sales to Taiwan will help stabilize the cross-Taiwan Strait situation and promote peace in the world.
During their talks at the Presidential Office, Chen expressed disagreement with Chin Yung's views over two matters.
Chin Yung had remarked at a symposium at the University of Zhejiang in October 1999 that news media should abide by the guidance of the national government and ruling political party.
Chen said that he disagreed with that view, noting that the world has entered an era of democracy.

During the 1996 missile crisis, the U.S. government dispatched two aircraft carriers to waters adjacent to the Taiwan Strait. The U.S. move was labeled by Chin Yung as contrary to mainland China's unification policy, but Chen disagreed with that view as well.
Despite their different opinions on these matters, the president stressed that he still respects Chin Yung and will defend Chin Yung's right to free speech.

Chin Yung told reporters after his meeting with Chen that he had expressed the hope that the ROC president will resolve all issues through peaceful means. Chin Yung said that Chen fully agreed with his suggestion and indicated that Taiwan's purchase of arms from the United States is designed to augment Taiwan's defense capability, and not to engage in war against mainland China. (By Victor Lai) ENDITME ZCZC CEP026 04-25-01 KING OF SWAZILAND TO SEEK MEDICAL TREATMENT IN TAIWAN

Johannesburg, April 24 (CNA) King Mswati III of Swaziland is expected to travel to Taiwan to receive medical treatment after allegedly being poisoned by one of his wives, a South African newspaper reported Tuesday.
According to a report filed from Swaziland's capital of Mbabane, King Mswati III is suffering from bromatoxism poisoning, but is recovering.

The report quoted the king's personal secretary as saying that although the king is doing better now, the speed of recovery is slow, prompting him to decide to head to Taiwan for further examination and treatment.
It was learned that the king's mother visited Taiwan last year to receive treatment for an undisclosed illness.

According to reports in other South African media, the king became sick after eating soup prepared by Lambikiza, one of his eight wives, who fled to Britain to live with her ambassador father following the incident, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS INVESTIGATE `BLACK GOLD' IN FARMERS' ASSOCIATION ELECTION

TEXT.P: Prosecutors brought in all 28 board trustees and supervisers of the Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association Wednesday for questioning on reported cases of vote-buying in that day's association chairman election.

The association, which supervises 304 local farmers' associations islandwide, has been plagued with rumors of vote-buying for sums as high as NT$40 million (US$1.2 million) per vote, free vacation give-aways and even sexual favors.

In the election, carried out via secret ballot, chairman contender Ku Yuan-chun received 12 board trustee votes, while Lin Chao-ying, who was backed by the opposition Kuomintang, received only nine votes.
The vote for association secretary-general followed immediately, with Huang Hsi-hsing elected.
Huang, two other candidates for secretary-general, five staffers and three other election-related individuals were also brought in for questioning at four separate locations in central Taiwan.
The new administration has vowed to fight "black gold," or the involvement of illegal monetary influence in elections and government affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE PREFER LOCAL BRANDS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan people prefer local soft drink Hey Song to Coca Cola and enjoy Taiwan beer more than Japan's Kirin's prime brew, according to a survey by the Asian edition of the Reader's Digest.

The survey on the consumer preferences of Asian and Taiwan people divided products into 38 categories, including cell phones, automobiles, hotels, beverages and cosmetics, and asked those polled to select their favorite brands based on quality, value, image, reliability and satisfaction.
Taiwan people said local brand Hey Song is their favorite soft drink, beating out Coca Cola, the survey found. The preference for local brands is also evident in other foodstuffs and beverages.
As well as beer, Taiwan respondents also said that local tea brands such as Tien Jen and Kaisi are as good as Lipton.
Instant noodles made by Wei Lih Men and seasonal products produced by Wei Chuan, two other local companies, are also favorites.
Among airlines, China Airlines (CAL) and Eva Airways, both Taiwan-based, received as high marks as Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific and Singapore Airlines, underscoring CAL's efforts to improve its image.
President Enterprises' products are very popular in Taiwan, with the highest or nearly highest scores in cooking oil, seasonal products, drinking water and instant noodles.
In terms of computers, local brand Acer won recognition equal to that of U.S. giant IBM among Taiwan users.
Among cosmetics, Taiwan women like SKII and France's Guerlain for skin care, and Shiseito and SKII for cosmetics.
In electronic appliances, National refrigerators and washing machines won recognition in Taiwan, along with Sanyo washing machines and Sony and Matsushita electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: 140,000 PEOPLE OUT OF WORK OVER PAST SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: Affected by economic sluggishness and an 84-hour bi-weekly work scheme, some 140,000 workers lost their jobs during the period between Aug. 2000 and Feb. 2001, according to the results of a recent survey.

Conducted by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the survey found that average working hours among Taiwan workers fell by 9.4 hours during the first two months of this year as compared to the year-earlier level, while the number of employed workers posted a sixth consecutive monthly drop.

Of the 9.4 million employed workers, some 5.72 million were working for private businesses, 950,000 were government employees and 1.48 million people owned their own businesses, according to the survey. Of the 140,000 who lost their jobs during the six-month period, around 139,000 were discharged by private firms, while the number of private business owners also fell by 30,000.

At the same time, the poll discovered that the average salary increase for local workers was only 1.68 percentage points in the first two months of the year, an historic low for the period. This is an indication that current economic problems have resulted in noticeable number of factory closures and employee layoffs, the DGBAS pointed out.

It is worth noting that the average working hours of domestic workers fell by 9.4 during the first two months of the year, as the legal working hours set by the government dropped from 96 hours every two weeks to 84 hours, the survey indicated.

It found that the food-processing sector registered the largest reduction in on-the-job hours, with workers in the industry working an average of 12 fewer hours. That figure was followed by financial service sector workers, who lost 9.2 working hours; and employees of the retail, restaurant and warehouse and distribution businesses, who worked an average of 8.9 fewer hours during the period, the survey found.

DOC.HEADLINE: KEELUNG FISHING BOAT COMMANDEERED TO GUAM
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, northern Taiwan, April 25 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese fishermen on board a Keelung-based fishing boat who were trussed up on the high seas last Wednesday by eight mainland Chinese crewmen were rescued Wednesday by U.S. forces stationed on Guam, according to a fishermen's radio station.

The mainland crewmen, after kidnapping the skipper and two other Taiwanese fishermen, sailed the craft into waters off the Pacific island of Guam, where they jumped ship and sneaked onto the island, a U.S. territory, the Keelung Fishermen Radio Station said.
The radio station said the Taiwanese crewmen sent a rescue signal and were rescued Wednesday by U.S. forces stationed on Guam.
The radio station said the three were still in Guam, adding that the U.S. side will decide when to let the mutiny victims go back to Taiwan after completing necessary investigations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SILICON VALLEY DELEGATION ARRIVES FOR FIVE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: A delegation comprised of Silicon Valley business leaders and officials from San Jose, California arrived here for a five-day visit Wednesday.

A spokesman for the group said that Silicon Valley and Taipei are two of the fastest growing cites and high-tech centers, and that there are many similarities between the two. The goal of the visit will be to promote trade exchanges between Silicon Valley and Taipei.

Taiwan is the third largest export market for San Jose, buying some US$3.06 billion worth of Silicon Valley-made products in 1999, and statistics show that there are about 50,000 engineers from Taiwan now living in Silicon Valley.
The delegation is expected to meet with business leaders in Taiwan's information industry and call on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou as well as foreign affairs officials during their stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASHES OF ROC SURVEILLANCE PLANE CREWMEN TO BE RETURNED TO FAMILIES

TEXT.P: Family members of the 14 crewmen of a Republic of China surveillance plane downed by mainland China in 1963 will travel to Jiangxi Province in early May to regain the ashes of their beloved ones.

The fate of the ROC crewmen contrasted greatly with that of the 24 crew members of a U.S. spy plane that collided in early April with a mainland Chinese fighter and made an emergency landing on the mainland-controlled island of Hainan. After much rhetorical jousting, the unharmed U.S. servicemen and women were released by mainland authorities.

Chou I-li, the former leader of the ROC military's 34th squadron -- also known as the "Black Bat Squadron" -- was the pilot of the ROC plane that was downed 38 years ago. His son, Chou Tien, narrated the story of the flight for reporters in his suburban Los Angeles residence.
Chou said the ill-fated P-2V plane entered mainland Chinese air space on a nighttime surveillance mission on June 19, 1963.

Eight mainland Chinese MiG fighters scrambled to chase and intercept the spy plane, which was eventually brought down over Linchuan in the central mainland province of Jiangxi, Chou said, adding that his father and 13 other crew members all died in the incident.

Chou said he had never stopped searching for his father until recently, when he found out -- 38 years after the incident -- that the remains of the crew members had been buried in a graveyard on the outskirts of Linchuan.
Chou then contacted the families of other crew members, and they decided to travel to Jiangxi Province to return the ashes of these heroic airmen to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC APPRECIATES U.S. ARMS SALES BASED ON SECURITY NEEDS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China welcomes the latest U.S. decision to sell it a package of defensive weapons based on the provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and its practical security needs, the Presidential Office said Wednesday.

The Presidential Office made the remarks in a press release. It was also the ROC's first official response to the Bush administration's Tuesday approval of a robust arms sale package to Taiwan, including eight diesel submarines, four Kidd-class destroyers and 12 P-3 Orion anti-submarine aircraft.

The press statement said the ROC government appreciates all the concern shown by the U.S. government, Congress and individual people in various social quarters for Taiwan's security and military balance of power in the Taiwan Strait in the U.S. decision-making process.

It pointed out that the U.S. decision will not only help beef up Taiwan's defense capability and reinforce self-confidence of the people of Taiwan but will also help maintain stability and balance of military strength in the Taiwan Strait and contribute to future cross-strait dialogue on an equal footing.

Noting that Taiwan full understands arms procurement is not the only way to defend its national security, the statement said true and permanent peace can be achieved only through constructive dialogue and normalization of relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In fact, the statement said, the ROC is forced to purchase necessary defensive weapons to meet its basic security needs and protect its people from military threat in the face of mainland China's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, its intensified deployment of Taiwan-targeting missiles and its reluctance to resume cross-strait dialogue.

"We earnestly hope that the Beijing leadership can understand that our arms purchases and defense policies are mainly aimed at countering mainland China' military threat," the statement said, adding that Taiwan looks forward to seeing mainland China change its practice, renounce the use of force, phase out all Taiwan-targeting missiles and resume peaceful cross-strait dialogue and consultations.

The statement also reiterated the ROC's expectation that both sides of the Taiwan Strait cut arms procurement and use the saved funds on economic development, infrastructure construction, medical service, education and social welfare programs.

It further said the two sides should engage in peaceful competition in political and social systems and work together to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and entire Asia-Pacific region.

Meanwhile, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said at a weekly Cabinet meeting that the ROC government is grateful for the U.S. decision to sell a package of advanced defensive weapons to Taiwan in line with the TRA and its defense requirements. The TRA is the U.S. law governing relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Chang also said the ROC will do its utmost to maintain stable relations across the Taiwan Strait and replace conflict with dialogue.
Stressing that the ROC has no intention of starting a cross-strait arms race, Chang said the ROC's biggest desire is to forge a stable, peaceful cross-strait relationship.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs also issued a statement Wednesday, welcoming the new U.S. arms sale package to Taiwan.
The ministry recognized the U.S. adherence to its security commitment to the ROC.
The ministry said the arms sale package will contribute to Taiwan's defense and upgrading of local people's confidence as well as to the maintenance of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that both the ROC and the United States uphold freedom, democracy and human rights, the ministry said substantive relations between the two countries will continue to grow in the years to come. (By Sofia Wu) ENITEM ZCZC CEP034 04-25-01 TAIWAN IC INDUSTRY CELEBRATES 25TH ANNIVERSARY

Taipei, April 25 (CNA) Beginning with a team of burgeoning young talent and a shady "model factory" in the outskirts of northern Hsinchu County in 1976, Taiwan has managed to transform itself into a world-class IC power under its own steam.
On the 25th anniversary of the introduction of IC technology into Taiwan, industry heavyweights and elites got together Wednesday to celebrate at the Grand Hotel.

Taking part in the event were Senior Presidential Advisers Sun Yun-suan and K. T. Li, the leading promoters of a government project that gave birth to Taiwan's IC industry, as well as foreign consultants and 43 members recruited by the government from both at home and abroad at that time.

Robert H.C. Tsao, board chairman of United Micro Electronics Co., Hu Ding-hua, manager of Macro International Corp., and Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) President Chintay Shih were among the young techies sent by the government to "take lessons" from the U.S.-based firm RCA 25 years ago under a special project initiated by then-President Chiang Ching-kuo in 1974.

Two years after they returned from the United States, the government-financed ITRI finally set up a "model factory" in a desolate location with a government subsidiary of NT$480 million in cooperation with the new IC experts.

The industry faced an unknown future 25 years ago, but Taiwan is now the world's third-largest IC power in terms of its production abilities, has a 13.5 percent stake in the global market, and is the world's fourth-largest producer in terms of output value.

United Micro Electronics Corp. was spun off by ITRI as the first such high-tech firm in 1980. Starting with just NT$360 million in capital and 36 employees, it has since developed into a major company with capital of NT$114.7 billion (US$3.5 billion) and 9,700 workers.

The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation, another world-class hi-tech firm, originated from ITRI in 1987. It has also expanded into an huge enterprise, boasting capital of NT$130 billion (US$4 billion) and a workforce of 14,400.

With a strong sense of social responsibility and an ambitious desire to succeed, these firms have accomplished the "impossible mission" of giving Taiwan a leading role in the world hi-tech spectrum. In the process, they broke all the rules and shattered the myth that developing countries should stay away from the automobile, airplane and IC industries.
The industry pioneers, most of whom were in their early 30s when it all started but have since become grizzled and savvy industry maestros, expressed no regrets over the path they took.
Now sitting on enviable fame and huge fortunes, all the industry pioneers who jumped into the venture so long ago had one unanimous exclamation: "It is fantastic, and it is worthy trying."

Voicing the hope that the experience of their lives will pass on to younger generations, they jointly made a donation to set up a fund in commemoration of the contribution made by W. Y. Pan. They said they wanted to encourage young men to build a strong sense of responsibility for the country at a time when it once again needs more creative and innovative ideas in the face of fierce competition from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPOWNERS BEAR ONLY LIMITED RESPONSIBILITY IN MARINE DISPUTE: MOTC

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) said that according to international maritime law, shipowners bear only limited responsibility for freight that is removed from their ships.

He added that Taiwan should pay US$1.8 million to settle the case of the Greek freighter "Amorgos," which ran aground in waters off the southern tip of Taiwan and spilled oil along the coast of the Kenting area last December. The payment has invited criticism from legislators, but MOTC Vice Minister Chang Chia-chu said that for Taiwan to assume part of the charges is in accordance with international norms.

According to international customs, the shipowner should bear the full responsibility of cleaning up the spilled oil but has limited responsibility of removing the ship's cargo, which means that Taiwan should pay part of the charges, Chang explained.

The "Amorgos" incident has gone through three stages -- cleaning up spilled oil, removing its cargo, and removing the ship itself. This has been carried out under the jurisdiction of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) and the MOTC, respectively, Chang said.
Chang pointed out that the MOTC and EPA have jointly named an attorney to handle negotiating the issue with the lawyer of the shipowner.

During the talks, the shipowner asked Taiwan to lift a prohibition on the return of the ship's four crewmembers and to abolish the NT$1.5 million daily fine imposed by the government agencies concerned, Chang said, adding that the shipowner at one point threatened to discard the ship and cargo at the scene.

Chang said that the government has lifted the exit prohibition order for one of the four crew members on humanitarian considerations, because he has suffered a family disaster since the accident. If the shipowner disagrees, he should resolve the dispute through an administrative suit, the minister added.
As to the US$1.5 million charge for cleaning up the oil, the shipowner should bear the full responsibility, Chang said. He added that the removal of the ship and its cargo will cost US$4.3 million.
After deducting the shipowner's bill of US$2.46 million, Taiwan will still have to cover US$1.84 million, in accordance with international customs, the minister said.

However, Chang said that the shipowner should bear the full responsibility of any compensatory damages for losses resulting from seawater pollution caused by oil spilled from the ship. The EPA has also asked for NT$250 million in compensation from the shipowner, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROVIDE MORE NEWS FROM A `THAI PERSPECTIVE': OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, April 25 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A senior Republic of China official told local media representatives Wednesday that the ROC Government Information Office (GIO) will strive to provide more news from "a Thai perspective" to promote greater understanding of Taiwan here.

Frederic P.N. Chang, deputy director-general of the GIO, said in the northern Thai city of Chiang Mai that the reports will focus on the actual living and working conditions of the 140,000-some Thai workers in Taiwan.

He added that the reports will also cover the effects of Taipei-Beijing relations on the security of the Southeast Asian region, Taiwan's investment potential in foreign countries and other issues related to Thailand.

Chang criticized Beijing for adversely affecting regional security through its saber-rattling at Taiwan. The choice of the 23 million people of Taiwan must be respected when determining future Taipei-Beijing relations, he said, adding that Beijing's unilateral explanation of the so-called "one China" principle completely disregards Taiwan's good will.
He urged the local media to report on the efforts Taiwan has made toward better Taipei-Beijing ties with professionalism, fairness, balance and objectivity.

Economic, civil and official exchanges between Taiwan and Thailand have not been affected despite the current lack of diplomatic ties, Chang continued. He noted that trade officials from the two governments often meet in international conferences, and that the two sides have close investment, labor and tourism ties.

Chang pointed out that Thailand is Taiwan's 12th largest trading partner and Taiwan is Thailand's sixth largest trading partner, with Thailand enjoying a trade surplus of US$200 million on bilateral trade totaling US$5.3 billion last year.

Taiwan is Thailand's fourth largest foreign investor, with a total of over US$10.3 billion invested, he said, adding that Taiwan is also Thailand's largest export market for laborers, accounting for 43 percent of Taiwan's total foreign labor force.
Also, over 550,000 Taiwan tourists visited Thailand last year, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 TAIWAN DEEP-SEA FISHING SHIPS SINK, ALL CREWMEN RESCUED
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, April 25 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Nine fishermen on board a Pingtung-based fishing boat were rescued by a foreign freighter early Wednesday after their boat sank due to a leak in the cabin, according to a fishermen's radio station, which added that they were sent to Japan.

The 48.29-ton fishing vessel "Hung Shun Tsai" was operating in waters southeast of the Pacific island of Guam, a U.S. territory, when its cabin began leaking Tuesday, Tungkang Fishery Radio Station said.

The skipper of the boat ordered that the ship be abandoned early Wednesday. Fortunately, all of the crewmen were rescued by a passing by foreign freighter and were brought to Japan, the fishermen's radio station said.

The radio station has informed the Council of Agriculture, Taiwan's highest government body in charge of agriculture, forest, fishery and livestock affairs, to help bring the fishermen back to Taiwan.

Tungkang Fishermen Radio Station also reported that another Pingtung-based vessel, the 62.76-ton "Jui Yi Hsiang No.2," sank Tuesday while fishing in waters off Sri Lanka, also due to a serious leak. All the 12 crewmen on board were rescued by another Taiwanese fishing boat.
The radio station said the rescued crewmen will arrive in Penang, Malaysia Sunday, from where they will return to Taiwan under the arrangements of their company.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT INFORMED OF U.S. DROPPING OF ANNUAL ARMS SALES REVIEW

TEXT.P: Taipei has not been informed thus far of any decision by Washington to drop the annual review of its requests for arms sales, according to the Ministry of National Defense Wednesday.

U.S. President George Bush told the Washington Post in an interview published Wednesday that his administration will scrap the annual review of Taiwan's requests for arms and will consider the island's defense needs whenever necessary.
A spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense refused to comment on the reports, saying only that Taiwan is unaware of Washington's decision thus far.

A number of Taiwan military officials were in Washington for a regular meeting with their U.S. counterparts to discuss the ROC's requests for arms, but a Taiwan official said that Bush's decision was not raised on Wednesday, the last day of the meeting.

However, Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said replacing the regular review with irregular meetings will not have any significant impact as long as Washington honors its commitments under the Taiwan Relations Act and provides the island with weapons necessary for its defense.

Regular meetings between Taiwan and U.S. officials on arms sales are more likely to draw attention from the international community, not least from Beijing, and could develop into a diplomatic issue, Yu said.
However, he expressed gratitude for Bush's statement to the ABC television network Wednesday that the United States will do whatever it takes to help Taiwan defend itself.

Arms are not the only way to guarantee peace across the Taiwan Strait, and Taiwan has no intention of starting an arms race with mainland China, Yu said. Rather, it will limit its arms purchases if Beijing tones down its military intimidation, he added.
Meanwhile a spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry said Taiwan has felt Washington's good will through the remarks of U.S. leaders.

Chang Siao-yue said she would not comment on Bush's remarks until she had looked more closely at his statement, but pointed out that Taiwan has already felt Washington's good will toward it through the remarks of many U.S. officials, from Secretary of State Colin Powell on down.

She denied that her unusually wary response has anything to do with reports that Foreign Minister Tien Hong-mao has raised eyebrows among government leaders for telling the San Jose Mercury News last week that Taiwan would understand if its demand for four Aegis-equipped destroyers were rejected by Washington.
Taiwan's representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen also shied away from the issue, saying that arms sales are not within his jurisdiction.
An analyst in Washington said Bush's decision will divide the annual arms sales package into several small sales and discussions over the course of the year.

He said the change is meant to avoid Beijing's almost certain protest and the negative implications it brings on Washington's already frayed ties with Beijing, not to mention the yearly meeting's effects on the potential of an arms race between Taiwan and mainland China.

Irregular meetings on an as-needed basis will give Bush's administration the leeway to consider Taiwan's defense needs at any time, and would allow it to reconsider Taiwan's requests even immediately after turning them down without waiting for the next year's review.
But the new measures could deprive Taiwan of the chance to raise its defense needs to Washington's attention every spring, said the analyst.

The analyst said the annual arms sales talks were set up by the administration of President Jimmy Carter in 1982 and are unique, since Washington usually weighs foreign countries' requests for arms purchases whenever it receives them.
Also, the analyst said Washington's promise to offer Taiwan European-built submarines is strategically significant, because "the more countries concerned with Taiwan's security, the better."

DOC.HEADLINE: AEC AGREES TO RESTART OPERATION OF UNIT 2 OF 3RD NUKE PLANT

TEXT.P: The Atomic Energy Council (AEC) on Wednesday gave the go ahead for the second unit of Taiwan's No. 3 nuclear plant to restart operations after a shutdown of more than one month.

The AEC, the nation's highest nuclear safety watchdog, ordered a full investigation of the first unit of the nuclear power plant in Pingtung, southern Taiwan, after a power outage at the plant caused by the first unit. The incident was ranked 3A on a scale of four international rankings of the danger levels of nuclear accidents -- the most severe ever to occur on the island.
The AEC also shut down the second unit until the cause of the first unit's problem is fully investigated.

AEC Vice Chairman Ouyang Min-sheng said that taking into consideration the investigation reports completed by scholars and experts, the AEC has demanded that state-owned Taiwan Power Company, which runs the nuclear power plant, must follow 12 safety checkup improvement measures before the second unit can be started.

Taipower has submitted a written agreement saying that whenever there are signs of saline fog, the nuclear power plant executives will remain vigilant against damage to the plant's components. Also, the firm agreed that every June before the typhoon season and saline haze season, it will arrange for two operation training drills in complete darkness.

Ouyang said that after reviewing Taipower's written report and on-site inspection, the AEC was convinced that Taipower has indeed completed its required improvements, and it has therefore agreed to allow the second unit to be restarted.
Ouyang said that restarting the first unit will have to await a strict safety inspection, which may still take some time.

On whether the darkness-operation training that is asked for in the third nuclear power plant will also be expanded to the first and second plants, in Taipei County in northern Taiwan, the AEC said that it will ask Taipower to submit their own training programs in the event of emergencies for AEC revisions, after which the agency will ask the respective plants to step up training.

The incident on March 18 took place when a high-tension transmission system carrying electricity from the nuclear plant to consumers broke down because saline fog blown inland from the nearby sea created a short circuit across the ceramic insulators.
As a result, the first and second units at the plant automatically shut down and caused a blackout at the nuclear plant complex.
To compound the disaster, one backup diesel generator failed to activate, while the power generated by the other could not be brought on-line because of a burned out component.

The total outage created the risk of a breakdown of the nuclear reactor's cooling system, which can operate for only eight hours on an emergency battery, and could have led to a nuclear accident if electricity had not restored in time. Nuclear plant workers managed to start a third backup generator to run the cooling system two hours later and defused the risk.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN INSTITUTIONS OVERBUY US$33 BILLION TAIWAN SHARES SINCE 1991

TEXT.P: The Securities and Futures Commission under the Ministry of Finance announced Wednesday that as of last Friday, foreign institutions as a whole have overbought US$33.283 billion in Taiwan stocks since 1991.

According to the commission, this figure was a US$67 million increase from the end of March, when the total amount that qualified foreign institutional investors (QFIIs) and non-QFII foreign investors overbought in the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) reached approximately US$33.216 billion.

Meanwhile, the commission announced that foreign investors bought NT$455.9 billion (US$13.9 billion) in listed TAIEX stocks this year as of last Friday, selling NT$346.9 billion (US$10.5 billion) in TAIEX stocks, for an overbuying of NT$109 billion (US$3.3 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD LEADER URGES LOCAL PEOPLE TO PUT OFF INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A Taiwan economic planner urged local entrepreneurs Wednesday to postpone their less "urgent" investment projects in mainland China amid the country's surging unemployment rate.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Wednesday that the government has generally approved any investment project presented by traditional industries to invest in mainland China without screening.

However, the government hopes that sectors whose investment projects need further screening by the government can put off by "at least one year" their "not so urgent" investment plans in mainland China for the sake of local laborers, Chen added.

Chen indicated that it is not a surprise that a country's jobless rate surges when it is undergoing an adjustment in its industrial structure. However, that process in Taiwan has coincided with a global economic slowdown and other problems such as the shorter workweek hours, he said.
The surging unemployment rate has brought much more impact on local people than the 1997 Asian financial crisis, Chen said.

Chen admitted that some industries should relocate their operations abroad to survive when their country is fully developed, and the quicker the pace of the relocation, the cheaper the move is for them. But the relocation spree will push other manufacturers to follow suit, he added.
Therefore, the government will coordinate with industry on the issue and urge some industries to put off their investment plans in mainland China, Chen said.

The economic planner said the government has presented a public construction expansion project aimed at offering more jobs to the unemployed, which is expected to bear fruit in the second half of this year.

Chen added that the government will actively stimulate private investment, and said some international economists have forecasted that Taiwan's economy will improve in the fourth quarter, both of which indicate a less serious unemployment problem.
The government hopes that this year's single monthly jobless rate will not exceed 4.5 percent and figure for the entire year will not surpass 4 percent, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SECURITY CRUCIAL TO REGIONAL STABILITY: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian stressed that ROC's security is crucial to the stability of the Asia Pacific region, saying that its procurement of arms from the United States is not only based on the consideration of its national security, but also that of the regional stability as a whole.
President Chen made the remarks when he was interviewed by major Italian financial newspaper Il Sole 24 Ore, which published the interview on half a page Wednesday.
The president said his government puts national security ahead of all other issues.

Chen also said that there has never a president in the history of Taiwan who has devoted more to the improvement of cross-strait relation as him. Though no major result has been achieved so far, he is not disheartened, and will continue to seek to restart constructive dialogues with mainland China.
Chen said that the ROC government has no preset ideas, preset conditions or set priorities in such talks, but only seeks that both sides sit down to talk.

Chen also pointed out that "one China" is not a question under the ROC Constitution. But he also said that "one China" must not be interpreted in a manner that makes Taiwan part of the People's Republic of China or that relegates Taiwan to the status of a local government, which would run counter to the will of the 23 million people on Taiwan.
On the risks Taiwan businessmen face when investing in the mainland, the President said that all investors must assess possible risks before making their moves.

Mainland China is still a place of high uncertainty for investors, the President said, adding that it makes promises it can not carry out and that it has no sufficient laws and regulations to protect investors.

Il Sole 24 Ore, with a circulation of 500,000, targets mainly people in political, economic and academic fields. The newspaper excels in financial and economic reports, and also pays great attention to the development of the Asian situation.
Wednesday's report was based on an interview conducted April 20 by the paper's Asian Bureau Chief Luca Vinciguerra.

Vinciguerra lauded Chen of the Democratic Progressive Party, which advocated Taiwan independence in the past, as the one who dared to challenge the five-decade rule of the Kuomintang in the presidential election on March 18, 2000.

Chen won the approval of Taiwan's people and later the election on his platform to crack down on "black gold"-- or government's links with the organized crime. One year in office, Chen has also defused Beijing's threats through his wisdom and soft approach toward the other side of Taiwan Strait, Vinciguerra said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES GERMANY TO SELL ARMS, RESUME MINISTERIAL TALKS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated Wednesday that the government of the Republic of China wishes to maintain cross-strait peace.

Chang also asked a visiting German parliamentary delegation to push their government leaders to sell arms to Taiwan so as to upgrade its defensive capabilities and to resume a ministerial-level economics meeting with Taiwan.
Chang made the remarks when he met with visiting German parliamentary delegation led by Vice Speaker Herman Otto Soles at the Executive Yuan.
Soles gave his promise to Chang that he will call on his government to resume the Taiwan-German economic ministers' meeting which has been interrupted for three years.

Chang told his German guests that the U.S. decision to sell arms to Taiwan will help strengthen Taiwan's defensive capability and Asian-Pacific regional security. However, Chang stressed that the ROC has no intention of conducting an arms race with Beijing.

But faced with the large number of missiles Beijing has deployed along its coast opposite Taiwan amid its denials that it intends to take Taiwan by force, Taiwan is forced to purchase arms so as to to upgrade its defensive capability, Chang said.

Chang also stressed that the ROC will continue to make an all-out effort to maintain cross-strait peace and stability in the expectation that a cross-strait dialogue will resume as soon as possible so as to resolve the disputes through negotiations rather than confrontation. He regretted that Beijing has still refused to resume talks with the ROC.

In return, Solms said he and his colleagues understood Taiwan's fears of Beijing's military threat, adding that he agrees that Taiwan needs a quantity of defensive weapons. He recalled that some officials in Germany wanted to sell arms to Taiwan 10 years ago, but Taiwan's request was turned down by the then Christien Democratic Party-led government.
But he and his delegation colleagues supported Taiwan's request at that time, Solms said, adding that he and his group will do whatever they can to pursue the government to sell arms to Taiwan.
Solms also said that he will urge his government to resume the meeting between the economics ministers of Taiwan and German as soon as possible and to sign a double-taxation exemption agreement.

Solms expressed his disappointment over Germany's failure to win its Taiwan High Speed Railway construction bid, but said he was pleased to see that China Airlines is negotiating with European firm Airbus on a purchase agreement.

Chang replied that the Taiwan High Speed Railway Company is a private company and the government has no right to interfere with its business. However he added that the government will continue to encourage local industry to strengthen economic interchanges with their German counterparts, Chang said.

Meanwhile, Klaus Buhler, one of the visiting parliamentarians, told the ROC premier that a group amicable to Taiwan has been set up within the German Parliament, aimed at strengthening Taiwan-German bilateral relations.

More than 70 parliamentarians have joined the group, Buhler said, also telling Chang that he told mainland leaders that they should not assert military force as a means to resolve cross-strait issues the last time he visited mainland China.

In addition to expressing gratitude to his guests and Klaus Rupprecht, director of German Trade Office in Taipei, for their contributions to promoting bilateral relations between Taiwan and Germany, Chang said he hopes the two countries will strengthen economic, technology and cultural cooperation and exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANALYST: BUSH MAKING HIS APPROACH TO BEIJING CLEAR

TEXT.P: A local political analyst welcomed U.S. President George Bush's confirmation of U.S. obligations to help defend Taiwan as a step to avoid any misjudgments on the part of Beijing.

Su Chi, former Mainland Affairs Council chairman and a researcher at the National Policy Foundation, a Kuomintang think tank, told CNA in an interview that Bush made his statement with an eye to preventing Beijing from making any military move against Taiwan after a possible miscalculation that Washington would not involve itself in a military conflict between Taiwan and mainland China.

Beijing's acquirement of advanced weaponry from Russia and the freezing of ties between Taiwan and mainland China ever since Presdient Chen Shui-bian was sworn in have contributed to the rising tension across the Taiwan Strait, which worries Washington that a military conflict could occur out of simple miscalculation, he said.

He didn't think the mid-air collision between a U.S. spy plane and a Beijing jet fighter had any role in Washington's decision to sell Taiwan 12 anti-submarine airplanes and eight diesel-powered submarines.

It is more of a decision to assuage Taiwan's supporters in the U.S. Congress than a move to retaliate against Beijing for detaining the 24 crew members of the U.S. plane for 11 days after the collision, said Su.

Meanwhile Wong Min-hsien, a professor at Tamkung University, cautioned that Bush didn't step beyond the United States' long-standing "one-China" policy, although he told the ABC television channel Wednesday that he believes Washington has an obligation to defend Taiwan and his administration will do whatever it takes to help Taiwan to defend itself.
Wong warned the public against believing that Washington will fight Beijing to protect the island, although he said Bush's statement is a step forward compared to his predecessor Bill Clinton.

He predicted that Washington will not starve Taiwan of military supplies as long as it is a pawn in U.S. strategy to counter Beijing's military build-up, but added it will not go so far as to cause military conflict over the Taiwan Strait.

He lauded Taiwan's acquisition of 12 anti-submarine airplanes and eight submarines as a breakthrough in the island's arms purchases from the United States. But he warned that the easier it is for Taiwan to get arms from the United States and the more heavily it depends on Washington for arms supplies in the short term, the more dangerous it is in the long term since it will discourage the island from developing its own defense industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. CHEN TO MAKE 2-NIGHT STAY IN HOUSTON ON WAY HOME FROM TRIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is likely to make a two-night stopover in New York on his way to Latin American and spend another two nights in Houston on his way home after concluding his trip to that part of the world, sources with the Presidential Office said Wednesday.

The sources said however that consultations are still underway between the U.S. and Republic of China governments on President Chen Shui-bian's transit on U.S. soil when he visits ROC allies in Central and South America during an upcoming trip.
This will be the second diplomatic overseas trip by President Chen since he assumed power last May 20. The trip will be dubbed "Taian Journey." He will be joined by many high-level officials.

Chen is expected to leave Taiwan for his Central and South American trip May 21 and is expected to return on the night of June 4 or the early morning of June 5. During his two-week trip, President Chen will visit El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama, Honduras and Paraguay.
ROC First Lady Wu Su-chen will accompany President Chen on the trip while Chang Jong-fa, president of Evergreen Group, will only accompany Chen to Panama.

Chen will arrive in El Salvador on the first leg of the five-nation trip on May 23, and he will attend the Second Summit between leader of the ROC and Central American countries there. Chen will arrive in Guatemala for the second leg of his visit May 26 and travel on to Panama May 28.

Chen will proceed to Paraguay in South America May 30 for a two-day visit and visit his last official destination -- Honduras -- June 1. Chen is expected to leave Honduras on June 2 for home, but the exact date of his return to Taiwan depends on how many days he will stay in Houston.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Bush says the United States will do 'whatever it took to help Taiwan defend itself.'
The China Times:
Bush reaffirms one-China policy and security commitment to Taiwan.
The United Daily News:
Bush vows to help defend Taiwan.

Bush says the United States would come to Taiwan's aid if attacked by mainland China.
