Bush says he will scrap annual process of Taiwan arms sales.
The Taiwan News:
Bush vows to defend Taiwan if attacked.
The Taipei Times:
U.S. 'will defend' Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 26, or the fourth day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper," and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese Communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1974: U.S. Congressman John T. Myers and his wife arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers of Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe, and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard, with only seven survivors.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
2000: New Philippine Representative to the Republic of China Rodolfo T. Reyes arrives in Taipei to assume office.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian pays a visit to former Premier Hau Pei-tsun for talks on a wide range of issues.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ARMS SALES DECISION REFLECTS ROC'S DEFENSIVE NEEDS: STATE DEP'T

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Wednesday responded to Communist China's formal protest against this year's arms sales package to Taiwan by saying that the U.S. decision reflects the defensive needs of the island and that America continues to stand firmly for a peaceful resolution to cross-strait differences.

State Department spokesman Philip Reeker emphasized at a routine press briefing that "our decision is in keeping with our obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act and the three communiques between the United States and China."

After hearing about Communist China's formal protest the day before, Reeker said, "we did make the point that China's own actions have an impact on the situation in the Taiwan Strait, and we urged that China take sensible steps to reduce tensions."
He added that "we did not discuss the specifics of our arms sales to Taiwan with those representatives of the People's Republic of China government."

Echoing the words of President George W. Bush and Secretary of State Colin Pollen, the spokesman said that "we seek a constructive relationship with China. And as the president has said, both the United States and China must make a determined choice to have a productive relationship that will contribute to a more secure, more prosperous and more peaceful world."

Regarding Bush's remarks about the U.S. readiness to defend Taiwan if mainland China launched a military attack against the island, Reeker pointed out that the president has said very specifically that nothing has changed in the U.S. policy.
"It hasn't changed in terms of what we have followed since 1979 with the passage of the Taiwan Relations Act," the spokesman said.
He added that what the United States wants to see is a peaceful resolution of cross-strait differences and issues through dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH REITERATES `ONE CHINA' POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 25 (CNA) (By Jay Chen, Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George W. Bush said Wednesday that the United States will help Taiwan defend itself, but he also noted that his administration strongly supports the "one China" policy and that Taiwan independence is not part of that policy.

In a live CNN interview hours after a previous interview with ABC's "Good Morning America" show, during which Bush said the U.S. will do whatever it takes to help Taiwan defend itself, Bush noted that this doesn't mean there has been a change in the United States' "one China" policy, which governs relations with Taiwan and mainland China.
"I think it is important for people to also note that my administration strongly supports the `one China' policy, and we expect any dispute to be resolved peacefully," Bush said.
"Nothing has really changed in policy as far as I am concerned, this is what other presidents have said and I will continue to say so."

Meanwhile, Bush also added that "I certainly hope Taiwan adheres to the `one China' policy and a declaration of independence is certainly not the `one China' policy, and we will work with Taiwan to make sure that doesn't happen."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 2.53 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 2.53 points to close at 5,518.73.
Market turnover amounted to NT$59.15 billion (US$1.8 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES 25 AMBULANCES TO INDIA
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, April 26 (CNA) (By C.N. Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private sector donated 25 ambulances to the Indian province of Gujarat Wednesday as part of efforts to help victims of a deadly earthquake that struck the province in January.

At a ceremony held at the Hotel Hyatt in New Delhi Wednesday evening, Yu Kuang-shih, leader of a 20-member Taiwan delegation which arrived in the Indian capital Tuesday, presented a cardboard ambulance to Indian parliamentarian Dileep Sanghani, who represents Gujarat Province, as a symbol of the donation of 25 ambulances currently being delivered to the earthquake-stricken area.

The 25 ambulances are only part of the US$1 million worth of donations that have been raised in Taiwan in recent months under a "With Love from Taiwan" campaign initiated by Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu earlier this year.

Of the total, US$700,000 is in the form of U.S. cash aid, while the remainder has been used to purchase relief goods. Both the cash and the relief goods will be brought to Gujarat Thursday by Yu and his delegation.
"Taiwan people can deeply sympathize with what the Indians have suffered as Taiwan was also stricken by a devastating earthquake in 1999," Yu said in his address at the ceremony.

The US$1 million worth of donations is not actually the end of Taiwan's compassion and empathy toward India, noted Yu, adding that a one-year fund-raising drive will still continue in Taiwan until more money is collected for the Indian earthquake victims.
Taiwan's EVA Airways and China Airlines transported free-of-charge other relief goods from Taiwan to Gujarat several days ago, according to Yu.

According to a World Bank report, the magnitude 7.7 earthquake that rattled Gujarat Province Jan. 26 lasted for a lengthy 110 seconds, taking the lives of 20,086 people and injuring some 176,000 others.

While Yu is leading part of the Taiwan delegation of lawmakers and volunteers to Gujarat, where they will gain a better understanding of the Indian people's plight and needs and will donate stationery to elementary school children, another part of the delegation will travel to the northern Indian city of Dharamsala Thursday.

The second group, being led by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Parris Chang, will travel to mountainous Dharamsala, the seat of the Tibetan government-in-exile, to study the feasibility of a proposal, also initiated by ROC Vice President Lu, to help the Tibetan government-in-exile build a school for children of Tibetan exiles in that area.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO DECIDE ON KIDD-CLASS WARSHIP DEAL IN 3 MONTHS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China military will make a final decision on whether to buy four Kidd-class destroyers offered by the United States in two to three months, a senior Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Thursday.
Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan defense committee meeting, MND Deputy Minister Kao Yang said the Kidd-class destroyers were not on the ROC military's shopping list.

"As the military and local society remain far divided over whether Taiwan should buy this type of warship, we should make a careful review, including both combat evaluation and systematic analysis, before making a final decision," Kao told lawmakers.
Noting that Taiwan's arms purchases are mainly aimed at countering mainland China's military threat, Kao said Beijing's annual military budget has been growing at a double-digit rate in recent years.
"In contrast, our military budget has been on the decline," Kao said, adding that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cannot compare in terms of tangible military force.
Kao stressed that the new U.S. arms sale package to Taiwan will contribute much to the upgrading of the ROC's overall defense capabilities.

Commenting on U.S. President George W. Bush's announcement in an interview with the Washington Post that his administration will scrap the once-a-year review of arms sale to Taiwan and instead meet with Taiwan on relevant issues on an as-needed basis, Kao said the U.S. government had discussed the issue with Taiwan in advance.

"The Bush administration hopes to exercise more flexibility in arms talks with Taiwan. They have consulted us about the issue. Concrete alternative measures will be crafted out later," Kao said, adding that Taiwan's arms deal dialogue channels with the United States have been working smoothly.

Kao further said arms talks on an as-needed basis will not affect Taiwan's arms procurement or acquisition. "And we'll be pleased to see more flexibility in U.S. arms sales to us within the framework of the Taiwan Relations Act," he added.

As for Bush's remarks made during an appearance on ABC's "Good Morning America" show Wednesday that the United States would do "whatever it took to help Taiwan defend herself," Kao said the ROC appreciates the U.S. determination to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region.

Stressing that Taiwan Strait peace is critical to Asia-Pacific regional stability, Kao said he is convinced that all Asia-Pacific countries would be more than willing to support any moves that could contribute to Taiwan Strait peace and security.

Kao also reminded local people that without a strong deterrent force, Taiwan would be vulnerable to mainland China's ever growing military threat. "Beefing up our self-defense strength is pivotal to ensuring our national security."

The United States announced earlier this week it would sell Taiwan more than US$4 billion in new weapons, including destroyers and submarines, in the largest arms sale to Taiwan since 1992 when it sold the island 150 F-16 jet fighters.
The U.S. announcement has drawn immediate protests from mainland China. But Kao said the ROC military has so far detected no unusual military movement on the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 2.53 points to close at 5,518.73

Encouraged by a rise in U.S. stocks prices, the bourse opened at 5,542.39 and began to go down due to selling pressure and a prevailing wait-and-see attitude on the part of investors. The bourse fluctuated between 5,548.67 and 5,461.5 during trading.

A total of 1.77 billion stocks worth NT$59.15 billion (US$1.8 billion) changed hands, compared with the previous trading session which saw 1.71 billion shares traded on market turnover of NT$60.05 billion (US$1.83 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 0.3 percent, followed by electrical shares at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.1 percent. Cement stocks remained unchanged.

The other major categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.4 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.3 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 304 to 193, with 98 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD URGES LOCAL BUSINESSES TO DEFER INVESTMENT IN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planner on Thursday urged domestic businesses to defer investment in mainland China in light of the high jobless rate in Taiwan.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development, said that the easing of the current "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in the mainland will become a trend, but he added that in view of the high domestic jobless rate, everyone has to think about deferring investment in the mainland.

Chen did not point out directly which sectors Taiwan businesspeople should defer investment in, only saying that he had talks with members of the Taipei Computer Association last year and that "so long as all refrain" from going, then it will do.
Chen would not say if this means the government will defer easing restrictions placed on information and other high-tech industries to invest in the mainland.

He only said that deferring investment in the mainland has to be considered pragmatically, pointing out that traditional industries, because of their high costs, are being forced to invest in the mainland. But he also added that "some industries still could be managed in Taiwan."

Chen said that there are many factors to be taken into consideration in regards to the policy toward investment in the mainland. If a business can defer investment in mainland China and still maintain its competitiveness, then it should refrain from doing so at present, he said.
Chen made the remarks while reporting to a joint meeting of the economic and budget committees in the Legislative Yuan.
Chen also mentioned that the jobless rate could hit a new high this August but that the average jobless rate should not exceed four percent for the whole of 2001.
Legislator Hsu Tien-tsai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said he is concerned that the employment of foreign laborers could reduce the employment opportunities for local workers.

Hsu said that many small- and medium- sized industry employers can not afford the retirement payments to domestic laborers and that as employers do not need to prepare for retirement payments for mainland and Southeast Asian workers, they have become the alternative to employing Taiwan laborers.

Hsu urged that domestic workers be employed for major public construction projects to decrease the unemployment rate. Chen echoed this suggestion by saying that all public infrastructure construction programs recently unveiled by the Executive Yuan, which have a combined budget of more than NT$110 billion, will employ local workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May moved up 35 points to close at 5,560, with 7,604 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June rose 42 points to finish at 5,545, with 52 contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,525 for May, 5,503 for June, 5,600 for September, 5,681 for December, and 5,672 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
May TE futures rose 0.6 points to finish at 281.5, with 2,108 contract transactions, while June TE futures moved up 0.5 points to close at 280.5, with three contract transactions.
Next March TE futures fell 7.7 points to finish at 283, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures decreased 1.6 points to finish at 714.4, with 351 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST CREDITOR CARD CRIME RING BUST

TEXT.P: A credit card forgery ring was broken by law enforcement authorities in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Thursday, marking the largest credit card crime bust in Taiwan.

After more than three months of investigations, Kaohsiung law enforcement authorities raided an apartment in the city Wednesday, nabbing seven suspects and seizing several credit card forging machines, computers and more than 6,000 blank cards.

The police said that credit card readers from two leading department stores in Kaohsiung have reportedly been implanted with "spy" silicon chips, enabling the counterfeiters to obtain cardholders' codes to reproduce fake cards.
Counterfeit cards were then sold to shop owners, who used them to charge the issuing banks for phony purchases, the police said.

According to tallies compiled by the five largest international credit card companies, purchases made by using fake credit cards amounted to NT$3 billion in Taiwan in 2000, constituting 0.41 percent of total spending by Taiwan cardholders for the year and representing the highest figure in the Asia-Pacific region.

No one is actually one hundred percent free from being a victim of credit card fraud, the police said, pointing out that even Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan has been a victim. Several prosecutors in Kaohsiung have also fallen victim, with one suffering a loss of NT$180,000, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ENCOURAGES TAXI DRIVERS TO LEARN ENGLISH

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Thursday encouraged the city's taxi drivers to learn English at an English speech class held by Taipei's traffic school in Neihu, eastern Taipei district, in order to make the city more functional for foreigners.

Ma said during one of the English classes designed for Taipei's taxi drivers that as Taipei becomes more internationalized and as foreigners take almost one million taxi rides every year in the city, it is important that taxi drivers be able to speak some English to provide better service for their English-speaking passengers.

The mayor remarked that the number of visitors to Taiwan has reached a level of 2.62 million per year and that nearly 85 percent of these visitors visit Taipei. He humorously said that it is time "for the mayor to learn Taiwanese and the taxi drivers to learn English".

Ma also said that the coming of summer vacation will bring a lot of foreigners to the city and that this will provide an opportunity for the city's taxi drivers to practice their English skills with their foreign passengers.

The English speech class is available to licensed taxi drivers who have received at least a junior high school level of education. Classes are held twice a week for three weeks, and qualified taxi drivers upon completion of their lessons will receive an "I Speak English" sticker which can be adhered to their yellow cabs.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR UPGRADING ITS STORAGE AND DISTRIBUTION BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: Southwestern Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor, the world's fourth largest container port, is working to regain its third-place ranking by pushing to develop its storage and distribution businesses.
Affected by the island's slumping economy, Kaohsiung Harbor lost its status as the world's third largest container port, a position it had held for years, to Pusan Harbor, South Korea.

Officials in the Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau said that in order to compete with other quickly developing ports, such as the port of Shanghai, the bureau has begun cooperating with three local shipping companies to enhance the port's storage and distribution management.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs has also set up facilities to promote storage transportation services near the port areas.

The Kaohsiung Harbor Bureau plans to upgrade the old port by creating new storage, distribution, and merchandise transporting areas as well as by providing a more professional and convenient business environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.01 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 32.918.
The local currency opened Thursday at 32.890 and was traded between 32.870 and 32.930.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$323 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO SIMPLIFY PROCEDURES FOR FOREIGNERS TO PROMOTE TOURISM

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Lai In-jaw said Thursday that the government is now working on measures to promote the local tourism industry, including simplification of visa and entry application procedures to attract more foreign tourists.

Lai stressed that President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Chang Chun-hsiung are concerned with promoting the domestic tourism industry, adding that substantial measures will be unveiled in the near future.

According to the proposed plan worked out by the Executive Yuan, the government will invest NT$50 billion (US$1.51 billion) over the next four years and solicit private investment of NT$200 billion (US$6.07 billion) to assist local tourism promotion.

DOC.HEADLINE: KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS ARE POTENT, PRAGMATIC: LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: Two Republic of China legislators have voiced their support for Taiwan's purchase of four Kidd-class destroyers from the United States, saying that they will become the largest and most potent vessels in the country's navy.

Legislators Lu Hsiu-yen of the opposition Kuomintang and Wang Tein-ching of the People First Party said that the 172-meter long, 8,910-ton vessel, powered by four gas turbine engines, is capable of cruising at a maximum of 33 knots.

The turbine engine is of the same type used on the ROC Navy's Cheng Kung-class vessels, which will simplify both maintenance and logistics, Legislator Wang said. He added that the Arleigh Burke-class destroyers that the United States decided not to sell Taiwan also use the turbine engines.
The ships are equipped with radar systems that have an effective range of 350 kilometers and can fire four anti-aircraft missiles simultaneously within a range of 70 kilometers, Wang said.

Wang noted that even if the United States decided to sell the Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan, they would not be ready for delivery until 2010. In view of mainland China's military expansion and purchase of modern destroyers from Russia, Taiwan must buy the Kidd-class destroyers to maintain balance in the Taiwan Strait and form an efficient military deterrent.

Legislator Lu also said that although Kidd-class destroyers are almost 20 years old, they still have another 20 to 30 years of service left in them, but carry a price tag of only about one sixth of that of a new vessel. She said the purchase will be a pragmatic choice.

The Kidd-class destroyers were originally built for use by Iran during the reign of the Shah, but the U.S. Navy took control of the ships in 1981 and 1982 after Iran's revolutionary Islamic regime took power. The destroyers, currently mothballed, will be ready for delivery by 2003.

Some legislators have voiced opposition to purchasing the Kidd-class destroyers, mainly because they are too old and too big -- making them easy targets for Beijing's military -- and that they were designed for long-haul combat missions, which runs counter to Taiwan's need for vessels capable of coastal combat missions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT SEES NO IMMEDIATE CROSS-STRAIT CONFLICT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 26 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has said in an interview with a Hong Kong daily that he sees no immediate possibility of a conflict erupting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chen said in the interview published in the Hong Kong Economic Journal Thursday that under his leadership, Taiwan will never take any provocative actions to irritate mainland China.
"Therefore, we'll never be a troublemaker nor will we be a warmonger," Chen stressed, adding that self-defense is the ROC's bottom line.
Chen further said he is hopeful that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can resume a dialogue as soon as possible to pave the way for normalization of bilateral relations.

"We believe that normalization of cross-strait ties is the greatest guarantee of permanent peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait," said Chen, the first ROC president from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chen recalled that when he won the presidential election in March 2000, many people were worried that his election might escalate cross-strait tension and increase the likeliness of confrontation.
"But nearly one year after my inauguration, a lot of the previous speculation and forecasts have been proved unfounded or wrong," Chen said.
The lawyer-turned-politician said he is fully aware that maintaining lasting peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait is his mandatory "mission, duty and responsibility."

"Therefore I see no immediate possibility of a war breaking out in the Taiwan Strait, nor do I believe that Hong Kong is likely to be dragged into a cross-strait confrontation," Chen stressed, adding he is convinced that safeguarding cross-strait peace will contribute to Hong Kong's prosperity and progress.

Touching on the recent U.S. approval of a robust arms sales package to Taiwan, Chen said the ROC government and people welcome the U.S. decision and appreciate the longtime U.S. concern for the stability and security of the Taiwan Strait.

Chen said he thinks that the new U.S. arms sales package, including four Kidd-class destroyers, eight diesel-powered submarines and 12 P-3 Orion anti-submarine aircraft, will be conducive to the balance of military power between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"The sale will also be helpful to maintaining cross-strait peace and stability as well as to the strengthening of self-confidence of the people of Taiwan and the reopening of a cross-strait dialogue," Chen said.
The president further said he believes that the Bush administration has made a wise decision based on the provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and Taiwan's basic defense requirements.

However, Chen said he also fully understands that Taiwan's security cannot be solely dependent on arms procurement. "We believe that only dialogue with mainland China and normalization of cross-strait ties can bring peace and stability to both sides of the Taiwan Strait."
For the sake of self-defense, Chen went on, Taiwan has no choice but to purchase new weaponry systems to cope with Beijing's mounting military threat.

Noting that mainland China's rising military spending and intensified military buildup and missile deployment along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan pose a great threat to the ROC's national security, Chen said arms purchases are a necessary evil.

Chen said Taiwan actually looks forward to resuming talks with mainland China and seeing Beijing stop targeting its missiles at Taiwan. "If that happens, our two sides can then cut our military budgets and use the saved funds on economic development, infrastructure construction, medical service, education and social welfare programs."

Chen also emphasized that the U.S. sale of necessary defensive weapons to Taiwan is not aimed at encouraging a cross-strait arms race, but at helping to safeguard Taiwan's democratic way of life and upgrade Taiwan's self-confidence in beginning a dialogue and negotiations with mainland China.
As for the U.S. role in the cross-strait relationship, Chen said the United States has long helped push for stable and balanced development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10,000 TONS OF RICE TO BE SENT TO LIBERIA FRIDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, April 26 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A total of 10,000 tons of rice will be sent off to Liberia Friday, the first rice export shipment to an African nation so far this year, a source at the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday.

Shao Yi-hsiung, director of the Kaohsiung office of southern Taiwan's food management department under the COA, said that workers started loading the 10,000 tons of rice onto bulk cargo freighter the "Alam Sempurna" on April 20.
After completing the loading process at noon Friday, the freighter will carry the rice to Liberia via Vietnam, he said.
Because rice is a common staple in Africa, rice exports to that continent are part of the government's efforts to solve problems caused by Taiwan's current rice glut, Shao said.
Each year, the COA carries out a rice purchasing plan to buy a certain quantity of rice from farmers at guaranteed prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: UPS SETS UP VENTURE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: UPS Capital Corporation announced the launch of its new Taipei branch Thursday, vowing to provide Taiwan businesses with more flexible trade, financial and credit loan services.

UPS Capital President Bob Bernabucci said in a speech at the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei Hotel that his company is the first of its kind to provide clients with high-tech, globalized financial services, including loans and risk management, on a customized basis.

UPS Capital Taiwan branch General Manager J. H. Chi pointed out that there is strong demand in the Taiwan market for financial services, due to its large number of small businesses and its leading role as a high-tech giant.
UPS Capital is an investment venture wholly owned by UPS Corporation, the world famous courier.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM MEDICAL TREATMENT IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, accompanied by his wife and a group of close aides, returned to Taipei Thursday afternoon after winding up five days of medical treatment in Japan.

A Japan Asia Airways (JAA) plane carrying Lee arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan at 2:40 p.m. Lee first allowed an ailing Japanese passenger to de-plane, after which the former president walked off the aircraft with a smile on his face to meet with government officials, civic leaders and friends who had gathered to welcome him home.

President of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng, Secretary General of the Presidential Office Yu Shyi-kun, Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan, Lee's daughter Anna Lee and his son in law Lai Kuo-chou were among those present to greet Lee.

Lee had traveled to Osaka for heart treatment on April 22. At Chuo Hospital in Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture, the renowned Japanese physician Kazuaki Mitsudo performed minor heart surgery on the former president. The same doctor had assisted doctors at National Taiwan University Hospital when they performed a coronary angioplasty operation on Lee last November in Taipei.

Responding to news media at the airport, Lee said he feels better, but added that he will heed his physician's advice that he postpone his scheduled trip to visit Cornell University, his alma matter, for another month.

Lee said that the Dr. Kazuaki Mitsudo had conducted a thorough checkup on his heart condition, and had decided to inserted a sixth supporter into his heart arteries after finding a problem with one of the old supporters.

Lee was undecided on whether he will go back to Japan six months from now to have his heart checked up again, but stressed that he would postpone his U.S. trip by one month under the recommendation of Dr. Mitsudo.
Lee was originally scheduled to visit Cornell University in upstate New York in early May.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STEEL FIRMS TO FACE U.S. ANTI-DUMPING DUTIES

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) has made a preliminary ruling to levy anti-dumping duties on U.S. imports of products from three Taiwanese steel companies, which it said were selling steel products at prices lower than their market value in the United States, Taiwan's Economics Ministry said Thursday.

The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said three Taiwan steel companies, including China Steel Corp. and Yieh Loong Enterprises Co., could face U.S. anti-dumping duties of as high as 29.41 percent, while the other steel firms will be subjected to less serious 20.28 percent duties.

BOFT officials said Taiwan is one of 11 countries upon which the United States might levy anti-dumping duties for steel imports. The other countries include South Africa, Thailand, Argentina, India, Indonesia, Holland, Romania, the Ukraine and Kazakhstan.

The U.S. Commerce Department made the preliminary ruling after receiving a petition from its domestic steel manufacturers and steel workers' unions last November. It is expected to make a final ruling between July 7 and Aug. 21.
BOFT officials said they will assist the local companies to appeal to the United States for a ruling more amicable to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EX PRESIDENT THANKS JAPANESE GOV'T AND PEOPLE FOR THEIR CONCERN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang, Huang Kuei-mei & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui Thursday thanked the Japanese government and people for their deep concern about his health, adding that their assistance made his recent heart check-up in Japan possible.
Lee said in his departing speech that he had received good treatment at the Chuo Hospital at Kurashiki city, Okayama prefecture, where he received minor heart surgery.
Lee also said that in addition to checking up his heart conditions, he also took the chance to tour Osaka and was very pleased to visit Japan despite his short stay of just five days.
"My wife joined me to express our heartfelt thanks to the Japanese government and people for their deep concern about my health and the hospitality extended to us during our stay in Japan," Lee said.

At the same time, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan also issued a statement to thank the Japanese government for granting a visa to the former ROC head of state, and other hospitality extended to him during his trip.
Meanwhile, more than 200 Japanese people and overseas Chinese crowded the Imperial Hotel, Osaka Thursday to bid farewell to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui.

They chanted "Lee Teng-hui Go! Go!" and "Taiwan Go! Go!" when Lee entered into the hall. Lee shook hands with his well-wishers, and speaking in Japanese language to local media, expressed his gratitude to the Japanese populace.
ROC representative to Japan Lo Fu-chen and Japan's Interchange Association's Board Chairman Toshio Goto saw Lee off at Kansai International Airport.
Lee arrived in Osaka April 22 for medical treatment for his heart condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINBOND SEEKING PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION AGAINST U.S. CUSTOMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 25 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Court of International Trade is scheduled next Wednesday to deliberate on a formal complaint filed by Taiwan-based Winbond Electronics Corp. that the U.S. Customs Service improperly detained the company's flash memory shipments.

According to documents filed with the court, Winbond is seeking a preliminary injunction against the U.S. Customs, which claimed that the impounded flash memory devices fall within the scope of a Limited Exclusion Order issued by the U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC). The ITC had ruled that any products infringing on a patent owned by U.S.-based Atmel Corp. cannot enter the United States for consumption.
However, Winbond claimed that the chips were redesigned and did not infringe on Atmel's U.S. patent, which it acquired from U.S.-based Seeq Technology in 1994 and is set to expire Sept. 18 this year.

U.S.-based Silicon Storage Technologies (SST) and Japan-based Sanyo Electric Co. have also filed separate complaints against Customs for preventing their shipments of flash devices from entering the United States.

This was the latest development in a five-year dispute between Atmel and the other companies. ITC investigation on the case began in 1996 and was terminated July 2, 1998 after finding no violation by Winbond and the other companies.
After Atmel filed an appeal that led to a second hearing, the ITC's Administrative Law Judge again found in favor of Winbond and the other defendants.

However, the ITC overruled its judge last October and issued the Limited Exclusion Order that precludes from entry into the United States all infringing Winbond, SST and Sanyo EPROMs, EEPROMS, flash memory, flash microcontroller semiconductor devices as well as all circuit boards containing such semiconductor devices.
The ruling was upheld by the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in February this year, cementing Atmel's victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY CONGRATULATES NEW JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday congratulated Junichiro Koizumi on his election as Japanese prime minister.

In a press release, MOFA announced that its representative office in Japan has been instructed to convey the ROC government's congratulations to Koizumi, who was elected earlier in the day by the Japanese parliament.

The press release pointed out that although Koizumi was not a member of a Japanese parliamentary group that promotes Taipei-Tokyo relations and has never visited Taiwan, his stance could be said to be friendly toward Taiwan, particularly because he voiced support for a controversial decision to allow former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to visit Japan for medical treatment.

The press release expressed MOFA's anticipation that Japan will see even further political and economic progress under Koizumi's leadership, and that Taipei-Tokyo friendly relations will continue to make headway.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS CONSULTED ROC ON CHANGES IN ARMS TALKS: MND

TEXT.P: The United States has consulted the Republic of China about more flexibility in bilateral arms trade talks, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) spokesman said Thursday.

MND military spokesman Huang Suey-sheng made the remarks after U.S. President George W. Bush said in an interview with the Washington Post earlier this week that his administration will scrap the annual arms sales talks.

While the United States will reserve the right to arm Taiwan, Bush said in the interview: "We have made it clear to Taiwan that we will not have this so-called annual review -- that we will meet on an as-needs basis."
Since 1982, ROC and U.S. officials have met annually to review Taiwan's arms procurement plans in terms of its defense requirements in the face of mainland China's military threat.
As Beijing has consistently protested U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, Bush indicated that his administration will try to avoid the contentious, once-a-year showdown over arms sales to Taiwan.

Commenting on Bush's remarks, Huang said changes in the style of arms procurement talks will not affect Taiwan's purchase of the defensive weapons and military equipment needed to protect its security.

Huang said the ROC recognizes the U.S. decision to exercise more flexibility in discussing arms sales to Taiwan based on the provisions of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), the U.S. law governing exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

Huang said the Bush administration has consulted Taiwan about future arms talks on an as-needed basis instead of the current once-a-year review. Nevertheless, he went on, the two sides have yet to craft concrete measures for future arms talks.
He further stressed that current Taiwan-U.S. dialogue channels for arms trades have been working smoothly. "We can fully exchange views on any issue or topic," he explained.
Huang also said the ROC will be pleased to see more flexibility in arms talks within the framework of the TRA.

DOC.HEADLINE: OSCAR-WINNING DIRECTOR HAILED AS EAST-WEST BRIDGE

TEXT.P: Oscar-winning Taiwan-born director Ang Lee was hailed Thursday by Republic of China officials for the contributions he has made to the country.

Speaking at a party at a local hotel sponsored by the Government Information Office (GIO) in honor of Lee and attended by representatives of the local film industry, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung praised Lee as "a bridge of communication" between the East and the West.

The premier also thanked all the workers who participated in the shooting of Lee's epic masterpiece -- "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" -- which won this year's Oscars for best foreign language film, best art direction, best cinematography and best original music.
GIO Director-General Su Cheng-ping lauded Lee for the great publicity he has created for the ROC and stressed that local movie makers need "greater encouragement from the public."
At the end of the party, a segment of this year's Oscar awards ceremony and a retrospective of Lee's past works were played, allowing the audience to enjoy a moment of laughter.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICE SECTOR GROWING AMID ECONOMIC RECESSION

TEXT.P: Amid an economic sluggishness that is weighing down almost all local industries, the service sector was the only one to post growth in job opportunities in March, according to government tallies.

Tallies released by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that an additional 87,000 people, or an annual increase of 1.68 percent, joined the service sector in March as compared to the year-earlier level.

In terms of occupations, the wholesale, retail and food and beverage industries registered a growth of 1.34 percent in terms of jobs, while the transportation, warehouse and telecommunications industries posted an increase of 3.73 percent. Financial, insurance and real estate industries showed a rise of 0.99 percent.

At the same time, the workforce in the agricultural sector registered a March decline of 8.4 percent -- or 64,000 people -- compared with the year-earlier level, while the industrial sector posted a fall of 2.11 percent, or 74,000 people, the statistics show.

Meanwhile, 56,000 jobs have disappeared in the manufacturing sector over the past five months, while 70,000 jobs have been eliminated in the construction sector over the past nine months, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE REACHES OUT TO FOREIGN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office opened its doors to local travel agencies that cater to foreign tourists Thursday in an attempt to woo more international visitors.
The Presidential Office, built by the Japanese when they ruled the island, is already a hot attraction for local people when it opens to visitors the first Sunday of every even month of the year.
It is also open to visitors from organizations every Tuesday and Thursday.
Public relations officials at the Presidential Office now have their sights set on making the historic office into an attraction for foreign travelers as well.
The travel agencies catering to foreigners urged the Presidential Office to increase the number of days that visitors are allowed in order to accommodate their increasing numbers.
They also appealed for the abolition of the mandatory ten-day notice for visiting groups, which makes it difficult for them to arrange or cancel visits on short notice.

A travel agency executive recommended that tour guides at the office give a more detailed explanation of building's history in order to make the tour slightly longer than its current length of 20 minutes.

Kuo Yao-chi, head of the Public Relations Department at the Presidential Office, said she invited the travel agency operators to visit the office after seeing many visitors taking pictures in front of the office without knowing that they can tour its interior.
She promised to seriously consider the travel agencies' recommendations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LUNCHES WITH LONGEST-MARRIED COUPLE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made good a promise Thursday by lunching at his office with a couple that boasts the longest marriage in Taiwan.
Chen invited Lin Hao and his wife Lin Cheng Chien to lunch at the Presidential Office Thursday to honor a promise he made April 12 when he visited the Chiayi couple who married 80 years ago.

Chen presented them on that occasion with a cash gift of NT$9,999 -- the pronunciation of which sounds similar to "long, long, long, long" in Chinese -- and invited them to visit him someday at his Taipei office.
Describing the lunch as "an honor of a lifetime," Lin said he never imagined that he would one day have lunch with the president at his office.
He said he was so excited that he did justice to the meal and would keep as a souvenir a bottle of liquor presented to him by Chen after the lunch.
He said he also asked the president to take good care of himself for the sake of the country.
When they posed for a picture, the president asked Lin Cheng Chien if she knew who he is, to which she jokingly replied that she did not and that she knew nobody but her husband.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG POLICE BUST CREDIT CARD FORGERY RING

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung police broke up a credit card fraud gang Thursday, confiscating more than 6,000 false cards, although 6,000 are feared to have already been circulated in the market, the police said.

The discovery is estimated to prevent possible losses of NT$1.3 million (US$39.5 million), but actual losses from counterfeit cards already circulated will not be know until an investigation has been carried out, the police said.

The police indicated that the credit card forgery ring had tight organization, as some members in mainland China were responsible for making blank cards, while local people were in charge of obtaining the secret codes of cardholders and imprinting them on the blank cards, as well as selling the cards.

Police detained seven suspects, including two department store employees. It was found that credit card readers in at least three department stores had special ICs inserted that could steal the secret codes of cardholders. Further suspects are suspected of being involved in the scam.

According to estimates by the five major credit card companies in the world, transactions made by phony cards reached NT$3 billion last year in Taiwan, accounting for 0.41 percent of the total transactions made by credit cards, the highest rate in the Asia Pacific area.
A Kaohsiung prosecutor said anyone could be a victim of the crime, citing the example of Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan, whose card was forged and used to make purchases.
The police revealed that four Kaohsiung prosecutors have also been the victims of credit card forgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLOOD DONATION PERSONS, SCHOOLS AND ORGANIZATIONS CITED

TEXT.P: The Taipei Blood Donation Center (TBDC) cited Thursday the city's outstanding blood donors -- individuals, schools and organizations.
More than 30,000 persons, 34 schools and 82 organizations were cited for their enthusiasm in donating blood.
Among those cited, Wang Sung, Huang Ching-hsiung and Chang Ting-wei ranked the top three on the list of blood donations, with each one having made more than 500 blood donations so far.
Chinese Culture University won first place for the seventh consecutive year in terms of the quantity of blood donated, with 3,174 bags of blood donated in the last year.
Tung Nan Institute of Technology came second, with 1,266 bags of blood donated in the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SEEKING GREATER U.S. SUPPORT FOR WHO MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government hopes for greater backing from the United States to help Taiwan join the World Health Organization (WHO) at an early date, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue said Thursday.

Chang said MOFA appreciates Resolution No. 428 adopted recently by the U.S. House of Representatives supporting observer status for Taiwan in the WHO and she urged the U.S. Senate to approve the resolution as soon as possible to help Taiwan's 23 million people enjoy better medical care.

Chang said it is a common desire among the people of Taiwan to take part in the international organization and that the ROC government is keen for the United States to do more to help Taiwan obtain this objective.

In a bid to push for this goal, the Executive Yuan recently set up a task force as part of the government's efforts to seek WHO membership for Taiwan. The ad hoc group is led jointly by Department of Health Director-General Lee Ming-liang and Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH NEWSPAPERS SPEAK OUT IN SUPPORT OF TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 26 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A British newspaper pointed out Thursday that Taiwan has the right to self-determination and that Europe should stand up for a democracy "constantly under pressure from an authoritarian bully" across the Taiwan Strait.

The Daily Telegraph editorial stressed that the Taiwan issue is simple: "It is whether a government that oppresses its own people should be allowed forcefully to extend that oppression to an island that has opted for democracy and has no wish for reunification while this yawning political gap endures."
The editorial speculated that an amphibious invasion of Taiwan by mainland China is still beyond its capabilities, but that the island could be crippled by a naval blockade or a missile attack.
The newspaper criticized Germany and Holland for having "preemptively kowtowed to Beijing" by ruling out the possibility of selling Taiwan the submarines that could prevent such blockades.

Meanwhile, the Financial Times charged that U.S. President George W. Bush's statement in a television interview Wednesday that America would do "whatever it took" to help Taiwan defend herself was "needless provocation."
The paper warned that the main casualty of any "bad atmospherics" between Beijing and Washington over Taiwan would be invariably Taiwan itself.

It urged Bush to clarify his views by reiterating key U.S. principles on Taiwan policy, including the acceptance of the "one China" policy and support for the peaceful unification of Taiwan and mainland China, should that accord with the wishes of the island's people.

Washington should also provide sufficient arms to Taiwan for the island's defense and lend direct support to Taiwan in the event of unprovoked aggression from mainland China, the Financial Times added.

However, the editorial stressed that Washington should be clear that it does not support moves toward Taiwan independence or the writing of a blank check for the island's defense should Taipei act "irresponsibly."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES PEOPLE VISITING INDONESIA TO `BE WARY'

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) urged local people Thursday to be cautious when visiting Indonesia, amid the confrontation between supporters and rivals of President Abdurrahman Wahid.

The warning came in the wake of an Indonesian government announcement that Jakarta will be on "first-grade alert" April 29-30, as Wahid's supporters are scheduled to stage a mass prayer rally in the center of the capital to back the president.
The supporters will also stage a demonstration outside the Congress April 30 in protest against its plan to vote on a second censure against the president.
The MOFA press release urged local people not to visit Jakarta or East Java -- Wahid's home province -- on the days in question.

"If they really must visit, ROC citizens should be especially cautious about Indonesia's situation and political developments and should maintain close contact with the ROC representative office in Indonesia," MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES TO CHERNOBYL NUCLEAR DISASTER VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, on behalf of the ROC government, has donated US$30,000 to help the surviving victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster that occurred 15 years ago, the government spokesman said Thursday.

Su Cheng-ping, director-general of the Government Information Office, said that US$20,000 will be given to the Belarus Chernobyl Disaster Handling Committee and the rest will be given to the Chernobyl Children's Fund, Japan (CCFJ) founded by Japanese photographer Takaichi Hirokawa.

Su said that Chang showed one of Hirokawa's pictures of a mother and a child, both victims of Chernobyl, when he announced the halting of construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant last Oct. 27.
Hirokawa founded the CCFJ in April 1991 after covering the disaster and now chairs the fund, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IT HARDWARE OUTPUT DOWN IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: The hardware production of Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry in the first quarter of this year registered negative growth in both value and volume, the Institute for Information Industry (III) revealed Thursday.
III statistics show that this was the first time a quarterly negative growth has been posted in the hardware production of the island's IT industry over the past decade.
The statistics indicate that IT hardware production in the January-March period totaled US$8.58 billion, down 10.1 percent against the same period of last year.
The production of notebook computers went down 18.1 percent and 5.9 percent, respectively, in terms of value and volume.
Production of monitors decreased 15.1 percent and 11.4 percent, respectively, in value and volume, while that of desk-top computers dropped 11.1 percent and 5.5 percent, respectively.
III analysts predicted that owing to global market sluggishness, the production of Taiwan's IT industry this year is likely to experience "stagnation" or "negative growth."

They said that the output of Taiwan's notebook computers this year may decrease 6.6 percent in value against last year and that the 2001 growth in value may go down 6.4 percent for monitors and 3.3 percent for desk-top computers.

The prediction for 2001 is extremely contrary to an III prediction made last year -- a 14.8 percent growth in value for notebook computers, up 19.8 percent for monitors and up 7 percent for desk-top computers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 56,020 TAIWAN COMPANIES FOLDED LAST YEAR: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: An opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator said Thursday that her party is working on a bill that would help the nation's worsening unemployment problem by preventing large numbers of workers from being laid off without warning.

Shen Chih-hwei said at a press conference that a recent Economics Ministry report, which was not disclosed to the public, listed as many as 56,020 firms that went out of business last year, a 6.33 percent increase over the previous year.
She went on to say that the 5,302 registered factory closures last year are another factor leading to the current unemployment high.
Shen urged the Cabinet to quickly come up with related bills to complement her party's proposed draft law.

Chiu Yi, a scholar who helped the PFP write the bill, said that the current draft calls for companies that seek to lay off more than 10 workers to provide a written proposal 60 days in advance. If the company then violates any rules or agreed-upon clauses, it could be punished in a variety of ways, he added.

On the issue of the possibility of foreign workers cutting into local jobs, Shen said that the foreign worker population currently stands at 327,000, which is rapidly approaching the nation's number of unemployed workers at 358,000.

A official of the Council of Labor Affairs who attended the press conference claimed that the number of foreign workers in Taiwan in the manufacturing industry is actually on a decline of approximately 5 percent to 6 percent annually.
However, he went on, the demand for foreign workers in the home care sector remains high, requiring further full-scale discussions with the Interior Ministry and other government agencies.
The official added that the key to the serious unemployment problem is finding ways to promote domestic investment willingness.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION AUTHORITIES BRACE FOR SIA LAWSUIT

TEXT.P: A local aviation official said Thursday that Taiwan's aviation authorities will brace for a demand from Singapore Airlines (SIA) to share the liability for a crash that occurred last year at Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) refused to comment on wire service reports that SIA will seek to name the CAA as a party to any litigation filed against SIA by the families of victims or survivors of the Oct. 31 crash.
Chang said it is too early to apportion the liability for the crash, as an investigation into the accident is still under way.
However, his administration will respond to any lawsuit brought against it, said Chang.
A total of 83 passengers aboard the Boeing 747-400 were killed in the accident which took place during a typhoon.
Some 80 suits have already been filed against the carrier in Los Angeles, the destination of the ill-fated airplane, although US$400,000 compensation for each victim was offered by SIA.

A preliminary investigation into the accident by the Taiwan authorities found that the pilot tried to take off from a runway closed for repair and crashed into concrete blocks and construction machinery left lying on the tarmac.

Although the airport blamed the pilot for turning onto the wrong runway, the airline suggested that the airport shared responsibility because the runway was lit for use and not properly closed off, causing the pilot to mistake it for the runway assigned to his plane.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 27, or the fifth day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: IMF FORECASTS TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 4.1 PERCENT FOR 2001
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The International Monetary Fund forecast in its latest report that Taiwan's economic growth will average around 4.1 percent for 2001 and 5.6 percent for 2002.
It its latest World Economic Outlook report, the IMF said Taiwan's growth for this year will be around 4.1 percent, the same as the figure it cited a month ago.
The IMF predicted that global growth in 2001 will continue to weaken, falling to 3.2 percent for this year, the lowest level since 1998, before rebounding to 4 percent in 2002.

Among the major economies surveyed, the IMF said that the U.S. economy will slide noticeably this year to a low growth of 1.5 percent before rebounding slightly to 2.5 percent for 2002. Japan's growth is forecast to be a mere 0.6 percent for this year, compared with mainland China's 7.1 percent.
Economic growth in Asia's developing countries, excluding Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and South Korea, is expected to average about 5.7 percent, according to the report.

Among the "Asian dragons," the report ranked Taiwan third for projected economic growth for 2001 at 4.1 percent, behind Singapore's 5 percent and Hong Kong's 4.8 percent, but ahead of South Korea's 3.5 percent. For 2002, the report ranked Taiwan second in this group with a projected growth of 5.6 percent.
