DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 102.06 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 102.06 points to close at 5,416.67.
Market turnover amounted to NT$44.64 billion (US$1.36 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CALLS FOR DIALOGUE, EXCHANGES TO BREAK CROSS-STRAIT STALEMATE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the key to easing tensions and stabilizing relations across the Taiwan Strait is for both sides to reopen negotiations, stressing that the "cross-strait dialogue must be resumed."

Chen said maintaining steady and peaceful relations with mainland China has been a top mission of his administration since he took office last May, adding that he will continue to make strenuous efforts to accelerate cross-strait ties based on the concept of "outperforming steely power with willowy softness."

The president made the remarks while paying a visit to Li Yuan-zu, former vice president and incumbent senior presidential adviser, at Li's residence in Miaoli County, northern Taiwan. The visit coincidentally took place on the eighth anniversary of landmark talks between top Taiwan negotiator Koo Chen-fu and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan.

Koo, chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, met with Wang, chairman of Beijing's intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, in Singapore on April 29, 1993, marking groundbreaking talks between the rival sides following a nearly five-decade hiatus in formal relations.
Chen paid a half-hour courtesy call at Li's residence, offering his personal greetings to the former vice president and exchanging views with him on a wide range of topics.

Li lauded Chen as a pragmatic statesman who can easily perceive and identify problems. Noting that it always requires a certain period of time before the performance of any new president or administration bears fruit, Li urged Chen to make the stabilizing of domestic politics and cross-strait relations his top priorities.
Li also noted that the government's administrative policies should be forward-thinking in outlook and should allow all levels of government equal financial opportunities and access.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORNELL CONFIRMS LEE'S VISIT POSTPONED TO LATE MAY

TEXT.P: Cornell University confirmed Friday that former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the school originally scheduled to kickoff next week will be postponed to May 29-31 due to the condition of Lee's health.
University officials stressed that Lee's visit will be private in nature. No public speeches nor press conferences will be held and press interviews will be limited, as Lee has requested.
A spokeswoman for Cornell University said that the school did not confirm Lee's itinerary until 9 a.m., Friday and that Lee decided to postpone his visit to the school until May 29.

Lee, who received his doctoral degree in agriculture and economy from Cornell University in 1968, is scheduled to announce the establishment of the Lee Teng-hui Institute for Scientific Research at the university during his second visit to his alma mater since 1995. He will also visit his granddaughter who is currently a student at the university.

The spokeswoman told a reporter from the Taiwan-based Central News Agency that a ceremony marking the establishment of the institute will not be open to the press, adding that only Lee and members of the school staff will be present at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Both cross-strait intermediary bodies call for reopening of dialogue based on 1992 consensus.
The China Times:
Top negotiators from Taiwan and mainland China simultaneously call for resumption of cross-strait dialogue as soon as possible.
The United Daily News:
There was a consensus in 1992 and it allowed both sides of the Taiwan Strait to interpret the "one China" term differently, says Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
The Liberty Times:
Major criminal cases must be handled under concerted efforts from related law enforcement divisions, says Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan.
The China Post:
WTO accession gives ROC-PRC chance at dialogue, SEF says. Taipei must recognize 'one China,' Beijing says.
The Taiwan News:
China rebuffs Taiwan call to resume stalled dialogue; Chen urges 'reopening door' on anniversary of Koo-Wang meet.
The Taipei Times:
Chen, Koo urge cross-strait talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 28, or the sixth day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1442: King Edward IV, the Yorkist leader during the War of the Roses, is born. He was crowned king of England after defeating the Lancastrians at Mortimer's Cross and Towton in 1461.
1545: Yi Sun-shin, Korean admiral and national hero, is born.
1758: James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States, is born. His administration is noted for the acquisition of Florida in 1819, and for the proclaiming of the Monroe Doctrine in 1823, which declared that no foreign power would be allowed to colonize any part of the Americas.
1789: On a return trip from Tahiti in the South Pacific, mutinous crew members of the British transport ship Bounty set Captain William Bligh and 18 sailors adrift in an open boat. Bligh and his royal crew manage to reach Timor Island near Java on June 14 after sailing 3,500 miles.
1788: Maryland becomes the seventh state of the United States.
1876: Queen Victoria of Britain is declared Empress of India.
1902: The U.S. Senate passes an anti-Chinese bill.
1922: War between Wu Pei-fu of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction breaks out.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a manifesto urging the reunification of China by peaceful means.
1937: Saddam Hussein, president of Iraq since 1979, is born.
1945: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini is shot by his countrymen, who then string up his body head down.
1952: At his own request, Dwight D. Eisenhower is relieved of duty as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. He is succeeded by Gen. Matthew Ridgway.
1952: The Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is signed in Taipei by Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh and Japan's special envoy, Isao Kawata.
1962: The Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd. is established in Taipei.
1963: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC's decathlon champion who won the first Olympic silver medal for his country on Sept. 6, 1960, sets a new world record in the sport in the United States with 9,121 points.
1963: Taiwan holds elections for the third Provincial Assembly.
1969: President Charles De Gaulle of France resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo is elected chairman of the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
1976: Delegates headed by Dr. Ku Cheng-kang, honorary president of the World Anti-Communist League, leave Taipei for Seoul and the Ninth General Assembly of the WACL.
1980: U.S. Secretary of State Cyrus Vance resigns.
1988: A Republic of China delegation attends the annual convention of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Manila.
1992: The Afghan government cedes power to Islamic guerrillas in Kabul, ending 14 years of armed resistance and civil war.
1992: Yang Chi-chang, a police officer, is killed in an explosion while trying to defuse a bomb placed by blackmailers near the McDonald's fast food branch on Minsheng East Road in Taipei.
1996: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that starting July 1, 1996, imports of another 1,609 categories of industrial commodities will be allowed into Taiwan from mainland China, marking the ROC government's largest ever relaxation of restrictions on mainland imports.
1998: David Hempleman-Adams, British explorer, reaches the geographic North Pole, becoming the first person to reach the Earth's northern magnetic and geographic poles.
2000: The Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to the Passport Law which extends the term of validity of Republic of China passports from the present six years to 10 years.
Confucius's lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character, he prefers to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN LEAVES FOR SPEECH TOUR OF U.S.

TEXT.P: Republic of China government spokesman Su Cheng-ping left for New York Saturday for a one-week speech tour of the United States, marking his first business visit to America since he assumed the post last May.

Su, a journalist-turned-official, will deliver two speeches, one at the Overseas Press Club of America located in New York and another at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, D.C., denoting the partnership between Taiwan and the United States.

He will take the opportunity to underline the importance of the U.S.-Taiwan partnership to various American sectors at a time when President George W. Bush has categorically reaffirmed America's commitment to Taiwan's self-defense and when triangular relations among the United States, Taiwan and mainland China are at a new crossroads, said GIO sources.
In his speeches, Su will openly urge mainland Chinese authorities to acknowledge Taiwan's goodwill and sincerity in its efforts at improving cross-strait relations, GIO officials said.

During his stay in New York, Su, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), is scheduled to visit the headquarters of leading think-tanks and mass media organizations, including the Council on Foreign Relations, Forbes magazine, Time magazine, the New York Times, Dow Jones & Company, and Newsweek.

After his New York visit, Su will proceed to Washington, D.C., where he will be interviewed by the Voice of America's Mandarin-language program "China Outlook." He is also scheduled to visit the headquarters of several prestigious think-tanks and mass media organizations, including the Cato Institute, the Heritage Foundation, the Washington Post and the Washington Times, according to GIO officials.
Su is scheduled to conclude his visit to the United States and head back to Taiwan on May 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG DISTRICT REPS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FOR EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A delegation comprised of representatives from Hong Kong's central-west district arrived in Taiwan Saturday for grassroots exchanges with their counterparts in Peitou district, northern Taiwan.

The group is scheduled to pay a call on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and visit the Taipei City Council, where they will be briefed on the city's garbage fees system and collection operations as well as the fingerprinting identification system used in the city's household administration offices.
Hong Kong's central-west district and Taiwan's Peitou district established sisterhood ties and signed an exchange memorandum when Ma visited Hong Kong in February this year.

Lin Cheng-hsiu, director of Taipei City Government's Bureau of Civil Affairs, said that many members of the delegation often visit Taiwan but that this is the first time they have come to the island for grassroots exchanges as district councilors.
They are also scheduled to tour Peitou's hot-spring museum, the new Peitou park, the relics museum, Yangmingshan National Park, and the Shilin night market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PRC SHOULD EMULATE EUROPEAN SPIRIT OF INTEGRATION: SEF OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) suggested Saturday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait emulate the European spirit of seeking peaceful and common development in order to help solve the cross-Taiwan Strait political stalemate.

Citing the European Union experience as an example, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin said that before Taiwan and mainland China integrate, neither side should insist on preconditions nor exert its own opinions on the other side.

In a symposium on the topic of seeing cross-strait relations through the European Union experience, Yen said that six European states grouped together in 1951 to form the Coal and Steel Community, which gradually evolved into the European Common Market and then today's European Union.
The European experience of integration provides invaluable inspiration to both sides of the Taiwan Strait in their reunification efforts, Yen said.

Stressing the importance of building "rules of the game" between the two sides before the integration process begins, Yen suggested that both sides refrain from making demands or setting preconditions on sovereignty and related political issues.
Yen urged Taiwan and mainland China to emulate the spirit of European integration instead of trying to force the other side to accept or forsake its own plans or ideology.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATOR SAYS U.S. POLICY TOWARD CHINA REMAINS BASICALLY UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: U.S. Senator Craig Thomas told an influential group of Chinese Americans Friday that he believes U.S. policy toward mainland China remains basically unchanged despite recent events that have strained bilateral relations.

Speaking at a luncheon session of the 10th annual conference of the Committee of 100, a New York-based organization of Chinese American leaders in various fields, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Subcommittee said that he believes the U.S. administration will continue to adhere to a "one China" policy, the "three communiques" and the Taiwan Relations Act.

He added that U.S. President George W. Bush's recent statement that America would do "whatever it took" to help Taiwan defend itself was a "message" for Beijing in the wake of the manner in which mainland China "tested" the U.S. administration through its handling of the April 1 incident involving a mid-air collision between a U.S. Navy reconnaissance plane and a mainland jet fighter.

Thomas said that Beijing's handling of the incident has led him and many of his congressional colleagues to trust mainland China even less because of the way it raised doubts as to whether it will follow appropriate international standards in handling related affairs.
He added that the incident has also made him and other Congress members re-examine whether the United States should provide even more weapons to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.

However, Thomas stressed that he advocates candid and public dialogue with Beijing on various issues instead of attempts to isolate or contain mainland China. He also said that he does not believe Washington-Beijing relations will continue to deteriorate.
In response to a question raised after his speech, Thomas stressed that the U.S. Congress is not "anti-Chinese" as many mainland students seem to believe.

He said that the United States supports a democratic Taiwan but that it will also try to ensure that the island does not take on any courses of action that will escalate tensions in the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, he added that the United States will also promote a strengthening of trade and investment relations between Taiwan and mainland China and urge the two sides to resolve their differences peacefully through dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS VISITING GUATEMALA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, April 27 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: A delegation of Republic of China legislators arrived in Guatemala Tuesday for a visit to be officially sworn in as "observers" in the Central American Parliament (Parlacen).
The delegation is comprised of ROC legislators Lin Chien-jung, Chang Chuan-tien, Tsai Chung-han and Chang Shih-liang as well as the Deputy Chief of the Legislative Yuan, Wu Cheng-fung.

The legislators were invited by Guatemala's foreign affairs committee chairman to a dinner party April 25. They also paid a visit to members of Parlacen and ambassadors from Central American countries April 26.
The group is scheduled to call on Guatemala Vice President Juan Francisco Royes Lopez on Saturday.

Parlacen, established in 1991, is comprised of 133 members from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama and the Dominican Republic. The ROC's Legislative Yuan was authorized to join the organization as an "observer" on June 30, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REPEATS PLEDGE THAT MEINUNG RESERVOIR WILL NOT BE BUILT
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung County, Taiwan, April 28 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reiterated Saturday that the proposed controversial Meinung Reservoir in southern Taiwan will not be constructed during his presidency.

Chen made the pledge while attending the opening of a Meinung Hakka Cultural Artifacts Museum. Residents of the area have been vehemently opposed to plans to build the dam due to the effects the dam would impart on the region's concentrated Hakka population.

The previous administration planned to construct a reservoir to pre-empt possible future water shortages for the region's growing industrial zones and to deal with concerns that water for the greater Kaohsiung region is drawn from polluted downstream Kaoping River sources.

However, Chen announced last August during a visit to the area that the dam will not be constructed and that alternative solutions will be offered to resolve the issues of polluted drinking water and possible future water shortages in the region.

Addressing Meinung Township residents again Saturday, Chen said that the government treats Hakka affairs seriously and that the establishment of a Executive Yuan committee to specifically handle such affairs was ratified by the Legislature last week.
Because Hakka residents make up approximately 15 percent of the island's population, Chen noted, the strengthening of Hakka language education is a direction to strive for.
During the day, Chen also attended the centennial anniversary celebration of Kaohsiung County's Lin Yuan Elementary School, the largest primary school in the county.
Chen said that the government is promoting the incorporation of kindergarten education in elementary schools that attempt to adapt to the students and not the other way around.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD-FAMOUS UNIVERSITIES TO COMPETE IN ILAN REGATTA

TEXT.P: Nineteen university men's and women's teams from Taiwan and abroad will compete in this September's international university rowing competition sponsored by Ilan County Government.

The county government has invited teams from Yale University and Harvard University in the United States, Oxford University and Cambridge University in England, Waseda University and Keio University in Japan, the University of Sydney in Australia, and the University of Hamburg in Germany to compete in the regatta to be held on a stretch of the Tungshan River Sep. 8-9.
The teams from Taiwan will include those from Taipei Physical Education College, National Taiwan Normal University and Fu Jen Catholic University.
County government officials said that approximately NT$20 million (US$625,000) will be needed to stage the event and that donations are welcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETERRENCE NAME OF THE GAME IN TAIPEI-BEIJING RELATIONS: DAILY

TEXT.P: Deterrence is the name of the game in Taipei-Beijing relations, a Canadian newspaper commented Friday following the apparent heightening of tensions between Washington and Beijing.

The Montreal Gazette said Taiwan has an interest in deterring Beijing from trying to reunite it with the mainland by force or the threat of force, Beijing has an interest in deterring the island from declaring independence, and Washington has an interest in deterring mainland China from doing the former and Taiwan from doing the latter.
Based on this premise, the article praised Washington for having "wisely turned down Taiwan's request to buy" destroyers equipped with the Aegis battle management system, at least for the time being.

In addition to approving the sale of a long list of military hardware, including submarines, patrol planes and Kidd-class destroyers, U.S. President George W. Bush gave something even more valuable to Taiwan, the Gazette said.
"He made the clearest statement in recent history of Washington's readiness to come to Taiwan's aid if it is attacked by the People's Republic of China," it said.

Taiwan needs a credible deterrent force to dissuade Beijing from trying to reunite the island with the mainland by force. That is in Washington's interest too, because the U.S. would just as soon not have to face a war against the nuclear-armed mainland China, the daily said.
At the same time, neither Washington nor Beijing wants Taiwan to feel invulnerable, lest it declare independence, it added.
In short, Taiwan is a prime example of a situation that should be left as it is, even if the situation does seem a little bizarre, the Gazette said.

The editorial explained that most of the world adheres to the notion that legally there is only one China, whose capital is in Beijing, while at the same time, in many practical ways, Taiwan acts as if it were an independent country and is widely treated as such.
"Washington is right to try to steer the middle course," - that is, to try to avoid any changes to the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, it concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIAL CALLS TAIWAN'S IPR PROGRESS `FAR FROM SATISFACTORY'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A senior U.S. trade official said Friday that although Taiwan has made progress in the protection of intellectual property rights over the past several weeks, "it is far from satisfactory."
The official, who asked not to be named, said that "we want to see a fully effective optical media law that addresses our concern."
He claimed that the version of the optical media management statute being drafted by the Republic of China's Executive Yuan with added provisions for criminal responsibility is "ineffective."

He added that the U.S. Trade Representative Office has completed preparations of its annual list of countries that it believes require close monitoring and that could be subject to trade sanctions under the Special 301 provisions of the 1989 U.S. Omnibus Trade Act if they fail to address U.S. concerns.
The list will be announced Monday, the official added, hinting that Taiwan may be included in the "priority watch list" this year as many have speculated.

The official said that the United States is very concerned about the seriousness of the compact disc piracy issue in Taiwan. He claimed that Taiwan's pirated CDs have even been sold in markets as far away as Brazil.
He cited the case of Digicode Technologies, a Taiwan-based company that he said was caught three times for allegedly selling pirated CDs.
On another issue of concern for U.S. trade officials, he reiterated that Taiwan should make its patent laws conform with World Trade Organization (WTO) standards.
Taiwan trade officials agreed in March to extend the maximum term of local patents issued prior to 1994 from 18 years to 20 years, but only after Taiwan is allowed to enter the WTO.
Patents issued in Taiwan since 1994 have followed the uniform 20-year term prescribed by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the precursor to the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S UPCOMING TRIP TO AMERICAS INTENTIONALLY BEING KEPT LOW-KEY

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office is intentionally keeping Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's forthcoming Latin American trip low profile, aiming to avoid provoking Beijing, a Presidential Office source said Saturday.

In order not to jab at Beijing's hyper-sensitive nerves, especially so soon after the collision between a U.S. Navy reconnaissance plane and a mainland jetfighter and also the U.S. decision to sell a hefty volume of weaponry to Taiwan, the Presidential Office has tried to keep low-key on the itinerary of Chen's stopover in the United States, said Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Eugene Chien.

Against this background, which coincidentally also includes a scheduled visit by former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to the United States in late May, Chien, who has been in charge of arranging Chen's overseas trip, said Taipei is allowing U.S. authorities to decide on the agenda and related affairs when Chen and his entourage make a stopover in the United States on their way to and from Central America and South America between May 21 and June 4.

According to the preliminary schedule, Chen is likely to make a two-night stopover in New York on his way to Latin America and spend another two nights in Houston on his way home after concluding his trip to that part of the world.
During the stopover in New York, Chen is expected to be met by several members of the U.S. Congress and to visit the Metropolitan Museum, Chien said.

Topping the itinerary of the forthcoming trip to five countries in Central America and South America is a state visit May 23 to El Salvador where he will attend a leadership summit of eight Central American heads of state, Chien noted.
The trip, the second of its kind since Chen took office last May, will also bring the president to Guatemala , Panama, Paraguay and Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-RCA WORKERS TO LODGE CROSS-BORDER LAWSUIT AGAINST COMPANY

TEXT.P: A group of former RCA Co. workers announced Saturday that they are lodging a cross-border lawsuit against the U.S. company and asking for compensation for employees who worked at RCA's Taoyuan plant and later developed cancer or other fatal diseases.

The ex-RCA workers, accompanied by Independent Legislator Shih Ming-teh and several lawyers, held a press conference at the Legislative Yuan to appeal for aid for their plight which has lasted since 1992.

According to the petitioners, a total of 1,059 former RCA workers have suffered from various kinds of serious diseases, including liver cancer and stomach cancer. Of them, 216 have died from cancer over the past several years.
RCA first set up production lines in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan in 1970 to produce television sets and other electronic home appliances.
The ex-RCA workers have claimed that the company continued digging wells near the Taoyuan plant for 20 years to store its toxic waste up until the time it shutdown its Taiwan operations in 1992.

The soil and artesian well water in the adjacent area became so seriously polluted that the Republic of China Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration formally declared the site of the former RCA factory a "permanently toxic" area in February 1998.

Many former RCA workers developed various forms of cancer or other diseases due to long-term exposure to the polluted environment, including contaminated drinking water, at the factory, the petitioners said.
The former RCA workers appealed on March 30 to the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations.
The AIT however initially shut its doors and refused to receive the petitioners. Security guards at the institute later agreed to help transfer the petition letter to relevant AIT officials.
According to the ex-RCA workers, the former Kuomintang government had organized an ad hoc group under the Executive Yuan, aiming at examining the occupational hazard case and related legal issues.
The ad hoc group, unfortunately, was disbanded by the new Democratic Progressive Party-run administration in January of this year, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIFFERENCES TOO GREAT TO APPLY E.U. MODEL: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Local scholars said Saturday at a seminar on Taipei-Beijing relations that the European Union model could not be easily applied to the case of Taiwan and mainland China as a means of "integration."

Despite repeated suggestions by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian that bilateral relations could follow the model of E.U. integration in the future, the scholars noted that the ideological gap between the people on the opposite sides of the Taiwan Strait are simply too great.

National Taiwan University (NTU) law professor Wang Tai-chuan said that Beijing's insistence on "one China" and its denial of the fact that the Republic of China is a sovereign nation make any attempt to pursue stable economic and political development under the E.U. model "difficult" for both sides.

With such widely different economic structures, mainstream values, and beliefs in human rights, Wang said that the E.U. model is not transplantable. The results of an integration under this model would probably not conform with the Taiwan people's interests, he added.

Meanwhile, Ko Tse-tung, a member of the Examination Yuan who once served as director of the NTU Law Institute, noted that E.U. members began with multilateral exchanges in such areas as trade, tariffs, currency and capital, and arrived at an economic integration before working toward political integration.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT RECRUITMENT OF FILIPINO WORKERS TO BE IMPLEMENTED FROM MAY 1

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will announce measures May 1 on the direct recruitment of Filipino workers for the manufacturing and construction industries, to be implemented immediately, CLA sources said Saturday.

It is estimated that Filipino workers recruited to work in Taiwan without going through a labor broker will pay only NT$35,000 to apply to work in Taiwan, a significant two-thirds decrease from the amount spent through brokerage companies.

CLA officials said the CLA and the Philippine Overseas Employment Administration (POEA) have reached consensus on the recruitment and labor condition contracts for the manufacturing and construction sectors.

The POEA has finally agreed that whether Taiwan employers must pay Filipino workers accommodation and food supplements will be decided through an agreement between the employers and workers themselves.

As for the direct recruitment of Filipinos to work as caregivers for Taiwan families, the CLA is inclined to follow the Labor Standard Law to set upper limits for daily work hours, vacations and salaries, which will be set forth in labor contracts.

However, the CLA will not announce and implement the direct recruitment of Filipino caregivers until Aug. 1 because the CLA and the POEA have yet to complete negotiations on labor contracts in this category.

The CLA officials were keen to point out, however, that even if the government makes an all-out implementation of the system from Aug. 1, it will not be a substitute for the current brokerage system. Instead, according to the officials, the government will allow the two systems to run concurrently, giving employers more choice in their hiring policies.

According to an operation flow chart agreed upon by the two nations, Taiwan employers must submit to the POEA a brief company introduction, a detailed explanation of manpower needs and a copy of the labor contract, as well as an approval certificate from the CLA and the planned date of recruitment.

The Philippine Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei will then check on the qualifications of the Taiwan employer and if he passes the screening, the POEA will take the first step of recruiting in the Philippines according to the employer's manpower needs.

The POEA will select workers from its own database, or through Philippine public employment service organizations and provide their data to the Taiwan employers, who will select the workers they want to recruit.
The Philippine government will arrange a physical examination for the recruited workers and also organize job seminars so that the new recruits will know what to expect in Taiwan.

After this, the Filipino workers will have to prepare all visa documents, while the Philippine Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei will inform the Taiwan employers of the arrival date of the new recruits, so that they can arrange their accommodation and meet them at the airport.
CLA officials said the new rules will further promote the relationship between Taiwan and the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL HEADS MISSION TO VISIT KINMEN

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) delegation led by the party's secretary-general, Wu Nai-jen, headed to Kinmen on Saturday to evaluate firsthand the results so far of the "three mini links" implemented unilaterally by the Republic of China government Jan. 1.

The DPP Central Standing Committee on April 10 approved the setting up of an ad hoc committee on the "three mini links," referring to direct trade, shipping, and postal links between the ROC-held islands of Matzu and Kinmen and selected ports in mainland China.

Kao said that visits between Xiamen and Kinmen and between Mawei and Matzu have been frequent since the implementation of the "three mini-links." He added that both sides have set up a formula for exchanges.

He also noted that the administration has an obligation to find out the local people's feelings concerning the "three mini links" and its effects so that they can be used as a reference by government authorities when mapping out the "big three links."
Wu and his entourage called on the Kinmen Chapter of the DPP where they were briefed on the Kinmen situation.

After holding a symposium with Kinmen County officials, including Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tzai and officials from the Kinmen Fishery Association and the Kinmen Farmers' Association, Wu stressed that the DPP-led government will build Kinmen into an economically prosperous island.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA FACING CHALLENGES WITH WTO ENTRY (I)

TEXT.P: Although the spotlight has recently been on the aftermath of the spat over a U.S. surveillance plane and its midair collision with a Chinese F-8 fighter, U.S. business leaders are looking beyond the incident and to China's future entry into the WTO.

In September of 2000, the U.S. Senate approved permanent normal trading relations with China by a vote of 83 to 15. Previously, the granting to China of most-favored-nation status, now called normal trading relations, was tied to a large extent to its record on human rights. Many feel that Beijing has not earned this preferential trading position.
Many say that China has not made improvements in respecting the rights of the individual to be granted an improved place in economic relations with the United States.

Of course, arguments to the contrary have been made: that China has, in fact, improved its record on human rights. That dialogue with China is the best way to steer them toward becoming a democratic country and that opening China to U.S. trade is in the national interest of the United States.

Some U.S. politicians say China must be admonished for its reluctance to return the crew members of the damaged U.S. surveillance plane, but official foreign policy statements say that the situation revolving around the incident will not include unrelated issues, such as arms sales to Taiwan. Businessmen are just as keen to see what is clearly a political and diplomatic problem stay well removed from impacting international trade issues.
That China will be admitted to the WTO is a foregone conclusion, but what is less clear is whether China is up to the challenges and obligations that member states must accept.

U.S. President George W. Bush said on May 17, 2000 that "economic freedom creates habits of liberty. And habits of liberty create expectations of democracy. Trade with China serves our own national interest, as well as the security interests of China's neighbors. China is not our 'strategic partner.' But neither is it our enemy. When both China and Taiwan are members of the WTO, both will need to apply global rules to their trade, including trade with one another, and the prospects for cross-strait relations should improve."

President Bush's view may be correct with regard to China, but what about Taiwan? Is there something missing within a 'normal relations' framework regarding Taiwan? Relations between China and Taiwan could improve after both are admitted to the WTO, but as long as the U.S. treats democratic Taiwan as the poor cousin to China, it will be difficult for the trilateral relationship to be based on equality.

But let's look at the issue of China's place in the WTO more closely. Although China is assured of admittance to the world trade body, Beijing still has much to do to satisfy the requirements as a member. More importantly, being a member of the WTO may be a double-edged sword for China: while entry should help the economy of the country, the changes that must ensue could well rock the foundations that Beijing has held so dear for so long. Foundations such as authoritarian rule, lax enforcement of law, rampant corruption throughout government and control over the workforce. The current consensus among WTO members is that Taiwan and China should be admitted at the same time, and although Taiwan has already finalized bilateral and multilateral negotiations, it must wait for China to complete all the necessary procedures.

According to Assistant U.S. Trade Representative Donald M. Phillip, China has made important concessions in intellectual property rights protection and service market opening and transparency during the working party's 14th meeting, which concluded on Dec. 8, 2000. However, according to Phillip, China has still failed to reach agreement with major WTO members on many sensitive issues, including farm produce subsidies, service trade and anti-dumping measures. As a result, WTO entry for both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be delayed with some wondering if entry might not even come before the end of the year. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA FACING CHALLENGES WITH WTO ENTRY (II)

TEXT.P: China has been dragging its feet on complying with certain terms with WTO members. European Union officials have complained of China's backsliding in the issuance of licenses to liberalize the insurance market and although China said that it would allow foreign firms into its mobile phone market, it has suggested that the best way to do this would be for the firms to work with one of China's three state-owned telecom enterprises.

None of this should come as a surprise to those who have always looked at China as a country unaccustomed to fair play and unfamiliar with international cooperation. It may be difficult for China to follow through with its promises and this raises serious questions about its ability to effectively enforce its obligations to the WTO.

One problem is the dealings between provinces in China. Although goods are supposed to be freely traded across provincial borders, this is not always the case. It is hard to see how China can effectively guarantee the free flow of goods and services into and around the country when it has trouble with its own commerce.

Local officials must also play a role in the new economic landscape after WTO entry. Cronyism and kickbacks will have a ripple effect that provincial administrators have never had to deal with before. And central government leaders will have their hands full "re-educating" officials on doing business without bribes or "facilitation money."

And what is to be done to police China's operations within the WTO framework? Beijing has done virtually nothing to address the concerns of the U.S. and other Western nations to begin an overhaul of their judicial system. How will businesses be able to redress grievances against their Chinese counterparts? Professionals may find that just because you can do business with China does not always mean that it is wise to do so.

Membership in the WTO is not supposed to have political implications. China is well aware of this when it suits their purpose. When observers point out China's dismal record on human rights, Beijing says that the WTO is concerned with business and human rights is an internal matter for China and has nothing to do with anyone or anything else. Suppression of religious choice, as in the continuing crackdown on practitioners of Falun Gong, should not be considered along with WTO entry.
But should any country speak positively about Taiwan's sovereignty, Beijing falls all over itself to link the politics of cross-strait affairs with the WTO.
Part of the heart of the WTO is its avoidance of ambiguity -- something that China may have trouble understanding.

Another issue to watch from China is how the workforce deals with the changes that WTO entry will bring. Increasing competition from outside China and the pressure on state-owned companies to perform at levels many of them are not prepared for will test the resolve of the management structure and, perhaps, the patience of workers.

It is certain that officials in Beijing have mulled over the possibility of workers going on strike and how to address such disturbances. One of the major challenges in the near future will be for Beijing to contain any flare-ups by displaced or disgruntled groups. In this case, the causes will not be student movements in Tiananamen or a wall dedicated to democracy -- it will be the economic disruption of a worker-class dependent on working within established and familiar frameworks.

Taiwan's entry into the WTO will also necessitate that it face the reality of keener competition, but Taiwan's government, economic and legal infrastructure is far advanced of that in China. Taiwan has much experience with international dealings -- from agricultural products to the highest cutting-edge technology imports and exports. Although Taiwan has not been a member of the WTO, it has developed a worldwide reputation for quality and dependability. In the last decade, Taiwan has liberalized its trade system, lowered tariffs and has improved protection of intellectual property rights to the level of other developed nations.

WTO membership will bring benefits to Taiwan, and may also for China, but Beijing will face unprecedented challenges to the way it has previously controlled the country. Whether or not China will rise above and follow the rules remains to be seen.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA TO BE ABSENT FROM ASIA-PACIFIC ENVIRONMENTAL SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Just days before the opening in Hawaii of the Second Mayors' Asia Pacific Environmental Summit, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has decided not to attend the meeting as previously scheduled, Taipei City Government sources said Sunday.

Ma changed his mind on attending the gathering of more than 100 mayors from 29 countries throughout the Asia-Pacific region after being notified by the organizers that he would not be allowed to deliver a speech during the meeting.
The summit, to be held May 4-6 in Honolulu, will be jointly sponsored by the Asian Development Bank and the U.S. Agency for International Development.

Ma had originally planned to take part in the summit and deliver a speech on Taipei City's new garbage collection system, which has since won applause locally and internationally since he put it into force last year.

The organizers of the summit reportedly asked Ma to make an appearance but not to make a speech in the meeting due to pressure from Beijing. The first Mayors' Asia Pacific Environmental Summit was held in Hawaii on Jan. 31, 1999.
However, the sources said that Ma will fly to Seattle, Washington to attend the Third Asia-Pacific City Summit on May 6-8.

During that summit, Ma will give a speech on Taipei's attempt to transform itself into a Web-based city. Ma will also take the opportunity to woo foreign investment in a newly opened software industrial zone in Taipei's Nankang District.
Ma and his predecessor, former Taipei Mayor and now Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, took part in the last two Asia Pacific City's Summits in Brisbane, Australia.
In addition to Ma, Deputy Kaohsiung City Mayor Lin Yung-chien and Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan will also attend the Seattle summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC ACTIVITY HAS SLOWED DOWN UNDER NEW ADMINISTRATION: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Economic activity in Taiwan is slowing down significantly under President Chen Shui-bian's administration, said an opposition lawmaker Sunday. The criticism comes amid reports that the nation's unemployment rate surged to a record high of 4 percent, or 380,000 people, in April.

Leg. Lai Shih-pao of the New Party said at a press conference called to unveil his plan to counter the swelling number of jobless people, Lai said that with one year in office, President Chen's administration has seen the economy slide and the unemployment rate surge.
He said the rising unemployment rate is a result of the sagging economic activity by private firms, gauged by 18 criteria.
Notable indicators of weakening economic activity are:
-- the number of business folding under the new administration is 233 more per month than that under the previous administration;

-- compared with the figures of the previous administration, the industrial growth index is 1.84 points less per month while business' inventory index has increased by 10.5 points per month, mainly because of a slowdown in sales;
-- loans extended by financial institutions to private firms has been pared by 2.07 percent per month;
-- the number of rubber checks drawn by businesses has increased by 0.06 percent per month; and
-- the growth of private investment is 5.81 percent less per month under the new administration than that of the previous administration.
In order to address the problem, he urged the government to cut down on the number of foreign workers brought to the island.
The number of foreign workers, standing at more than 325,000 in April, is 23,000 more than that under the previous government and has contributed to the increasing jobless population, Lai said.
He also announced the launch of a non-profit business consultancy on his personal website with the aim of helping local businesses weather the hardship.
The economist-turned lawmaker said he has lined up more than a hundred business administration experts to answer questions facing local businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRBUS TRYING HARD TO LURE TAIWAN AIRLINES

TEXT.P: With the good performance of its aircraft in Taiwan's market over the past 20 years, Airbus Industrie is working actively to lure more orders for its superjumbo jet A380 from Taiwan's airlines.
According to sources from China Airlines (CAL), the company maintains a "positive view" on the aircraft, which was just introduced to the market late last year.
During her visit to Toulouse, France to witness the delivery of an Airbus A340-300 jetliner April 27, a high-level CAL executive was a major target of Airbus promotion of the A380.

Airbus considers Taiwanese airlines to be potential customers, as evidenced by the firm's previous consultations with two of the island's airlines when it was designing the jumbo jet, which will be able to accommodate 555 passengers on two decks.
Relations between Airbus and Taiwan dates back to 20 years ago, when CAL first bought A300 aircraft from the firm.
CAL was satisfied with the performance of the airplanes and decided to buy A300-600 aircraft in 1988, adding eight A340 orders in 1999.
Taiwan's EVA Airways became an Airbus customer earlier this year, when it ordered eight A330-200s to replace its aging B767s.
During the delivery ceremony for the A340-300, the CAL executive described the A380 as a excellent aircraft designed for real needs, and hinted that her company might buy the aircraft in the future.

Airbus has already received orders for 62 A380s from eight air carriers worldwide, with Singapore Airlines the only airline in Asia to have placed such an order. The first A380 is scheduled to be delivered in 2006.
With its 20-year effort in the Taiwan market, Airbus has plenty of confidence that it will eventually sell the A380 to Taiwan's airlines, according to John Leahy, Airbus executive vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S SON TO BE INDUCTED INTO MILITARY IN JUNE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's son, who sang that he wanted to be a soldier in one of Chen's campaign commercials, will finally get his wish when he is inducted into the military to answer a draft call in July, a local newspaper reported Sunday.

The United Daily News said Chen Chih-chung, the only son of Chen Shui-bian, will graduate from National Taiwan University this spring, and has chosen to enter Taiwan's 20-month mandatory military service before continuing with his studies, although he would be eligible for deferment if he were accepted by any graduate school.

Chen Chih-chung has already passed a screening to serve as a military legal clerk, and his parents reportedly prefer that he perform his military service before continuing on with his studies. The younger Chen's conscription will also help reassure people that his father's campaign promise that he would not seek war with Beijing still holds true.
Military spokesman Hwang Hui-sheng was reported as saying that the president's son will be treated the same as any other conscript, and will not be given special treatment.

Chen Chih-chung appeared in one commercial during his father's presidential campaign in 2000, during which he sang that he wanted to be a soldier. The advertisement was aimed at scuttling the claims of his father's political rivals that a victory for Chen Shui-bian in the election would put the island on the path of military conflict with Beijing because of his pro-independence stance.
Chen Shui-bian's campaign used the commercial featuring his son to emphasize that he would carefully steer the island away from war, since his son was scheduled to serve in the army soon.
Chen Chih-chung's induction might also ease the criticism of his would-be brother-in-law Chao Chien-ming, whose planned engagement in June with the president's only daughter recently came to light.

Chao, a doctor at National Taiwan University Hospital, has drawn fire from critics of the president since they found the apparently healthy young man was exempted from military service for medical reasons.

Current law requires all Taiwanese men who have reached 18 years of age and have finished their studies to serve in the military for 22 months. However, the system has been charged with favoring the middle and upper classes, because an unusually large proportion of politicians' sons have been exempted from it. Draft-dodging is especially rampant among medical school students, who know how to take advantage of medical exemption loopholes in the law. According to one estimate, about one third of male medical students never serve in the military.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP SUGGESTS TURNING ISLET INTO 'LONGEVITY ISLAND'

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu suggested Sunday that a tiny island off the coast of southern Taiwan be developed into a resort for the country's increasing population of senior citizens.
In an event marking the upcoming Mother's Day, Lu suggested the government to turn Pingtung County's barren islet of Hsiaoliuchiu into an exclusive resort for pensioners, or a "longevity island."
It would also boost the islet's faltering economy and enhance the lives of Hsialiuchiu's dwellers, said Lu.

The country's first woman vice president met with 21 female centenarians at an event held in their honor at a local hotel Sunday. She presented bouquets to each of them and wished them a happy Mother's Day.
Lu's suggestion was welcomed by Tsai Chia-chiang, Hsiaoliuchiu's administrator. He said any proposal which might create jobs on the islet would be accepted with pleasure by the local people.

Tsai said Hsiaoliuchiu, located west of the Pingtung County coast, has suffered a mass exodus of residents because of the scarcity of jobs there. Many of the island's former dwellers have moved to Taiwan proper to seek better lives, and only 12,000 people live on the islet now, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY LAWMAKER TO LEAD MILITARY EXPERTS ON MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: New Party lawmaker Elmer Fung announced Sunday that he will lead a group of more than 30 retired generals and military experts on a visit to mainland China in June, in a bid to dissolve tension and create a mechanism for military trust between both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Speaking at a news conference he called at the Legislative Yuan, Fung said that he will head the group of former generals, military experts and academics in accordance with government rules.

He added that they will leave for mainland China June 3 at the invitation of relevant mainland Chinese military authorities through the arrangements of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
During their stay, Fung said they will hold seminars with local military units in Beijing and Nanjing and meet with Beijing officials to exchange opinions on cross-strait relations.

Accusing the United States of purposely sparking tension between Taiwan and mainland China under the pretext that its weapons sales to Taiwan are aimed at helping the island counter attacks from the mainland, he urged the government led by pro-independence President Chen Shui-bian to recognize that "Taiwanese are Chinese" as soon as possible. "Chinese people don't fight Chinese people," he added.

According to the lawmaker with the pro-unification New Party, the purpose of the U.S. decision to sell Taiwan four "like-destroyer" Kidd-class vessels is to form a small battle group to cut down on risks in the deployment of U.S. aircraft carriers.

Fung said although the new U.S. strategy to "lure Taiwan to shift to an offshore defensive policy" seems to enable the Republic of China to increase its combat abilities, he contended that it will actually "escalate tension" and "block the unification" between the two sides.
He pointed out that it would result in a "nobody-wins situation" for both Taiwan and mainland China, in order to ensure the U.S. status as the sole world power.

Meanwhile, ranking officials of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the ROC's highest government agency in charge of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said that they have not seen any application for such a mainland trip by Fung and stressed that all moves must be in compliance with government rules.

Regarding the definition of the so-called "retired military generals," the MAC officials said they will study relevant government rules in order to gain an understanding of whether they are viewed as "ordinary retired government officials." Such officials are subject to certain limitations regarding visits to the mainland.

If necessary, the MAC will ask relevant government organizations to give an explanation on the status of any retired military general who wishes to pay a visit to the mainland on the tour organized by Fung.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPROVAL RATING FOR PRESIDENT CHEN ON REBOUND: POLL

TEXT.P: Despite the spat over the construction of the fourth nuclear power plant and the stalemate between the ruling and opposition parties in the Legislative Yuan, President Chen Shui-bian's approval rating has rebounded, a recent survey has found.

According to the results of the survey on the performance of Chen, who will celebrate his first anniversary as the head of state of the Republic of China on May 20, some 57 percent of respondents expressed satisfaction with Chen's performance, an increase from previous levels that fell as below 40 percent. Just 27 percent voiced a lack of satisfaction with Chen's performance in the latest poll.
Of the people who are contented with Chen's performance, 7.4 percent said they are "very satisfied," while 49.8 percent said they are "satisfied."

At the same time, as many as 76 percent of respondents said they are unsatisfied with the performance of the Legislative Yuan, and more than 60 percent of them agree with a proposal to cut the number of legislative seats by half, the survey discovered. Only around 10 percent said they are satisfied with the lawmakers' performance.

Lawmaker Lin Cho-shui of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that he is ashamed of the low public approval rating for parliamentarians. He pointed out that this is an indication that legislative reforms are a pressing issue.

Lawmaker Chen Horng-chi of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), said that public discontent with legislators will be reflected in the legislative election slated for December, which he said is a warning to his party that it must field qualified candidates in the year-end contest as a means of reform.

In face of mainland China's efforts to block Taiwan's presence in the international community, more than 50 percent of Taiwan residents believe that a recent medical trip to Japan by former President Lee Teng-hui and his planned visit to the United States will help improve Taiwan's diplomatic position, while 20 percent are of the opposite opinion.

As to Chen's forthcoming visit to the ROC's diplomatic allies in Central America and his two unofficial stopovers in the U.S., around 65 percent of the Taiwan people contend that the trip will help Taiwan diplomatically, while 15 percent said they don't think so.
The telephone survey was conducted April 24-26, and 1,075 valid samples of Taiwan residents aged over 20 were taken.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU URGES TAIWANESE LETTER CAMPAIGN TO ASK BEIJING TO DISMANTLE MISSILES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu asked local people Sunday to write to mainland Chinese leader Jiang Zemin in order to urge him to dismantle the missiles Beijing has deployed along its southeastern coast.

Lu made the remarks while attending a ceremony in celebration of Buddha's birthday organized by the International Fukuan Association at the National College of Physical Education and Sports in Taoyuan.

More than 20,000 Buddhists attended the activity in which Buddha's image was bathed, including some high-ranking government officials such as Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh.
In her speech after the rite, Lu said she knows that many people have been upset recently by changes in their jobs or lives, but that these things are normal in any person's lifetime.
She suggested that people learn modesty during fruitful times, and how to endure the pain when hardship attacks them.
Lu urged people to show more concern to the unemployed, and asked the wealthy to show mercy toward those less privileged.

Changing her topic to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Lu urged the leaders of mainland China to stop deploying missiles with Taiwan as their apparent target, and instead use the money to care for the mainland's needy.

The vice president then called on local people to write to Jiang Zemin on Aug. 14, the anniversary of the last day of the Second World War, asking him to dismantle the missiles aimed at Taiwan quickly in order to create a better environment between the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD CALLS FOR PEACEFUL COMPETITION BETWEEN TAIPEI AND BEIJING

TEXT.P: The root of the dispute between Taiwan and mainland China lies in the differences in their political institutions rather than a struggle for national reunification or Taiwan independence, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said Sunday.

In a statement marking the 10th anniversary of the end of "the period of national mobilization for the suppression of communist rebellion" -- otherwise known as martial law -- Lien stressed the good will underlying the erstwhile KMT government's far-reaching move to no longer consider the authorities in Beijing rebels against KMT rule.

Lien said the daring step taken by the KMT-led government 10 years ago had led to peaceful economic and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China over the past decade as well as a series of measures to promote bilateral talks.

He lamented that the process started by the KMT was disrupted after 1999, saying that a new impasse had emerged after the DPP took presidential power because of its refusal to bow to Beijing's demand that "one China" be used as the principle of negotiations between the two sides.
Lien called on Beijing and Taipei to return to their 1992 consensus on "one China with separate definitions" and start engaging in peaceful competition.

He said Beijing should be more sympathetic of the feelings of people in Taiwan and stop its attempts to isolate the island diplomatically. He then urged Taiwan's ruling DPP to give up what he called its insistence on the pursuit of Taiwan independence and shift its policy toward the middle of the road.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN PARLIAMENTARIAN TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Carl-Dieter Spranger, vice chairman of Germany's Parliamentarian Foreign Relations Committee, will arrive in Taipei Monday for a six-day visit to the Republic of China.
During his stay in Taiwan, Spranger will meet with President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen and other high-ranking officials.

Spranger's visit follows that of German Parliamentarian Deputy Speaker Herman Otto Soles, who recently led a parliamentary delegation to Taiwan and promised to call on his government to resume the Taiwan-German meeting of economic ministers, which has been interrupted for three years.

Taiwan has tried in vain to purchase submarines from Germany in the past. However, the United States included eight diesel submarines in the recently-announced package of weaponry systems it will sell Taiwan this year.

As the United States has not manufactured diesel submarines for years, it may seek cooperation with a third country to supply the submarines to Taiwan, with possible partners including Germany and the Netherlands.
Spranger's visit has aroused speculation on whether Taiwan and Germany can cooperate in related fields in the future.
Spranger is scheduled to leave Taiwan May 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HAILED FOR CRACKDOWN ON 'BLACK GOLD'

TEXT.P: A recent survey has revealed that the Taiwan people praise the current administration led by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for its efforts to eradicate corruption, but complain that it lags far behind the public's expectations on reviving the local economy.

According to the poll carried out April 24-26, 62 percent of respondents said they are satisfied with the government's performance in its efforts to clamp down on the so-called "black gold" -- referring to corruption involving the government with vested interests. At the same time, as many as 72 percent showed agreement with the idea of setting up an "anti-corruption" government agency.

The poll also found that only 19.3 percent of Taiwan's people are "satisfied" or "very satisfied" with the government's performance, while 66 percent voiced their "dissatisfaction" or "extreme dissatisfaction," as the present DPP-led administration is to mark its first anniversary on May 20.

Regarding the economic sluggishness which is sweeping most local businesses, some 30 percent attributed the situation to an ongoing economic slowdown in the global market, ahead of 27 percent who blamed inadequate government policy and 15 percent who pointed to the political boycott from the opposition parties.

As to the legislative election planned for the end of this year, around 23 percent said they have a philosophy similar to that of the DPP, some 20 percent said they hold the same viewpoints as the People First Party, and 10 percent identified themselves with the Kuomintang.

Meanwhile, about 63 percent of the Taiwan people think that U.S. sales of advanced weapons to Taiwan will help safeguard the island's security, in contrast to some 20 percent who view the U.S. arms sales of destroyers or submarines as "not very helpful" or "very unhelpful."

On the foreign and mainland affairs policies adopted by the DPP-led administration, an equal percentage of the public -- 38 percent -- voiced "satisfaction" and "dissatisfaction," respectively, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 30, or the eighth day of the fourth month of the Year of the Snake according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 35 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 35 points to close at 5,381.67.
Market turnover amounted to NT$55.36 billion (US$1.68 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTED PRICE HIKE PLAN BY TAIWAN RAIL MAY HIT SNAG

TEXT.P: A price hike plan that has reportedly been proposed by the state-run Taiwan Railway Administration may hit a snag before it becomes a policy, sources from the Legislative Yuan said Monday.

During a Transportation and Communications Committee hearing in the Legislative Yuan on Monday, legislators from among the major parties unanimously opposed an alleged plan by Taiwan Railway to raise its ticket prices from 15 percent to 50 percent depending on the class of the ticket.

Fielding questions at the legislative committee hearing, Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan said she thinks it is not appropriate at this time for Taiwan Railway to launch an across-the-board price hike as the gap between the services now provided by Taiwan's sole railroad company and passengers' expectations is still wide.

Yeh denied that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is holding a closed-door meeting Monday to discuss Taiwan Railway's price hike plan. She did note that Taiwan Railway's management has recently begun discussing a price hike plan but added that the plan is only in the draft stage and is still far from becoming policy.

She stressed that the MOTC will place the safety of the railway system and the quality of the system's services as the top priorities when assessing the feasibility of a price hike plan if the company puts forth such a plan.

Legislator Wang Tuo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said there is no way that he will approve a price hike at a time when Taiwan Railway has just reported a spate of accidents and persistent and serious schedule delays as well as has demonstrated poor crisis management abilities.
Wang said he is opposed to a Taiwan Railway price hike before the quality of the company's services is improved.

Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung of the People First Party said 90 percent of Taiwan Railway's customers are students, salary men, or female office workers. A price hike at a time when the nation's economy is slumping would only drive away the company's regular customers and would be counterproductive to achieving the company's goal of raising more money, he added.

Noting that Taiwan Railway regularly suffers annual losses of about NT$10 billion, Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ching-pao said he is not against Taiwan Railway's plan to raise ticket prices, but he urged the company to reevaluate such a hike before coming to a decision.
Chen warned that an across-the-board price hike might spook Taiwan Railway's regular customers, who he said have incomes that are not that high, thereby causing greater losses for the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 35 points to close at 5,381.67.
The bourse opened at 5,430.59 and began to go down later due to the poor performance of electronics shares. The bourse fluctuated between 5,469.66 and 5,371.81 during trading.

A total of 1.51 billion stocks worth NT$55.36 billion (US$1.68 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.38 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$44.64 billion (US$1.36 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues and construction stocks moving down the most, both at 3.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.7 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1 percent, textile issues and bank and insurance shares, both at 0.8 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 461 to 78, with 53 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May moved down 9 points to close at 5,430, with 6,616 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June lost 10 points to finish at 5,420, with 29 contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,439 for May, 5,430 for June, 5,500 for September, 5,595 for December, and 5,586 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
May TE futures remained unchanged at 275, with 1,886 contract transactions, while June TE futures moved up 0.95 points to close at 274.5, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures decreased 6 points to finish at 694, with 373 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO DIRECTOR ARRIVES IN NEW YORK FOR U.S. SPEECH TOUR
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 29 (CNA) (By David Wang and Francy Fang)

TEXT.P: The director general of the Republic of China's Government Information Office (GIO) arrived in New York Saturday night for a six-day U.S. speech tour promoting the Democratic Progressive Party-led administration's national policies.

Su Cheng-ping received a warm welcome from ROC officials upon his arrival at Newark International Airport in New Jersey, kicking off his first visit to America since he assumed his current post last year.

The GIO director general will stay in New York for the first three days of his visit before heading to Washington, D.C. He is scheduled to visit the headquarters of several leading think tanks and mass media organizations as well as the GIO's branch offices in the two cities.
On Monday, Su will deliver a speech at the luncheon of Overseas Press Club of America located in New York, expressing Taiwan's views on democracy, peace and prosperity.
He is scheduled to visit the headquarters of Forbes magazine, Time magazine, and Wall Street Journal Monday morning, and then the New York Times, Dow Jones & Company, and Newsweek on Tuesday.
Su will leave for Washington, D.C. on May 2 and then head back to Taiwan on May 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY FIELDS 3 CANDIDATES FOR NORTHERN TAIPEI PARLIAMENTARY RACE

TEXT.P: The tiny opposition New Party announced its decision Monday to nominate three candidates for the year-end parliamentary elections in metropolitan Taipei's northern electoral district.

The party's nomination committee said at a press conference that it has decided to nominate former Legislators Yok Mu-ming and Kao Hui-yu and incumbent Taipei City Council Deputy Speaker Fei Hung-tai to run for legislative seats in the northern Taipei constituency.

Earlier this month, the pro-unification party also nominated three standard bearers to run in the southern Taipei district parliamentary elections -- incumbent Legislators Lai Shyh-bao and Elmer Feng and Taipei City Councilor Chin Li-fang.

Nearly all New Party heavyweights, including the convener and deputy convener of the party's nomination committee, Hsu Li-nung and Wang Chien-hsien, as well as convener of the party's national campaign and development committee Hsieh Chi-ta, were present at the news conference to introduce the three candidates for the northern Taipei constituency.

New Party convener Hsieh, herself a legislator, said all the party's three nominees for the northern Taipei district have their own working styles and support bases, the party has thus decided to nominate them.

Hsieh said all New Party members and supporters are working hard to ensure that the party garners at least 5 percent of the vote cast in regional legislative elections to qualify for securing at-large seats in the parliament.

"We have full confidence in realizing our goal," Hsieh said, adding she is convinced that all of the six New Party candidates for the Taipei regional legislative elections will be able to win their electoral bids.
Speaking on the same occasion, Yok said with Taiwan's economy mired in the doldrums, the New Party should focus its campaign strategy more on economic issues than on political topics.
