DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S DECISION MAY BE EFFORT TO EASE U.S.-PRC TENSIONS: CBC

TEXT.P: The Canadian Broadcasting Corp. said Sunday that Beijing's decision to allow American officials to take a look at the U.S. Navy reconnaissance plane being held on Hainan Island in southern China could be seen as an effort to ease tensions in U.S.-mainland China bilateral relations.

The CBC quoted the official mainland Chinese news agency Xinhua as reporting that Beijing has decided to let the officials inspect the aircraft which made an emergency landing at a military airport on Hainan Island after colliding with a Chinese jet fighter.

Xinhua said the U.S. has agreed to make a payment to mainland China in the wake of the April 1 collision between the U.S. plane and the mainland Chinese jet fighter, whose pilot is still missing and presumed dead.
There will be more negotiations on the specific amount of the U.S. payment and what exactly the payment will be for, according to the report.
There is no indication of when the inspection by the U.S. officials might take place, the CBC noted.

Beijing's decision to let American personnel inspect the plane suggests that the Communist Chinese leaders are interested in easing tensions between the United States and mainland China caused by the incident, the CBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AND TRADE UNIONS TO LAUNCH LARGEST-EVER RALLY MAY 1

TEXT.P: Two leading domestic labor and trade union
groups are scheduled to launch the largest-ever Labor Day rally in Taiwan Tuesday, taking the plight of local workers to the streets, labor sources said Monday.

More than 10,000 blue-collar workers are expected to join the Labor Day rally to transmit their view that "laborers need a chance to survive and all sectors in society should have equal opportunities," said Huang Ching-hsien, chairman of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions, the sponsor of Tuesday's rally.

According to Huang, the demonstrations will highlight such issues as accelerating the privatization of state-run enterprises, allowing blue-collar workers the opportunity to be elected to the board of directors of state-run enterprises, and demanding that the Council of Labor Affairs be made to give a clear explanation of the government's shortened workweek policy.

The demonstrators will also approach the Ministry of Education, asking the government to grant subsidies to children of unemployed workers on the same standards that it now grants subsidies to children of teachers, military personnel and public functionaries.

Members of the Bank Employees' Confederation will appeal to the Ministry of Finance for an explicit guarantee of their work rights after several government-guided mergers take effect, according to Huang.
Workers of the Confederation of Welfare for the Elderly will ask the Legislative Yuan for quick legislation to allow the initiation of the national annuity program as soon as possible, Huang added.

Lin Hui-kuan, chairman of the Chinese Federation of Labor, another group sponsoring Tuesday's demonstration, noted at a Legislative Yuan hearing that the Labor Day rally is aimed at enabling the people in power to hear the voices of Taiwan's laborers.

Lin said laborers and blue-collar workers have been the major victims of the past year's economic slump and added that he sincerely hopes that next year's Labor Day will not be as miserable for Taiwan's laborers as this year's.

Meanwhile, Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said he feels sadness for the nation's laborers, particularly on the eve of Labor Day, a day designated to mark the significance of workers' contribution to society.

Citing that Taiwan's unemployment rate reached an unprecedented high of 3.8 percent in March and the figure is expected to shoot up to 4 percent for the entire year of 2001, Lien called for the Democratic Progressive Party-ruled government to show some guts and ability and to help laborers and low-income people secure work opportunities amid the nationwide economic slump.

Meanwhile, Chou Po-lun, Democratic Progressive Party whip in the Legislative Yuan, called for members of the labor and trade union groups not to be "used" by a few people for their political gain. "The DPP is always with the laborers," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AUTOMAKERS SEEK GOVERNMENT ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's automobile manufacturers asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Monday to provide effective assistance for them to tide over the pressing difficulties their industry is now facing.
They presented their request while meeting with Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi and other MOEA officials at a symposium.
Participants noted that sales of automobiles on the Taiwan market have sharply declined over the past few years, down from 570,000 vehicles in 1994 to 420,000 vehicles last year.

They described the present economic stagnation as another heavy blow to the local auto makers following the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake of 1999, and expressed the hope that the government will provide long-term low-interest loans for the industry.

Some executives also asked the government to provide incentives for automobile development and help them establish subsidiaries in foreign countries, as well as adjust the "go slow, be patient" policy to enable them to make investment in mainland China.
In response, MOEA officials said that Taiwan has already signed investment protection agreements with Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand.
Regarding investment in the mainland, they pointed out that readjustment of the "go slow, be patient" policy must be decided through negotiations with other government agencies.
Participants at the symposium included executives from Yulon Motor, China Motor, Kuozui Motors, Ford Lio Ho Motor, San Yang Industrial, Taching Motors, Taiwan Suzuki and Prince Motors.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.01 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$32.918.
The local currency opened at 32.918 and was traded between 32.894 and 32.928.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$350 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PROMOTES DIPLOMATIC ALTERNATIVE TO MANDATORY MILITARY SERVICE

TEXT.P: In an effort to relieve Taiwan's shortage of foreign service workers, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has been promoting diplomatic service as an alternative to compulsory military service.

Initially, some 35 conscripts will travel overseas to engage in technical and medical service for Taiwan's allies as an alternative to serving in the military, with the first screening of candidates beginning on April 11 and ending Monday. Before they are dispatched overseas, the selected men will receive five weeks of military training starting this July and undergo three months of technical and language training beginning in September.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue expressed her gratitude for the young men who have shown interest in the foreign service, saying that the diplomatic alternative to compulsory military service is an effective utilization of human resources and an important part of the Republic of China's diplomacy.

The implementation of the program has been one of MOFA's six major administrative focuses of this year, and the MOFA and the Ministry of the Interior cooperated to establish the alternative program's regulations, Chang said.

Meanwhile, in the face of widespread bickering over controversial issues such as military service term management, eligibility and qualifications, Chang said that the MOFA will consult with related government agencies before making its final decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN ASTROPHYSICIST GETS AWARD FOR RESEARCH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Victor La)

TEXT.P: Michelle Ma, a Taiwan-born professor of astrophysics at the University of Pennsylvania, was awarded year 2000 "outstanding young researcher award" by the Overseas Chinese Physicists Association Saturday.
She won the honor because of her research on the evolution of the universe.
The Overseas Chinese Physicists Association now has some 400 members.
Ma was named the winner of the award by a panel composed of noted Chinese-American scientists, including Nobel laureates Yang Chen-ning and Samuel Ting.
Ma, 34, is the daughter of senior journalism scholar Ma Chi-shen and former Control Yuan member Huang Chao-heng. She obtained her doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO RECORD SHOWING U.S. PACIFIC COMMANDER VISITS TAIWAN: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Monday that it has no knowledge of any secret visit to Taiwan by Dennis Blair, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Pacific Command, early this month.
"There is no record showing that Admiral Blair visited Taiwan recently," said an MND official who preferred anonymity.
The official was responding to a media report that Blair made a one-day secret visit to Taiwan nearly three weeks ago.
Noting that the Republic of China and the United States have long maintained close military exchanges, the official said exchanges of visits by their senior officers are "nothing unusual."

"Out of concern of protests and boycotts by mainland China, those visits have traditionally been kept secret," the official explained. "However, there is in fact no record showing that Blair recently visited Taiwan."
The official went on to say that the U.S. military usually invites the commander-in-chief of a branch of the ROC armed forces to visit the United States each year.
"And in return, we have also invited American generals to visit Taiwan regularly to exchange views on the latest situation in the Taiwan Strait and Taiwan's defense capabilities," the official said.

As Taiwan's location is strategically important in the Pacific Ocean, the official said the U.S. Pacific Command of course maintains close relations with Taiwan and that its commander is high on Taiwan's invitation list.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, U.S. SHARE COMMON INTEREST IN ASIA-PACIFIC PEACE: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday that peace in the Taiwan Strait is not only crucial to the Republic of China's well-being but also complies with its common interests with the United States.

MOFA spokeswoman Chang Siao-yue made the remarks in response to press queries about the ministry's views on the latest media reports that the United States will beef up its West Pacific military forces to cope with mainland China's intensified military buildup, particularly its deployment of a large number of missiles targeting Taiwan along the southeastern mainland coast.

Noting that peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait have been the ROC's top security concern, Chang said several influential figures in the new Bush administration recently reaffirmed the U.S. commitment to helping maintain peace and stability in the strait based on the Taiwan Relations Act.

"We recognize the U.S. determination and efforts to help safeguard Taiwan's security," Chang said, adding that the ROC and the United States share common interests in maintaining Asia-Pacific regional peace and stability.

As peace in the Taiwan Strait is critical to Taiwan's very survival, Chang said, the ROC is also endeavoring to reinforce its own defense capabilities to protect the lives and property of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOTAL NUMBER, VALUE OF RUBBER CHECKS ON THE INCREASE

TEXT.P: The number of returned checks due to insufficient funds reached 0.52 percent of all checks drawn in March, with their value accounting for some 0.42 percent of the value of all checks during the same month, according to statistics compiled by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The CBC figures are the highest in three months and two months, respectively.
Some 14.6 million checks were issued during March, of which a total of 75,478 -- or 0.52 percent -- were returned due to insufficient funds, the figures show.

Meanwhile, a total of NT$3,552.219 billion in checks were exchanged at Taiwan's check clearing house during the same period, of which checks valued at NT$14,899 million -- or 0.42 of the total value -- were found to be drawing on insufficient funds, according to the CBC.

The number of bouncing checks was up 0.05 percent compared with the previous year, while the ratio of the value of returned checks to the value of all checks in the same month increased by 0.01 percent compared to the previous year.

A banking industry source attributed the ongoing decline of private credit to the local economic stagnation and the poor performance of the Taiwan Stock Exchange. The situation is not likely to turn for the better in the short term, the source added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS URGE CHEN TO POSTPONE O'SEAS TRIP

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the opposition Kuomintang on Monday called on President Chen Shui-bian to postpone his forthcoming trip to Latin America amid the nationwide economic slump.

In a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, KMT lawmakers ridiculed the president as believing that going overseas to shake the hands of foreigners is more important than the livelihood of Taiwan's laborers who have been the major victims of the country's sagging economy.
The KMT lawmakers asked Chen to postpone his Latin American trip slated for May 21-June 4 until the economy at home takes a turn for the better.

KMT Legislator Cheng Feng-shih said he personally does not buy the results of a recent public opinion poll conducted by a pro-Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) poll company indicating that Chen's approval ratings have increased in recent weeks to reach over 50 percent amid rising unemployment and a collapsing economy.

Meanwhile, Chou Po-lun, DPP party whip in the Legislative Yuan, said rising unemployment and the continually sliding domestic economy indicates that the new DPP-rule government still has ample room to review its economic policies.

Chou called for the Executive Yuan to put forth concrete and effective measures to redress the economic slump so as to regain the people's confidence in the government. Otherwise, he added, some related officials should consider stepping down from their posts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, SOUTH KOREAN LAWMAKERS TO PROMOTE RESUMPTION OF DIRECT AIR LINK
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 30 (CNA) (By Chiang Yuan-chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the Republic of China and South Korea agreed Monday to call on their respective governments to resume direct Taipei-Seoul air links for the good of bilateral trade and tourism.

The five-member ROC delegation, led by legislator Lin Feng-hsi, and their Korean counterparts also resolved to create a common front with lawmakers in 16 other Asian countries in response to Japan's adoption of new history textbooks that include whitewashed accounts of its actions during World War II.

The lawmakers condemned what they called the resurrection of Japanese militarism and the distortion of history but stressed that their criticism does not imply they are against or will discriminate against Japan. Political, economic, social and cultural exchanges with Japan will continue, they noted.

In a resolution announced after their meeting, the legislators also said that they will work together to respond to outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease in both countries and to increase bilateral exchanges among Christian lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA MAINTAINS `MEASURED' PRESSURE ON TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China has continued to maintain "measured pressure" on Taiwan in the wake of a recent series of contentious events, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.
The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the remarks in an internal report delivered at an MAC advisory meeting.

The report pointed out that mainland China has launched verbal attacks on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's recent medical trip to Japan, his plan to visit his alma mater -- Cornell University in New York State -- and the new U.S. arms sale package to the ROC.
Nevertheless, the report went on, mainland China has so far not raised its "measured pressure" on Taiwan to the level of "strong action" against the island.
The report noted that the mainland and the United States have resolved through diplomatic channels their dispute over a midair collision between a U.S. surveillance plane and a mainland jet fighter.

As mainland China has not tried to take advantage of the collision incident to escalate its confrontation with the United States, the report said, this indicates that Beijing-Washington engagements will focus on strategic and military security affairs in the short term.
As for the incident's possible impact on future relations across the Taiwan Strait, the report said it would be premature to make any forecast in this regard at the moment.

The report further said mainland China's intensified efforts to strengthen relations with its neighbors such as North Korea, India and Vietnam, as well as mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's recent visit to major Latin American countries, signify Beijing's drive against U.S. hegemony.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN RECOGNIZES MILITARY NEUTRALIZATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that nearly one year after his inauguration, he takes great pleasure in seeing achievements in neutralization of the ROC armed forces.

"Nearly after one year in office, I'm most satisfied with our achievements in military neutralization, in addition to breakthroughs on arms procurement and diplomatic fronts," President Chen said while meeting with visiting Guatemalan Defense Minister Eduardo Arevalo Lacs.
Noting that he came from an opposition party, Chen said his family and career backgrounds had not allowed him to forge any ties with the military before he took office last May.

"Nevertheless, our servicemen are loyal to our country, constitution and the 23 million people of Taiwan," Chen said, adding that over the past year, those who have shown the greatest amount of support, loyalty and allegiance to the ROC's popularly elected president are its military officers and enlisted men.
Chen said he appreciates ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen and Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming for their efforts in promoting military neutralization.

Chen went on to point out that Guatemalan President Alfonso Antonio Portillo Cabrera also came from the opposition camp and that he has been impressed by Portillo's efforts to neutralize Guatemala's armed forces.
For his part, Arevalo said he fully agrees with Chen's recognition of the importance of military neutralization in a country's national development.

Stressing that the pivotal functions of a country's armed forces lie in maintaining national sovereignty, dignity and security, Arevalo said the Guatemalan military will continue to dedicate itself to protecting national security, people's well-being and human rights.
As President Chen is scheduled to visit Guatemala in late May, Arevalo said the Guatemalan government and people welcome Chen's upcoming visit.
"We believe that your visit will be a historic event in the ROC-Guatemalan relationship and will further boost bilateral cooperation," he told Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER: NO QUICK CURE FOR AILING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: One day before labor groups are expected to take to the streets to protest rising unemployment, Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Hsin-yi said Monday he has no ready answer for the problems facing the island's economy.
Lin made the comment after being bombarded with questions from lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan about the surging unemployment.
He said the measures taken by his ministry to boost the faltering economy will take "a couple of years" to take effect amid the worldwide economic depression.

Lin, who warned his fellow countrymen earlier this year to brace for coming hardships, came under fire after ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Frank Hsieh blamed the Ministry of Economic Affairs Sunday for "reconstructing state-run enterprises" through massive layoffs.

Hsieh is also mayor of Kaohsiung City, the location of the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. and Taiwan Machinery Manufacturing Corp., among others, and bears the brunt of the government's efforts to slim down state-run businesses.

Lin said he respected Hsieh's opinion, but noted that it will take time for an economic turnaround. The programs implemented by his ministry to upgrade conventional industries, which are being edged out of market because of rising labor costs, will not become effective for another couple of years.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS TO BE HELD DEC. 1

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) called a meeting Monday and formally decided to set Dec. 1 as the date for the election of members of the Legislative Yuan.

A CEC official said that announcement for the elections will be promulgated Sept. 20 and that candidates will be required to register between Oct. 7-11, with the namelist of the elected candidates announced Dec. 7.

The Legislative Yuan has 225 members, 168 of whom are elected from the special municipalities, counties and cities, four each of whom are elected from lowland and highland aboriginal regions, eight of whom are elected from among overseas Chinese residents and 41 of whom are elected from national constituencies.
Elections for county magistrates and city mayors are expected to be held on the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-NSB AGENT SEEKING NT$100 MILLION COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: A former agent of the National Security Bureau (NSB) said Monday that he would lodge a lawsuit against the NSB to seek NT$100 million compensation for being assigned to work in mainland China.

Chang Chih-peng, accompanied by his lawyer, said at a press conference that former President Lee Teng-hui's declaration in 1996 that missiles fired by the mainland into waters near Taiwan were not armed led to a number of secret agents working in the mainland being arrested.
He also said the NSB and the Intelligence Bureau of the Ministry of National Defense have so far not yet responded to his appeal, prompting him to lodge his lawsuit.

Chang also said that he will leave for Hong Kong June 1 to retrieve a tape believed to contain NSB instructions to its operatives from a safe in Hong Kong. He said he will then go to the mainland and attempt to turn himself in to Beijing authorities in return for the release of his captured NSB comrades. He also said he will not rule out "stronger retaliation" to "punish the Taiwan intelligence authorities."

Legislator Lee Ching-hua has accused Lee of leaking state secrets by declaring that Beijing fired blanks during the 1996 missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait. As a result, he claimed, "a lot of our agents working in the mainland were arrested and punished by mainland authorities." Chang was forced to flee from the mainland and the Taiwan intelligence network in mainland was destroyed, he further claimed.

Chang told another press conference held last March that two People's Liberation Army officers -- Liu Lienkun and Zhow Chengjung -- were sentenced to death last August for spying on behalf of Taiwan. He also said his manager in the Hong Kong-based company Yao Chia-chen was also arrested on spying charges.
He accused the government of "neglecting the contributions" made by its agents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO INCREASE JOBS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday "job first" will be the top working principle for his administration and that the government is reinforcing social security measures and subsidies to the unemployed to minimize pressure on local workers.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with 30 model workers selected from various manufacturing and service sectors in celebration of the May 1 Labor Day, which falls on Tuesday.

Noting that the 21st century would be an era of "low economic growth and high unemployment rate," Chen said the government is keeping high alert on a possible scenario in the near future that the domestic jobless rate exceeds 4 percent.

"From America to Asia, countries in the world are facing the challenge of adjusting to economic transition," Chen said, adding: "Taiwan is no exception. Tens of thousands of blue- and white-collar workers and their families are suffering from the impact of the transition."
And in the face of gloomy job prospects, Chen assured the labor representatives that his administration will do its utmost to create more jobs and help local workers find a way out.

With the domestic unemployment rate skyrocketing, many unemployed workers are planning to take to streets Tuesday to appeal for government attention to their plight. Chen's remarks were seen as part of the government's efforts to calm disgruntled jobless laborers.
President Chen said he is confident that his administration is moving in the right direction centering around "three firsts" -- "Taiwan first, economy first and investment first."

In the short term, Chen said, the government is promoting various job creation programs by stimulating domestic demand, such as the "8100" public construction and investment projects and domestic tourist industry development plan.

In the long term, Chen said, the government will substantiate manpower resources development project, knowledge-based economy development plan, global logistics center development project, and revitalize traditional industries, remove investment barriers and improve overall investment climate.

Later in the day, Chen made an inspection tour of the central Taiwan county of Taichung, including visiting several community manufacturing cooperatives and vocational training centers in townships hard-hit by a devastating earthquake that rattled central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999.
During the inspection tour, Chen said the government will upgrade the quality of local work force by encouraging lifelong study and offering on-job training and employment services.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT WITNESSES BIKE DONATION BY TAIWANESE

TEXT.P: Dominican Republic President Hipolito Mejia presided recently over a ceremony to mark a donation of bicycles by Taiwan businessmen, Republic of China Foreign Ministry officials said Monday.
The 10,000 bicycles were donated by the businessmen to the Dominican Republic's poor children.

The donation ceremony was jointly presided over by Mejia, ROC Ambassador to the Dominican Republic Adolfo Sun and Taiwan Chamber of Commerce Chairman Lu Wei-ming and attended by more than 100 Dominican officials, foreign diplomats and Taiwan businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRONIC TOLL STATIONS TO BE USED ON FREEWAYS

TEXT.P: Officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC) signed an agreement with Chunghwa Telecom Monday to install electronic toll stations on Taiwan's freeways.
MOTC officials announced that the electronic toll stations are scheduled to be partially installed the end of 2002.
Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau Director Ho Nuan-Hsuan and Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Mao Chi-Kuo jointly hosted the contract-signing ceremony.

Ho noted that the bilateral agreement will remain valid for 17 years and will include two construction phases. The first phase will see the introduction of at least one electronic tollbooth at each toll collection point on the freeways before the end of 2002.
The second phase, which has no firm completion date, will see multiple electronic tollbooths at each toll station. Ho added that toll prices will depend on the type of electronic system to be used.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN SLAMS OFFICIALS FOR `VALUING WINE OVER WORK'

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung denied Tuesday charges by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh that "some officials" spend more time "sampling wine and playing cards" than they do at work.
Chang added that in fact, his Cabinet has been working "day and night" without weekends off or holidays.

Responding to another accusation by Hsieh -- that state-run enterprise lay-offs have only worsened the nation's unemployment problem -- Chang said that although the government is "very concerned" about the issue, it has to strike a balance between increasing the competitiveness of state enterprises and caring for workers.
He added that a responsible Cabinet cannot look at the issue from only one perspective.

Hsieh, who serves concurrently as mayor of the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung, said at an interpellation session of the Kaohsiung City Council earlier in the day that although President Chen Shui-bian has been trying to narrow the economic gap between northern and southern Taiwan, "some officials" still do not understand the south.
He added that only if these officials can take the time out to understand the people's "sufferings" will the nation's politics show any signs of change for the better.

After the interpellation session, he said that the unemployment problem is very serious in southern Taiwan and that lay-offs from state enterprises have not been accompanied by measures to help the workers find other jobs.
Hsieh urged Cabinet officials and legislators to listen more to the "voice of the grassroots."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOULD NOT BE RANKED 'PRIORITY FOREIGN COUNTRY' BY U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan has no idea whether it will be put on the "priority watch list" by the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) office, but is sure that it will not be named a "priority foreign country," an economics official said Monday.

The USTR office was expected to unveil as early as late Monday its annual report, which ranks its trade partners engaging in what it calls "unfair trade practices" in five categories. "Priority foreign country" is the most serious listing and can draw trade sanctions from Washington, followed by "priority watch list," "watch list," "special mention list" and "other observation list."

Taiwan has been put on the watch list for two consecutive years and there is no chance of the island being removed from the list this year in light of Washington's complaints over intellectual property rights violations by Taiwan companies, said Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long, who is the island's leading trade negotiator with the United States.

Preliminary reports from Washington said Taiwan might be further penalized on the five-rank scale because of its failure to live up to U.S. expectations regarding intellectual property rights protection.
Chen would not speculate on whether Taiwan would be named on the priority watch list, but said there is "no question" of the island being placed on the priority foreign country list.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY CHIEFS BRIEFED ON U.S. ARMS SALE PACKAGE

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen and Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming were briefed Monday on the results of the just-concluded arms procurement talks with the United States, military sources said.

The briefing was given by Vice Chief of the General Staff Huo Shou-yeh and several other military officers who wrapped up the Republic of China's annual discussion with the United States on the procurement of new weaponry systems in Washington, D.C. last week.

During the talks, the Bush administration approved the biggest U.S. arms sale package to Taiwan since 1992, including eight diesel-powered submarines, 12 P-3C anti-submarines aircraft and four Kidd-class destroyers.
The sales package is expected to help upgrade Taiwan's naval defense capabilities, military experts said.

Ministry of National Defense (MND) sources said Defense Minister Wu has ordered the General Staff Headquarters (GSH) and the Navy General Headquarters to finalize evaluations as soon as possible of various weaponry items that the United States has agreed to sell.

According to the sources, both the MND and the GSH fully support the purchases of the eight diesel submarines. Although the United States has yet to determine how to help Taiwan acquire the badly needed submarines, the MND and the GSH have agreed to push the government to earmark funds to finance the procurement plan.

As local society remains far divided over the Kidd-class destroyers procurement plan, the MND plans to invite lawmakers, scholars and military experts to discuss whether Taiwan should buy this type of warplanes. And the Navy General Headquarters is expected to come up with a detailed evaluation for the MND to make a final decision within three months, MND sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASING NUMBER OF FOREIGN BUYERS AT ELECTRONICS SHOW: CETRA

TEXT.P: China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) officials noted Monday that the number of foreign buyers attending the five-day Taipei International Electronics Spring Show has increased over previous years.

CETRA officials said that during the show, which ended that day, over 30,000 visitors flooded into the exhibition, with professional foreign buyers amounting to 3,167, a 35 percent growth over the year-earlier level.

More than 500 companies displayed their latest electronic products, including color LCDs, PDA watches and network-capable refrigerators. CETRA officials said most of the foreign buyers were from the United States, followed by Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MEDICAL MISSION IN MALAWI TO BE REORGANIZED: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Monday that the ROC medical mission in Malawi will be reorganized to focus on providing assistance and training only.

In a news release, the ministry revealed that an inspection team sent to Malawi by the prestigious National Taiwan University Hospital had already returned to Taiwan and had briefed the ministry on its findings.
The team advised that the medical mission should concentrate on such fundamental jobs as assisting in hospital management, creating patient history files and managing pharmaceuticals.
The ministry agreed to follow the team's suggestions and re-examine the nation's medical mission policies.

Last month, a former member of the ROC medical mission in Malawi accused the mission's leader of "medical negligence" that allegedly led to the death of a Malawi state minister -- who was suffering from polio, obesity, high blood pressure, an enlarged spleen and malaria.

The former mission member also alleged that the team leader had never addressed a nurse's charges of sexual harassment against one of the mission's doctors, and that he was fired after reporting the mission leader's alleged misconduct to the ROC embassy in Malawi.
The ministry stated that the dispute will be handled through a personnel reshuffle at the mission.
Under a five-year aid program, the Republic of China has been assisting Malawi to establish and operate a modern hospital through funding that has reached US$17 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WILL IMPROVE EMPLOYMENT PROSPECTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday that the government will take effective steps to increase local work opportunities.
He made the remarks at a ceremony held under the sponsorship of the Council of Labor Affairs to commend model workers.
Chang attributed the recent sharp rise in Taiwan's jobless rate to economic stagnation, the shortening of the work-week, the exodus of manufacturing firms and a decline in production.
To counter the situation, the premier said, the government is considering five "effective measures" to improve the employment situation:
-- Creating some 98,000 jobs through an expansion of government projects;
-- Promoting domestic tourism and exhibitions to stimulate investment and consumption;
-- Providing well-trained workers;
-- Raising the adjustment function of the labor market; and
-- Offering assistance to unemployed workers.

Chang noted that more focus will be placed on the development of the industries which can help improve the quality of life of local people and on the training of workers to meet the demand of the labor market.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SAID `LURING' RETIRED ROC GENERALS TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A Republic of China legislator claimed Monday that Beijing has recently started a project to attract retired Republic of China generals to work in mainland China.

Legislator Tsai Trong-rong of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), claimed that mainland China is "targeting former high-ranking officers from Taiwan" who have retired because of the military's streamlining program and "plans to offer them good posts" in state enterprises or private corporations with investment from Taiwan, Hong Kong or elsewhere.

Speaking on a planned visit of a group of retired local generals to mainland China in June to be led by Legislator Fung Hu-hsiang of the opposition New Party, Tsai said the DPP is glad to see exchanges between retired military leaders of both sides of the Taiwan Strait. However, he warned the retired generals not to "fall into the traps set by mainland China," which would see them used as "bargaining chips."

Tsai claimed that Beijing has "reserved high posts" in "at least 100 state enterprises" for Taiwan's retired generals, and has also "arranged some posts" for "other high-ranking retired Taiwan officers."

He urged local intelligence agencies to keep an eye on Beijing's new united front operations and "the newest developments" regarding Taiwan's high-ranking retired officers to "prevent the leaking of ROC military secrets" to the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, Fung pointed out that it was he who took the initiative in suggesting to Beijing the visit of a group of Taiwan retired generals to mainland China, a suggestion to which Beijing agreed only after long deliberation. He denied that the visit is part of a "united front operation."

He went on to say that mainland Chinese state enterprises are also undergoing streamlining and that many companies are slashing their manpower. "In this situation, how can they be offering so many high-level posts for retired generals from Taiwan?" Fung asked.

Fung further pointed out that the retired officers are now ordinary citizens who are at complete liberty to visit the mainland in accordance with government regulations, and their visit is in fact aimed at strengthening communications and avoiding conflict in the face of increased military confrontation between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND ASIAN PHYSICS OLYMPIAD CONCLUDES

TEXT.P: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concluded in Taipei Monday after more than 10 days of competition and Singapore's selection as host of the third competition.

A score of government leaders, including Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh and National Science Council Chairman Wei Tseh-ho witnessed the award presentation ceremony held at the Public Functionaries Manpower Development Center in Taipei.
A total of 81 students representing 12 countries and regions in Asia took part in the competition, which was held in Taiwan for the first time.
Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations, were awarded to the winners.
An eight-member team of the host country chalked up eight medals including four golds, a silver and two bronzes, together with an honorary citation.

Tsai Hsin-yu, a third grader at a senior high school in the Hsinchu-based Science Industrial Park, won overall first place. She also won the best experimental design award and the best girl student award.

In his address, Chang said that the development of scientific education and the cultivation of scientific talent are important for Asia's participation in the new century. The ROC is willing to play a more active role as a participant and a contributor to Asian scientific development, he went on.
Academia Sinica President Lee also exhorted the participants to spare no efforts in their pursuit of a career in science.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIGHT REASSESS ARMS PURCHASES: ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan could rethink its military procurements if Beijing cuts its military buildup, Taiwan's top representative in the United States said Monday.

In an interview published in the Washington Times, Chen Chien-jen, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States said: "If the People's Republic of China is going to pull back or reduce its missile deployment ... we can rethink our military procurements."

That would mean the Aegis-equipped destroyers and the Patriot-3 anti-missile systems that Taiwan was denied by Washington could come off Taipei's wish-list, although the island would go ahead with the deal already approved by the United States, said the Washington Times.

Chen said Taiwan is concerned for its security because of the increase in mainland China's defense budget, its acquisition of new weapons and its deployment of missiles in mainland provinces opposite Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA: DECISION TO PUT TAIWAN ON `PRIORITY WATCH LIST' REGRETFUL
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Monday expressed its regret over the United States' decision to put Taiwan on the "priority watch list" this year despite the island's effort to enhance intellectual property protection.

A CNA report from Washington D.C. said that Taiwan was put on the "priority watch list" of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) office, for what USTR officials said was the island's discriminatory trade practice and government procurement policies against foreigners.
Taiwan, was on the "priority watch list" along with 15 other countries as widely expected.
Ukraine is the only country being ranked the priority foreign country in the report.

The USTR office on Monday unveiled its annual report, which ranks its trade partners engaging in what it calls "unfair trade practices" in five categories. "Priority foreign country" is the most serious listing and can draw trade sanctions from Washington, followed by "priority watch list," "watch list," "special mention list" and "other observation list."

Taiwan has been put on the watch list for two consecutive years and there is no chance of the island being removed from the list this year in light of Washington's complaints over intellectual property rights violations by Taiwan companies, said Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long, who is the island's leading trade negotiator with the United States.

Preliminary reports from Washington said Taiwan might be further penalized on the five-rank scale because of its failure to live up to U.S. expectations regarding intellectual property rights protection.
Chen would not speculate on whether Taiwan would be named on the priority watch list, but said there is "no question" of the island being placed on the priority foreign country list.
